passage_content: בשלח בשלח פרעה את העם ולא נחם אלקים דרך ארץ פלשתים כי קרוב הוא כי אמר אלקים פן ינחם העם וגו' ושבו מצרימה, במד"ר (פ' כ' סימן ט') ויהי בשלח פרעה מי צווח ווי פרעה, משל לאחד שמצא צרור של מרגליות ולא הי' יודע מה בידו וכו', כשנודע לו שווי' קרע את בגדיו, אמר כל העושר הזה בידי הי' וחנם הוצאתי מידי, אוי לו לאותו האיש שכך הוציא מידו, כך הי' פרעה, הצרור של מרגליות אלו ישראל וכו' כשראה פרעה כל האוכלסין התחיל צווח ווי עכ"ד המדרש, ולכאורה הול"ל דרשא זו לעיל בפ' בא עה"פ קומי צאו מתוך עמי וגו' או אצל ויהי בעצם היום הזה יצאו כל צבאות ד' מאמ"צ, דשם עיקר סיפור היציאה, וכאן לא נכתב אלא אגב גררא להורות דרך נסיעתם במדבר.
translation: When Pharaoh sent the people away, God did not lead them by the way of the land of the Philistines, for it was near; for God said, "Lest the people change their minds when they see war and return to Egypt." In the Midrash (Parashat Ki Tisa, Section 9), it is said: "When Pharaoh sent them away, who cried out, 'Woe to Pharaoh!' This is like a person who found a pouch of pearls and did not know what he had in his hand. When he realized their value, he tore his garments and said, 'All this wealth was in my hands, and I foolishly let it go!' Woe to that man for having let it slip from his grasp." So it was with Pharaoh; these pearls of great value were the Israelites. When Pharaoh saw all the multitudes, he began to cry out, 'Woe!' Thus concludes the Midrash. At first glance, this interpretation should have been stated earlier in Parashat Bo regarding the verse, "Get up, go out from among my people," or in the verse, "And it came to pass on that very day that all the hosts of the Lord went out from the land of Egypt," for there the main narrative of the Exodus is found, and here it is only mentioned in passing to indicate their route in the desert.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author reflects on the moment Pharaoh released the Israelites, likening them to a treasure he did not recognize until it was too late. The Midrash illustrates Pharaoh's regret upon realizing the value of the Israelites, emphasizing the theme of lost opportunity and the spiritual blindness of those who fail to see the divine purpose in their actions. This narrative highlights the tension between divine providence and human agency, suggesting that even in moments of apparent loss, there is a deeper significance to the unfolding of events in the spiritual realm.

passage_content: ב) ראוי להבין דהרי בשעת יציאתם שמחו המצרים., כמשה"כ שמח מצרים בצאתם כי נפל פחדם עליהם, ומדוע נתהפכה שמחתם לתוגה ואיך אזדה הפחד מנהו לגמרי.
translation: It is fitting to understand that at the time of their departure, the Egyptians rejoiced, as it is written, "The Egyptians were glad at their going out, for their fear had fallen upon them." And why did their joy turn into sorrow, and how did their fear completely depart from them?
summary: The passage discusses the transformation of the Egyptians' joy into sorrow at the moment of the Israelites' departure, highlighting that their initial happiness was rooted in a false sense of security. It emphasizes that the fear of the Israelites ultimately overcame them, leading to despair. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the nature of divine intervention, where the apparent joy of the oppressors is fleeting and can swiftly turn into dread when faced with the power of God. The text illustrates the contrast between superficial happiness and the profound fear that arises from recognizing divine authority.

passage_content: ג) איתא במדרש (פרשה כ' סימן ח') ויהי בשלח פרעה מי אמר ווי, משה אמר ווי וכו', אמר משה צועק אני שנתיגעתי להוציא את ישראל ממצרים ואיני נכנס עמהם לארץ ע"כ, וצ"ב דהול"ל דרשא זו לעיל בפ' בא עה"פ יצאו כל צבאות ד' מאמ"צ כי שם הוא עיקר סיפור היציאה, ולפי שראה שמוציאם ואין סופו להכניסם ע"כ צווח ווי, אבל אין לו קישור למה ששלח פרעה את העם.
translation: 3) It is stated in the Midrash (Parashat 20, Siman 8) that when Pharaoh sent out the people, who said "Woe"? Moses said "Woe," etc. Moses exclaimed, "I cry out because I have labored to bring the Israelites out of Egypt, and I will not enter the land with them." Therefore, it is puzzling why this teaching was not mentioned earlier in Parashat Bo regarding the verse "All the hosts of the Lord went out from the land of Egypt," for there is where the main narrative of the Exodus is found. And since he saw that he was bringing them out and would not ultimately bring them in, he cried "Woe," but it does not connect to why Pharaoh sent the people out.
summary: The passage discusses a Midrashic interpretation of Moses' lamentation upon the Israelites' exodus from Egypt, expressing his sorrow for not entering the Promised Land with them. It raises a question about why this lamentation is mentioned in the context of Pharaoh's sending out the Israelites rather than earlier during the actual Exodus narrative. The theological insight emphasizes Moses' deep connection to the fate of the Israelites and his anguish over his own exclusion from their future, highlighting themes of leadership, sacrifice, and the emotional burden of guiding a people toward redemption.

passage_content: ד) ממ"ש להלן בפ' שירה תביאמו ותטעמו בהר נחלתך פרש"י נתנבא משה שלא יכנס לארץ, לכך לא נאמר תביאנו ולא כלל את עצמו עמהן, והקשו המפרשים הא עדיין לא נגזרה הגזירה כמ"ש רש"י (בפ' בהעלותך) עה"פ נוסעים אנחנו אל המקום וגו', ששיתף עצמו עמהם מפני שעדיין לא נגזרה הגזירה עליו וכסבור הי' שנכנס, ומצינו שהתפלל אח"כ לבטל הגזירה, והי' סבור עדיין שיכנס, ואיך אפשר שהתנבא כאן שלא יכנס לארץ, ותירץ הרא"ם ז"ל שזה שאמר תביאמו הי' בבחי' ניבא ולא ידע מה ניבא, שבאמת לא הי' עדיין הגזירה, או אפשר שהי' סבור שלא יכניסם כמו מנהיג, אבל יכנס גם הוא עמהם כשאר העם עיי"ש, וכמו"כ יקשה גם כאן על מה שדרשו ז"ל דמשה צווח ווי שלא יכנס עמהם לארץ, הרי עדיין לא נגזרה הגזירה, ומדוע לא הקשו המפרשים כמו"כ הכא וצ"ב.
translation: D) As mentioned below in Parashat Shira, "You will bring them and plant them on the mountain of Your inheritance," Rashi explains that Moses prophesied that he would not enter the land, which is why it does not say "You will bring us" and he did not include himself with them. The commentators questioned, how could it be that the decree had not yet been issued, as Rashi explains (in Parashat Beha'alotecha) regarding the verse "We are traveling to the place," where he included himself with them because the decree had not yet been issued against him, and he thought he would enter. We find that he later prayed to annul the decree, still believing he would enter. How is it possible that he prophesied here that he would not enter the land? The Ra'ah answered that when he said "You will bring them," it was in the manner of prophecy, and he did not know what he was prophesying, as the decree had not yet been issued. Alternatively, he might have thought that he would not lead them in, like a leader, but he himself would enter with the rest of the people, as noted there. Similarly, it is also difficult here regarding what our sages have said that Moses cried out "Woe" that he would not enter with them into the land, yet the decree had still not been issued. Why did the commentators not question this here as well? This remains to be clarified.
summary: The passage discusses the prophetic nature of Moses' statements regarding his entry into the Promised Land, highlighting the tension between his initial belief that he would enter and the later realization of the decree against him. It reflects on the concept of prophecy, suggesting that Moses may have spoken without full awareness of the implications, as the decree had not yet been pronounced. This illustrates the complexity of divine communication and human understanding within Hasidic thought, emphasizing the interplay between leadership, faith, and the unfolding of divine will.

passage_content: ה) קשה למה צריך הכתוב לחזור ולכפול ויהי בשלח פרעה את העם הרי כבר אמור לעיל (בפ' בא) שאמר פרעה קומו צאו מתוך עמי וגו' ותחזק מצרים על העם למהר לשלחם מן הארץ וגו', ואם בשביל להודיע שלא נחם אלקים דרך ארץ פלשתים אלא דרך המדבר, הול"ל הודעה זו בלבד ולא לחזור על הראשונות, כי אין לה קישור מוחלט עם שליחות פרעה, כי הטעם שנתן הכתוב פן ינחם העם וגו' שייך אף אם הי' היציאה באופן אחר שלא בשליחות פרעה.
translation: 5) It is difficult to understand why the text needs to repeat "And it was when Pharaoh sent out the people," for it has already been stated earlier (in Parashat Bo) that Pharaoh said, "Get up, go out from my people," etc., and Egypt was strengthened against the people to hasten to send them out of the land, etc. And if it is to inform us that God did not lead them through the way of the land of the Philistines but rather through the wilderness, it should have stated this information alone and not repeated the earlier verses, for it does not have a complete connection with Pharaoh's sending, since the reason given in the text, "lest the people regret," etc., applies even if the departure had occurred in a different manner and not through Pharaoh's sending.
summary: The passage discusses the repetition of the phrase "And it came to pass when Pharaoh sent out the people," questioning its necessity since Pharaoh had already commanded their departure. It suggests that the emphasis on Pharaoh's role serves to highlight divine providence in guiding the Israelites through the wilderness rather than the direct path to the Promised Land. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of understanding God's overarching plan, where even seemingly redundant details reveal deeper theological insights about faith and divine guidance in the journey of the Jewish people.

passage_content: ו) צ"ב אריכות הלשון כי קרוב הוא כי אמר אלקים פן ינחם העם. וממנ"פ אם חדא טעמא הוא. דלפי שקרוב הדרך ונוח לשוב ע"כ אמר אלקים פן ינחם העם וגו', א"כ תרי זמני כי למה, הול"ל כי קרוב הוא ואמר אלקים פן ינחם העם וגו' ואם תרי טעמי נינהו א"כ אינו מובן הטעם כי קרוב הוא, אדרבה קירוב הדרך בכל מקום היא סיבה ללכת בה, ולא סיבת המניעה מלילך בה.
translation: And it is difficult to understand the length of the language, for it is close that God said, "Lest the people regret." And according to the principle of "if it is one reason," since the way is close and easy to return, therefore God said, "Lest the people regret," etc. If so, there are two times for what reason; it should have said, "For it is close," and God said, "Lest the people regret," etc. And if there are two reasons, then the reason that it is close is not understood; on the contrary, the closeness of the way is always a reason to go on it, and not a reason to refrain from going on it.
summary: The passage discusses the divine concern that the people might regret their journey if the path to repentance is too accessible. It suggests that the ease of returning to God could lead to a lack of genuine commitment, as the proximity of the path may not inherently encourage movement towards it. The text raises a theological tension between the accessibility of repentance and the potential for insincerity in the return to faith. Ultimately, it emphasizes the complexity of divine guidance in the context of human choice and the nature of repentance.

passage_content: ז) רש"י ז"ל נראה דחד טעמא הוא, דפי' כי קרוב הוא ונוח לשוב באותו דרך למצרים, כי אמר אלקים פן ינחם העם וגו', אם הלכו דרך ישר היו חוזרים, ומה אם כשהקיפם דרך מעוקם אמרו ניתנה ראש ונשובה מצרימה, אם הולכים בפשוטה עאכו"כ עכ"ל, ויש להבין דהרי גם כשהקיפם דרך מעוקם רצו לחזור ולשוב, אבל מן השמים עיכבו בידם, ולא ניתן להם הרשות והיכולת לחזור ולשוב, גם בני לוי רדפו אחריהם והחזירום כדברי רז"ל, ואצלו ית' אין נפקמ"נ בין דרך קרוב לרחוק, וגם בדרך קרוב לא הי' היכולת בידם לשוב נגד רצונו ית' וכמ"ש הרא"ם ז"ל דאין ללמוד מהק"ו, אלא שאם הוליכן בפשוטה עאכו"כ שהיו אומרים ניתנה ראש, אבל חזרה לא שמענו מהק"ו, דלא באו לכלל חזרה מעולם.
translation: Rashi, may his memory be blessed, seems to indicate that there is one reason for this, that it is because it is close and easy to return by that way to Egypt, as God said, "lest the people regret" etc. If they had gone by a straight path, they would have returned, and what if, when they were taken around a crooked path, they said, "Let us appoint a leader and return to Egypt"? If they were going by a simple path, all the more so! And we must understand that even when they were taken around a crooked path, they wanted to return, but from Heaven, they were prevented from doing so, and they were not given the permission and ability to return. Even the sons of Levi pursued them and brought them back, as our sages have said. And with Him, blessed be He, there is no difference between a close path and a far one, and even on the close path, they did not have the ability to return against His will, as the Ra'ah, may his memory be blessed, wrote that one cannot learn from a fortiori reasoning, except that if He led them by a simple path, all the more so they would say, "Let us appoint a leader," but we have not heard of a return from a fortiori reasoning, for they never came to the point of returning at all.
summary: The passage discusses the divine intervention in the Israelites' journey from Egypt, emphasizing that even when they were led on a convoluted path, their desire to return was thwarted by God. It highlights the idea that their inclination to return was not merely a result of the route taken, but rather a reflection of divine will, which prevented them from turning back. The text suggests that regardless of the path—straight or winding—God's authority ultimately dictated their journey, illustrating the concept of divine control over human choices. This underscores a key Hasidic belief in the omnipotence of God and the importance of aligning one's will with divine purpose.

passage_content: ח) מ"ש הכתוב הטעם כי קרוב הוא, פן ינחם העם וגו' ושבו מצרימה, והרי עוד בעמדם על ים סוף התחרטו על שיצאו, והתרעמו על משה מה זאת עשית לנו להוציאנו ממצרים, והיו קרובים אז עדיין למצרים, וא"כ אף שהלכו דרך המדבר עדיין החששא במקומה עומדת פן ינחם העם ושבו מצרימה, ועוד דארץ ישראל קרובה מאוד למצרים, ועיקר מלחמת ל"א מלכים היתה בא"י, וא"כ כמו"כ הי' אפשר לחשוש, שבבואם לא"י ויראו מלחמת ל"א מלכים, פן ינחם העם ושבו מצרימה, ומה יועיל הליכתם דרך המדבר ודרך מעוקם, אם אחר שיצאו מן המדבר ויתקרבו לארץ ישראל שהוא קרובה למצרים חזרה החששא למקומה פן ינחם העם וגו' ושבו מצרימה, ורש"י פי' בראותם מלחמה כגון מלחמת וירד העמלקי והכנעני וגו', והרי מורא זה הי"ל גם בכניסה לארץ שנאמר עמלק יושב בארץ הנגב: ומה הועיל הליכתם דרך המדבר.
translation: (8) What the scripture means by saying "for he is close," lest the people regret and return to Egypt, is that even while they stood at the Sea of Reeds, they regretted having left and complained to Moses, "What is this you have done to us, to bring us out of Egypt?" They were still close to Egypt at that time. Therefore, even though they went through the desert, the concern remained that they might regret and return to Egypt. Furthermore, the Land of Israel is very close to Egypt, and the main battle against the thirty-one kings took place in the Land of Israel. Thus, it was also possible to be concerned that when they arrived in the Land of Israel and saw the battle against the thirty-one kings, they might regret and return to Egypt. What benefit was there in their journey through the desert and the winding path, if after leaving the desert and getting closer to the Land of Israel, which is near Egypt, the concern returned to its place, that they might regret and return to Egypt? Rashi explains that upon seeing war, such as the battle against Amalek and the Canaanite, this fear would also apply upon entering the land, as it is said, "Amalek dwells in the land of the Negev." What benefit was there in their journey through the desert?
summary: The passage discusses the concern that the Israelites, even after their miraculous exodus from Egypt, might regret their decision and wish to return when faced with challenges, such as the wars in the Promised Land. It highlights the proximity of Egypt to both the Red Sea and the Land of Israel, suggesting that the fear of returning could persist despite their journey through the desert. The text emphasizes the psychological struggle of the people, illustrating the ongoing battle between faith and fear, and questions the effectiveness of their desert journey if the threat of returning to Egypt remains. Ultimately, it reflects on the deep-seated anxieties that accompany spiritual and physical transitions.

passage_content: ט) מלחמה פי' רש"י בשם המכילתא זו מלחמת וירד העמלקי והכנעני האמור במעשה מרגלים והקשו המפרשים מדוע לא נקט ויבא עמלק שהי' מיד סמוך ליציאתם, ותירץ המהרש"ל משום דבאותה מלחמה נצחו ישראל את עמלק, ולא הי' לחוש כ"כ שיתנו לב לשוב, אבל גבי וירד העמלקי כתיב ויכום ויכתום, יש מקום לחוש יותר שיתנו לב לשוב, אמנם קשה דאדרבה מזו דויבא עמלק הי"ל לירא יותר, דשם בא עמלק מארצו ונלחם בהם לשנאתו אותם, ולא הי' מקום להיות נשמר ממנו, אלא שניצולו בדרך נס, אבל שם הי' מקום להיות ניצל ממנו, שהזהירם הקב"ה לא תעלו ולא תלחמו ולא תנגפו לפני אויביכם, וא"כ אין מקום לחשוש כ"כ פן ישובו מיראתו למצרים.
translation: 9) War, as Rashi explains in the name of the Mechilta, refers to the battle against the Amalekite and Canaanite mentioned in the story of the spies. The commentators questioned why it did not mention "and Amalek came" which was immediately after their departure. The Maharsha answered that in that battle, Israel defeated Amalek, and there was not much concern that they would turn back. However, regarding "and the Amalekite descended," it is written "and they struck them and crushed them," there is more reason to be concerned that they would turn back. Yet, it is difficult because, on the contrary, from "and Amalek came," they should have feared more, as there Amalek came from his land and fought against them out of hatred, and there was no place to be cautious of him, except that they were saved by a miracle. But there, there was reason to be saved from him, as the Holy One, Blessed be He, warned them not to ascend, not to fight, and not to be struck before their enemies. Therefore, there is no reason to be so concerned that they would turn back out of fear of him to Egypt.
summary: The passage discusses the conflict between Israel and Amalek, highlighting the theological implications of divine protection and human fear. It contrasts two battles: one where Israel defeats Amalek and another where Amalek attacks unexpectedly. The text suggests that despite the apparent danger from Amalek, God's command to avoid confrontation should instill confidence rather than fear. This reflects a deeper Hasidic understanding of reliance on divine guidance and the importance of faith in overcoming challenges.

passage_content: י) במכילתא לא הביאן הקב"ה דרך פשוטה לארץ ישראל אלא דרך המדבר, אמר הקב"ה אם אני מביא עכשיו ישראל לארץ מיד מחזיקים אדם בשדהו ואדם בכרמו והן בטלים מן התורה, אלא אקיפם במדבר מ' שנה, שיהיו אוכלין מן ושותין מי הבאר והתורה נבללת בגופן, מכאן הי' ר' שמעון אומר לא ניתנה תורה לדרוש אלא לאוכלי המן, ושניים להם אוכלי תרומה ע"כ, וצ"ב דאין זה הטעם המבואר בכתוב, דהתוה"ק נתנה טעם פן ינחם העם בראותם מלחמה וגו', ולמה נטו חז"ל בדרשתם ליתן טעם חדש שונה מהמפורש בפסוק, ופרשתי כבר דטעם המכילתא נכלל בטעם המבואר בפסוק, דאמרו חז"ל (ברכות דף ל"ה ע"ב) בזמן שישראל עושין רצונו של מקום מלאכתן נעשית ע"י אחרים, וא"כ אילו היו ישראל עושין רצונו של מקום לא הי' צורך להקיפם במדבר, דבלא"ה לא יצטרכו להיות בטלים מדברי תורה ע"י עבודת שדה וכרם, דהי' נתקיים בהם הבטחת הכתוב ועמדו זרים ורעו צאנכם וגו'. אלא מפני כי אמר אלקים פן ינחם העם וגו', ופן לא יהיו עושין רצונו של מקום, ע"כ לא הכניסם מיד כדי שלא יהיו בעלים מדברי תורה ונמצא דהא בהא תליא, אולם אעפ"כ עיקר חסר מן הספר, ולא נרמז בכתוב טעם המכילתא כלל ומאין למדו חז"ל לומר כן.
translation: In the Mechilta, it is not stated that the Holy One, blessed be He, brought them to the Land of Israel through a straightforward path, but rather through the desert. The Holy One, blessed be He, said, "If I bring Israel to the land now, immediately a person will take hold of his field and another will take hold of his vineyard, and they will be neglecting the Torah." Therefore, I will encircle them in the desert for forty years, so that they will eat from the manna and drink from the well, and the Torah will be absorbed within them. From here, Rabbi Shimon would say that the Torah was not given to be expounded upon except for those who eat the manna, and for the two who eat terumah, thus. However, it is puzzling that this is not the reason explained in the verse, for the Holy Torah gives a reason lest the people regret upon seeing war, etc. Why did the Sages deviate in their interpretation to provide a new reason different from what is explicitly stated in the verse? I have already explained that the reason of the Mechilta is included in the reason stated in the verse, for the Sages said (Berakhot 35b) that when Israel does the will of the Omnipresent, their work is done by others. Therefore, if Israel were doing the will of the Omnipresent, there would be no need to encircle them in the desert, for otherwise they would not need to be neglecting the words of the Torah due to working the field and vineyard, and the promise of the verse would be fulfilled, "And strangers shall stand and feed your flocks," etc. Rather, because God said, "Lest the people regret," etc., and "Lest they not do the will of the Omnipresent," therefore He did not bring them in immediately so that they would not be preoccupied with the words of the Torah. It turns out that this is dependent on that. However, nevertheless, the main point is lacking from the book, and the reason of the Mechilta is not hinted at in the verse at all, and from where did the Sages learn to say this?
summary: The passage discusses the divine decision to lead the Israelites through the desert rather than directly to the Promised Land, emphasizing that this was to prevent them from becoming preoccupied with their fields and neglecting the study of Torah. It highlights the idea that spiritual sustenance, represented by the manna and water from the well, was essential for their connection to the Torah. The text also reflects on the tension between the explicit biblical reason for the desert journey and the deeper insights offered by the sages, suggesting that the ultimate goal was to ensure the Israelites remained focused on fulfilling God's will. This underscores the Hasidic belief in the importance of spiritual nourishment and the necessity of divine guidance in maintaining a connection to sacred teachings.

passage_content: יא) קשה לפי טעם המכילתא הנ"ל דהי' הכרח שיתעכבו ישראל ארבעים שנה במדבר, כדי שיהי' התורה נבללת בגופן, דלא ניתנה תורה אלא לאוכלי המן ושני' להם אוכלי תרומה. דא"כ איפוא יהי' תקנתן של דורות הבאים שלא יהיו אוכלי המן, ואוכלי תרומה מועטין הם, ואיך יכנס התורה בגופן, ואכתי איכא חששא זו אצלן דזה פונה לכרמו וכו' ותורה מה תהא עלי'. ואף בדור המדבר ודור באי הארץ עצמן, אותן שנולדו לסוף הארבעים ונכנסו לארץ ישראל כשהיו קטנים ולא הגיעו לכלל דעת, ולא נשלמה קנין התורה בגופן בעודן במדבר, דאין אדם עומד על דעת רבו עד ארבעין שנין, וכיון דלא ניתנה תורה אלא לאוכלי המן. איך יהי' התורה נבללת בגופן, והדרא החששא לדוכתי' דזה פונה לכרמו וכו' ותורה מה תהא עלי' ונמצא שלא היה תקנה זו אלא לזקנים שבדור, והיתכן אחרי שהוא חששא קרובה, למה לא חש הקב"ה לעשות תקנה לכל ישראל וגם לדורות הבאים.
translation: 11) It is difficult according to the reasoning of the aforementioned Mechilta that it was necessary for Israel to linger for forty years in the desert, so that the Torah would be absorbed into their very being, for the Torah was given only to those who ate the manna, and secondarily to those who ate terumah. If so, what will be the remedy for the generations to come, since they will not be eating the manna, and the eaters of terumah are few, and how will the Torah enter into their being? Moreover, there is still this concern among them that one might turn to his vineyard, etc., and what will be with the Torah? Even in the generation of the desert and the generation of those who entered the land, those who were born at the end of the forty years and entered the land of Israel when they were young and did not reach the age of understanding, and the acquisition of the Torah was not completed in their being while they were in the desert, for a person does not grasp the understanding of his teacher until he is forty years old. And since the Torah was given only to those who ate the manna, how will the Torah be absorbed into their being? And the concern returns to their place that one might turn to his vineyard, etc., and what will be with the Torah? It turns out that this remedy was only for the elders of the generation, and is it possible, after all, that this is a close concern, that why did the Holy One, blessed be He, not establish a remedy for all of Israel and also for future generations?
summary: The passage discusses the necessity of the Israelites' forty-year sojourn in the desert for the Torah to be internalized within them, as it was given only to those who consumed the manna, symbolizing spiritual sustenance. It raises concerns about future generations who would not experience this divine provision, questioning how the Torah could be integrated into their lives. The text emphasizes that the Torah's transmission and understanding are contingent upon a deep, experiential connection, which is primarily accessible to the elders of the generation. Ultimately, it reflects on God's wisdom in ensuring that the Torah remains relevant and integrated within the Jewish people across generations.

passage_content: יב) ינחם העם בראותם מלחמה ושבו מצרימה, יל"ד דהול"ל לשוב מצרימה, דכונת הכתוב שיתנו לב לשוב. ובאמרו ושבו משמע שישובו בפועל, וזה א"א דכיון שאין רצון הבוי"ת שישובו: אין מציאות בעולם שישובו, ובאמת לא שבו אלא רצו לשוב שאמרו נתנה ראש ונשובה.
translation: 11) The people will be comforted when they see war and return to Egypt. It should have said "to return to Egypt," for the intent of the verse is that they should pay attention to return. And by saying "and they will return," it implies that they will actually return, which is impossible because since the Creator does not desire for them to return, there is no reality in the world for them to return. In truth, they did not return, but they wanted to return, as they said, "Let us appoint a leader and return."
summary: The passage discusses the people's desire to return to Egypt in the face of war, emphasizing that their intention to return is not aligned with the will of the Creator. It highlights that true return is impossible if it contradicts divine will, suggesting that their longing to return is merely a fleeting thought rather than a genuine action. The text underscores the importance of aligning one's desires with divine intention, illustrating a key Hasidic concept of the relationship between human will and divine purpose.

passage_content: יג) (רמז רכ"ו) ולא נחם אלקים דרך ארץ פלשתים כי קרוב הוא שנא' (תהלים קמ"ח) לבני ישראל עם קרובו, והובא בבעלי התוס' וז"ל, כלומר העם קרוב של הקב"ה וכו' ולכך לא הנהיגם כמנהגו של עולם, וצ"ב נתינת טעם זו.
translation: 13) (Hint 256) And God did not lead them through the land of the Philistines, for it was near, as it is said (Psalms 148) to the children of Israel, His close ones. And it was brought by the Ba'alei Tosafot, and it means that the people are close to the Holy One, Blessed be He, etc., and therefore He did not guide them as is the way of the world. And the reason for this is to be considered.
summary: In this passage, it is emphasized that God did not lead the Israelites through the land of the Philistines because they are considered His close people, as reflected in the verse from Psalms. This closeness implies a special relationship that transcends the usual ways of divine guidance. The text suggests that the unique bond between God and the Jewish people necessitates a different approach in their journey, highlighting the significance of their covenantal status. The inquiry into the reasoning behind this divine decision invites deeper reflection on the nature of God's relationship with His chosen people.

passage_content: יד) לבב פרעה ועבדיו ויאמרו מה זאת עשינו כי שלחנו את ישראל מעבדינו וגו' הקשה האוהחה"ק דמשמע שנתחרטו על הדבר אשר עשוהו, והדברים תמוהים וכי לרצונם עשו, והלא הוכו מכות גדולות עד אשר כמעט ספו תמו ובעכ"ח שלחום, ואיך נהפך לבם בדבר שלא הי' רצונם בו מתחלה, ורצונם עתה כרצונם מאז, ולא הי' כאן שינוי והתהפכות ברצון לבם כלל.
translation: (15) The heart of Pharaoh and his servants said, "What is this we have done, that we have sent Israel away from our service?" The holy question arises, for it implies that they regretted the act they had performed. The matter is perplexing; did they act according to their will? Were they not struck with great plagues until they were almost completely consumed, and yet they sent them away? How could their hearts be turned regarding something they did not desire initially? Their will now is as it was then, and there was no change or reversal in the desire of their hearts at all.
summary: The passage discusses the paradox of Pharaoh and his servants regretting their decision to release the Israelites after experiencing severe plagues. It raises the question of how their hearts could change when their initial desire was to keep the Israelites enslaved, suggesting that their later regret was not a true transformation of will. This reflects a deeper Hasidic concept of the struggle between divine will and human agency, emphasizing the complexity of free will in the face of divine intervention. Ultimately, it highlights the tension between external circumstances and internal desires in the context of redemption and spiritual growth.

passage_content: טו) יל"ד מ"ש מה זאת עשינו כי שלחנו את ישראל מעבדינו, משמע שהם ב' דברים העשי' לבד והשליחות לבד, ובאמת לא הי' כאן עשי' אחרת אלא ששלחו את ישראל, והול"ל מה זאת שלחנו את ישראל וגו'. וגם מ"ש כי שלחנו וגו' משמע שזה טעם ופירוש על תמיהתם באמירת מה זאת עשינו, ובאמת היינו הך ואינו אלא חדא ולמ"ל להזכירו בב' לשונות עשי' ושליחות ויספיק באחד מהם.
translation: 15) It is said, "What is this we have done, for we have sent Israel away from our service," implying that there are two separate matters: the act itself and the sending away. In truth, there was no other act here except for sending away Israel, and it should have said, "What is this we have sent Israel away," etc. Furthermore, the phrase "for we have sent away" implies that this is a reason and explanation for their astonishment in saying, "What is this we have done." In truth, it is the same, and it is only one matter. It was necessary to mention it in two expressions: act and sending, and one of them would have sufficed.
summary: The passage discusses the dual expressions of action and sending in the context of the Israelites' departure from Egypt, emphasizing that these are not separate actions but rather one unified act. The use of both terms highlights the significance of the act of sending, suggesting a deeper theological insight into the nature of divine intervention and human agency. The text implies that the questioning of their actions reflects a misunderstanding of the singularity of their deed, reinforcing the idea that divine will and human actions are interconnected. Ultimately, it underscores the importance of recognizing the unity in God's plans and the role of individuals within that framework.

passage_content: טז) כאשר ראיתם את מצרים היום לא תספו לראותם עוד עד עולם, ופליגי בזה מוני המצות אם פסוק זה מצות לא תעשה לדורות או הבטחה בלבד, ועוד נבאר בזה להלן, אבל בכל אופן קשה מ"ש כי כאשר ראיתם את מצרים היום, ובתרגום ארי כמא די חזיתון ית מצראי יומא דין לא תוספון למחזיהן וכו', מדוע תלה הכתוב מאמר לא תוסיפו במה שראו המצרים היום, ומאי נפק"מ אם כמא דחזיתון או באופן אחר, והול"ל לא תוסיפו לראותם וגו' ודי בזה ומאמר כאשר ראיתם מיותר.
translation: 16) "As you have seen Egypt today, you shall never see them again forever." There is a dispute among the enumerators of the commandments whether this verse is a prohibition for all generations or merely a promise. We will elaborate on this later, but in any case, it is difficult what is meant by "as you have seen Egypt today," and in the translation, "as you have seen the Egyptians today, you shall not see them again," why does the verse link the statement "you shall not see them again" to what they saw of the Egyptians today? And what difference does it make if it is as they saw or in another manner? It could have simply stated "you shall not see them again," and that would suffice, making the phrase "as you have seen" superfluous.
summary: The passage discusses the verse "As you have seen Egypt today, you shall never see them again," exploring whether it serves as a prohibition for future generations or merely a promise. It raises questions about the significance of the phrase "as you have seen" and its implications for understanding the nature of divine intervention and the permanence of God's promises. The text emphasizes the importance of witnessing God's actions and the transformative impact of such experiences on faith and belief. Ultimately, it highlights the relationship between perception, memory, and the assurance of divine protection.

passage_content: יז) הקשה ר' ייסא שאיל ואמר כתיב וירא ישראל את מצרים מת וגו' וכתיב לא תוסיפו לראותם עוד עד עולם א"ר יוסי מתין חמו להו: כלומר דמה דכתיב לא תוסיפו לראותם היינו בחייהון, וק"ז היש"מ זלל"ה מביא קושיא בשם תשו' בית יעקב (סימן ו') מהא דאיתא בכתובות (פ"ג ע"א) ר"י אמר לעולם הוא אוכל פרי פירות וכו' עד שיכתוב לה דין ודברים אין לי בנכסיך ובפרותיהן וכו' עד עולם, וכתבו התוס' שם דעד עולם פירושו שלא יאכל בין בחיי' ובין במותה, א"כ ה"נ כיון דכתיב כאן לא תוסיפו לראותם עוד עד עולם משמעו בין בחייהון ובין במיתתם א"כ הדרא קושית הזוה"ק לדוכתי', על מה דכתיב וירא ישראל את מצרים מת על שפת הים.
translation: 17) Rabbi Yisa raised a question and said, it is written, "And Israel saw the Egyptians dead," etc., and it is written, "You shall not see them again forever." Rabbi Yossi said, they die in their lifetime. Meaning, what is written "You shall not see them again" refers to their lifetime. And the holy Yismach Moshe, may his memory be blessed, brings a question in the name of the responsa of Beit Yaakov (Siman 6) from what is stated in Ketubot (Perek 3, Ahalacha 1), Rabbi Yochanan said, "He is always eating the fruits of the fruits," etc., until he writes to her, "I have no claims on your property and on her fruits," etc., forever. And the Tosafot there wrote that "forever" means that he shall not eat, whether in her lifetime or after her death. Therefore, here too, since it is written "You shall not see them again forever," it implies both in their lifetime and in their death. Thus, the question of the Zohar returns to its place regarding what is written, "And Israel saw the Egyptians dead by the edge of the sea."
summary: The passage discusses the paradox of Israel witnessing the death of the Egyptians at the Red Sea while being commanded not to see them again forever. Rabbi Yossi interprets this as referring to the Egyptians' existence in life, suggesting that the prohibition applies both in life and death. The text raises a question about the implications of this command, linking it to a broader theological understanding of the relationship between life, death, and divine justice, as reflected in the teachings of Hasidic thought. Ultimately, it emphasizes the eternal separation between Israel and their oppressors, underscoring a profound spiritual and moral lesson.

passage_content: יח) ישיר משה ובנ"י את השירה הזאת לד' ויאמרו לאמר וגו' פרש"י אז כשראה הנס עלה בלבו שישיר שירה ע"כ, והוכרח לומר כן דקשיא לי' דאז לשון עבר הוא וישיר משמע לעתיד והול"ל אז שר, ע"כ פירש דישיר קאי על המחשבה, והרמב"ן ז"ל הקשה עליו עיי"ש, והגו"א הקשה ג"כ על פרש"י דלמה לי' למימר שעלה בלבו שישיר הרי מבואר בכתוב ששר שנא' ויאמרו לאמר, ובודאי שעלה בלבו קודם, ולמ"ל להאריך ולכתוב תרווייהו שעלה בלבו וגם שר. וחז"ל דרשו (במס' סנהדרין צ"א) ר' מאיר אומר מנין לתחיית המתים מן התורה שנא' אז ישיר משה, שר לא נאמר אלא ישיר, אולם לפי פשוטו שפרש"י ז"ל קשה כנ"ל.
translation: 18) "Then Moses and the children of Israel sang this song to the Lord, and they said, saying, etc." Rashi explains that when he saw the miracle, it arose in his heart to sing a song, therefore he was compelled to say so, for it is difficult for him that "then" is in the past tense, and "sang" implies the future, and it should have said "then he sang." Therefore, he explains that "sang" refers to the thought. However, Ramban, may his memory be blessed, challenges him, as noted there, and the G'ra also questions Rashi's explanation, asking why it is necessary to say that it arose in his heart to sing, since it is clear from the text that he sang, as it is written "and they said, saying." Certainly, it arose in his heart beforehand, so why elaborate and write both that it arose in his heart and that he sang? And our Sages expounded (in Tractate Sanhedrin 91) Rabbi Meir says, "From where do we know the resurrection of the dead from the Torah? As it is said, 'Then Moses sang,' 'sang' is not said, but 'will sing.'" However, according to the simple interpretation that Rashi, may his memory be blessed, explained, it is difficult as mentioned above.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the discussion centers on the phrase "Then Moses and the Israelites sang this song to the Lord," highlighting the significance of the word "will sing" as an expression of intention and thought before the actual act of singing. The commentary explores the tension between the past and future tense, suggesting that the act of singing was premeditated in Moses' heart. Additionally, it references the rabbinic interpretation that connects this moment to the concept of resurrection, indicating a deeper theological insight into the nature of song as a vehicle for spiritual expression and prophetic vision.

passage_content: יט) המחלה אשר שמתי במצרים לא אשים עליך כי אני ד' רופאך, וקשה דאם לא ישים רפואה למה, וכן הקשה ר' יצחק במכילתא אם אין בהם מחלה מפני מה הם צריכים רפואה. ופרש"י לתרץ זה דהכוונה לא אשים ואם אשים ה"ה כלא הושמה, כי אני ד' רופאך והם דברי ר' יהושע במכילתא, אולם קשה ע"ז דהרי לא כתיב אם אשים, ומשמעות הכתוב מורה דלא אשים כלל, וא"כ רפואה למה, ע"כ פרש"י עוד דלפי פשוטו של מקרא, כי אני ד' רופאך מלמדך תורה ומצות למען תנצל מחולאים, כרופא הזה המזהיר לאדם שלא יאכל דברים המזיקים ומביאים אותו לידי חולי, אולם גם לפירוש זה קשה, כי אחרי שהתוה"ק מלמדו שלא יבוא לידי חולי, א"כ לא יצטרך לרפואה, ולמה כתיב כי אני ד' רופאך.
translation: 19) The disease that I placed upon Egypt I will not place upon you, for I am the Lord your Healer. And it is difficult, for if He will not place healing, then why? And Rabbi Yitzchak asked in the Mechilta, if there is no disease, why do they need healing? Rashi explains to resolve this that the intention is "I will not place," and if I do place, it is as if it was not placed at all, for I am the Lord your Healer. These are the words of Rabbi Yehoshua in the Mechilta. However, this is difficult, for it is not written "if I place," and the meaning of the verse indicates that I will not place at all. Therefore, why healing? Rashi further explains that according to the simple meaning of the verse, "for I am the Lord your Healer" teaches you Torah and commandments so that you may be saved from ailments, like a doctor who warns a person not to eat harmful things that bring him to illness. However, even according to this explanation, it is difficult, for after the Holy Torah teaches him not to come to illness, then he should not need healing, so why is it written "for I am the Lord your Healer"?
summary: The passage discusses the verse "I will not put the disease upon you, for I am the Lord your healer," raising questions about the necessity of healing if there is no illness. It references Rabbi Yitzchak's inquiry in the Mekilta regarding the need for healing if there are no diseases present. The interpretation suggests that God provides guidance through Torah and commandments to prevent illness, akin to a doctor advising against harmful practices. However, the text grapples with the paradox of needing healing when the Torah is meant to protect from sickness, emphasizing the profound relationship between divine guidance and human health.

passage_content: כ) בסוף הפרשה ויבא עמלק וילחם בישראל וגו' הקשה הגו"א דהול"ל ויצא עמלק כדכתיב ויצא סיחון, ויצא אדום ובכל מלחמה דרך הכתוב לומר כך, ולמה כתיב כאן ויבא. ובמכילתא דרשו ר' אליעזר אומר ויבא עמלק שבא בגלוי פנים, לפי שכל הביאות שבא לא בא אלא במטמוניות וכו', אבל ביאה זו לא בא אלא בגלוי פנים, לכך נאמר ויבא עמלק שבא בגלוי פנים ר' נתן אומר לא בא אלא מהררי שעיר, ד' מאות פרסה פסע עמלק ובא ונלחם עם ישראל. וראוי להבין מה הי' תכלית ביאתו במטמוניות, והאיך נלחם בסתר, גם לא מצינו בשום מקום שבא עמלק להלחם עם ישראל במטמוניות וצ"ב.
translation: At the end of the parsha, "And Amalek came and fought with Israel," the Gaon asks why it does not say "And Amalek went out," as it is written "And Sichon went out," and "And Edom went out," and in all wars, the scripture usually states it this way. Why is it written here "And Amalek came"? In the Mekilta, it is expounded: Rabbi Eliezer says "And Amalek came" means he came with revealed intentions, for all other arrivals were not but in hidden ways, etc. But this arrival was only with revealed intentions; therefore, it is said "And Amalek came" that he came with revealed intentions. Rabbi Natan says he came only from the mountains of Seir, and Amalek traveled four hundred parasangs and came and fought with Israel. It is worth understanding what was the purpose of his coming in hidden ways, and how he fought in secret. Also, we do not find anywhere that Amalek came to fight with Israel in hidden ways, and this is a question.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author discusses the unique nature of Amalek's approach to battle against Israel, emphasizing that Amalek came "openly" rather than through stealth, as was typical in previous encounters. This is interpreted by Rabbi Eliezer as a significant revelation of Amalek's intent, contrasting with the hidden tactics of other nations. Rabbi Natan adds that Amalek traveled a great distance from the mountains of Seir to confront Israel, highlighting the determination of this adversary. The text raises questions about the purpose of Amalek's direct confrontation and the implications of such an open challenge in the broader context of spiritual warfare.

passage_content: ולבאר הענין נקדים מה דאיתא בגמ' סנהדרין (דף ק"י ע"ב) ת"ר דור המדבר אין להם חלק לעוה"ב, שנא' במדבר הזה יתמו ושם ימותו, יתמו בעוה"ז ושם ימותו לעוה"ב, ואומר אשר נשבעתי באפי אם יבואון אל מנוחתי (דרשוהו על מנוחת עוה"ב עי' במהרש"א) דברי ר"ע ר' אליעזר אומר באים הם לעוה"ב שנא' אספו לי חסידי כורתי בריתי עלי זבח, אמר רבב"ח א"ר יוחנן שבקיה ר"ע לחסידותיה שנאמר (ירמי' ב') הלוך וקראת באזני ירושלים לאמר זכרתי לך חסד נעוריך וגו' לכתך אחרי במדבר בארץ לא זרועה, ומה אחרים באים בזכותם הם עצמן לא כ"ש. וכתב העיון יעקב דר"ע לא יקשה עליו מהאי קרא דזכרתי לך חסד נעוריך, דסבירא לי' דהאי קרא מיירי באותן שהיו פחותין מבן כ' ויתרים על בן ס' שלא היו בכלל גזירת המרגלים כדאיתא בב"ב עיי"ש.
translation: To clarify the matter, we will begin with what is stated in the Gemara in Sanhedrin (page 110b): The generation of the desert has no share in the World to Come, as it is said, "In this desert they shall be consumed, and there they shall die." They shall be consumed in this world, and there they shall die in the World to Come. And it says, "As I have sworn in My wrath, if they shall enter into My rest" (this is interpreted as referring to the rest of the World to Come, see Maharsha). These are the words of Rabbi Akiva. Rabbi Eliezer says they do enter the World to Come, as it is said, "Gather to Me My pious ones, those who made a covenant with Me by sacrifice." Rabbi B'Chai said in the name of Rabbi Yochanan that Rabbi Akiva left aside his piety, as it is stated (Jeremiah 2), "Go and proclaim in the ears of Jerusalem, saying, 'I remember for you the kindness of your youth... when you followed Me in the wilderness, in a land not sown.'" If others enter by virtue of their own merit, how much more so! And the Iyun Yaakov wrote that Rabbi Akiva is not troubled by this verse, "I remember for you the kindness of your youth," for he holds that this verse refers to those who were under twenty and over sixty, who were not included in the decree of the spies, as is stated in Baba Batra, see there.
summary: The passage discusses the fate of the generation that wandered in the desert, with a debate on whether they have a share in the World to Come. Rabbi Akiva argues that they do, citing the verse about gathering the righteous who uphold God's covenant, while others, like Rabbi Eliezer, maintain that they do not, based on the consequences of their actions in the desert. The text highlights the tension between divine justice and mercy, emphasizing the significance of faithfulness and the potential for redemption, particularly for those who were young and not part of the sin of the spies.

passage_content: ולכאורה אינו מתיישב בתירוצו של העיון יעקב, ועדיין יקשה לר"ע מק"ו הנ"ל, עפי"מ דאיתא במכילתא (פ' בא) וגם צדה לא עשו להם, להודיע שבחן של ישראל שלא אמרו למשה האיך נצא למדבר ואין לנו צדה לדרך, אלא האמינו והלכו אחר משה, ועליהם מפורש בקבלה הלוך וקראת באזני ירושלים לאמר זכרתי לך חסד נעוריך וגו' לכתך אחרי במדבר בארץ לא זרועה, מה שכר נטלו על כך קדש ישראל לד' ראשית תבואתו כל אכליו יאשמו רעה תבוא אליהם נאם ד', וכן איתא במכילתא פ' בשלח ובתנחומא פ' בא, מבואר דזכות דור המדבר והאמונה שהאמינו בו ית', והלכו אחרי דיבורו ביד משה למדבר לא זרועה, הקב"ה זוכר לנו זכות הזה עד סוף כל הדורות, ונקראו ישראל קודש בשכר זה, וכל אכליו יאשמו כמאה"כ, וא"כ אכתי יקשה לר"ע דזכות אמונה זו הי' לכל דור המדבר, ואף לאלו שהיו בכלל הגזרה, ולומר שאבדו זכות האמונה ע"י העון של מרגלים, בודאי לא ניחא למרייהו לומר עלייהו הכי, והרי כללא הוא דאין עבירה מכבה מצו', וא"א לומר על דור קדוש כזה שאבדו זכותם לגמרי, וא"כ כח הק"ו חזקה הוא, דאם כל הדורות יהנו בזכותן, דור המדבר עצמן לא כ"ש שיזכו לעוה"ב, וצ"ב דברי ר"ע במ"ש דור המדבר אין להם חלק לעוה"ב
translation: And seemingly it does not settle with the explanation of the Iyun Yaakov, and it is still difficult for Rabbi Akiva from the aforementioned a fortiori argument, according to what is stated in the Mechilta (Parashat Bo) that they also did not prepare provisions for themselves, to inform us of the merit of Israel, who did not say to Moses, "How will we go out to the desert when we have no provisions for the way?" Rather, they believed and followed Moses, and it is explicitly stated in the tradition, "Go and proclaim in the ears of Jerusalem, saying, 'I remember for you the kindness of your youth... when you went after Me in the wilderness, in a land not sown.'" What reward did Israel receive for this? "The holiness of Israel is to the Lord, the first of His harvest; all who eat it will be guilty of evil, says the Lord." And it is also stated in the Mechilta of Parashat Beshalach and in the Tanchuma of Parashat Bo, it is clear that the merit of the generation of the desert and the faith they had in Him, blessed be He, and that they followed His word through Moses into the unsown wilderness, the Holy One, blessed be He, remembers this merit for us until the end of all generations, and Israel is called holy for this merit, and all who eat it will be guilty as the verse states. And if so, it is still difficult for Rabbi Akiva that this merit of faith was for the entire generation of the desert, even for those who were included in the decree, and to say that they lost the merit of faith due to the sin of the spies, certainly it would not be pleasing to them to say such a thing about them, and behold, it is a general rule that no sin extinguishes a commandment, and it is impossible to say about such a holy generation that they completely lost their merit. And therefore, the strength of the a fortiori argument is strong, that if all generations benefit from their merit, how much more so the generation of the desert themselves should merit the World to Come. And the words of Rabbi Akiva regarding the statement that the generation of the desert has no share in the World to Come are indeed puzzling.
summary: The passage discusses the faith of the Israelites during their journey in the desert, highlighting their trust in God and Moses despite lacking provisions. It emphasizes that this faith granted them a unique merit, making them "holy" and ensuring that their righteousness is remembered throughout generations. The author questions Rabbi Akiva's assertion that the generation of the desert has no share in the World to Come, arguing that their inherent faith and the divine acknowledgment of their merit should secure them a place in the afterlife, despite their eventual transgressions.

passage_content: ובאמת קשה להבין דברי ר"ע בלא"ה, אף לולי פירכת ר' יוחנן מכח הק"ו, ממ"ד בזוה"ק פ' שלח (דף קס"ג) זכאה דרא דא (דור המדבר) מכל דרין דעלמא: נפקי ממתיבתא דמשה ופרחי לגבי מתיבתא דרקיעא, ואותן שהיו ראוים פרחו לגבי מתיבתא עלאה, על ההוא דרא כתיב אשרי העם שככה לו אשרי העם שד' אלקיו. ואיתא במכילתא הנ"ל דע"י שאכלו מן ושתו מי באר נבללת התורה בגופן, ושמעו הדברות מפי הגבורה והיו מקור התורה לכל דורות ישראל, ובפרדר"א (פרק מ') כל אותו דור ששמעו קולו של הקב"ה בהר סיני זכו להיות כמלאכי השרת, לא ראו טיפת קרי מימיהם וכו' ובמותם לא שלטה בהם רמה ותולעה ע"כ, (ובדפוסים שלנו נשמט המאמר לא ראו קרי מימיהם, אבל ברוב ספרים שהעתיקו דברי הפרדר"א הנ"ל הביאו בגרסתם מאמר זה, וכן בילקוט המכירי (תהלים קמ"ד) והחיד"א ז"ל הביא גירסא זו ועוד בכ"מ) נראה שזו גירסא האמיתית, עכ"פ הי' להם מדריגות קדושות יותר מכל הדורות, ולא הי' כמותם ולא יהי' דור כזה עד ביאת המשיח, ומאמר זה דלא שלטה בהם רמה ותולעה נמצא בכל הספרים כן, ולמדריגה זו לא זכו כ"א יחידי סגולה כמ"ש במס' ב"ב (דף י"ז ע"א) שבעה לא שלט בהם רמה ותולעה ואלו הן אברהם יצחק ויעקב משה ואהרן ומרים ובנימין בן יעקב, וי"א אף דוד דכתיב אף בשרי ישכון לבטח, ואידך ההוא רחמי הוא דקא בעי.
translation: And indeed, it is difficult to understand the words of Rabbi Akiva without this, even without the refutation of Rabbi Yochanan based on the a fortiori argument. It is stated in the Zohar, Parashat Shelach (page 163), that the generation of the wilderness is more deserving than all the generations of the world: they emerged from the study hall of Moshe and soared to the study hall of the heavens, and those who were worthy soared to the higher study hall. Concerning that generation, it is written, "Blessed is the people that is so; blessed is the people whose God is the Lord." And it is stated in the aforementioned Mekilta that by eating the manna and drinking from the well, they internalized the Torah within themselves, and they heard the commandments from the mouth of the Holy One, Blessed be He, and they were the source of the Torah for all generations of Israel. And in Pirkei deRabbi Eliezer (Chapter 40), it is said that all that generation who heard the voice of the Holy One at Mount Sinai merited to be like the ministering angels; they did not see a drop of impurity in their days, etc., and in their death, decay and worm did not have dominion over them. (And in our printed editions, the statement that they did not see impurity in their days is omitted, but in most books that copied the words of the aforementioned Pirkei deRabbi Eliezer, this statement is included in their version, as well as in the Yalkut Me'am Loez (Psalms 144), and the Chida, may his memory be blessed, brought this version and more in other places.) It seems that this is the authentic version; in any case, they had more sacred levels than all the generations, and there was none like them, nor will there be such a generation until the coming of the Messiah. And this statement that decay and worm did not have dominion over them is found in all the books in this manner, and to this level, only select individuals merited, as stated in Tractate Bava Batra (page 17a) that seven did not have decay and worm rule over them, and these are Abraham, Isaac, Jacob, Moshe, Aaron, Miriam, and Benjamin the son of Jacob, and some say even David, as it is written, "Even in my flesh shall I dwell in safety." And the other one is a mercy that he seeks.
summary: The passage discusses the unique spiritual status of the generation that received the Torah at Sinai, highlighting their elevated sanctity and connection to divine wisdom. It emphasizes that this generation, having directly experienced God's voice and consumed the manna, became the source of Torah for all future generations, achieving a level of purity where decay and corruption did not affect them. The text asserts that such a holy status is unparalleled and will not be replicated until the coming of the Messiah, with only a select few individuals throughout history attaining similar sanctity.

passage_content: ולפי"ז הי' מדרגתם קרובה למדריגת האבות הק' ומשה ואהרן, וגודל מדריגתם אין לשער, ובפרט לגרסת הספרים שלא ראו קרי מימיהם, לא הי' מעולם דור כזה שיוכלו להתפאר במידה זאת, שכללות הדור לא ראו קרי מימיהם, ואיך יעלה על הדעת שלא יהי' להם חלק לעוה"ב, ואיך אמר ר"ע כן, והוא דבר מבהיל הרעיון דאם יהי' המציאות כן א"כ לא שבקת חי לכל ברי' ונמצא נעילת דלת בפני השבין, דהנה ישראל עשו תשובה על חטא המרגלים שנא' וישכמו בבקר וכו' לאמר הננו ועלינו אל המקום אשר אמר ד' כי חטאנו ויתאבלו העם מאוד. ואיתא בתנדב"א באותה שעה א"ל הקב"ה למשה, משה בוא ורצה אותם העניים שכבר יצא לבם מעליהם וכו', הרי ששבו בכל לבם, הגם שהי' פגם חטאם גדול מאוד בערך גודל מדריגת קדושתן ע"ד וסביביו נשערה מאוד והיתה הגזירה מוחלטת שלא יכנסו כל אותו הדור לא"י, כמ"ש אשר נשבעתי באפי אם יבואון אל מנוחתי, ולא הועיל תשובתם להתיר להם כניסת הארץ, ובאמת הי' ההכרח כן שלא יכנסו לארץ ונתלה בהם העלילה בבחי' נורא עלילה על בנ"א, כמו חטא אדה"ר וחטא מכירת יוסף וכדאיתא בתנחומא פ' וישב. אבל טעם זה מספיק לענין שלא נתקבלה תשובתן להתיר להם כניסת הארץ אבל שלא יהא להם חלק לעוה"ב, איך יעלה על הדעת לומר כן.
translation: According to this, their level was close to that of the holy Patriarchs, Moses, and Aaron, and the greatness of their level is beyond measure, especially considering the version of the books that state they never saw a "keri" in their days. There has never been a generation that could boast of such a measure, that the entirety of the generation never saw a "keri" in their days. How can it be conceived that they would not have a share in the World to Come? And how could Rabbi Akiva say such a thing? It is a terrifying thought that if reality were so, then they would not leave life for any creature, and the door would be closed to those who repent. Behold, Israel repented for the sin of the spies, as it is said, "And they rose early in the morning... saying, 'Here we are, and we will go up to the place that the Lord has spoken of, for we have sinned,' and the people mourned greatly." And it is stated in Tana d'Bei Eliyahu that at that time, the Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Moses, "Moses, come and see those poor ones whose hearts have already turned away from them," etc. This shows that they returned with all their hearts, even though their sin was a very great blemish in relation to the greatness of their holiness, as it is said, "and around Him was greatly feared," and there was a complete decree that that entire generation would not enter the Land of Israel, as it is said, "As I have sworn in My anger, if they shall enter into My rest." Their repentance did not help to permit them entry into the land, and indeed it was necessary that they not enter the land, and the accusation against them was in a manner of a terrible accusation against humanity, like the sin of Adam HaRishon and the sin of the sale of Joseph, as it is stated in Tanchuma, Parashat Vayeshev. But this reason is sufficient to explain why their repentance was not accepted to permit them entry into the land, but how can it be conceived that they would not have a share in the World to Come?
summary: The passage discusses the elevated spiritual status of certain generations, likening them to the patriarchs and Moses, particularly emphasizing a unique generation that never witnessed a specific sin. It raises a theological concern regarding the implications of their repentance for the sin of the spies, questioning how it could be conceivable that such a generation would be denied a share in the World to Come despite their sincere return to God. The text highlights the tension between the severity of their sin and the possibility of redemption, ultimately asserting the incomprehensibility of denying them eternal reward.

passage_content: גם ראוי להבין דברי ר' יוחנן במ"ש שבקי' ר"ע לחסידותי', הרי טען והשיב על דברי ר"ע לחלוק עליו מהוכחת הכתוב הלוך וקראת וגו' ומכח הק"ו ור"ע הביא ראי' לסברתו מקרא, ואין דבר זה תלוי בחסידות, אלא פלוגתתם תליא בדרשת הכתובים, ומדוע טען על ר"ע דשבקי' לחסידותי' וצ"ב הכוונה בזה.
translation: It is also appropriate to understand the words of Rabbi Yochanan regarding what he said that Rabbi Akiva abandoned his Hasidic approach. He indeed argued and responded to Rabbi Akiva's words to dispute him based on the proof of the verse "Go and read..." and from the strength of the a fortiori argument, and Rabbi Akiva brought a proof for his opinion from a verse. This matter is not dependent on Hasidut, but their dispute is based on the interpretation of the scriptures. And why did he claim about Rabbi Akiva that he abandoned his Hasidic approach? This requires clarification.
summary: The passage discusses a debate between Rabbi Yochanan and Rabbi Akiva regarding the interpretation of scriptural texts, emphasizing that their disagreement is rooted in textual exegesis rather than a matter of Hasidic piety. Rabbi Yochanan challenges Rabbi Akiva's reliance on a specific scriptural proof, suggesting that the essence of their dispute lies in the interpretation of the verses rather than in the realm of Hasidic thought. The text raises questions about the implications of labeling Rabbi Akiva's approach as lacking in Hasidic depth, prompting a deeper exploration of the relationship between textual interpretation and spiritual practice.

passage_content: עוד ראוי לדקדק בפסוק הנ"ל זכרתי לך חסד נעוריך וגו' לכתך אחרי במדבר בארץ לא זרועה, שלכאורה הול"ל במדבר לא זרועה. וכבר הזכיר מדבר ואין צורך במילת בארץ. ועוד דכל המאמר בארץ לא זרועה מיותר הוא, דכבר אמר הכתוב לכתך אחרי במדבר וידוע דמדבר לא זרועה הוא, והרד"ק ז"ל דקדק עוד במ"ש חסד נעוריך, ומדוע כינה הכתוב לדור המדבר נעוריך, ופי' שימים הקדמונים נקראים ימי הנעורים בדרך שאלה ומשל, כמו שימי הנעורים קודמים לימי הזקנה עיי"ש, ולכאורה עדיין צ"ב הכוונה דהרי מפורש דמיירי בדור המדבר ובימים הקדמונים כמ"ש לכתך אחרי במדבר ולמה יתאר אותם עוד בשם חסד נעוריך, ולמאי נפק"מ אם הוא חסד נעוריך או לא
translation: It is also appropriate to pay attention to the aforementioned verse, "I remember for you the kindness of your youth, etc., your following after Me in the wilderness, in a land not sown," for it could have simply said "in the wilderness not sown." The term "wilderness" has already been mentioned, and there is no need for the word "land." Furthermore, the entire phrase "in a land not sown" is superfluous, as the verse has already stated "your following after Me in the wilderness," and it is known that a wilderness is not sown. The Radak, of blessed memory, further noted regarding the phrase "the kindness of your youth," and why the verse refers to the generation of the wilderness as "your youth." He explained that the days of old are called the days of youth in a manner of question and parable, just as the days of youth precede the days of old age, as mentioned there. However, it still remains to be understood what the intention is, since it is explicitly stated that it is discussing the generation of the wilderness and the days of old, as it says "your following after Me in the wilderness," so why does it further describe them as "the kindness of your youth," and what difference does it make whether it is "the kindness of your youth" or not?
summary: The passage reflects on the biblical verse "I remember the kindness of your youth, the love of your betrothals, when you went after Me in the wilderness, in a land not sown." It questions the necessity of the phrase "in a land not sown" and the term "youth" to describe the generation in the desert, suggesting that the "youth" symbolizes the early, formative relationship between God and Israel. This relationship is characterized by divine kindness and love, emphasizing the significance of the past and the foundational experiences that shape spiritual identity. The inquiry into these terms highlights the enduring nature of God's covenant and the importance of remembering the initial fervor of faith.

passage_content: ואפ"ל עוד כוונה בזה מלבד פשטות המשמעות, דלכאורה אין כ"כ רבותא וחידוש על דור המדבר מה שהאמינו בד' ובמשה עבדו, והלכו במצותו בארץ לא זרועה, דאחרי שראו כל אותן הנסים והנפלאות שעשה ד' עמהם בהוציאם ממצרים, ונתאמת אצלם נבואת משרע"ה בירור גמור ע"י האותות, וע"י הסימן של פקידה כפולה, (כמ"ש בחידושינו פ' שמות) וראו שנתקיים כל הבטחתו שאמר להם בשליחות השי"ת, ובפרט לפי ערך מדריגת הדור ההוא, אין חידוש כ"כ שבטחו והאמינו בו ית' שגם לחם יוכל תת ויכין שאר לעמו, ויצאו עפ"י ציוויו למדבר, ועוד דאלולי החטא היו נכנסין לא"י מיד, ולא היו מתעכבים במדבר כ"א זמן קצר, ועל דעת כן שיכנסו לא"י מיד יצאו ממצרים בידים ריקנות, דעוגות שהוציאו ממצרים הי' מספיק להם על ל"א יום כדאיתא במכילתא, ועוד דהרי הי' עמהם רכוש רב וכסף וזהב הרבה מרכוש מצרים, ותגרי האומות היו מביאים להם כל צרכיהם, אלא שהי' רצון השי"ת שיתפרנסו מן המן לחם אבירים וישתו מי באר, ולפי"ז לכאורה לא הי' הנסיון גדול כ"כ, ואפשר שגם אנשים שאינם בערך מדריגתם היו עומדים בנסיון זה, וא"כ צ"ב להבין ענין הנסיון שהפליג הכתוב כ"כ בשבחו.
translation: And although there is another intention in this besides the simplicity of the meaning, it seems that there is not so much greatness and novelty regarding the generation of the desert in that they believed in the Holy One, blessed be He, and in Moses, His servant, and followed His commandments in a land that was not sown. For after they saw all those miracles and wonders that the Holy One, blessed be He, performed with them in taking them out of Egypt, and the prophecy of Moses was confirmed for them through the signs, and through the sign of the double appointment (as we explained in our commentary on Parashat Shemot), and they saw that all His promises, which He said to them in the name of the Holy One, blessed be He, were fulfilled, especially considering the level of that generation, there is not so much novelty that they trusted and believed in Him, blessed be He, that He could provide bread and prepare sustenance for His people, and they went out according to His command to the desert. Moreover, had it not been for the sin, they would have entered the Land of Israel immediately and would not have lingered in the desert except for a short time. Based on this, they left Egypt empty-handed, for the cakes they took out of Egypt would have sufficed them for thirty-one days, as it is stated in the Mekhilta. Furthermore, they had with them great wealth and much silver and gold from the possessions of Egypt, and the merchants of the nations would bring them all their needs. Rather, it was the will of the Holy One, blessed be He, that they should be sustained by the manna, the bread of the mighty, and drink from the well. According to this, it seems that the trial was not so great, and it is possible that even people who are not on the level of their stature would withstand this trial. Therefore, it is necessary to understand the matter of the trial that the scripture extols so greatly.
summary: The passage discusses the faith of the Israelites in the desert, emphasizing that their belief in God and Moses, despite witnessing miracles, may not seem extraordinary given their experiences. It suggests that their reliance on divine sustenance, like manna, was part of God's plan, and questions the significance of their trial in the wilderness. The author seeks to understand why the biblical text praises their faith so highly, considering that even those of lesser spiritual stature might have succeeded in such a test. This reflects a deeper exploration of the nature of faith and divine providence in the context of the Israelites' journey.

passage_content: אמנם נבאר להלן בע"ה דאדרבה לצד גודל מדריגתן, והתיקון הגדול שנעשה על ידיהם, ע"כ היתה הסתת היצר והתגברות כוחות החיצונים חזקה עליהם מאוד, והיתה נסיון גדול אצליהם לעמוד באמונתם ולהתגבר על כוחות היצר, וע"כ זוכר הקב"ה לדורות עולם החסד שעשו, כמ"ש הכתוב זכרתי לך חסד נעוריך וגו' לכתך אחרי במדבר, ואחרים עומדים בזכותם כמ"ש בגמ' הנ"ל, דזכותם גדול מאוד, לפי שעמדו בנסיון נגד ההתגברות הנורא, ויבואר להלן באריכות אי"ה.
translation: Indeed, we will explain below, with G-d's help, that on the contrary, due to the greatness of their level and the great rectification that was accomplished through them, the temptation of the evil inclination and the strengthening of external forces was very strong against them, and it was a great trial for them to stand firm in their faith and to overcome the forces of the evil inclination. Therefore, the Holy One, Blessed be He, remembers for all generations the kindness they performed, as it is written, "I remember for you the kindness of your youth... when you followed Me in the wilderness," and others stand in their merit, as stated in the aforementioned Gemara, for their merit is very great, since they stood firm in the trial against the terrible onslaught, and it will be explained further at length, G-d willing.
summary: The passage discusses the significant spiritual elevation and rectification achieved by certain individuals, which in turn led to intense challenges from external forces and the evil inclination. Their steadfastness in faith amidst these trials is remembered by God, as reflected in the biblical verse about recalling the kindness of their youth. The text emphasizes that their merit is profound, as they successfully faced overwhelming temptations, and this merit continues to benefit future generations. Further elaboration on these themes is promised in the continuation of the discussion.

passage_content: אולם עוד דברים בגו, ואפשר שנרמז בכוונת הכתוב לבאר לנו גודל מדריגתן של דור המדבר בעבודת השי"ת, עפ"י מ"ש בפרדר"א הנ"ל דכל אותו הדור ששמעו קולו של הקב"ה וכו' זכו להיות כמלאכי השרת ולא ראו טיפת קרי מימיהם, והנה מצינו בדור המבול שאמרו רז"ל שהי' חטאם בהשחתת זרע ר"ל, כמ"ש ברותחין קלקלו, וכן בער ואונן שחטאו בעון זה ר"ל, הכתוב אומר ושחת "ארצה", ובדור המבול כתיב כי השחית כל בשר את דרכו על "הארץ", והטעם שייחס הכתוב השחתה זו אל הארץ, בעבור שהזרע הקודש הולך לאיבוד לאשפתות למקום יניקת החיצונים ר"ל, ואפשר שירמוז כאן הכתוב לספר בשבח דור המדבר, שכל הדור ניצולו מן העון הנורא הזה, ולא נכשלו בה כל ימיהם. ואף שהי' התגברות הסתת היצר גדולה מאוד אצליהם לפי גודל מדריגתם כמו שיבואר להלן. וכמ"ש ז"ל (סוכה דף נ"ב ע"א) כל הגדול מחבירו יצרו גדול הימנו, אעפ"כ ניצולו כולם מחטא זה, וז"ש לכתך אחרי במדבר, שהלכו אחרי מצותיו ית' בארץ לא זרועה, ר"ל שכל הדור הקדוש ניצולו מחטא הנורא ההוא כדברי הפרדר"א הנ"ל והעיד הכתוב ע"ז שהיתה הארץ לא זרועה, ולא יצא הזרע למקום יניקת החיצונים ר"ל כ"א אל מקום הקדושה ואפשר שע"כ קראם הכתוב חסד נעוריך, שהקב"ה זוכר להם החסד והזכות הגדול של ימי נעוריהם, שהיו נקיים בלי שום פגם ועון, והי' כלו חסד וזכות, ויבואר עוד להלן.
translation: However, there are further matters to consider, and it is possible that the intent of the text is to clarify to us the greatness of the level of the generation of the desert in their service of the Holy One, Blessed be He, according to what is stated in the aforementioned Pirkei DeRabbi Eliezer, that the entire generation that heard the voice of the Holy One, Blessed be He, etc., merited to be like the ministering angels and did not see a drop of impurity in their days. And behold, we find in the generation of the Flood that our Sages said their sin was in the corruption of seed, as it is said, "they corrupted in boiling," and likewise with Er and Onan who sinned with this sin, as it is said, "and the earth was corrupt." And in the generation of the Flood, it is written, "for all flesh had corrupted its way upon the earth," and the reason the text attributes this corruption to the earth is because the holy seed was lost to the refuse, to the place of the nourishment of the external forces. And it is possible that the text hints here to speak in praise of the generation of the desert, that the entire generation was saved from this terrible sin and did not stumble in it all their days. And even though the temptation of the evil inclination was very great upon them due to their high level, as will be explained below, as our Sages said (Sukkah 52a), "the greater one is than his friend, his evil inclination is greater than him," nevertheless, they were all saved from this sin. And this is what is meant by "I led you through the wilderness," that they followed His commandments in a land not sown, meaning that the entire holy generation was saved from that terrible sin, as stated in the aforementioned Pirkei DeRabbi Eliezer, and the text bears witness to this that the land was not sown, and the seed did not go to the place of the nourishment of the external forces, but rather to the place of holiness. And it is possible that is why the text calls them "the kindness of your youth," for the Holy One, Blessed be He, remembers for them the great kindness and merit of their youth, that they were pure without any blemish or sin, and all was kindness and merit, and it will be further explained below.
summary: The passage highlights the spiritual elevation of the generation of the desert, emphasizing their unique connection to God, as they were likened to angels and remained free from sin, particularly the sin of sexual immorality. It contrasts their purity with the corruption seen in previous generations, such as the Flood, where the sanctity of procreation was violated. The text suggests that their adherence to God's commandments in the wilderness, a barren land, preserved them from moral decay, and God remembers their innocence and righteousness from their youth as a profound act of divine grace.

passage_content: ונקדים מ"ש דוד המע"ה נעים זמירות ישראל והכין ברוח קדשו תפלה זו לכל ישראל, (תהלים כ"ה) חטאות נעורי ופשעי אל תזכור כחסדך זכר לי אתה למען טובך ה', ולכאורה צ"ב הקישור ולמה תלה זכורת החסד, באי זכירת חטא ופשע, גם הול"ל חסדך זכר לי, ולמה אמר כחסדך, משמע דקאי אדלעיל מני', וצ"ב הכוונה בזה.
translation: And we will precede with what King David, may his memory be blessed, said, "The pleasant songs of Israel," and he prepared this prayer in his holy spirit for all of Israel, (Psalms 25) "Do not remember the sins of my youth and my transgressions; according to Your kindness, remember me for the sake of Your goodness, O Lord." And at first glance, the connection is puzzling, and why does he link the remembrance of kindness to the non-remembrance of sin and transgression? It could have simply said, "Your kindness, remember me," and why did he say "according to Your kindness"? It implies that it refers to what is above, and the intention in this is unclear.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author reflects on King David's prayer in Psalms 25, where he asks God not to remember his youthful sins and transgressions, but rather to remember him for the sake of God's kindness. The connection between God's kindness and the request to forget sins raises questions about the nature of divine mercy and forgiveness. The phrase "according to Your kindness" suggests a deeper understanding of how God's attributes interact with human shortcomings, emphasizing the importance of divine grace in the process of repentance and redemption. This highlights a key Hasidic concept that God's love and mercy can transcend human failings, offering hope for spiritual renewal.

passage_content: ואפ"ל עפ"י מ"ש ז"ל במס' חגיגה (י"ב ע"א) אמר ר"ל כל העוסק תורה בלילה, הקב"ה מושך עליו חוט של חסד ביום, שנא' יומם יצוה ד' חסדו, ומה טעם משום דבלילה שירה עמי עכ"ד הגמרא, והנה כמו"כ חלילה להפך. אם נכשל ח"ו האדם במקרה לילה ר"ל, נבראים מזה מזיקין וקליפות שמקטרגים וממשיכין עליו את הדין ח"ו, אבל יש עצה ע"ז להשקיט מעליו שליטת הדין, דע"י לימוד תורה בלילה הקב"ה מושך עליו חוט של חסד, וממילא נמתקים הדינים מעליו, הגם שכתב הרמב"ם ז"ל, וכעין זה איתא בזוה"ק וכ"כ כל חכמי האמת, דהמצות שעושין בעודו מלוכלך בעונות טורפין אותו בפניו, ומוסיפין עוד כח בהטומאה ח"ו. (עיין בספר ויואל משה מאמר ב' סעיף מ"ז שהארכתי בזה). אמנם הבאתי שם מספה"ק דרך פקודיך ואגרא דכלה, שע"י תשובה וביטול בלב דרכו הרעה וקבלה על להבא, יקובל לרצון לפני השי"ת תורתו ותפלתו ויוסיף קדושה ע"י עסק התורה, ויאיר ד' עיניו וילמדהו דעת לתקן מידותיו ולשוב תשובה הגונה עיי"ש, ואפשר שזה תפלתינו ובקשתינו חטאות נעורי ופשעי אל תזכור, וכדי להשקיט מעלינו קטרוג הדין, ע"כ אנו מבקשים כחסדך זכר לי אתה למען טובך ד', שתמשוך עלינו חוט של חסד ע"י עסק התורה בלילה כמה שהבטחתני, ועי"ז יומתקו שליטת הדינים וממילא לא יזכרו ולא יפקדו חטאות נעורים: וא"ש הקישור דזכירת החסד הוא תיקון ועצה להעלמת הרושם והקטרוג של חטאות נעורים.
translation: And even though according to what is stated by our sages in Tractate Chagigah (12a), Rabbi Levi said: "Anyone who engages in Torah at night, the Holy One, blessed be He, draws upon him a thread of kindness by day," as it is said, "By day the Lord commands His kindness," and what is the reason? Because at night there is song among the angels, thus concludes the Gemara. And behold, similarly, God forbid, the opposite is true. If a person unfortunately stumbles at night, God forbid, from this are created harmful spirits and klipot that accuse and draw upon him judgment, God forbid. However, there is advice for this to calm the dominion of judgment, for through the study of Torah at night, the Holy One, blessed be He, draws upon him a thread of kindness, and consequently, the judgments are sweetened from him. Even though the Rambam wrote, and it is similarly stated in the Zohar, and so too all the sages of truth, that the commandments performed while one is still stained with sins are detrimental to him and add strength to the impurity, God forbid. (See in the book Vayole Moshe, Article 2, Section 47, where I elaborated on this). However, I brought there from the holy book Derech Pekudecha and Agra D'Kallah, that through repentance and the nullification in the heart of his evil ways and acceptance for the future, his Torah and prayer will be accepted favorably before the Holy One, blessed be He, and he will add holiness through the engagement in Torah, and the Lord will illuminate his eyes and teach him knowledge to rectify his character traits and to return with a proper repentance, as stated there. And perhaps this is our prayer and request: "Do not remember the sins of my youth and my transgressions," and in order to calm the accusations of judgment from upon us, therefore we ask, "According to Your kindness, remember me for Your goodness, O Lord," that You should draw upon us a thread of kindness through the engagement in Torah at night, as You have promised me, and thereby the dominion of judgments will be sweetened, and consequently, the sins of my youth will not be remembered or counted. And this explains the connection that the remembrance of kindness is a rectification and advice for the concealment of the impression and accusation of the sins of youth.
summary: The passage emphasizes the significance of studying Torah at night, which draws down a "thread of kindness" from God during the day, thereby mitigating harsh judgments. It warns that failing to engage in Torah study can lead to the emergence of harmful spiritual forces that exacerbate one's sins. However, through sincere repentance and commitment to improvement, one can still attain divine favor and transform their spiritual state. Ultimately, the text highlights the connection between remembering God's kindness and alleviating the consequences of past transgressions.

passage_content: ואפ"ל עוד עפימ"ש בספה"ק ארץ החיים (תהלים כ"ה) וז"ל יש במדרש שלע"ל יבא הקב"ה ליתן שכר ועונש, ויקטרגו המקטריגים על ישראל ויסדרו עונותיהם, ויאמר הקב"ה כי קטן יעקב ודל, וכל מה שהקטן עושה לא נחשב לו כי קטן הוא, ואח"כ כשיבא הקב"ה ליתן שכר לישראל, יאמר השטן ומה שכר תתן לישראל שהם קטנים בלתי שכל, ויאמר הקב"ה בני בכורי ישראל עכ"ד המדרש, ופי' בזה בספר הנ"ל מאמה"כ חטאות נעורי ופשעי אל תזכור, כי יש לימוד זכות עליהם לפניו ית' שמעשה נערות הם, וכל מה שהקטן עושה לא נחשב לו, אבל כחסדך זכר לי והטוב שעשיתי זכר לי, דלענין קיבול שכר לא תחשבינו לקטן ובבחינת נער, למען טובך ד' כי זו מידת טובך להתנהג עם ישראל לפנים משורת הדין עכת"ד ז"ל. ולכאורה ראוי להבין דברי המדרש הנ"ל, דהו' תרתי מילי דסתרי אהדדי וכמזכה שטרי לבי תרי, דממנ"פ אם הקב"ה מחשיב ישראל בבחי' נער וקטן. אין להם גם שכר בעבודתם, ואם לאו מגיע להם ח"ו גם עונש, ואיך יסתום בזה פי המקטרג, ואם אין הקב"ה שומע לטענותיו לא הו"ל להשיב כלל על דבריו. ואחרי שהשיב הקב"ה על טענותיו, א"כ צריך להשיב לו טענה הנשמעת ותשובה ניצחת, ואין בטענה זו לכאורה כדי לסתור את דבריו.
translation:
And even though it is said in the holy book "Eretz HaChaim" (Psalms 25) that there is in the Midrash that in the future, the Holy One, blessed be He, will come to give reward and punishment, and the accusers will accuse Israel and will arrange their sins, the Holy One, blessed be He, will say that Jacob is small and poor, and all that the small one does is not considered for him because he is small. And afterwards, when the Holy One, blessed be He, comes to give reward to Israel, the Satan will say, "What reward will You give to Israel who are small and without understanding?" And the Holy One, blessed be He, will say, "My firstborn sons are Israel," thus concludes the Midrash. And it is explained in the aforementioned book from the verse, "Do not remember the sins of my youth and my transgressions," for there is a merit for them before Him, blessed be He, that their actions are those of youth, and all that the small one does is not considered for him. But for the sake of Your kindness, remember me, and for the good that I have done, remember me, for regarding the acceptance of reward, do not consider me as small and in the category of youth, for the sake of Your goodness, O Lord, for this is the measure of Your goodness to deal with Israel beyond the letter of the law. Thus far the words of the sage. 

And at first glance, it is appropriate to understand the words of the aforementioned Midrash, for they are two statements that contradict each other, like a witness who contradicts himself. For if the Holy One, blessed be He, considers Israel in the category of youth and small, they have no reward for their service, and if not, they would, Heaven forbid, deserve punishment. How then can the accuser's mouth be stopped? And if the Holy One, blessed be He, does not listen to his claims, He should not have responded at all to his words. And after the Holy One, blessed be He, responded to his claims, then He must respond to him with a sound argument and a decisive answer, and this argument, at first glance, does not seem to refute his words.
summary: The passage discusses a Midrashic interpretation regarding God's judgment of Israel, emphasizing that despite their shortcomings, they are viewed as "small" or "youthful" in their actions, which diminishes the weight of their sins. God defends Israel against accusations by asserting their status as His "firstborn," highlighting His merciful nature and willingness to treat them favorably beyond strict justice. The text raises a theological tension about the implications of this defense, questioning how God can both acknowledge their immaturity and still reward them without undermining justice. Ultimately, it reflects the Hasidic belief in God's compassion and the idea that divine grace can transcend human failings.
