passage_content: ולפי"ז יובן מאמה"כ כי כאשר ראיתם את מצרים היום לא תוסיפו לראותם עוד עד עולם, ובתרגום כמא די חזיתון ית מצראי יומא דין וכו', ולכאורה מאי נפק"מ אם כמא דחזיתון או באופן אחר, ולמה תלה הכתוב האיסור בכאשר ראיתם את מצרים היום כקושיתנו לעיל, ולדברי הריטב"א א"ש, דתנאי הי' באיסור, ולא אסרה תורה אלא בבחינת היום, שכבר יצאו מהגלות ומוכנים ליכנס לארץ. ובאופן זה מוזהרים על לא תוסיפו לראותם, אבל בזמן גזירת הגלות גם מצרים שוה לשאר ארצות וע"כ כתבה תוה"ק כאשר ראיתם את מצרים היום, בבחי' זו שאתם בני חורין, וכ"כ התרגום כמא די חזיתון ית מצראי יומא דין לא תוסיפו לראותם וכו'.
translation: According to this, it will be understood from the verse that when you have seen Egypt today, you will not see them again forever. And in the translation, "as you have seen Egypt today," etc. At first glance, what difference does it make whether it is "as you have seen" or in another manner? And why does the verse tie the prohibition to "as you have seen Egypt today," as we questioned above? According to the words of the Ritva, it is clear that there was a condition in the prohibition, and the Torah only forbade it in the context of "today," since they had already left the exile and were prepared to enter the land. In this way, they are warned not to see them again, but at the time of the decree of exile, even Egypt is equal to other lands. Therefore, the Holy Torah wrote "as you have seen Egypt today," in the aspect that you are free men. And so the translation states, "as you have seen Egypt today, you will not see them again," etc.
summary: The passage discusses the biblical injunction against seeing Egypt again, emphasizing that this prohibition is contingent upon the Israelites' current state of freedom, as they are no longer in exile. It highlights that the Torah's command is relevant only in the context of their liberation, distinguishing their experience of Egypt as free individuals from their previous state of bondage. The text suggests that during the time of exile, Egypt was akin to other nations, but now, as they prepare to enter the Promised Land, they are warned not to return to their former oppressors. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the significance of freedom and the transformative nature of redemption in the Hasidic perspective.

passage_content: ולפי"ז לא יקשה קושית הבית יעקב על הזוה"ק, דכיון דכתיב עד עולם א"כ פירושו אפי' לאחר מיתתן, וא"כ קשה מה דכתיב וירא ישראל את מצרים מת על שפת הים, והרי כתיב לא תוסיפו לראותם עוד עד עולם, ולדברינו ולדברי הריטב"א ז"ל א"ש, דהכא ע"כ תנאי יש בדבר כאשר ראיתם את מצרים היום, דרק בבחי' זו אתם מוזהרים בלא תוסיפי לראותם עד עולם, ובזמן הגלות הותרה לשוב מצרים, א"כ הכא עכ"ח עד עולם לאו לרבויי אתי הכל, וא"ש דלא נאסרו לראותם רק בחייהם כמשה"כ כאשר ראיתם את מצרים היום דהיינו בחייהון, וכמ"ש המתרגם כמא די חזיתון, ובאופן זה אתם מוזהרין שלא לראותם עד עולם, אבל מתין חמו להון וא"ש דברי הזוה"ק.
translation: According to this, the question of the house of Jacob on the Zohar will not be difficult, for since it is written "forever," it means even after their death. Therefore, it is difficult what is written, "And Israel saw Egypt dead on the shore of the sea," and it is written, "You shall not see them again forever." According to our words and the words of the Ritva, it is understood well, for here there is indeed a condition in the matter: "As you have seen Egypt today," that only in this aspect are you warned not to see them again forever. And in the time of exile, it is permitted to return to Egypt. Thus, here, "forever" does not come to include everything. It is understood that they were not forbidden to see them only during their lifetime, as it is written, "As you have seen Egypt today," meaning in their lifetime, and as the translator says, "as you have seen." In this way, you are warned not to see them forever, but they die, and it is understood well the words of the Zohar.
summary: The passage discusses the interpretation of the phrase "until eternity" in relation to the Israelites' experience with Egypt, suggesting that this prohibition applies only during the lifetime of the Egyptians. It emphasizes that the warning against seeing Egypt again is conditional, as it pertains to their current state of existence. The text reconciles this with the Zohar by indicating that after death, the prohibition no longer applies, allowing for a return to Egypt in a different context. This reflects a deeper understanding of divine commandments and their temporal nature within the framework of Jewish thought.

passage_content: ועתה יבואר מאמה"כ פן ינחם העם בראותם מלחמה ושבו מצרימה, ואין הכוונה שירצו לשוב מצרימה ע"צ האיסור, דא"א שישובו נגד רצונו ית', ואצלו ית' אין נפק"מ למנוע אותם בין דרך קרוב או דרך רחוק אבל הכוונה דידע הקב"ה שינחם העם בראותם מלחמה, ורש"י פי' כגון מלחמת וירד עמלקי והכנעני האמור במרגלים, וחטאם יגרום עליהם גזירת הגלות, וכמ"ש ז"ל הם בכו בכי' של חנם ע"כ נקבע להם בכי' לדורות, ואפשר עוד דכוונת הכתוב במ"ש בראותם מלחמה, גם על מלחמת היצר והס"מ דהוא עמלק, ויתעורר להחטיאם במדבר בכמה נסיונות, ורוה"ק אומרת כן דינחם העם בראותם מלחמה, ויגרום מצבם גזירת הגלות וז"ש ושבו מצרימה, ולא כתיב לשוב מצרימה, אלא שישובו באמת למצרים ע"י גזירת הגלות, כמשאה"כ והשיבך ד' מצרים באניות, ומעתה יצטרכו ישראל לזכות של דור המדבר כמשאה"כ זכרתי לך חסד נעוריך לכתך אחרי במדבר, ובזכות זה יגאלם השי"ת אף אם לא יהיו ראוים, ע"כ הקדים השי"ת הרפואה למכה, ולא נחם אלקים דרך ארץ פלשתים כי קרוב הוא, ואם הי' נכנסים לא"י מיד בדרך הקרוב, ולא יעברו דרך המדבר לא יהי' להם זכות התורה, ולא היתה התורה נבללת בגופן כמ"ש לעיל, גם לא הי' להם כל הנסיונות והזכותים של לכתך אחרי במדבר בארץ לא זרועה, ולא הי' להם ח"ו מציאות להגאל בלי זכותם של דור המדבר, ע"כ ויסב אלקים את העם דרך המדבר, כדי שיהי' להם זכות וחסד של דור המדבר, וכמ"ש הכלי יקר עה"פ וחמושים עלו בנ"י מאמ"צ, דירמוז על זכות התורה שהיא הי' כלי זיינם של ישראל, גם ירמוז על ה' חומשי תורה, עכ"פ ע"י שהקיפם הקב"ה דרך המדבר הי' בידם זכות התורה, שהעמידו יסודות התורה, ואותו הדור הי' מקור התורה ומקור הקבלה לכל דורות ישראל כמ"ש לעיל, ועמדו בנסיון דלכתך אחרי במדבר, ויעמוד להם זכות זה להגאל לעת קץ.
translation: And now it will be explained from the Holy Scriptures, lest the people regret upon seeing war and return to Egypt. The intention is not that they would want to return to Egypt due to the prohibition, for it is impossible for them to return against His will. And with Him, there is no difference in preventing them whether by a near way or a far way. But the intention is that the Holy One, blessed be He, knew that the people would regret upon seeing war, and Rashi explained this as similar to the war of the Amalekite and the Canaanite mentioned in the spies. Their sin will cause upon them the decree of exile, and as our sages said, they cried an undeserved cry, therefore a cry was established for them for generations. It is also possible that the intention of the verse in saying "upon seeing war" refers also to the war of the evil inclination and the Satan, who is Amalek, and he will be stirred to cause them to sin in the desert with various trials. And the Holy Spirit says that the people will regret upon seeing war, and their situation will cause the decree of exile, and thus it is said, "and they will return to Egypt," and it is not written "to return to Egypt," but that they will truly return to Egypt through the decree of exile, as it is written, "and the Lord will return you to Egypt in ships." And from now on, Israel will need the merit of the generation of the desert, as it is written, "I remember for you the kindness of your youth, your following after Me in the wilderness," and by virtue of this, the Holy One, blessed be He, will redeem them even if they are not worthy. Therefore, the Holy One, blessed be He, preceded the remedy to the blow, and God did not lead the people by the way of the land of the Philistines, for it was near. And if they had entered the Land of Israel immediately by the near way, and had not passed through the desert, they would not have the merit of the Torah, and the Torah would not have been integrated within them, as mentioned above. They also would not have had all the trials and merits of "following after Me in the wilderness in a land not sown," and they would not have had, Heaven forbid, the reality to be redeemed without the merit of the generation of the desert. Therefore, God turned the people around by the way of the desert, so that they would have the merit and kindness of the generation of the desert. And as the Kli Yakar explains on the verse "and armed went up the children of Israel from the land of Egypt," it hints at the merit of the Torah, which was their weapon. It also hints at the five books of the Torah. In any case, by surrounding them through the desert, they had the merit of the Torah, which established the foundations of the Torah, and that generation was the source of the Torah and the source of the tradition for all generations of Israel, as mentioned above. They stood in the trial of "following after Me in the wilderness," and this merit will stand for them to be redeemed at the end of days.
summary: The passage discusses the concern that the Israelites might regret their journey when faced with war, leading them to desire a return to Egypt. It emphasizes that God, knowing their potential for regret, orchestrated their path through the desert to ensure they would gain merit through trials and the giving of the Torah. This merit, rooted in the experiences of the generation in the desert, is essential for their eventual redemption, highlighting the importance of spiritual growth and the foundational role of the Torah in their identity. Ultimately, the text illustrates the divine plan to provide the Israelites with the necessary spiritual tools to achieve redemption, even if they may not seem worthy at the time.

passage_content: ומ"ש הכתוב כי קרוב הוא כי אמר אלקים פן ינחם העם וגו', אינה סיבת הטעם דעל כי קרוב הוא ע"כ אמר אלקים, דא"כ למה כפל מילת כי תרי זמני, והול"ל כי קרוב הוא ואמר אלקים, גם אצלו ית' אין נפק"מ למנוע מדרך קרוב או רחוק, אבל הם ב' דברים נפרדים והא' משלים לחבירו, ור"ל ולא נחם אלקים וגו' כי קרוב הוא, ולא יהי' להם הזכות והחסד של דור המדבר, כי אמר אלקים פן ינחם העם וגו' ושבו מצרימה וידע השי"ת שיהי' עליהם גזירת הגלות ויצטרכו לזכות דור המדבר. ובאמת היתה לפניו ידיעה ברורה שעוד יהי' גזירת הגלות עליהם, והי' מוכן הגזירה שלא יכנסו לא"י בבחינת נורא עלילה כמ"ש לעיל וכדאיתא במדרש תנחומא, אלא שהכתוב אומר פן ינחם העם ע"צ הספק, דאם יאמר הכתוב ע"צ ודאי, שיתחרטו ולא יעמדו בנסיון אז יתבטל הבחירה מהם, כי הדיבור מכריח הבחירה, אבל ידע השי"ת שיהי' כן, וע"כ תיקן והקדים הרפואה לזה והכין להם זכות דור המדבר, ובזה יתבאר דברי הילקוט הנ"ל (בקושיא י"ג) כי קרוב הוא שנא' לבני ישראל עם קרובו וכו' עיי"ש, ואפ"ל לדרכנו דהנה דור המדבר נקראים חסידי כמו שדרשו ז"ל מהאי קרא דאספו לי חסידי כנ"ל, וביארנו לעיל דע"כ הסיבן הקב"ה דרך המדבר, כדי שיהי' זכותם של דור המדבר מגין על ישראל בגלותם, ובזכותם יתקרבו ישראל אל אביהם שבשמים, כמו שדרשו ז"ל דאחרים באים בזכותן לעוה"ב וכו' ובזה יתבאר קישור דברי הילקוט ולא נחם אלקים דרך ארץ פלשתים. אלא הקיפן דרך המדבר, והטעם כי קרוב הוא שנא' לבני ישראל עם קרובו, שעל ידם יתקרבו כל ישראל להיות עם קרובו של הקב"ה. ובזה נתבאר הענין וסרו כל הקושיות הנ"ל.
translation: And what the scripture says, "For it is close," because God said, "Lest the people regret..." is not the reason for the statement "For it is close." If that were the case, why does the word "for" appear twice? It could have simply said, "For it is close," and then "God said." Also, for Him, it does not matter whether the path is close or far, but these are two separate matters, and one complements the other. And it means, "And God did not regret..." because it is close, and they will not have the merit and grace of the generation of the wilderness, for God said, "Lest the people regret..." and return to Egypt, and the Holy One, blessed be He, knew that there would be a decree of exile upon them, and they would need the merit of the generation of the wilderness. And indeed, it was before Him a clear knowledge that there would still be a decree of exile upon them, and the decree was prepared that they would not enter the Land of Israel in a manner of "fearful accusation," as mentioned above and as stated in the Midrash Tanchuma, but the scripture says, "Lest the people regret" based on the doubt, for if the scripture were to say based on certainty that they would regret and not stand the test, then choice would be nullified for them, for speech compels choice. But the Holy One, blessed be He, knew that it would be so, and therefore He arranged and prepared the remedy for this and prepared for them the merit of the generation of the wilderness. And this will clarify the words of the aforementioned Yalkut (in question 13), "For it is close," which was said to the children of Israel, a people close to Him, etc., as mentioned there. And it can be said in our way that the generation of the wilderness is called "Hasidim," as our sages of blessed memory expounded from this verse, "Gather to Me My Hasidim," as mentioned above. And we explained earlier that the Holy One, blessed be He, led them through the wilderness so that the merit of the generation of the wilderness would protect Israel in their exile, and through their merit, Israel would draw closer to their Father in Heaven, as our sages of blessed memory expounded that others come in their merit to the World to Come, etc. And this will clarify the connection of the words of the Yalkut, "And God did not regret the way of the land of the Philistines." Rather, He surrounded them through the wilderness, and the reason is "For it is close," which was said to the children of Israel, a people close to Him, so that through them all Israel would draw closer to be a people close to the Holy One, blessed be He. And thus the matter is clarified, and all the aforementioned questions are resolved.
summary: The passage discusses the divine reasoning behind God's decision to lead the Israelites through the wilderness rather than directly to the Promised Land, emphasizing the importance of the merit of the generation of the desert. It highlights that God's foreknowledge of future events, including the impending exile, necessitated this path to ensure that the Israelites would have the spiritual merit of their ancestors to support them. The text underscores the concept of divine providence and the relationship between the people and God, suggesting that the hardships faced in the wilderness were ultimately for their spiritual benefit and closeness to the Divine.

passage_content: ועתה נבאר ענין ויבא עמלק והדקדוקים בענין שנפרטו לעיל, ונקדים מ"ש הבעלי תוס' וז"ל, תימה למה איחר להלחם עם ישראל עד עכשיו, ולא בא מיד בשעה שירדו למצרים שלא היו כ"א שבעים נפש, י"ל שא"ל הקב"ה לאברהם ועבדום וענו אותם, וכשמת אברהם אבינו ע"ה הוטל החוב על יצחק, וכשמת יצחק הוטל על יעקב ובניו ועשו ובניו, ואמר עמלק הרשע, אם אכרית את יעקב וזרעו יהי' החוב מוטל עלי, שהי' בן אליפז בן עשו לכך המתין עד שיצאו ממצרים שכבר נפרע החוב, ואז בא להלחם עמהן עכ"ד ז"ל, אולם עדיין קשה למה לא בא מיד בצאתן ממצרים ולמה המתין עד רפידים, ואמרו חז"ל במכילתא שפסע ד' מאות פרסה בכשפים עד שהגיע אצליהם, ולמה לא יצא מיד לקראתם ביציאתם ממצרים, והי' יכול להגיע עליהם בדרך הטבע במשך זמן קצר, ומדוע נתעורר בביאתו פתאום. גם יש להבין מ"ש ז"ל במכילתא שכל הביאות שבא עד הנה הי' במטמוניות, וביאה זו הי' בגלוי פנים, וראוי להבין הכונה היכן מצינו שבא במטמוניות.
translation: And now we will explain the matter of "And Amalek came," and the nuances regarding this matter that we detailed above. We will begin with what the Ba'alei Tosafot wrote, and they said: It is a wonder why he delayed to wage war against Israel until now, and did not come immediately when they descended to Egypt, when they were only seventy souls. It can be said that the Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Abraham, "And they will enslave them and oppress them," and when our father Abraham passed away, the obligation was placed upon Isaac, and when Isaac passed away, it was placed upon Jacob and his sons, and Esau and his sons. Amalek the wicked said, "If I destroy Jacob and his seed, the obligation will be placed upon me," for he was the son of Eliphaz, the son of Esau. Therefore, he waited until they left Egypt, when the obligation had already been fulfilled, and then he came to wage war against them, thus far their words. However, it is still difficult to understand why he did not come immediately upon their departure from Egypt and why he waited until Rephidim. The Sages said in the Mechilta that he walked four hundred parasangs through sorcery until he reached them. Why did he not go out immediately to meet them upon their departure from Egypt, when he could have reached them naturally in a short time? And why was he suddenly stirred to come? It is also necessary to understand what they said in the Mechilta, that all the arrivals he made until now were in secret, and this arrival was with revealed faces, and it is fitting to understand the meaning of where we find that he came in secret.
summary: The passage discusses the timing and nature of Amalek's attack on the Israelites after their exodus from Egypt, emphasizing that Amalek waited until the Israelites had fulfilled their spiritual obligations, which were seen as debts owed to God. It suggests that Amalek, being a descendant of Esau, believed that by destroying Jacob and his descendants, he could take on the burden of these obligations. The text also highlights the significance of Amalek's approach, noting that while previous encounters were hidden, this attack was open and direct, raising questions about the spiritual implications of such a confrontation.

passage_content: ונקדים מ"ש רש"י ז"ל ויבא עמלק סמך פרשה זו למקרא זה, לפי שאמרו ישראל היש ד' בקרבנו אם אין לפיכך נזדמן להם עמלק משל לאדם וכו' והקשו המזרחי והגו"א כי אין דרכו של רש"י לדרוש סמוכין כי אם בסמיכות שאין שם מקומו, כי שם ניתן לדרוש אבל כאן הרי זה מקומו, שהרי ברפידים הי' שנא' וילחם עם ישראל ברפידים, ובהכרח שתסמוך פרשה זו לזו להיות שניהם במקום א' ובזמן א' ואיך ניתן לדרוש סמיכות זו.
translation: And we will precede what Rashi, may his memory be blessed, said: "Amalek came close to this section of the Torah," because the Israelites said, "Is there a God in our midst or not?" Therefore, Amalek encountered them, like a parable of a person, etc. And the Mizrachi and the Gaon of Vilna questioned that it is not Rashi's way to interpret adjacent verses unless there is no place for it, for there it is appropriate to interpret. But here, this is indeed its place, as it is stated in Rephidim, "And he fought with Israel in Rephidim," and it is necessary for this section to be adjacent to that one, as they are both in the same place and at the same time. How can we interpret this adjacency?
summary: The passage discusses Rashi's interpretation of the connection between the attack of Amalek and the Israelites' questioning of God's presence among them. It highlights the theological insight that Amalek's assault serves as a response to Israel's doubt, illustrating the struggle between faith and despair. The text also addresses the challenge of interpreting this connection, emphasizing that the events are indeed linked in both time and place, which raises questions about the appropriateness of drawing such parallels. Ultimately, it reflects on the deeper spiritual implications of faith in the face of adversity.

passage_content: אמנם יבואר הענין, דהנה רפידים היתה הנסיעה האחרונה לפני ביאתם למדבר סיני לקבל את התורה, וע"כ הי' ההתגברות גדול מצד סטרא דעמלק דהוא הס"מ למונעם מזה, וכמ"ש בזוה"ק דב' מלחמות היו כאן, דמשרע"ה נלחם עם שרו של עמלק למעלה דהיינו הס"מ, ויהושע זמין גרמי' למלחמה דלמטה עם עמלק עיי"ש, ומקור המלחמה הי' עם הס"מ, והוא גרם להם מה שאמרו היש ד' בקרבנו אם אין ומה שרפו ידיהם מן התורה, והכין כל זה בתחבולותיו כדי שיוכל לבוא ולהלחם עמהם ע"י חיילותיו למטה, כי ידע כי זולת זה לא יוכל להלחם בהם כלל, ומעתה יבואר מ"ש במכילתא הנ"ל שכל הביאות שבא עד עכשיו הי' במטמונית, וביאה זו הי' בגלוי פנים ובא להלחם עמהם בגלוי. והכוונה על הס"מ, שכן דרכו תמיד שבא במטמוניות ומתחיל במחשבות דקות, מלובש בכמה מלבושים עד שלא ידעו כלל להשמר ממנו, וכמו"כ אירע לנו בעוה"ר בימינו אלה, שחבורת רשעים אשר שמו למטרתם עקירת התוה"ק והריסת הדת, התחילו מלאכתם כבר במטמוניות לפני מאה שנה בערך, והי' בהסתר ובמחשך מעשיהם בעצת הס"מ, שחשב מחשבות להדיח ח"ו את ישראל מאמונתם, והי' כ"כ מלובש ומעוטף בלבושים שונים ובשמות נרדפים, עד שלא ידעו רובא דעלמא להשמר ממנו, וכ"ז מתחבולות היצר שעשה הכנות ופעולות ומעשים רבים בסתר, עד שבא בגלוי פנים אל המלחמה הנוראה, ועכשיו נעשתה ע"י שליחיו הריסת הדת בגלוי לעיני השמש, ובעו"ה נחטפו על ידו רוב מנין ורוב בנין בית ישראל השם ירחם.
translation:
Indeed, the matter will be explained. Behold, Rephidim was the last journey before their arrival at Mount Sinai to receive the Torah, and therefore the struggle was great on the part of the side of Amalek, who is the Sitra Achra, to prevent them from this. As it is written in the Zohar, there were two wars here: Moshe Rabbeinu fought with the minister of Amalek above, which is the Sitra Achra, and Yehoshua was prepared to fight below with Amalek, as mentioned there. The source of the war was with the Sitra Achra, and he caused them to say, "Is the Lord among us or not?" and that their hands became weak from the Torah. He prepared all this with his cunning so that he could come and fight with them through his legions below, for he knew that without this he would not be able to fight them at all. 

From now on, it will be explained what is stated in the aforementioned Mekilta, that all the arrivals until now were in a hidden manner, and this arrival was with revealed faces and came to fight with them openly. The intention is towards the Sitra Achra, for it is always his way to come in hidden ways and to begin with subtle thoughts, clothed in various garments until they do not know at all to guard themselves against him. Likewise, it has happened to us, may God have mercy, in our days, that a group of wicked people who have set their goal to uproot the Holy Torah and destroy the religion began their work already in hidden ways about a hundred years ago, and it was in secrecy and darkness of their actions by the counsel of the Sitra Achra, who thought thoughts to lead Israel astray, God forbid. It was so clothed and wrapped in different garments and in synonymous names that most of the world did not know to guard themselves against him. And all this was from the cunning of the Yetzer, who made preparations and many actions in secret, until he came with revealed faces to the terrible war, and now the destruction of the religion has been done openly before the sun by his emissaries, and, alas, a large portion of the community and the majority of the building of the House of Israel have been taken by him, may God have mercy.
summary: The passage discusses the spiritual battle faced by the Israelites as they approached Mount Sinai to receive the Torah, highlighting the significant opposition from Amalek, symbolizing the forces of evil (the "sitra achra"). It emphasizes that this struggle is not only physical but also deeply rooted in spiritual warfare, where the adversary operates subtly and insidiously, often disguised to mislead the faithful. The text draws parallels to contemporary challenges, suggesting that similar hidden efforts to undermine faith have been at work for generations, culminating in overt attacks on religious observance. Ultimately, it underscores the importance of vigilance against these spiritual threats, which seek to lead the Jewish people away from their beliefs.

passage_content: וכמו"כ הי' אז בביאת עמלק שעד עכשיו הי' כל ביאתו במטמוניות, והתגנב בתוך לבבות בנ"י בהסתר ובלבושים, עד שהביאם למדריגה זו שאמרו היש ד' בקרבנו ורפו ידיהם מן התורה, ואז בא להלחם עמהם בגלוי עם חיילותיו, כי לא הי' לו שליטה עליהם רק ע"י שפגמו באמונה ורפו ידיהם מן התורה, ולכך המתין עמלק ולא בא עד עכשיו, ומקודם עשה הכנות בסתר והזמינם לידי כך. ומעתה א"ש הסמוכין שכתב רש"י ז"ל דבשביל שאמרו היש ד' בקרבנו ורפו ידיהם מן התורה ע"כ בא עמלק, ואע"ג דהכא מוכרח הסמוכין דכאן הי' מקומו כקושיתנו הנ"ל, אולם מזה עצמו נלמד הסמוכין, דמדוע הי' כאן מקומו וזמנו, ולמה לא בא מיד ביציאתם ממצרים, אלא לצד שהמתין עד שרפו ידיהם מן התורה ומן האמונה כנ"ל.
translation: And likewise, at the time of Amalek's arrival, until now, all his coming was in hidden ways, and he crept into the hearts of the Jewish people in secrecy and with disguises, until he brought them to such a level that they said, "Is there a God in our midst?" and their hands became weak from the Torah. Then he came to fight against them openly with his armies, for he had no control over them except through their blemishing of faith and their weakening of hands from the Torah. Therefore, Amalek waited and did not come until now, and beforehand he made preparations in secret and brought them to this state. From now on, it is clear why the verses that Rashi, may his memory be blessed, wrote indicate that because they said, "Is there a God in our midst?" and their hands became weak from the Torah, therefore Amalek came. And although here the connection is necessary, as we questioned above, nonetheless, from this alone we learn the connection, why his place and time were here, and why he did not come immediately upon their departure from Egypt, but rather because he waited until they weakened their hands from the Torah and from faith, as mentioned above.
summary: The passage discusses the insidious nature of Amalek's attacks on the Jewish people, emphasizing that Amalek's influence was initially hidden, infiltrating their hearts and leading them to doubt God's presence and weaken their commitment to the Torah. This spiritual decline prompted Amalek to reveal himself and confront the Israelites openly. The text highlights that Amalek waited for the moment when the Jews' faith and adherence to the Torah faltered, illustrating the connection between belief, spiritual strength, and the challenges faced by the community. Ultimately, it underscores the importance of maintaining faith and commitment to the Torah to withstand external threats.

passage_content: עוד אפ"ל ענין הנ"ל באופן אחר דהנה בין הערב רב היו גם עמלקים, וכמו שכתב בזוה"ק פ' בראשית (דף כ"ה ע"א) חמש מינין אינון בערב רב וא' מהם עמלקים, ועלייהו אתמר תמחה את זכר עמלק ומלחמה לד' בעמלק מדר דר עיי"ש, עוד איתא בזוה"ק בראשית (קס"ט) תמחה את זכר עמלק אילין בכורי מצרים ערב רב מעורבים בישראל עכ"ד, ובכל הדורות יש בינינו מן הערב רב הבאים ע"י גלגול בזרע ישראל, ויש שנשמותיהם משורש עמלק, ובאותו הדור מבואר בזוה"ק שהי' בהם מזרע עמלק ממש שנתגיירו ונכנסו עם הערב רב, והם שגרמו כל הצרות והכניסו בישראל חולשה באמונת השי"ת עד שאמרו היש ד' בקרבנו וגרמו שרפו ידיהם מן התורה, והם שעשו את העגל והמתאוננים והמתלוננים הכל הי' ע"י הערב רב ושורש עמלק אשר בקרבם.
translation: Another aspect of the aforementioned matter can be explained differently. Behold, among the mixed multitude (Erev Rav) were also Amalekites, as it is written in the Zohar, Parashat Bereishit (page 25a), that there are five kinds among the Erev Rav, and one of them is Amalek. Concerning them, it is said, "You shall blot out the memory of Amalek," and "It is a war for the Lord against Amalek from generation to generation," as stated there. Furthermore, it is written in the Zohar, Bereishit (69), "You shall blot out the memory of Amalek," referring to those firstborns of Egypt, the Erev Rav mixed among Israel. Thus, in all generations, there are among us those of the Erev Rav who come through reincarnation in the seed of Israel, and some of their souls are rooted in Amalek. In that generation, it is explained in the Zohar that there were those from the seed of Amalek who converted and joined the Erev Rav, and they caused all the troubles and brought weakness to the faith in the Holy One, Blessed be He, until they said, "Is the Lord in our midst?" and caused their hands to be weakened from the Torah. They were the ones who made the Golden Calf and the complainers; all of this was through the Erev Rav and the root of Amalek that was among them.
summary: The passage discusses the presence of Amalekites among the mixed multitude (Erev Rav) that joined the Israelites, as noted in the Zohar. It emphasizes that throughout generations, some souls from this mixed multitude, rooted in Amalek, have caused spiritual weakness and crises of faith among the Jewish people. These individuals are linked to significant transgressions, such as the sin of the Golden Calf and the complaints against God, highlighting the ongoing struggle against these negative influences within the community. The text underscores the importance of recognizing and combating these spiritual challenges to maintain faith in God.

passage_content: והנה מעולם הי' קשה לי דמצינו בחלוקת הארץ שנתחלקה א"י לשבטים לבד, כמ"ש לרב תרבו נחלתו וגו', ולא תסוב נחלה ממטה למטה וגו' ולא מצינו שניתנה חלק בארץ גם לערב רב, והם היו הרבה יותר מישראל, ואפוא הי' מקום נחלתם בא"י. אולם ראיתי באוהחה"ק פ' תשא שכתב וז"ל ונראה כי כל ערב רב שהיו אז בשעת העגל מתו בחרון אף, כי הסכים משה רבינו על כלותם, ולא בקש רחמים כ"א על ישראל עיי"ש, הגם שבזוה"ק משמע שהיו עוד מהערב רב גם אחר מעשה העגל, אולם נצטרך לומר דמתו אח"כ במ' שנה שהיו ישראל במדבר ולא באו לא"י, כי לא מצינו שהיו בין באי הארץ.
translation: And behold, it has always been difficult for me that we find in the division of the land that Eretz Yisrael was divided only among the tribes, as it is written, "To a great one you shall increase his inheritance," and "The inheritance shall not move from tribe to tribe," and we do not find that a portion of the land was given to the Erev Rav, who were much more numerous than Israel. So where would their inheritance be in Eretz Yisrael? However, I saw in the holy writings of Parashat Tisa that it is written, "And it seems that all the Erev Rav who were there at the time of the Golden Calf died in the wrath of Hashem, for Moshe Rabbeinu agreed to their destruction and did not ask for mercy except for Israel," as stated there. Although in the Zohar it seems that there were still some from the Erev Rav even after the incident of the Golden Calf, we must say that they died later during the forty years that Israel were in the desert and did not enter Eretz Yisrael, for we do not find that they were among those who entered the land.
summary: The passage discusses the absence of the mixed multitude (Erev Rav) in the division of the Land of Israel among the tribes, highlighting that they were not granted a portion despite their larger numbers. It suggests that the Erev Rav who participated in the sin of the Golden Calf perished in God's wrath, as Moses did not plead for their mercy, focusing solely on the Israelites. The text implies that any remaining Erev Rav died during the 40 years in the desert, reinforcing the idea that they did not enter the Promised Land. This reflects a theological perspective on divine justice and the consequences of sin within the context of the Jewish people’s journey.

passage_content: ונקדים עוד מ"ש האוהחה"ק בפ' תבא ויוציאנו ד' ממצרים ביד חזקה וגו' זו הצלת יצה"ר וכוחותיו המצירים אותנו, ביד החזקה זו התורה עיי"ש, ובזוה"ק אמרו מצרים זו מצר ים, ומבואר בדברינו כ"פ דמבלעדי נס היציאה, היתה עיקר הנס שהוציאנו השי"ת מכוחות וקליפות מצרים, והוציא טומאת מצרים מתוך לבבות בנ"י, ופירשתי בזה משה"כ לקחת לו גוי מקרב גוי עיי"ש, וכמו"כ אפ"ל דמ"ש הכתוב ושבו מצרימה, אין הכוונה שישובו בפועל למצרים, כי א"א שישובו נגד רצונו ית', אולם אפשר דכוונת הכתוב פן ינחם העם דהיינו הערב רב שנקראו עם. שהם יגרמו קלקול ויחטיאו את בנ"י בעגל ושאר חטאים, ושבו מצרימה ר"ל דעי"ז ישובו את בנ"י לטומאת מצרים, וכאשר כן הי' באמת. ובזה מתורץ דלכאורה לפי פשוטו הול"ל ושבו למצרים, ולמה כתוב ושבו מצרימה, ורש"י פי' בכ"מ דה' בסוף התיבה במקום ל' בתחילתה, וכאלו כתיב ושבו למצרים, אבל מ"מ טעמא בעי למה שינתה הכתוב לכתוב ה' במקום ל', ולדרכינו יתפרש שפיר כי אין הכוונה שישובו למצרים, אלא לבחינת מצרים, וז"ש ושבו מצרימה היינו פנימיות בחי' מצרים.
translation: And we will further precede what the holy Baal Shem Tov said in Parshat Ki Tavo, "And the Lord took us out of Egypt with a strong hand," etc. This refers to the salvation from the Yetzer Hara and its forces that oppress us, with this strong hand being the Torah, as explained there. And in the Zohar it is said that Egypt is the constriction of the sea, and it is clarified in our words that apart from the miracle of the exodus, the main miracle was that the Holy One, blessed be He, took us out from the forces and klipot of Egypt, and removed the impurity of Egypt from the hearts of the Children of Israel. I explained this in light of the verse "to take for Himself a nation from the midst of a nation," as well as it can be said that what the verse states, "and they shall return to Egypt," does not mean that they will actually return to Egypt, for it is impossible for them to return against His will, blessed be He. However, it is possible that the intention of the verse is that the mixed multitude, which is called a nation, will cause corruption and lead the Children of Israel to sin with the Golden Calf and other sins, and "they shall return to Egypt" means that through this they will bring the Children of Israel back to the impurity of Egypt, and indeed this was the case. And this resolves the question that seemingly according to the simple meaning it should have said "and they shall return to Egypt," and why does it say "and they shall return to Egypt"? Rashi explains in many places that the letter "He" at the end of the word is in place of the letter "Lamed" at the beginning, as if it were written "and they shall return to Egypt." Nevertheless, there is still a need for a reason why the verse changed to write "He" instead of "Lamed," and according to our approach it can be well explained that the intention is not that they will return to Egypt, but to the aspect of Egypt, and this is what is meant by "and they shall return to Egypt," referring to the inner aspect of Egypt.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of redemption from the spiritual and moral impurities represented by Egypt, emphasizing that God's strong hand symbolizes the Torah, which aids in overcoming the evil inclination and its forces. It interprets the term "Egypt" as a metaphor for spiritual constraints, suggesting that the true miracle of the Exodus was the removal of these negative influences from the hearts of the Jewish people. The text also warns against the potential for the mixed multitude (Erev Rav) to lead the Israelites back to spiritual degradation, indicating that "returning to Egypt" refers to a regression into the inner state of impurity rather than a physical return to the land.

passage_content: ונקדים עוד מ"ש הרמב"ן ז"ל בפ' וירא (עה"פ ונדעה אותם) כי משפט סדום הי' למעלת א"י, כי הוא מכלל נחלת ה', ואינה סובלת אנשי תועבות, וראה הקב"ה שיהי' לאות לבני מרי לישראל העתידים ליורשה, כאשר התרה בהן גפרית ומלח שרפה כל ארצה, כמהפכת סדום ועמורה וגו' כי יש באומות רעים וחטאים מאוד ולא עשה להם ככה, אבל למעלת א"י הי' כל זה, כי שם היכל ד' עכת"ד, ומעתה יבואר מאה"כ דאלו הלכו ישראל בדרך קרוב לא"י ולא נשתהו במדבר ארבעים שנה, הי' באים גם הערב רב עמהם לא"י, והיו עושים העגל בא"י בהיכל ד', והעיקר הוא השורש והתחלה, ובפעם הראשונה שקלקלו בעגל אלמלי הי' החטא בא"י הי' הפגם גדול מאוד, וע"כ הסיבם ד' במדבר מ' שנה עד אשר תמו ונכרתו ונשארו הערב רב במדבר כנ"ל.
translation: And we will further precede with what the Ramban, may his memory be blessed, said in Parashat Vayera (on the verse "and we will know them") that the judgment of Sodom was for the merit of the Land of Israel, for it is part of the inheritance of the Holy One, blessed be He, and it does not tolerate people of abominations. And the Holy One, blessed be He, saw that it would be a sign for the rebellious children of Israel who were destined to inherit it, as He warned them with sulfur and salt that burned all its land, like the overturning of Sodom and Gomorrah, etc. For among the nations there are wicked and very sinful people, and He did not do such to them, but for the merit of the Land of Israel was all this, for there is the Temple of the Holy One, blessed be He, as stated. And from now on it will be explained from the verse that if Israel had gone the way close to the Land of Israel and had not delayed in the desert for forty years, the mixed multitude would have also come with them to the Land of Israel, and they would have made the calf in the Land of Israel in the Temple of the Holy One, blessed be He. And the essence is the root and the beginning, and at the first time they corrupted with the calf, had the sin occurred in the Land of Israel, the blemish would have been very great. Therefore, the Holy One, blessed be He, caused them to wander in the desert for forty years until they were finished and cut off, and the mixed multitude remained in the desert as mentioned.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the land of Israel as a divine inheritance that cannot tolerate wickedness, as exemplified by the destruction of Sodom and Gomorrah. It emphasizes that had the Israelites entered the land sooner, the mixed multitude (erev rav) would have accompanied them and potentially led to greater sin, such as the sin of the Golden Calf occurring in the Holy Temple. The forty years of wandering in the desert served to purify the Israelites, ensuring that only the worthy would enter the land, thus preserving its sanctity. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of the importance of spiritual readiness and the unique holiness of the land of Israel.

passage_content: וז"ש הכתוב ויהי בשלח פרעה את העם, ששלח עמם הערב רב הנקראים עם, ומה"ט ולא נחם אלקים דרך ארץ פלשתים כי קרוב הוא, כי אמר אלקים פן ינחם העם וגו' ושבו מצרימה, שהערב רב יחטיאו אותם ויחזרו לטומאת מצרים, ואם יעשו זאת בא"י יהי' הפגם גדול מאוד, ע"כ ויסב אלקים את העם דרך המדבר וגו' וחמושים עלו בנ"י, כמשפרש"י שלא עלו אלא א' מחמושים ולפי פשוטו מזויינים, ואפשר דהכוונה על כח התורה שהוא כלי זיין להגין מפני היצה"ר, כמ"ש ז"ל עה"פ חגור חרבך על ירך, והכלי יקר פי' וחמושים רמז לחמשה חומשי תורה, ומעתה כח התורה יהי' מגין עליהם ממלחמת היצר. וכל הפגמים והתלונות והעגל שנעשה ע"י הערב רב הי' הכל במדבר, ולא הי' הפגם גדול כ"כ כאלו נעשתה בא"י.
translation: And this is what the verse means: "And it came to pass when Pharaoh sent the people," that he sent with them the mixed multitude, who are called a people. For this reason, God did not lead them by the way of the land of the Philistines, for it was near; for God said, "Lest the people change their minds when they see war and return to Egypt," because the mixed multitude would cause them to sin and they would return to the impurity of Egypt. And if they were to do this in the Land of Israel, the blemish would be very great. Therefore, God turned the people around by the way of the wilderness, and the children of Israel went up armed, as Rashi explains that they did not go up except one out of five armed, and according to the simple meaning, they were equipped. It is possible that the intention is regarding the strength of the Torah, which is a weapon to defend against the evil inclination, as our sages said on the verse "Gird your sword upon your thigh." The "Kli Yakar" explains that "armed" hints at the five books of the Torah, and from now on, the strength of the Torah will protect them from the war of the yetzer. All the blemishes, complaints, and the calf that were caused by the mixed multitude occurred in the wilderness, and the blemish was not as great as if it had happened in the Land of Israel.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the mixed multitude (erev rav) that accompanied the Israelites during their exodus from Egypt, suggesting that their presence posed a risk of leading the people back to idolatry and impurity. God chose to guide the Israelites through the wilderness to prevent them from encountering the temptations of the land of the Philistines, which could have resulted in a greater spiritual downfall. The reference to the Israelites being "armed" symbolizes the protective power of the Torah, which serves as a defense against the evil inclination. Ultimately, the text emphasizes that the spiritual failings and challenges faced in the wilderness were less severe than if they had occurred in the Holy Land.

passage_content: ולדרכינו יתבאר הכתוב הנני ממטיר לכם לחם מן השמים ויצא העם ולקטו דבר יום ביומו למען אנסנו הילך בתורתי אם לא ולכאורה מה הי' הנסיון בזה, בתת להם לחם מן השמים דבר יום ביומו, וזה הי' חסד גדול ולא נסיון, אולם יתבאר לפי דברי המכילתא הנ"ל דע"כ הקיפם הקב"ה במדבר ואכלו את המן ושתו מי באר כדי שיהי' התורה נבללת בגופן, דלא ניתנה תורה לדרוש אלא לאוכלי המן, ונתבאר בדברינו לעיל דהי' ההכרח כן שיהיו כל אותן הדור פנוים לעסק התורה, ויסודות התורה והקבלה בכל חלקי התורה נשלמה ע"י דור ההוא, ונתגלה להם כל טעמי תורה ופירושה וכל מה שתלמיד ותיק עתיד לחדש, ואח"כ מסרוה בקבלה מדור אל דור, וע"כ כל מה שניתוסף מדריגתם בתורה נתוספת התגברות היצה"ר עליהם, והיו נסיונות אותו הדור גדולים מאוד, וכמ"ש ז"ל (סוכה דף נ"ב ע"א) כל הגדול מחבירו יצרו גדול הימנו וכיו"ב אמרו ז"ל (שם) דיצה"ר מניח כל האומות ואינו מתגרה אלא בישראל ובתלמידי חכמים יותר מכולם.
translation: And according to our path, the verse will be clarified: "Behold, I am raining down bread from heaven for you," and the people went out and gathered a portion each day, in order to test them whether they would walk in My Torah or not. And seemingly, what was the test in this, by giving them bread from heaven, a portion each day? This was a great kindness and not a test. However, it will be clarified according to the words of the Mekilta mentioned above, that the Holy One, blessed be He, surrounded them in the desert, and they ate the manna and drank from the well, so that the Torah would be absorbed in their bodies, for the Torah was not given to be expounded except to those who ate the manna. And it has been explained in our words above that it was necessary for all those of that generation to be free to engage in the study of Torah, and the foundations of the Torah and the Kabbalah in all parts of the Torah were completed by that generation. They were revealed to them all the reasons for the Torah and its interpretations, and all that a seasoned student would later innovate, and afterwards they transmitted it in tradition from generation to generation. Therefore, all that was added to their level in Torah, the strength of the evil inclination was increased upon them, and the trials of that generation were very great, as our sages of blessed memory said (Sukkah 52a): "The greater one is than his friend, the greater his evil inclination is than him." And similarly, our sages of blessed memory said (there) that the evil inclination leaves all the nations and only provokes Israel, and among the Torah scholars more than all.
summary: The passage discusses the divine provision of manna in the desert as a means to test the Israelites' adherence to the Torah, emphasizing that the Torah was given specifically to those who consumed the manna. It highlights the necessity for the generation that received the Torah to be fully devoted to its study, as they were endowed with profound insights and teachings that would be passed down through generations. The text also notes that with increased spiritual elevation comes greater challenges from the yetzer hara (evil inclination), particularly for the Jewish people and scholars, indicating that spiritual growth invites significant trials.

passage_content: ופרשתי בזה דברי הגמ' במס' סוכה (נ"ב ע"א) לע"ל צדיקים נדמה להם היצה"ר כהר גבוה ורשעים נדמה להם כחוט השערה, הללו בוכין והללו בוכין, צדיקים בוכין ואומרים האיך יכולנו לכבוש הר גבו' כזה ורשעים בוכין ואומרים האיך לא יכולנו לכבוש את חוט השערה הזה וכו'. ולכאורה צ"ב דממנ"פ אם הוא כהר גדול איך נדמה לרשעים כחוט השערה, ואם הוא כחוט השערה איך ידמה לצדיקים כהר, ומאי נפק"מ בדמיון אם האמת אינו כן. אולם שניהם אמת, דאצל הרשעים אין עליהם התגברות היצר רק כחוט השערה, כי לא צריך יצה"ר להתגברות אחרי שהרשע שומע לו ואינו ממרה עצתו, אבל לצדיקים התגברות היצר גדול מאוד, ובאמת הוא כהר גדול ואלמלא הקב"ה עזרו אינו יכול לו (וכעין זה ראיתי בגאון יעקב על העין יעקב שכ"כ בשם חכמי ספרד).
translation: And I have explained here the words of the Gemara in Tractate Sukkah (N. B. 52a) regarding the future: the righteous perceive the evil inclination as a high mountain, while the wicked perceive it as a hair's breadth. These cry, and those cry; the righteous cry and say, "How could we conquer such a high mountain?" and the wicked cry and say, "How could we not conquer this hair's breadth?" And at first glance, it is difficult to understand: if it is like a great mountain, how can it appear to the wicked as a hair's breadth? And if it is like a hair's breadth, how can it appear to the righteous as a mountain? And what is the practical difference in this perception if the truth is not so? However, both are true: for the wicked, the evil inclination does not overpower them except as a hair's breadth, because the evil inclination does not need to overpower them once the wicked listens to it and does not rebel against its counsel. But for the righteous, the struggle against the evil inclination is very great, and indeed it is like a great mountain, and were it not for the Holy One, blessed be He, helping him, he would not be able to overcome it (and I have seen something similar in the Gaon Yaakov on the Ein Yaakov, who wrote this in the name of the sages of Spain).
summary: The passage discusses the differing perceptions of the yetzer hara (evil inclination) between the righteous and the wicked, as described in the Talmud. For the righteous, the yetzer hara appears as a great mountain, symbolizing the significant struggle they face in overcoming it, while for the wicked, it seems like a mere thread, indicating their lack of resistance. This duality highlights that the righteous experience a profound internal battle, requiring divine assistance, whereas the wicked do not perceive any substantial challenge, as they yield to their inclinations without resistance. Ultimately, both perspectives are true, reflecting the varying spiritual realities of individuals based on their moral choices.

passage_content: וזשה"כ שאמר הקב"ה הנני ממטיר לכם לחם מן השמים ויצאו העם ולקטו דבר יום ביומו כדי שיהיו פנוים לעסק התורה ויתגדל מעלתם מאוד, אבל תדעו שגם הנסיונות יתגדלו עד מאוד, וז"ש למען אנסנו הילך בתורתי אם לא, והסוף שעמדו דור המדבר בנסיונם, והי' מדריגתם גדולה מאוד כמשאה"כ זכרתי לך חסד נעוריך, חוץ מפגמים אחדים שנכשלו בהם ועשו אח"כ תשובה שלימה עליהם.
translation: And as it is written, the Holy One, blessed be He, said, "Here I am, raining down bread for you from the heavens," and the people went out and gathered it day by day so that they would be free to engage in the study of Torah and their stature would be greatly elevated. But know that the trials will also increase greatly, as it is said, "In order to test us, whether we will walk in My Torah or not." In the end, the generation of the wilderness stood firm in their trials, and their level was very great, as it is written, "I remember for you the kindness of your youth," aside from a few blemishes in which they stumbled and later repented completely for them.
summary: The passage discusses God's provision of manna from heaven to the Israelites, allowing them to focus on Torah study and elevate their spiritual status. It emphasizes that with divine blessings come increased challenges, as indicated by the trials they faced to test their adherence to God's teachings. Despite some failures, the generation in the desert ultimately achieved a high spiritual level, and their sincere repentance for their shortcomings is acknowledged.

passage_content: ועתה נבוא לביאור הכתוב כל המחלה אשר שמתי במצרים לא אשים עליך כי אני ד' רופאיך, ולכאורה א"כ רפואה ל"ל מאחר שלא ישימם עליך, עוד יל"ד דלמה אמר הכתוב כל המחלה אשר שמתי במצרים הו"ל לשלול כל המחלות, דגם אלו אשר לא היו במצרים לא אשימם עליך, ואם כל המחלות נכללו במכות מצרים. הול"ל כל המחלה לא אשים עליך והכל בכלל, אולם יובן עפ"י מ"ד בירושלמי דמס' שבת (פי"ד ה"ג) והסיר ד' ממך כל חולי א"ר אבון זה יצה"ר דראשו מתוק וסופו מר ע"כ. והנה מחלה זו מצוי בישראל יותר, כמ"ש ז"ל במס' סוכה (נ"ב) שמניח יצה"ר את כל האומות ואינו מתגרה אלא בישראל, וזה רצונו ית' כדי להגדיל שכרן אם יזכו לנצח אותו. ובחי' מחלה זו לא הי' במצרים, וזשה"כ כל המחלה אשר שמתי במצרים לא אשים עליך, אבל יש בחי' מחלה שלא שמתי במצרים ואשימם עליך, ואין זה נכלל בכל המחלה אשר שמתי במצרים, ע"ז באה ההבטחה כי אני ד' רופאיך ממחלה זו, כמ"ש ז"ל (קידושין דף ל' ע"ב) אלמלא הקב"ה עזרו לא יכול לו, וכשרוצים להתדבק בדרכיו ית' הקב"ה עוזר ומושיע ומעלה ארוכה למחלה זו, וזהו קישור הכתוב אם שמוע תשמע לקול ד' אלקיך וגו' והאזנת למצותיו ושמרת כל חקיו, אז תנצל מכל המחלות, דכל המחלה אשר שמתי במצרים לא אשים עליך, ומן המחלה השכיח בישראל יותר מכל האומות אני ד' רופאיך.
translation:
And now we will explain the verse: "All the sickness that I placed in Egypt I will not place upon you, for I am the Lord your Healer." At first glance, it seems that if He will not place them upon you, then there is no need for healing. Furthermore, one might ask why the verse states "all the sickness that I placed in Egypt"—it should have excluded all sicknesses, including those that were not in Egypt, saying that I will not place them upon you. If all sicknesses were included in the plagues of Egypt, it should have simply stated, "I will not place any sickness upon you," and that would encompass everything. However, this can be understood according to what is said in the Jerusalem Talmud in Tractate Shabbat (Chapter 14, Halacha 3): "And the Lord will remove from you all sickness." Rabbi Avun said this refers to the evil inclination, whose beginning is sweet and whose end is bitter. 

Now, this sickness is more prevalent among Israel, as our sages say in Tractate Sukkah (52b) that the evil inclination leaves all the nations and only provokes Israel. This is His will, blessed be He, in order to increase their reward if they merit to overcome it. And this type of sickness was not present in Egypt, which is why it says, "All the sickness that I placed in Egypt I will not place upon you." However, there is a type of sickness that I did not place in Egypt, and I will place it upon you, and this is not included in "all the sickness that I placed in Egypt." For this, the promise comes: "For I am the Lord your Healer" from this sickness, as our sages say (Kiddushin 30b) that if the Holy One, blessed be He, does not help him, he cannot overcome it. And when one wishes to cling to His ways, the Holy One, blessed be He, helps and saves and provides a remedy for this sickness. 

And this is the connection to the verse: "If you will diligently listen to the voice of the Lord your God... and give ear to His commandments and keep all His statutes, then I will put none of the diseases upon you, which I brought upon the Egyptians; for I am the Lord your Healer." Thus, you will be saved from all sicknesses, for "all the sickness that I placed in Egypt I will not place upon you," and from the sickness that is more common among Israel than among all the nations, "I am the Lord your Healer."
summary: The passage discusses the promise of divine healing, emphasizing that God will not impose upon Israel the diseases that afflicted Egypt, which symbolizes a higher spiritual state. It highlights the unique struggle of the Jewish people against the yetzer hara (evil inclination), which is more prevalent among them than other nations, thus increasing their potential reward for overcoming it. The text reassures that while certain spiritual ailments may exist, God, as their healer, provides assistance to those who strive to adhere to His commandments. Ultimately, the connection between obedience to God's voice and the promise of protection from illness is underscored.

passage_content: ולדרכנו יבואר המדרש הנ"ל דמשה צווח ווי שלא יכנס לארץ, ואפשר לדרכינו מפני שהשיג עכשיו בדיבורו של הקב"ה פן ינחם העם וכו' ושבו מצרימה שנרמז בזה גזירת הגלות, כי א"א שישובו מצרימה אלא ע"י גזירת הגלות כמ"ש והשיבך ד' מצרים באניות, גם הטעם שהסיבן הקב"ה דרך המדבר הי' לטעם החורבן והגלות, כדי שיזכור להם הקב"ה זכות דור המדבר וחסד נעוריך ובזכות זה יגאלו לימות המשיח, מזה ידע משרע"ה שלא יכניסם לארץ ישראל, כמ"ש ז"ל דאלמלא נכנס משרע"ה לא"י לא הי' נחרב ביהמ"ק ולא היתה אומה ולשון שולטת בישראל, והגם שלא נגזרה גזרה עדיין. אבל מציווי השי"ת אל ישראל התבונן אל הגזירה המוכנת עליו שלא יכנס לארץ וע"כ צוח וויי.
translation: And according to our path, the aforementioned Midrash will be explained that Moses cried out "Woe" that he would not enter the Land, and it is possible according to our understanding that he realized now from the words of the Holy One, Blessed be He, "lest the people regret" etc., and that they would return to Egypt, which hints at the decree of exile, for it is impossible for them to return to Egypt except through the decree of exile, as it is said, "And the Lord will bring you back to Egypt in ships." Also, the reason that the Holy One, Blessed be He, led them through the desert was for the reason of destruction and exile, so that the Holy One, Blessed be He, would remember for them the merit of the generation of the desert and the kindness of your youth, and by virtue of this, they will be redeemed in the days of the Messiah. From this, Moses knew that he would not bring them into the Land of Israel, as our sages have said that had Moses entered the Land of Israel, the Holy Temple would not have been destroyed, and no nation or language would have ruled over Israel. And although a decree had not yet been issued, from the command of the Blessed One to Israel, he contemplated the decree prepared against him that he would not enter the Land, and therefore he cried "Woe."
summary: The passage discusses Moses' lamentation over not entering the Promised Land, interpreting it through a Hasidic lens that connects his realization to the impending exile of the Jewish people. It suggests that the journey through the desert was divinely orchestrated to remind the people of God's past kindness and the merits of the generation that left Egypt, which would ultimately lead to their redemption in the Messianic era. passage_content: ויבואר ג"כ המדרש הנ"ל ויהי בשלח פרעה וגו' מי צווח ווי פרעה צווח ווי, בהקדם מ"ש האוהחה"ק (פ' שמות) עה"פ ואת צעקתם שמעתי מפני נגשיו, דלכאורה הול"ל ואת צעקתם מפני נגשיו שמעתי, דהצעקה הי' מפני נגשיו ולא השמיעה. ותירץ דלישראל עדיין לא נשלם זמן הגלות, אלא מפני שנתמלא סאתם של מצרים ליפרע מהם, שהרעו ונגשו את ישראל יותר מהמדה, וע"כ רשעת הגוים גרם שנגאלו ישראל לפני הזמן, ואלולא רשעתם של הנוגשים לא היו ישראל ראוים עדיין להגאל, וז"ש ואת צעקתם שמעתי מפני נגשיו עיי"ש, ואפשר שזה המכוון בדברי המדרש ויהי בשלח פרעה את העם ולא נחם אלקים וגו' ושבו מצרימה, ומזה שפט פרעה כי עוד יבואו ישראל בשאר גליות, כי א"א שיתקיים ושבו מצרים אלא ע"י הגלות כנ"ל והבין מזה כי עדיין לא נשלמה זמן שעבודם במצרים ויושלם בשאר גליות, וע"כ התחרט על שהי' נוגש בהם יותר מדאי, וגרם בזה שיגאלו לפני השלמת זמן שעבודם, וזה שאה"כ ויהפך לבב פרעה וגו' ויאמרו מה זאת עשינו ר"ל בנגישה יותר מדאי, ובזה גרמנו כי שלחנו את ישראל מעבדנו, כי לולי כן לא היו ישראל ראוים עדיין שיגאלו, וא"ש מ"ש במדרש פרעה צווח ווי, אע"פ דשמחו מצרים בצאתם, אבל עכשיו שראו דעדיין לא נשלם זמן הגלות, ע"כ התחרטו על מה שגרמו במעשיהם וע"י אכזריותם שיגאלו לפני הזמן, וע"כ דרשוהו חז"ל כאן בפ' ויהי בשלח ולא דרשו כן לעיל בפ' בא בעיקר סיפור היציאה ממצרים, דשם לא צווח פרעה ווי, ואדרבה שמחו מצרים בצאתם כי נפל פחדם עליהם. אבל כאן נתעורר להתחרט, מפני שראה שלא נשלם גלותם עדיין, והוא סייע ליציאתם ע"י מעשיו כנ"ל.
translation:
And the aforementioned Midrash is also explained: "And it was when Pharaoh sent out the people..." Who cried out? Woe to Pharaoh! Woe! This is preceded by what is stated in the holy Torah (Parashat Shemot) regarding the verse "And I have heard their cry because of their taskmasters." It could have simply said, "And I have heard their cry because of their taskmasters," for the cry was because of their taskmasters and not the other way around. It is explained that for Israel, the time of their exile had not yet been completed, but because the measure of the Egyptians was filled to punish them, they oppressed and tormented Israel beyond measure. Therefore, the wickedness of the nations caused that Israel was redeemed before the time. Had it not been for the wickedness of the taskmasters, Israel would not have been worthy of redemption yet. This is what is meant by "And I have heard their cry because of their taskmasters," as explained there. 

And it is possible that this is what is intended in the words of the Midrash: "And it was when Pharaoh sent out the people, and God did not lead them..." and they returned to Egypt. From this, Pharaoh judged that Israel would still come in other exiles, for it is impossible that "and they returned to Egypt" would be fulfilled except through exile, as mentioned. He understood from this that the time of their servitude in Egypt was not yet completed and would be completed in other exiles. Therefore, he regretted that he had oppressed them too much, causing them to be redeemed before the completion of the time of their servitude. This is what is meant by "And God hardened Pharaoh's heart..." and they said, "What is this we have done?" meaning by oppressing them too much, and in this we caused that we sent Israel away from our service, for had it not been so, Israel would not have been worthy of redemption yet. 

And this explains what is stated in the Midrash: "Pharaoh cried out, Woe!" Even though the Egyptians rejoiced at their departure, now that they saw that the time of their exile was still not completed, they regretted what they caused by their actions and through their cruelty that they would be redeemed before the time. Therefore, our Sages sought this here in Parashat "And it was when Pharaoh sent out" and did not seek it earlier in Parashat "Bo," which primarily tells the story of the exodus from Egypt, for there Pharaoh did not cry out "Woe!" On the contrary, the Egyptians rejoiced at their departure because their fear had fallen upon them. But here he was stirred to regret, because he saw that their exile was still not completed, and he aided their departure through his actions, as mentioned.
summary: The passage discusses the concept that the Israelites were not yet deserving of redemption from Egypt, as their time of servitude had not been completed. However, the excessive cruelty of the Egyptians led to an early redemption, as their wickedness filled the measure of iniquity. Pharaoh's regret, expressed through his cries, reflects an understanding that his actions inadvertently facilitated the Israelites' liberation before their appointed time. This highlights the theological idea that divine timing and human actions are intricately connected in the unfolding of redemption.

passage_content: ואפ"ל עוד באופן אחר בהקדם מ"ד במד"ר (פר' כ"ג סי"ב) אז ישיר משה וגו' משל לאשה שהיתה נדה, השלימה ימי נידתה וטבלה, א"ל בעלה מי מעיד עליך שטהרת, אמרת לו הרי שפחתי מעידה שטהרתי לפני' וטבלתי, לכך נאמר את השירה הזאת נאים אנו לומר שירה לפניך שאין בנו טומאה, והרי המילה העידה עלינו שאנו טהורים לכך נאמר את השירה הזאת ואין זאת אלא מילה שנא' זאת בריתי אשר תשמרו ע"כ. וראוי להבין דאין המשל דומה לנמשל דשם שפחתה מעידה עלי' שטבלה לפני' וטיהרה מטומאתה, אבל איך יהי' המילה עדות שישראל טהורים הן, ומה צד עדות יש בה.
translation: And even if we explain it in another way, as is brought in Midrash (Parashat Ki Tisa, Section 12), "Then Moses sang..."—this is comparable to a woman who was in a state of nida, completed her days of nida, and immersed. Her husband said to her, "Who can testify that you have become pure?" She replied, "Behold, my maidservant testifies that I have purified myself before her and immersed." Therefore, it is said that we sing this song, for we are worthy to sing a song before You, as there is no impurity among us, and behold, the circumcision testifies about us that we are pure. Thus, it is said that we sing this song, and this is nothing other than the circumcision, as it is said, "This is My covenant that you shall keep." It is fitting to understand that the parable is not similar to the interpretation, for there the maidservant testifies about her that she immersed before her and purified herself from her impurity. But how can the circumcision be a testimony that the Jewish people are pure? And what aspect of testimony is there in it?
summary: The passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel draws a parallel between the purification of a woman after her menstrual period and the spiritual purity of the Jewish people, as expressed through the act of circumcision. It emphasizes that just as a servant can testify to a woman's purification, the act of circumcision serves as a testimony to the inherent purity of the Jewish people. The text invites reflection on the deeper significance of this testimony, suggesting that the covenant symbolized by circumcision affirms the spiritual status of Israel as pure and connected to God. Ultimately, it highlights the importance of the covenant in establishing the identity and sanctity of the Jewish people.

passage_content: ויובן עפ"י דברינו (בפ' ויגש עמוד תי"ב) עה"פ והנה עיניכם הרואות פרש"י שאני אחיכם שאני מהול ככם, והקשה הרמב"ן והגו"א ומה ראי' הוא זו, ואפשר שיהי' ערבי מהול או מבני קטורה, ופירשנו עפ"י מ"ש בזוה"ק דהנוטר בריתו שריא עלי' שם שי"ן דל"ת יו"ד: והפוגם בריתו ח"ו שריא עלי' ס"מ, ע"כ במה שהראה להם המילה ראו שהוא צדיק אמת עיי"ש, וכמו"כ ישראל במצרים שאמרו בזוה"ק דאסתמרו מנדה ובת אל נכר והיו שמורים מעריות, וחלק גדול היו נוטרי ברית, וע"כ היתה המילה עדות שהם טהורים, דהי' שם הקדוש שורה עליהם, וא"ש מ"ש במדרש אין זאת אלא המילה, והרי המילה מעידה עלינו שאנו טהורים.
translation: And it is understood according to our words (in Parashat Vayigash, page 12) on the verse "And behold, your eyes see," Rashi explains that I am your brother, I am circumcised like you. And the Ramban and the Gaon of Vilna questioned, what proof is this? And it is possible that an Arab is circumcised or from the children of Keturah. We explained according to what is said in the Zohar that the one who guards his covenant has the Shechinah resting upon him, as indicated by the letters Shin, Dalet, and Yud. And one who damages his covenant, Heaven forbid, has the Sitra Achra resting upon him. Therefore, in what he showed them, the circumcision, they saw that he is a true righteous person, as mentioned there. Likewise, Israel in Egypt, who are said in the Zohar to have been guarded from impurity and the daughters of foreigners, and many of them were guardians of the covenant. Therefore, the circumcision was a testimony that they are pure, for the Holy One was present among them. And it is clear what is stated in the Midrash, "This is none other than the circumcision," for indeed the circumcision testifies about us that we are pure.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of circumcision as a testament to purity and righteousness among the Jewish people. It references the Zohar, emphasizing that those who uphold the covenant of circumcision are under divine protection, while those who violate it are associated with negative spiritual forces. The text highlights that the act of circumcision serves as a clear sign of the Jewish people's sanctity, particularly in the context of their historical experiences, such as in Egypt. Ultimately, it asserts that circumcision is a powerful symbol of spiritual integrity and divine presence among the Jewish people.

passage_content: ואפשר שזה הפשט בפסוק והי' כי תמצאן אותו רעות רבות וצרות וענתה השירה הזאת לפניו לעד, ר"ל שיתרעמו ישראל על הצרות הבאות עליהם, יהי' הברית מילה עדות עליהם אם הם טהורים ואין זאת אלא המילה כמ"ש במדרש הנ"ל, ואיתא בזוה"ק פ' שמות (דף ט"ו ע"א) אמר הקב"ה דלמא ח"ו יתערבון ישראל בשאר עממין וכו' מה עבד קב"ה טלטל להו עד דנחתו למצרים, והמצריים היו מבזין אותם ולא רצו להתחתן בם, וחשיבו להון עבדים אנשים מאסו בהן ונשים מאסו בהן וכו', וכד נפקו נפקו זרעין קדישין דכתיב שבטי ד' עדות לישראל ע"כ, נמצא דזה הי' לטובתם וחסד מהשי"ת שמאסו בהם המצרים, כדי שלא יתערב זרע ישראל בעכו"ם ח"ו.
translation: And it is possible that this is the explanation of the verse "And it shall be when you find him many evils and troubles, that this song shall answer before Him forever," meaning that Israel will be stirred up over the troubles that come upon them. The covenant of circumcision will be a testimony for them if they are pure, and this is nothing other than the circumcision, as stated in the aforementioned Midrash. And it is written in the Zohar, Parashat Shemot (page 15a), that the Holy One, Blessed be He, said, "Perhaps, Heaven forbid, Israel will intermingle with other nations," etc. What did the Holy One do? He caused them to be tossed until they descended to Egypt, and the Egyptians despised them and did not want to marry them, considering them to be slaves; they rejected the men and rejected the women, etc. And when they left, they left behind holy seeds, as it is written, "The tribes of the Lord are a testimony for Israel." Therefore, it turns out that this was for their good and a kindness from the Holy One, Blessed be He, that the Egyptians rejected them, so that the seed of Israel would not intermingle with idolaters, Heaven forbid.
summary: The passage discusses the idea that the suffering of the Israelites in Egypt served a divine purpose, protecting their identity and purity as a people. It emphasizes that their covenant of circumcision stands as a testimony to their holiness amidst adversity. The text highlights God's intervention in ensuring that the Egyptians rejected intermarriage with the Israelites, thereby preserving the sanctity of the Jewish lineage. This is portrayed as an act of kindness from God, safeguarding the Israelites from potential assimilation with other nations.

passage_content: ואפשר שזה הפשט שהיו המצרים מתחרטים על שעזרו להם בשמירת הברית, ע"י שהתרחקו מהם ומאסו אותם, וע"י כן ניצולו ישראל ובזכות זה נגאלו כמ"ש במדרש, וז"ש ויהפך לבב פרעה ועבדיו ויאמרו מה "זאת" עשינו, ר"ל שגרמנו ע"י מעשינו שיש להם עדות המילה הנקראת זאת, כמ"ש זאת בריתי אשר תשמרו, ובזה גרמנו כי שלחנו את ישראל מעבדנו, ולא על עצם השחרור התחרטו כי היו מוכרחים ע"ז, אחרי שהוכו מכות גדולות, אבל התחרטו על שגרמו זאת במעשיהם ע"י שמאסו בהון. ובזה יובן מה שדרשו במדרש כאן דפרעה צווח ווי, דמתחלה בשעת יציאתן שמחו המצרים, כמ"ש שמח מצרים בצאתם כי נפל פחדם עליהם, אבל עתה ראה כי עדיין לא נשלמה זמן גלותם, ונגאלו רק ע"י זכות שמירת הברית, כמ"ש במדרש שזו א' מד' דברים שבזכותן נגאלו ישראל, והם גרמו זאת ע"י שהיו מרוחקים מהם, ועי"ז הי' להם כח לעמוד בנסיונות, והתחרט פרעה ע"ז וצווח ווי.
translation:
And it is possible that this is the explanation that the Egyptians were regretting having assisted them in keeping the covenant, by distancing themselves from them and rejecting them. And through this, Israel was saved, and because of this, they were redeemed, as it is stated in the Midrash. And this is what is meant by "And the heart of Pharaoh and his servants was turned," and they said, "What is this we have done?" meaning that we caused, through our actions, that they have the testimony of the covenant, which is called "this," as it is said, "This is My covenant which you shall keep." And through this, we caused that we sent Israel away from our service, and they did not regret the very act of liberation, for they were compelled to do so after they were struck with great plagues, but they regretted that they caused this through their actions by rejecting the wealth. 

And this explains what is taught in the Midrash here that Pharaoh cried "Woe," for initially at the time of their departure, the Egyptians rejoiced, as it is said, "Egypt was glad at their going out, for the fear of them had fallen upon them." But now he saw that the time of their exile was still not complete, and they were redeemed only through the merit of keeping the covenant, as it is stated in the Midrash that this is one of the four things through which Israel was redeemed, and they caused this by being distanced from them, and through this, they had the strength to withstand the trials, and Pharaoh regretted this and cried "Woe."
summary: The passage discusses the regret of the Egyptians for having distanced themselves from the Israelites, which ultimately led to the latter's redemption. It emphasizes that the Egyptians' actions, particularly their disdain for the Israelites, inadvertently contributed to the Israelites' strength in maintaining their covenant with God. This covenant, symbolized by circumcision, played a crucial role in their liberation, as highlighted in the Midrash. Pharaoh's lamentation reflects the realization that their oppression was not merely a physical act but had spiritual consequences that facilitated the Israelites' eventual freedom.

passage_content: והנה אמרו ז"ל במדרש ילקוט (רמז רמ"א) מנין לתחה"מ מן התורה שנא' אז ישיר שר לא נאמר אלא ישיר, וכן איתא בזוה"ק אז ישיר שר מבעי' ליה, אלא מלה דא תליא וכו' ולזמנא דא זמינין ישראל לשבחא שירתא דא, תנינן משה זמין למימר שירתא לזימנא דאתי, דכתיב כימי צאתך מאמ"צ אראנו נפלאות, אראנו כתיב למאן דחמו בקדמיתא יחמי לי' תנינות ע"כ, מבואר דמשרע"ה עתיד לומר שירה עם ישראל לע"ל, ואפשר דע"כ כתוב אז ישיר, דאז הוא לשון עבר וישיר לשון עתיד, לפי שמשרע"ה בשעה שאמר שירה הי' מדבק עצמו בבוי"ת, ואצלו ית' העבר וההו' והעתיד הכל ברגע א', וע"כ אמר מיד שירה בבחי' דלעתיד, וא"ש מ"ש כאן לשון עבר ועתיד, כי השתמש משרע"ה בב' הבחינות גם יחד, ואמרו חז"ל במס' סנהדרין (צ"ט ע"א) כי יום נקם בלבי ושנת גאולי באה, א"ר יוחנן ללבי גליתי לאבריי לא גליתי וכו' וחכמי אמת מפרשים דישנם נשמות צדיקים שהם בבחי' ליבא להם נתגלה סוד הגאולה, ואלו שהם בבחי' פומא לא נתגלה להם, ומשה רבינו השיג סוד הגאולה ובחינתו, וע"כ אמר שירה בבחי' הגאולה העתידה, אבל בחי' זו עלה בלבו, שהכניס עצמו לבחי' ליבא להשיג בחינת הגאולה, וזה שפרש"י אז כשראה הנס (השיג ג"כ בחי' הנס דלעתיד בעת הגאולה), ועלה בלבו שישיר שירה מיד, בבחינת גאולה העתידה, וז"ש במדרש מכאן לתחיית המתים מן התורה, דהשירה היתה גם אז בבחי' העתיד.
translation: And behold, our sages said in the Midrash Yalkut (Remez 251) from where do we know about the resurrection of the dead from the Torah, as it is said, "Then shall sing" — it does not say "shall sing" but "sang." And it is also stated in the Zohar, "Then shall sing" — it should have said, but rather this word is dependent, etc. And at that time, Israel is prepared to praise this song. We learn that Moses is prepared to recite the song for the time to come, as it is written, "As the days of your coming out of Egypt, I will show you wonders." "I will show" is written for those who were strong in the beginning; He will show them wonders. Therefore, it is clear that Moses will sing a song with Israel in the future, and it is possible that is why it is written "then shall sing," for "then" is in the past and "shall sing" is in the future, since at the time Moses recited the song, he was connecting himself to the future redemption. And for Him, blessed be He, the past, present, and future are all at one moment. Therefore, he immediately sang the song in the aspect of the future. And it is understood why it is written here in the language of past and future, for Moses used both aspects together. And our sages said in Tractate Sanhedrin (90a), "For the day of vengeance is in My heart, and the year of My redeemed has come." Rabbi Yochanan said, "To My heart I revealed, but to My limbs I did not reveal," etc. And the sages of truth explain that there are righteous souls that are in the aspect of the heart to whom the secret of redemption was revealed, while those who are in the aspect of the mouth were not revealed to. And Moses our teacher grasped the secret of redemption in his aspect, and therefore he sang the song in the aspect of the future redemption. But this aspect arose in his heart, as he entered into the aspect of the heart to grasp the aspect of redemption. And this is what Rashi explained: "Then, when he saw the miracle (he also grasped the aspect of the miracle of the future at the time of redemption)," and it arose in his heart that he should sing a song immediately, in the aspect of the future redemption. And this is what is said in the Midrash, from here to the resurrection of the dead from the Torah, that the song was also then in the aspect of the future.
summary: The passage discusses the connection between the song of Moses and the future redemption, emphasizing that Moses, in his song, transcended time by uniting past, present, and future. It highlights that the term "אז ישיר" (then he will sing) reflects both a historical event and a prophetic vision of future redemption, indicating that Moses was inspired by the ultimate redemption and the resurrection of the dead. The text suggests that certain righteous souls are privy to the secrets of redemption, while others are not, and Moses's understanding of the future redemption allowed him to sing in anticipation of it. Thus, the song serves as a bridge between the historical exodus and the eschatological hope of the Jewish people.

passage_content: עוד אפ"ל בביאור המדרשים והדקדוקים הנ"ל בהקדם מ"ד בילקוט (רמז רל"ג) והוא במכילתא ובתרגום יוב"ע, ד' כתות נעשו ישראל על הים, אחת אומרת נפול לים, וא' אומרת לחזור למצרים ואחת אומרת נעשה מלחמה כנגדן, וא' אומרת נצווח כנגדן, זו שאומרת נפול לים נאמר להם התיצבו וראו וגו' זו שאומרת נחזור למצרים נאמר להם כי כאשר ראיתם את מצרים היום לא תוסיפו לראותם וגו' וכו' עיי"ש. לכאורה קשה להבין מה היתה סברת אותן שאמרו נחזור למצרים, וכי לא סבלו די צרות ושעבוד ומאסר כ"ז היותם במצרים, ועכשיו שיצאו משם בנסי נסים מדוע רצו לחזור ומה ירויחו בזה. וכמו"כ אותן שאמרו נפול לים מה ירויחו בזה, וכן ראוי להבין סברת האומרים נצווח קדמיהון, מה יועילו בצווחה נגד חיל כבד וגדול וצ"ב.
translation: It can also be explained in the interpretation of the aforementioned midrashim and grammatical points, in advance of what is stated in the Yalkut (hint 243), which is in the Mechilta and in the Targum Yonatan ben Uziel: Four groups were formed by Israel at the sea; one said, "Let us fall into the sea," another said, "Let us return to Egypt," one said, "Let us wage war against them," and one said, "Let us cry out against them." To the one who said, "Let us fall into the sea," it was said, "Stand firm and see..." To the one who said, "Let us return to Egypt," it was said, "For as you have seen Egypt today, you shall never see them again..." etc. There, it is difficult to understand the reasoning of those who said, "Let us return to Egypt." Did they not suffer enough troubles, servitude, and imprisonment during their time in Egypt? Now that they have miraculously left, why would they want to return, and what would they gain from it? Similarly, those who said, "Let us fall into the sea," what would they gain from that? It is also appropriate to understand the reasoning of those who said, "Let us cry out against them," what benefit would there be in crying out against a heavy and large army? This requires further investigation.
summary: The passage discusses the various responses of the Israelites at the Red Sea, highlighting four distinct groups: those who wished to drown, those who wanted to return to Egypt, those who proposed to fight, and those who suggested crying out. It questions the rationale behind the desire to return to Egypt despite their suffering, as well as the motivations of those who wished to drown or cry out against a formidable enemy. This reflects a deeper exploration of despair, faith, and the human condition in the face of overwhelming challenges, emphasizing the struggle between fear and trust in divine intervention.

passage_content: ב) (הובא בישמח משה) ויאמר ד' מה תצעק אלי אמר הקב"ה למשה הים סוער והשונא רודף ואתה עומד ומרבה בתפלה לפני, אמר לו משה מה לי לעשות, אמר לו ואתה הרם את מטך, באותה שעה אמרו ישראל ד' ימלוך לעולם ועד, עכ"ד המדרש: והוא תמוה מאוד.
translation: (As brought in Yismach Moshe) And the Lord said, "Why do you cry out to Me?" The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Moses, "The sea is raging and the enemy is pursuing, and you stand and increase your prayers before Me." Moses replied, "What should I do?" He said to him, "And you lift up your staff." At that moment, Israel said, "The Lord shall reign forever and ever." Thus concludes the Midrash: and it is very puzzling.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the dialogue between God and Moses highlights the tension between prayer and action during a crisis. God instructs Moses to raise his staff instead of merely praying, emphasizing the importance of taking initiative in the face of adversity. The Israelites' declaration that "the Lord will reign forever" reflects their faith and trust in divine sovereignty, even amidst turmoil. This interaction illustrates a key Hasidic concept: the balance between spiritual devotion and practical response to challenges.
