passage_content: ובדרך אגב נל"פ דברי הגמ' במסכת מגילה (ז' ע"א) דאיכא שם הרבה ילפיתות דאסתר ברוה"ק נאמרה, ר' יוסי בן דורמסקית אומר אסתר ברוה"ק נאמרה שנאמר ובביזה לא שלחו את ידם, פרש"י האיך ידעו מה עשו הרחוקים אי לאו דברוה"ק נאמרה, אמר שמואל אי הואי התם הוה אמינא מלתא דעדיפא מכולהו שנא' קימו וקבלו וכו', אמר רבא לכולהו אית להו פירכא לבר מדשמואל דלית ליה פירכא וכו' והא דר' יוסי בן דורמסקית דלמא פריסתקי שדור פרש"י שלוחים שלחו להם למרדכי ואסתר שלא נגענו בביזה שלא ירע למלך, וא"כ אין ראי' מזה דברוה"ק נאמרה עכ"ד הגמ', ויל"ד מאי הי' ס"ד דגמ' מעיקרא לילף מהכא דברוה"ק נאמרה, הלא המגילה לא נכתבה מיד כ"א אחר זמן, כאמרז"ל שלחה אסתר לחכמים קבעוני לדורות ולא רצו עד שדרשו כתוב זאת זכרון בספר וכו' עיי"ש, וא"כ במשך הזמן אפשר שחקרו כל פרטי פרטיים וגם שלחו הרחוקים שלוחים כקושית הגמ', ומנ"ל דברוה"ק נאמרה.
translation: And incidentally, it seems to me that the words of the Gemara in Tractate Megillah (7a) indicate that there are many teachings that Esther was said with divine inspiration. Rabbi Yossi ben Dromaskit says that Esther was said with divine inspiration, as it is stated, "And they did not send their hand in the plunder." Rashi explains how did they know what the distant ones did if it was not said with divine inspiration. Shmuel said, if I were there, I would have said something greater than all of them, as it is stated, "They established and accepted," etc. Rava said that for all of them there is a refutation except for Shmuel, who has no refutation, etc. And regarding Rabbi Yossi ben Dromaskit, perhaps it is a matter of interpretation that Rashi explains that they sent messengers to Mordechai and Esther saying that we did not touch the plunder so that it would not be bad for the king. And if so, there is no proof from this that it was said with divine inspiration, thus concludes the Gemara. And it is to be wondered what was the initial thought of the Gemara to learn from here that it was said with divine inspiration, for the Megillah was not written immediately but rather after some time, as our sages said, Esther sent to the sages to establish it for generations, and they did not want to until they expounded, "Write this as a memorial in a book," etc. Therefore, over time, it is possible that they investigated all the details, and also the distant ones sent messengers as the Gemara questions, and from where do we know that it was said with divine inspiration.
summary: The passage discusses the Talmudic interpretation regarding the Book of Esther, particularly the notion that it was divinely inspired (ruach hakodesh). Rabbi Yossi ben Dromaskit argues that the phrase "and they did not send their hands to the plunder" indicates a divine revelation, as it suggests knowledge of distant events. The text raises questions about the timing of the Megillah's writing and the possibility that details were clarified over time, emphasizing the importance of divine guidance in understanding the events of Purim. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of the interplay between divine providence and human action in the unfolding of Jewish history.

passage_content: וק"ז הישמח משה זלה"ה (בפ' ואתחנן) ביאר דברי הגמ' הנ"ל בדרך נעים ונחמד וז"ל יש להבין מה הי' הכוונה בזה שלא שללו וכו' והנ"ל דיש בו ענין נסתר לבד הפשוט, דהנה יש להבין מ"ד בגמ' (גיטין נ"ז) מבני בניו של המן למדו תורה ברבים וא"כ מזה מוכרח שלא כלו זרע המן. וע"ז יש לתמוה שמהסברא הי' ראוי לראשונה לכלות זרע הצורר, אבל הענין יובן עפימ"ש ז"ל (שמו"ר פ"א סכ"ט) ויפן כה וכה וירא כי אין איש עתיד לצאת ממנו שיתגייר, ולכך באלו שהי' בהן ניצוצות הקדושה לא נגעו בהן. או שנשפע רוה"ק על כל ישראל וכו', ואנשי הכנה"ג כתבו המגילה וידעו זה ברוה"ק, והנה איתא בספרים על פסוק ושבתי אני וראיתי דמעת העשוקים, שהכוונה על ניצוצות הקדושה שנשבו בתוך הטומאה, ועפי"ז מדוקדק מאוד הלשון ובביזה במקום שיש ביזה לא שלחו את ידם. אמנם לפי"ז צ"ב פירכת הגמ' דלמא פרסתקי שדור, והוא ז"ל תירץ דהפירכא רק לפי הפשטיות שהוא הלבוש, משא"כ להפנימות, ולכך לא אמר אית להו תיובתא עייש"ד כי נעמו ועוד נבאר בזה לדרכנו.
translation: And so, Moshe, may his memory be blessed (in Parshat Va'etchanan), explained the words of the aforementioned Gemara in a pleasant and delightful manner, saying: One must understand what was the intention in this that they did not completely destroy... and the aforementioned indicates that there is a hidden aspect beyond the simple meaning. Behold, one can understand from the statement in the Gemara (Gittin 57) that from the descendants of Haman, they learned Torah in public, and therefore it is evident that not all of Haman's seed was exterminated. And to this, one might wonder that logically, it would have been appropriate to completely eradicate the seed of the oppressor, but the matter can be understood according to what is stated (Shemot Rabbah 1:69) that he looked this way and that and saw that no one would emerge from him who would convert, and therefore those who had within them sparks of holiness were not touched. Or perhaps the Holy Spirit was poured out upon all of Israel... and the men of the Great Assembly wrote the Megillah and knew this through the Holy Spirit. And it is stated in the books regarding the verse "And I returned and saw the tears of the oppressed," that the intention is regarding the sparks of holiness that were captured within the impurity. And according to this, the language is very precise, and in a place where there is plunder, they did not stretch out their hand. However, according to this, the question arises regarding the Gemara's challenge of perhaps they were Persians, and he, may his memory be blessed, answered that the challenge is only according to the superficiality, which is the garment, whereas in terms of the inner essence, therefore he did not say "there is a refutation to them," as it is pleasing, and we will further explain this in our way.
summary: The passage discusses the survival of certain descendants of Haman, suggesting that not all of his lineage was eradicated due to the presence of divine sparks of holiness within them. It emphasizes the idea that the Jewish people, through their spiritual sensitivity and the influence of the Holy Spirit, recognized these sparks and refrained from harming those who contained them. The text highlights the tension between the apparent destruction of evil and the deeper, hidden aspects of redemption and sanctity that persist even within darkness. Ultimately, it reflects on the complexity of divine providence and the interplay between external appearances and inner spiritual realities.

passage_content: ונל"פ אף לפי פשוטו דהכוונה על ביזה של כסף וזהב וכלים נחמדים, דהנה בני ישראל היו עסוקים לכלות שונאיהם ושונאי ד' זרע עמלק נוסף לזה היו צריכים להזהר שלא להרוג אותן שיש בהן ניצוצות הקדושה, כמ"ש ק"ז זלל"ה שנשפע רוה"ק על כל ישראל וידעו להזהר בזה, אמנם הנותן דעתו אל הביזה, לא ימלט שלא ינטה מן תכליתו, כי נעשה משוחד אל הרצון הזה, וכל מטרתו רק להשיג מן הביזה כל מה שאפשר, לז"א הכתוב והרוג בשונאיהם חמשה ושבעים אלף, ואל תחשוב שלא כוונו אל המערה להרוג הראויים ליהרג, ולהניח הראויים להמלט, לז"א ובביזה לא שלחו את ידם, שלא נגעו בביזה כלל, ואם אין משוחדים אל הביזה אז מגיעים אל האמת.
translation: And it can be said that even according to its simple meaning, the intention is regarding the plunder of silver, gold, and precious vessels. Behold, the children of Israel were occupied with annihilating their enemies and the enemies of God, the seed of Amalek. In addition to this, they needed to be careful not to kill those who contained sparks of holiness, as it is written in Zohar that the Holy Spirit was poured out upon all of Israel, and they knew to be cautious in this matter. However, one who focuses on the plunder will not escape from deviating from his purpose, for he becomes corrupted by this desire, and his entire aim is only to obtain from the plunder all that is possible. Therefore, the scripture says, "And they killed of their enemies five hundred seventy thousand," and do not think that they intended to the cave to kill those who were deserving of death and to spare those who were deserving of escape. Thus it is said, "And in the plunder they did not stretch out their hand," for they did not touch the plunder at all. And if they are not corrupted by the plunder, then they reach the truth.
summary: The passage discusses the importance of intention in the context of the Israelites' battle against their enemies, particularly the Amalekites. It emphasizes that while they were focused on defeating their foes, they needed to be cautious not to harm those who contained sparks of holiness. The text warns that an obsession with material gain, such as the spoils of war, can lead one away from their true purpose. Ultimately, it asserts that by avoiding greed and remaining true to their spiritual mission, they can achieve a deeper understanding of truth and holiness.

passage_content: אמנם לא יספיק מה שלא לקחו מן הביזה בפועל, דאף אם רק נותנים דעתם להשיג מן הביזה, א"א לכוון אל האמת, וכמו שאירע להרבה בנ"א שתעו מדרך האמת, בשביל שהיו מצפים להנאה המדומה ונשתחדו אל הרצון הזה, אף שלא הגיע אליהם ונסתיים בהבל וריק, אולם כותבי המגילה ידעו ברוה"ק שלא כוונו שום א' מישראל אל הביזה, ולא שלחו את ידם להרוג בשונאיהם לכוונת הביזה, ומזה למדו ז"ל דאסתר ברוה"ק נאמרה, ול"ק דחיית הגמ' דלמא פריסתקי שדור, ששלחו שלוחים להודיע למרדכי ואסתר שלא נגעו בביזה, דא"א לברר דבר זה על ידי שליח ואין אדם יודע מה שבלב חבירו ועכ"ח דברוה"ק נאמרה, ומה דדחו בגמ' דברי ר"י דדלמא פריסתקי שדור, היינו אלמלי לא הי' לנו ילפותא דשמואל דאסתר ברוה"ק נאמרה, היינו מפרשים ובביזה לא שלחו את ידם שלא לקחו בפועל, וא"כ אין ראי' דברוה"ק נאמרה, דדבר זה אפשר שהודיעו ע"י שלוחים כדחיית הגמ' דלמא פריסתקי שדור, אבל לפי המסקנא דאסתר ברוה"ק נאמרה, נרמז בכתוב גם שלא נתכוונו אל הביזה וע"כ ע"י רוה"ק דאל"ה מנא ידעי, וכמו"כ אפ"ל לדרך ק"ז הישמח משה זלה"ה, דבאמת לפי המסקנא שכבר נתברר לנו ממקו"א דאסתר ברוה"ק נאמרה, מסתבר שנרמז ג"ז בפסוק ובביזה לא שלחו את ידם, שלא נגעו להרוג במקום שיש ניצה"ק, ומה דדחי בגמ' דלמא פריסתקי שדור, היינו אלמלי לא הי' לנו ילפותא ממקו"א אין הכרח מכאן דברוה"ק נאמרה, דדלמא פי' הכתוב כפשוטו, וע"ז איכא דחויא דלמא פריסתקי שדור והבן.
translation: Indeed, it is not sufficient what they did not take from the spoils in practice, for even if they only set their minds to obtain from the spoils, it is impossible to aim for the truth. This is as happened to many people who strayed from the path of truth because they were expecting a false benefit and were drawn to this desire, even though it did not reach them and ended in vanity and emptiness. However, the authors of the scroll knew through the Holy Spirit that no one from Israel aimed for the spoils, nor did they extend their hands to kill their enemies with the intention of the spoils. From this, our sages learned that Esther was said with the Holy Spirit, and it is not difficult to understand the rejection of the Gemara that perhaps they were messengers of the generation who sent messengers to inform Mordechai and Esther that they did not touch the spoils. It is impossible to clarify this matter through a messenger, for no one knows what is in the heart of his friend, and thus it is said with the Holy Spirit. And what the Gemara rejects regarding the words of Rabbi Yochanan, that perhaps they were messengers of the generation, is that were it not for the teaching we have from other sources that Esther was said with the Holy Spirit, we would interpret that they did not send their hands to the spoils, that they did not take in practice. Therefore, there is no proof that it was said with the Holy Spirit, for this matter could have been communicated through messengers, as the Gemara's rejection suggests that perhaps they were messengers of the generation. But according to the conclusion that Esther was said with the Holy Spirit, it is hinted in the verse that they also did not intend for the spoils, and therefore through the Holy Spirit, for otherwise how would we know? Likewise, it can be said according to the way of the holy Rabbi Moshe, may his memory be blessed, that indeed according to the conclusion that has already been clarified to us from other sources that Esther was said with the Holy Spirit, it is reasonable that this is also hinted in the verse that they did not send their hands to the spoils, that they did not touch to kill where there was a spark of holiness. And what the Gemara rejects regarding perhaps they were messengers of the generation, is that were it not for the teaching we have from other sources, there is no necessity from here that it was said with the Holy Spirit, for perhaps the verse means simply, and to this there is a challenge that perhaps they were messengers of the generation, and understand.
summary: The passage emphasizes the importance of intention in actions, particularly regarding the spoils of war. It argues that true alignment with divine will cannot be achieved if one is motivated by material gain, as seen in the case of the Purim story where the Jewish people did not seek personal benefit from their victory. The text asserts that the spiritual essence of Esther's narrative reveals that the Israelites acted without the desire for plunder, highlighting a deeper understanding of their actions as guided by divine inspiration. Ultimately, it underscores the notion that genuine faith and intention are paramount in fulfilling one's spiritual obligations.

passage_content: היוצא לנו מזה דבמקום שיש עסק של ביזה צריך לסייעתא דשמיא מרובה שלא יכשל האדם וינטה מדרך האמת, כי השוחד יעוור עיני חכמים, וכבר פירשתי במאמר הנביא (ישעי' א') שמתאונן שם על מצב הדור בעת החורבן ואמר שריך סוררים וחברי גנבים כולו אוהב שוחד ורודף שלמונים וגו', דהנה ממ"ש כולו אוהב שוחד ולא אמר כולו לוקחי שוחד. משמע שלא הי' כללות הדור בזה הבחי' רעה לקבל שוחד: רק היו אוהבי שוחד, ולכאורה מאי גריעותא כ"כ אם רק אהבו את השוחד ונתגברו על יצרן ולא קבלו, ומדוע מונה אותו הנביא בין עבירות החמורות כ"כ, ויש מהקדמונים דס"ל דעדיף טפי מי שיש לו נטי' אל הרע ומתגבר עליו, שעושה לכבוד קונו, משא"כ מי שבטבעיותו מרוחק ממנה במה עובד את אדוניו, ומסייע להם מדברי רז"ל (תו"כ סו"פ קדושים) אל יאמר אדם אי אפשי בבשר חזיר וכו' והרמב"ם חולק עליהם, (עיין ישמח משה פ' ראה) אמנם שאני שוחד מכל עבירות שבתורה, דאם יש לאדם נטי' ח"ו אל א' מהעבירות ונתגבר על יצרו ולא עשאה, הרי עדיין לא פעל און ואדרבה עבודה גדולה הוא, משא"כ שוחד מעוור עיני האדם ומרחיקו מדרך האמת, וע"כ אף אם יש לו רק נטי' ואוהב את השוחד ומצפה לקבלו, אף אם לא יקבל כלום, הדמיון בלבד מעוור עיני שכלו, ואף שוחד דברים נמי אסור כאמרז"ל (כתובות ק"ה ע"ב) והביאו בגמ' שם מעשה בר' ישמעאל בר אלישע דאייתי לי' האי גברא ראשית הגז, וא"ל דינא אית לי, א"ל פסילנא לך לדינא ולא קביל מיני', אותיב לי' זוגא דרבנן וקדייני לי', בהדי דקאזיל ואתי אמר אי בעי טעין הכי ואי בעי טעין הכא, (פרש"י בכל אשר הולך ובא הי' לבו לזכותו וכו', ואומר בלבו הלואי ויטעון כך וכך ויזכה בדין) אמר תיפח נפשם של מקבלי שוחד. ומה אני שלא נטלתי ואם נטלתי שלי נטלתי כך, מקבלי שוחד עאכו"כ, ולזה התאונן הנביא כולו אוהבי שוחד, אף שלא היו כולם מקבלי שוחד אבל מפני שהי' ענין השוחד אהוב אצלם כבר נתרחקו מאור האמת וצריך למאוס בזה בתכלית ההתרחקות.
translation: The conclusion we draw from this is that in a place where there is a business of plunder, one needs a great assistance from Heaven so that a person does not stumble and deviate from the path of truth, for bribery blinds the eyes of the wise. I have already explained in the prophet's discourse (Isaiah 1) where he laments the state of the generation at the time of the destruction, saying, "Your rulers are rebellious and companions of thieves; everyone loves bribes and pursues rewards," etc. Behold, from what he says, "everyone loves bribes" and he did not say "everyone takes bribes." It implies that not the entirety of the generation was in this bad trait of accepting bribes; rather, they were lovers of bribes. And seemingly, what is so bad if they only loved the bribe and overcame their inclination and did not accept it? Why does the prophet count this among such severe transgressions? There are some of the ancients who hold that it is better for one who has an inclination towards evil and overcomes it, as he does so for the honor of his Creator, unlike one who is naturally distant from it; how does he serve his Master? And they support this from the words of our Sages (Toras Kohanim, Parshas Kedoshim) that one should not say, "I do not desire pig meat," etc. However, Maimonides disagrees with them (see Yismach Moshe, Parshas Re'eh). Nevertheless, I differentiate bribery from all the transgressions in the Torah, for if a person has an inclination, Heaven forbid, towards one of the transgressions and overcomes his inclination and does not commit it, he has not yet acted wickedly, and on the contrary, it is a great service. However, bribery blinds a person's eyes and distances him from the path of truth. Therefore, even if he only has an inclination and loves the bribe and expects to receive it, even if he does not receive anything, the mere thought blinds his intellect. And even verbal bribery is also forbidden, as our Sages said (Ketubot 105b), and they brought there a story about Rabbi Yishmael ben Elisha, who was brought a certain man with the first shearing, and he said to him, "I have a legal claim against you." He replied, "I disqualify myself from the legal claim and do not accept from you." He then brought him a pair of Rabbis and they judged him. As they were going and coming, he said, "If I want to claim this way, and if I want to claim that way," (Rashi explains, "In all that he goes and comes, his heart was to justify himself," etc., and he says in his heart, "Would that he would claim this and this and be justified in the judgment"). He said, "May the souls of those who accept bribes be crushed." And as for me, who did not take, and if I took, I took what is mine, how much more so for those who accept bribes! And for this, the prophet lamented, "Everyone loves bribes," even though not all of them were accepting bribes, but because the matter of bribery was beloved to them, they have already distanced themselves from the light of truth, and one must abhor this with the utmost distance.
summary: The passage emphasizes the dangers of favoritism and corruption, particularly the love of bribes, which can blind individuals to the truth and lead them away from righteousness. It highlights that even a mere inclination towards accepting bribes, without actually taking them, is a serious moral failing, as it distances one from divine truth. The text contrasts this with other sins, suggesting that the love of bribes is uniquely detrimental because it corrupts the mind and spirit, necessitating a complete rejection of such inclinations. Ultimately, the prophet's lament about the prevalence of this love for bribes underscores the urgent need for spiritual vigilance and integrity.

passage_content: ובזה יתבאר דברי הגמ' (סוטה י"ג ע"א) שכל ישראל נתעסקו בביזה ומשרע"ה נתעסק בעצמות יוסף שנא' חכם לב יקח מצות, (עיין לעיל קושיא ב') דאה"נ שגם ישראל לש"ש נתכוונו ונצטוו על ככה מפי ד', ואמרז"ל בגמרא ברכות (דף ט' ע"א) שא"ל הקב"ה למשה בבקשה ממך לך ואמור לישראל בבקשה מכם שאלו ממצרים כלי כסף וכלי זהב וכו' ומה דשבקו העסק בעצמות יוסף על משרע"ה, היתה ג"כ כוונתם לש"ש כאמרז"ל שאמרו כבודו בגדולים יותר מבקטנים, אמנם מפני שהיו עסוקין בביזה נעשו משוחדין אלי' והשוחד יעוור עיני חכמים ואמרז"ל אם חכם חכמתו מסתלקת ממנו, משא"כ משרע"ה נתקיימה חכמתו. ולזה דרשו רז"ל חכם לב יקח מצות זה משה שעסק בעצמות יוסף ונסתלק מן הביזה, ולכך תיארוהו בזה בתואר חכם, וסיפי' דקרא ואויל שפתיים ילבט נדרש על ישראל דמפני שהרבו העסק בביזה נאבדה חכמתם, ואפשר דאילולי כן היו מכריעים לקיים שניהם.
translation: And this will clarify the words of the Gemara (Sotah 13a) that all of Israel were engaged in plunder, while Moshe Rabbeinu was occupied with the bones of Yosef, as it is said, "A wise heart will acquire commandments" (Proverbs 10:8). (See above for the question.) Indeed, it is true that Israel also intended for the sake of Heaven and were commanded thus from the mouth of the Holy One, Blessed be He. And our Sages said in the Gemara Berakhot (9a) that the Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Moshe, "Please go and tell Israel, 'Please, from you, ask the Egyptians for silver and gold vessels,' etc." And the reason they abandoned the task of the bones of Yosef for Moshe Rabbeinu was also with the intention for the sake of Heaven, as our Sages said, "His honor is greater in the great ones than in the small ones." However, because they were occupied with plunder, they became corrupted by it, and bribery blinds the eyes of the wise. And our Sages said, "If a wise man is bribed, his wisdom departs from him," whereas with Moshe Rabbeinu, his wisdom was sustained. Therefore, our Sages expounded, "A wise heart will acquire commandments" refers to Moshe, who was engaged with the bones of Yosef and distanced himself from the plunder. For this reason, he is described here with the title of "wise." And the end of the verse, "And a fool with his lips will be ruined," is interpreted regarding Israel, that because they increased their engagement in plunder, their wisdom was lost. And it is possible that had it not been for this, they would have been able to fulfill both.
summary: The passage discusses the distinction between the actions of the Israelites and Moses during the Exodus, highlighting that while the Israelites were preoccupied with plundering the Egyptians, Moses focused on retrieving the bones of Joseph. This reflects a key Hasidic concept that true wisdom and spiritual insight come from selfless actions directed towards fulfilling divine commandments. The text emphasizes that Moses's dedication to this task preserved his wisdom, while the Israelites' distraction with material gain led to a loss of their spiritual clarity. Ultimately, it illustrates the importance of prioritizing spiritual pursuits over worldly concerns to maintain one's connection to divine wisdom.

passage_content: ויהי בשלח פרעה את העם וגו', במד"ר (פרשה כ' סימן ז') מי צווח ווי פרעה משל למלך שהי' בנו הולך למדינה א' ושרה אצל עשיר אחד וכו', והיה המלך משלח אגרות אל אותו האיש וכו', עד שהלך והוציא את בנו בעצמו, התחיל אותו האיש צווח וכו', כך פרעה אמר כשהיו ישראל אצלי הי' הקב"ה משלח לי אגרת בכל שעה, כה אמר ה' שלח עמי וכו', כשהוציא הקב"ה את ישראל התחיל פרעה צועק ווי ששלחתי את ישראל עכ"ד, וצ"ב כי אין המשל דומה לנמשל כי האגרות שקבל פרעה היו התראות על המכות ולא של כבוד, ולמה הי' משתוקק אליהם עד שצווח עבורם ווי.
translation: And it was when Pharaoh sent out the people, etc. In the Midrash (Parashat 20, Siman 7), who cried out "Woe!" Pharaoh is likened to a king whose son was going to a certain city and was staying with a wealthy man, etc. The king was sending letters to that man, etc., until he went and brought his son out himself. Then that man began to cry out, etc. So too, Pharaoh said, when Israel was with me, the Holy One, blessed be He, was sending me a letter at every hour, thus said the Lord, "Let My people go," etc. When the Holy One, blessed be He, took Israel out, Pharaoh began to cry out, "Woe that I sent Israel!" Thus far is the explanation. And it is difficult to understand because the parable does not resemble the allegory, for the letters that Pharaoh received were warnings about the plagues and not letters of honor. Why then was he so eager for them that he cried out "Woe" for them?
summary: The passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel discusses the moment Pharaoh sends the Israelites away, likening it to a king whose son is taken by a wealthy man, prompting the king to send letters of warning. Pharaoh, who received divine messages about the plagues, expresses regret and anguish upon their departure, despite these messages being warnings rather than honors. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the nature of divine communication and the human response to loss, highlighting the tension between authority and vulnerability in the face of God's will. The passage invites contemplation on the complexities of divine justice and mercy as experienced by both Pharaoh and the Israelites.

passage_content: ב) לבב פרעה ועבדיו אל העם ויאמרו מה זאת עשינו וגו', הקשה האוהחה"ק וכי לרצונם שלחו. והלא הכו מכות גדולות ובע"כ שלחום, ולא הי' כאן שנוי רצון כלל, דרצונם עתה כרצונם מאז, ולא יתכן לומר ויהפך לבם.
translation: B) The heart of Pharaoh and his servants turned to the people, and they said, "What is this we have done, etc." The holy question arises: Did they send them willingly? But they inflicted great plagues upon them and sent them against their will. There was no change of will at all, for their will now is as their will was then, and it cannot be said that their hearts were turned.
summary: The passage discusses the moment when Pharaoh and his servants reflect on their decision to release the Israelites, questioning whether it was truly their will to do so. It highlights the idea that despite the severe plagues they endured, their desire to let the Israelites go remained unchanged, suggesting that their hearts were not genuinely transformed. This raises a theological insight about the nature of free will and divine influence, emphasizing that even in moments of apparent change, the underlying intentions may remain consistent. Ultimately, it suggests a complex interplay between human agency and divine orchestration in the unfolding of events.

passage_content: ג) יל"ד מ"ש מה זאת עשינו כי שלחנו את ישראל וגו', ובאמת לא הי' כאן עשיה אחרת זולתי השליחות, והול"ל מה זאת שלחנו את ישראל וגו', ולמה האריך הכתוב לכתוב תרתי מילי עשי' ושליחות, ולפי הנראה אינו אלא חדא, גם הלשון כי שלחנו אינו מובן.
translation: 3) What is meant by "What is this we have done that we have sent away Israel," and in truth, there was no other action here besides the sending, and it should have said, "What is this we have sent away Israel," and why did the text take the time to write two terms, action and sending? It seems that they are one and the same, and also the expression "that we have sent" is not clear.
summary: The passage discusses the phrase "What is this we have done that we have sent away Israel," emphasizing that the act of sending away is the only action taken, suggesting a deeper connection between action and intention. The author questions why the text distinguishes between "action" and "sending," implying that they are fundamentally one and the same. This reflects a Hasidic perspective on the unity of thought and deed, highlighting the importance of intention behind actions in the spiritual realm. The inquiry into the language used reveals a theological insight into the nature of divine service and the significance of one's choices.

passage_content: ד) במה שפי' רש"י ז"ל ויהפך נהפכו לרדוף אחריהם בשביל ממונם שהשאילום, ויש להבין למה שינה רש"י מהטעם המפורש בקרא כי שלחנו את ישראל מעבדנו, ונתן טעם חדש בשביל ממונם שאינו מרומז בכתוב כלל.
translation: In what Rashi, may his memory be blessed, explained, "and he turned to pursue them for the sake of their money that he had borrowed from them," one must understand why Rashi altered the explicit reason in the verse, "for we have sent away the Israelites from our service," and provided a new reason concerning their money, which is not hinted at in the text at all.
summary: In this passage, the author discusses Rashi's interpretation of the biblical verse regarding the Egyptians' pursuit of the Israelites, suggesting that they were motivated by the desire to reclaim their possessions that had been lent to them. The author questions why Rashi deviates from the explicit reason given in the text, which is the Israelites' release from servitude, and instead introduces a new rationale centered on material wealth. This highlights a key Hasidic concept that emphasizes the spiritual implications of material possessions and the deeper motivations behind human actions. Ultimately, it reflects on the interplay between physical and spiritual realms in understanding divine providence and human behavior.

passage_content: ה) (ס"י) ויהי בשלח פרעה הה"ד אמרו לאלקים מה נורא מעשיך ברוב עוזך יכחשו לך אויביך וכו' ר' ברכיה אמר יעשו כזבים בדבריהם כענין שנאמר וכחש בעמיתו, מתחלה אמר וגם את ישראל לא אשלח, ואח"כ הוא הי' מחזיר על פתחיהן של ישראל וא"ל לכו לשלום צאו לשלום הוי ברוב עזך יכחשו לך אויביך ע"כ, ראוי להבין דלכאורה אין זה בגדר כחש וכזב, דמתחלה כשאמר את ישראל לא אשלח כן הי' דעתו ורצונו באמת, ופיו ולבו שווין, וגם עתה לא נשתנה רצונו, אלא שבע"כ שלחם, ולא שינה דיבורו דמ"ש לא אשלח כוונתו שלא ישלח ברצון עצמו, ולא עבר ע"ז. ואין זה בגדר כחש וכזב, גם קשה דהול"ל דרשא זו על פסוק קומי צאי מתוך עמי, כי שם מקומו בפ' הקודמת, ולמה המתין עד הכא. ואיך שייכא דרשא זו לכאן.
translation: 5) (S.Y.) And it came to pass when Pharaoh sent forth the people, as it is said, "Say to God, how awesome are Your deeds; in the abundance of Your might, Your enemies will feign." Rabbi Berachiah said they will make falsehoods in their words, as it is stated, "and he deceived his fellow." At first, he said, "I will not send Israel," and afterwards he was returning to the doorways of Israel and said to them, "Go in peace, depart in peace; in the abundance of Your might, Your enemies will feign." Therefore, it is appropriate to understand that seemingly this does not fall under the category of deception and falsehood, for at first when he said, "I will not send Israel," that was indeed his true intention and desire, and his heart and mouth were in agreement. And even now, his desire has not changed, except that he was compelled to send them, and he did not change his words, for when he said, "I will not send," his intention was that he would not send them of his own will, and he did not transgress this. And this does not fall under the category of deception and falsehood. It is also difficult, for this interpretation should have been stated on the verse "Arise, go out from among my people," for there is its place in the previous chapter, and why did he wait until here? And how is this interpretation relevant here?
summary: The passage discusses the paradox of Pharaoh's refusal to let the Israelites go, highlighting the tension between his initial intentions and the eventual outcome. It emphasizes that although Pharaoh's words indicated a firm refusal, his actions ultimately contradicted his will, as he was compelled to release them against his desires. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the nature of divine intervention, where God's will prevails despite human resistance, illustrating the concept of "truth" versus "falsehood" in intentions and actions. The text invites contemplation on the complexities of free will and divine orchestration in the unfolding of events.

passage_content: ו) ויהי בשלח פרעה וגו' ילמדינו רבינו השולח יד בפקדונו של חבירו כיצד הוא נגבה, כך שנו רבותינו השולח יד בפקדון ב"ש אומרים ילקה בחסר וביתר, וב"ה אומרים כשעת הגזילה וכו' ומנין שהיו ישראל בידו פקדון. שכן הוא אומר למשה שיאמר לישראל פקד פקדתי אתכם וכו' ובשביל ששלח יד בהם שבר הקב"ה את זרועו וכו', ולכאורה קשה דלמה לי טעמא דפקדון, והלא בלא"ה ראוי שיענש, שהושלכו ילדיהם ליאור על פקודתו ושקעם בבנין, והכו ע"י הנוגשים, והרבה עליהם גזירות רעות, ומי שעושה כל אלה ראוי שיענש אפי' אינם בתורת פקדון אצלו, גם ראוי להבין דהול"ל דרשא זו בפ' שמות עה"פ הבה נתחכמה, וימררו את חייהם, כי שם מקומו, ולמה הסמיכו דרשא זו לפ' ויהי בשלח פרעה, וצ"ב.
translation: And it came to pass when Pharaoh sent forth, etc. Our Rabbi teaches us how one is punished for the entrusted property of a friend. Thus our sages taught: One who sends his hand upon a deposit, Beit Shammai says he is liable for less and for more, and Beit Hillel says he is liable as at the time of the theft, etc. And from where do we know that Israel was in his possession as a deposit? For it says to Moses to tell Israel, "I have surely remembered you," etc. And because he sent his hand upon them, the Holy One, Blessed be He, broke his arm, etc. However, it is difficult to understand why we need the reasoning of a deposit, for without it he is certainly deserving of punishment, as he cast their children into the Nile at his command and oppressed them in building, and they were beaten by the taskmasters, and many evil decrees were upon them. One who does all these things is certainly deserving of punishment even if they are not considered a deposit in his eyes. It is also worth understanding why this interpretation was not stated in Parashat Shemot regarding the verse "Come, let us deal wisely," for that is its place, and why this interpretation is connected to the portion "And it came to pass when Pharaoh sent forth," and this is a question.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of "pledge" in relation to the suffering of the Israelites under Pharaoh's rule, emphasizing that their oppression was akin to a violation of a trust. It highlights the theological idea that God intervened and punished Pharaoh for his actions, which included the brutal treatment of the Israelites. The text questions why the notion of "pledge" is emphasized, given the severity of Pharaoh's sins, and why this interpretation is linked to the narrative of the Exodus rather than the earlier oppression. This reflects a deeper understanding of divine justice and the moral implications of one's actions in the context of communal suffering.

passage_content: ולבאר כל הענין נקדים מה שהקשה האוהחה"ק בפ' שמות וז"ל: צריך לתת לב, למה יצו ה' דברים שאינם מהמוסר, לגנוב דעתם של המצרים במ"ש נלכה נא דרך שלשת ימים, כי ח"ו לא קצור קצרה ידו מפדות ישראל בע"כ, גם בהשאלת כליהם למה יצטרכו לעשות דרך ערמה, הלא הי' ביכולת השי"ת להוציא ממונם בע"כ ועיניהם רואות וכלות, גם היו המצרים נותנים להם ברצונם אפי' בדרך מתנה כמ"ש במדרש שאמרו עול שנים וצא, כי אמרו כולנו מתים, ותירץ האוהחה"ק כי נתכוין ה' בזה להטעותם כדי שירדפו אחריהם, וזולת השאלה, גם זולת הליכתם בדרך זה על דעת לחזור, לא היו המצרים רודפים אחריהם והיו מתייאשים מחזרתם, ומ"ש נלכה נא דרך שלשת ימים לא הי' דברי השי"ת, אלא זקני ישראל אמרו כן, גם השאלת כליהם אין בו דברי שקר, כי בתורת שאלה בא לידם אלא שעכבוהו בעד תביעתם של שכר שכיר שעבדו להם וכו' עיי"ש.
translation: To clarify the entire matter, we will begin with the question posed by the holy author in Parashat Shemot, and he writes: One must pay attention to why the Holy One, Blessed be He, commanded things that are not from the realm of ethics, to deceive the Egyptians with the statement "Let us go a three-day journey," for Heaven forbid, His hand is not too short to redeem Israel against their will. Also, regarding the borrowing of their vessels, why would they need to act deceitfully? Surely it was within the capability of the Blessed One to take their possessions against their will, and their eyes would see and be consumed. Moreover, the Egyptians would have willingly given them even as a gift, as stated in the Midrash, where they said, "We are all dying," and the holy author answered that the intent of the Holy One was to mislead them so that they would pursue them. Without this question, and aside from their journey in this manner with the intention of returning, the Egyptians would not have pursued them and would have despaired of their return. And the statement "Let us go a three-day journey" was not the words of the Holy One, but rather the elders of Israel said this. Additionally, the borrowing of their vessels does not contain falsehood, for it came to them as a request, but they were held back due to their claim for wages for the work they had done for them, etc. See there.
summary: The passage discusses the divine strategy behind the Israelites' request to the Egyptians to journey for three days, highlighting that this was not a command from God but rather a suggestion from the elders of Israel. It emphasizes that God orchestrated this deception to provoke the Egyptians into pursuing the Israelites, ensuring their eventual liberation. Additionally, the text reflects on the nature of divine providence, suggesting that God could have freed the Israelites without subterfuge, yet chose a path that would lead to a greater demonstration of His power and the fulfillment of His promises.

passage_content: אמנם עדיין צ"ב כי למה יצטרך להטעותם בשביל שיתנו לב לרדוף אחריהם, והרי כמה דרכים למקום, והי' אפשר שיתן השי"ת בלבם כבדות לב שירדפו אחריהם אף אם יהי' תחילת הליכתם שלא ע"מ לחזור, ואמרו ז"ל במדרש שפרעה שחרר אותם לגמרי בשעה שיצאו וא"ל הרי אתם בן חורין הרי אתם ברשותכם, ואעפ"כ הפך לבו ורדף אחריהם, וכמו"כ הי' רודף אחריהם אף אם לא אמרו לו מתחלה נלכה נא דרך שלשת ימים. גם מה שתירץ האוהחה"ק דזקני ישראל אמרו כן, ולא הי' דברי השי"ת, אינו מתורץ בזה כל צרכו, שהרי אמרו חכז"ל במס' סוכה (דף מ"ו ע"ב) לא לימא איניש לינוקא דיהיבנא לך מידי ולא יהיב לי' משום דאתי לאגמורי' שיקרא, שנאמר למדו לשונם דבר שקר, ואיך יתכן שבשעת שיצאו ישראל ממצרים והיו מוכנים לקבלת התורה, ועתה הי' התחלת הדרכתם לתורה ומצות, שילמדו לשונם דבר מרמה, וצ"ב.
translation: However, it is still questionable why He needed to deceive them so that they would pay attention to pursue them, as there are many paths to the place, and it would have been possible for the Holy One, Blessed be He, to place heaviness in their hearts so that they would pursue them even if their initial intention was not to return. And our Sages, of blessed memory, said in the Midrash that Pharaoh completely freed them at the moment they left and said to them, "Behold, you are free men; you are in your own authority," and nevertheless, his heart was turned and he pursued them. Similarly, he would have pursued them even if they had not initially said, "Let us go a three-day journey." Also, the explanation given by the holy author that the elders of Israel said so, and it was not the words of the Holy One, Blessed be He, does not fully resolve the matter, for our Sages, of blessed memory, said in Tractate Sukkah (46b) that one should not say to a child, "I will give you something," and then not give it to him, for he will come to learn to speak falsehood, as it is said, "They taught their tongue to speak deceit." How is it possible that at the time the Israelites left Egypt and were prepared to receive the Torah, and now was the beginning of their guidance towards the Torah and commandments, they would learn to speak deceitful words? This remains a question.
summary: The passage questions why God would need to deceive the Egyptians to prompt their pursuit of the Israelites, suggesting that there were other ways to instill a desire for pursuit. It references the Midrash, noting that Pharaoh initially released the Israelites, yet his heart was hardened to chase them regardless. Additionally, it raises concerns about the integrity of the Israelites' intentions, as they were on the verge of receiving the Torah, questioning how they could be led to speak deceitfully at such a critical moment in their spiritual journey.

passage_content: ולבאר כל אלה נקדים מה שהקשה הפרשת דרכים (בדרוש ה' דרך מצרים) וז"ל איך דן הקב"ה את המצריים במיתה וממון, והא קיי"ל דאין אדם מת ומשלם. וכתבו התוס' בפ"ה דמס' ע"ז (דף ע"א) דגם בבני נח אמרינן קים לי' בדרבה מיני' וא"כ כיון שהמצריים נתחייבו מיתה איך נענשו גם בממון, ותירץ דקיי"ל כרבנן דס"ל דלא אמרינן קים לי' בדרבה מיני' אלא במיתה בידי אדם, אבל במיתה בידי שמים אדם מת ומשלם דלא קיי"ל כר' נחוניא בן הקנה שהי' עושה את יוהכ"פ כשבת עיי"ש, ובדרך המצפה (בדרוש כ"ו) כתב לתרץ קושיא זו דאפי' לדברי ר' נחוניא בן הקנה א"ש, עפימ"ש התוס' בכתובות (דף ל' ע"ב ד"ה זר), דגזירת הכתוב הוא בהקדש ותרומה דלא אמרינן קים לי' בדרבה מיני', ואמרי בהו מת ומשלם, ומעתה א"ש אפי' לר' נחוניא דכיון דישראל קודש וראשית תבואתו של הקב"ה דהיינו תרומה, כדמשמע מסוגית הגמ' קידושין (דף נ"ג ע"א) דראשית תבואתו היינו תרומה עיי"ש, וע"כ מדינא חייבים המצריים וכל האומה"ע המריעים לישראל להיות לוקים ומשתלמים על ידיהם, ופי' בזה הכתוב קודש ישראל לה' ראשית תבואתו, ע"כ כל אוכליו יאשמו, ר"ל שחייבים לשלם מלשון ואת אשמו ישוב בראשו, וגם רעה תבוא עליהם שיענשו בידי שמים, עכת"ד ז"ל. ומעתה א"ש דהי' ההכרח ליקח מידם הרכוש בתורת שאלה, דאלמלי הגיע לידם מעיקרא בתורת תשלומין, הי' פתחון פה למקטרג שלא יוכו המצריים עוד שאין אדם לוקה ומשלם, ע"כ קבלוהו מעיקרא בתורת שאלה, ואחר שיצאו ונעשו הקדש כמו שיתבאר להלן זכו בהרכוש להיות שלהם לחלוטין.
translation: To explain all this, we will first address the difficulty raised by the separation of paths (in the discourse "The Way of Egypt"), which states: How did the Holy One, blessed be He, judge the Egyptians with death and monetary loss, when we hold that a person does not die and pay? The Tosafot wrote in the fifth chapter of Tractate Avodah Zarah (page 71) that even regarding the descendants of Noah, we say that he has a claim in many ways. Therefore, since the Egyptians were liable for death, how were they also punished in monetary matters? It was answered that we hold like the Rabbis who say that we do not say he has a claim in many ways except for death at the hands of man, but in death at the hands of Heaven, a person dies and pays, as we do not hold like Rabbi Nechunya ben HaKana, who treated Yom Kippur like Shabbat, as stated there. In "The Way of the Watchtower" (in discourse 26), it was written to resolve this difficulty that even according to the words of Rabbi Nechunya ben HaKana, it is understandable, as the Tosafot state in Ketubot (page 30b, "Zar"), that it is a decree of Scripture regarding consecrated items and offerings that we do not say he has a claim in many ways, and they say about them that he dies and pays. Therefore, it is understandable even according to Rabbi Nechunya, since Israel is holy and the first of the produce of the Holy One, blessed be He, which is the offering, as implied in the Gemara's discussion in Kiddushin (page 53a) that the first of the produce refers to the offering, and thus, by law, the Egyptians and all the nations of the world that harm Israel are liable to be struck and to pay through them. The verse explains this: "The holiness of Israel belongs to the Lord, the first of His produce," therefore, all who eat of it will be guilty, meaning they are obligated to pay, from the language of "and his guilt shall return upon his head," and also evil will come upon them that they will be punished at the hands of Heaven. Thus far is his holy word. And now it is clear that it was necessary to take their possessions as a loan, for had it come to them initially as a payment, there would have been a justification for the accuser that the Egyptians would not be struck again, since a person does not strike and pay. Therefore, they accepted it initially as a loan, and after they left and it became consecrated, as will be explained below, they merited that the possessions would be entirely theirs.
summary: The passage discusses the theological implications of God's judgment on the Egyptians, who were punished with death and loss of property despite the principle that a person does not pay for their death. It explains that, according to certain rabbinic interpretations, the Egyptians were liable for both death and financial restitution because their actions warranted divine retribution. The text emphasizes that the Israelites, as God's chosen people, have a unique status, and thus the Egyptians' possessions were taken as a loan, allowing for their eventual ownership after the Exodus. This reflects the deeper Hasidic concept of divine justice and the sanctity of Israel's relationship with God.

passage_content: ובזה יתבארו דברי רש"י ז"ל ויהפך לבב פרעה וגו' נהפכו לרדוף אחריהם בשביל ממונם שהשאילום, שאמרו לקינו ונטלו ממוננו ושלחנום וכו', כי מעיקרא היו מוכרחים לשלחם מפני המכות, ושמחו מצרים בצאתם, אבל עכשיו שנטלו את ממונם לחלוטין חשב פרעה כי מעתה בלא"ה לא היו לוקין עוד, כי אין אדם לוקה ומשלם וע"כ התחרט על מה ששלחם, וזה שפרש"י ויהפך לבב פרעה וסיבת ההחרטה הי' בשביל ממונם שהשאילום שאמרו לקינו ונטלו ממוננו ושלחנום, כי לא הי' מוכרח עוד השליחות כי בלא"ה לא היינו לוקים עוד אחרי שנטלו ממוננו, ולא ידע פרעה גם לא האמין שיש להם דין הקדש ע"כ התחרט על ששלחם, וסיבת החרטה היתה בשביל ממונם כמו שפירש"י וא"ש.
translation: And this will clarify the words of Rashi, may his memory be blessed: "And the heart of Pharaoh was hardened," etc. They were turned to pursue them because of their money that they had borrowed, as they said, "You have made us lose our possessions and sent us away," etc. For initially, they were compelled to send them away because of the plagues, and the Egyptians rejoiced at their departure. But now that they had taken their possessions completely, Pharaoh thought that from now on they would not be afflicted anymore, for no one is afflicted and pays at the same time. Therefore, he regretted having sent them away. This is what Rashi explains: "And the heart of Pharaoh was hardened," and the reason for his regret was because of their money that they had borrowed, as they said, "You have made us lose our possessions and sent us away," for he was no longer compelled to send them away since, in any case, they would not be afflicted anymore after they had taken their possessions. And Pharaoh did not know, nor did he believe, that they had the status of holy property; therefore, he regretted having sent them away, and the reason for his regret was because of their money, as Rashi explained, and it is clear.
summary: The passage discusses the transformation of Pharaoh's heart, as explained by Rashi, emphasizing that Pharaoh's regret for releasing the Israelites stemmed from the loss of their possessions, which he believed would prevent further plagues. Initially, the Egyptians were compelled to let the Israelites go due to the plagues, but once their wealth was taken, Pharaoh thought they would no longer suffer consequences. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the relationship between material possessions and spiritual accountability, highlighting Pharaoh's misunderstanding of divine justice and the sanctity of the Israelites. Ultimately, Pharaoh's change of heart was driven by a focus on material loss rather than a recognition of the spiritual implications of his actions.

passage_content: ונקדים עוד מ"ד במד"ר פרשת בא (פ' ט"ז סימן ב') משכו וקחו לכם צאן הה"ד בשובה ונחת תושעון וצ"ב, אכן יתבאר עפי"ד הירושלמי במס' תענית (פ"א ה"א) ר' אחא בש"ר תנחום בי ר' חייה אמר אילו ישראל עושין תשובה יום א' מיד הי' בן דוד בא, מ"ט היום אם בקולו תשמעו, א"ר לוי אילו היו ישראל משמרין שבת אחת כתיקונה מיד הי' בן דוד בא, מ"ט דכתיב כי שבת היום לה' חד יום, (ופי' בקרבן העדה דיליף לי' גז"ש היום היום, מפסוק הנ"ל היום אם בקולו תשמעו) ואומר בשובה ונחת תושעון, בשובה ונייח תתפרקון ע"כ, עכ"פ דרשת הירושלמי מהאי קרא דע"י תשובה ומנוחת השבת יזכו ישראל לגאולתם, בשובה היינו תשובה, ונייח היינו מנוחת השבת, ובזכותם תושעון, והנה קיימו ישראל ב' בחינות הנ"ל, דמצוה זו דמשכו וקחו לכם קיימו בעשור לחודש שהי' שבת הגדול, ואמרו חכז"ל משכו ידיכם מע"ז וכו' ואיתא במדרש שכפרו בע"ז ועשו תשובה הגונה, נמצא שהי' להם ב' הזכותים, זכות השבת, וזכות התשובה, והיו ראויים להגאל, ועפימ"ש הטו"ז (בסי' רמ"ב) עמ"ש חז"ל כל המשמר שבת כהלכתה אפי' עוע"ז כדור אנוש מוחלין לו. איכא למידק ממנ"פ אי לא עשה תשובה שבת מאי מהניא, ואי עשה תשובה שבת ל"ל, ותירץ דמיירי שעשה תשובה, אלא דתשובה לא מהני שיהא מוחלין לו לגמרי כדאיתא במס' יומא בפ' יוהכ"פ, עבר על כריתות ומיתות ב"ד תשובה תולה ומיתה ממרקת, קמ"ל כאן דאם בעשותו תשובה שומר שבת כהלכתה, מהני התשובה שיהא נמחל לו לגמרי, וע"כ בנ"י במצרים שהיו עוע"ז ועברו על מיתת ב"ד, היו צריכין לתשובה בצירוף שמירת שבת, ועי"ז נמחלו עונותיהם והי' ראויים לגאולה, וז"ש במדרש הנ"ל משכו וקחו לכם הה"ד בשובה ונחת תושעון. שהי' להם כאן צירוף זכות שניהם תשובה ושבת, ובזכות זה נגאלו וא"ש.
translation:
And we will precede with the words of the Midrash in Parashat Bo (Chapter 16, Section 2): "Draw and take for yourselves sheep," which corresponds to "In returning and rest you shall be saved," and it is to be understood. Indeed, it will be explained according to the words of the Jerusalem Talmud in Tractate Taanit (Chapter 1, Halacha 1), Rabbi Acha in the name of Rabbi Tanachum, son of Rabbi Chiya, said: "If Israel would repent for one day, immediately the son of David would come." Why? Because today, if you will listen to His voice. Rabbi Levi said: "If Israel would observe one Shabbat properly, immediately the son of David would come." Why? Because it is written, "For today is a Sabbath to the Lord, a single day." (And the explanation in the Korban HaEdah derives from this a verbal analogy: "today, today," from the above verse, "today, if you will listen to His voice.") And it says, "In returning and rest you shall be saved," in returning means repentance, and rest means the rest of Shabbat, and by their merit you shall be saved. 

And behold, Israel fulfilled these two aspects mentioned, for this commandment of "Draw and take for yourselves" they fulfilled on the tenth of the month, which was the Great Shabbat, and our sages said: "Withdraw your hands from idolatry," etc. And it is stated in the Midrash that they denied idolatry and did proper repentance, thus they had two merits: the merit of Shabbat and the merit of repentance, and they were worthy of redemption. 

And according to what is stated in the Taz (in Section 152), our sages said: "Whoever observes Shabbat properly, even if he is an idolater like the generation of Enosh, he is forgiven." One might ask: If he did not repent, what benefit is there from Shabbat? And if he repented, what need is there for Shabbat? And it was answered that it speaks of one who did repent, but the repentance alone does not suffice for him to be completely forgiven, as it is stated in Tractate Yoma in the chapter on Yom Kippur: "If one transgressed the prohibitions of kareit and the death penalties of the court, repentance suspends [the punishment] and death atones." Here it teaches us that if, in doing repentance, he observes Shabbat properly, the repentance is effective for him to be completely forgiven. 

And therefore, the Jewish people in Egypt, who were idolaters and transgressed the death penalties of the court, needed repentance along with the observance of Shabbat, and through this, their sins were forgiven and they were worthy of redemption. And this is what is said in the aforementioned Midrash: "Draw and take for yourselves," which corresponds to "In returning and rest you shall be saved," for they had here the combination of both merits: repentance and Shabbat, and by this merit, they were redeemed, and it is clear.
summary: The passage discusses the connection between repentance (teshuva) and the observance of the Sabbath (Shabbat) as prerequisites for redemption. It cites teachings from the Jerusalem Talmud, emphasizing that if the Israelites had repented even once or properly observed the Sabbath, they would have immediately merited the arrival of the Messiah. The text highlights that during their time in Egypt, the Israelites combined both repentance and Sabbath observance, which led to the forgiveness of their sins and their subsequent redemption. Thus, the dual merits of teshuva and Shabbat are presented as essential for achieving salvation.

passage_content: ונקדים עוד מ"ש המראה פנים להקשות על דברי ירושלמי הנ"ל ממה דאיתא בגמ' שבת (דף קי"ח ע"ב) אמר ר' יוחנן אמר רשב"י אלמלא משמרין ישראל שתי שבתות כהלכתן מיד נגאלים שנא' כה אמר ה' לסריסים אשר ישמרו את שבתותי, וכתיב בתרי' והביאותים אל הר קדשי וגו' ובירושלמי הנ"ל מבואר דע"י שמירת שבת א' מיד נגאלין, עיי"ש שכתב דפליגי הבבלי והירושלמי, אמנם אין סברא לאפושי פלוגתא במקום שאפשר להשוות דבריהם ואפשר לתרץ בהקדם מה שהקשה המהרש"א ז"ל (במס' נדה דף ל"ח ע"א) דאיך למדו רז"ל מהאי קרא דאשר ישמרו את שבתותי, אלמלי שמרו ישראל ב' שבתות מיד נגאלין, מדכתיב שבתותי ומעוט רבים שנים, הא כתיב בתורה כה"ג כמו אך את שבתותי תשמרו וכולל כל השבתות עד סוף ימי עמידת העולם ומהיכי תיתי לדרוש כאן על ב' שבתות לבד ע"כ קושיתו.
translation: And we will also precede with what the vision of faces is to challenge the words of the aforementioned Jerusalem Talmud from what is stated in the Gemara Shabbat (page 118b) that Rabbi Yochanan said in the name of Rabbi Shimon Bar Yochai: If Israel would observe two Shabbats properly, they would be redeemed immediately, as it is written: "Thus says the Lord to the eunuchs who keep My Sabbaths," and it is written afterwards: "And I will bring them to My holy mountain," etc. And in the aforementioned Jerusalem Talmud, it is explained that through the observance of one Shabbat, they are redeemed immediately. See there that it is written that the Babylonian and Jerusalem Talmud disagree. However, there is no reason to broaden the dispute where it is possible to reconcile their words, and it is possible to address in advance what the Maharsha, of blessed memory, questioned (in Tractate Niddah, page 38a) as to how the sages learned from this verse "who keep My Sabbaths," that if Israel would keep two Shabbats, they would be redeemed immediately, since it is written "My Sabbaths" and the plural implies two, but it is written in the Torah in this manner: "But you shall keep My Sabbaths," which includes all the Shabbats until the end of the days of the world's standing, and from where do we derive to interpret here about only two Shabbats alone? Thus is his question.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of observing the Sabbath in relation to redemption, referencing a debate between the Babylonian and Jerusalem Talmuds. Rabbi Yochanan cites Rabbi Shimon Bar Yochai, suggesting that if the Jewish people were to properly observe two Sabbaths, they would be redeemed immediately. The text highlights a theological tension regarding the interpretation of the term "Sabbaths," with the Jerusalem Talmud implying that even the observance of one Sabbath could lead to redemption, while the Babylonian Talmud emphasizes the necessity of two. This reflects a deeper Hasidic concept of the transformative power of Sabbath observance in the spiritual and communal life of Israel.

passage_content: וק"ז הישמח משה זלה"ה (בפ' תשא) כתב לתרץ קושיא זו ותו"ד דיסוד האי כללא שאמרו חכז"ל מיעוט רבים שנים, אף דלכאורה ראוי לן למיזל לחומרא ולומר שרבים משמעותו יותר משנים, אבל אם תרבה אין לו שיעור, ולא בא הכתוב לסתום אלא לפרש, והי"ל להכתוב לפרש כמה, ע"כ אוקמי' אמיעוטי' ומיעוט רבים שנים והיינו רק במקום שבוודאי יש לו סוף ושעור, אלא שאין ידוע כמה אז אמרינן מעוט רבים שנים, אבל במקום שבאמת אין לו סוף, א"כ לא בא הכתוב לסתום, דפירושו באמת לעולם, וא"ש דמ"ש אך את שבתותי תשמורו פירושו לעולם, אבל מ"ש ז"ל דאלמלא שמרו ישראל ב' שבתות מיד נגאלין ולמדו כן מדכתיב אשר ישמרו את שבתותי, ע"כ אין פירושו לעולם דכי עד עולם לא יגאלו ח"ו עד שישמרו כל שבתות עולם, א"ו יש בו שיעור ולא ידוע כמה, בזה אמרינן מעוט רבים שנים דלא בא הכתוב לסתום, ואם תאמר יותר הי"ל להכתוב לפרש, עכת"ד ז"ל.
translation: And so, Moshe, may his memory be blessed (in Parashat Tisa), wrote to resolve this question and the foundation of this principle that our Sages, may their memory be blessed, said regarding the minority of many being two. Even though it seems appropriate for us to be stringent and say that "many" means more than two, if there is an increase, it has no measure, and the scripture did not come to close off but to clarify. The scripture should have clarified how much, therefore we establish the minority and the minority of many as two, and this is only in a place where it certainly has an end and a measure, but it is not known how much, then we say the minority of many is two. However, in a place where it truly has no end, then the scripture did not come to close off, for its meaning is indeed forever. And it is clear that when it says, "But you shall keep My Sabbaths," it means forever. But when our Sages said that had Israel kept two Sabbaths they would have been redeemed immediately, and they learned this from the verse "which shall keep My Sabbaths," therefore its meaning is not forever, for if it were forever, they would not be redeemed, Heaven forbid, until they keep all the Sabbaths of the world. Rather, it has a measure, and it is not known how much, in this we say the minority of many is two, that the scripture did not come to close off. And if you say it would have been better for the scripture to clarify, thus concludes his words, may his memory be blessed.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of "minority among the majority" in the context of Jewish law, emphasizing that while the term "many" typically implies more than two, in certain cases it refers to a defined quantity. It highlights that the Torah does not intend to obscure meaning but rather to clarify it, particularly regarding the observance of Shabbat. The text suggests that the commandment to keep the Sabbath is eternal, yet the redemption of Israel is contingent upon the observance of specific Shabbatot, indicating a balance between the infinite and the finite in divine commandments.

passage_content: ויתבאר עוד בהקדם מ"ש ק"ז הישמח משה זלה"ה בפ' תשא) דכתבו המפורשים הטעם מ"ש חכז"ל שני שבתות דוקא, דלא הוי שבת אמיתי כמאמרם שביתה ביום השביעי, רק אם שומר מקודם שבת א'. וא"כ מתחילין אחריו ששת ימי המעשה ואח"כ שובת ביום השביעי, הרי קיים בזה מצות שבת כהלכתה, אבל שבת הראשון ששמר, אין זה יום השביעי אחר ששת ימי המעשה, רק אחר כמה מאות או אלפים ימי המעשה, ולא קיים המצוה כהלכתה, ופי' בזה ושמרו בנ"י את השבת ר"ל שצריכין לשמור שבת א', לעשות את השבת, ר"ל כדי שיעשו את השבת האחר לשבת אמיתי ואז לדורותיכם לברית עולם, ובזכות זה יהיו נגאלין ויהי' כולו שבת עכדה"ק.
translation: And it will be further explained in advance what is written in K.Z. (Kedushat Zvi) that Moshe, may his memory be blessed, rejoiced in Parashat Tisa, that the commentators wrote the reason for what our sages said about two Shabbatot specifically, that it is not a true Shabbat according to their statement of resting on the seventh day, only if one observes from before Shabbat One. And therefore, they begin after it with six days of work, and then rest on the seventh day, thus fulfilling the commandment of Shabbat properly. However, the first Shabbat that he observed is not the seventh day after six days of work, but rather after several hundreds or thousands of days of work, and he did not fulfill the commandment properly. And the explanation of this is, "And the children of Israel shall observe the Shabbat," meaning that they need to observe Shabbat One, to make the Shabbat, meaning in order to make the other Shabbat a true Shabbat, and then for your generations as an everlasting covenant, and in merit of this they will be redeemed, and it will all be Shabbat, blessed be His Name.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of observing two Shabbatot, emphasizing that true rest on the seventh day can only be achieved if one first observes the initial Shabbat properly. It highlights that the first Shabbat is not a true seventh day if it follows an extended period of work, thus failing to fulfill the commandment as intended. The text underscores the importance of preparing for Shabbat to ensure that the subsequent Shabbat is a genuine day of rest, which is essential for the Jewish people's covenant and future redemption, ultimately leading to a complete state of spiritual rest.

passage_content: ומעתה לא יקשה קושית המראה פנים, ולא יהי' סתירה בין הבבלי והירושלמי, דבאמת אלו שמרו ישראל שבת א' מיד נגאלין כמ"ש בירושלמי, וגם הבבלי סובר כן, ומ"ש במס' שבת הנ"ל דצריך שני שבתות, הוא לטעם הנ"ל דא"א שיהי' שבת א' כהלכתה, אא"כ יקדים לה עוד שבת כדי שיהי' שמירת שבת ביום השביעי שאחר ששת ימי המעשה, ומתורץ ג"כ קושית המהרש"א ז"ל דבאמת ע"י שמירת שבת א' מיד נגאלין ונדרש כן ממ"ש שבת היום כמ"ש בירושלמי, ומ"ש שני שבתות היינו טעמא משום דא"א שיהי' שמירת שבת כהלכתה, בלתי אם יקדים לה שבת א', אבל לא הכריחו כן מדכתיב שבתות ומיעוט רבים שנים, ול"ק קושית המהרש"א ז"ל.
translation: And from now on, the question of the appearance of faces will not be difficult, and there will be no contradiction between the Babylonian and Jerusalem Talmuds, for in truth, if Israel observes one Shabbat, they are immediately redeemed, as it is stated in the Jerusalem Talmud. The Babylonian Talmud also holds this view, and what is stated in the aforementioned tractate of Shabbat that two Shabbatot are required is for the reason that it is impossible for there to be one Shabbat observed properly unless another Shabbat is observed beforehand, so that the observance of Shabbat is on the seventh day after the six days of work. The question of the Maharsha is also resolved, for indeed, through the observance of one Shabbat, they are immediately redeemed, and this is derived from what is stated, "Shabbat today," as mentioned in the Jerusalem Talmud. And when it says two Shabbatot, this is the reason because it is impossible for there to be a proper observance of Shabbat unless another Shabbat is observed beforehand. However, they did not derive this from the fact that it is written "Shabbatot" and the minority of the plural is two, and the question of the Maharsha is not difficult.
summary: The passage discusses the relationship between the Babylonian and Jerusalem Talmuds regarding the observance of Shabbat and its connection to redemption. It emphasizes that if the Jewish people observe one Shabbat properly, they will be redeemed immediately, as stated in the Jerusalem Talmud. The Babylonian Talmud's requirement for two Shabbatot is explained as a necessity for ensuring that the first Shabbat is observed correctly, thereby facilitating the proper observance of the seventh day following six days of work. Ultimately, the text reconciles apparent contradictions by affirming that both Talmuds agree on the significance of Shabbat in the context of redemption.

passage_content: ובזה יתורץ קושית האוהחה"ק במאמה"כ דרך שלשת ימים נלך דאפשר שמעיקרא הי' יציאתם רק על ג' ימים, דהנה בעשור לחודש שמרו ישראל שבת ראשונה כהלכתה בצירוף התשובה, כמ"ש הטו"ז דצריך שמירת שבת בצירוף תשובה, אולם עדיין חסרו להם ששת ימי המעשה, דא"א שמירת שבת כהלכתה מבלי שיקדים לה ששת ימי המעשה, וע"כ הי' צורך לזכות גאולתם עוד שמירת שבת א', והנה כשיצאו ישראל ממצרים חמישי בשבת הי' וביום ג' שלאחר יציאתם שבת הי', ע"כ מתחלה יצאו רק על ג' ימים. והי' תלוי זכות גאולתם בשבת הבאה, וכששמרו שבת שני' כתיקונה נגאלו לחלוטין ואלולי כן היו מוכרחים לחזור למצרים אחר ג' ימים, נמצא דמ"ש נלכה נא דרך שלשת ימים, האמת כן הי' בשעת אמירתם, ולא הי' בזה רמאות ושקר חלילה והבוי"ת מגיד מראשית אחרית ידע מתחלה שישמרו שבת שני' כהלכתה, וע"כ לא נזכר במאמר השי"ת הזמן של ג' ימים, כי היתה ידיעה אצלו שלא יחזרו לסוף ג' ימים למצרים, אבל זקני ישראל הם שאמרו לפרעה נלכה נא דרך ג' ימים כי כן הי' התנאי בשעת יציאתם כנ"ל.
translation: And with this, the question of the holy Baal Shem Tov is resolved regarding the statement, "We will go a three-day journey," that it is possible that initially their departure was only for three days. For on the tenth of the month, Israel observed the first Shabbat properly, along with repentance, as the Taz writes that Shabbat observance must be accompanied by repentance. However, they still lacked the six days of work, for it is impossible to observe Shabbat properly without first having the six days of work. Therefore, there was a need to merit their redemption through another Shabbat observance. And behold, when Israel left Egypt, it was on a Friday, and the following Tuesday was Shabbat, thus initially they left only for three days. Their redemption was dependent on the next Shabbat, and when they observed the second Shabbat properly, they were completely redeemed; otherwise, they would have been compelled to return to Egypt after three days. It turns out that what they said, "Let us go a three-day journey," was indeed true at the time of their statement, and there was no deception or falsehood, heaven forbid. The Holy One, Blessed be He, who declares the end from the beginning, knew from the outset that they would observe the second Shabbat properly. Therefore, the time of three days was not mentioned in the statement of the Holy One, Blessed be He, because it was known to Him that they would not return to Egypt after three days. Rather, it was the elders of Israel who said to Pharaoh, "Let us go a three-day journey," for that was the condition at the time of their departure, as mentioned above.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the Israelites' initial request to Pharaoh to journey three days into the wilderness, emphasizing that their eventual redemption was contingent upon their observance of the Sabbath. It highlights the necessity of preparing for the Sabbath through six days of work, suggesting that their first observance of the Sabbath was crucial for their complete liberation. The text asserts that this request was sincere and not deceitful, as God, in His foreknowledge, understood that the Israelites would indeed keep the Sabbath properly, ensuring their ultimate freedom from Egypt.

passage_content: ואפשר דע"י ששמרו ישראל שבת שני' כהלכתה ובצירוף תשובה הגונה נעשו ישראל קודש לה', ומעתה דינם של המצרים להיות לוקים ומשלמים על ידיהם, ומתחלה הי' ההכרח ליקח מידם הרכוש בתורת שאלה כמו שכתבנו לעיל, ואחר שנעשו קודש זכו בה ועכבוהו בתורת תשלומין, ויובן בזה מה שפירש"י ז"ל בשם המכילתא ויסע משה את ישראל מים סוף, הסיען בעל כרחן שלא רצו לפרוש מפני ביזת הים שהי' גדולה מאוד והוצרך להסיען בע"כ, ולכאורה קשה ממ"ש ז"ל (במס' ברכות דף ז') דבר נא באזני העם וישאלו איש מאת רעהו וגו' אין נא אלא לשון בקשה, בבקשה ממך הזהירם על כך שלא יאמר אותו צדיק אברהם ואח"כ יצאו ברכוש גדול לא קיים בהם, הרי שלא רצו ליטול הרכוש והוצרך לבקשם ולהזהירם, ומדוע נשתנה רצונם בביזת הים שלא רצו לפרוש ממנה, ולדרכינו א"ש כי מתחלה הוכרחו ליטלו בדרך שאלה דייקא וע"כ לא הי' רצונם לקבלו, כי למה להם להטריח ברכוש שאינה שלהם. אבל בקריעת ים סוף שזכו בה בתורת תשלומין להיות מוחלטת אצלם, שכבר הי' דינם כקודש להיות המצריים לוקין ומשלמין, מעתה לקחוהו ברצון לבם.
translation: And it is possible that by keeping the Sabbath properly, along with a sincere repentance, the Jewish people became holy to the Lord. From now on, the Egyptians are to be punished and pay for their actions. Initially, it was necessary to take the possessions from them as a loan, as we wrote above. But after they became holy, they merited to keep it as a payment. This can be understood from what Rashi, of blessed memory, explained in the name of the Mechilta: "And Moses led the Israelites from the Sea of Reeds," he led them against their will because they did not want to depart due to the great spoils of the sea, and he had to lead them forcibly. At first glance, it is difficult to understand what our sages said (in Berakhot 7): "Speak now in the ears of the people, and let them ask each man from his neighbor," for "now" is only a term of request, as if he was asking them to be careful not to let that righteous one, Abraham, say, and then they would leave with great wealth, which would not be fulfilled in them. Thus, they did not want to take the possessions, and he had to ask and warn them. Why then did their desire change regarding the spoils of the sea, where they did not want to depart from it? According to our approach, it is clear that initially, they were compelled to take it as a loan, and therefore they did not want to accept it, for why should they trouble themselves with possessions that were not theirs? But at the splitting of the Sea of Reeds, they merited it as a payment, which was absolute for them, since their judgment was as holy, with the Egyptians being punished and paying. From then on, they took it willingly with their hearts.
summary: The passage discusses the transformation of the Israelites into a holy people through their observance of the Sabbath and sincere repentance, which allowed them to rightfully claim the wealth of the Egyptians. Initially, they were compelled to take the riches as a loan, reflecting their reluctance to accept what did not belong to them. However, after the miraculous event of the splitting of the Red Sea, they were deemed worthy and could joyfully accept the wealth as a rightful payment, as the Egyptians were now punished for their actions. This shift illustrates the theological concept of divine justice and the elevation of the Israelites' status through their faithfulness.

passage_content: באופן אחר אפשר לתרץ קושית האוהחה"ק הנ"ל, עפי"מ דאיתא בפסיקתא הנ"ל דישראל היו בתורת פקדון במצרים כמ"ש פקד פקדתי אתכם וגו' והדין בשומר ששלח יד בפקדון ושינה מדעת הבעלים שחייב לשלם הנזק ולהחזיר את הפקדון מיד, שיכולים הבעלים לומר אינך נאמן עוד על השמירה, ואפי' בשואל ששאל על זמן קצוב ואין ביד הבעלים להחזירו מידו עד סוף ימי השאלה, אבל אם שלח בה יד ושינה מדעת הבעלים. דבר פשוט שיכולין הבעלים להחזירו מידו לפני תשלום הזמן. כי אינו נאמן על שמירתו, ובזה יתבאר דמתחלה בשליחות הראשונה אמרו לפרעה דרך שלשת ימים נלך והי' האמת כן כי הי' תליא גאולתם בזכות המעשים כנ"ל, אבל אחר שסירב כ"כ ולא רצה לשלחם במצות השי"ת אף על ג' ימים, הי' שולח יד בפקדון ושינה מדעת הבעלים ופסקה שמירתו והפקדון חזרה לבעלים הראשונים, וע"כ נעשו בן חורין לחלוטין, ולא חזרו אליו אחר ג' ימים.
translation: In another way, one can explain the question of the aforementioned holy author, according to what is stated in the aforementioned Pesikta that Israel was in a state of deposit in Egypt, as it is written, "I have surely remembered you," etc. The law regarding a guardian who misappropriates a deposit and alters it against the will of the owners is that he is obligated to pay for the damage and return the deposit immediately, as the owners can say, "You are no longer trustworthy regarding the guarding." This applies even to a borrower who borrowed for a fixed time and the owners cannot reclaim it from him until the end of the borrowing period. However, if he misappropriated it and altered it against the will of the owners, it is clear that the owners can reclaim it from him before the time of payment, for he is not trustworthy regarding its guarding. In this way, it can be explained that initially, in the first mission, they told Pharaoh, "We will go for three days," and this was indeed true, for their redemption was dependent on the merit of their deeds, as mentioned. But after he refused so much and did not want to send them for the command of the Holy One, blessed be He, even for three days, he misappropriated the deposit and altered it against the will of the owners, and his guarding ceased, and the deposit returned to the original owners. Therefore, they became completely free and did not return to him after three days.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of Israel's status in Egypt as a "deposit" and the implications of Pharaoh's refusal to release them. It explains that when a guardian (Pharaoh) misappropriates a deposit (the Israelites) against the owner's (God's) will, the owner can reclaim it immediately, signifying that Israel's liberation was contingent upon their actions and Pharaoh's refusal invalidated his claim. Consequently, Israel became completely free and was not bound to return after three days, highlighting the theological principle of divine justice and the relationship between human actions and divine redemption.

passage_content: והנה פרעה לא ידע דע"י זכות שמירת שבת וכח התשובה נגאלו לחלוטין, אבל חשב דרק בשביל שפשע מדעת הבעלים וסירב מלשלחם, ע"כ נפסקה שמירתו ולא חזרו לידו, ולזה התחרט על מה שסירב ולא אבה לשלחם על שלשת ימים, וחשב שאלמלי נתרצה לשלחם על ג' ימים ולא הי' מסרב לדברי השי"ת, היו חוזרים להתעכב בארצו עד כלות זמן הפקדון ד' מאות שנה, וזה שאמה"כ ויהפך לבב פרעה שהתחרט על מעשיו, מה שסירב לשמוע בשליחות השי"ת, ואמר מה זאת עשינו ר"ל לשלוח יד בפקדון, ועי"ז כי שלחנו את ישראל מעבדנו, וע"ד שדרשו חכז"ל ושלחה מי שמשלחה ואינה חוזרת, וז"ש כי שלחנו את ישראל, שאנחנו גרמנו ששלחנום לחלוטין ולא יחזרו עוד.
translation: And behold, Pharaoh did not know that through the merit of observing the Sabbath and the power of repentance, they were completely redeemed. Rather, he thought that it was only because he transgressed against the will of the owners and refused to send them away, therefore his protection was severed and they did not return to him. For this reason, he regretted what he had refused and was unwilling to send them away for three days, and he thought that had he consented to send them away for three days and not refused the words of the Holy One, blessed be He, they would have remained in his land until the completion of the time of the deposit of four hundred years. This is as it is written, "And the heart of Pharaoh was changed," that he regretted his actions, that he refused to listen to the mission of the Holy One, blessed be He, and said, "What is this we have done," meaning to lay a hand on the deposit, and as a result, by sending away Israel from our servitude, and according to what our Sages, of blessed memory, have said, "And he sent away one who sends away and does not return," as it is said, "For we have sent away Israel," that we caused them to be sent away completely and not to return again.
summary: The passage discusses Pharaoh's failure to recognize that the Israelites' redemption was due to the merit of observing the Sabbath and the power of repentance. Instead, he believed that his refusal to release them for three days led to their permanent departure. This reflects a deeper theological insight that by resisting God's command, Pharaoh inadvertently facilitated the Israelites' complete liberation, illustrating the concept that divine will prevails despite human opposition. Ultimately, Pharaoh's regret signifies a recognition of the consequences of his actions against God's plan.

passage_content: ובזה יתבאר דברי המדרש שהתחלנו בפתח דברינו, מי צווח ווי פרעה צווח ווי משל למלך וכו' כך פרעה אמר כשהיו ישראל אצלו, הי' הקב"ה משלח לו אגרות בכל שעה, כה אמר ד' שלח עמי וגו' הכוונה בזה כי פרעה הי' סבור שאלמלי היה משלחם על ג' ימים ולא הי' מסרב, היו ישראל חוזרים לארצו עד כלות הזמן של ד' מאות שנה ובכל פעם שהי' רצון השי"ת שיזבחו לפניו במדבר, הי' משלח אליו אגרות ושליחים לאמר שלח עמי ויחוגו לי במדבר, וא"ש מה שהתחרט פרעה וצווח ווי, והמשל דומה לנמשל.
translation: And this will clarify the words of the Midrash that we began with at the opening of our discourse, "Who cried 'Woe' like Pharaoh, cried 'Woe' like a parable of a king, etc." Thus, Pharaoh said when the Israelites were with him, the Holy One, blessed be He, was sending him letters at all times, saying, "So says the Lord, 'Let My people go,' etc." The intention here is that Pharaoh thought that if he were to send them away for three days and not refuse, the Israelites would return to their land by the end of the four hundred years. And every time the Blessed One desired that they should offer sacrifices to Him in the desert, He would send him letters and messengers to say, "Let My people go, and they shall celebrate to Me in the desert." And it is understood why Pharaoh regretted and cried 'Woe,' and the parable is similar to the lesson.
summary: The passage discusses the idea that Pharaoh, when confronted with the Israelites' request for freedom, believed that if he allowed them to leave for just three days, they would return to their land by the end of the 400 years of servitude. However, God continually sent messages urging Pharaoh to let the Israelites go so they could worship Him in the desert. Pharaoh's eventual regret and cries of despair reflect a deeper understanding of divine will and the inevitability of Israel's liberation, illustrating the tension between human authority and divine purpose.

passage_content: ומעתה יובן דברי המדרש הנ"ל הה"ד ברוב עוזך יכחשו לך אויביך וכו' ר' ברכיה אמר יעשו כזבים בדבריהם כענין שנא' וכחש בעמיתו, הכוונה בזה דע"י שאמר גם את ישראל לא אשלח שלח יד בפקדון, וע"כ דרשו חכז"ל יכחשו מלשון וכחש בעמיתו ר"ל שהכחש האמור כאן הכוונה ששלח יד בפקדון כמ"ש וכחש בעמיתו בפקדון, וע"כ סיימו במדרש בשביל שאמר וגם את ישראל לא אשלח, אח"כ הוא הי' מחזיר על פתחיהן של ישראל וא"ל צאי לשלום, ונשתחררו מתחת ידו לחלוטין, וזה כוונת הפסיקתא שהביא לכאן האי דינא דשולח יד בפקדון, דפרעה שלח יד בפקדונו ולכך הוציא השי"ת את ישראל מתחת ידו, וע"כ צווח פרעה ווי, כי התחרט על מה ששלח יד בהם, וא"ש קישור דרשא זו לכאן.
translation: And from now on, the words of the aforementioned Midrash will be understood, as it is said, "In the abundance of Your strength, Your enemies will deny You," etc. Rabbi Berachiah said they will make falsehoods in their words, as it is stated, "And he denied his fellow." The intention here is that by saying, "I will not send away Israel," he sent forth his hand upon the deposit. Therefore, our Sages derived that "they will deny" is from the language of "and he denied his fellow," meaning that the denial mentioned here refers to sending forth his hand upon the deposit, as it is written, "and he denied his fellow regarding the deposit." Thus, they concluded in the Midrash that because he said, "I will not send away Israel," afterwards he was returning to the doorways of Israel and said to them, "Go in peace," and they were completely freed from his hand. This is the intention of the Pesikta that brought here the law of sending forth a hand upon the deposit, for Pharaoh sent forth his hand upon his deposit, and therefore the Holy One, blessed be He, took Israel out from under his hand. Hence, Pharaoh cried out, "Woe," because he regretted having sent forth his hand against them. And this connects the interpretation of this teaching here.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of divine justice and protection over Israel, emphasizing that when Pharaoh wrongfully seized what belonged to Israel, God intervened and liberated them. The reference to "כחש בעמיתו" (deceit against a fellow) highlights the moral implications of betrayal and wrongful possession. Ultimately, the text illustrates that God's commitment to Israel's safety leads to their complete release from oppression, showcasing the theme of divine retribution against those who harm His people. This reflects a broader Hasidic understanding of God's active role in safeguarding the righteous.

passage_content: באופן אחר אפ"ל דברי המדרשים והדקדוקים הנ"ל בהקדם דברי התנחומא ופרעה הקריב וגו' הקריב את ישראל לתשובה, כיון שראו ששבו ישראל לאחוריהם וחנו לפני פי החירות לפני בעל צפון. אמר פרעה בעל צפון הסכים על גזרתי לאבדם במים, התחיל לזבח לקטר ולנסך לע"ז לכך נאמר ופרעה הקריב עכ"ד המדרש, וצ"ב דרישי' לאו סיפי'. דברישא דרשו הקריב את ישראל לתשובה, וסיום דבריהם הקריב לע"ז והול"ל דבר אחר לחלק ביניהם. ומדערבינהו נראה דיש קישור ביניהם וצ"ב הקישור.
translation: In another way, one can say the words of the Midrashim and the grammatical interpretations mentioned above, in advance of the words of the Tanchuma: "And Pharaoh drew near," etc. "He drew the Israelites to repentance," for when they saw that the Israelites had turned back and encamped before the mouth of freedom, before Baal Tzafon, Pharaoh, Baal Tzafon, agreed to my decree to destroy them in the waters. He began to offer sacrifices, to incense, and to libate to idolatry. Therefore, it is said, "And Pharaoh drew near," thus concludes the Midrash. However, it is puzzling why they did not conclude with a different interpretation. In the beginning, they interpreted "He drew the Israelites to repentance," and at the end of their words, they interpreted "to idolatry," and it should have been stated differently to differentiate between them. From their understanding, it seems there is a connection between them, and the connection is puzzling.
summary: The passage discusses the dual interpretations of Pharaoh's actions in relation to the Israelites' repentance. Initially, it highlights that Pharaoh's recognition of the Israelites returning to God prompted him to bring them closer to repentance. However, it contrasts this with his subsequent turn to idolatry, suggesting a deeper connection between the two interpretations. The text invites reflection on the relationship between repentance and the allure of false worship, emphasizing the complexity of spiritual choices faced by individuals.
