passage_content: ויתבאר כל הענין עפימ"ש במכילתא דאלמלי זכו ישראל היו נגאלים במצרים גאולה לדורות שאין אחרי' גלות עוד, אלא שלא היתה זכותם מספקת לכך וע"כ היתה רק גאולה לשעה, ונקדים מ"ש בספה"ק קדושת לוי זלה"ה לפרש אומרם ז"ל (פסחים קי"ח ע"ב) הללו את ה' כל גוים אגבורות ונפלאות דעביד בהדייהו, כל שכן אנו דגבר עלינו חסדו ולכאורה דברי רז"ל נעלמים מאתנו וכו', הלא מקרא כתיב או הנסה אלקים לבוא לקחת לו גוי מקרב גוי, בזה עיקר הבטחותינו שהבוי"ת מראה גודל אהבתו ותשוקתו לעמו בית ישראל שבכל דור ודור עושה לנו נסים ונפלאות ומשלם גמול לכל אויבי נפשינו, וחלילה לומר שהשי"ת עושה להם נסים ונפלאות, ותוכן תירוצו דע"י הכאות הרשעים שהבוי"ת עושה בהם דין, נתגדל ונתקדש שמו ית' בעולם, וזה באמת טובה גדולה גם להם דמאתו לא תצא רעה כתיב, וכאשר יפקחו עיניהם יראו גודל התועלת המגיע להם, רק הרשעים הם ערלי לב ולבם אטום מהבין זאת וכו', וז"פ הגמרא דבאמת אין הקב"ה עושה נסים ונפלאות רק לישראל עם קרובו. ולאומה"ע מכה אותם השי"ת בעונשין וגואל את ישראל מתוכם, ועי"ז נתקדש ש"ש וצריכים הם להלל את השי"ת מה שנתקדש על ידם ש"ש וז"פ הללו את ה' כל גוים אנסים ונפלאות שעושה הקב"ה עם ישראל ונפרע להם מכל צריהם הוא בהדייהו, כלומר שאלו הנסים והטובות הם מחמתם, שע"י הכאתם נעשה נסים לישראל ונתקדש ש"ש על ידם, ולעתיד גם האומות ישמחו ויהללו וישבחו לה' על החסד שעושה לישראל, וכמו שפי' בספר בינה לעתים (דרוש י"ט) עה"פ הנ"ל הללו את ה' כל גוים וגו' כי גבר עלינו חסדו, וקשה ראובן בשמחה שמעון מה איכפת לי' ואיך יצוה לגוים שיהללו וישבחו על כי גבר עלינו חסדו, ותי' שטובה ותועלת גדולה נמשך לאומות ממה שעושה הקב"ה נסים ונפלאות לישראל, כי בעודנו בגלות אין השגחתו ית' מתפרסמת ולא ניכר אלקותו האמיתי אצל הכל, כי הם נעדרי ידיעתו, אבל לעתיד ע"י גאולת ישראל תתפרסם גדולתו ויכלתו, וכל העולם יכירו וידעו כי אמת מלכינו ואפס זולתו, היש תועלת גדול מזה לעוורים לא ראו אור, ולזה אמר אתם הגוים הללו ושבחו שמו ית', על כי גבר עלינו חסדו להוציאנו מאפילה לאורה, כי הלא ע"י חסד זה ואמת ה' לעולם: האמת הגמור מאלקותו ית' מתפשט לעולם בכללי כי כולם יכירהו, וכיון שכן גם אתם חייבים להללו ולשבחו ע"כ דבריו.
translation: And the entire matter will be clarified according to what is said in the Mechilta: Had the Jewish people merited, they would have been redeemed in Egypt with a redemption for all generations, with no subsequent exile. However, their merit was not sufficient for that, and therefore it was only a temporary redemption. We will precede with what is stated in the holy book Kedushas Levi, may his merit protect us, to explain the words of our sages, of blessed memory (Pesachim 118b): "Praise the Lord, all you nations; praise Him for His mighty deeds and wonders that He has done with them." All the more so for us, who have been favored by His kindness. And seemingly, the words of our sages are hidden from us, etc. Is it not written: "Or has God attempted to go and take for Himself a nation from the midst of another nation?" This is the essence of our promises, that the Blessed One shows the greatness of His love and desire for His people, the House of Israel, that in every generation He performs miracles and wonders for us and repays all our enemies. And it is forbidden to say that the Holy One, blessed be He, performs miracles and wonders for them. The essence of your answer is that through the punishments of the wicked, which the Blessed One administers to them, His name is magnified and sanctified in the world. And this is indeed a great benefit for them, for from Him no evil will come, as it is written. And when their eyes are opened, they will see the great benefit that comes to them; only the wicked are uncircumcised in heart, and their hearts are hardened to understand this, etc. Thus, the Gemara indeed states that the Holy One, blessed be He, does not perform miracles and wonders except for Israel, His close nation. And for the nations of the world, the Holy One punishes them, and redeems Israel from among them. And through this, His name is sanctified, and they must praise the Holy One for the sanctification of His name through them. Thus, "Praise the Lord, all you nations; for the mighty deeds and wonders that the Holy One does with Israel, and He exacts retribution from all their oppressors, is with them," meaning that these miracles and benefits are because of them, that through their punishment, miracles are done for Israel, and His name is sanctified through them. In the future, even the nations will rejoice and praise and glorify the Lord for the kindness He does for Israel, as explained in the book Bina Le'itim (Drush 19) on the above verse: "Praise the Lord, all you nations, etc., for His kindness has prevailed over us." And it is difficult: Reuven, in joy; Shimon, what does it matter to him? And how can he command the nations to praise and glorify for His kindness that has prevailed over us? The answer is that a great benefit and advantage comes to the nations from what the Holy One does, miracles and wonders for Israel, for while we are in exile, His providence is not revealed, and His true divinity is not apparent to all, for they lack knowledge of Him. But in the future, through the redemption of Israel, His greatness and power will be revealed, and the whole world will recognize and know that our King is true, and there is none besides Him. Is there a greater benefit than this for the blind who have not seen light? Therefore, He said: "You, the nations, praise His name," for His kindness has prevailed over us to bring us from darkness to light, for through this kindness and the truth of the Lord is forever: the complete truth of His divinity will spread throughout the world universally, for all will recognize Him. And since this is so, you too are obligated to praise and glorify Him; thus are His words.
summary: The passage discusses the nature of divine redemption and the relationship between God and the Jewish people, emphasizing that Israel's redemption from Egypt was a temporary measure due to insufficient merit. It highlights that God's miracles and kindness towards Israel serve to sanctify His name in the world, and that even the nations will ultimately recognize and praise God for the benefits they receive through Israel's redemption. The text asserts that God's true greatness and presence will be revealed through the future redemption, leading all nations to acknowledge His sovereignty and the goodness of His actions towards Israel.

passage_content: וכתב הרמב"ם ז"ל באגרת תימן שכשיבוא מלך המשיח, לא יצטרך ללחום עם מלכי האומות רק ע"י שיראו גודל חכמתו וקדושתו יהי' להם התבטלות נגדו בלי שום מלחמה, נמצא לפי"ז אלמלי הי' גאולת מצרים גאולה שלימה שהי' מציאות לזה כנ"ל, אז לא הי' מתחרט פרעה מה ששלח את ישראל מארצו, שהרי הי' משיג את גודל התועלת שהגיע גם אליו מה שנתקדש על ידו ש"ש, ורק מפני שלא הי' עדיין השלימות הגמור, לא באו האומות להשגה זו לראות האמת, ע"כ צווח ווי על ששלח את ישראל מארצו, ומבואר בספה"ק דאלמלי זכו ישראל אז לתיקון השלימות הי' משרע"ה נכנס לא"י עמהם, והי' הוא בונה ביהמ"ק ולא הי' נחרב לעולם דלא שלטו האויבים במעשה ידיו, נמצא דמה שלא נכנס משרע"ה לא"י מיד, מפני שלא הגיעו ישראל לתכלית השלימות עדיין.
translation: The Rambam, may his memory be blessed, wrote in the Letter to Yemen that when the Messiah comes, he will not need to wage war against the kings of the nations; rather, by the greatness of his wisdom and holiness, they will be nullified before him without any battle. Thus, according to this, had the redemption from Egypt been a complete redemption, which had the potential for this as mentioned, then Pharaoh would not have regretted sending the Israelites out of his land, for he would have realized the great benefit that came to him from the sanctification that occurred through him, blessed be His Name. And only because the complete perfection had not yet been achieved, the nations did not come to this understanding to see the truth. Therefore, he cried out, "Woe to me for having sent the Israelites out of my land." It is explained in the holy books that had the Israelites merited the rectification of completeness at that time, Moses would have entered the Land of Israel with them, and he would have built the Holy Temple, which would never have been destroyed, for the enemies would not have had power over the work of his hands. Thus, the reason Moses did not enter the Land of Israel immediately was because the Israelites had not yet reached the ultimate perfection.
summary: The passage discusses the teachings of the Rambam regarding the Messianic era, emphasizing that the Messiah will not need to wage war against nations, as they will recognize his wisdom and holiness, leading to their submission without conflict. It reflects on the incomplete redemption during the Exodus, suggesting that had the Israelites achieved full spiritual rectification, Pharaoh would not have regretted releasing them, understanding the benefits of their sanctification. The text implies that Moses' failure to enter the Promised Land was due to the Israelites not reaching their ultimate spiritual perfection at that time, which would have allowed for a lasting Temple and protection from enemies.

passage_content: ובזה יתיישבו דברי המדרשים הנ"ל פרעה צווח ווי, ואידך דברי המדרש משה אמר ווי על שאינו נכנס עמהן לארץ ושניהן על קוטב א' יסובבו, דמפני שלא נחם אלקים דרך ארץ פלשתים, מטעם פן ינחם העם וגו' ושבו מצרימה, ה"ז מורה שלא הגיעו ישראל עדיין לשלימות האמיתי, ומה"ט משה צווח ווי על שלא יכנס לארץ, וגם פרעה צווח ווי על ששלחם, ואלמלי הי' תיקון השלימות מיד, הי' שש ושמח על כי גבר עלינו חסדו ית' כנ"ל. ויתבאר בזה גם דברי המכילתא הנ"ל כי קרוב הוא קרובה השבועה שנשבע אברהם אבינו לאבימלך וכו' ועדיין נכדו קיים, והוא מקושר עם טעם הכתוב פן ינחם העם וגו' דאלמלי זכו ישראל לתיקון השלימות היו הפלשתים בעצמם מבטלים השבועה. דהנשבע על דעת חבירו אינו יכול להתיר שבועתו שלא בפניו, אבל על דעת המודר יכול להתיר, ואז היו כל האומות מכירין שגדולתם של ישראל טובה ותועלת גם להם ובל"ס היו מוותרין על השבועה, אלא מפני שהי' קיים החשש זה פן ינחם העם וגו' ושבו מצרימה, וכמו שאמרו אח"כ נתנה ראש ונשובה מצרימה, ודרשו רז"ל אין ראש אלא ע"ז, ע"כ לא זכו לגאולה נצחיות מיד ומה"ט כח השבועה עדיין במקומה עומדת, ולז"א במכילתא קרובה השבועה שנשבע אאע"ה וכו' ועדיין נכדו קיים, והוא טעם א' עם טעם המפורש בפסוק פן ינחם העם וגו'.
translation:
And with this, the words of the aforementioned Midrashim are clarified: Pharaoh cried "Woe," and on the other hand, the words of the Midrash state that Moses said "Woe" for not entering the land with them, and both are revolving around one pole. This is because God did not lead them by the way of the land of the Philistines, for fear that the people would have a change of heart and return to Egypt. This indicates that Israel had not yet reached true completeness. For this reason, Moses cried "Woe" for not entering the land, and Pharaoh cried "Woe" for having sent them away. Had the rectification of completeness occurred immediately, he would have been joyful and happy that God's kindness had prevailed over us, as mentioned above. 

This also explains the words of the aforementioned Mekilta, that the oath which Abraham our father swore to Abimelech is close, and his descendant still exists. This is connected to the reason stated in the verse, "for fear that the people would have a change of heart," for had Israel merited the rectification of completeness, the Philistines themselves would have nullified the oath. For one who swears on behalf of another cannot annul his oath without the presence of the one he swore for, but on behalf of one who is prohibited, he can annul it. Then all the nations would recognize that the greatness of Israel is good and beneficial for them, and certainly they would have waived the oath. However, because this concern existed, "for fear that the people would have a change of heart," and they would return to Egypt, as they later said, "Let us appoint a leader and return to Egypt," and our Sages interpreted that "there is no leader except for idolatry," therefore they did not merit an eternal redemption immediately, and for this reason, the power of the oath still stands in its place. And this is what is meant in the Mekilta, that the oath which Abraham our father swore is close, and his descendant still exists, which is one reason along with the reason explicitly stated in the verse, "for fear that the people would have a change of heart."
summary: The passage discusses the interconnectedness of the suffering of both Pharaoh and Moses, each lamenting their respective fates regarding the Israelites' journey to the Promised Land. It emphasizes that the Israelites had not yet achieved true spiritual completeness, which is why Moses mourned his inability to enter the land and Pharaoh lamented their departure. The text also highlights the significance of Abraham's oath to Abimelech, suggesting that had the Israelites attained their spiritual rectification, the Philistines would have nullified the oath, recognizing the inherent goodness of Israel's greatness. Ultimately, the passage reflects on the ongoing struggle and the conditions that delayed the Israelites' complete redemption.

passage_content: ועד"ז יתבארו דברי המדרשים הנ"ל בענין קרי"ס, בהקדם מה שפירשתי בספרי ויואל משה (מאמר א' סי' כ"ד) מ"ש רז"ל (כתובות קי"א ע"א) שהשביע הקב"ה את ישראל שלא ידחקו את הקץ פירש"י ז"ל שלא ירבו בתחנונים על כך יותר מדאי, וק"ז זלה"ה בתפלה למשה (סי' קכ"ז) ובפי' על שה"ש עמד בדברי רש"י אלו דאינו מובן מה הוא הגבול של בקשת רחמים ומה נקרא יותר מדאי, ועו"ק למה לא מצינו בדברי הפוסקים שיזהירו שלא להפציר בתפלה על הגאולה, עיי"ש שפי' לדרכו, והנלפענ"ד עפי"ד הגמ' ב"מ (דף פ"ה ע"ב) אלי' הוה שכיח במתיבתא דרבי, יומא חד הוה נגה לי' ולא אתא, א"ל מאי טעמא נגה לי' למר א"ל אדאוקימנא לאברהם ומשינא ידי' ומצלי ומגנינא לי' וכן ליצחק וכן ליעקב, ולוקמינהו בהדי הדדי, סברי תקפי ברחמי ומייתי לי' למשיח בלא זמני', א"ל ויש דוגמתן בעוה"ז, א"ל איכא ר' חייא ובניו, גזר רבי תעניתא אחתינהו לר' חייא ובניו, אמר משיב הרוח ונשב זיקא, אמר מוריד הגשם ואתא מיטרא: מטא למימר מחיה המתים רגש עלמא, אמרי ברקיעא מאן גלי רזיא בעלמא, אמרי אלי' וכו' אתא אידמי כדובא דנורא על בינייהו וטרדינהו, ופי' שם המהרש"א ז"ל דאתי לומר שלא אתי עדיין זמן המשיח עיי"ש, הרי מבואר שיש מדריגת צדיקים אשר להם הכח בתפלתם להביא משיח בלא זמני', אלא שמנעום מן השמים להתפלל תפלה כזו המכרחת ואתי אלי' וטרדינהו, ותפלה כזה הוא בגדר דחיקת הקץ, ולכן לא ביארו הפוסקים מהו הגבול של רבוי תחנונים יותר מדאי, דכח תפלה כזו המכרחת לא נמצא כ"א ביחידי סגולה כמו ר' חייא ובניו, ומשמרים אותם מן השמים שלא יבואו לידי כך כמ"ש בגמ', ומי שלא הגיע למעלה זו מותר לו להתפלל כמה שירצה ומצוה להתפלל ולאפושי ברחמי שימהר השי"ת ויגאלינו, עייש"ד באריכות.
translation: And similarly, the words of the aforementioned Midrashim regarding the matter of the reading of the Shema will be clarified, by first mentioning what I explained in my book Vayoeil Moshe (Article 1, Section 24) regarding what our Sages of blessed memory said (Ketubot 111a) that the Holy One, blessed be He, admonished Israel not to hasten the end. Rashi, of blessed memory, explained that they should not increase their supplications on this matter excessively, and this is also hinted at in the prayer of Moses (Section 127) and in the commentary on the Song of Songs, where he stood by these words of Rashi, which is not understood: what is the limit of requesting mercy and what is considered excessive? Furthermore, why do we not find in the words of the halachic authorities a warning against urging in prayer for redemption? There, he explained according to his way, and I believe that according to the Gemara in Bava Metzia (55b), it was common for Eliyahu to be in the study hall of Rabbi. One day, he was shining for him and did not come. He asked, "What is the reason that he was shining for the master?" He replied, "I was about to bring him to Abraham, and I changed my hands and prayed, and I protected him, and so for Isaac and for Jacob, and I established them together. They thought to be strong in mercy and bring him to the Messiah without a set time." He said, "And there are examples of them in this world." He said, "There is Rabbi Chiya and his sons." Rabbi decreed a fast for Rabbi Chiya and his sons. He said, "He who returns the wind, and it blew a storm." He said, "He who brings down the rain, and the rain came." When it came to say, "He who revives the dead," the world trembled. They said in the heavens, "Who revealed the secret in the world?" They said, "To Eliyahu," etc. A fire came and appeared like a lion among them and drove them away. And there, the Maharsha, of blessed memory, explained that this indicates that the time of the Messiah has not yet come. It is clear that there is a level of righteous individuals who have the power in their prayer to bring the Messiah without a set time, but they are prevented from Heaven from praying such a compelling prayer that would bring him and drive him away. Such a prayer falls under the category of hastening the end. Therefore, the halachic authorities did not clarify what the limit is for an excessive number of supplications, for the power of such a compelling prayer is found only in unique individuals like Rabbi Chiya and his sons, and they are guarded from Heaven so that they do not come to such a state, as stated in the Gemara. And one who has not reached this level is permitted to pray as much as he wishes, and it is a mitzvah to pray and to plead for mercy that the Holy One, blessed be He, should hasten and redeem us, as I have explained in detail.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of prayer and its limits regarding the redemption of Israel, emphasizing that while the Torah warns against excessive pleading for the end of days, there are exceptional righteous individuals, like Rabbi Chiya and his sons, who possess the unique ability to invoke the Messiah outside of the appointed time. However, the heavens prevent them from doing so to avoid forcing the end. For the general populace, it is encouraged to pray fervently for redemption, as such prayers are seen as a mitzvah and a means to invoke divine mercy. The text highlights the balance between human initiative in prayer and the divine timing of redemption.

passage_content: והנה משה רבינו וודאי הי' לו כח תפלה זו המכרחת כר' חייא ובניו, ואפשר שעד"ז היתה תפלת משרע"ה על ישראל בעמדם על שפת הים, כי ידע שינצלו ישראל מיד מצרים ולא יטבעו בים כי כבר הבטיחו הבוי"ת בהוציאך את העם ממצרים תעבדון את האלקים על ההר הזה, ובהכרח שיצילם השי"ת כדי שיהיו ראויים לקבל התורה ולהכניסם לא"י, אמנם רצה משרע"ה לפעול בתפלתו שתהי' גאולה נצחיות שאין אחרי' גלות עוד, ולא הניחוהו מן השמים דלא הי' עדיין זמנו, ולז"א לו הקב"ה מה תצעק אלי, וכפירש"י עלי הדבר תלוי ולא עליך, דענין הגאולה לא נמסר לשום נברא, כ"א ביד הבוית"ש לבדו ואפס בלתך גואלינו לימות המשיח. ולטעם זה מנעו מן השמים רצון צדיק ולא הרשוהו להתפלל תפלה המכרחת למהר הגאולה לפני זמנו.
translation: And behold, Moshe Rabbeinu certainly had the power of this prayer that compels like Rabbi Chiya and his sons, and it is possible that similarly was Moshe Rabbeinu's prayer for Israel as they stood by the edge of the sea, for he knew that Israel would be saved from the hand of Egypt and would not drown in the sea, for the Holy One, Blessed be He, had already promised, "When you bring the people out of Egypt, you shall serve God on this mountain." It was necessary that He would save them so that they would be worthy to receive the Torah and to bring them into the Land of Israel. However, Moshe Rabbeinu wanted to effect through his prayer a redemption that would be eternal, with no subsequent exile, but they did not allow him from the heavens, for his time had not yet come. Therefore, the Holy One, Blessed be He, said to him, "Why do you cry out to Me?" As Rashi explains, "The matter depends on Me and not on you," for the matter of redemption was not entrusted to any created being, but only in the hands of the Holy One, Blessed be He, and there is no other redeemer for us except for the days of the Messiah. For this reason, they prevented from the heavens the desire of the righteous and did not allow him to pray a prayer that compels for the redemption to come before its time.
summary: The passage discusses Moses' powerful prayer at the Red Sea, likening it to that of Rabbi Chiya and his sons, emphasizing that Moses knew the Israelites would be saved from Egypt as God had promised. However, he sought a permanent redemption without subsequent exile, which was not permitted by Heaven due to the timing not being right. God’s response to Moses, "Why do you cry out to Me?" indicates that the matter of redemption is solely in God's hands and not subject to human intervention. This reflects the Hasidic belief that ultimate redemption is divinely ordained and cannot be hastened by human prayer.

passage_content: וז"פ המדרש דבר אל בני ישראל ויסעו יסיעו הדבר מלבן, ר"ל שילמד לבנ"י דעת שדבר זה לעשות פעולה בענין הגאולה יסיעו מלבן ודעתם, וכמו שפירשתי אמרם ז"ל (סנהדרין צ"ז) אין בן דוד בא עד שיתייאשו מן הגאולה וכו', כי הא דר' זירא כי הוה משכח רבנן דמעסקי בי', (פירש"י לידע מתי יבוא) אמר להו במטותא בעינא מינייכו לא תרחקוה דתניא ג' באין בהיסח הדעת אלו הן משיח וכו' ולכאורה ה"ה מעיקרי האמונה להאמין בביאת המשיח ובזכות אמונה זו יהיו ישראל נגאלים, ואיך יובן אמרם ז"ל דאין ב"ד בא אלא בהיסח הדעת, אמנם הכוונה בזה שלא להיות ממחשבי קיצין ושלא לצייר בדעתינו שום מחשבה לקרב הגאולה ע"י פעולת אדם, רק לצפות ולחכות על ישועתו ית', ולקבוע בלבנו שאין בדעת האדם להשיג קץ הפלאות, וזהו בחי' היסח הדעת שאמרו רז"ל.
translation: And the Midrash says, "Speak to the children of Israel and they shall journey," meaning that one should teach the children of Israel the understanding that this matter is to take action regarding the redemption, to journey from their understanding. And as I have explained, our sages of blessed memory said (Sanhedrin 97) that the Messiah does not come until they despair of the redemption, etc. For this is like the case of Rabbi Zeira, who when he would find the sages engaged in this matter (as Rashi explains, to know when he would come), said to them, "I request of you not to distance yourselves," for it is taught that three come without warning, these are the Messiah, etc. And seemingly, this is one of the fundamentals of faith, to believe in the coming of the Messiah, and through the merit of this faith, Israel will be redeemed. But how can we understand the statement of our sages of blessed memory that the Messiah comes only when there is a distraction of thought? However, the intention here is not to be among those who calculate the end and not to conceive in our minds any thought to bring the redemption through human action, but rather to anticipate and wait for His salvation, blessed be He, and to establish in our hearts that it is beyond human understanding to grasp the end of wonders. And this is the aspect of the distraction of thought that our sages have spoken of.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of redemption in Hasidic thought, emphasizing that the Jewish people must cultivate a mindset of waiting for divine salvation rather than attempting to calculate or hasten the arrival of the Messiah through human efforts. It references the teaching that the Messiah will come when people have despaired of redemption, highlighting the importance of faith and trust in God's timing. The idea of "hesach hada'at" (distraction of the mind) is presented as a necessary state to avoid premature expectations and to fully rely on God's will for the ultimate redemption.

passage_content: והנה אמרז"ל במד"ר (פ' קרח פ' י"ח סי' כ"ג) עה"פ ומטה אהרן וגו' יש אומרים שהוא המטה שהי' ביד משה וכו' ואותו המעה הי' ביד כל מלך ומלך עד שחרב ביהמ"ק ונגנז, ואותו המטה עתיד להיות ביד מלך המשיח במהרה בימינו שנאמר מטה עוזך ישלח ה' מציון וגו' עכ"ד המדרש נמצא שזהו מסימני הגאולה האמיתית, כשיראו ישראל מטה משה רבינו ביד הגואל העתיד, הוא הגואל האמיתי שכך קבלו רבותינו ז"ל שאותו המטה עתיד להיות ביד מלך המשיח, ואולי לטעם זה א"ל הקב"ה למשה רבינו ואתה הרם את מטך ונטה את ידך על הים ובקעהו, שכח הגאולה אשר בו נגנז עד שיבוא מלך המשיח. וע"כ הי' נס קריעת ים סוף ע"י נטיית ידו של משרע"ה ולא באמצעות המטה, וצוהו הקב"ה להרימו כלפי מעלה להורות לישראל שבחי' הגאולה הוא ביד הקב"ה לבדו, עד שיעלה רצון העליון וימסרנה ביד מלך המשיח, גם אפשר שענין הרמתו הי' כדי להראותו לכל ישראל שיכירו בו לסימן הגאולה ולא יטעו בגאולה כוזבת, ולטעם זה נקרא המעה אות, שזהו סימן על הגאולה, וכמ"ש הרמב"ן ז"ל דענין האות הוא סימן על דבר שיהי' כן בדמיונו.
translation: And behold, our Sages of blessed memory said in the Midrash (Parashat Korach, Chapter 18, Section 23) regarding the verse "And the staff of Aaron, etc." that some say it is the staff that was in the hand of Moses, etc. And that staff was in the hand of every king until the Holy Temple was destroyed and it was hidden away. That staff is destined to be in the hand of the King Messiah speedily in our days, as it is said, "The staff of Your strength the Lord will send from Zion," etc. Thus, it is found that this is one of the signs of the true redemption, when Israel will see the staff of our teacher Moses in the hand of the future redeemer, who is the true redeemer, as our Rabbis of blessed memory received that this staff is destined to be in the hand of the King Messiah. Perhaps for this reason, the Holy One, blessed be He, said to our teacher Moses, "And you lift up your staff and stretch out your hand over the sea and divide it," for the power of redemption which was hidden until the King Messiah comes. Therefore, the miracle of the splitting of the sea was through the stretching of the hand of Moses and not through the staff, and the Holy One, blessed be He, commanded him to lift it upwards to indicate to Israel that the essence of redemption is in the hands of the Holy One alone, until the supreme will arises and it is given into the hand of the King Messiah. It is also possible that the matter of lifting it was to show it to all of Israel so that they would recognize it as a sign of redemption and not be misled by a false redemption. For this reason, the staff is called a sign, as it is a symbol of redemption, and as the Ramban of blessed memory wrote, the matter of the sign is a symbol of something that will be so in its imagination.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of Aaron's staff, which is linked to the future redemption and the coming of the Messiah. It emphasizes that this staff, once held by Moses, symbolizes the true redemption that will be recognized by the Jewish people when they see it in the hands of the Messiah. The act of raising the staff during the splitting of the Red Sea serves as a reminder that ultimate redemption is solely in God's hands until the appointed time for the Messiah. This connection highlights the importance of recognizing genuine signs of redemption to avoid being misled by false claims.

passage_content: ובזה יובן דברי המדרש באותה שעה אמרו ישראל ה' ימלוך לעולם ועד, דממה שראו ישראל שנמנע משרע"ה מלהתפלל תפלה המכרחת להחיש הגאולה, גם ממה שצוה לו ית' ואתה הרם את מטך כפי' הנ"ל, השיגו ישראל שעדיין לא קרבה עת הגאולה הנצחית, ולכן אמרו ה' ימלוך לעתיד לבוא, דאיתא במדרש אילו אמרו ישראל ה' מלך לא היתה אומה ולשון שולטת בהם לעולם, אמנם השיגו ישראל שעדיין לא זכו לתיקון השלימות, לז"א ה' ימלוך לעתיד לבוא.
translation: And with this, the words of the Midrash will be understood: at that time, Israel said, "The Lord shall reign forever and ever." For when Israel saw that it was prevented from Moshe Rabbeinu praying a prayer that would hasten the redemption, and also from what He commanded him, "And you raise your staff," as mentioned above, Israel understood that the time for the eternal redemption had not yet drawn near. Therefore, they said, "The Lord shall reign in the future to come," for it is stated in the Midrash that if Israel had said, "The Lord is King," no nation or tongue would have dominion over them forever. However, Israel understood that they had not yet merited the rectification of completeness, hence they said, "The Lord shall reign in the future to come."
summary: The passage discusses the moment when the Israelites recognized that the time for ultimate redemption had not yet arrived, as evidenced by Moses being instructed not to pray for immediate salvation. They understood that their spiritual state was not yet complete, leading them to declare, "The Lord will reign in the future." This reflects a Hasidic belief in the importance of spiritual readiness and the idea that true redemption is contingent upon achieving a state of perfection. The statement implies that if they had proclaimed God's kingship in the present, they would have been free from foreign dominion, highlighting the connection between divine acknowledgment and the fulfillment of redemption.

passage_content: באופן אחר אפ"ל דברי המדרש משה צוח ווי וכו' בהקדם קושית הח"ס זלה"ה, דמה צורך לטעם פן ינחם העם ושבו מצרימה, הרי הי' הכרח בלא"ה להנחותם דרך המדבר כדי שתנתן להם התורה בהר סיני, כי הי' ההר הזה דייקא מוכן לכך כמבואר בדרז"ל, ובמכילתא דרשו רז"ל כי קרוב הוא, קרוב הוא הדבר שאמר הקב"ה למשה בהוציאך וגו' תעבדון את האלקים על ההר הזה ע"כ, א"כ טעם זה לבד מספיק ומה צורך לטעם פן ינחם העם, ע"כ קושיתו ונשאר בצ"ע.
translation: In another way, one can say the words of the Midrash: "Moshe cried, 'Woe!'" etc., in advance of the question of the Chasam Sofer, may his merit protect us, regarding what need there is for the reason "lest the people regret and return to Egypt." For it was necessary, without a doubt, to guide them through the desert so that the Torah would be given to them at Mount Sinai, for this mountain was specifically prepared for that purpose, as explained in the teachings of our Sages. And in the Mekilta, our Sages expounded that it is close, it is close to the matter that the Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Moshe, "When you bring the people out, you shall serve God on this mountain." Therefore, this reason alone is sufficient, and what need is there for the reason "lest the people regret"? Thus, his question remains, and it is left as an open question.
summary: The passage discusses a question raised by the Chasam Sofer regarding God's reasoning for leading the Israelites through the wilderness to avoid their potential regret and return to Egypt. It emphasizes that the primary purpose of this journey was to prepare them for receiving the Torah at Mount Sinai, which was specifically designated for this event. The text suggests that the divine instruction to Moses about worshiping at the mountain suffices as a rationale, leaving the question of the additional reasoning about the people's mindset unresolved. This reflects a deeper exploration of divine providence and the significance of the Torah in the Hasidic tradition.

passage_content: ואפ"ל עפימ"ש ק"ז זלה"ה (בתפלה למשה ס"ח) לפרש מה שיסד רבינו מאיר בקינה וזלה"ק: סיני העל כן בחר בך אלקים ומאס בגדולים וזרח בגבולך, להיות לאות ולמופת לדת כי תמעט ותרד מכבודה, דלכאורה הוא נגד דברי רז"ל במס' מגילה וכו' א"ר יוסף לעולם ילמוד אדם מדעת קונו, שהרי הניח השי"ת כל ההרים וגבעות שבעולם ולא השרה שכינתו אלא על הר סיני, פירש"י ילמוד אדם מדעת קונו לאהוב הנמיכות, א"כ מבואר דהיא ללמד ענוה ולא לסימן לדת שתרד מכבודה, ולמה שאבאר דברי רבינו מאיר המה אחדים עם דברי רז"ל ובקנה אחד עולים, דהלא כבר הרגישו המפורשים במדרש שהביא היפ"ת (סדר ויחי פ' צ"ט) עה"פ נכון יהי' הר בית ה' בראש ההרים, ההרים שהיו כבר עכ"ד המדרש, והקשו הלא השי"ת בוחר בנמוכים וכו', ואבאר זה דבאמת וודאי כבוד שמים הוא להיות מקום כבודו והשראתו ית"ש ברומו של עולם וכו', אך קודם שנתגלה מלכותו כי בכל משלה, וקודם שנודע לכל שאין זולתו, רצונו ית"ש להסתיר לבוש הגאות ולא להתלבש בו, כדי שלא יטעו עי"ז מכח מאמר נעשה אדם, כי יאמרו הלא אינו מתנהג בענוה, והם לא יבינו כי בא ללמד ענוה לאחרים ויפלו באמונות שניות ח"ו, ע"כ בחר לו ה' לשכון במקום נמוך, אבל לעתיד שיתגלה לעין כי אפס בלתו וכו', אז יתלבש בלבושו ההדר לו וכו', ועפי"ז א"ש דברי רבינו מאיר הנ"ל, כי ידוע כי התורה ניתנה ע"ד חירות וכו', דאילו לא חטאו הי' נשאר כבוד ה' כמו שיהי' לעתיד, וא"כ למה בחר הנמיכות, אלא הוא כי הכל צפוי אף שהרשות נתונה, וא"כ א"ר מאיר שפיר סימן לדת שתרד מכבודה, כי אלולי כן לא הי' בוחר הנמוך כמו שלא יבחר לעתיד עכל"ק.
translation:
And even though, according to the words of our teacher Rabbi Meir in the lamentation, it is stated: "Sinai, therefore God chose you and rejected the great ones, and shone in your borders, to be a sign and a wonder for the faith, for it will diminish and descend from its glory," it seems to contradict the words of our sages in Tractate Megillah, etc. Rabbi Yosef said: "A person should always learn from the knowledge of his Creator," for the Holy One, blessed be He, left all the mountains and hills of the world and did not rest His Shechinah except on Mount Sinai. Rashi explains that a person should learn from the knowledge of his Creator to love humility. Therefore, it is clear that this is to teach humility and not as a sign for the faith that it will diminish from its glory. 

As for the words of our teacher Rabbi Meir, they are in agreement with the words of our sages and rise together in one measure, for the interpreters have already noted in the Midrash that the Yefet brought (in the order of Vayechi, Parashat Tzav) on the verse "It shall be established that the house of the Lord will be on the top of the mountains," the mountains that were already, thus said the Midrash, and they questioned: "But the Holy One, blessed be He, chooses the lowly," etc. 

I will explain this: In truth, it is certainly the honor of Heaven to have a place of His honor and His Shechinah in the heights of the world, etc., but before His kingship is revealed, for He rules over all, and before it is known to all that there is none besides Him, His will, blessed be He, is to conceal the garment of pride and not to be clothed in it, so that they will not be misled by the saying "Let us make man," for they will say: "Behold, He does not conduct Himself with humility," and they will not understand that He comes to teach humility to others and will fall into secondary beliefs, Heaven forbid. Therefore, the Lord chose to dwell in a low place, but in the future, when it will be revealed to the eye that there is none besides Him, etc., then He will be clothed in His glorious garment, etc. 

According to this, the words of our teacher Rabbi Meir above are understood, for it is known that the Torah was given in the manner of freedom, etc., for had they not sinned, the honor of the Lord would have remained as it will be in the future. And if so, why did He choose the lowly? Rather, it is because everything is foreseen even though the permission is given. And thus Rabbi Meir said that it is indeed a sign for the faith that it will diminish from its glory, for otherwise He would not have chosen the lowly, just as He will not choose in the future, as is clear.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of God's choice of Mount Sinai, a lowly mountain, as the site for the giving of the Torah, emphasizing humility and the importance of recognizing divine presence in the humble. It contrasts this with the future revelation of God's glory, where He will be adorned in majesty. The text suggests that God's initial choice of a lowly place serves to teach humility and prevent misconceptions about His nature, while also indicating that the decline in the honor of the Torah is a reflection of human shortcomings. Ultimately, it highlights the tension between divine majesty and the need for humility in the relationship between God and humanity.

passage_content: ובזה יתיישב קושית החת"ס זלה"ה, דדרשת המכילתא כי קרוב הוא קרוב הוא הדבר שאמר הקב"ה למשה בהוציאך את העם וגו' תעבדון את האלקים על ההר הזה, מקושר הוא עם טעם המפורש בכתוב פן ינחם העם ושבו מצרימה, דאלמלי זכו ישראל לשלימות התיקון בבחי' דלעתיד, הי' ניתנה להם התורה בהר תבור וכרמל וסיני בבחי' שיתאחדו כולם לעתיד במקום המקדש, ולא הי' צורך להוליכם דרך המדבר לטעם זה שתנתן להם התורה בהר סיני, אבל מפני כי אמר אלקים פן ינחם העם ושבו מצרימה, ועדיין לא הגיעו אל השלימות, ע"כ הי' צורך להוליכם דרך המדבר כדברי המכילתא כי קרוב הדבר שאמר הקב"ה למשה תעבדון את האלקים על ההר הזה, ומזה השיג משרע"ה שלא יכנס לארץ וע"כ צווח ווי.
translation: And with this, the question of the Chasam Sofer, may his memory be blessed, is resolved, that the Midrash interprets that it is close, it is close to the matter that the Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Moses, "When you bring out the people... you shall serve God on this mountain," is connected to the explicit reason in the verse, "lest the people regret and return to Egypt," for had Israel merited the completeness of the rectification in the aspect of the future, the Torah would have been given to them on Mount Tabor and Carmel and Sinai in a way that they would all unite in the future at the place of the Temple, and there would have been no need to lead them through the desert for this reason that the Torah would be given to them on Mount Sinai. But because God said, "lest the people regret and return to Egypt," and they had not yet reached completeness, therefore it was necessary to lead them through the desert, as the Midrash states, that it is close to the matter that the Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Moses, "You shall serve God on this mountain," and from this, Moses understood that he would not enter the land, and therefore he cried out, "Woe."
summary: The passage discusses the reasoning behind God's command to Moses regarding the Israelites' worship at Mount Sinai, linking it to the concern that the people might regret their liberation and return to Egypt. It suggests that had the Israelites achieved a higher spiritual completeness, the Torah could have been given at a more exalted location, such as Mount Tabor or Carmel. However, due to their current spiritual state, they needed to journey through the desert to receive the Torah at Sinai. This realization led Moses to understand that he would not enter the Promised Land, resulting in his lament.

passage_content: ויהי בשלח פרעה את העם וגו', במד"ר (פרשה כ' סימן ב') הה"ד (ירמיה ז') כה אמר ה' צבאות וכו' מלה"ד לאדם שהי' לו פרדס, א"ל חבירו מכור לי את הפרדס הזה, מכרו לו במנה ולא הי' יודע בעל הפרדס מה בתוכו, אמר לו בכמה מכרת את הפרדס, א"ל במנה, א"ל יש בו זתים בק' מנה וכו' ואילו לא הי' של לוקח אלא מעיינות שבתוכו די שנאמר מעין גנים וגו', התחיל המוכר תוהא, כך הי' פרעה כששלח את ישראל לא היו לפניו כלום, א"ל גדולי מלכות מה עשית אילו לא הי' בידם אלא הביזה לבדם דיים שנאמר וגם ערב רב עלה אתם וכו', באותה שעה התחיל קורא ווי ווי הוי ויהי בשלח עכ"ד המדרש, וראוי להבין ענין הנמשל אילו לא הי' בידם אלא הביזה לבדם דיים שנא' וגם ערב רב עלה אתם וגו' ומה רבותייהם דערב רב, ואיך יתאים אל דמיון המשל שא"ל אילו לא הי' בידו אלא מעיינות שבתוכו די, גם מדוע יכנה הערב רב בשם ביזה ומה ענין התייחסות שם זה להם.
translation:
And it came to pass when Pharaoh sent the people away, etc. In the Midrash (Parashat 20, Siman 2), it is stated (Jeremiah 7) "Thus says the Lord of Hosts," etc. This can be compared to a person who had an orchard. His friend said to him, "Sell me this orchard." He sold it to him for a maneh, not knowing what was inside the orchard. The buyer asked him, "For how much did you sell the orchard?" He replied, "For a maneh." The buyer said, "There are olives worth a hundred maneh in it," etc. And if the buyer had only the springs within it, it would suffice, as it is said, "a spring of gardens," etc. The seller began to wonder. So it was with Pharaoh when he sent Israel away; he had nothing before him. The nobles of the kingdom said to him, "What have you done? If they had only the plunder, it would suffice, as it is said, 'And a mixed multitude went up with them,' etc." At that moment, he began to cry, "Woe, woe!" And it came to pass when Pharaoh sent them away, etc. Thus far is the Midrash. 

It is fitting to understand the matter of the parable: if they had only the plunder, it would suffice, as it is said, "And a mixed multitude went up with them," etc. And what is the significance of the great multitude, the mixed multitude? And how does it fit the analogy where he said to him, "If he had only the springs within it, it would suffice"? Also, why is the mixed multitude referred to as plunder, and what is the significance of this name in relation to them?
summary: The passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel discusses the moment Pharaoh released the Israelites, likening it to a man who sells a garden without knowing its true value. The key Hasidic insight emphasizes that the Israelites, despite appearing to leave with only the spoils of Egypt, carried within them the spiritual wealth symbolized by the "mixed multitude" (Erev Rav). This reflects the idea that true value lies not in material possessions but in the spiritual essence and potential that one possesses, suggesting that even what seems like mere plunder can hold profound significance.

passage_content: ב) (פ' כ' סימן ח') ד"א ויהי בשלח פרעה, מי אמר ווי משה אמר ווי, משל לאחד שנעשה לבתו של מלך שושבין, והי' רואה במזל שהוא מוציאה מבית אביה ואינו בא עמה לבית החתן לחופתה, התחיל בוכה וכו', כך אמר משה צועק אני שנתייגעתי להוציא את ישראל ממצרים ואיני נכנס עמהן לארץ לכך ויהי בשלח עכ"ד המדרש, וצ"ב קישור ענין זה לכאן, ויותר נכון מקומו לעיל בפ' בא בסיפור יציאת ישראל ממצרים או להלן כשנגזר עליו שלא יכנס לארץ.
translation: B) (Parashat Ki Tisa, Siman 8) D'var Acher, "And it was when Pharaoh sent out," who said "Woe"? Moses said "Woe." It is like a certain man who became the groomsman for the daughter of a king, and he saw in the stars that he was taking her out from her father's house but would not go with her to the groom's house for the wedding; he began to cry, etc. Thus, Moses said, "I cry out, I have toiled to bring Israel out of Egypt, and I will not enter with them into the Land." Therefore, "And it was when Pharaoh sent out," thus concludes the Midrash. And it is puzzling how this matter connects here, and it is more appropriate for it to be placed earlier in Parashat Bo in the narrative of Israel's exodus from Egypt or later when it was decreed upon him that he would not enter the Land.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author reflects on the moment when Pharaoh sends the Israelites out of Egypt, likening Moses' feelings to that of a wedding attendant who sees the bride leaving her father's house but cannot accompany her to the wedding. This metaphor highlights Moses' deep sorrow for having labored to free the Israelites yet being denied entry into the Promised Land. The text raises questions about the appropriateness of this narrative's placement, suggesting a deeper connection to Moses' struggles and the overarching themes of redemption and longing within the Hasidic tradition.

passage_content: ג) (פ' כ' סימן ג') ויהי בשלח פרעה וכי פרעה שלחם, בלעם אמר א"ל מוציאם ממצרים וכאן כתיב ויהי בשלח פרעה, אלא מלמד שהי' פרעה מלוה אותם וכו' ואין שילוח האמור כאן אלא לוי' שנאמר ואברהם הולך עמם לשלחם, אמנם לפי פשוטו קשה וכי פרעה שלחם וכו'.
translation: 3) (Parashat Ki Tisa, Siman 3) And it was when Pharaoh sent them, and when Pharaoh sent them, Bilaam said to him, "He is taking them out of Egypt," and here it is written, "And it was when Pharaoh sent them." Rather, it teaches that Pharaoh was accompanying them, etc., and the sending mentioned here is nothing other than accompanying, as it is said, "And Abraham went with them to send them." However, according to its simple meaning, it is difficult: Did Pharaoh send them, etc.?
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author discusses the moment of Pharaoh's decision to send the Israelites out of Egypt, emphasizing that Pharaoh did not merely send them away but accompanied them, reflecting a deeper spiritual connection. The text highlights the concept of "sending" as a form of escorting, paralleling Abraham's act of accompanying those he sent away. This interpretation suggests that true liberation involves not just physical departure but also spiritual support and guidance. The passage invites readers to consider the complexities of freedom and the roles of both the oppressor and the liberator in the process of redemption.

passage_content: ונל"פ עפ"י הידוע בדברי חז"ל ובזוה"ק שבכ"מ שנאמר העם הכוונה על הערב רב, ולכאורה יש לתמוה איך יצאו הערב רב ממצרים, וחז"ל דרשו עה"פ כי הוציא ה' את ישראל ממצרים זו גדולה על כולם שהרי אין עבד יכול לברוח ממצרים, והתינח בנ"י יצאו בדרך נס שהוציאם הקב"ה ביד חזקה ובזרוע נטוי', אבל הערב רב לא הסכים הקב"ה שיצטרפו אל בני ישראל ביציאתם ממצרים כמ"ש רש"י ז"ל עה"פ שחת עמך אשר הוצאת ממצרים שחת העם לא נאמר, אלא שחת עמך, ערב רב שקבלת מעצמך ולא נמלכת בי, ואמרת טוב שידבקו גרים בשכינה הם שחתו והשחיתו עכ"ל, וא"כ איך זכו הם לנס היציאה שהי' נמנע בדרך הטבע לצאת משם כאמרז"ל, וקושיא זו כחה יפה גם על בני אפרים שאמרו חז"ל שיצאו שלשים שנה לפני הזמן נשיהן בניהם ובנותיהם, ואיך יכלו לצאת עם רב וארץ מצרים היתה מוקפת בכשפים שאף עבד לא יכול הי' לברוח משם.
translation: And it is understood according to what is known from the words of our Sages and the Zohar that wherever it says "the people," it refers to the mixed multitude (Erev Rav). At first glance, one might wonder how the Erev Rav left Egypt, and our Sages expounded on the verse "For the Lord took Israel out of Egypt," which is a great miracle above all, for no slave can escape from Egypt. It is understandable that the Children of Israel left through a miracle, as the Holy One, blessed be He, took them out with a strong hand and an outstretched arm. However, the Holy One, blessed be He, did not allow the Erev Rav to join the Children of Israel in their exodus from Egypt, as Rashi, of blessed memory, explains on the verse "You have corrupted your people whom You brought out of Egypt" — it does not say "the people," but rather "Your people," the Erev Rav that you accepted upon yourself and did not consult with Me, and you said it is good for converts to cling to the Divine Presence; they have corrupted and destroyed. Therefore, how did they merit the miracle of the exodus, which was impossible by natural means, as our Sages said? This question also applies strongly to the Children of Ephraim, of whom our Sages said that they left thirty years before the time, with their wives, sons, and daughters. How could they leave with a multitude when the land of Egypt was surrounded by sorcery, such that even a slave could not escape from there?
summary: The passage discusses the concept of the "erev rav" (mixed multitude) that left Egypt alongside the Israelites, questioning how they were able to escape given that no slave could naturally flee from such a powerful land. It references the teachings of the sages and the Zohar, emphasizing that while the Israelites were miraculously freed by God, the erev rav's inclusion was not sanctioned by divine will, as they were seen as a corrupting influence. The text also raises a parallel concern regarding the tribe of Ephraim, who attempted to leave prematurely, highlighting the theological tension between divine intervention and the natural order of redemption.

passage_content: אכן ל"ק דמה שלא הי' עבד יכול לברוח ממצרים הי' ע"י כח הכשפים שהם כוחות הסט"א והואיל ובני אפרים עשו שלא כדת לעבור את פי ה' ליקח לעצמם חירות וגאולה לפני הזמן לכן לא מנעו בעדם כוחות הסט"א, ועוד סייעו בידם לעבור את פי ה' לקחת חירות וגאולה לפני הזמן, לכן פתחה להם הסט"א פתח כפתחו של אולם ויצאו בדרך הטבע באין מפריע ואין לתמוה מה שרדפו אח"כ המצריים אחריהם והרגום, דזהו דרך הסט"א לפתות את ישראל לדבר עבירה ואח"כ מקטרגים עליהם להענישם, וכענין הזה הי' גם בערב רב שעלו עם ישראל, דהנה המה היו המביאים וגורמים לבנ"י לכל חטאת ולכל עון למעול מעל בה', והם שעשו את העגל והחטיאו את ישראל וגרמו למשרע"ה שלא יכנס לארץ לכן סייע להם הסט"א שיוכלו לצאת עם ישראל, ופרעה והמצריים לא התנגדו ליציאתם, ואדרבה שלחו אותם כדי שיהיו לבנ"י לאבן נגף ולמכשול, וז"ש הפסוק ויהי בשלח פרעה את העם היינו הערב רב ול"ק קושית המדרש בלעם אמר אל מוציאם ממצרים דזה נאמר על בנ"י והקב"ה הוציאם ולא פרעה שלחם, אבל את העם היינו הע"ר שלח פרעה עם ישראל מרצונו כדי להצר לישראל.
translation: Indeed, it is not difficult to understand that the reason a servant could not escape from Egypt was due to the power of sorcery, which are the forces of the Other Side (Sitra Achra). Since the children of Ephraim acted improperly by transgressing the word of Hashem to take for themselves freedom and redemption before the appointed time, therefore the forces of the Other Side did not prevent them, and moreover, they assisted them in transgressing the word of Hashem to take freedom and redemption before the appointed time. Thus, the Other Side opened for them a passage like the opening of a hall, and they went out naturally without hindrance. There is no reason to wonder why the Egyptians later pursued them and killed them, for this is the way of the Other Side to entice Israel to sin, and then to accuse them in order to punish them. A similar situation occurred with the mixed multitude that ascended with Israel; they were the ones who brought and caused the children of Israel to commit all sins and transgressions against Hashem, and they were the ones who made the golden calf and caused Israel to sin, leading to Moshe Rabbeinu not entering the land. Therefore, the Other Side assisted them so that they could leave with Israel, and Pharaoh and the Egyptians did not oppose their departure; on the contrary, they sent them out so that they would be a stumbling block and a trap for the children of Israel. This is what the verse means when it says, "And it was when Pharaoh sent the people," referring to the mixed multitude. It is not difficult to understand the question of the Midrash regarding Bilaam, who said, "He who brings them out of Egypt," for this is said about the children of Israel, and the Holy One, Blessed be He, brought them out, not Pharaoh who sent them. But regarding the people, it was the mixed multitude that Pharaoh sent with Israel willingly to cause distress to Israel.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of spiritual forces, particularly the powers of the "Sitra Achra" (the Other Side), which enabled the Israelites, specifically the tribe of Ephraim, to escape Egypt prematurely by defying God's command. This act of rebellion attracted the attention of these dark forces, which later sought to ensnare the Israelites in sin and punishment. Additionally, it highlights the role of the mixed multitude (Erev Rav) in leading the Israelites astray, ultimately serving as a stumbling block to their spiritual journey. The text emphasizes that while God orchestrated the Exodus, the Erev Rav was sent by Pharaoh to hinder the Israelites' progress.

passage_content: ואמרז"ל בספרי וגם ערב רב עלה אתם כאן נתקיים בהם ואח"כ יצאו ברכוש גדול וצ"ב, והוא כעין מה שדרשו ז"ל במדרש הנ"ל וגם ערב רב עלה אתם היא הביזה ושניהם צריכין ביאור, ואפ"ל שטעמו של משרע"ה שקבל הערב רב הי' מחמת שראה ברוח קדשו שנבלע בתוכם נשמות קדושות שעתידין להתברר ולהתקרב אל הקדושה לעתיד, ובאמת הי' ג"כ רצון הבוי"ת לקבלם ולהציל נשמות שבתוכם דלא יצוייר שעשה משרע"ה דבר נגד רצונו ית', אלא מפני שראתה חכמתו ית' שיצא תקלה לישראל ע"י הערב רב, לא צוהו על ככה אלא משרע"ה מגרמי' עבד ונקראת על שמו, דלא יאות שיתייחס פעולת הרע אליו ית', וכעי"ז מצינו בזוה"ק פ' לך (דף פ"ב ע"א) א"ר יצחק בגין כך לא פקיד קוב"ה (לאאע"ה) לנחתא למצרים, אלא הוא מגרמי' נחת, בגין דלא יהא פתחון פה לבני עלמא, דאמר לי' כן ולבתר אצטער על אתתי' עכ"ל, ומבואר שם בזוה"ק (דף פ"ג ע"א) שהי' רצון הבוי"ת שירד למצרים עיי"ש, אלא שלא צוהו על ככה לטעם המבואר לעיל בדברי הזוה"ק, ולעיל בדברינו (פ' לך עמוד רל"ז) ביארנו מ"ש בזוה"ק שם כיון דנחת אברהם למצרים בלא רשו, אשתעבידו בנוי במצרים ד' מאה שנין וכו', דאף שהי' רצונו ית' כך, מ"מ נחשב לו לפגם בבחי' נורא עלילה עיי"ש, ועד"ז בשליחות המרגלים א"ל הקב"ה למשה אני איני מצוה אותך אם תרצה שלח, וכמו"כ בענין הערב רב רצונו ית' הי' שיעשה משרע"ה מעצמו, והשיג משרע"ה שעתידין לצאת מהם נשמות גבוהות וע"כ קיבלם.
translation: And our sages of blessed memory said in the Sifrei that the mixed multitude ascended with them, and it was fulfilled in them, and afterwards they went out with great wealth, and this is a question. It is similar to what our sages of blessed memory expounded in the aforementioned Midrash, and also the mixed multitude ascended with them refers to the plunder, and both require explanation. One could say that the reason of Moshe Rabbeinu accepting the mixed multitude was because he saw with his holy spirit that holy souls were absorbed within them that would eventually be clarified and drawn closer to holiness in the future. And indeed, it was also the will of the Blessed One to accept them and to save the souls within them, for it cannot be imagined that Moshe Rabbeinu did something against His will, but rather because he saw the wisdom of the Blessed One that a remedy would come to Israel through the mixed multitude, he was not commanded to do so, but Moshe Rabbeinu acted of his own accord and it is called by his name, for it would not be fitting for the evil action to be attributed to Him. And similarly, we find in the Zohar, Parashat Lech (page 82a), Rabbi Yitzchak said that for this reason the Holy One, blessed be He, did not command to descend to Egypt, but he acted of his own accord, so that there would not be a claim against the Holy One, blessed be He, that He said this and afterwards regretted His descent. It is explained there in the Zohar (page 83a) that it was the will of the Blessed One that he should descend to Egypt, as stated there, but He did not command him to do so for the reason explained above in the words of the Zohar. And earlier in our discussion (Parashat Lech, page 237) we explained what is stated in the Zohar there that since Abraham descended to Egypt without permission, he was enslaved there for four hundred years, etc. For even though it was His will, nonetheless, it was considered a blemish in the aspect of a terrible accusation, as stated there. And similarly, regarding the mission of the spies, the Holy One, blessed be He, said to Moshe, I do not command you; if you wish, send. And likewise, concerning the mixed multitude, it was the will of the Blessed One that Moshe Rabbeinu should do it of his own accord, and Moshe Rabbeinu understood that there were high souls destined to come out from them, and therefore he accepted them.
summary: The passage discusses the complex nature of the "Erev Rav" (mixed multitude) that joined the Israelites during the Exodus, suggesting that Moses accepted them because he foresaw, through divine inspiration, the holy souls within them that would eventually be redeemed. It emphasizes that God's will was to save these souls, even though Moses acted independently in this decision, reflecting a deeper understanding of divine wisdom and the interplay between free will and divine intention. The text also highlights that while God's ultimate plan included the Erev Rav, it was not explicitly commanded, indicating a nuanced relationship between divine providence and human action.

passage_content: ונקדים דברי ק"ז היש"מ זלה"ה (פ' תולדות ד"ה ויאהב יצחק) לפרש הפסוק ובביזה לא שלחו את ידם עפי"מ שמצינו בגמ' (גיטין דף נ"ז ע"ב) שמבני בניו של המן למדו תורה ברבים, הרי שלא כלה זרעו לגמרי, והטעם ע"ד דכתיב וירא כי אין איש עתיד להתגייר ע"כ ויך את המצרי וגו' ולכך באלו שראו ברוה"ק שהיו בהם ניצוצות קדושות לא נגעו בהן, וידוע מה שפירשו וראיתי את דמעת העשוקים, דקאי על ניצוצות הקדושה העשוקים בתוך הטומאה, וז"ש ובביזה, במקום ביזה לא שלחו את ידם לנגוע בהם עכ"ל, ובזה יובן דברי המדרש הנ"ל אמרו לו גדולי מלכות מה עשית אילו לא הי' בידם אלא הביזה לבדם דיים, היינו הנשמות הקדושות שהוליכו עמהם ממצרים שהם נקראים ביזה כפי' היש"מ, שנאמר וגם ערב רב עלה אתם דמה"ט קבלם משה רבינו מפני שראה בהם נשמות קדושות, ונצטערו המצריים מאוד שנשמות אלו נתקרבו אל הקדושה ולפיכך צוח פרעה ווי.
translation: And we will precede the words of K"Z the holy Yeshiva (Parshat Toldot, D"var Vaye'ahav Yitzchak) to explain the verse "And in the plunder they did not send forth their hand," according to what we find in the Gemara (Gittin 57b) that from the descendants of Haman, they learned Torah in public, thus it is evident that his seed was not entirely consumed. The reason is as it is written, "And he saw that there was no man who would convert," therefore he struck the Egyptian, and for this reason, those who saw in the Holy Spirit that there were within them holy sparks did not touch them. It is known what is explained, "And I saw the tears of the oppressed," which refers to the holy sparks oppressed within the impurity. Therefore, it is said, "And in the plunder," in the place of plunder, they did not send forth their hand to touch them. Thus, the words of the aforementioned Midrash will be understood: the great ones of the kingdom said to him, "What have you done? If they had only had the plunder in their hands, it would have been enough," meaning the holy souls that they took with them from Egypt, which are called plunder according to the holy Yeshiva, as it is stated, "And a mixed multitude went up with them." For this reason, Moshe Rabbeinu accepted them because he saw within them holy souls, and the Egyptians were very distressed that these souls had drawn close to holiness, and therefore Pharaoh cried out, "Woe!"
summary: The passage discusses the concept of holy sparks within the context of the Jewish exodus from Egypt, emphasizing that not all of Haman's descendants were lost to evil, as some retained the potential for holiness. It highlights the idea that the Israelites refrained from touching the "bounty" of the Egyptians, which symbolizes the sacred souls trapped within impurity. The text also reflects on the suffering of the Egyptians, particularly Pharaoh, who lamented the loss of these holy souls as they drew closer to sanctity. This underscores the Hasidic belief in the redemptive potential of every soul, even those associated with darkness.

passage_content: ויובן בזה דמיון הנמשל למעיינות שבפרדס, דכמו שהמעיין תמיד הוא נובע ומתרבה, וכאשר האדם מסתכל בו אינו רואה מקורו ולא ישיג אכותו ומהותו דמקור המעיין מכוסה מעין, כמו כן הערב רב שקבלם משה רבינו שלפי ראות העין לא היו ראויין להתקרב אל הקדושה, אעפ"כ הי' מובלעים בתוכם נשמות יקרות שעתידין להתברר אחר ביאת המשיח, וזה ראה משה רבינו וע"כ קיבל אותם, ומבואר בדברי חכז"ל דאלמלי נכנס משה רבינו ע"ה לארץ ישראל הי' מיד עולם התיקון. ואז היו מתבררין כל הנשמות של הע"ר, ובוודאי לא הי' פרעה משלח אותם, כי לא הי' ברצונו להוסיף קדושה על קדושה, ורק מפני שראה שלא קרבה הגאולה שלימה כמו שאמר בלעם אראנו ולא עתה אשורנו ולא קרוב, ע"כ הסכים לשלוח הע"ר עם ישראל כדי להצר להם, ובזה יתבאר דברי המדרש ויהי בשלח פרעה את העם, ר"ל הע"ר עם ישראל, משה צווח ווי שלא יכנס לארץ.
translation: It will be understood in this that the analogy of the parable is like the springs in the orchard, for just as the spring is always flowing and increasing, and when a person looks at it, he does not see its source nor comprehend its quality and essence, for the source of the spring is hidden from the eye, so too the mixed multitude that Moshe Rabbeinu accepted, that according to what is seen with the eye, they were not worthy to approach holiness, nevertheless, there were precious souls concealed within them that will be clarified after the coming of the Messiah. This Moshe Rabbeinu saw, and therefore he accepted them. It is explained in the words of our Sages that had Moshe Rabbeinu entered the Land of Israel, the world of rectification would have immediately begun. Then all the souls of the mixed multitude would have been clarified, and certainly Pharaoh would not have sent them away, for he did not wish to add holiness upon holiness. Only because he saw that the complete redemption was not approaching, as Bilaam said, "I see him, but not now; I behold him, but not near," therefore he agreed to send the mixed multitude with Israel in order to trouble them. And in this, the words of the Midrash will be clarified: "And it was when Pharaoh sent the people," meaning the mixed multitude with Israel, Moshe cried out, "Woe!" that he would not enter the Land.
summary: The passage draws a parallel between the hidden source of a spring and the mixed multitude (Erev Rav) that accompanied the Israelites, suggesting that although they appeared unworthy of holiness, they contained precious souls destined for redemption in the Messianic era. Moses recognized this potential and accepted them, understanding that their true essence was obscured. The text emphasizes that had Moses entered the Promised Land, the process of rectification for these souls would have begun immediately, but Pharaoh's reluctance to allow this reflects a deeper struggle against the increase of holiness. Ultimately, the narrative highlights the tension between visible reality and hidden spiritual potential, underscoring the importance of faith in the unseen.

passage_content: ויהי בשלח פרעה את העם ולא נחם אלקים דרך ארץ פלשתים כי קרוב הוא, במכילתא לא הביאן הקב"ה דרך פשוטה לארץ ישראל אלא דרך המדבר, אמר הקב"ה אם אני מביא עכשיו ישראל לארץ, מיד מחזיקים אדם בשדהו ואדם בכרמו, והן בטלים מן התורה, אלא אקיפם במדבר מ' שנה, שיהיו אוכלין מן ושותין מי הבאר, והתורה נבללת בגופן, מכאן הי' ר' שמעון אומר לא ניתנה תורה אלא לאוכלי המן, ושניים להם אוכלי תרומה עכ"ד המכילתא, וצ"ב דאין זה הטעם המפורש בכתוב פן ינחם העם בראותם מלחמה וגו', ומדוע נטו חכז"ל בדרשתם ליתן טעם חדש שונה מהמפורש בפסוק.
translation: And it came to pass when Pharaoh sent the people, that God did not lead them by the way of the land of the Philistines, for it was near; in the Mechilta it is stated that the Holy One, blessed be He, did not bring them by a straightforward path to the Land of Israel, but rather through the wilderness. The Holy One, blessed be He, said: If I bring Israel to the land now, immediately a man will cling to his field and another to his vineyard, and they will be neglectful of the Torah. Rather, I will encircle them in the wilderness for forty years, so that they will eat from the manna and drink from the well, and the Torah will be absorbed within them. From here Rabbi Shimon would say that the Torah was given only to those who eat the manna, and to those who eat terumah. Thus far the Mechilta. And it is puzzling why this is not the explicit reason given in the verse, "lest the people repent when they see war," and why our sages chose to provide a new reason that differs from what is stated in the verse.
summary: The passage discusses God's decision to lead the Israelites through the desert rather than directly to the Promised Land, emphasizing the importance of spiritual preparation over immediate material concerns. It suggests that if the Israelites were to enter the land too soon, they would become preoccupied with their fields and vineyards, neglecting their commitment to the Torah. By wandering in the desert for forty years, they would be sustained by divine provisions, allowing the Torah to become ingrained in their lives. This reflects a Hasidic understanding of the necessity of spiritual nourishment and the transformative power of divine experiences in shaping one's relationship with God and the Torah.

passage_content: ב) (פרשה כ' סי' ט"ז) ד"א ולא נחם אלקים, למה דרך פלשתים, א"ר שמעון בן אבא א"ר יוחנן כיון ששמעו הכנענים שישראל נכנסין לארץ, עמדו וקצצו הנטיעות שהיו להם, כיון ששמעו שנתעכבו במדבר מ' שנה היו סבורים שבמדבר תהא דירתם, עמדו ונטעו נטיעות וגדלו אותן ואח"כ הכניסן לארץ עכ"ד המדרש, ולכאורה גם זה צ"ב דאין זה טעם המפורש בכתוב פן ינחם העם וגו'.
translation: B) (Parashat Ki Tisa, Siman 16) Another explanation: "And God did not lead them" - why the way of the Philistines? Rabbi Shimon ben Abba said in the name of Rabbi Yochanan: When the Canaanites heard that Israel was entering the land, they stood up and cut down the saplings they had. When they heard that they were delayed in the desert for forty years, they thought that their dwelling would be in the desert. They stood up, planted saplings, and nurtured them, and afterwards brought them into the land. Thus is the teaching of the Midrash. And at first glance, this too is difficult, for it is not the reason explicitly stated in the verse, "lest the people regret..."
summary: The passage discusses the reason why God did not lead the Israelites through the land of the Philistines, as explained by Rabbi Shimon ben Abba in the name of Rabbi Yochanan. It highlights that the Canaanites, upon hearing of the Israelites' entry into the land, cut down their trees, believing that the Israelites would remain in the desert for 40 years. This reflects a deeper theological insight into divine providence and the unfolding of God's plan, suggesting that the Israelites' journey and the Canaanites' actions were part of a larger divine strategy, even if not explicitly stated in the text.

passage_content: ונל"פ בהקדם לבאר בדברי המדרש הנ"ל דהטעם שהסיבם הקב"ה דרך המדבר, הי' בשביל שקצצו הכנענים כל הנטיעות, והקב"ה הבטיח לישראל להביאם אל ארץ טובה ורחבה וע"י שנתעכבו ישראל מ' שנה במדבר, חזרו ונטעו נטיעות חדשים, ולכאורה טעם זה צ"ב דכמו שנתן הקב"ה בלבם לנטוע נטיעות חדשים אח"כ, כמו"כ הי' היכולת בידו ית' למנוע אותם מתחלה, או ליתן בלבם עצה שלא לקצצם, ומדוע בשביל טעם זה בלבד הי' ההכרח לסבבם מ' שנה במדבר, אלא וודאי שהי' רצון הבוי"ת כן שיקצצו כל הנטיעות וינטעו חדשים וצ"ב הטעם,
translation: And we will explain in advance to clarify the words of the aforementioned Midrash that the reason the Holy One, blessed be He, led them through the desert was because the Canaanites had cut down all the saplings, and the Holy One, blessed be He, promised Israel to bring them to a good and spacious land. And since Israel was delayed for forty years in the desert, they returned and planted new saplings. At first glance, this reason is puzzling, for just as the Holy One, blessed be He, put it in their hearts to plant new saplings afterward, so too it was within His ability to prevent them from cutting them down in the first place, or to give them advice not to cut them. And why, for this reason alone, was it necessary to cause them to wander for forty years in the desert? Rather, it is certain that it was the will of the Creator that they should cut down all the saplings and plant new ones, and the reason for this is indeed a question.
summary: The passage discusses the reason why God led the Israelites through the desert for forty years, specifically in response to the Canaanites cutting down their trees. It raises the question of why God did not prevent this destruction if He later inspired the Israelites to plant new trees. The text suggests that it was God's will for the Canaanites to cut down the trees, indicating a deeper divine purpose behind the events, emphasizing the themes of renewal and divine providence in the Hasidic tradition.

passage_content: ויתבאר בהקדם דברי הגמ' (ע"ז דף נ"ג ע"ב) א"ר אלעזר וכו' דאמר רחמנא ואשיריהם תשרפון באש, מכדי ירושה הוא להם מאבותיהם, ואין אדם אוסר דבר שאינו שלו, ואי משום הנך דמעיקרא, (פירש"י משום אשירות דמעיקרא היו קודם שניתנו לאברהם, ולא ידעינן הי נינהו), בביטולא בעלמא סגי להו, (פירש"י דקיי"ל נכרי מבטל ע"ז של עכו"ם על כרחו ליכפינהו לעובדי כוכבים וליבטלינהו), ותירצו בגמ' מדפלחו ישראל לעגל גלו אדעתייהו דניחא להו בע"ז, וכי אתו עכו"ם שליחותא דידהו עבדי, (פירש"י הלכך הוי ע"ז של ישראל ואינה בטילה עולמית) עכ"ד הגמ' לענינינו, והנה דרשו רז"ל עה"פ נתנה ראש ונשובה מצרימה, אין ראש אלא ע"ז שנאמר ויהי דוד בא עד הראש, ולפי שהי' גלוי וידוע לפניו ית' שיחשבו ישראל מחשבה אחרת ויטעו בעגל, ומעתה יאסרו כל הנטיעות שעבדו להם הכנענים, דגלו ישראל אדעתייהו דניחא להו והוי כע"ז של ישראל, ע"כ נתן השי"ת בלב הכנענים שיעקרו כל הנטיעות ויתבטל הע"ז, דבלא"ה לא יוכלו ישראל ליהנות מהם ויצטרכו לעקרם, ואחר שעשו ישראל תשובה על חטא העגל, ונטעו הכנענים נטיעות חדשים ולזה מהני ביטול דלא הוי כע"ז של ישראל, דכבר גלו ישראל אדעתייהו דלא ניחא להו בע"ז, אלא שחכז"ל נתנו סימנא להכיר האשירות האסורים כאמרז"ל (ע"ז דף מ"ה ע"ב) אר"ע כל מקום שאתה מוצא הר גבוה וגבעה נשאה ועץ רענן דע שיש שם ע"ז, ואפשר דאלו לא נעקרו ע"י הכנענים והניחום לתקלה לישראל ולזה לא מהני להו ביטול כע"ז של ישראל, אבל שאר הנטיעות שנטעו הכנענים אח"כ יכלו ישראל ליהנות מהם ע"י ביטול.
translation: And it will be explained in advance the words of the Gemara (Avodah Zarah 53b) that Rabbi Elazar said, etc., that the Holy One, blessed be He, said, "And their ashes you shall burn in fire." Since it is an inheritance for them from their ancestors, and a person cannot prohibit something that does not belong to him, and if it is because of those that were from the beginning (Rashi explains that the wealth was originally theirs before it was given to Abraham, and we do not know who they are), it is sufficient for them to be nullified in a mere annulment (Rashi explains that we hold that a non-Jew can nullify the idol of a gentile against his will and nullify it). The Gemara answers that since the Jews danced around the calf, they revealed their intention that they were pleased with idolatry, and when the gentiles come, they are their agents (Rashi explains that therefore it is considered an idol of Israel and is not nullified forever). Thus concludes the Gemara regarding our matter. And behold, our Sages expounded on the verse "He gave a head and we will return to Egypt," that "head" refers to idolatry, as it is said, "And it was when David came to the head." And since it was revealed and known before Him, blessed be He, that the Jews would think another thought and be misled by the calf, from now on they will prohibit all the plantings that the Canaanites worked for them, for the Jews revealed their intention that they were pleased with it, and it is considered as the idolatry of Israel. Therefore, the Holy One, blessed be He, put it in the hearts of the Canaanites to uproot all the plantings and nullify the idolatry, for otherwise the Jews would not be able to benefit from them and would need to uproot them. And after the Jews repented for the sin of the calf, and the Canaanites planted new plantings, the nullification is effective since it is not considered as the idolatry of Israel, for the Jews have already revealed their intention that they are not pleased with idolatry. However, our Sages gave a sign to recognize the forbidden wealth, as our Sages said (Avodah Zarah 45b), "Wherever you find a high mountain and a raised hill and a fresh tree, know that there is idolatry there." And it is possible that if these were not uprooted by the Canaanites and they left them as a stumbling block for Israel, then the nullification would not be effective as the idolatry of Israel. But the other plantings that the Canaanites planted afterward, the Jews could benefit from them through nullification.
summary: The passage discusses the Talmudic interpretation regarding the prohibition of idolatry and its implications for the Jewish people, particularly in relation to the Canaanite practices. It emphasizes that since the Israelites willingly engaged in idolatry, the Canaanite trees they planted became associated with their idolatrous practices and could not be nullified. However, after the Israelites repented for the sin of the Golden Calf, new plantings by the Canaanites could be enjoyed by the Israelites, as they no longer had the same idolatrous connotation. The text highlights the dynamic relationship between sin, repentance, and the status of objects in the context of Jewish law.

passage_content: ומעתה א"ש דמ"ש במדרש דטעם עיכובם של ישראל במדבר הי' בשביל הנטיעות, הוא מקושר עם טעם המפורש בכתוב פן ינחם העם וגו', דמפני שהי' חשש זה קיים שיחשבו מחשבה אחרת לטעות אחר ע"ז, וכמו שאירע באמת שטעו אחר העגל ונאסרו כל הנטיעות, לכן נתעכבו ישראל במדבר עד שנטעו חדשים לאחר שעשו ישראל תשובה והותרו להם, ועד"ז אפ"ל דגם טעם המכילתא מקושר עם טעם המפורש בכתוב, דהנה הבטיח הקב"ה לישראל שיביאם אל ארץ טובה ורחבה וגו' בתים מלאים כל טוב, כרמים וזתים אשר לא נטעת, וא"כ לא יצטרכו לעבוד עבודת שדה וכרם כלל, ומדוע חש הקב"ה שיחזיקו איש בשדהו ובכרמו ויתבטלו מן התורה אמנם מפני שהי' חשש זה קיים פן ינחם העם כנ"ל. ולזה הי' צורך שיעקרו הכנענים כל הנטיעות, ואלמלי נכנסו ישראל מיד, היו צריכים לעמול בעבודת שדה וכרם ויתבטלו מן התורה, וע"כ הקיפם הקב"ה במדבר מ' שנה שיהיו אוכלין מן ושותין מי באר והתורה נבללת בגופן שם כי לא הי' מתקיים עסק התורה בידם בארץ ישראל, ולאחר שחזרו ונטעו הכנענים כל הנטיעות, נכנסו לארץ מלאה כל טוב ונתקיים עסק התורה בידם גם לאח"כ, וא"ש דכולהו טעמים שאמרז"ל נרמזו בטעם הכתוב פן ינחם העם וגו'.
translation: And from now on, I understand that what is stated in the Midrash regarding the reason for the delay of Israel in the desert was for the sake of the plantings, is connected with the reason explicitly mentioned in the verse, "lest the people regret..." For because this concern existed that they might think another thought to err after idolatry, and as it indeed happened that they erred after the calf and all the plantings were forbidden, therefore Israel was delayed in the desert until they planted anew after Israel repented and it was permitted to them. Similarly, it can be said that the reason of the Mechilta is also connected with the reason explicitly mentioned in the verse, for behold, the Holy One, blessed be He, promised Israel that He would bring them to a good and spacious land... houses full of all good things, vineyards and olive trees which you did not plant, and thus they would not need to work the fields and vineyards at all. And why did the Holy One, blessed be He, fear that a man would cling to his field and vineyard and become distracted from the Torah? Indeed, because this concern existed, "lest the people regret," as mentioned above. Therefore, it was necessary for the Canaanites to uproot all the plantings, and had Israel entered immediately, they would have had to toil in the work of the fields and vineyards and would have been distracted from the Torah. And thus, the Holy One, blessed be He, surrounded them in the desert for forty years so that they would eat manna and drink from the well, and the Torah would be absorbed within them there, for the study of Torah would not have been sustained in their hands in the Land of Israel. And after the Canaanites returned and planted all the plantings, they entered a land full of all good, and the study of Torah was sustained in their hands even afterwards. And it is clear that all the reasons stated by our Sages are hinted at in the reason of the verse, "lest the people regret..."
summary: The passage discusses the reasons for the Israelites' prolonged wandering in the desert, linking it to the need for spiritual preparation and the avoidance of idolatry. It emphasizes that God delayed their entry into the Promised Land to prevent them from becoming distracted by agricultural work, which could lead them away from the study of Torah. The text highlights that the Israelites needed to repent and that the Canaanites had to remove their plantings before the Israelites could enter a land filled with blessings, ensuring that their focus remained on spiritual pursuits. Ultimately, the passage illustrates the interconnectedness of divine providence, repentance, and the importance of maintaining a commitment to Torah study.

passage_content: ויהי בשלח פרעה וגו' במד"ר (פ' כ' סי' ה') הה"ד (שה"ש ד') שלחיך פרדס רמונים, א"ר לוי משל לאחד שהי' לו שדה והי' בה גל של צרורות, עמד ומכרה לאחר, עמד אותו האיש שקנאה והעביר אותו הגל מתוכה, ומצא תחתיו מים חיים: נטעה גפנים עשאה שורות שורות נטע בה כל מיני בשמים וכו' והושיב בתוכה שומר וכו', עבר עלי' אותו האיש שמכרה ראה אותה מליאה כל טוב, אמר אוי לי שכך מכרתי, אוי לי שכך הוצאתי מידי, כך היו ישראל במצרים גל של צרורות וכו', כיון שיצאו נעשו פרדס רמונים וכו' לכך נאמר ויהי בשלח פרעה עכ"ד המדרש וצ"ב דמיון המשל שאינו מתאים לכאורה עם הנמשל, כי בסיפור המשל הי' המעיין מכוסה בגל של צרורות, ולא הרגיש בו המוכר כלל ופנים חדשות באו אח"כ ביד הקונה, משא"כ פרעה הכיר וידע איכותם ומספרם של ישראל גם במצרים, ומה נתגלה לו מגדולתם יותר בעמדם על הים, ואם לצד שנתעלו במעלות הנפשות וברוחני, אין זה סיבה לפרעה שיתחרט עבור זה.
translation:
And it came to pass when Pharaoh sent forth, etc. (Midrash Rabbah, Parashat Ki Tisa, Section 5) as it is written (Song of Songs 4:13) "Your shoots are a paradise of pomegranates." Rabbi Levi said: This is comparable to a man who had a field and there was a heap of stones in it. He stood up and sold it to another. That man who bought it removed the heap from it and found living waters underneath. He planted vines and made rows, and he planted in it all kinds of spices, etc., and he set a guard over it, etc. The man who sold it passed by and saw it full of all good things. He said, "Woe to me for having sold it! Woe to me for having removed it from my hands!" Thus were the Israelites in Egypt, a heap of stones, etc. When they went out, they became a paradise of pomegranates, etc. Therefore it is said, "And it came to pass when Pharaoh sent forth." Thus far is the Midrash. 

And it is difficult to understand the analogy of the parable, which seemingly does not fit with the interpretation, for in the story of the parable, the spring was covered by a heap of stones, and the seller did not feel it at all, and new faces came afterward into the hands of the buyer. Whereas Pharaoh recognized and knew the quality and number of the Israelites even in Egypt, and what was revealed to him of their greatness more so when they stood by the sea. And even if they were elevated in the levels of souls and spirituality, this is not a reason for Pharaoh to regret it.
summary: The passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel uses a parable to illustrate the transformation of the Israelites from a state of oppression in Egypt, likened to a field covered with stones, to a flourishing garden filled with blessings upon their exodus. It highlights the idea that while Pharaoh was aware of the Israelites' potential, he failed to recognize their true spiritual elevation until they stood at the sea. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the nature of redemption and the hidden potential within suffering, suggesting that true greatness can emerge from adversity. The contrast between the visible and the hidden underscores the theme of divine revelation and the awakening of spiritual awareness.
