passage_content: ומעתה אפשר לומר שלכן לא צוה יוסף שישאוהו מיד ממצרים, שכמו שהוצרך להקדים לבוא לפניהם למצרים, בשביל שיהי' צינור המשפיע בימי הרעב נגד הטבע, כמשה"כ וישלחנו אלקים לפניכם לשום לכם שארית בארץ, כמו כן גם בעת היציאה ממצרים שהוצרכו לרכוש גדול ולהשפעה מרובה, הוצרך גם יוסף הצדיק להיות שם שיומשך להם על ידו כח קדושה זו להמשיך צינור ההשפעה, אמנם כאשר נראה שהוצרכו להשתדלות עבור הרכוש, זה הי' לאות כי לא דבקו בקדושה זו שאמר יוסף כי פי המדבר אליכם בלה"ק שלא עשה דבריו חולין כלל, כי אלו הי' כן הי' בכחם לפעול הכל בדיבור בלי שום השתדלות, ואך במשה מצינו ויקח משה את עצמות יוסף עמו שהשתדל רק בעצמות יוסף ולא הוצרך להשתדל בכסף וזהב.
translation: And from now on, it is possible to say that this is why Joseph did not command that he be taken immediately from Egypt, for just as he needed to come before them in Egypt in order to be a conduit of influence during the years of famine against nature, as it is written, "And God sent him before you to establish for you a remnant in the land," so too, at the time of the exodus from Egypt, when they needed great wealth and abundant influence, it was also necessary for the righteous Joseph to be there, so that through him this holy power of influence would be drawn down. However, when it appeared that they needed to exert effort for the wealth, this was a sign that they did not cling to this holiness that Joseph spoke of, for his mouth spoke to you in the holy tongue, that he did not make his words mundane at all, for if it were so, they would have had the power to accomplish everything through speech without any effort. Only with Moses do we find that "Moses took the bones of Joseph with him," for he only exerted effort for the bones of Joseph and did not need to exert effort for gold and silver.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of Joseph's role in the spiritual and material sustenance of the Israelites during their time in Egypt and their subsequent exodus. It emphasizes that Joseph's presence was essential for channeling divine influence and blessings, particularly during times of need, such as famine and the acquisition of wealth. The text suggests that the Israelites' reliance on material efforts indicated a lack of connection to the holiness that Joseph embodied, as true spiritual power would allow them to achieve their needs through divine speech alone. Ultimately, Moses' act of taking Joseph's bones signifies a return to that spiritual essence without the need for material struggle.

passage_content: ואפשר לפרש ויקח משה את עצמות יוסף עמו ר"ל עצמותו של יוסף וכח קדושתו לקח עמו ולעצמו, שיהי' לו כח השפעה אף חוץ לדרך הטבע, אמנם עבור מרע"ה א"א לומר שהוצרך יוסף להשאר בשם שיהי' בכחו להשיג קדושה זו ע"י יוסף, כאשר כתב בשו"ת השיב משה (באו"ח סי' ב') שזה וודאי שכל מה שמצינו באחד מבני עלי' וודאי דמשה כללא דכולהו, וא"כ א"א לומר במרע"ה שהוצרך לסיוע מזולתו להשיג איזה קדושה.
translation: And it is possible to interpret that Moses took the bones of Joseph with him, meaning the bones of Joseph, and he took with him the power of his holiness, so that he would have the power of influence even outside the natural order. However, regarding Moses our teacher, it cannot be said that Joseph needed to remain in name so that he would have the power to attain this holiness through Joseph, as it is written in the responsa of the Shive Moshe (Orach Chaim 2) that it is certainly true that whatever we find in one of the sons of elevation, it is certainly a general principle for all of them, and therefore it cannot be said about Moses our teacher that he needed assistance from another to attain any holiness.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of Moses taking the bones of Joseph with him, symbolizing the transmission of Joseph's holiness and spiritual power. It emphasizes that Moses, as a leader and prophet, did not require external assistance from Joseph to attain holiness, as he embodies the collective spiritual potential of all the righteous. The text highlights the idea that true spiritual elevation comes from within, rather than relying on others, reinforcing the unique status of Moses in the realm of divine connection.

passage_content: ובזה אפשר לפרש דברי רש"י ז"ל שאצל סיפור השבועה לא קשיא לי' למה לא השביע בניו שישאוהו מיד, שאז הי' אפשר לתרץ אולי הוצרך להיות בשם שלבסוף יזכו ישראל על ידו להשפיע בכח הדיבור חוץ לדרך הטבע, אבל כאשר אמר הכתוב ויקח משה את עצמות יוסף עמו, שמבואר שאך משה לקח עמו עצמותו של יוסף הצדיק ע"ה, ועבורו לא הוצרך להיות בשם, כי בכחו לבוא למדריגה זו בלי שום סיוע כנ"ל, ולזה הקשה למה לא השביען שישאוהו מיד והבן, (ע"כ מכתי"ק).
translation: And with this, it is possible to explain the words of Rashi, may his memory be blessed, regarding the story of the oath: it is not difficult for him why he did not swear his sons to carry him immediately, for then it could have been explained that perhaps it was necessary to be in the name so that in the end, Israel would merit through him to influence with the power of speech beyond the natural order. But when the verse states, "And Moses took the bones of Joseph with him," it is clear that only Moses took with him the bones of Joseph the righteous, peace be upon him, and for him it was not necessary to be in the name, for he had the power to reach this level without any assistance, as mentioned. Therefore, he questioned why he did not swear them to carry him immediately, and understand. (Thus I have written).
summary: The passage discusses the significance of Moses taking the bones of Joseph during the Exodus, emphasizing that Moses possessed the spiritual capacity to achieve this without needing a divine name or intervention. It raises the question of why Joseph did not require his sons to swear to carry him immediately, suggesting that Moses's unique spiritual stature allowed him to fulfill this task independently. This reflects a deeper Hasidic understanding of the power of righteous individuals to transcend natural limitations through their faith and connection to God. Ultimately, it highlights the importance of spiritual leadership and the potential for divine influence through righteous actions.

passage_content: ויקח משה את עצמות יוסף עמו כי השבע השביע את בנ"י לאמר פקוד יפקוד וגו', פירש"י בשם המכילתא השביעם שישביעו לבניהם, ולמה לא השביע בניו שישאוהו לארץ כנען מיד כמו שהשביע יעקב, אמר יוסף אני שליט הייתי במצרים וכו', אבל בני לא יניחום מצרים לעשות וכו' עכ"ל, והקושיא מפורסמת מדוע לא הקשה רש"י זאת בפ' ויחי אצל סיפור השבועה הזאת, וכן הקשה ק"ז הישמח משה זלה"ה עיי"ש תירוצו.
translation: And Moses took the bones of Joseph with him, for he had made the children of Israel swear, saying, "God will surely visit you," etc. Rashi explains in the name of the Mekilta that he made them swear that they would make their children swear. And why did he not make his sons swear to carry him to the land of Canaan immediately, as Jacob had sworn? Joseph said, "I was a ruler in Egypt," etc., but my sons will not allow the Egyptians to do so, etc. Thus far the text. And the question is well-known: why did Rashi not raise this issue in Parashat Vayechi regarding the story of this oath? And so questioned Rabbi Moshe, may his memory be blessed, as mentioned there, and he provided an answer.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the focus is on Joseph's oath to his brothers regarding the future exodus from Egypt, emphasizing the importance of passing down this commitment to future generations. The text highlights the distinction between Joseph's own authority in Egypt and the potential reluctance of his descendants to fulfill the oath, reflecting a deeper theological insight into the challenges of faith and continuity within the Jewish people. The discussion also raises questions about the timing and context of the oath, suggesting a tension between individual agency and collective responsibility in the fulfillment of divine promises.

passage_content: ב) סוטה (י"ג ע"א) בא וראה כמה חביבות מצות על משה רבינו, שכל ישראל נתעסקו בביזה והוא נתעסק במצות שנאמר חכם לב יקח מצות ובמכילתא הגירסא בא וראה חכמתו של משה וכו', וכבר דקדקו קמאי מה שתיארוהו חז"ל במעשה זו בתואר חכם, ויותר יאות אליו תואר צדיק (עיין בח"א מהרש"א מ"ש בזה), גם מ"ש יקח מצות בלשון רבים, ואין זה אלא מצוה א'.
translation: B) Sotah (Yud Gimmel Amud Aleph) Come and see how beloved the mitzvot are to Moshe Rabbeinu, for all of Israel were occupied with the spoils, and he was occupied with the mitzvot, as it is said, "A wise heart will take mitzvot." And in the Mekhilta, the version states, "Come and see the wisdom of Moshe," etc. And the early ones have already noted what our Sages described him in this act with the title "wise," and the title "tzaddik" is more fitting for him (see in Chiddushei Agadot of the Maharsha what is said about this). Also, the phrase "will take mitzvot" is in the plural, and this is nothing but a reference to the first mitzvah.
summary: The passage highlights the deep affection that Moses had for the commandments, contrasting his focus on fulfilling God's will with the rest of Israel, who were preoccupied with material gain. It emphasizes Moses' wisdom, as noted by the sages, but suggests that the title of "righteous" (tzaddik) is more fitting for him. Additionally, the use of the plural form "mitzvot" indicates a broader commitment to the commandments, underscoring the importance of spiritual pursuits over worldly distractions.

passage_content: ויתבאר בהקדם מה שפירשתי בטעם שהוצרך משרע"ה לשאול בדבר ה' בפרשת טמאים דכתיב (בפ' בהעלותך) ויאמר אליהם משה עמדו ואשמעה מה יצוה ה' לכם, ובפ' פנחס בענין בנות צלפחד כתיב ויקרב משה את משפטן לפני ה', ורז"ל דרשו ראוי' היתה פרשה זו להאמר ע"י משה כשאר כל התורה כולה, אלא שזכו אלו שתאמר על ידיהן וכו' (הביאו רש"י ז"ל), מ"מ טעמא בעי מדוע נשתנו ב' מצות אלו מכל מצות התורה שהוצרך משרע"ה להימלך בגבורה, והרי כל חלקי התורה נגלו לפניו וקבלם מסיני, ופירשתי עפי"ד ק"ז הישמח משה זלה"ה (בפ' שמיני) דנמצא בדברי רז"ל סתירות הרבה בהך הלכתא אי קברי צדיקים מטמאים או לאו, והוא ז"ל הכריע דמעצם הדין ראוי להיות שצדיקים לא יטמאו, כי אין טומאה להם ובמיתתן נקראו חיים אך לא ניתנה לנו להתנהג בדין זה, כי הכרעה זו אין דעתינו דעת האנושי מקפת אותה, כי אני ה' חוקר לב ובוחן כליות כתיב, והאדם יראה לעינים, ולכך אין לנו להתנהג בזה כלל, אף אם נודע לנו שהוא צדיק, כדי שלא לחלק בין צדיק לצדיק דאין כח המבחין בידינו וכו' כנ"ל ברור ואמת בס"ד עכ"ל.
translation: And it will be explained in advance what I have interpreted regarding the reason that Moshe Rabbeinu needed to inquire of the word of Hashem in the matter of the impure in Parashat Beha'alotecha, as it is written (in Parashat Beha'alotecha) "And Moshe said to them, 'Stand and I will hear what Hashem commands you.'" And in Parashat Pinchas regarding the daughters of Tzelophehad, it is written, "And Moshe brought their case before Hashem." And our Sages of blessed memory expounded that this section was fitting to be said by Moshe like all of the Torah, but these were meritorious that it should be said through them, etc. (as brought by Rashi, of blessed memory). Nevertheless, there is a reason to ask why these two commandments were different from all the commandments of the Torah, that Moshe Rabbeinu needed to consult with the mighty one, and behold, all parts of the Torah were revealed to him and he received them from Sinai. I have explained according to the words of the holy Zohar (in Parashat Shemini) that there are many contradictions in the words of our Sages regarding this halacha, whether the graves of the righteous render one impure or not. And he, of blessed memory, concluded that by the very law it is fitting that the righteous should not render impure, for they have no impurity, and in their death they are called alive. However, we were not given to conduct ourselves according to this law, for this conclusion is beyond human understanding, as it is written, "For I, Hashem, search the heart and examine the kidneys," and man sees only with his eyes. Therefore, we should not conduct ourselves in this matter at all, even if we know that he is a righteous person, so as not to create a distinction between one righteous person and another, for we do not have the power to discern between them, etc. As stated, it is clear and true, with the help of Hashem.
summary: The passage discusses the necessity for Moses to seek divine guidance regarding specific commandments, highlighting the unique nature of the laws concerning the daughters of Zelophehad and the concept of the purity of the righteous. It emphasizes that while the Torah was fully revealed to Moses, certain matters require divine insight beyond human understanding, particularly regarding the status of the righteous after death. The text underscores the idea that the righteous are considered alive even in death, and thus, human judgment should not differentiate between them, as true discernment belongs to God alone.

passage_content: ובזה יתבאר לענינינו דהנה איתא בגמרא (סוכה כ"ה ע"א) ויהי אנשים אשר היו טמאים לנפש אדם, מי היו נושאי ארונו של יוסף היו, נמצא דאם צדיקים אינם מטמאים, היו ראויים אלו להקריב הפסח במועדו ככל ישראל, ולזה באו בטענה לפני משה ואהרן אנחנו טמאים לנפש אדם, היינו לנפש צדיק למה נגרע לבלתי הקריב את קרבן ה' במועדו בתוך בנ"י, והשיב להם משרע"ה עמדו ואשמעה מה יצוה ה' לכם, להורות כי לא ניתן הכרעה זו ביד בי"ד של מטה, ואף אם נודע לנו בבירור שהוא צדיק מטעם שלא לחלק בין צדיק לצדיק דאין כח המבחין בידינו כנ"ל, ובזה א"ש שבתשובתו של הקב"ה למשרע"ה לא נתפרש על פרט הנשאל אם יקריבו הם הפסח במועדו או לאו, רק הודיעו ההלכה בסתם טמאים דעלמא, איש איש כי יהי' טמא לנפש וגו' והטעם כי לא נתנה לנו להתנהג בדין זה כנ"ל, וטמאים דעלמא נדחו לפסח שני והבן. ועד"ז יתבאר בענין בנות צלפחד, דאיתא בספרי לאלה תחלק הארץ צדיקים כמותכם, ואמרז"ל (שבת צ"ו ע"ב) מקושש זה צלפחד ולפי"ז מה מקום לטענתם ליטול חלק בארץ, אמנם כתבו התוס' במס' ב"ב בשם המדרש דמקושש לש"ש נתכוין עיי"ש, ועד"ז הי' טענתם דצדיק גמור הי', וע"כ ויקרב משה את משפטן לפני ה' דלא ניתן לבי"ד של מטה להכריע בזה דרק הבוי"ת חוקר לב ובוחן כליות לידע מחשבה שבלב והבן. (עיין בדברינו במקומו תקחנו משם).
translation:
And this will clarify our matter, for it is stated in the Gemara (Sukkah 25a) that there were men who were impure due to a dead body; they were the bearers of Joseph's coffin. It turns out that if the righteous do not render themselves impure, these men were worthy to bring the Passover offering at its appointed time like all of Israel. Therefore, they came with a claim before Moses and Aaron, saying, "We are impure due to a dead body," meaning due to the dead body of a righteous person. "Why should we be diminished from bringing the offering of the Lord at its appointed time among the children of Israel?" Moses replied to them, "Stand and I will hear what the Lord commands you," to indicate that this decision was not given into the hands of the earthly court. Even if it were known to us clearly that he was a righteous person, for the reason that we do not differentiate between one righteous person and another, as we do not have the power to discern, as mentioned above. And thus, it is understood that in God's response to Moses, it was not clarified regarding the specific question of whether they would bring the Passover at its appointed time or not; rather, He informed him of the general law regarding the impure, that each person who is impure due to a dead body, etc., and the reason is that we were not given the authority to act in this matter, as mentioned above. The general impure ones were pushed off to the second Passover, and understand this. 

Similarly, it can be explained regarding the daughters of Zelophehad, as it is stated in the Sifrei, "To these shall the land be divided, like you righteous ones." And our sages said (Shabbat 96b) that the gatherer was Zelophehad. According to this, what place did they have to claim a portion in the land? However, the Tosafot wrote in Bava Batra in the name of the Midrash that the gatherer intended for the sake of Heaven, see there. And similarly, their claim was that he was a complete righteous person. Therefore, Moses brought their case before the Lord, for it was not given to the earthly court to decide in this matter, as only the Blessed One searches the heart and examines the innermost thoughts to know the thoughts in the heart, and understand this. (Refer to our words in their place, take it from there).
summary: The passage discusses the concept of purity and the status of the righteous in relation to communal obligations, specifically the Passover sacrifice. It highlights that even those who are ritually impure due to contact with a dead body, like the bearers of Joseph's coffin, felt entitled to participate in the sacrifice, arguing their righteousness. Moses' response emphasizes that the determination of such matters is beyond human judgment, as only God knows the true intentions of the heart. This reflects a broader theological insight that divine authority supersedes human legalistic interpretations, particularly in matters of spiritual significance.

passage_content: ונקדים עוד מ"ש האוהחה"ק (פ' חקת) שלא מצינו שהקפיד ה' בפסח מצרים על דין הטומאה, שיהיו טמאי מתים נדחין מלעשות הפסח, וטעם הדבר כי ישראל לא היו טמאי מת, הגם שנגעו והאהילו על המת, אבל לפי שעדיין לא קבלו את התורה, דנו בהם דין גר שנתגייר ביום י"ד ששוחטין עליו ואין חוששין לטומאה שנטמא קודם שנתגייר, ופי' בזה מאמה"כ זאת חקת התורה וגו', פי' חקה זו של הטומאה ותנאי טהרתה תסובב מהתורה, כי ע"י שקבלו התורה נעשו עם בני ישראל דבר שהרוחנים השפלים תאבים להדבק בהם וכו' ובמותם ג"כ תתרבה הטומאה כאמרם ז"ל ישראל מטמאין באהל ואין אומות מטמאין באוהל וכו' ואשר יסובב הכל הוא התורה עייש"ד, ועפי"ז פירשתי דברי המכילתא בפרשת קרבן פסח, וילכו ויעשו בנ"י כאשר צוה ה' את משה ואהרן כן עשו, מה ת"ל כן עשו, אף משה ואהרן כן עשו עכ"ד המכילתא (והובא ברש"י ז"ל) וצ"ב מה צורך להשמיענו שאף משה ואהרן קיימו מצות הפסח ככל ישראל, ולדרכינו נאמר כי הנה בנ"י לא נזהרו מטומאת מת בפסח מצרים, שערם קבלתם התורה לא הי' נוהג לגבייהו דין טומאת מת כדברי האוהחה"ק הנ"ל, אמנם משה ואהרן שקיימו את התורה בעודם במצרים איך הקריבו קרבן פסח, ואפשר מפני דישראל קודם קבלת התורה לא הי' נוהג לגבייהו דין טומאה כלל, וכמו שלא נטמאו במת כך אינם מטמאין אחרים הנוגעים בהם, ולדברי הסובר דעכו"ם מטמא במשא ורק מטומאת אהל נתמעטו אפשר דנזהרו משה ואהרן ממשא וא"ש שהקריבו קרבן פסח. (עיין בדברינו פ' וישלח עמוד קנ"ו עוד בענין זה) אמנם הרי מפורש בפסוק שנשא משה עצמות יוסף עמו, ויוסף הצדיק וודאי הי' לו דין ישראל לחומרא, ואיך הקריב קרבן פסח, אכן כבר ביררנו לעיל דצדיקים אין להם טומאה ובמיתתם נקראו חיים, וא"ש דהוצרך להשמיענו דאף משה ואהרן כן עשו והקריבו את הפסח, ולא נמנעו מדין הטומאה שנהג בהם, ואפשר שלטעם זה לא נכתב בפירוש שאף משה הקריב הפסח, דדין זה שאין צדיקים מטמאים לא ניתן לקבוע הלכה בפירוש, דאין כח המבחין בידינו כמ"ש ק"ז הישמח משה זלה"ה, וע"כ נכתב רק ברמז במאמר כן עשו, דלפי פשוטו קאי על בני ישראל, אלא שהכריחו רז"ל מיתורא דקרא, שנרמז בו שאף משה ואהרן קיימו מצות הפסח, ולא נמנעו לצד דין הטומאה שנוהגת אצלם.
translation: And we will also preface what the holy author writes (in Parashat Chukat) that we do not find that the Holy One, blessed be He, was particular about the law of impurity during the Passover in Egypt, that those who were impure from the dead were pushed away from performing the Passover. The reason for this is that the Israelites were not impure from the dead, even though they touched and were in the tent of the dead, but since they had not yet received the Torah, they were judged as a convert who converts on the 14th, for whom they slaughter the Passover and do not concern themselves with the impurity that he became impure before he converted. And this is explained by the verse: "This is the statute of the Torah," meaning that this statute of impurity and the conditions of its purity revolve around the Torah, for by receiving the Torah, they became part of the people of Israel, a thing that the lowly spirits desire to cling to, etc., and in their death, impurity also increases, as our sages said, "Israel imparts impurity in a tent, and the nations do not impart impurity in a tent," etc. And that which encompasses everything is the Torah, as is known. And according to this, I explained the words of the Mekilta in the section of the Passover offering, "And the children of Israel went and did as the Lord commanded Moses and Aaron; so they did." What does it mean, "so they did"? Even Moses and Aaron did so, thus says the Mekilta (and it is brought in Rashi). And it is necessary to ask what is the need to inform us that even Moses and Aaron fulfilled the commandment of the Passover like all of Israel. According to our approach, we can say that behold, the children of Israel did not guard against the impurity of the dead during the Passover in Egypt, since their receiving of the Torah did not apply to them the law of impurity of the dead, as the holy author mentioned above. However, Moses and Aaron, who fulfilled the Torah while still in Egypt, how did they offer the Passover sacrifice? It is possible that because the Israelites, prior to receiving the Torah, did not have the law of impurity apply to them at all, just as they were not made impure by the dead, so they do not make others impure who touch them. And according to the opinion that a non-Jew imparts impurity through carrying, and only through the impurity of a tent they were diminished, it is possible that Moses and Aaron were careful about carrying, and it is understood that they offered the Passover sacrifice. (See our words in Parashat Vayishlach, page 156, further on this matter.) However, it is explicitly stated in the verse that Moses carried the bones of Joseph with him, and Joseph the righteous certainly had the status of Israel stringently. How then did he offer the Passover sacrifice? Indeed, we have already clarified above that the righteous have no impurity, and in their death, they are called alive. And it is understood that it was necessary to inform us that even Moses and Aaron did so and offered the Passover, and they were not prevented by the law of impurity that applied to them. And it is possible that for this reason it was not explicitly written that even Moses offered the Passover, for the law that the righteous do not impart impurity cannot be established as a clear halacha, for we do not have the discerning power, as it is said, "Blessed is he who rejoices in Moses, our teacher." Therefore, it was written only in hint in the statement "so they did," that according to its simple meaning it refers to the children of Israel, except that the sages were compelled by the excess of the verse to hint that even Moses and Aaron fulfilled the commandment of the Passover and were not prevented by the law of impurity that was applicable to them.
summary: The passage discusses the unique status of the Israelites during the Passover in Egypt, emphasizing that they were not considered ritually impure despite contact with the dead, as they had not yet received the Torah. It highlights the concept that prior to the giving of the Torah, the laws of impurity did not apply to them, akin to a convert who is not held accountable for past impurities. The text also addresses the actions of Moses and Aaron, who, despite their adherence to the Torah, were able to perform the Passover sacrifice without being affected by the laws of impurity, illustrating the idea that the righteous, like Joseph, are not subject to the same spiritual limitations. Ultimately, the passage underscores the transformative power of the Torah in defining the spiritual identity and purity of the Jewish people.

passage_content: ובזה יתבארו דברי המכילתא בא וראה חכמתו של משה שכל ישראל נתעסקו בביזה והוא נתעסק במצות שנאמר חכם לב יקח מצות, ולכאורה מדוע יחסוהו אל חכמתו ומה ענין החכמה בזה, ויותר יאות ליחסהו אל צדקותו וחסידותו, גם מ"ש מצות בלשון רבים צ"ב ואינו כ"א מצוה אחת, אמנם הי' לו לחוש שע"י העסק בעצמות יוסף ימנע ממנו הקרבת הפסח, ואולי גם השראת השכינה שהי' תדירה אצלו, אלא שחכמתו עמדה לו והשיג שהעסק בעצמות יוסף לא ימנעהו מן המצות, וזה וזה יתקיימו בידו, והכרעה זו אין דעת אנושי מקפת אותה, אבל משרע"ה נתעלה בחכמת אלקית מבחי' חכמה עליונה, והכריע כן בחכמתו שעי"ז ישיג מצות הרבה, וז"ש בא וראה חכמתו של משה וכו' שנא' חכם לב יקח מצות והבן.
translation: And in this, the words of the Mechilta will be clarified: Come and see the wisdom of Moses, for all of Israel were occupied with the spoils, and he was engaged in the commandments, as it is said, "A wise heart will acquire commandments." At first glance, why is this attributed to his wisdom, and what is the connection of wisdom to this? It would be more fitting to attribute it to his righteousness and piety. Also, the term "commandments" in the plural is puzzling, as it refers to only one commandment. However, he had to be concerned that by engaging with the bones of Joseph, he would be prevented from offering the Passover sacrifice, and perhaps also from the resting of the Shechinah that was constantly with him. Yet, his wisdom stood by him, and he understood that engaging with the bones of Joseph would not prevent him from the commandments, and both this and that would be fulfilled in his hands. This decision is beyond human understanding, but since Moshe Rabbeinu was elevated in divine wisdom from the aspect of supreme wisdom, he decided thus in his wisdom, through which he would attain many commandments. Therefore, it is said, "Come and see the wisdom of Moses," etc., as it is stated, "A wise heart will acquire commandments," and understand.
summary: The passage highlights the profound wisdom of Moses, who prioritized the fulfillment of commandments over the material concerns of the Israelites during the plunder. It emphasizes that his wisdom, rooted in divine understanding, allowed him to engage in the mitzvah of handling Joseph's bones without neglecting the Passover sacrifice. This illustrates a unique aspect of his righteousness, where his elevated spiritual insight enabled him to harmonize multiple commandments simultaneously, showcasing the depth of his connection to divine wisdom. Ultimately, it underscores the idea that true wisdom in serving God transcends human understanding.

passage_content: ואפ"ל עוד דהנה ישראל נתעסקו בביזה עפ"י מצות השם עליהם, ובוודאי שלא יצוה ה' ליקח ממון של אחרים שלא מן הדין, והרבה תירוצים נאמרו בזה, והאמת שכל רכוש מצרים מגיע לישראל מדינא שזכו בהם מיוסף הצדיק, כדאיתא במדרש ילקוט (פ' ויגש רמז קנ"ח) וילקט יוסף את כל הכסף וגו' א"ר יהודה אמר שמואל כל כסף וזהב שבעולם לקט יוסף והביא למצרים, שנאמר וילקט יוסף את כל הכסף, אין לו אלא בארץ מצרים, שבארץ כנען ובשאר ארצות מנין, תלמוד לומר וכל הארץ באו מצרימה, וכשעלו ישראל ממצרים העלוהו עמהם שנאמר וינצלו את מצרים עכ"ד המדרש, מבואר דעפ"י הדין ה"ה של ישראל שיוסף הצדיק זכה בהם בשבילם, אלא שאחר הסתלקותו נטלוהו המצרים שלא בדין, וכשיצאו ישראל הצילו מידם את שלהם, וע"כ בעת שכל ישראל נתעסקו בביזה נתעסק משה רבינו בעצמות יוסף להראות שהוא הזוכה ומזכה לישראל בביזה ושלהם נטלו, וז"ש במכילתא בא וראה חכמתו של משה שכל ישראל נתעסקו בביזה והוא נתעסק במצות וא"ש הקישור.
translation: And even though it is true that Israel was engaged in plunder according to the command of the Holy One, Blessed be He, it is certain that the Lord would not command to take the property of others unjustly. Many explanations have been given regarding this, and the truth is that all the wealth of Egypt rightfully belongs to Israel, as they acquired it through Joseph the Righteous, as it is stated in the Midrash Yalkut (Parashat Vayigash, Remez 158): "And Joseph gathered all the money, etc." Rabbi Judah said in the name of Shmuel: "All the silver and gold in the world was gathered by Joseph and brought to Egypt," as it is said, "And Joseph gathered all the money." It is only in the land of Egypt; from where do we know it is in the land of Canaan and other lands? The verse states, "And all the land came to Egypt." And when Israel ascended from Egypt, they took it with them, as it is said, "And they plundered the Egyptians." Thus, it is clear that according to the law, it belongs to Israel, which Joseph the Righteous acquired for them, but after his passing, the Egyptians took it from them unjustly. When Israel left Egypt, they reclaimed what was theirs from them. Therefore, at the time when all of Israel was engaged in plunder, Moses our Teacher was occupied with the bones of Joseph to show that he is the rightful one and is granting Israel their share of the plunder, and that which they took was theirs. This is what is stated in the Mekilta: "Come and see the wisdom of Moses, for all of Israel was engaged in plunder, and he was engaged in a commandment," and this clarifies the connection.
summary: The passage discusses the theological justification for the Israelites taking wealth from the Egyptians during the Exodus, asserting that this wealth rightfully belonged to them due to Joseph's actions in Egypt. It emphasizes that the riches were originally acquired by Joseph for the benefit of Israel, and when the Egyptians wrongfully retained them, the Israelites reclaimed what was theirs upon leaving. Additionally, it highlights Moses' focus on retrieving Joseph's bones as a demonstration of rightful ownership and adherence to divine commandments, illustrating the connection between spiritual duty and material justice.

passage_content: ונבוא לתרץ קושית המפורשים על מ"ש רש"י ז"ל בשם המכילתא למה לא השביע יוסף את בניו שישאוהו לא"י מיד כמו שהשביע יעקב וכו', ולכאורה הול"ל קושיא זאת לעיל בפ' ויחי אצל סיפור השבועה זאת, (עיין קושיא א' לעיל), ויתבאר בהקדם דברי הזוה"ק פ' תרומה (דף קמ"א ע"ב) גופיהון דצדיקיא דלא מתענגי בהאי עלמא אלא מתענוגי דמצוה וכו' ההוא רוח מסאבא לא יכיל לשלטאה עלייהו, דהא לא אתענגו מדילי' כלום וכו', מאן דנשמתיה נפקא לבר מארעא קדישא, והאי גופא אסתאב בההוא רוח מסאבו וכו', ואי האי גופא סלקין לי' לאתקברא גו ארעא קדישא, עלי' כתיב (ירמיה ב') ותבואו ותטמאו את ארצי ונחלתי שמתם לתועבה וכו' יוסף לא שליט על גופי' רוח מסאבו לעלמין וכו', ועם כל דא לא בעא דגופי' יסלקון לי' לאתקברא בארעא קדישא, אלא אמר והעליתם את עצמותי ולא גופי', יעקב לא מית וגופי' אתקיים בקיומא תדיר ולא דחיל לסט"א וכו', ועל דא כתיב ושכבתי עם אבותי ונשאתני ממצרים גופא שלים עכ"ד הזוה"ק לענינינו, הרי מבואר הטעם שלא השביע יוסף לבניו שישאוהו לא"י מיד, שלא יהי' בכלל ונחלתי שמתם לתועבה, ואף דלפי מדריגת קדושתו לא שייך לגבי', דלא שליט בי' רוח מסאבא כלל, מ"מ לרוב ענותנותו חשש ונמנע להעלות גופו לטעם זה, ואפשר דע"כ לא הקשו במכילתא התם למה לא השביע יוסף את בניו שישאוהו לא"י מיד, דניחא להו בתירוץ הזוה"ק הנ"ל, אמנם בפסוק זה דכתיב ויקח משה את עצמות יוסף עמו עמו במחיצתו, מבואר מזה דאין בו דין טומאה כלל, דצדיקים אינם מטמאים אף במותם, ומעתה לא יונח עוד בטעמו של הזוה"ק, ע"כ הוקשה להם מ"ט לא השביע לבניו שישאוהו לא"י מיד, ותירצו כי חשש שמא לא יניחום המצרים ולא יוכלו לקיים שבועתו, ואפשר שמקושר טעם זה עם טעם הזוה"ק, דלצד שחשד א"ע שאינו ראוי לכך, ע"כ חש שמא לא יסתייע מילתא ויעכבו המצריים בידם, ולטעם זה השביעם לשיגאלו ויצאו ממצרים יעלו את עצמותיו, (ועיין בדברינו פ' ויחי עמוד תקי"ז מ"ש בזה).
translation: And we come to explain the question of the commentators on what Rashi, of blessed memory, said in the name of the Mechilta, why Joseph did not swear his sons to carry him to the Land of Israel immediately, as Jacob swore, etc. At first glance, this question should have been raised earlier in Parashat Vayechi regarding the story of this oath (see the first question above), and it will be clarified by first explaining the words of the Zohar, Parashat Terumah (page 131b), regarding the righteous who do not take pleasure in this world but in the pleasure of the mitzvah, etc. That spirit of impurity cannot rule over them, for they do not take any pleasure from it, etc. Whoever's soul departs from the Holy Land, and this very thing is bound to that spirit of impurity, etc. And if this very thing ascends to be buried in the Holy Land, it is written about it (Jeremiah 2): "And you came and defiled My land, and made My inheritance an abomination," etc. Joseph did not allow the spirit of impurity to rule over his body, etc. And despite all this, he did not want his body to be removed to be buried in the Holy Land, but rather said, "And you shall carry my bones up," not my body. Jacob did not die, and his body remains in a constant state of existence and did not fear the Other Side, etc. Therefore, it is written, "And I will lie with my fathers, and you shall carry me out of Egypt," my body is whole. Thus, the Zohar explains in relation to our matter, it is clear the reason why Joseph did not swear his sons to carry him to the Land of Israel immediately, so that he would not be included in "and made My inheritance an abomination." And even though according to his level of holiness it does not apply to him, for the spirit of impurity does not rule over him at all, nevertheless, out of great humility, he was concerned and refrained from raising his body for this reason. And it is possible that this is why they did not ask in the Mechilta there why Joseph did not swear his sons to carry him to the Land of Israel immediately, for they were satisfied with the answer of the aforementioned Zohar. However, in this verse that states, "And Moses took the bones of Joseph with him," it is clear from this that there is no law of impurity at all, for the righteous do not defile even in their death. From now on, it will not rest on the reasoning of the Zohar, therefore it was difficult for them why he did not swear his sons to carry him to the Land of Israel immediately, and they answered that he was concerned that the Egyptians would not allow them and they would not be able to fulfill his oath. And it is possible that this reason is connected to the reason of the Zohar, that on the one hand he suspected himself of being unworthy of this, therefore he was concerned that perhaps the matter would not succeed and the Egyptians would hold them back. And for this reason, he swore them to redeem and leave Egypt, to take his bones up (and see our words in Parashat Vayechi, page 117 regarding this).
summary: The passage discusses why Joseph did not swear his sons to carry his bones to the Land of Israel immediately, unlike Jacob. It highlights the concept that righteous individuals, who derive pleasure solely from fulfilling commandments, are not subject to the impurity of this world. Joseph, despite his elevated spiritual status, refrained from insisting on his burial in the Holy Land out of humility and concern that it might lead to impurity or be hindered by the Egyptians. Ultimately, he instructed them to ensure his bones would be taken out of Egypt when they left, reflecting a deep awareness of both spiritual and practical considerations in the fulfillment of divine promises.

passage_content: ויקח משה את עצמות יוסף עמו, במס' סוטה (י"ג ע"א) בא וראה כמה חביבות מצות על משה רבינו, שכל ישראל נתעסקו בביזה והוא נתעסק במצות שנא' חכם לב יקח מצות וגו' ומנין היה יודע משה רבינו היכן יוסף קבור, אמרו סרח בת אשר נשתיירה מאותו הדור, הלך משה אצלה א"ל כלום את יודעת היכן יוסף קבור, אמרה לו ארון של מתכת עשו לו המצרים וקבעוהו בנילוס וכו', וכתב המהרש"א ז"ל דגם שאר ארונות של השבטים העלו עמהם וכו', אבל היו יודעין קבורתם, משא"כ ביוסף שהעלימו המצרים קבורתו וכו', ולהכי קבעי מנין הי' יודע משה היכן יוסף קבור, דאינו דומה שידע זה בנבואה כיון שלא הוזכר בקרא, אבל ידע ע"י סרח בת אשר שהוא היתה מאותו הדור עכ"ל המהרש"א ז"ל, לכאורה תירוצו אינו מספיק דאינו מן הנמנע שהשיג משרע"ה בנבואה מקום קבורתו של יוסף ואף שלא הוזכר בקרא, וכמו שהשיג הרבה דברים נעלמים שאינם מפורשים בפסוקי התורה, ומאי קא קשיא לי' לגמ' מנין היה משה רבינו יודע וכו', גם צ"ב הקישור אל מה שדרשו חכם לב יקח מצות וגו' ומנין הי' יודע משה רבינו וכו', ומדוע ל"ק להו בל"ז, וכן דקדק ק"ז הישמח משה זלל"ה (בפ' בשלח).
translation: And Moses took the bones of Joseph with him. In the tractate Sotah (13a), it says, "Come and see how beloved the commandments are to our teacher Moses, for all of Israel were occupied with the spoils, and he was occupied with the commandments," as it is stated, "A wise heart will take commandments," etc. And how did our teacher Moses know where Joseph was buried? They said that Serach, the daughter of Asher, who remained from that generation, went to Moses and he asked her, "Do you know where Joseph is buried?" She told him, "The Egyptians made a metal coffin for him and placed it in the Nile," etc. And the Maharsha, may his memory be blessed, wrote that the other coffins of the tribes were also brought up with them, etc., but they knew their burial places, unlike Joseph, whose burial place was concealed by the Egyptians, etc. Therefore, the question arises, how did Moses know where Joseph was buried? It is not comparable to know this through prophecy since it was not mentioned in the verse, but he knew through Serach, the daughter of Asher, who was from that generation. Thus far the Maharsha, may his memory be blessed. At first glance, his answer is not sufficient, for it is not impossible that Moses received through prophecy the location of Joseph's burial, even though it was not mentioned in the verse, just as he grasped many hidden matters that are not explicitly stated in the verses of the Torah. And what is the Gemara's question to him, "How did our teacher Moses know?" Also, it is puzzling the connection to what they expounded, "A wise heart will take commandments," etc., and why it was not stated to them in a different manner. And thus, the Yismach Moshe, may his memory be blessed, was particular about this in Parashat Beshalach.
summary: The passage discusses Moses' dedication to fulfilling the commandment of taking Joseph's bones from Egypt, highlighting his exceptional commitment to mitzvot amidst the distractions of the Israelites. It raises the question of how Moses knew the location of Joseph's burial, suggesting that he learned it from Serach bat Asher, the last survivor of that generation. The text emphasizes the idea that divine knowledge can be conveyed through human means, and it reflects on the significance of wisdom and understanding in the observance of commandments. The connection between Moses' actions and the concept of a "wise heart" underscores the importance of prioritizing spiritual duties over material concerns.

passage_content: ב) הקשה ק"ז זלה"ה דמשמע דדרשו חז"ל רישא דקרא חכם לב יקח מצות, בשבח משרע"ה שהיתה המצוה חביבה עליו, וסיפא דקרא ואויל שפתים ילבט על ישראל שנתעסקו בביזה (עיין בח"א מהרש"א שם) ולכאורה יש להפליא דהרי עסקו בביזה שלא ברצונם, כ"א נצטוו על זה מפי הגבורה וקיימו בזה מצות הבוי"ת, ומה דשבקו העסק בעצמות יוסף למשרע"ה, מבואר שם בגמ' דכוונתם לש"ש היתה ואמרו כבודו בגדולים יותר מבקטנים.
translation: B) The difficulty is raised in K"Z Z"L"H that it implies that the Sages interpreted the beginning of the verse "A wise heart will acquire commandments" as a praise of Moshe Rabbeinu, that the commandment was dear to him, and the end of the verse "but a fool's lips will bring about strife" refers to Israel who were engaged in plunder (see in Ch"A Maharsha there). At first glance, it is astonishing, for they were engaged in plunder not of their own will, but rather they were commanded to do so from the mouth of the Almighty and fulfilled the commandment of the Blessed One. And what they left the engagement with the bones of Yosef for Moshe Rabbeinu, it is explained there in the Gemara that their intention was for the sake of Heaven, and they said that his honor is greater among the great than among the small.
summary: The passage discusses the dual interpretation of the verse "A wise heart will acquire commandments," highlighting the reverence Moses had for the commandments. It contrasts this with the behavior of the Israelites, who engaged in plunder not out of desire but as a divine command, thus fulfilling God's will. The text emphasizes that their intention was for the sake of Heaven, indicating a deeper spiritual commitment, as they prioritized honoring God over personal gain.

passage_content: ג) יל"ד דדרשו חכם לב יקח מצות על משרע"ה שנתעסק בעצמות יוסף, ואין זו אלא מצוה א', ומה דדרשו אויל שפתים ילבט על ישראל שעסקו בביזה צ"ב דאין ענין זה לשפתים.
translation: 3) It was said that a wise-hearted person will take the mitzvah regarding Moshe Rabbeinu, who was involved with the bones of Yosef, and this is nothing but one mitzvah. And what they said, "A fool's lips will bring strife" regarding Israel who were engaged in plunder, is a question of whether this matter pertains to lips.
summary: The passage emphasizes the significance of engaging with the essence of spiritual matters, as exemplified by Moses' involvement with the bones of Joseph, which is seen as a singular mitzvah (commandment). It contrasts this with the superficiality of those who merely speak without true understanding, particularly regarding the Israelites' focus on material gain. This highlights the Hasidic teaching that true devotion and understanding come from deep, meaningful engagement with one's faith and heritage, rather than mere external observance. Ultimately, it calls for a deeper connection to the spiritual essence behind religious practices.

passage_content: ויתבאר הענין בהקדם דברי המדרש (ילקוט סו"פ ברכה רמז תתקס"ה) ויקבור אותו בגי, במה זכה משה שהקב"ה נתעסק בו, אלא בשעה שהיו ישראל עסוקין בביזה, הי' מסבב את העיר ג' ימים וג' לילות למצוא ארונו של יוסף ולא מצאו, אחר שנתיגע הרבה פגעה בו סרח בת אשר, אמרה לו רבינו משה למה אתה יגע כל כך אמר לה ג' ימים וג' לילות סבבתי את העיר לבקש ארונו של יוסף ואיני מוצאו, אמרה לו בוא עמי הוליכו לנהר נילוס וכו', א"ל הקב"ה אם בעיניך דבר קטן שעשית חסד, גדול הוא בעיני שלא השגחת בכסף וזהב, ואף אני ארד בכבודי ובעצמי לעשות עמך חסד כשתפטר מן העולם עכ"ד המדרש ולכאורה צ"ב דהרי הג' ימים וג' לילות שהי' משרע"ה מסבב את העיר למצוא ארונו של יוסף, היו בהכרח ג' ימים סמוך ליציאתם, ויתכן שהי' בג' ימי אפילה, דלפי חשבון הרמב"ן ז"ל (בר"פ בא) נמשכו ימי האפילה עד ערב פסח עיי"ש, וישראל עסקו בהשאלת כליהם של מצרים רק אחר מכת בכורות, כמבואר בפסוקים ותחזק מצרים על העם למהר לשלחם וגו' ובנ"י עשו כדבר משה וישאלו ממצרים וגו', ולפי"ז לא היו בזמן א' וביום א', וצ"ב לשון הילקוט הנ"ל בשעה שהיו ישראל עסוקין בביזה, הי' משרע"ה מסבב את העיר ג' ימים וג' לילות, גם דברי הגמ' דסוטה הנ"ל צ"ב, במ"ש שכל ישראל נתעסקו בביזה והוא נתעסק בעצמות יוסף, והרי זמנו של זה לא כזמנו של זה. ואיך דרשוהו רז"ל בשבח משה שלא השגיח בכסף וזהב וכו' ובגנותן של ישראל דשבקו העסק בעצמות יוסף ועסקו בביזה ולא קרב זל"ז בזמן וצ"ב.
translation:
And the matter will be clarified by first mentioning the words of the Midrash (Yalkut, end of Parashat Berachah, hint 865). And he buried him in the valley; what merit did Moses have that the Holy One, Blessed be He, engaged with him? Rather, at the time when Israel was occupied with the plunder, he was circling the city for three days and three nights to find the coffin of Joseph, but he did not find it. After he exerted himself greatly, he encountered Serach bat Asher, who said to him, "Our teacher Moses, why are you exerting yourself so much?" He said to her, "For three days and three nights I have been circling the city to seek the coffin of Joseph, and I cannot find it." She said to him, "Come with me; I will lead you to the Nile River," etc. The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to him, "If in your eyes it is a small matter that you did kindness, it is great in My eyes that you did not concern yourself with silver and gold, and I too will descend in My glory and personally do kindness with you when you depart from this world." Thus far the Midrash. 

And at first glance, it is difficult to understand, for the three days and three nights that Moshe Rabbeinu was circling the city to find the coffin of Joseph must have been necessarily three days close to their departure. It is possible that it was during the three days of darkness, for according to the calculation of the Ramban, the days of darkness extended until the eve of Passover, as noted there. And Israel was occupied with borrowing the vessels of Egypt only after the plague of the firstborn, as is explained in the verses, "And the Egyptians urged the people to hasten to send them out," etc., and the children of Israel did as Moses had spoken and borrowed from Egypt, etc. According to this, they were not at the same time, and it is difficult to understand the language of the aforementioned Yalkut, "At the time when Israel was occupied with the plunder, Moshe Rabbeinu was circling the city for three days and three nights." The words of the Gemara in Sotah are also difficult, in that it states that all of Israel was engaged in plunder while he was occupied with the bones of Joseph, and the time of this one is not the same as the time of that one. How did our Sages interpret this in praise of Moses, that he did not concern himself with silver and gold, etc., and in condemnation of Israel, that they abandoned the engagement with the bones of Joseph and occupied themselves with plunder, and they did not come close to one another in time? And this is difficult.
summary: The passage discusses the merit of Moses in seeking the bones of Joseph while the Israelites were preoccupied with plundering the Egyptians. It highlights the contrast between Moses's selfless act of kindness, which was deemed significant by God, and the Israelites' focus on material wealth. The text raises questions about the timing of these events, suggesting a deeper theological insight into the nature of true devotion and the value of spiritual pursuits over material gain. Ultimately, it emphasizes the importance of prioritizing acts of kindness and faithfulness in the face of worldly distractions.

passage_content: ונל"פ דמה שעסקו ישראל בהשאלת כלי המצריים אחר מכת בכורות, יפה עשו וכדין עשו וקיימו מצות הבוי"ת, אבל בג' ימי האפילה שנתעסקו ישראל לחפש בתי המצרים, ובאותו זמן נתייגע משה רבינו למצוא ארונו של יוסף, לזה דרשוהו רז"ל בשבח משה וגנותן של ישראל, דאף שהי' רצון הבוי"ת שיראו ישראל כליהם כמבואר במד"ר דזו א' מהטעמים שהביא הקב"ה חשך על המצריים, אולם להשלים רצון הבוי"ת הי' מספיק בראי' בעלמא ובזמן קצר, ונחשב לחסרון מה שהרבו ההתעסקות בו, כדמשמע מדברי הילקוט הנ"ל שג' ימים וג' לילות שהיה משרע"ה מסבב את העיר לחפש ארונו של יוסף, היו ישראל עסוקין בביזה, ולזה דרשו רז"ל ואויל שפתים ילבט על ישראל, דעצם לקיחת הביזה מצוה הוא, והחסרון הי' מה שהרבו דבר שפתים בענין הביזה, ולא בעסק עצמות יוסף, והגם דלישא ארונו של יוסף כבודו יותר בגדולים ומה"ט הניחוהו למשרע"ה, אבל מה שנתייגע משרע"ה ג' ימים וג' לילות למצוא ארונו של יוסף, הי"ל לישראל להצטרף עמו ולהתעסק במצוה זו והם היו עסוקים בביזה.
translation: And it seems that what the Israelites engaged in by borrowing the vessels of the Egyptians after the plague of the firstborn was indeed a good thing, and they acted correctly and fulfilled the command of the Holy One, Blessed be He. However, during the three days of darkness, when the Israelites were busy searching the houses of the Egyptians, at that same time, our teacher Moses was laboring to find the coffin of Joseph. For this, our Sages praised Moses and criticized Israel, for although it was the will of the Holy One, Blessed be He, that the Israelites should see their vessels, as explained in the Midrash, that this is one of the reasons that the Holy One, Blessed be He, brought darkness upon the Egyptians, nevertheless, to fulfill the will of the Holy One, Blessed be He, it would have been sufficient to see them in a mere moment, and it was considered a shortcoming that they engaged so much in it, as is implied from the words of the aforementioned Yalkut, that for three days and three nights, Moses was circling the city to search for the coffin of Joseph, while the Israelites were occupied with plunder. And for this, our Sages said, "A fool with lips will argue against Israel," for the very act of taking the plunder is a commandment, and the shortcoming was that they spoke excessively about the plunder and not about the matter of the bones of Joseph. And although carrying the coffin of Joseph is a greater honor for the great ones, and for this reason they left it to Moses, nonetheless, the fact that Moses labored for three days and three nights to find the coffin of Joseph, the Israelites should have joined him and engaged in this commandment, while they were busy with the plunder.
summary: The passage discusses the actions of the Israelites during the plagues in Egypt, particularly their engagement in taking the Egyptians' possessions after the plague of the firstborn. It highlights that while this act was a fulfillment of God's command, their excessive focus on material gain during the three days of darkness was seen as a shortcoming. In contrast, Moses's dedication to finding Joseph's bones is praised, suggesting that the Israelites should have joined him in this significant mitzvah instead of being preoccupied with plunder. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the importance of prioritizing spiritual obligations over material pursuits.

passage_content: ואפשר שהעלימו מן השמים ממשרע"ה השגת ידיעה זו היכן יוסף קבור, כדי שתהי' פעולת מצותו יתירה, ובכל פסיעה ופסיעה שנתייגע למצוא ארונו של יוסף קיים מצוה וקבל שכר, וע"ד שאמרז"ל (בב"ר פ' ל"ט סימן ט') באברהם שא"ל הקב"ה אל הארץ אשר אראך ולמה לא גילה לו מיד, כדי לחבבה בעיניו וליתן שכר על כל פסיעה ופסיעה, ולזה דרשו רז"ל חכם לב יקח מצות על משרע"ה, שנתייגע למצוא ארונו של יוסף וקיים בזה מצות הרבה בכל פסיעה ופסיעה, וא"ש הקישור ומנין הי' יודע משה רבינו היכן יוסף קבור, דכיון שהעלימו מן השמים ידיעה זו ממנו כדי להרבות שכרו, א"כ מנין הי' יודע, ותירצו דאחר שנתייגע הרבה פגעה בו סרח בת אשר והראה לו מקום קבורתו.
translation: And it is possible that they concealed from the heavens from Moshe Rabbeinu the knowledge of where Yosef is buried, so that the fulfillment of his commandment would be greater, and with every step he took in his effort to find the coffin of Yosef, he would fulfill a commandment and receive reward. This is in accordance with what our Sages of blessed memory said (in Bereishit Rabbah, Parashah 39, Section 9) regarding Avraham, to whom the Holy One, Blessed be He, said, "To the land that I will show you," and why He did not reveal it to him immediately, in order to endear it in his eyes and to give reward for every step he took. And for this reason, our Sages of blessed memory expounded that a wise heart will acquire commandments for Moshe Rabbeinu, who toiled to find the coffin of Yosef and fulfilled many commandments with every step he took. And this clarifies the connection and how Moshe Rabbeinu would know where Yosef was buried, for since they concealed this knowledge from him in order to increase his reward, how would he know? They answered that after he toiled greatly, he encountered Serach bat Asher, who showed him the place of his burial.
summary: The passage discusses the idea that God concealed from Moses the location of Joseph's burial to enhance the merit of his efforts in fulfilling the commandment to find it. This aligns with the teaching that God often withholds information to increase the reward for each step taken in the pursuit of a mitzvah. Ultimately, after much effort, Moses was guided to the burial site by Serach bat Asher, illustrating the value of perseverance in spiritual endeavors. This reflects a broader Hasidic theme of the importance of striving for divine connection and the rewards that come from such efforts.

passage_content: ויגד למלך מצרים כי ברח העם, פרש"י איקטורין שלח עמהם, וכיון שהגיעו לג' ימים שקבעו לילך ולשוב וראו שאינן חוזרין למצרים, באו והגידו לפרעה ביום ד', ובחמישי ובששי רדפו אחריהם וליל שביעי ירדו לים בשחרית אמרו שירה והוא יום ז' של פסח: לכן אנו קורין השירה ביום השביעי עכ"ל רש"י ז"ל, והקשה הרא"ם ז"ל דמהכא משמע שלא שהו ישראל משיצאו ממצרים עד שאמרו שירה רק ז' ימים, ובסו"פ שלח כתב רשיז"ל מיסודו של ר' משה הדרשן שמנה ימים שהו ישראל משיצאו ממצרים עד שאמרו שירה, ושמא י"ל שר' משה הדרשן חולק עם האגדה האומרה בז' אמרו שירה עכ"ל הרא"ם, ותירוצו קשה דלא יתכן לומר שיחלקו במציאות, ויותר קשה דמפורש בגמ' (סוטה י"ב ע"ב) דבכ"א בניסן אמרו ישראל שירה, ומפורש בפסוק (במדבר ל"ג ג') ויסעו מרעמסס וגו' בחמשה עשר יום לחודש הראשון וגו', נמצא שביום הז' אמרו שירה, ואיך יחלוק ר"מ הדרשן על זה.
translation: And it was told to the king of Egypt that the people had fled. Rashi explains that Ikhtorin sent with them, and when they reached the three days they had set to go and return, and they saw that they were not returning to Egypt, they came and told Pharaoh on the fourth day. On the fifth and sixth, they pursued them, and on the night of the seventh, they descended to the sea at dawn and sang a song, and it was the seventh day of Passover. Therefore, we read the song on the seventh day, thus concludes Rashi, may his memory be blessed. The Ra'ah, may his memory be blessed, questioned that from here it seems that Israel did not stay from the time they left Egypt until they sang the song for only seven days. However, at the end of Shelach, Rashi, may his memory be blessed, wrote based on the foundation of Rabbi Moshe the preacher that Israel stayed seven days from the time they left Egypt until they sang the song. Perhaps one could say that Rabbi Moshe the preacher disagrees with the legend that states they sang the song on the seventh. Thus concludes the Ra'ah, and his answer is difficult, for it is not reasonable to say that they would disagree in reality. It is even more difficult, for it is explicitly stated in the Gemara (Sotah 12b) that on the twenty-first of Nisan, Israel sang a song, and it is explicitly stated in the verse (Numbers 33:3) that they departed from Rameses on the fifteenth day of the first month, etc. Thus, it turns out that on the seventh day they sang a song, and how could Rabbi Moshe the preacher disagree with this?
summary: The passage discusses the timeline of the Israelites' exodus from Egypt and their subsequent song of praise at the Sea of Reeds, emphasizing the significance of the seventh day of Passover when they sang. It highlights a debate among scholars regarding the duration of their journey before singing, with some asserting it was only seven days while others suggest a longer period. The theological insight reflects on the importance of divine intervention and the joy of redemption, as well as the unity of tradition and interpretation within Jewish thought. Ultimately, it underscores the miraculous nature of the Exodus and the celebration of freedom through song.

passage_content: ונקדים עוד קושית המזרחי (בפ' יתרו) עה"פ ואשא אתכם על כנפי נשרים, פרש"י (מדברי המכילתא) זה יום שבאו ישראל לרעמסס, שהיו ישראל מפוזרין בכל ארץ גושן. ולשעה קלה כשבאו ליסע ולצאת נקבצו כולם לרעמסס, אבל בפ' בא בפסוק ויסעו בנ"י מרעמסס סכותה, אמרו במכילתא והביאו רש"י בפירושו, ק"כ מיל הי' ובאו שם לפי שעה שנאמר ואשא אתכם על כנפי נשרים. (ולפי"ז הנס של כנפי נשרים נעשה להם בנסיעתם מרעמסס לסוכות), ושמא י"ל שקול הוא ויבואו שניהם, דתרווייהו משתמעי מהאי קרא עכ"ל הרא"ם ז"ל, ר"ל דתרווייהו הי' ע"י כנפי נשרים ובשעה קלה שלא כדרך הטבע, אמנם לפי"ז צ"ב מ"ש רשיז"ל כאן (בפ' בשלח) עה"פ ויסעו מסוכות וגו' ביום השני, שהרי בראשון באו מרעמסס לסוכות, ולפי"ד המכילתא ורש"י ז"ל (בפ' בא) שנסיעתם מרעמסס לסוכות על כנפי נשרים ובשעה קלה הי', א"כ אין מוכרח שנסיעתם מסוכות ביום השני הי', והי' אפשר שיהי' הכל ביום א', כיון שלא הי' דרך הטבע כלל.
translation: And we will also present the question of the Mizrachi (in Parashat Yitro) on the verse "And I bore you on the wings of eagles." Rashi explains (from the words of the Mechilta) that this refers to the day when Israel came to Raamses, as the Israelites were scattered throughout the land of Goshen. For a brief moment, when they were about to travel and leave, they all gathered in Raamses. However, in Parashat Bo, in the verse "And the children of Israel journeyed from Raamses to Succoth," it is stated in the Mechilta, and Rashi brought it in his commentary, that it was a distance of 200 mil, and they arrived there for a moment, as it is said, "And I bore you on the wings of eagles." (According to this, the miracle of the wings of eagles occurred during their journey from Raamses to Succoth.) Perhaps one could say that both are equal and they both came, as both can be understood from this verse, thus said the Ra'ah"m, may his memory be blessed, meaning that both occurred through the wings of eagles and in a brief moment, contrary to the natural way. However, according to this, it is difficult to understand what Rashi, may his memory be blessed, wrote here (in Parashat Beshalach) on the verse "And they journeyed from Succoth" etc. on the second day, since on the first day they came from Raamses to Succoth. According to the Mechilta and Rashi, may his memory be blessed (in Parashat Bo), that their journey from Raamses to Succoth was on the wings of eagles and in a brief moment, then it is not necessary that their journey from Succoth on the second day occurred, and it would have been possible for everything to happen on the first day, since there was no natural way at all.
summary: The passage discusses the miraculous journey of the Israelites from Raamses to Sukkot, emphasizing the concept of divine intervention as they were "carried on the wings of eagles." It highlights the tension between the natural order and supernatural occurrences, suggesting that both the initial gathering and the subsequent travel could have occurred instantaneously through divine means. The text raises questions about the timeline of events, indicating that the miraculous nature of their exodus allows for a reinterpretation of the sequence of their travels. Ultimately, it reflects on the profound theological insight that God's guidance transcends natural limitations.

passage_content: ונקדים עוד דברי המכילתא (פ' בא) עה"פ ויסעו בנ"י מרעמסס סכתה וגו', ק"כ מיל, כהרף עין נסעו בנ"י מרעמסס לסוכות, לקיים מ"ש ואשא אתכם על כנפי נשרים. סכותה סכות ממש וכו' דברי ר' אליעזר, ר"ע אומר אין סוכות אלא ענני הכבוד וכו' עכ"ד המכילתא, ובמרכבת המשנה הקשה איכא למידק למ"ד סוכות ממש עשו להם, הלא נאסרו במלאכת יו"ט במצרים, וזה הי' ביום ט"ו איך עשו מלאכה ובנו סוכות, אם לא כשיטת הפסיקתא פ' מסעי דביאתם לסוכות הי' ביום ט"ז והוא הנקרא מחרת הפסח, ואף דחוה"מ הי' דאסור ג"כ בעשיית מלאכה. אפשר שעדיין לא הוזהרו אשביתת חוה"מ, כמו שלא נזהרו אחימוץ אלא יום א' עכ"ל המרכבת.
translation: And we will precede with the words of the Mechilta (Parashat Bo) on the verse "And the children of Israel journeyed from Raamses to Succoth," which is 120 mil. In the blink of an eye, the children of Israel journeyed from Raamses to Succoth, to fulfill what is said, "And I bore you on the wings of eagles." Succoth is actual booths, etc., according to the words of Rabbi Eliezer. Rabbi Akiva says that Succoth refers only to the Clouds of Glory, etc. Thus far is the Mechilta. And in the Merkevet HaMishnah, it is difficult to understand how those who say they made actual booths, for they were prohibited from work on Yom Tov in Egypt, and this was on the 15th day. How did they perform work and build booths, unless according to the opinion of the Pesikta in Parashat Masei that their arrival at Succoth was on the 16th, which is called the day after Passover? And although it was the intermediate days of the festival, which is also prohibited for work, it is possible that they were not yet warned about the cessation of work during the intermediate days, just as they were not careful about the prohibition of leaven except on the first day. Thus far is the Merkevet.
summary: The passage discusses the journey of the Israelites from Raamses to Sukkot, emphasizing the miraculous nature of their travel, akin to being carried on the wings of eagles. It presents differing interpretations of "Sukkot," with Rabbi Eliezer suggesting they built actual booths, while Rabbi Akiva posits that they were enveloped in divine clouds of glory. The text raises questions about the feasibility of constructing these booths during the holiday, suggesting that the Israelites may not have been fully aware of the prohibitions against work at that time. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the relationship between divine intervention and human action during the Exodus.

passage_content: ותירוצו צ"ב דהרי מפורש בתורה (פ' מסעי ל"ג ג') ויסעו מרעמסס בחדש הראשון בחמשה עשר יום וגו' ממחרת הפסח וגו', והתוס' במס' קדושין (ל"ז ע"ב) הביאו ראי' מהאי קרא, דממחרת הפסח משמעותו ממחרת שחיטת הפסח דהיינו יום ט"ו, שבו נסעו ישראל מרעמסס כמפורש בקרא עייש"ד התוס', וכיון שנסיעתם מרעמסס לסוכות כהרף עין ועל כנפי נשרים הי', ויצאו מרעמסס ביום ט"ו איך לא הגיעו לסוכות עד יום ט"ז, אם לא שנדחוק דר"א דס"ל סוכות ממש, והפסיקתא דפ' מסעי דס"ל ביום ט"ז הגיעו לסוכות, חולקים על שיטה זו דנסיעתם מרעמסס לסוכות על כנפי נשרים וכהרף עין הי', אמנם בלא"ה קשה דהרי ק"כ מיל מרעמסס לסוכות, ומהלך אדם בינוני י' פרסה ליום דהיינו ארבעים מיל, נמצא ק"כ מיל הוא מהלך ג' ימים בדרך הטבע, ואף לדברי הפסיקתא שביום ט"ז הגיעו לסוכות עכ"ח בדרך נס הי', וא"כ מ"ט מוכרח לומר שלא הגיעו לסוכות עד יום ט"ז, ושמא ביום ט"ו שנסעו מרעמסס, מיד כהרף עין הגיעו לסוכות.
translation: And the question remains, for it is explicitly stated in the Torah (Parashat Masei 33:3) "And they traveled from Rameses in the first month on the fifteenth day... the day after Passover..." and the Tosafot in Tractate Kiddushin (37b) bring a proof from this verse, that "the day after Passover" means the day after the slaughtering of the Passover, which is the fifteenth day, on which Israel traveled from Rameses as is explicitly stated in the Tosafot. And since their journey from Rameses to Sukkot was in the blink of an eye and on the wings of eagles, and they left Rameses on the fifteenth day, how could they not have reached Sukkot until the sixteenth day, unless we force the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer who holds that Sukkot is indeed the fifteenth day, while the Pesikta of Parashat Masei holds that they reached Sukkot on the sixteenth day, contradicting this view that their journey from Rameses to Sukkot was on the wings of eagles and in the blink of an eye. However, it is still difficult, for it is one hundred and twenty mil from Rameses to Sukkot, and an average person walks ten parasangs a day, which is forty mil, thus one hundred and twenty mil would take three days to travel by natural means. And even according to the Pesikta that they reached Sukkot on the sixteenth day, it must be said that it was through a miracle. Therefore, why must we say that they did not reach Sukkot until the sixteenth day, and perhaps on the fifteenth day when they traveled from Rameses, they immediately reached Sukkot in the blink of an eye.
summary: The passage discusses the timing of the Israelites' journey from Raamses to Sukkot, emphasizing the miraculous nature of their travel, which is described as being swift and on "wings of eagles." It highlights a theological tension between the literal interpretation of the Torah and the understanding of the journey's duration, suggesting that despite the natural expectation of a longer travel time, divine intervention allowed for an instantaneous arrival. The text reflects on the significance of faith in God's miracles and the complexities of reconciling scriptural accounts with human understanding of time and distance.

passage_content: ואפ"ל עפי"ד הגמ' (שבת פ"ז ע"ב) ששי למאי רבא אמר ששי לחנייתן ר' אחא בר יעקב אמר ששי למסען, וקמפלגי בשבת דמרה, מר סבר אשבת איפקוד אתחומין לא איפקוד, (פרש"י הלכך כשנסעו מרפידים נסעו בשבת, שלא הוזהרו שלא לילך יותר מאלפים אמה) ומר סבר אתחומין נמי איפקוד עיי"ש, והנה על שביתת יו"ט של פסח נצטוו ישראל במצרים טרם שנצטוו על השבת, שנאמר מקרא קודש יהי' לכם וכמ"ש במרכבת לעיל, ורוב פוסקים ס"ל דתחומין נאסרו ביו"ט כמו בשבת, ולפי"ז לא יכלו לנסוע מרעמסס לסוכות ק"כ מיל ביו"ט, די"ב מיל מדאורייתא ואף דנסיעתם בדרך נס ועל כנפי נשרים הי', מ"מ גם בדרך זה איכא איסור תחומין, וראי' מדברי הגמ' (ערובין מ"ג ע"ב) דמספקא לי' אי יש תחומין למעלה מי' או לא, ואי יש תחומין לא אתי אלי' בשבת משום תחומין עיי"ש, וביאת אלי' לא בדרך הטבע יהי' ועכ"ח גם בזה איכא תחומין.
translation: And even though according to the Gemara (Shabbat 87b) it is said that the sixth (day) is for their resting, Rabbi Acha bar Yaakov said it is for their traveling, they argue regarding the Sabbath of Mara; one holds that on the Sabbath, the boundaries are not enforced, while the other holds that the boundaries are indeed enforced. Rashi explains that therefore when they traveled from Refidim, they traveled on the Sabbath, as they were not warned not to go more than two thousand amot. And the other holds that the boundaries are also enforced. And behold, concerning the resting of the Yom Tov of Pesach, Israel was commanded in Egypt before they were commanded about the Sabbath, as it is said, "A holy convocation shall be for you," as mentioned in the chariot above. And most poskim hold that boundaries are prohibited on Yom Tov just as on Shabbat. According to this, they could not travel from Raamses to Sukkot, which is 120 mil on Yom Tov, as 12 mil is from the Torah, and even though their traveling was in a miraculous way and on the wings of eagles, nevertheless, even in this way, there is a prohibition of boundaries. And there is proof from the words of the Gemara (Eruvin 43b) that it is uncertain whether there are boundaries above ten or not, and if there are boundaries, it does not come to me on Shabbat because of boundaries. And the coming of Eliyahu will not be in a natural way, and thus, even in this matter, there are boundaries.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of boundaries (techumim) in relation to the observance of Shabbat and Yom Tov, highlighting a debate among sages about whether these boundaries apply on holidays as they do on Shabbat. It emphasizes that the Israelites were commanded to observe the sanctity of Yom Tov before Shabbat, indicating a foundational understanding of time and holiness in Jewish law. The text illustrates that even miraculous journeys, such as traveling on "wings of eagles," are still subject to these divine restrictions, reinforcing the idea that spiritual laws govern all aspects of existence, including supernatural occurrences. Ultimately, it reflects a deep theological insight into the interplay between divine commandments and the nature of time and space in Jewish thought.

passage_content: ובזה יתבאר לעניננו דלא יכלו לנסוע מרעמסס לסוכות ביום ט"ו משום איסור תחומין די"ב מיל, אמנם לא יכלו להתמהמה במצרים עוד, וכמ"ש האריז"ל דאלמלי נשתהו עוד רגע במצרים, היו משוקעים בשער הנו"ן של טומאה והוכרחו לצאת מיד, לכן יצאו מרעמסס ביום ט"ו א' דפסח, אך לא הרחיקו לילך חוץ לתחום משום יו"ט, ועמדו מחוץ לעיר כדי שלא יתמהמהו במקום טומאה, וביום ט"ז שהוא חוה"מ נסעו משם לסוכות ק"כ מיל בשעה קלה, ובזה יתיישב לשון הכתוב בפ' מסעי ויסעו מרעמסס בחדש הראשון בחמשה עשר יום וגו', ויסעו בני ישראל מרעמסס ויחנו בסוכות, וצ"ב מדוע כפל הכתוב להזכיר נסיעתם מרעמסס ב"פ וסגי בחדא, ולדרכנו נסעו ישראל מרעמסס ב"פ, ביום ט"ו יצאו מן העיר שלא לשהות במקום טומאה עוד רגע, אבל חנו בעיבורה של עיר בתוך התחום כנ"ל, ולענין הרבה דברים נחשב סמוך ונראה כתוך העיר כמבואר בגמ' מגילה עיי"ש, ע"כ כפל הכתוב עוה"פ ויסעו בנ"י מרעמסס ויחנו בסוכות, וזה הי' ביום ט"ז, ויתיישב בזה שיטת הפסיקתא פ' מסעי וגם תי' המרכבת דביאתם לסוכות ביום ט"ז הי', ואף שביום ט"ו נסעו מרעמסס כמפורש בקרא, ונסיעתם הי' על כנפי נשרים וכהרף עין, מ"מ לא הגיעו לסוכות ביום שיצאו לטעם איסור תחומין כנ"ל.
translation: And this will clarify for our purposes that they could not travel from Raamses to Sukkot on the 15th day due to the prohibition of boundaries of 12 mil. However, they could not delay any longer in Egypt, as the Arizal states that had they lingered even a moment longer in Egypt, they would have been sunk in the gate of Nun of impurity and were compelled to leave immediately. Therefore, they left Raamses on the 15th day of Passover, but did not venture outside the boundary due to the holiday, and they stood outside the city so that they would not delay in a place of impurity. On the 16th day, which is Chol Hamoed, they traveled from there to Sukkot, 210 mil in a short time. This explains the wording of the verse in Parashat Masei, "And they traveled from Raamses in the first month on the fifteenth day," etc., "And the children of Israel traveled from Raamses and camped in Sukkot." It is puzzling why the verse repeats their departure from Raamses twice when one mention would suffice. According to our explanation, the Israelites traveled from Raamses twice: on the 15th, they left the city so as not to linger in a place of impurity for even a moment, but they camped within the city limits, as mentioned above. Regarding many matters, it is considered close and visible as if within the city, as explained in the Gemara in Megillah, see there. Therefore, the verse repeats, "And the children of Israel traveled from Raamses and camped in Sukkot," and this was on the 16th. This aligns with the opinion of the Pesikta in Parashat Masei and also with the explanation of the Merkevet regarding their arrival in Sukkot on the 16th, even though on the 15th they traveled from Raamses as explicitly stated in the verse, and their travel was on the wings of eagles and in the blink of an eye. Nevertheless, they did not reach Sukkot on the day they left due to the reason of the prohibition of boundaries, as mentioned above.
summary: The passage discusses the Israelites' departure from Raamses to Sukkot, emphasizing the prohibition of traveling beyond a certain distance on Yom Tov, which prevented them from leaving immediately. It highlights the urgency of their departure to avoid remaining in a place of impurity, as they were on the brink of spiritual danger. The text also reflects on the dual mention of their journey in the Torah, suggesting that while they left on the 15th of Nisan, they only reached Sukkot on the 16th due to these restrictions. This illustrates the Hasidic concept of divine providence guiding their actions and the importance of spiritual readiness in their journey.

passage_content: ולכאורה אפשר לתרץ בזה סתירת דברי רשיז"ל (עיין לעיל קושיא א'), דאם נחשוב מיציאה ראשונה שהי' ביום ט"ו ניסן, שיצאו רק מתוך העיר שלא לשהות במקום טומאה כנ"ל, אפשר ששהו ישראל ח' ימים עד שאמרו שירה, ואם נחשוב מיציאה השני' שנסעו מתחומה של עיר ביום ע"ז, נמצא ששהו רק ז' ימים עד שאמרו שירה על הים, אמנם אין תירוץ זה מספיק שעדיין יקשה מדברי הגמ' (סוטה י"ב ע"ב הנ"ל) דבכ"א בניסן אמרו ישראל שירה, א"כ אינו אלא ז' ימים אף אם נחשוב מהיציאה של יום ט"ו.
translation: And seemingly, it is possible to resolve the contradiction in the words of the Rashiz”l (see above question 1), that if we consider the first departure which was on the 15th of Nisan, when they only left the city in order not to remain in a place of impurity as mentioned, it is possible that the Israelites stayed for eight days until they sang the song. However, if we consider the second departure when they traveled beyond the city limits on the 21st, it turns out that they only stayed for seven days until they sang the song by the sea. Nevertheless, this resolution is not sufficient, as it is still difficult from the words of the Gemara (Sota 12b as mentioned above) that on the 21st of Nisan the Israelites sang the song; thus, it is only seven days even if we consider the departure of the 15th.
summary: The passage discusses a theological dilemma regarding the timing of the Israelites' song of praise after their exodus from Egypt. It examines the discrepancy between the initial departure on the 15th of Nissan and the subsequent journey, questioning how many days elapsed before they sang. The text highlights the complexity of understanding divine timing and the significance of praise in the context of redemption, emphasizing the importance of spiritual awareness in the journey from bondage to freedom. Ultimately, it reflects on the deeper implications of faith and the relationship between time, experience, and divine intervention.

passage_content: ואפ"ל ששהו ונתעכבו ישראל על הים גם יום ח', דלא יכלו ליסע משם בז' של פסח משום תחומין כנ"ל, שהרי נצטוו ביום השביעי מקרא קודש, ועוד טעם בדבר דהרי כל כליהם של המצריים של ע"ז הי', והי' צורך לבטל הע"ז טרם שזכו בה ישראל, דאח"כ אין לו ביטול עולמית, וביו"ט א"א לבטלו דהוי כתיקון מנא, דזהו הכשרן וא"א להשתמש בהם זולת זה, ע"כ לא הי' אפשר להם ליטול ביזת הים ביום ז', ונשארו שם ליום ח' ואמרו עוד הפעם שירה, נמצא שאמרו שירה ביום ז' וביום ח', ומ"ש בגמ' בכ"א בניסן אמרו שירה ומ"ש רש"י בשביעי אמרו שירה ובמקו"א כתב שאמרו שירה לח' ימים כולהו איתנייהו וא"ש.
translation: And even if the Israelites lingered and delayed at the sea until the eighth day, they could not depart from there on the seventh of Passover due to the boundaries, as mentioned above, since they were commanded on the seventh to observe a holy day. Furthermore, there is another reason: all the vessels of the Egyptians were idolatrous, and it was necessary to nullify the idolatry before the Israelites could benefit from them, for afterwards there would be no possibility of nullification forever. And on a festival, it is impossible to nullify them, as it is considered a rectification of a vessel, for this is their preparation, and it is impossible to use them except for this purpose. Therefore, it was not possible for them to take the spoils of the sea on the seventh day, and they remained there until the eighth day and sang again. Thus, they sang on the seventh day and on the eighth day. And what is stated in the Gemara that on the twenty-first of Nisan they sang, and what Rashi writes that on the seventh they sang, and in other places it is written that they sang for eight days, all of them are correct and understood.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the Israelites' delay at the sea until the eighth day of Passover, emphasizing the need to first nullify the Egyptian idols before benefiting from their spoils. It highlights the theological concept that the sanctity of the holiday prohibits the use of items associated with idolatry, which must be eradicated before the Israelites could claim them. The text also notes that the Israelites sang songs of praise on both the seventh and eighth days, reflecting a deep spiritual connection and gratitude for their redemption. This dual expression of song underscores the ongoing celebration of divine deliverance throughout the festival.

passage_content: ויגד למלך מצרים כי ברח העם וגו', פרש"י ז"ל איקטורין שלח עמהם, וכיון שהגיעו לג' ימים וכו' באו והגידו לפרעה ביום ד', ובחמשה ובששי רדפו אחריהם וליל שביעי ירדו לים, בשחרית אמרו שירה והוא יום ז' של פסח וכו' והקשו המפורשים דבסו"פ שלח כתב רש"י ז"ל שמונה חוטים שבציצית כנגד שמונה ימים ששהו ישראל משיצאו ממצרים עד שאמרו שירה על הים, והוא סתירה.
translation: And it was told to the king of Egypt that the people had fled, etc. Rashi, of blessed memory, explained that he sent Ikhtorin with them. And when they reached three days, etc., they came and told Pharaoh on the fourth day, and on the fifth and sixth they pursued them, and on the night of the seventh they descended to the sea. In the morning, they sang a song, and it was the seventh day of Passover, etc. And the commentators questioned that at the end of Parashat Shlach, Rashi, of blessed memory, wrote that the eight threads of the tzitzit correspond to the eight days that Israel stayed from the time they left Egypt until they sang a song at the sea, and this is a contradiction.
summary: The passage discusses the timeline of the Israelites' exodus from Egypt, highlighting the significance of the seventh day of Passover when they sang a song of praise at the sea. It references Rashi's commentary on the eight threads of the tzitzit, which symbolize the eight days from their departure until the song was sung, presenting a seeming contradiction. This reflects key Hasidic themes of divine timing and the spiritual journey of the Jewish people, emphasizing the importance of song and gratitude in their relationship with God. The tension between the timeline and the symbolism invites deeper contemplation on the nature of redemption and faith.

translation: B) "Then Moses and the children of Israel will sing this song to the Lord, and they will say, saying, etc." One must understand why it says "will sing" in the future tense; it could have said "then Moses sang," etc. Also, the repetition "and they will say, saying" is puzzling.
summary: In this passage, the use of the future tense "ישיר" (will sing) suggests a prophetic vision of the ongoing relationship between Moses, the Israelites, and God, indicating that their song transcends time and continues to resonate in the hearts of the Jewish people. The repetition of "ויאמרו לאמר" (and they said to say) emphasizes the importance of vocalizing faith and gratitude, highlighting the communal aspect of worship and the necessity of expressing one's connection to the Divine. This reflects a key Hasidic concept that the act of singing and praising God is not merely a historical event but an eternal, living practice that fosters spiritual connection and renewal.
