passage_content: ונל"פ בהקדם דברי החת"ס זלה"ה לפרש בנוסח התפלה וזדים טבעת וידידים העברת ויכסו מים צריהם וכו', על זאת שבחו אהובים וכו' על שפת הים יחד כולם הודו וכו', דיל"ד אחר שכבר אמר על זאת שבחו אהובים מה זה שחזר ואמר על שפת הים יחד כולם הודו וכו', ופי' שהיו בישראל שני כתות, האהובים והידידים שבישראל תיכף כשידידים העברת ויכסו מים צריהם, שבחו והודו להקב"ה שהאמינו בו ית"ש שהציל אותם מיד המצריים, אך שאר העם לא שבחו כי אמרו כשם שאנו עולים מצד זה כך מצרים עולים מצד אחר והמרו על ים בים סוף, עד שרמז הקב"ה ופלטם הים לחוץ כדכתיב וירא ישראל את מצרים מת על שפת הים, וז"פ על שפת הים יחד כולם הודו שירת הים אפילו אותם שאינם אהובים ידידים אלא כולם אמרו שירה עכ"ל היוצא לנו מדבריו הקדושים שאמרו ישראל שירה ב"פ משה רבינו ובני העלי' אמרו שירה מיד כשידידים העברת ויכסו מים צריהם, ושאר העם לא אמרו שירה עד שפלט הים את המצריים ואז חזרו ואמרו כל ישראל שירה: האמנם שממשמעות הלשון נראה שגם הידידים והאהובים לא אמרו שירה עד לאחר שיצאו מן הים ויכסו מים צריהם, ולפי"ז אינו מדוייק כ"כ מה שאמר על שפת הים יחד כולם הודו, שהרי גם כשאמרו הידידים כבר היו על שפת הים, אמנם נראה לומר שהידידים והאהובים אמרו שירה מיד כשנכנסו בתוך הים ביבשה, שהאמינו שהקב"ה יעשה להם נס בשלימות להציל אותם מיד המצריים, וממ"ש על זאת שבחו אהובים וכו' אחר וידידים העברת ויכסו מים צריהם אינו מוכרח שאח"כ שבחו אהובים, אולם מאמר על זאת שבחו סובב על תחלת הענין שאמר וים סוף להם בקעת וכו' ומיד התחילו לומר שירה על שם העתיד שהאמינו בהשי"ת שיגמור הנס בשלימות להציל אותם הצלה גמורה.
translation: And we will explain, at the outset, the words of the Chasam Sofer, may his merit protect us, regarding the wording of the prayer: "And the waters covered their foes," etc. On this, the beloved ones praised, etc., "by the shore of the sea, together all acknowledged," etc. It seems difficult that after it is already stated, "On this, the beloved ones praised," why does it repeat, "by the shore of the sea, together all acknowledged," etc.? And he explains that there were two groups in Israel: the beloved ones and the friends among Israel. Immediately when the friends "covered their foes with water," they praised and acknowledged the Holy One, blessed be He, for they believed in Him, may He be blessed, that He saved them from the hands of the Egyptians. However, the rest of the people did not praise, for they said, "Just as we ascend from this side, so the Egyptians ascend from the other side," and they rebelled against the sea in the Sea of Reeds, until the Holy One, blessed be He, hinted and the sea expelled them outside, as it is written, "And Israel saw the Egyptians dead on the shore of the sea." Thus, it is explained, "By the shore of the sea, together all acknowledged," the Song of the Sea, even those who are not beloved friends, but all sang a song. Thus, from his holy words, it emerges that Israel sang a song twice: Moses our Rabbi and the sons of the elevation sang a song immediately when the friends "covered their foes with water," and the rest of the people did not sing a song until the sea expelled the Egyptians, and then all of Israel returned and sang a song. Indeed, from the meaning of the language, it seems that even the friends and the beloved ones did not sing a song until after they came out of the sea and the waters covered their foes. According to this, it is not so precise what is said, "By the shore of the sea, together all acknowledged," for even when the friends sang, they were already on the shore of the sea. However, it seems to say that the friends and the beloved ones sang a song immediately when they entered the sea on dry land, for they believed that the Holy One, blessed be He, would perform a complete miracle to save them from the hands of the Egyptians. And from what is said, "On this, the beloved ones praised," etc., after "the friends covered their foes with water," it is not necessary that afterwards the beloved ones praised. However, the statement "On this, the beloved ones praised" refers to the beginning of the matter, as it is said, "And the Sea of Reeds was for them a valley," etc., and immediately they began to sing a song in anticipation of the future, for they believed in the Blessed One that He would complete the miracle fully to save them with complete salvation.
summary: The passage discusses the differing responses of two groups within Israel—those referred to as "the beloved" and "the friends"—during the crossing of the Red Sea. While the beloved immediately praised God for their faith in His salvation, the rest of the people hesitated until they witnessed the destruction of the Egyptians. Ultimately, the text emphasizes that all of Israel sang praises together after the miracle, highlighting the importance of faith and collective gratitude in recognizing God's deliverance. The theological insight reflects the belief in God's complete and ultimate salvation, encouraging a proactive faith in divine intervention.

passage_content: והנה כתבו התוס' (ערכין ט"ו ע"א) שישראל לא עברו הים לרחבו מצד זה לזה, רק הלכו כחצי גורן עגולה ועיין בספר ערבי נחל פרשת בשלח שהאריך לבאר דבריהם ז"ל וכתב שי"ב שבילים היו לי"ב שבטים ועיגול החיצונה הי' גדול מאוד להקיף כל העיגולים הפנימיים עיי"ש, ומובן שמשעה שנכנסו לתוך הים עד שעברו כולם נשתהו זמן רב, ואינו מפורש להדיא כמה שהו בעברם את הים, ויתכן לומר מסברא ששהו יום אחד שלם, כי האנשים לבד היו ששים רבוא והנשים וילדיהם ונוסף עליהם הערב רב שהיו הרבה יותר מישראל וע"כ מסתבר שנשתהו בעברם את הים יום אחד שלם, ואף אם נאמר שעברו כולם את הים בליל שביעי של פסח כנראה מפשטות לשון רש"י והמדרשים, אבל מה שפלט הים את המצריים על שפתו זה וודאי אפ"ל שנשתהה עד יום ח' כי אינו מבואר בדבריהם כלל אימת הי' א"כ י"ל שנתעכבו בתוך הים עד שחרית של יום שמיני ואז פלט אותם הים וחזרו כל ישראל לומר שירה יחד כולם, נמצא דביום אחרון של פסח חזרו ואמרו שירה על שפת הים, ומעתה אין עוד סתירה בדברי רש"י ז"ל דתרווייהו אתנהו, ביום שביעי של פסח אמרו שירה האהובים והידידים מיד, ואח"כ ביום שמיני חזרו כולם יחד ואמרו עוה"פ שירה על שפת הים אחר שפלט הים את המצריים.
translation: And behold, the Tosafot wrote (Erchin 15a) that Israel did not cross the sea from one side to the other, but rather walked as if through half a circular threshing floor. And see in the book "Arvei Nachal," in the portion of Beshalach, which elaborates on their words and writes that there were twelve paths corresponding to the twelve tribes, and the outer circle was very large to encompass all the inner circles. It is understood that from the moment they entered the sea until they all crossed, they took a long time, and it is not explicitly stated how long they took to cross the sea. It can be reasoned that they took a full day, for the men alone were six hundred thousand, and the women and children, in addition to the mixed multitude, were much more than Israel. Therefore, it is reasonable to say that they took a full day to cross the sea. Even if we say that they all crossed the sea on the night of the seventh of Passover, it is evident from the simple wording of Rashi and the Midrashim. However, regarding the fact that the sea expelled the Egyptians on its shore, it can certainly be said that they delayed until the eighth day, for it is not clarified in their words at what time this was. Therefore, it can be said that they were delayed in the sea until the morning of the eighth day, and then the sea expelled them, and all of Israel returned to sing together. Thus, on the last day of Passover, they returned and sang on the shore of the sea. From now on, there is no contradiction in the words of Rashi, for both are true: on the seventh day of Passover, the beloved and dear ones sang immediately, and then on the eighth day, they all returned together and sang a new song on the shore of the sea after the sea expelled the Egyptians.
summary: The passage discusses the miraculous crossing of the Red Sea by the Israelites, emphasizing that they did not traverse in a straight line but rather in a circular path, symbolizing a deeper spiritual journey. It suggests that the Israelites may have taken a significant amount of time to cross, possibly a full day, due to the large number of people involved. The text highlights the theological significance of the Israelites singing praises to God both on the seventh day of Passover and again on the eighth day, reflecting a continuous celebration of divine salvation. This dual expression of gratitude underscores the importance of communal worship and the acknowledgment of God's intervention in their liberation.

passage_content: ובזה מדוייק לשון הפסוק אז ישיר משה וגו' דבשעה שאמרו שירה פעם ראשונה, ראו ברוה"ק שעתידים לומר עוה"פ שירה לכך אמר ישיר בלשון עתיד, וז"פ ויאמרו לאמר שאמרו שירה בידיעה זו שיחזרו עוה"פ לומר כולם יחד על שפת הים, וזה שהסמיכו במדרש לכאן הפסוק פיה פתחה בחכמה וגו' דאיזהו חכם הרואה את הנולד, וגם המה ראו בחכמתם וברוה"ק שעתידים לומר שירה עוה"פ, ומדוייק הלשון "פתחה" שהם עשו פתיחה והתחלה ויחד כולם גמרו ביום המחרת.
translation: In this, the wording of the verse "Then Moses will sing" is precise, for at the time they sang the song for the first time, they saw through the Holy Spirit that they would sing again in the future. Therefore, it says "will sing" in the future tense. And similarly, "and they said to say" indicates that they sang the song with the knowledge that they would return in the future to sing all together by the shore of the sea. This is why the Midrash connects here the verse "She opens her mouth with wisdom," for who is wise? One who sees the future. And they too saw with their wisdom and through the Holy Spirit that they would sing the song in the future. The wording "opened" is precise, as they made an opening and a beginning, and together they all completed it the next day.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the phrase "then Moses will sing" in the context of the Israelites' first song of praise after crossing the Red Sea. It emphasizes that they were inspired by the Holy Spirit to foresee that they would sing again in the future, thus using the future tense to indicate a collective, prophetic understanding. The reference to wisdom highlights that true wisdom involves recognizing future events, and the term "opened" signifies the initiation of this song, which would be completed together by all the people the following day.

passage_content: או י"ל עפי"מ שפירשתי בדברי רש"י ז"ל (איכה ב') עה"פ פצו עליך פיהם וגו' מפני מה הקדים פ"א לעי"ן מפני שהיו אומרים בפיהם מה שלא ראו בעיניהם. עפ"י מה שפי' השלה"ק אמרם ז"ל (שמו"ר פ' כ"ג) עתידים ישראל לומר שירה לעתיד לבוא, היינו שיאמרו ישראל שירה וישבחו להקב"ה על הנס העתיד לבוא ואף שלא הגיע עליהם מאמינים הם בהקב"ה שבודאי יקיים הבטחתו ואומרים שירה על זה, וז"פ שהיו אומרים בפיהם מה שלא ראו בעיניהם, ר"ל שגם בשעת החורבן שלא ראו בעיניהם שום טובה ונחמה אעפי"כ שבחו והודו להקב"ה ע"ש הישועה העתידה להיות, ועד"ז לענינינו דהאהובים וידידים אמרו שירה תיכף אף שלא ראו עדיין בעיניהם הישועה וההצלה מידי המצריים, אעפי"כ פתחו לומר שירה והקדימו פיהם לעיניהם, וזהו פי' הפסוק פיה פתחה בחכמה שעשו פתיחה והתחלה בפיהם ולא המתינו מלומר שירה עד שיראו הנס בעיניהם, וזהו תורת חסד על לשונה דהנה אחר שרואין הישועה צריכים לומר שירה מן הדין, אבל טרם שראו הישועה אמרו שירה מצד החסד ולפנים משוה"ד וא"ש קישור פסוק זה לשירת הים.
translation: Or it can be said, according to what I explained in the words of Rashi, may his memory be blessed (Lamentations 2:14), regarding the verse "They opened their mouths against you," etc., why did the letter Pe precede the letter Ayin? Because they were saying with their mouths what they did not see with their eyes. According to what the Shelah HaKadosh explained, our sages, may their memory be blessed (Genesis Rabbah, Parashah 23), said that the Jewish people are destined to sing a song in the future, meaning that the Jewish people will sing and praise the Holy One, Blessed be He, for the miracle that is to come, and even though it has not yet come upon them, they believe in the Holy One, Blessed be He, that He will surely fulfill His promise, and they sing a song about this. This is what is meant by "they were saying with their mouths what they did not see with their eyes," meaning that even at the time of the destruction, when they did not see any good or comfort with their eyes, nevertheless, they praised and thanked the Holy One, Blessed be He, for the future salvation that is to be. Similarly, regarding our matter, the beloved and friends began to sing immediately, even though they had not yet seen the salvation and deliverance from the Egyptians with their eyes; nevertheless, they opened their mouths to sing and preceded their mouths to their eyes. This is the meaning of the verse "Her mouth opened in wisdom," that they made an opening and a beginning with their mouths and did not wait to sing until they saw the miracle with their eyes. This is the Torah of kindness upon her tongue, for behold, after they see the salvation, they are required to sing a song by law, but before they saw the salvation, they sang a song out of kindness and beyond the letter of the law. And it is clear how this verse connects to the Song of the Sea.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of faith and praise in the face of adversity, emphasizing that the Jewish people sang songs of praise to God even before witnessing their salvation. This act of expressing gratitude and belief in future redemption, despite current suffering, reflects a profound level of trust in God's promises. The text highlights the idea that true devotion involves praising God out of love and grace, rather than merely in response to visible miracles. This theme connects to the broader Hasidic teaching of recognizing and celebrating divine goodness, even in times of hardship.

passage_content: עוד אפ"ל בהקדם דברי המדרש (ילקוט שה"ש ד' רמז תתקפ"ח) כמגדל דוד צוארך כמו שגדלו דוד בספרו לגוזר ים סוף לגזרים וגו' וצ"ב, ונקדים דברי המד"ר (פ' וישב פרשה פ"ד סימן ח') ועשה לו כתונת פסים, כתיב לכו וראו מפעלות אלקים וכתיב בתרי' הפך ים ליבשה, למה וישנאו אותו בשביל שיקרע הים לפניהם וצ"ב, ויתבאר עפי"ד ק"ז היש"מ זלה"ה (פ' בשלח) לפרש המדרש פליאה הים ראה וינוס מה ראה ברייתא דרבי ישמעאל ראה, וז"ל דאיתא במדרש כשהעמיד יהושע את החמה אמרה לו אני קשיש ממך, אמר יהושע וכי אומר עבד זקן לאדון קטון אני קשיש ממך כבר נשתעבדת לזקני יוסף שנאמר והנה השמש וגו', ואיתא במדרש (פ' כ"א סי' ו') כי הים טען ג"כ אני קשיש ממך, וז"ש מה ראה לסתור טענתו ראה ארונו של יוסף דנשתעבדו לו כל הנמצאים השמימה, וכ"ת ים מנ"ל, ראה ברייתא דרבי ישמעאל דדריש ק"ו וכו', ומה גרמי השמימיים שהם נמצאים נכבדים נשתעבדו ליוסף, כש"כ הנמצאים בעולם היסודות וע"כ נס מפניו עכ"ל, והנה כתב הרע"ב מברטנורא במשנה (אבות פ"ה מ"ד) עשרה נסים נעשו לאבותינו במצרים ועשרה על הים, דא' מהנסים שנקרע הים לי"ב גזרים כמספר השבטים, וכל שבע עבר בדרך מיוחד וזה שנאמר לגוזר ים סוף לגזרים. והוא מאמר חכז"ל במדרש ולכאורה לפי דברי ק"ז היש"מ זלה"ה שדן הים ק"ו מהשתעבדות השמש ליוסף. אין זה רק לשבע יוסף משא"כ בשאר שבטים לא הי' לו ק"ו זה ולמה נקרע לכל שבע ושבט בפ"ע.
translation: It can also be said, in advance of the words of the Midrash (Yalkut Shmuel, Song of Songs, Remez 829), "As the tower of David is your neck," as David grew in his book to divide the Sea of Reeds into pieces, etc., and it requires clarification. We will precede the words of the Midrash (Parashat Vayeshev, Parashah 84, Siman 8), "And he made for him a coat of many colors." It is written, "Go and see the deeds of God," and it is written afterwards, "He turned the sea into dry land." Why did they hate him? Because he would split the sea before them, and it requires clarification. It will be explained according to the words of the holy Yeshiva (Parashat Beshalach) to interpret the Midrash: "The sea saw and fled." What did it see? The teaching of Rabbi Yishmael: It saw, as it is said in the Midrash, when Joshua stood the sun still, it said to him, "I am older than you." Joshua replied, "And does a servant say to his master, 'I am older than you'? You have already been subjugated to the elder Joseph, as it is said, 'And behold, the sun,' etc." And it is stated in the Midrash (Parashat 21, Siman 6) that the sea also claimed, "I am older than you." Therefore, what did it see to refute its claim? It saw the coffin of Joseph, to whom all the beings in the heavens were subjugated. And you might ask, "From where does the sea know this?" It saw the teaching of Rabbi Yishmael, who derives a fortiori, etc. If the celestial bodies, which are esteemed beings, were subjugated to Joseph, how much more so the beings in the world of the elements! Therefore, it fled before him. Thus, the Ra'avad of Bartenura wrote in the Mishnah (Ethics of the Fathers, Chapter 5, Mishnah 4) that ten miracles were performed for our ancestors in Egypt and ten at the sea. One of the miracles was that the sea was split into twelve pieces, corresponding to the number of the tribes, and all seven passed through in a special way, and this is what is meant by "to divide the Sea of Reeds into pieces." This is the statement of our sages in the Midrash, and at first glance, according to the words of the holy Yeshiva, which discussed the sea's fortiori from the subjugation of the sun to Joseph, this only applies to the seven of Joseph, whereas the other tribes did not have this fortiori. Why was the sea split for all seven and each tribe individually?
summary: The passage discusses the miraculous splitting of the Red Sea, emphasizing the theological significance of this event in relation to the Jewish people's connection to Joseph and the twelve tribes. It highlights the idea that even the natural elements, like the sea and the sun, recognize their subservience to Joseph's legacy, which is rooted in the divine plan. The text also reflects on the unique miracles performed for each tribe, suggesting a deep spiritual connection and individual significance for each one. Ultimately, it illustrates the overarching theme of divine intervention and the special status of the Jewish people in the context of their history and faith.

passage_content: וביארתי עפימ"ד בזוה"ק (פרשת וישב) שהכרח גדול הי' שישלטו השבטים על יוסף דעי"ז שלטו אח"כ על מצרים כי יוסף הי' השליט במצרים והם שלטו עליו ועי"ז הי' להם הכח להתגבר על טומאת מצרים, ולולא זאת לא היו יכולין לצאת משם ח"ו לעולם עיי"ש, ולפי"ז אם נקרע הים לפני יוסף ק"ו שיש לו להקרע לפני כל השבטים שהם שלטו על יוסף במה שמכרו אותו לעבד, וזהו פי' המדרש למה וישנאו אותו כדי שיקרע הים לפניהם דייקא ולא ליוסף בלבד וזה נסתבב ע"י השנאה שמכרוהו לעבד, מבואר דממה שנקרע הים לי"ב גזרים נתוודע ונתברר שכל הנמצאים בעולם משועבדים לכולם, וזהו פי' המדרש כמגדל דוד צוארך כמו שגדלו דוד בספרו לגוזר ים סוף לגזרים דמפסוק זה נלמד שנקרע הים לי"ב גזרים לכל שבט בפ"ע כנ"ל במדרש ובזה הגדיל דוד את השבטים הק' שהי' להם שליטה על יוסף ועי"ז היו שולטין להתגבר על טומאת מצרים וכל הנמצאים המשועבדים להם.
translation: And I explained according to the teachings of the Zohar (Parashat Vayeshev) that there was a great necessity for the tribes to have dominion over Joseph, for through this they later ruled over Egypt, since Joseph was the ruler in Egypt and they ruled over him. As a result, they had the strength to overcome the impurity of Egypt, and had it not been for this, they would not have been able to leave there, Heaven forbid, forever, as stated there. According to this, if the sea was split before Joseph, certainly it should split before all the tribes, who had dominion over Joseph by selling him as a slave. This is the explanation of the Midrash, "And they hated him," so that the sea would split specifically for them and not just for Joseph alone, and this was caused by the hatred that led them to sell him as a slave. It is clear that from the fact that the sea was split into twelve pieces, it became known and clarified that all beings in the world are subservient to them all. This is the explanation of the Midrash, "Like the tower of David is your neck," as David grew in his book to divide the sea of reeds into pieces. From this verse, we learn that the sea was split into twelve pieces for each tribe individually, as mentioned in the Midrash, and through this, David elevated the holy tribes, who had dominion over Joseph, and thereby they were able to overcome the impurity of Egypt and all the beings that were subservient to them.
summary: The passage explains that the tribes of Israel needed to dominate Joseph in order to gain the strength to overcome the impurity of Egypt, where Joseph was a ruler. This dynamic of power is illustrated by the splitting of the sea, which occurred not just for Joseph but for all the tribes, emphasizing their collective authority. The division of the sea into twelve parts symbolizes the interconnectedness of all beings, showing that everything in the world is subservient to the tribes. Ultimately, this narrative highlights the significance of unity and authority among the tribes in their spiritual journey and liberation from Egypt.

passage_content: אמנם יש להבין הלא קוב"ה לא עביד ניסא למגנא ולאיזה צורך נקרע הים לי"ב גזרים דוקא, וכמו"כ היו יכולין לעבור דרך הים כולם בדרך אחד. ויל"פ ע"ד מ"ש האריה"ק בענין נוסח התפלה שאין לשנות מנוסח לנוסח כי כל שבט יש לו שער בפ"ע להכניס התפלה ומי שמשנה לנוסח שבט אחר אין תפלתו מתקבלת, אולם האריז"ל תיקן נוסח כולל ואף אם אין ידוע מאיזה שבט הוא יוכל להתפלל בנוסח זה, ועד"ז אפ"ל לענינינו דע"כ עברו ישראל את הים בי"ב שבילין, כי מיד שנכנסו ישראל בתוך הים ביבשה התחילו לומר שירה כנ"ל וכל שבט ושבט יש לו שער בפ"ע להעלות תפלתו, ובחינת התפלה שונה זה מזה, ולרמז זאת נעשה להם י"ב שבילין לכל א' דרך בפ"ע, ואחר שעלו מן הים עשו רמז ופועל דמיוני על נוסח הכולל כתקנת האריז"ל וחזרו לומר שירה חדשה יחד כולם, ולז"א על זאת שבחו אהובים וכו' ונתנו ידידים זמירות שירות ותשבחות, ר"ל כ"א לפי בחינתו ואח"כ שירה חדשה שבחו גאולים על שפת הים כולם הודו והמליכו ואמרו, שנשתתפו בזה כולם יחד בנוסח הכולל לכל השבעים.
translation: Indeed, it must be understood that the Holy One, blessed be He, did not perform miracles for protection, and for what purpose was the sea split into twelve specific paths? Likewise, they could have crossed the sea all together on one path. It can be explained according to what the holy Ari wrote regarding the wording of prayer, that one should not change from one formulation to another, for each tribe has its own gate to enter their prayer, and one who changes to the formulation of another tribe, their prayer is not accepted. However, the Ari zal established a universal formulation, and even if it is not known from which tribe one is, they can pray with this formulation. Similarly, it can be said regarding our matter that Israel crossed the sea in twelve paths, for as soon as Israel entered the sea on dry land, they began to sing a song as mentioned, and each tribe has its own gate to elevate its prayer, and the aspect of prayer differs from one to another. To hint at this, twelve paths were made for them, each one a separate way. And after they ascended from the sea, they made a hint and a symbolic act regarding the universal formulation as established by the Ari zal, and they returned to sing a new song together, and thus it is said, "On this, they praised the beloved ones," etc., and they gave friends melodies, songs, and praises, meaning each according to their aspect, and afterwards a new song was sung, praising the redeemed on the shore of the sea, all acknowledged and crowned Him, and they said, that all participated together in the universal formulation for all seventy.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the twelve paths through the sea that the Israelites took during the Exodus, emphasizing that each tribe has its own unique way of connecting to God through prayer. It highlights the idea that while individual expressions of prayer are important, there is also a collective, universal prayer that encompasses all tribes, as established by the teachings of the Arizal. After crossing the sea, the Israelites sang a new song together, symbolizing their unity and shared experience, while still acknowledging their distinct spiritual identities. This reflects the balance between individuality and collective worship in the Hasidic tradition.

passage_content: עוד י"ל עפי"ד הנ"ל שתכלית שנאת השבטים ליוסף הי' בשביל שיקרע הים לפניהם. והנה כל זמן שלא נתגלה להם תכלית השנאה שהוא קי"ס, הי' להם להשבטים הק' קצת טינא בלבם על שבע יוסף, וחשבו סיבת השנאה לטעם אחר כמבואר במדרשי חז"ל שראו ברוה"ק ירבעם יוצא ממנו וכדומה, וא"כ לא הי' ביניהם אחדות ושלום כ"כ, משא"כ אחר קרי"ס נתברר להם שהי' זאת סיבה מן השמים כדי שיקרע הים לפניהם אז נעשה שלום ואחדות גמור בין השבטים וחזרו לשבח את הקב"ה כולם יחד, וזהו פי' על שפת הים אחר שעלו מן הים ונתברר להם סיבת שנאתם ליוסף, יחד כולם הודו בשירה חדשה להקב"ה.
translation: It can also be said according to the above explanation that the ultimate reason for the hatred of the tribes towards Joseph was so that the sea would split before them. And behold, as long as the ultimate reason for the hatred, which is the splitting of the sea, was not revealed to them, the holy tribes had some resentment in their hearts against Joseph, and they thought the reason for the hatred was for another cause, as explained in the Midrashim of our Sages, that they saw in the Holy Spirit that Jeroboam would come from him and the like. Therefore, there was not such unity and peace among them. However, after the splitting of the sea, it became clear to them that this was a reason from Heaven so that the sea would split before them. Then complete peace and unity arose among the tribes, and they all returned to praise the Holy One, Blessed be He, together. This is the explanation of the song at the sea, after they emerged from the sea and it became clear to them the reason for their hatred towards Joseph; together they all acknowledged with a new song to the Holy One, Blessed be He.
summary: The passage discusses the underlying purpose of the brothers' hatred towards Joseph, which was ultimately to facilitate the miraculous splitting of the sea for the Israelites. Initially, the brothers harbored resentment, believing their animosity stemmed from different reasons, such as prophetic visions of future leaders. However, after witnessing the miracle of the sea, they realized that their hatred was divinely orchestrated, leading to complete unity and peace among them. This newfound understanding prompted them to collectively praise God with a new song, highlighting the transformative power of divine revelation and unity in faith.

passage_content: עוד י"ל עפי"מ דאיתא במד"ר פ' זו (פ' כ"ג סי' ז') אז ישיר משה הה"ד קדמו שרים אחר נוגנים וכו' כיון שיצאו ישראל מן הים באו המלאכים להקדים שירה לפני הקב"ה, א"ל הקב"ה יקדמו בני תחלה וכו', ואיתא בדרז"ל שישראל מקדימין לומר שירה להקב"ה ואח"כ המלאכים, ושוב חוזרים ואומרים ישראל והמלאכים שירה ביחד וכמו שאומרים בקדושה כתר יתנו לך ה"א מלאכים המוני מעלה עם עמך ישראל קבוצי מטה יחד כולם קדושה לך ישלשו וכו', וזהו פי' על שפת הים יחד כולם הודו, היינו המלאכים עם ישראל אחר שכבר אמרו בפ"ע חזרו ואמרו עוה"פ שירה חדשה כולם יחד. ועפ"י דרכים הנ"ל יתיישב ג"כ סתירת דברי רש"י ז"ל שהובא לעיל (בדרוש הקדום קושיא א') דבפ' בשלח כתב דבשחרית ז' דפסח אמרו שירה, ובסו"פ שלח כתב שאמרו שירה ביום ח' עיי"ש, אמנם כיון שמוכרח בלא"ה שאמרו שירה שני פעמים כנראה מנוסח לשון התפלה, יתכן לומר שפעם שנית אמרו ביום אחרון של פסח, ואין סתירה בדברי רש"י ז"ל ושניהם צדקו יחדיו, השי"ת ירחם עלינו יחיינו ויקרבינו לגאולה האמיתית ונזכה כולנו לישועה שלימה ואמיתית, ישמחו השמים ותגל הארץ, ונזכה לכל מיני ישועות טובות בקדושה ובטהרה בהתרוממות קרן התורה וישראל ובהתגלות כבוד שמים עלינו במהרה בימינו אמן.
translation: It can also be said according to what is written in the Midrash, Parashat Zohar (Parashat 23, Section 7), "Then Moses sang," as it is stated, "The leaders preceded after the melodies," etc. When Israel went out from the sea, the angels came to precede singing before the Holy One, Blessed be He. The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to them, "Let My children precede first," etc. And it is stated in the teachings of our sages that Israel precedes in singing to the Holy One, Blessed be He, and afterwards the angels. Then they return and sing together, as they say in the Kedushah, "The angels give You a crown, O God, the multitudes on high with Your people Israel, gathered together, all of them in holiness to You, they will triple," etc. This is the explanation of "At the sea, together all of them gave thanks," meaning the angels with Israel, after they had already sung separately, they returned and sang a new song together. According to the aforementioned paths, it also resolves the contradiction in the words of Rashi, may his memory be blessed, which was brought above (in the ancient discourse, question 1), that in Parashat Beshalach he wrote that in the morning of the seventh day of Passover they sang, and at the end of Parashat Shelach he wrote that they sang on the eighth day, see there. However, since it is necessary to say that they sang twice, as is evident from the wording of the prayer, it is possible to say that they sang a second time on the last day of Passover, and there is no contradiction in the words of Rashi, may his memory be blessed, and both were correct together. May the Holy One, Blessed be He, have mercy on us, give us life, and bring us closer to the true redemption, and may we all merit complete and true salvation. Let the heavens rejoice and the earth be glad, and may we merit all kinds of good salvations in holiness and purity, with the elevation of the banner of the Torah and Israel, and with the revelation of the glory of Heaven upon us speedily in our days, Amen.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the song sung by the Israelites after crossing the Red Sea, emphasizing that they precede the angels in praising God. It highlights the unity of Israel and the angels in worship, reflecting a deep connection between the divine and the Jewish people. The text also reconciles apparent contradictions in the timing of the song's recitation, suggesting that both instances of singing are valid and part of a greater spiritual truth. Ultimately, it expresses a yearning for redemption and the fulfillment of divine promises, invoking a vision of collective joy and salvation for Israel.

passage_content: ויגד למלך מצרים כי ברח העם וגו' פירש"י איקטורין שלח עמהם וכיון שהגיעו לשלשת ימים שקבעו לילך ולשוב וראו שאינן חוזרין למצרים באו והגידו לפרעה ביום ד', ובחמישי ובששי רדפו אחריהם וליל שביעי ירדו לים בשחרית אמרו שירה והוא יום שביעי של פסח לכן אנו קורין השירה ביום השביעי ע"כ, כבר הבאנו לעיל קושית המפורשים דזה סותר למש"כ רש"י ז"ל (סו"פ שלח) בשם ר' משה הדרשן דשמונה ימים שהו ישראל משיצאו ממצרים עד שאמרו שירה.
translation: And it was told to the king of Egypt that the people had fled, etc. Rashi explains that he sent horsemen with them, and when they reached the three days that they had set to go and return, and they saw that they were not returning to Egypt, they came and told Pharaoh on the fourth day. And on the fifth and sixth days, they pursued them, and on the night of the seventh, they descended to the sea in the morning and sang a song. And it is the seventh day of Passover; therefore, we read the song on the seventh day. Thus, we have already brought above the question of the commentators that this contradicts what Rashi, of blessed memory, wrote (in Parashat Shlach) in the name of Rabbi Moshe the preacher, that the Israelites stayed for eight days from the time they left Egypt until they sang the song.
summary: The passage discusses the timeline of the Israelites' exodus from Egypt and their subsequent crossing of the Red Sea, highlighting the significance of the seventh day of Passover when they sang a song of praise. It references the tension between different interpretations regarding the duration of their journey before singing, emphasizing the importance of divine intervention and the miraculous nature of their liberation. This reflects key Hasidic themes of faith, redemption, and the celebration of spiritual milestones in the Jewish tradition.

passage_content: ב) ילקוט (רמז רנ"ד) ויסע משה את ישראל מהו ויסע שהסיען בעל כרחן. דכתיב ויקח שש מאות רכב עמד פרעה וקשט אותן הסוסים באבנים טובות ומרגליות, וכשנטבעו בים היו צפין על שפת הים והיו ישראל יורדין בכל יום ונוטלין מהן. ולא היו מבקשין לזוז משם כיון שראה משה כך א"ל מה אתם סבורים שבכל יום הים מעלה לכם אבנים טובות ומרגליות, עמד והסיען בעל כרחן ע"כ, וצ"ב מדוע הסיען בעל כרחן הלא הי' רצון השי"ת שיטלו הרכוש דמהאי טעמא הי' הים מעלה להם אבנים טובות ומרגליות וכמ"ש בילקוט (רמז רל"ט) עה"כ וירא ישראל את מצרים מת מפני ארבעה דברים ראו ישראל את מצרים מתים וכו' וכדי שיקחו ישראל את הביזה שהיו טעונין כסף וזהב ואבנים טובות ומרגליות וכו', וירא ישראל את מצרים מתים אינו אומר אלא מת, מתים ולא מתים כענין שנאמר ויהי בצאת נפשה כי מתה, וכי מתה היתה אלא מתה ולא מתה עכ"ד המדרש, גם ראוי להבין מדוע עשה ה' ככה שיהיו המצריים חיים לאחר שפלטם הים.
translation: B) Yalkut (Remez 274) And Moses led Israel away, what does it mean "and he led them away"? That he led them against their will. As it is written, "And Pharaoh took six hundred chariots," and he adorned those horses with precious stones and pearls. And when they were drowned in the sea, they were found on the shore of the sea, and Israel would go down every day and take from them. And they did not wish to move from there. When Moses saw this, he said to them, "What do you think, that every day the sea brings you precious stones and pearls?" He stood up and led them away against their will. Therefore, it is necessary to understand why he led them away against their will; after all, it was the will of the Holy One, blessed be He, that they should take the wealth. For this reason, the sea was bringing them precious stones and pearls, as it is stated in the Yalkut (Remez 239) regarding the verse "And Israel saw the Egyptians dead," because Israel saw the Egyptians dead, etc., and in order that Israel should take the spoils that they were laden with silver and gold and precious stones and pearls, etc. "And Israel saw the Egyptians dead" does not say but "dead," dead and not dead, in the manner that it is said, "And it came to pass as her soul departed, for she died," and was she really dead? Rather, she died and did not die. Thus concludes the Midrash. It is also fitting to understand why the Holy One, blessed be He, did this, that the Egyptians should be alive after the sea had released them.
summary: The passage discusses the miraculous events during the Exodus, particularly how Moses compelled the Israelites to leave the shores of the Red Sea despite their desire to collect precious stones and jewels that had washed up. It raises questions about God's intentions, as the Israelites were meant to take the Egyptians' wealth, yet the Egyptians remained alive after the sea parted. This reflects a deeper theological insight into divine providence and the complexities of God's plans, emphasizing that even in miraculous circumstances, human understanding may be limited.

passage_content: ואפ"ל עפי"ד המדרש שהמצריים היו מקשטין סוסיהם באבנים טובות ומרגליות, והנה כל כליהם היו של ע"ז וישראל אי אפשר לבטל ע"ז של עכו"ם וע"כ הי' הכרח שיהיו חיים עדיין והם עצמם יבטלו הע"ז, העולה מדברינו שכן הי' רצון השי"ת שיעלו ישראל רכוש הים, וא"כ קשה מדוע הסיען משרע"ה בעל כרחן.
translation: And although according to the Midrash it is stated that the Egyptians adorned their horses with precious stones and pearls, behold, all their vessels were for idolatry, and it is impossible for Israel to nullify the idolatry of the nations. Therefore, it was necessary for them to still be alive, and they themselves would nullify the idolatry. This arises from our words that it was indeed the will of the Blessed One that Israel should take the wealth of the sea. And thus, it is difficult to understand why He caused them to be driven away by Moshe against their will.
summary: The passage discusses the idea that the Egyptians adorned their horses with precious stones, symbolizing their idolatrous practices. It suggests that the Israelites could not eliminate the idolatry of the Egyptians directly, which necessitated their continued existence. The text reflects on the divine will for the Israelites to take the wealth of the sea, raising the question of why Moses had to compel them against their will. This highlights the tension between divine intention and human agency in the context of redemption and spiritual elevation.

passage_content: אמנם נראה דאף שהי' רצון הבוי"ת שיטלו הרכוש אבל רק במדה ידועה ולא יותר מדאי דאז יותר משהוא מועיל הוא מזיק, וכמ"ש הכתוב ודי זהב שבשביל רוב הזהב שהי' להם עשו את העגל, ועל כן הסיען משה בעל כרחן שלא יקחו יותר מדאי, ומבואר בדברי המדרש הנ"ל שהיו ישראל יורדין בכל יום ונועלין מהם וכו' א"ל משה מה אתם סבורים שבכל יום הים מעלה וכו' ע"כ, ולא מצאתי מבואר בשום מקום כמה ימים נשתהו שם, ועכ"פ משמע מלשון המדרש ששהו אצל עכ"פ שני ימים דהרי מיעוט רבים שנים וע"ז קאמר בכל יום, ואפשר דע"כ נשתהו שני ימים מפני שביום שביעי של פסח הוא יו"ט ולא היו יכולין ללקוט מהביזה דברים המוקצים ביו"ט, ויצאו אל שפת הים גם ביום השני שהוא שמיני ליציאתם, ועל שראו במפלת שונאיהם אמרו שירה עוד פעם, ולפי"ז יתכן שאמרו ישראל שירה בשביעי ובשמיני ליציאתם, ובזה יתורץ דברי רש"י ז"ל, שבפרשה זו כתב דבשביעי אמרו שירה, ובסו"פ שלח כתב בש"ר משה הדרשן בשמיני ליציאתם אמרו שירה, ולדרכינו תרווייהו אתנייהו וא"ש.
translation: Indeed, it seems that although it was the will of the Creator that they should take the spoils, it was only to a certain measure and not excessively, for then it would be more harmful than beneficial, as the verse states, "And the gold was sufficient," for because of the abundance of gold they had, they made the calf. Therefore, Moses forcibly led them away so that they would not take too much. It is explained in the aforementioned Midrash that the Israelites descended every day and locked from them, etc. Moses said to them, "What do you think, that the sea rises every day?" Therefore, I did not find explicitly stated anywhere how many days they lingered there, and nevertheless, it seems from the language of the Midrash that they lingered at least two days, for the minority of many is two, and this is why it says "every day." It is possible that they lingered two days because on the seventh day of Passover it is a festival, and they could not gather from the spoils items that are set aside on a festival. They also went out to the edge of the sea on the second day, which was the eighth of their departure, and because they saw the downfall of their enemies, they sang a song once again. According to this, it is possible that the Israelites sang a song on the seventh and the eighth of their departure. This clarifies the words of Rashi, who in this section wrote that on the seventh they sang a song, and at the end of the portion of Shelach, he wrote in the name of Rabbi Moshe the preacher that on the eighth of their departure they sang a song. According to our approach, both are correct, and it is understood.
summary: The passage discusses the balance between divine will and human action, emphasizing that while God desired the Israelites to take wealth from Egypt, it was limited to a certain measure to prevent harm. It reflects on the dangers of excess, as illustrated by the incident of the Golden Calf, and highlights the importance of restraint. The text also notes the significance of the Israelites singing praises to God on the seventh and eighth days of their exodus, linking their spiritual expression to their experiences of divine salvation. This underscores the Hasidic theme of recognizing God's presence and guidance in both material and spiritual realms.

passage_content: ויהפך לבב פרעה ועבדיו אל העם ויאמרו מה זאת עשינו כי שלחנו את ישראל מעבדנו, יל"ד באומרו ויהפך וגו' דהרי מעיקרא בשלחם לא עשו זאת מדעתם ורצונם כ"א אנוס על פי הדיבור שהוכו במכות נמרצות ואיך יצדק לומר ויהפך, גם יל"ד בטעם שינוי הלשונות מתחלה אמר את העם ואח"כ כי שלחנו את ישראל.
translation: And the heart of Pharaoh and his servants was turned to the people, and they said, "What is this we have done, that we have sent Israel away from our service?" It is asked regarding the phrase "and it was turned" that initially, when they sent them away, they did not do so of their own will and desire, but rather were compelled by the force of the words, as they were struck with severe plagues. How can it be justified to say "and it was turned"? Additionally, it is asked about the change in language; at first, it says "the people," and afterwards, "that we have sent Israel."
summary: The passage discusses the transformation of Pharaoh's heart and that of his servants after releasing the Israelites, questioning the sincerity of their initial decision to let them go. It highlights that their choice was not made willingly but was compelled by the severe plagues they endured. The use of the term "and he turned" suggests a deeper divine influence on their hearts, indicating that their change of mind was orchestrated by God. Additionally, the shift in language from "the people" to "Israel" reflects a deeper recognition of the Israelites' unique status and the gravity of their liberation.

passage_content: ב) (פרשה כ' סימן ה') ויהי בשלח פרעה וגו' הה"ד (שה"ש ד') שלחיך פרדס רמונים: א"ר לוי משל לאחד שהי' לו שדה והי' בה גל של צרורות, עמד ומכרה לאחר, עמד אותו האיש שקנאה והעביר את הגל מתוכה ומצא תחתיו מים חיים, נטעה גפנים וכו' נטע בה כל מיני בשמים וכו', כל מי שהי' עובר עלי' היה משבחה, עבר עליה אותו האיש שמכרה ראה אותה מליאה כל טוב, אמר אוי לי שכך מכרתי אוי לי שכך הוצאתי מידי, כך היו ישראל במצרים גל של צרורות שנאמר (שם) גן נעול אחותי כלה גל נעול מעין חתום, כיון שיצאו נעשו פרדס רמונים וכו', כל הימים שהיו הבריות רואים את ישראל היו משבחין אותן וכו', פרעה ראה אותן שורות שורות כהנים לוים וישראלים דגלים דגלים התחיל צוח ואמר אוי לו לאותו האיש שכך הוציא מתחת ידו לכך נאמר ויהי בשלח פרעה עכ"ד המדרש, וצ"ב דמיון המשל, ומדוע נמשלו ישראל במצרים לגל של צרורות, גם הראי' שהביא המדרש מפסוק גל נעול מעין חתום אינו מובן דאדרבה ה"ז מורה למעלתן וחשיבותן שלא נטמעו באומות כאמרז"ל, גם סיום דברי המדרש צ"ב פרעה ראה אותן שורות שורות וכו' דגלים דגלים התחיל צווח ואומר אוי לי וכו' לכך נאמר ויהי בשלח פרעה, לכאורה הלא לא נעשו ישראל לדגלים כ"א במדבר ואחר קרי"ס, ואיך התחרט עכשיו על מה שלא ראה, ואם ראה העתידות באצטגנינות כמ"ש ראו כי רעה נגד פניכם, ובמדרש שאמר מי ומי ההולכים כולם ימותו במדבר ולא יכנסו לארץ כ"א יהושע וכלב, א"כ איך לא ראה כמו"כ בראשונה כששלחם, ומה ניתוסף עכשיו בידיעתו מגדולת חשיבותן של ישראל, שעבור זה התחרט על שליחתם.
translation:
B) (Parashat Ki Teitzei, Siman 5) And it came to pass when Pharaoh sent forth, etc. as it is written (Song of Songs 4) "Your shoots are a paradise of pomegranates": Rabbi Levi said, this is comparable to a man who had a field and there was a heap of stones in it. He stood up and sold it to another. That man who bought it removed the heap and found beneath it living waters. He planted vines, etc., and planted in it all kinds of spices, etc. Anyone who passed by it praised it. The man who sold it passed by and saw it full of goodness, and he said, "Woe to me that I sold it! Woe to me that I removed it from my hands!" Thus were the Israelites in Egypt, a heap of stones, as it is said (there) "A locked garden, my sister, my bride, a locked garden, a sealed fountain." When they went out, they became a paradise of pomegranates, etc. All the days that people saw the Israelites, they praised them, etc. Pharaoh saw them in rows, priests, Levites, and Israelites in banners, and he began to scream and said, "Woe to that man who removed such from his hands!" Therefore it is said, "And it came to pass when Pharaoh sent forth." Thus far the Midrash. 

And it is necessary to understand the analogy of the parable, and why the Israelites in Egypt are compared to a heap of stones. Also, the proof that the Midrash brought from the verse "A locked garden, a sealed fountain" is not understood, for on the contrary, this indicates their greatness and importance, that they were not mixed among the nations, as our sages have said. Also, the conclusion of the Midrash is puzzling: Pharaoh saw them in rows, etc., in banners, and he began to scream and say, "Woe to me," etc. Therefore it is said, "And it came to pass when Pharaoh sent forth." At first glance, it seems that the Israelites were not made into banners until they were in the desert and after the splitting of the sea. How could he regret now what he did not see? And if he saw the future through astrology, as it is said, "See, for evil is before you," and in the Midrash that said, "Who are those going? All will die in the desert and will not enter the land except for Joshua and Caleb," then how did he not see likewise at first when he sent them? And what was added now to his knowledge regarding the greatness and importance of Israel, that for this he regretted sending them?
summary: The passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel uses a parable to illustrate the transformation of the Israelites from a state of oppression in Egypt, likened to a field filled with stones, to a flourishing garden of abundance upon their liberation. It emphasizes the inherent value and potential of the Jewish people, who, despite their suffering, possess a divine essence that becomes evident after their exodus. The text questions Pharaoh's sudden realization of the Israelites' greatness, suggesting that his regret stems from a deeper understanding of their significance, which he failed to perceive initially. This reflects key Hasidic themes of redemption, the hidden potential within suffering, and the recognition of divine purpose in the Jewish experience.

passage_content: והנל"פ עפימ"ד בזוה"ק (פ' שמות ט"ו ע"א) כד חמא קוב"ה חדוותא סגיאה דהאי עלמא תתאה וכו'. אמר דלמא ח"ו יתערבון בשאר עממין וישתאר פגימותא בכלהו עלמין, מה עבד קב"ה טלטל לכלהו וכו' עד דנחתו למצרים למידר דיוריהון בעם קשי קדל דמבזין נימוסיהון ומבזין להון לאתחתנא בהון וכו' גוברין געלן בהון נוקבתא געלן בהון. עד דאשתכלל כלא בזרעא קדישא וכו' עכ"ד הזוה"ק, מבואר שהי' סיבה מהבוי"ת שיהיו ישראל נמאסים בעיני המצרים ועי"ז ניצולו מהתחברותם ומלהתחתן עמהם ונשארו זרע קודש, ואילולא כן לא היו ראויים לקבלת התורה כמבואר בזוה"ק פ' יתרו, ומעתה אין זה תימה שלא הכיר פרעה גדולתן של ישראל ולא השיג אף גדולתן העתיד עד לאחר שיצאו מארצו, אף שידע מקצת מן העתידות באצטגנינות, אבל ענין זה העלימו מידיעתו, ונסתבב בגזירת הבוי"ת שיהיו ישראל נמאסין בעיניו כדי שישארו עם קדוש, ולאחר שיצאו מארצו לא הי' צורך לזה, אז השיג גדולתן העתיד בדגלים וכהנים לוים וישראל וצווח ווי וא"ש דברי המדרש.
translation: And this is what is implied in the Zohar (Parashat Shemot 15a) that when the Holy One, blessed be He, saw the great joy of this lower world, etc. He said perhaps, Heaven forbid, they would mix with the other nations and there would remain blemishes in all the worlds. What did the Holy One do? He stirred all of them, etc., until He brought them to Egypt to measure their dwelling among a stiff-necked people who despise their customs and scorn them to marry them, etc. Strong men were taken from them, women were taken from them. Until all were included in the holy seed, etc. Thus the Zohar explains, it is clear that there was a reason from the Creator that the Israelites should be despised in the eyes of the Egyptians, and thereby they were saved from mingling and marrying with them, and remained a holy seed. And if not for this, they would not have been worthy of receiving the Torah, as explained in the Zohar, Parashat Yitro. From now on, it is not surprising that Pharaoh did not recognize the greatness of Israel and did not grasp even their future greatness until after they left his land, even though he knew some of the future through astrology. But this matter was hidden from his knowledge, and it was decreed by the Creator that the Israelites should be despised in his eyes so that they would remain a holy people. After they left his land, there was no longer a need for this, then he recognized their future greatness with banners and priests, Levites, and Israelites, and he cried out, "Woe!" And the words of the Midrash are clear.
summary: The passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel discusses the divine wisdom behind the Israelites being despised by the Egyptians, which served to prevent intermarriage and preserve their identity as a holy seed. This separation was essential for their worthiness to receive the Torah, as highlighted in the Zohar. Pharaoh's inability to recognize the future greatness of the Israelites was a result of God's decree, ensuring their sanctity until their liberation, after which their true significance became apparent. Ultimately, this reflects the Hasidic belief in God's providence and the importance of maintaining spiritual purity.

passage_content: ועד"ז יתבאר במאמה"כ ויהפך לבב פרעה וגו' (עיין קושיא א') בהקדם לבאר הכתוב (בפ' בא) ויקם פרעה לילה הוא וכל עבדיו וכל מצרים וגו' כי אין בית אשר אין שם מת, ויקרא למשה ולאהרן לילה ויאמר קומו צאו מתוך עמי וגו', ותחזק מצרים על העם למהר לשלחם מן הארץ כי אמרו כולנו מתים, ויל"ד שהתחיל ויקם פרעה לילה הוא וכל עבדיו וכל מצרים וגו' וסיים ותחזק מצרים על העם והשמיט פרעה ועבדיו, ואפ"ל כי פרעה ועבדיו ידעו שלא יבא עוד מכה עליהם, כי כך התרה משרע"ה בהם שמכת בכורות הוא האחרונה שבכולם וזו כבר עברה, וע"כ הם עצמם לא הסכימו לשלוח את ישראל מארצם, אך מלחץ העם שאמרו כלנו מתים, ובמכילתא שאמרו לא כגזירת משה הוא, שהרי אמר ומת כל בכור, וכאן אף הפשוטים מתים ה' או י' בבית אחד, והטעם מפני שהיו המצריות מזנות וילדות מרווקים פנויים והיו להם בכורות הרבה כפירש"י עה"פ כי אין בית אשר אין שם מת, ואולי פרעה ועבדיו השיגו דבר זה שכל אלו בכורים הם וע"כ לא חששו שיביא עוד מכות עליהם ולא מיראת המות שלחו את ישראל, אלא מפני שכל מצרים החזיקו עליהם למהר לשלחם מן הארץ כי אמרו כולנו מתים, לכן הסכים גם פרעה ואמר קומו צאו מתוך עמי וגו', ועיקר הטעם שנתפתה לדבריהם מפני שלא ידע חשיבותם של ישראל והיו מבוזין בעיניו כי כן סיבב הבוי"ת כנז"ל בדברי הזוה"ק, אמנם לאחר שיצאו ישראל מארצו השיג גדולת מעלתם, וגם זה היתה סיבה מאת ה' כדי שיחזק לבו לרדוף אחריהם, ע"כ עכשיו ויהפך לבב פרעה ועבדיו אל העם, כלומר אל המצריים ויאמרו מה זאת עשינו כי שלחנו את ישראל מעבדנו, הזכיר ישראל שזה מורה על חשיבות בני ישראל, ומה"ט נתחרטו על ששלח אותם שעכשיו כבר הכירו חשיבותן של ישראל.
translation: And similarly, it will be explained in the verse, "And the Lord hardened the heart of Pharaoh" (see question A) by first clarifying the written text (in Parashat Bo) "And it came to pass that at midnight, the Lord smote all the firstborn in the land of Egypt" (Exodus 12:29), and "And Pharaoh rose up in the night, he and all his servants and all Egypt" (Exodus 12:30), for there was no house where there was not one dead. And he called for Moses and Aaron by night and said, "Rise up, get you out from among my people" (Exodus 12:31). And the Egyptians urged the people to hasten to send them out of the land, for they said, "We are all dead." It is to be noted that it began with "And Pharaoh rose up in the night, he and all his servants and all Egypt" and concluded with "And the Egyptians urged the people," omitting Pharaoh and his servants. One might say that Pharaoh and his servants knew that no more plague would come upon them, for thus did Moshe Rabbeinu warn them that the plague of the firstborn was the last of all, and that had already passed. Therefore, they themselves did not agree to send Israel out of their land, but rather due to the pressure of the people who said, "We are all dead." And in the Mekhilta, they said, "It is not like the decree of Moshe," for he said, "And every firstborn shall die," and here even the simple ones die, five or ten in one house. The reason is that the Egyptian women were committing adultery and giving birth to many firstborns from single men, as Rashi explains on the verse, "For there was no house where there was not one dead." And perhaps Pharaoh and his servants realized that all these were firstborns, and therefore they did not fear that more plagues would come upon them, nor did they send Israel out of fear of death, but because all of Egypt pressed upon them to hasten to send them out of the land, for they said, "We are all dead." Therefore, Pharaoh also agreed and said, "Rise up, get you out from among my people." The main reason that he was persuaded by their words was that he did not recognize the importance of Israel, and they were despised in his eyes, for thus did the Blessed One arrange, as mentioned in the words of the Zohar. However, after Israel left his land, he recognized their great stature, and this was also a reason from the Lord so that he would strengthen his heart to pursue them. Therefore, now "And the Lord turned the heart of Pharaoh and his servants toward the people," meaning toward the Egyptians, and they said, "What is this we have done, that we have sent Israel from our service?" The mention of Israel indicates the importance of the Children of Israel, and for this reason they regretted having sent them, for now they had already recognized the importance of Israel.
summary: The passage discusses the transformation of Pharaoh's heart and the motivations behind his decision to release the Israelites. Initially, Pharaoh and his servants did not fear further plagues, believing the death of the firstborn was the last strike. However, the overwhelming fear of death among the Egyptians compelled Pharaoh to act. After the Israelites left, Pharaoh recognized their significance, leading to his regret and the subsequent hardening of his heart to pursue them, illustrating the divine orchestration of events to reveal the true value of the Israelites.

passage_content: עוד י"ל עפי"ד הנועם אלימלך זלה"ה (פ' בשלח) וזל"ק דאיתא בגמרא (עירובין דף נ"ד ע"א) המהלך בדרך ואין עמו לוי' יעסוק בתורה ולכאורה הלא בלאו הכי הוא מחויב תמיד לעסוק בתורה, כמאמר התנא המהלך בדרך ומפנה לבו וכו', ונראה לי ליתן טעם למצות לוי', כשהצדיק מלוה את חבירו הם מתקשרים זה בזה בקדושתם ונעשים כאחד וקדושתו של זה הצדיק העוסק בתורה בביתו הוא משמר את חבירו בדרך, כאילו הוא עצמו עוסק בתורה וכו', זה הוא כשהצדיק הוא המלוה, אבל אם הוא איש נעצב וריקן אין תועלת לזה במה שזה מלווהו, ואדרבה הוא מכניס בו עצבותו וכו', וזהו ויהי בשלח פרעה ר"ל מחמת שפרעה שלח את ישראל וכו' ולכן ולא נחם אלקים וגו' כי קרוב הוא, ר"ל זה קאי אפרעה מחמת שעתה מקרוב הלך מאצלם, והי' עדיין רושם עצבותו בהם ולכן ויסב וגו' עכ"ד, וראוי להבין מה שתיאר לפרעה איש נעצב וריקן ומהו עצבותו, ויותר יאות לו תואר רשע.
translation: It can also be said according to the words of the pleasant Elimelech, may his memory be blessed (Parashat Beshalach), and it is written that in the Gemara (Eruvin 54a), one who walks on the road and does not have a companion should engage in Torah study. At first glance, it seems that he is always obligated to engage in Torah, as stated by the Tanna, "one who walks on the road and turns his heart," etc. It seems to me to provide a reason for the mitzvah of companionship; when a righteous person accompanies his friend, they connect with each other in their holiness and become as one, and the holiness of this righteous person who engages in Torah in his home protects his friend on the way, as if he himself is engaged in Torah, etc. This is when the righteous person is the one accompanying. However, if he is a sad and empty person, there is no benefit to the one he accompanies; on the contrary, he brings his sadness into him, etc. This is what is meant by "And it was when Pharaoh sent out the people," meaning that because Pharaoh sent out Israel, etc., therefore "God did not lead them," etc., because he was close, meaning this refers to Pharaoh because he had just recently left them, and the impression of his sadness was still upon them. Therefore, "He turned," etc. Thus far. It is appropriate to understand what he described about Pharaoh as a sad and empty man and what his sadness is; it would be more fitting for him to be described as wicked.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of companionship and spiritual connection, emphasizing that when a righteous person accompanies another, they create a bond of holiness that enhances both individuals' spiritual states. It contrasts the uplifting influence of a joyful, righteous person with the detrimental effect of a sorrowful individual, suggesting that the latter can impart their negativity to others. The reference to Pharaoh highlights how his recent departure from the Israelites left a lingering sadness that could affect their spiritual journey. Ultimately, the text underscores the importance of positive spiritual companionship in maintaining one's connection to Torah and holiness.

passage_content: ואפ"ל עפימ"ש הקדושת לוי זלה"ה (פ' שמות) שע"י הכאת מצרים נתגדל ונתקדש שמו הגדול והקדוש, ולהכי מכת בכורות הי' ע"י הבורא ב"ה בעצמו, כי הוא היתה עיקר הגורם יציאת בנ"י ממצרים, ומחמת יצי"מ נתגדל ונתקדש שמו הגדול וכו' וגם להאומות היתה טובה, שהמצרים נעשים כלים שעל ידם נודע מציאות הבורא וכו' עכ"ד לענינינו, והנה לפי"ז הי' להם זכות שנעשו כלים שנתקדש על ידם ש"ש, אמנם אמרז"ל (קידושין מ' ע"ב) בתוהא על הראשונות ומתחרט על הטוב איבד כל זכותו ונתרוקן מהם עיי"ש, וכמו"כ בפרעה שאמר קומי צאי ושלח את ישראל, וע"י יצי"מ נתקדש שמו ית' בעולם, נמצא הי' כלי להתקדש ש"ש על ידו, אולם אח"כ התחרט ונהפך לבו וצווח ווי על ששלחם, ובזה אבד כל זכותו, ולזה יתואר איש נעצב וריקן, שע"י עצבותו שהתחרט וצווח ווי, נתרוקן ונתערטל מכל זכיותיו.
translation: And even though, according to what is said in the Kedushas Levi, that through the smiting of Egypt, His great and holy name was magnified and sanctified, and therefore the plague of the firstborn was by the Creator Himself, blessed be He, for it was the main cause of the Exodus of the Children of Israel from Egypt, and because of the Exodus, His great name was magnified and sanctified, etc., and it was also a benefit to the nations, as the Egyptians became vessels through which the existence of the Creator was made known, etc., thus they had the merit of becoming vessels through which His name was sanctified, blessed be He. However, our sages said (Kiddushin 40b) that one who is perplexed about the earlier ones and regrets the good has lost all his merit and has been emptied of it, as stated there. Similarly, with Pharaoh, who said, "Get up, go out, and send the Israelites away," and through the Exodus, His name was sanctified in the world, it turns out that he was a vessel for His name to be sanctified through him. However, afterwards he regretted and his heart turned, and he cried out, "Woe to me for having sent them away," and in this, he lost all his merit. Therefore, he is described as a man who is sad and empty, for through his sadness, having regretted and cried out "woe," he was emptied and stripped of all his merits.
summary: The passage discusses the concept that through the plagues of Egypt, particularly the death of the firstborn, God's name was sanctified and revealed to both the Israelites and the nations. It emphasizes that the Egyptians, despite being instruments of God's will, lost their merit when Pharaoh regretted his decision to release the Israelites, illustrating the idea that regret can lead to the loss of spiritual merit. The text highlights the transformative power of divine actions and the importance of intention and acknowledgment in the process of sanctification. Ultimately, it portrays the tragic consequence of turning away from one's role in God's plan, resulting in spiritual emptiness.

passage_content: ובזה יל"פ ויהפך לבב פרעה וגו', מלת לבב מורה על ב' הלבבות, וע"ד שדרשו רז"ל באברהם שהפכו כולו לטוב מדכתיב ומצאת את לבבו נאמן לפניך ולהיפך בפרעה הפכו כולו לרע, ובחי' קדושה שנקנה אליו ע"י שנתקדש ש"ש על ידו, עכשיו נתרוקן ממנה ונהפך כולו לרע, ויאמרו מה "זאת" עשינו כי שלחנו את ישראל, ירמוז עפימ"ש ז"ל (ע"ז ב' ע"ב) אין זאת אלא תורה שנא' וזאת התורה וגו' ע"י יצי"מ זכו ישראל לקבלת התורה, והם התחרטו על שהיו כלים לגרום קדושה גדולה זו, וז"ש מה "זאת" עשינו כי שלחנו את ישראל והבן.
translation: And in this, it can be explained that "And He hardened Pharaoh's heart," the word "heart" indicates two hearts. This is in accordance with what our Sages taught regarding Abraham, who turned his heart entirely to good, as it is written, "And you have found his heart faithful before You," and conversely, in Pharaoh, his heart was turned entirely to evil. The aspect of holiness that was acquired by him through being sanctified by the Holy Name, now became emptied from it and turned entirely to evil. And they said, "What is this we have done, for we have sent away Israel?" This hints at what our Sages said (Avodah Zarah 2b), "This is nothing but the Torah," as it is said, "And this is the Torah," etc. Through the Exodus from Egypt, Israel merited to receive the Torah, and they regretted that they were vessels to bring about this great holiness. Therefore, it is said, "What is this we have done, for we have sent away Israel," and understand.
summary: The passage discusses the transformation of Pharaoh's heart, highlighting the dual nature of the heart as seen in both Abraham and Pharaoh. While Abraham's heart was turned entirely to good, Pharaoh's was turned to evil, reflecting the consequences of spiritual choices. The text emphasizes that the sanctity acquired through the Exodus led to the Israelites receiving the Torah, and Pharaoh's regret stems from realizing that he played a role in facilitating this divine gift. The phrase "What have we done?" signifies his acknowledgment of the loss of the opportunity for holiness.

passage_content: ויהפך לבב פרעה ועבדיו אל העם ויאמרו מה זאת עשינו כי שלחנו את ישראל מעבדנו, צ"ב דהלא מתחילה לא שלחו מדעתם ומרצונם רק אחר שהכה ה' אותם במכות, וא"כ לא שייך הלשון ויהפך דלא הי' באמת שום הפיכה, ועוד צ"ב דבאמת איך לא יראו אחר כל המכות למרות פי ה' ולרדוף אחריהם להחזירם, וברש"י פי' בשביל ממונם שהשאילום, וגם זה צ"ב וכי הי' ממונם חביב עליהם יותר מגופם, ואיך נכנסו בסכנת הגוף בשביל ממונם, גם דמפורש בפסוק טעם אחר על הרדיפה.
translation: And the heart of Pharaoh and his servants turned to the people, and they said, "What is this we have done, that we have sent Israel from our service?" It is difficult to understand, for initially they did not send them of their own accord and will, but only after the Lord struck them with plagues. Therefore, the term "turned" is not applicable, as there was truly no turning. Furthermore, it is difficult to understand how, after all the plagues, they did not see the word of the Lord and pursued them to bring them back. Rashi explains that it was for their money that they had lent them, but this is also difficult to understand—was their money more precious to them than their own bodies? How could they put themselves in danger for the sake of their money? Additionally, it is explicitly stated in the verse that there is another reason for the pursuit.
summary: The passage discusses the transformation of Pharaoh's heart and that of his servants after releasing the Israelites, questioning the nature of their decision to pursue them. It highlights the idea that their initial release was not voluntary but compelled by divine plagues, raising doubts about the authenticity of their change of heart. Additionally, it critiques the notion that their material possessions were valued more than their own lives, suggesting a deeper theological reflection on the nature of attachment and the human condition in the face of divine intervention.

passage_content: ויתבאר הענין בהקדם דברי הגמ' (ב"ב דף י' ע"ב) ואיפסק להלכה בשו"ע יור"ד (סי' רנ"ד) דאסור לקבל צדקה מן הנכרים ולמדו זאת מפסוק (ישעי' כ"ז) ביבש קצירה תשברנה נשים באות מאירות אותה, פירש"י ז"ל כשתכלה זכות שבידן וייבש לחלוחית מעשה צדקה שלהן אז ישברו עכ"ל, ולפי"ז אם מקבלים מהם צדקה נותנים להם חיות וזכות חדש, ועד"ז יסבר טעותו של פרעה כי אף שהוכה במכות נוראים עד שהוכרח לשלחם, דימה בנפשו שנענש משום חוסר זכותו אבל לאחר שהשאילו לישראל כלי כסף ושמלות סבור הי' שמעכשיו ניתוספו זכיותיו ויגינו עליו מעונשים ויסורים, וז"ש ויהפך לבב פרעה וגו' מה זאת עשינו כי שלחנו את ישראל מעבדנו, פי' רשיז"ל בשביל ממונם שהשאילום, ר"ל זהו טעם שהפך לבו לרדוף אחריהם כי סמך שבכח הצדקה זו ינצל מן העונשים.
translation: And the matter will be clarified by first mentioning the words of the Gemara (Baba Batra 10b) and it is concluded in the Shulchan Aruch Yoreh De'ah (Siman 294) that it is forbidden to accept charity from non-Jews, and they learned this from the verse (Isaiah 27:11) "When its harvest is dried up, women come and break it," Rashi explains that when the merit in their hands is exhausted and the moisture of their charitable deeds dries up, then they will break. According to this, if we accept charity from them, we give them vitality and a new merit. Similarly, Pharaoh's mistake can be understood, for even though he was struck with terrible plagues until he was forced to send them away, he thought in his heart that he was punished because of his lack of merit. But after he lent the Israelites silver vessels and garments, he thought that now his merits would increase and protect him from punishments and suffering. And this is what is meant by "And the heart of Pharaoh was turned" etc., "What is this we have done that we have sent Israel away from our service," meaning because of the money that he lent them. This is the reason that his heart turned to pursue them, for he relied on the power of this charity to save him from punishments.
summary: The passage discusses the prohibition against accepting charity from non-Jews, based on a Talmudic source and a verse from Isaiah, which suggests that receiving such charity can diminish one's spiritual merit. It illustrates this concept through the example of Pharaoh, who mistakenly believed that lending valuables to the Israelites would increase his own merits and protect him from punishment. Ultimately, the text emphasizes the idea that reliance on external sources of merit, such as charity from others, can lead to spiritual downfall and misjudgment.

passage_content: אמנם צ"ב למה באמת צוה הקב"ה שיקחו ישראל מהם בדרך שאלה ואיכא חשש שיתרבה זכותם, גם באמת זכותם של המצריים ששאלו לישראל בטובם להיכן אזלא, ואפ"ל דהנה הקשו המפורשים הלא יעקב ועשו חלקו בנחלת שני עולמים, יעקב נטל עוה"ב ועשו עוה"ז ואיך הותר ליעקב ליהנות מעוה"ז והוא חלקו של עשו, ותירצו דאף חלקו של עשו מגיע ליעקב כמ"ש יצחק אבינו הן גביר שמתיו וכו' ומה איפוא אעשה לך דמה שקנה עבד קנה רבו והנה כ"ז ניחא בזמן שעושין רצונו של מקום. אבל אם ח"ו אין עושין נתבטל העבדות כמ"ש והי' כאשר תריד ופרקת עולו, וכמו"כ יש לומר לענינינו דכל זמן שבנ"י היו משועבדים תחת ידם של המצריים לא הי' באפשרות ליטול מהם דבר, דשלא ברשות ה"ה גזל ואם יתנוהו בטובם הרי יתוסף זכותם, אבל אחר שהוציא הקב"ה את בנ"י מתחת ידי המצריים אזי נהפכו המצריים להיות כדין עבדים לישראל, כי יצאו ע"ש זכות העתיד שיקבלו התורה ושוב אמרינן כל מה שקנה עבד קנה רבו והרכוש שלהם הוא ולא ניתוסף למצרים זכות עבור זה, כי החזיקו ישראל בשלהם.
translation: Indeed, it is questionable why the Holy One, blessed be He, commanded that Israel take from them in the manner of asking, and there is a concern that their merit would increase. Also, in truth, there is the merit of the Egyptians who asked Israel kindly where they were going. And it can be said that the commentators have asked, did not Jacob and Esau divide the inheritance of the two worlds? Jacob took the World to Come and Esau took this world, and how was it permitted for Jacob to benefit from this world, which is Esau's portion? They answered that even Esau's portion comes to Jacob, as our forefather Isaac said, "Behold, the master of the land is dead," etc., and what then shall I do for you, for what a servant acquires, his master acquires. And all this is acceptable when they are doing the will of the Omnipresent. But if, Heaven forbid, they are not doing so, the servitude is nullified, as it is said, "And it shall be when you rest, you shall remove his yoke." Likewise, we can say regarding our matter that as long as the Children of Israel were enslaved under the hands of the Egyptians, it was not possible to take anything from them, for without permission it is considered theft, and if they were to give it willingly, their merit would increase. But after the Holy One, blessed be He, took the Children of Israel out from under the hands of the Egyptians, then the Egyptians became like servants to Israel, for they left in the merit of the future that they would receive the Torah. And again we say, all that a servant acquires, his master acquires, and their property belongs to them, and the Egyptians do not gain merit from this, for Israel held onto what is theirs.
summary: The passage discusses the theological implications of the Israelites asking the Egyptians for valuables before their exodus. It raises the question of why God commanded this, considering the potential increase in the Egyptians' merit. The text explains that while the Egyptians initially had a claim to their possessions, once the Israelites were freed from bondage, the Egyptians became like servants to the Israelites, allowing the latter to rightfully claim the wealth as their own. This reflects the idea that when fulfilling God's will, the dynamics of ownership and merit shift, emphasizing the transformative power of divine intervention.

passage_content: ובזה יתבאר דברי המדרש הים ראה וינוס וכו' דהנה הים לא רצה להקרע והי' קטרוג גדול הללו והללו עוע"ז והי' צריכים זכות גדול להנצל, אמנם כאשר ראה ישראל באים ורכוש מצרים בידם ר"ל ברשותם, וע"כ דכל מה שקנה עבד קנה רבו ואין זה רק בעושין רצונו של מקום, א"כ מוכרח שיש להם זכות קבלת התורה ע"ש העתיד וע"כ וינוס מפניהם והבן.
translation: And this will clarify the words of the Midrash: "The sea saw and fled," etc. Behold, the sea did not want to split, and there was a great accusation against them, these and those, idol worshippers, and they needed a great merit to be saved. However, when it saw Israel coming with the wealth of Egypt in their hands, meaning with their permission, and therefore, all that a servant acquires, his master acquires, and this is only when they do the will of the Omnipresent, it follows that they must have the merit of receiving the Torah for the sake of the future. Therefore, it fled before them, and understand.
summary: The passage discusses the Midrashic interpretation of the sea's reluctance to part for the Israelites, highlighting the significant spiritual contention between the forces of idolatry and the Jewish people. It emphasizes that the Israelites' possession of Egyptian wealth symbolized their connection to divine will, as everything an enslaved person acquires belongs to their master. This connection implies that the Israelites had a merit rooted in their future acceptance of the Torah, which ultimately compelled the sea to flee before them. The text underscores the importance of divine merit and the anticipation of receiving the Torah as pivotal in their redemption.

passage_content: באופן אחר יתבארו דקדוקים הנ"ל בהקדם להעיר במאמה"כ בפרשת בא, דבר נא באזני העם וישאלו איש מאת רעהו וגו' כלי כסף וכלי זהב פירש"י אין נא אלא לשון בקשה, בבקשה ממך הזהירם על כך שלא יאמר אותו צדיק אברהם ועבדום וענו אותם קיים בהם ואח"כ יצאו ברכוש גדול לא קיים בהם עכ"ל, כבר דקדקו קמאי דמה צורך לטעם שלא יאמר אותו צדיק הלא חותמו של הקב"ה אמת ונאמן הוא ית' לקיים הבטחתו אף אם לא יאמר אותו צדיק, והפרשת דרכים דייק בלשון קיים "בהם", לא קיים "בהם", שמלת בהם מיותר ומחוסר הבנה ע"כ קושיתו, גם קשה מה צורך הי' להזהירן כ"כ שיקחו כלי כסף וכלי זהב, והם דברים שנפשו של אדם מחמדתן, ומצינו בביזת הים ויסע משה את בנ"י פרש"י הסיעם בע"כ שהי' רצונם להתעכב עוד למלאות ידם מביזת הים, ומדוע בביזת מצרים הי' צורך לאזהרה ולשון בקשה.
translation: In another way, the aforementioned nuances will be clarified by first noting in the Holy Scriptures in Parashat Bo, "Speak now in the ears of the people, and let them ask every man of his neighbor, and every woman of her neighbor for silver vessels and gold vessels." Rashi explains that "na" is only a term of request, a request from you to warn them not to say that righteous Abraham, "And they shall serve them, and they shall afflict them," is fulfilled in them, and afterwards they went out with great wealth is not fulfilled in them. Thus far his words. The early commentators already questioned what need there is for the reasoning that the righteous one should not say this, for is it not the seal of the Holy One, blessed be He, is truth, and He is faithful to fulfill His promise even if the righteous one does not say it? And the separation of paths is precise in the language of "fulfilled in them," "not fulfilled in them," that the word "in them" is superfluous and lacking understanding, therefore their question. It is also difficult what need there was to warn them so much to take silver vessels and gold vessels, for these are things that a person's soul covets. And we find in the plunder of the sea, "And Moses took the children of Israel," Rashi explains that he took them against their will because they wanted to delay further to fill their hands with the plunder of the sea. And why in the plunder of Egypt was there a need for a warning and a term of request?
summary: The passage discusses the request made to the Israelites to ask their neighbors for gold and silver, emphasizing the importance of this act as a divine command rather than mere human desire. It raises questions about the necessity of this request, given God's faithfulness to His promises, and highlights the distinction between the Israelites' eagerness for wealth in both the Egyptian and Red Sea contexts. The text reflects on the deeper theological implications of divine providence and the human inclination towards material possessions, suggesting that even righteous figures like Abraham are not the sole guarantors of God's promises.

passage_content: ב) הקשה האוהחה"ק בפ' שמות דמה צורך הי' ליטול בשאלה שאינו מהמוסר לגנוב דעתם של המצרים, ובימי אלכסנדר מוקדן הי' להם טענה על ישראל שנטלן ממונם, הלא הקב"ה כל יכול, וכמו שנתן את חן העם בעיני מצרים להשאיל להם, כמו"כ ביכולתו ית' ליתן בדעתם שיתנו במתנה לצמיתות ולא יהי' להם עוד טענה עליהם.
translation: B) The holy and exalted one asked in Parashat Shemot what need there was to take in a manner that does not align with the ethics of deceiving the Egyptians. And in the days of Alexander the Great, they had a claim against Israel for taking their possessions. Is not the Holy One, blessed be He, all-powerful? Just as He granted favor to the people in the eyes of the Egyptians to borrow from them, so too, it is within His ability to instill in their minds that they should give as a gift permanently, and they would no longer have a claim against them.
summary: The passage discusses the necessity of the Israelites asking the Egyptians for their possessions, despite the potential for misunderstanding or resentment. It highlights the omnipotence of God, who could have instilled in the Egyptians a willingness to give freely, thus eliminating any grounds for complaint. This reflects a deeper Hasidic understanding of divine providence and the complexities of human interactions within the framework of God's will. Ultimately, it emphasizes the balance between human agency and divine intervention in the unfolding of events.

passage_content: ג) ברכות (דף ט' ע"ב) כשאמר משה לישראל וישאלו איש מאת רעהו וגו' אמרו לו ולואי שנצא בעצמנו, משל לאדם שהי' חבוש בבית האסורין והיו אומרים לו מוציאין אותך למחר וכו' ונותנין לך ממון הרבה, ואומר להם בבקשה מכם הוציאוני עכשיו ואיני מבקש ממון עכ"ד הגמ', לכאורה אין המשל דומה לנמשל, דבהמשל אמרו לו שלמחר מוציאין אותך ונותנין לך ממון הרבה, ע"כ וויתר על הרווחת הממון שלא יתארך מאסרו ויצא מיד, אבל במצרים הכי הי' ס"ד שע"י שישאלו ממצרים יתארך גלותם, ומה טעם שימאנו בדבר ומה צורך להזהירם ואינו דומה להמשל כלל.
translation: 3) Blessings (page 9b) When Moses said to Israel, "And let every man ask of his neighbor," they replied, "If only we could go out by ourselves." This is comparable to a person who was imprisoned and was told, "Tomorrow they will take you out and give you a lot of money," and he said to them, "Please, let me out now, and I do not ask for money." Thus concludes the Gemara. At first glance, the parable does not resemble the lesson, for in the parable they told him that tomorrow they would take him out and give him a lot of money; therefore, he relinquished the benefit of the money so that his imprisonment would not be prolonged and he would go out immediately. However, in Egypt, the thought was that by asking to leave Egypt, their exile would be prolonged. What reason would they have to refuse this, and what need is there to warn them? It is not at all similar to the parable.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author reflects on the moment when Moses instructs the Israelites to ask their neighbors for valuables before leaving Egypt. The comparison made to a prisoner longing for immediate release rather than wealth highlights a deeper theological insight: the struggle between the desire for immediate freedom and the fear of prolonged suffering. The text suggests that the Israelites' reluctance to ask for riches stems from a concern that doing so might delay their liberation, emphasizing the tension between spiritual aspirations and material concerns. Ultimately, it illustrates the importance of faith and the urgency of liberation over worldly gain.

passage_content: ויתבאר בהקדם דברי הזוה"ק פ' שמות (דף ג' ע"א) ואלה שמות בנ"י וגו' ר' חייא פתח (משלי כ"ג) אל תלחם את לחם רע עין ואל תתאו למטעמותיו וכו', דאי כד נחתו ישראל למצרים לא יטעמון נהמא דמצראי, לא אשתבקו בגלותא ולא יעיקון לון מצראי א"ל ר' יצחק והא גזירה אתגזר א"ל הא לא אתגזר במצרים דוקא אלא בארץ לא להם ואפילו בארעא אחרא עכ"ד הזוה"ק, מבואר דבשביל שנהנו ישראל מן המצריים ע"כ יכלו להם לשעבדם ולצערם, ובעה"ת הביאו מדרש (בפ' שמות) שפרעה נתן להם שכר בתחלה, ודחקו עצמן מפני חימוד השכר, ואח"כ גזר עליהם בכפי' להשלים חקם כאשר עשו בהיות השכר נתן להם, אבל שבט לוי לא קבלו עליהם לעבוד בשכר וע"כ לא הי' לו פתחון פה לשעבד בהם גם בכפי' עכ"ד המדרש, ולכאורה הרי השעבוד הי' בגזירת מלכות ובעכ"ח ומי מעכב בידם ואף שלא עבדו בשכר הי' בידו להכריחם אח"כ בכפי' ומדוע בשביל טעם זה מאנו מלשעבדם, אמנם יבואר הענין עפי"ד הזוה"ק הנ"ל שישראל על ידי שנהנו מהם מתחלה הי' להם שליטה עליהם, אבל שבט לוי לא נהנו מהם לא הי' היכולת בידם להשתעבד בהם.
translation: And it will be explained in advance the words of the Zohar, Parashat Shemot (page 3, column 1): "And these are the names of the children of Israel," etc. Rabbi Chiya opened (Proverbs 23): "Do not eat the bread of a bad eye, and do not crave his delicacies," etc. For if when Israel descended to Egypt, they would not taste the bread of the Egyptians, they would not be entangled in exile, and the Egyptians would not oppress them. Rabbi Yitzchak said to him, "But isn't it a decree?" He replied, "It is not decreed specifically in Egypt, but in a land not theirs, and even in another land." Thus far the Zohar. It is explained that because the Israelites benefited from the Egyptians, therefore they were able to enslave them and afflict them. In the Holy Torah, it brought a Midrash (in Parashat Shemot) that Pharaoh initially gave them wages, and they pressed themselves because of the desire for the wages. And afterwards, he decreed upon them to complete their work as they did when the wages were given to them. However, the tribe of Levi did not accept upon themselves to work for wages, and therefore he had no opening to enslave them even with a decree. Thus far the Midrash. And seemingly, the enslavement was by royal decree, and who could prevent them? And even though they did not work for wages, he could have compelled them afterwards with a decree. Why, then, did they refuse to enslave them for this reason? However, the matter will be explained according to the aforementioned Zohar, that Israel, by having benefited from them initially, had control over them. But since the tribe of Levi did not benefit from them, they did not have the ability to be enslaved by them.
summary: The passage discusses the Zohar's interpretation of the Israelites' experience in Egypt, emphasizing that their initial enjoyment of the Egyptians' provisions gave the Egyptians power to enslave them. In contrast, the tribe of Levi refrained from benefiting from the Egyptians, which rendered them immune to subjugation. This highlights a key Hasidic concept that spiritual integrity and detachment from material gain can protect one from oppression, illustrating the profound connection between one's actions and their spiritual consequences.
