passage_content: ואיתא במדרש (הובא בילקו"ש תהלים פ"ז) אלקים אל דמי לך אל תחרש ואל תשקוט קל, החרשתנו שנאמר ה' ילחם לכם ואתם תחרישון, לכך אל תחרש ואל תשקוט קל, ויובן עפי"ד הילקוט (פ' בא רמז קצ"א) מי פורע לכם ממלכות רביעית נטרונא, פי' בזכות שימתינו ישראל על ישועת ה' ולא יעשו פעולה לדחוק הקץ יזכו לגאולה, ועד"ז בקשתינו החרשתנו שנאמר ה' ילחם לכם ואתם תחרישון, וע"ד שביארנו לעיל שנצטווינו שלא לעשות פעולה אף בתפלה יותר מדאי, לכך בזכות זאת אל תחרש ואל תשקוט קל למהר ישועתינו בב"א.
translation: And it is stated in the Midrash (brought in Yalkut Shimoni Tehillim 87) "God, do not be silent to me; do not be quiet, O God." We have been silenced, as it is said, "The Lord will fight for you, and you shall be silent." Therefore, do not be silent and do not be quiet, O God. It is understood according to the Yalkut (Parashat Bo, Remez 121) that who will exact retribution from you for the fourth kingdom, the one of oppression. This means that in the merit of the Jewish people waiting for the salvation of God and not taking action to hasten the end, they will merit redemption. Similarly, in our request, we have been silenced, as it is said, "The Lord will fight for you, and you shall be silent." And as we explained above, we were commanded not to take action even in prayer more than necessary. Therefore, in the merit of this, do not be silent and do not be quiet, O God, to hasten our salvation speedily, Amen.
summary: The passage discusses the importance of waiting for God's salvation without taking premature actions to hasten it, as emphasized in the Midrash. It highlights that Israel's patience and trust in divine intervention, rather than their own efforts, will lead to redemption. The reference to the verse "The Lord will fight for you, and you shall hold your peace" underscores the belief that true faith involves refraining from excessive prayer or action that might imply a lack of trust in God's timing. Ultimately, the text conveys a deep theological insight into the relationship between human action and divine will in the context of redemption.

passage_content: ויאמר ה' אל משה מה תצעק אלי וגו' פירש"י למדנו שהי' משה עומד ומתפלל, אמר לו הקב"ה לא עת עתה להאריך בתפלה שישראל נתונים בצרה. וצ"ב דאדרבה היא הנותנת להתפלל להקב"ה, ובמד"ר (פרשה כ' סימן ב') מה תצעק אלי הה"ד (איוב כ"ב) ותגזר אומר ויקם לך, א"ר לוי כשם שהקב"ה מצוה למשה ומדבר עמו כך הי' משה מצוה כביכול לפני הקב"ה וכו' משל לאוהבו של מלך שהי' לו עסק הלך לצעוק לפני המלך א"ל המלך מה אתה צועק גזור ואני אעשה, כך אמר הקב"ה למשה מה תצעק אלי דבר ואני עושה וצ"ב.
translation: And the Lord said to Moses, "Why do you cry out to Me?" Rashi explains: We learn that Moses was standing and praying. The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to him, "Now is not the time to prolong in prayer, for Israel is in distress." And it is puzzling, for on the contrary, this is the very reason to pray to the Holy One, Blessed be He. And in the Midrash (Parashat 20, Section 2), "Why do you cry out to Me?" This is as it is written (Job 22), "And you will decree a thing, and it will be established for you." Rabbi Levi said: Just as the Holy One, Blessed be He, commands Moses and speaks with him, so too was Moses, as it were, commanding before the Holy One, Blessed be He. It is like a beloved of the king who had a matter to discuss and went to cry out before the king. The king said to him, "Why are you crying? Decree, and I will do." Thus, the Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Moses, "Why do you cry out to Me? Speak, and I will act," and it is puzzling.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, God instructs Moses not to prolong his prayers during a time of crisis for the Israelites, emphasizing the urgency of action over supplication. The text highlights the relationship between God and Moses, suggesting that just as God commands Moses, Moses also has the authority to command God in a sense. This dynamic illustrates the concept of partnership between the divine and human efforts in the face of adversity, underscoring the importance of decisive action in moments of need.

passage_content: ב) (הובא בישמח משה) אמר הקב"ה למשה הים סוער והשונא רודף ואתה עומד ומרבה בתפלה לפני, אמר לו משה מה לי לעשות, א"ל ואתה הרם את מטך, באותה שעה אמרו ישראל ה' ימלוך לעולם ועד, ותמה ק"ז הישמח משה זללה"ה ד' תמיהות, חדא מה זה שאמר הקב"ה שני טעמים הים סוער והשונא רודף, ב' מ"ש ואתה עומד ומרבה בתפלה קשה, למה לא יתפלל בצרת ישראל, ג' להבין מה שהשיב לו ואתה הרם את מטך, ד' למה באותה שעה אמרו ה' ימלוך לעולם ועד.
translation: B) (As brought in Yismach Moshe) The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Moshe, "The sea is raging and the enemy is pursuing, and you are standing and increasing in prayer before Me." Moshe replied, "What should I do?" He said to him, "And you lift up your staff." At that moment, Israel said, "The Lord shall reign forever and ever." Yismach Moshe, may his memory be blessed, wondered at four things: First, what is this that the Holy One, Blessed be He, said two reasons: the sea is raging and the enemy is pursuing? Second, what does it mean that you are standing and increasing in prayer, which is difficult—why not pray in the distress of Israel? Third, to understand what He answered him, "And you lift up your staff." Fourth, why at that moment did they say, "The Lord shall reign forever and ever"?
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the dialogue between God and Moses highlights the tension between divine intervention and human action during a crisis, as the Israelites face danger from the sea and their enemies. God instructs Moses to raise his staff, emphasizing the importance of faith and proactive response in prayer. The Israelites' declaration of "The Lord shall reign forever and ever" signifies their trust in God's sovereignty amidst adversity. The text raises profound questions about the nature of prayer, the reasons for suffering, and the interplay between divine will and human agency.

passage_content: ג) הרם את מטך וגו' במד"ר (פ' כ"א סימן ט') אמר ר' סימון משל לבעל הזמורה וכו' אמרו אילולי שהזמורה בידו לא הי' מתכבד שמע המלך וא"ל העבר הזמורה ממך וצא לחוץ, וכל מי שאינו שואל בשלומך אני נוטל את ראשו, כך אמרו המצריים לא הי' יכול משה לעשות כלום אלא במטה. בו הכה היאור בו הביא כל המכות, כיון שבאו ישראל לתוך הים והמצרים עומדים מאחריהם, אמר הקב"ה למשה השלך את מטך שלא יאמרו אילולא המעה לא הי' יכול לקרוע את הים שנאמר הרם את מטך עכ"ד המדרש, לכאורה אין המשל דומה לנמשל, דאין זה דרך הטבע לקרוע את הים במטה ובעכ"ח שהוא כח אלקי ובדרך נס, ומנפק"מ אם יהי' באמצעות המטה או לא ובין כך ובין כך נס גדול הוא. גם יש להבין מדוע דוקא בנס קרי"ס צוהו הקב"ה להשליך המטה ולא בשאר הנסים עד עכשיו שנעשו ג"כ ע"י המטה הזה, ועוד הלא מטה זה יהי' ביד מלך המשיח כמבואר במדרשי חז"ל, ולמה חששו יותר בקריעת ים סוף שלא יאמרו אילולי המטה לא הי' יכול לקרוע הים, ובאמת מצינו גם בחטא מי מריבה שזה הי' הפגם מה שהכה את הסלע במטה כדכתיב יען לא האמנתם בי וגו', אולם לפי זה טעמא בעי למה נצטוה בפעם הראשון להכות במטה על הסלע שא"ל הקב"ה ומטך אשר הכית בו את היאור קח בידך והלכת וגו' והכית בצור ויצאו ממנו מים וגו'.
translation: 3) "Raise your staff, etc." In the Midrash (Parashat Ki Tisa, Siman 9), Rabbi Simon said: This is comparable to a master of the vine, etc. They said, if not for the vine being in his hand, he would not have been honored by the king's name, and he said to him, 'Pass the vine from you and go outside, and anyone who does not inquire about your well-being, I will take his head.' Thus, the Egyptians said that Moses could do nothing except with the staff. With it, he struck the Nile, and with it, he brought all the plagues. When Israel entered the sea and the Egyptians were standing behind them, the Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Moses, 'Throw down your staff, so that they will not say, "If not for the staff, he would not have been able to split the sea," as it is said, "Raise your staff."' Thus far the Midrash. At first glance, the parable does not resemble the interpretation, for it is not the way of nature to split the sea with a staff, and certainly it is a divine power and a miracle. It makes no difference whether it will be through the staff or not; in either case, it is a great miracle. It is also necessary to understand why specifically in the miracle of the splitting of the sea was he commanded by the Holy One, Blessed be He, to throw down the staff and not in the other miracles that were also performed through this staff until now. Moreover, this staff will be in the hand of the King Messiah, as explained in the Midrashim of our Sages. Why were they more concerned in the splitting of the Sea of Reeds that they would say, "If not for the staff, he would not have been able to split the sea"? In truth, we also find in the sin of the waters of Meribah that the flaw was that he struck the rock with the staff, as it is written, "Because you did not believe in Me," etc. However, according to this, we need to understand why he was commanded the first time to strike the rock with the staff, as the Holy One, Blessed be He, said to him, "And your staff with which you struck the Nile, take in your hand and go," etc., and "Strike the rock, and water will come out of it," etc.

passage_content: ולבאר הענין נקדים לפרש במאמה"כ (פרשת ויחי) פחז כמים אל תותר ובמד"ר (פ' צ"ח סי' ד') אתה חטאת במים יבוא משוי ממים (פי' משה דכתיב בי' כי מן המים משיתיהו) ויקרבוך יחי ראובן ואל ימות וצ"ב, עוד במדרש כמים, מה מים ניתרין ממקום למקום כך הותרה לך, רבי אליעזר המודעי אומר אין עושין מקוה של יין של שמן אלא של מים, כך עשית לך מקוה של מים וטיהרת עצמך בו, וצ"ב מדוע המשיל בחי' חטאו למים וגם את התשובה למים.
translation: To clarify the matter, we will begin by interpreting the verse in the Torah (Parashat Vayechi) "Unstable as water, you shall not excel," and in the Midrash (Parashat Tzav, Section 4) "You have sinned with water, let your atonement come from water" (meaning, as Moses explained, "for from the water I will draw them"). And may Reuven be brought close and not die, and this is puzzling. Furthermore, in the Midrash, it states, "Just as water is permitted to move from place to place, so you are permitted." Rabbi Eliezer the Modai says, "One does not make a mikveh of wine or oil, but only of water." Thus, you have made for yourself a mikveh of water and purified yourself in it, and this is puzzling why he compared the aspect of his sin to water and also the repentance to water.
summary: The passage discusses the metaphor of water in relation to sin and repentance, drawing from biblical and midrashic sources. It highlights that just as water can flow and be purified, so too can one's sins be cleansed through sincere repentance. The comparison emphasizes the transformative power of repentance, suggesting that it can restore one's spiritual state, akin to the purifying nature of water. The text raises questions about the significance of this water analogy in understanding the nature of sin and the process of atonement.

passage_content: ואפשר לומר עפ"י מש"כ הרח"ו זלה"ה (בספרו שער הקדושה פ"א ופ"ב) בענין הד' יסודות אש רוח מים עפר שמהם גוף האדם נוצר, וקנין המדות הם כמו"כ מד' יסודות אלו וזל"ק, יסוד האש ממנו נמשכה הגאוה הנקרא גסות הרוח. להיותו היסוד הקל וגבוה מכולן, ובכללה הכעס וכו', יסוד הרוח ממנו נמשך דיבור הנקרא שיחה בטלה וכו' יסוד המים ממנו תאות התענוגים: כי כן המים מצמיחין כל מיני תענוג וכו', יסוד העפר ממנו מדת העצבות וכו' וארבעתן נמשכות מד' קליפות היצה"ר שבנפש היסודית, והפכן הן ד' מדות טובות, נמשכות מד' יסודות הטוב שבנפש היסודית והן הענוה וכו' והשתיקה כאלם לא יפתח פיו לבד בעסק תורה ומצות וכו', והמיאוס בכל תענוגי הגוף וכו' והשמחה התדירית בחלקו וכו' עכלה"ק.
translation: And it can be said according to what the holy Rabbi Chaim Vital, may his memory be blessed, wrote (in his book Shaar HaKedusha, chapters 1 and 2) regarding the four elements of fire, wind, water, and earth from which the human body is formed, and the acquisition of the character traits is likewise from these four elements. The element of fire is the source of arrogance, which is called the coarseness of spirit, being the lightest and highest of all, and includes anger, etc. The element of wind is the source of speech, which is called idle chatter, etc. The element of water is the source of the desires for pleasures, for indeed water brings forth all kinds of pleasures, etc. The element of earth is the source of the trait of sadness, etc. And all four are drawn from the four klipot of the evil inclination that are in the fundamental soul, and their opposites are the four good character traits, which are drawn from the four elements of good in the fundamental soul, and they are humility, etc., and silence like a mute who does not open his mouth except in the study of Torah and commandments, etc., and the disdain for all bodily pleasures, etc., and the constant joy in his portion, etc. Thus concludes the holy text.
summary: The passage discusses the four fundamental elements—fire, air, water, and earth—that constitute the human body and their corresponding emotional traits. It explains that each element gives rise to negative traits: fire leads to pride and anger, air to idle chatter, water to sensual desires, and earth to sadness. These negative traits are associated with the four "klipot" (shells) of the evil inclination within the soul. Conversely, the text emphasizes that these elements can be transformed into positive attributes: humility, silence in the pursuit of Torah and mitzvot, disdain for physical pleasures, and constant joy in one's spiritual portion.

passage_content: ועפי"ז יובן קצת מה שהמשיל הכתוב בחי' חטאו של ראובן למים דהנה אמרו חכז"ל (שבת דף נ"ה ע"ב) כל האומר ראובן חטא אינו אלא טועה מ"מ אם התורה הקדושה כתבה עליו וישכב פלגש אביו בוודאי הי' בחי' פגם בדבר בערך קדושתו, והנה שורש החטא זה מיסוד המים, וז"ש פחז כמים שהוא שורש מדת התאוה, אלא שגבי ראובן לא הי' בפועל ח"ו רק בחי' פגם בערך רוב קדושתו, לז"א כמים בכ"ף הדמיון, וגם את התשובה המשיל למים דכמו"כ המדות טובות בהפכן נמשכים ג"כ מד' יסודות הנ"ל, וידוע שבזוה"ק החמירו מאוד בעון פגם חטא הידוע, עד שבמקום אחד כתבו דאינו מועיל תשובה אבל כבר פירשו דהכוונה רק על תשובה מיראת העונש, אבל תשובה מאהבה מועיל גם על חטא זה, והאהבה להשי"ת נמשכה ג"כ מיסוד המים שנקראת תאוה כמו שאה"כ נפשי אויתיך בלילה, ואם מתעורר נפש האדם חלק אלקי ממעל להשתוקק להשי"ת להיות דבוק בו ית' במסנ"פ באמת, גם זה נמשך מיסוד המים, נמצא שע"י יסוד המים אפשר לירד למקום נמוך ביותר ע"י התאוות לדברים האסורים, ולעומת זה אפשר לעלות למדריגות גבוהות ונשגבות, וזה שאמר המדרש מה מים ניתרין ממקום למקום כך הותרה לו, דע"י יסוד המים אפשר לירד ממקום גבוה למקום נמוך וכן אפשר גם לעלות ממקום נמוך למקום גבוה, וע"י התשובה שעשה ראובן על חטא זה שהוא מיסוד המים הותרה לו.
translation: And according to this, we can understand somewhat what the verse compares the sin of Reuben to water. Behold, our sages have said (Shabbat 55b) that anyone who says Reuben sinned is merely mistaken. Nevertheless, if the Holy Torah wrote about him, "and he lay with his father's concubine," there was certainly a flaw in this matter in relation to his holiness. The root of this sin is from the element of water, as it is said, "You are unstable as water," which is the root of the trait of desire. However, regarding Reuben, it was not in practice, Heaven forbid, but rather a flaw in relation to the majority of his holiness. Therefore, it is said "like water" with the letter "kaf" of resemblance. And the repentance is also compared to water, for likewise, good traits, when reversed, are also drawn from the four aforementioned elements. It is known that in the Zohar they are very strict about the sin of the known flaw, to the extent that in one place it is written that repentance does not help. However, it has already been explained that the intention is only regarding repentance out of fear of punishment, but repentance out of love is effective even for this sin. And the love for the Holy One, blessed be He, is also drawn from the element of water, which is called desire, as it is written, "My soul longs for You at night." If the divine soul, a part of God above, awakens to yearn for the Holy One, to be attached to Him truly, this too is drawn from the element of water. Thus, through the element of water, one can descend to the lowest place through desires for forbidden things, and conversely, one can ascend to high and exalted levels. This is what the Midrash says: "Just as water flows from place to place, so was it permitted to him." Know that through the element of water, it is possible to descend from a high place to a low place, and likewise, it is also possible to ascend from a low place to a high place. And through the repentance that Reuben did for this sin, which is from the element of water, it was permitted to him.
summary: The passage discusses the nature of Reuben's sin, comparing it to water, which symbolizes desire and the potential for both downfall and elevation. It emphasizes that while Reuben's actions represented a flaw in his holiness, they did not constitute a complete transgression, as he ultimately repented. The text highlights that true repentance, especially when motivated by love for God, can transcend even the gravest of sins. Thus, the element of water serves as a metaphor for the dual capacity of desire to lead one to lowliness or to elevate one to spiritual heights through sincere repentance.

passage_content: ובזה נל"פ הא דאיתא במדרש (פ' עקב פרשה ג' סי' ח') שמע ישראל אתה עובר היום את הירדן בא וראה כל הנסים שעשה הקב"ה לישראל לא עשאן אלא על המים, כיצד עד שהן במצרים עשה להם נסים ביאור וכו' וכשיצאו ישראל ממצרים וכו', א"ל משה הוו יודעין כל נסים שעשה לכם הקב"ה לא עשה אלא על המים, ואף בשעה שתעברו את הירדן לירש את הארץ עתיד הוא לעשות לכם נסים במי הירדן ע"כ וצ"ב דהרי נעשו לישראל הרבה נסים אף שלא על המים, ואיך קאמר שכל הנסים לא עשאן אלא על המים, ועוד הרי טיטוס הרשע אמר שאין כחו של אלקי ישראל אלא על המים כדאיתא בגמרא גיטין (דף נ"ו ע"ב) ואיך אמרו שכל הנסים לא עשאן אלא על המים.
translation: And with this, we can understand the teaching found in the Midrash (Parashat Eikev, section 3, sign 8): "Hear, O Israel, you are crossing today the Jordan. Come and see all the miracles that the Holy One, blessed be He, performed for Israel; He did them only on the water. How so? While they were in Egypt, He performed miracles for them in the sea, etc. And when Israel left Egypt, etc., Moses said to them, 'Know that all the miracles that the Holy One, blessed be He, performed for you were done only on the water, and even at the time you cross the Jordan to inherit the land, He is destined to perform miracles for you in the waters of the Jordan.' Therefore, it is puzzling, for many miracles were performed for Israel even not on the water, and how can it be said that all the miracles were done only on the water? Furthermore, it is known that the wicked Titus said that the power of the God of Israel is only over the water, as stated in the Gemara Gittin (56b), and how can it be said that all the miracles were done only on the water?
summary: The passage discusses the idea that all miracles performed by God for the Israelites were fundamentally connected to water, as highlighted in the Midrash. It emphasizes that even the miracles in Egypt and during the crossing of the Jordan River were manifestations of divine intervention through water. The text raises questions about this assertion, noting that many miracles occurred without a direct connection to water, and references the challenge posed by the wicked Titus, who claimed that God's power was limited to water. Ultimately, it reflects on the profound relationship between divine miracles and the element of water in the context of Jewish faith and history.

passage_content: ואפ"ל ענין הרמז עפ"י דרכינו הנ"ל, דע"י תאוות הרעות הבאים מיסוד המים עלול האדם ליפול ר"ל עד לדיוטא התחתונה, ולהיפך ע"י מדות הטובות שביסוד המים יזכה לעלות מעלה מעלה, וזה תכלית כל הנסים שנעשו לישראל, להעלות יסוד המים לשרשה, באהבה נפלאה והשתוקקות להשי"ת ע"י חביבות הנס והכרה אמיתית בהשפעה אלקית וגדולת הבוית"ש, וזהו רמזו חז"ל במתק לשונם, א"ל משה הוו יודעין שכל הנסים שעשה לכם הקב"ה, לא עשה אלא על המים, לתקן מה שפגמו ביסוד המים ולהעלותה לשרשה, ואפשר דגם נס קרי"ס הי' להמשיך פעולה זו, כי הי' צורך להפריש את ישראל מתאות מצרים, ואף שהיו גדורים מעריות ולא נטמעו ביניהם, מ"מ אם מידי עבירה יצאו מידי הרהור לא יצאו, וע"י נס קרי"ס הופרשו מתאות האסורים ובאו לתאוה דקדושה, והעלו יסוד המים לשורשה ולתנאם הראשון שנבראו ע"ש כך מששת ימי בראשית, ואפשר לרמוז זה באמרם ז"ל וישב הים לאיתנו לתנאו הראשון והבן.
translation: And even if the matter of the hint is according to our aforementioned path, know that through the evil desires that come from the element of water, a person can fall, Heaven forbid, to the lowest level. Conversely, through the good traits that stem from the element of water, one can merit to rise higher and higher. This is the purpose of all the miracles that were performed for Israel, to elevate the element of water to its root, with a wondrous love and yearning for the Blessed One, through the cherished nature of the miracle and a true recognition of the Divine influence and the greatness of the Holy One, Blessed be He. This is hinted at by our Sages in their sweet language, as Moses said, "Know that all the miracles that the Holy One, Blessed be He, performed for you were only on account of the water, to rectify what was damaged in the element of water and to elevate it to its root." It is possible that even the miracle of the splitting of the sea was to continue this action, for there was a need to separate Israel from the desires of Egypt. And although they were fenced off from immorality and did not intermingle with them, nonetheless, if they had not exited from sin, they had not exited from improper thoughts. And through the miracle of the splitting of the sea, they were separated from the forbidden desires and came to a desire of holiness, elevating the element of water to its root and to the original condition for which it was created, as mentioned from the six days of creation. It is possible to hint at this in their saying, "And the sea returned to its strength, to its original condition," and understand.
summary: The passage discusses the dual nature of water as a foundational element in both negative and positive contexts. It emphasizes that through negative desires stemming from the water's essence, a person can descend spiritually, while positive attributes can elevate them. The miracles performed for Israel, particularly the splitting of the sea, served to rectify the spiritual state of water, separating the Israelites from the temptations of Egypt and leading them towards a holy desire. Ultimately, this reflects the divine intention to restore the original state of creation as intended from the beginning.

passage_content: וכבר בארנו מה דאיתא במדרש שנעשה נס במטה שבלע כל המטות של החרטומים ולא נתעבה כלל, וראוי להבין מדוע הי' צורך בנס זה (עיין בדברינו לעיל), ועכשיו נ"ל להסביר באופן אחר דאפשר שאותו המטה לא בלע את מטותם כלל, דאלמלי הי' בולע מכוחות הטומאה לא היו משתמשין לעשות בו נסי הגאולה כי א"א שבגאולת ישראל יהי' איזה תערובת מכוחות הסט"א, אך נראה כי לשון בליעה האמור כאן יש לו מובן אחר, דמצינו אצל המלאכים שבאו אל אברהם אבינו ע"ה כתיב והוא עומד עליהם וגו' ויאכלו ודרשו רז"ל במד"ר (פ' וירא פרשה מ"ח סי' י"ד) וכי אוכלין היו אלא נראין כאוכלין ראשון ראשון מסתלק, הרי דהבערה מן העולם נקרא ג"כ בלשון אכילה, וכמו"כ אפ"ל כאן ויבלע מטה אהרן את מטותם, דאין הכוונה שבלע אותם ממש אלא שמטה אהרן התגבר על מטותם, וראשון ראשון נסתלק מן העולם עד שנאבדו לגמרי, וכ"כ בעלי התוספות (פ' מקץ) עה"פ ותבלענה השבלים אין לפרש לשון בליעה ממש דאין מראין לו לאדם דעייל פילא בקופא דמחטא עיי"ש, נמצא לפי"ז דהיינו טעמא שלא נתעבה המטה, לפי שלא נכנסו בו מטות החרטומים כלל רק נעשה נס שמטה אהרן ביער כל מטות החרטומים. אלא שהחרטומים והמכשפים אמרו להיפך שכוחות הטומאה דחו את כח הקדושה, לכן כדי להוציא מלבם של צדוקים צוה הקב"ה למשה ואתה הרם את מטך, שיסלק את המטה בקרי"ס כי ישועתן של ישראל צריכה שתבוא רק מצד הקדושה באופן שלא יהי' מקום לטעות, וח"ו להעלות על הדעת שיבוא ישועה לישראל ע"י מינים וכופרים, לא תהא כזאת בישראל, ורק לה' הישועה.
translation: And we have already explained what is stated in the Midrash that a miracle occurred with the staff, which swallowed all the staffs of the magicians and did not become thick at all. It is appropriate to understand why there was a need for this miracle (see our words above). Now it seems to me to explain in another way that perhaps that staff did not swallow their staffs at all. For if it had absorbed the forces of impurity, they would not have used it to perform the miracles of redemption, for it is impossible that in the redemption of Israel there should be any mixture of the forces of the Other Side. However, it appears that the term "swallowing" mentioned here has another meaning. We find regarding the angels who came to our father Abraham, may peace be upon him, it is written, "And he stood over them" and so on, "and they ate," and our sages have interpreted in the Midrash (Parashat Vayera, section 48, sign 14) that they were not actually eating, but rather they appeared as if they were eating, and one by one they departed. Thus, the removal from the world is also called by the term "eating." Similarly, it can be said here, "And the staff of Aaron swallowed their staffs," meaning that the intention is not that it literally swallowed them, but rather that the staff of Aaron overcame their staffs, and one by one they vanished from the world until they were completely lost. And so too the Ba'alei Tosafot (Parashat Miketz) explain on the verse "And the ears swallowed them," that the term "swallowing" should not be understood literally, for it does not appear to a person that an elephant enters a needle's eye, as stated there. Therefore, according to this, the reason that the staff did not become thick is that the staffs of the magicians did not enter it at all; rather, a miracle occurred that the staff of Aaron consumed all the staffs of the magicians. However, the magicians and sorcerers said the opposite, that the forces of impurity repelled the force of holiness. Therefore, in order to remove from their hearts the thoughts of the Sadducees, the Holy One, blessed be He, commanded Moses, "And you raise your staff," so that the staff would be lifted in a manner that the redemption of Israel should come only from the side of holiness, in a way that there would be no room for error, and God forbid to entertain the thought that salvation for Israel would come through heretics and deniers; may such a thing not be in Israel, for salvation belongs only to the Lord.
summary: The passage discusses the miracle of Aaron's staff swallowing the staffs of the Egyptian magicians, emphasizing that this act did not involve a literal absorption of their powers, as that would imply a mixture of holiness and impurity. Instead, it suggests that Aaron's staff symbolically overpowered the magicians' staffs, leading to their eventual disappearance. This interpretation reinforces the idea that Israel's redemption must come solely from divine holiness, without any influence from forces of impurity or heresy, affirming that true salvation is exclusively from God.

passage_content: ואפשר דהיינו טעמא נמי שהי' פגם בדבר אשר הכה מרע"ה את הסלע במטה, יען שהיו שם דתן ואבירם והע"ר והי' חשש שיאמרו שהנס נעשה ע"י המטה מפני שיש בו מכוחות הטומאה של מטות החרטומים, וע"כ נצטוה להוציא המים מן הסלע בדיבור גרידא ולא במטה כדי להתוודע ולהגלות שלא המטה הוא המוציא מים מחלמיש צור, ולפיכך הי' פגם בדבר שלא נתקדש ש"ש מטעם שהי' פתחון פה לרשעים לומר כנ"ל, אמנם בפרשה זו נצטוה משה רבינו ע"ה והכית בצור וגו', אפשר יען שעדיין היו עומדים לפני מלחמת עמלק, לא הי' חשש שיאמרו כן, לפי שהיו ישראל טהורים ונקיים מכל שמץ מחשבת פיגול, משא"כ אחר מלחמת עמלק שהכניס בהם פגם וחסרון אמונה, ומלחמה לה' בעמלק מדור דור, ודרשו רז"ל מדורו של משה עד דורו של משיח שאז ימחה שמו של עמלק, ואיתא במדרש שהמלך המשיח ישתמש במטה שהי' ביד משה, אמנם אז לא יעלה על הדעת שיש במטה ערבוב מכוחות הטומאה, כי אז יכלה כוחו של עמלק מן העולם, ויתכן דגם בנס קרי"ס לא הי' יכול להשתמש במטה מה"ט לפי שלא היו ישראל עדיין חזקים באמונה כ"כ עד אחר שעברו את הים ונתקדשו ונטהרו כמ"ש ויאמינו בה' ובמשה עבדו, וקודם קרי"ס התגברו כוחות הטומאה והסט"א מאוד כדאיתא במדרש שכל שרי האומות באו לעזור למצרים והי' חשש כנ"ל, לכן אמר לו הקב"ה למשה ואתה הרם את מטך שיסלק את המטה ורק בדיבור בלבד יקרע את הים.
translation: And it is possible that this is also the reason that there was a flaw in the matter when Moshe Rabbeinu struck the rock with the staff, because there were Datan and Aviram and the mixed multitude there, and there was a concern that they would say that the miracle was performed by the staff due to the forces of impurity that are in the staffs of the sorcerers. Therefore, he was commanded to bring forth the water from the rock only by speech and not with the staff, in order to make known and reveal that it is not the staff that brings forth water from the flint rock. And thus, there was a flaw in the matter that the Shabbat was not sanctified, because there was an opening for the wicked to say as mentioned. However, in this section, Moshe Rabbeinu was commanded, "And you shall strike the rock," possibly because they were still standing before the war with Amalek, there was no concern that they would say so, since Israel was pure and clean from any trace of impure thoughts. In contrast, after the war with Amalek, they had a flaw and a deficiency in faith, and there is a war for the Lord against Amalek from generation to generation. And our sages have taught that from the generation of Moshe until the generation of the Messiah, at which time the name of Amalek will be blotted out. And it is stated in the Midrash that the King Messiah will use the staff that was in the hand of Moshe. However, then it would not enter anyone's mind that there is a mixture of the forces of impurity in the staff, because then the power of Amalek would be eradicated from the world. It is also possible that even in the miracle of the splitting of the sea, he could not use the staff for this reason, since Israel was not yet strong in faith until after they crossed the sea and were sanctified and purified, as it is written, "And they believed in the Lord and in His servant Moshe." Before the splitting of the sea, the forces of impurity and the Other Side were very strong, as it is stated in the Midrash that all the princes of the nations came to help Egypt, and there was a concern as mentioned. Therefore, the Holy One, blessed be He, said to Moshe, "And you raise your staff," so that the staff would be removed, and only by speech would he split the sea.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of Moses striking the rock with his staff, highlighting concerns about the potential misinterpretation of divine miracles as being caused by the staff, which could be associated with impure forces. It emphasizes that during the battle against Amalek, the Israelites were pure and free from doubt, allowing for the use of the staff without fear of misrepresentation. The text also notes that prior to the crossing of the Red Sea, the Israelites lacked sufficient faith, necessitating a divine command to separate the staff from the miracle of the sea's splitting, reinforcing the idea that true faith and purity are essential for recognizing God's direct intervention.

passage_content: והנה בזמן שכח הקטרוג חזקה צריך הצדיק להסתיר תפילתו שלא יבינו המקטריגים ולא יקטרגו לבטל תפילתו, כמ"ש בספה"ק נועם אלימלך (פ' וישלח) עה"פ כה תאמרון לאדוני לעשו, דהנה דרך הצדיק בדברו עם אנשים, אזי הוא מדקדק בדבריו להשכיל, שיהיו דבריו נשמעים וכו' דברים כפשוטן לאיש המדבר עמו, שנית הוא העיקר תוכן דבר שמכוין באותן הדיבורים, שיהיו תפלה ותחנונים לפני המקום ב"ה וב"ש, והכוונה בזה שמסתיר דבריו של התפלה בהדיבורים שמדבר עם האדם, ואינו מתפלל תפלתו הצורך לו בפירוש הוא למען המקטרג שלא יבין כוונתו בדבריו שמכניס בהם תפלה, ולא יקטרג עליו כי אינו יודע שזה מתפלל עכלה"ק, והנה בקרי"ס הי' הקטרוג גדול מאוד כמבואר בדרז"ל, וע"כ אין העת מוכשר להאריך בתפלה לטעם הנ"ל, ולזה נתן הקב"ה עצה למשרע"ה שלא יאריך בתפלתו, כ"א ימשיך הנס והישועה בבחי' צדיק גוזר והקב"ה מקיים, ואף זו יסתיר בדבריו למען לא יבינו המקטריגים, ולז"א לו דבר אל בני ישראל ויסעו, ועי"ז ימשיך נס קרי"ס בבחי' צדיק גוזר, ובזה יתבאר דברי המדרש הנ"ל אמר הקב"ה למשה מה תצעק אלי, דבר ואני עושה, כי לא עת להאריך בתפלה שישראל נתונים בצרה מפני סכנת הקטרוג.
translation: And behold, at the time when the power of accusation is strong, the righteous one must conceal his prayer so that the accusers do not understand and do not accuse to nullify his prayer, as it is written in the holy book Noam Elimelech (Parashat Vayishlach) on the verse "Thus shall you say to my lord, to Esau." The way of the righteous when speaking with people is that he is careful with his words to be wise, so that his words are heard, etc., straightforward words to the person he is speaking with. Secondly, the main content of the matter is directed in those words, that they should be prayer and supplications before the Blessed One, and the intention here is that he conceals the words of prayer within the words he speaks to the person, and he does not explicitly pray for his needs so that the accuser does not understand his intention in the words that contain prayer, and he will not accuse him because he does not know that this one is praying. And behold, at the splitting of the sea, the accusation was very great as explained in the Sages, and therefore the time is not suitable to prolong in prayer for the aforementioned reason. For this reason, the Holy One, blessed be He, gave advice to Moshe that he should not prolong in his prayer, but rather continue the miracle and salvation in the manner of "the righteous decrees and the Holy One, blessed be He, fulfills." And even this he should conceal in his words so that the accusers do not understand. Therefore, it is said to him, "Speak to the children of Israel and let them journey," and through this, he will continue the miracle of the splitting of the sea in the manner of "the righteous decrees." And this will clarify the words of the aforementioned Midrash: the Holy One, blessed be He, said to Moshe, "Why do you cry out to Me? Speak, and I will act," for it is not the time to prolong in prayer since Israel is in distress due to the danger of accusation.
summary: In the passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, it is emphasized that during times of strong accusation (ketrug), a righteous person (tzaddik) must conceal their prayers to prevent adversaries from understanding and thwarting them. The tzaddik carefully chooses their words in conversations, embedding prayers within them to shield their true intentions from the accusers. This approach is illustrated through the example of Moses, who is advised not to prolong his prayers during a crisis, as the situation requires immediate divine intervention, demonstrating the balance between prayer and action in the face of adversity.

passage_content: ומעתה נבוא לבאר דברי המדרש המובא בישמח משה והדקדוקים שבו (לעיל קושיא ב') אמר הקב"ה למשה הים סוער והשונא רודף וכו' וירמוז לדרכינו דמפני שתגבורת התאוה הבא מיסוד המים סוער וגדל, עי"ז השונא רודף והקטרוג גדול מאוד, ומה"ט לא עת להאריך בתפלה כנ"ל, וז"ש לו הים סוער והשונא רודף ואתה עומד ומרבה בתפלה לפני, אמר לו משה ומה עלי לעשות, א"ל ואתה הרם את מטך, ר"ל שיסלק המטה ובדיבורו בלבד יקרע הים כמ"ש לו דבר אל בנ"י ויסעו בבחי' גזור ואני אעשה, ובזמן כזה שכח הקטרוג חזקה צריך זהירות יתירה שלא יטעו ישראל בהנס שיש בו מכוחות הסט"א, וע"כ צוהו לסלק המטה ובדיבורו לבד יפעול להמשיך הנס, וע"כ באותה שעה אמרו ה' ימלוך לעולם ועד, עפימ"ד במדרש ילקוט (רמז רנ"ג) ר' יוסי אומר אלו אמרו ישראל על הים ה' מלך לעולם ועד, לא היתה אומה ולשון שולטת בהן לעולם אלא אמרו ה' ימלוך לעולם ועד לעתיד לבא, ולכאורה באמת טעמא בעי מדוע אמרו כן בלשון עתיד, אמנם לדרכינו אפ"ל שהשיגו ממה שצוה הקב"ה למשה לסלק המטה מחשש שלא יאמרו שנעשה הנס בסיוע כוחות הטומאה ממטות החרטומים שנבלעו בו, ומזה הבינו כי עדיין לא הגיע זמן התגלות כבוד מלכותו ית', דאז לא יעלה על הדעת עוד מחשבת ב' רשויות, ויכירו וידעו כל יושבי תבל כי אין בלתו ואפס זולתו, ומה"ט כאשר שמעו ישראל שצוה ה' למשה הרם את מטך, באותה שעה אמרו ה' ימלוך לעולם ועד בלשון עתיד והבן.
translation: And from now on we will explain the words of the Midrash brought in Yismach Moshe and the nuances within it (above, question 2). The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Moses, "The sea is raging and the enemy is pursuing," etc. This hints to our ways that because of the strength of the desire that comes from the element of water, it is raging and growing; as a result, the enemy is pursuing and the accusation is very great. For this reason, it is not the time to prolong in prayer, as mentioned above. And this is what He said to him: "The sea is raging and the enemy is pursuing, and you are standing and increasing in prayer before Me." Moses said to Him, "What should I do?" He said to him, "And you raise your staff," meaning that he should remove the staff and with his speech alone he would split the sea, as He told him, "Speak to the Children of Israel and let them go," in a manner of decree, "and I will act." And at such a time, the strong accusation is forgotten; one must be especially careful not to let Israel be misled by the miracle that has within it the forces of the Other Side. Therefore, He commanded him to remove the staff and with his speech alone to bring forth the miracle. And for this reason, at that time they said, "The Lord shall reign forever and ever." According to the Midrash Yalkut (Remez 253), Rabbi Yossi says that if Israel had said at the sea, "The Lord reigns forever and ever," no nation or tongue would have ruled over them forever. Rather, they said, "The Lord shall reign forever and ever in the future." And seemingly, there is indeed a reason why they said it in the future tense. However, according to our ways, it can be said that they understood from what the Holy One, Blessed be He, commanded Moses to remove the staff, out of concern that they would say that the miracle was done with the assistance of the forces of impurity from the staffs of the sorcerers that were swallowed up in it. From this, they understood that the time for the revelation of His glorious kingship had not yet arrived, for then the thought of two authorities would no longer enter the mind, and all the inhabitants of the world would recognize and know that there is none besides Him and nothing else. And for this reason, when Israel heard that the Lord commanded Moses to raise his staff, at that time they said, "The Lord shall reign forever and ever" in the future tense, and understand.
summary: The passage discusses the tension between divine intervention and the forces of opposition, represented by the sea and the enemy pursuing the Israelites. It emphasizes the importance of faith and the need for caution in recognizing God's sovereignty, particularly during miraculous events. The command for Moses to raise his staff symbolizes the necessity of relying solely on God's power, without attributing the miracle to external forces. The Israelites' declaration of "The Lord will reign forever and ever" in the future tense reflects their understanding that true recognition of God's kingship will only be fully realized when all doubts about duality are eliminated.

passage_content: ויאמר ה' אל משה מה תצעק אלי וגו', במדרש (הובא בישמח משה) אמר הקב"ה למשה הים סוער והשונא רודף ואתה עומד ומרבה בתפלה, א"ל ומה עלי לעשות, א"ל ואתה הרם את מטך, באותה שעה אמרו ה' ימלוך לעולם ועד, וצ"ב כוונת הקישור, גם כוונת הטענה הים סוער וכו' ואתה מרבה בתפלה ואדרבה הוא הנותנת לצעוק אל ה' בעת צרה.
translation: And the Lord said to Moses, "Why do you cry out to Me?" In the Midrash (brought in Yismach Moshe), it is said that the Holy One, Blessed be He, told Moses, "The sea is raging and the enemy is pursuing, and you stand and increase in prayer." He said to Him, "What should I do?" He said, "And you lift up your staff." At that moment, they said, "The Lord shall reign forever and ever." And it is puzzling what the connection is, as well as the intent of the claim that the sea is raging, etc., and you are increasing in prayer, and on the contrary, it is the very reason to cry out to the Lord in times of trouble.
summary: In the passage, God instructs Moses to stop praying and instead raise his staff to part the sea, highlighting the tension between prayer and action in times of crisis. The reference to the turbulent sea and the pursuing enemy underscores the urgency of the situation, suggesting that while prayer is vital, it must be accompanied by decisive action. This reflects a key Hasidic concept that emphasizes the balance between faith and practical response, illustrating that true reliance on God involves both heartfelt supplication and proactive measures. The declaration "The Lord shall reign forever" serves as a reminder of divine sovereignty amidst chaos.

translation: B) Wonder, the Lord will fight for you, and you shall be silent in singing, and this is a wonder.
summary: The passage emphasizes the miraculous nature of divine intervention, suggesting that God will fight for the people while they remain silent, refraining from singing praises. This silence is portrayed as a profound wonder, highlighting the idea that true faith sometimes requires passive trust in God's actions. The theological insight reflects a deep understanding of the relationship between human agency and divine will, where the faithful are called to recognize and accept the mysteries of God's workings in their lives.

passage_content: ג) תצעק אלי, פירש"י ז"ל עלי הדבר תלוי וכו' וצ"ב דאדרבה לטעם זה צריכים דוקא להתפלל אליו ית' שבו הדבר תלוי
translation: 3) "Cry out to Me," Rashi explains that the matter is dependent on Me, etc. And it is questionable, for on the contrary, for this reason we specifically need to pray to the Blessed One, in whom the matter is dependent.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of calling out to God, as interpreted by Rashi, emphasizing that one's prayers are essential because the matter at hand is dependent on divine intervention. It raises a question about the necessity of prayer, suggesting that if the outcome relies on God, one should specifically pray to Him. This highlights the Hasidic belief in the importance of direct communication with the Divine and the understanding that human effort in prayer is crucial in influencing spiritual realities. Ultimately, it reflects the theological insight that while God is sovereign, human supplication plays a vital role in the unfolding of events.

passage_content: וכל אלה באחת יבוארו בהקדם דברי אא"ז הייטב לב זצוקלה"ה בשם המפורשים לפרש מאמר המשנה הקורא את המגילה למפרע לא יצא, היינו על מה שהי' כבר בימי מרדכי ואסתר לא יצא דצריך להמשיך השפעת הנס גם על להבא ובכל דור ודור צריכין אנו לישועת ה', ואמרו חכז"ל (תדב"א ב') דבכל יום ויום נעשו לישראל נסים כפליים כיוצאי מצרים אלא שאין בעל הנס מכיר בניסו, ולזה צריכין לעורר כח הנסים שעשה הקב"ה לאבותינו ולהמשיכם גם להבא עכת"ד ז"ל, והנה צריך שיהא הנס ע"י אתערותא דלתתא ובהכנת מצות ומע"ט, ואז יש לו כח נצחי להמשיכו גם להבא, אבל אם נמשך הנס רק בהתערותא דלעילא לבד ה"ה הוראת שעה אשר בהכרח הוצרך הקב"ה להושיען אף בלי זכות, עוד איתא בספה"ק דע"י שירה ממשיכים כח הנס גם להבא.
translation: And all these will be explained in advance by the words of our teacher, the esteemed Rabbi Haytev Lev, may his memory be a blessing, in the name of the commentators, to explain the saying of the Mishnah that one who reads the Megillah in reverse has not fulfilled his obligation. This means that regarding what was already in the days of Mordechai and Esther, one has not fulfilled his obligation, for it is necessary to continue the influence of the miracle also for the future, and in every generation we need the salvation of Hashem. And our sages, of blessed memory, said (Tadva B') that every day miracles were done for Israel twice as much as for those who went out of Egypt, but the master of the miracle does not recognize his miracle. Therefore, we need to awaken the power of the miracles that the Holy One, Blessed be He, did for our forefathers and to continue them also for the future, thus far their words. And behold, it is necessary that the miracle should be through an awakening from below and through the preparation of mitzvot and good deeds, and then it has an eternal power to continue it also for the future. But if the miracle is only drawn down through an awakening from above alone, it is a temporary instruction, for which the Holy One, Blessed be He, was necessarily required to save them even without merit. Furthermore, it is written in the holy books that through song we continue the power of the miracle also for the future.
summary: The passage emphasizes the importance of actively continuing the influence of past miracles, particularly those experienced during the times of Mordechai and Esther, to ensure ongoing divine assistance in every generation. It highlights that while God performs miracles daily, they often go unrecognized, necessitating a conscious effort to evoke the power of these miracles through acts of goodness and kindness. The text also notes that true continuation of miracles requires a partnership between divine intervention and human initiative, particularly through prayer and song, which can sustain the miraculous influence into the future.

passage_content: והנה משה רבינו הי' מצפה שיהי' עולם התיקון וגאולה נצחי מיד, וא"כ אין צורך להמשיך בחי' נס זה לדורות, ולז"א כי כאשר ראיתם את מצרים היום לא תוסיפו לראותם עד עולם וגו', ומהאי טעמא ה' ילחם לכם שיבוא הנס בהתעוררות של מעלה. ואתם תחרישון מלומר שירה כי אין צורך להמשיך בחי' הנס הזה לדורות, ועמד בתפלה להמשיך הנס באתערותא דלעילא, א"ל הקב"ה מה תצעק אלי פירש"י עלי הדבר תלוי, וע"ד שאמה"כ (ישעי' מ"ה) ישראל נושע בה' תשועת עולמים, דכמו שהוא ית' נצחי ואין סוף, כך בבחינה זו שולח ישועתו לישראל שיהא תשועת עולמים ונצחי, וז"ש עלי הדבר תלוי וצריך שיהא ישועה נצחי גם לדורות, ואין די בהתערותא דלעילא לבד שאתה מרבה בתפלה, דאם יהי' בלי התעוררות דלתתא אין בו כח להמשיך בחי' הנס לדורות, ע"כ דבר אל בני ישראל ויסעו שיעשו אתערותא דלתתא וכן עשו שנכנסו לתוך הים במסירת נפש ובאו המים עד צווארם ועי"ז נמשך כח הנס גם על להבא.
translation: And behold, Moshe Rabbeinu was expecting that the world of תיקון (Tikkun) and eternal redemption would come immediately, and therefore there was no need to continue this aspect of the miracle for generations. Thus it is said, "For the Egyptians whom you see today, you shall never see them again forever," etc. For this reason, "Hashem will fight for you," meaning that the miracle will come through an awakening from above. And you shall be silent in singing, for there is no need to continue this aspect of the miracle for generations. He stood in prayer to continue the miracle through an awakening from above. The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to him, "Why do you cry out to Me?" Rashi explains that the matter depends on you, and in accordance with what is written (Isaiah 45), "Israel is saved by Hashem with an eternal salvation," for just as He is eternal and infinite, so in this aspect He sends His salvation to Israel to be an eternal and everlasting salvation. This is what is meant by "the matter depends on you," and it is necessary for there to be an eternal salvation also for generations. It is not enough to have an awakening from above alone; you must also increase in prayer, for if there is no awakening from below, it does not have the strength to continue the aspect of the miracle for generations. Therefore, "Speak to the Children of Israel and let them journey," so that they will create an awakening from below. And so they did, entering into the sea with self-sacrifice, and the waters reached their necks, and through this, the power of the miracle was also extended for the future.
summary: Moses anticipated an immediate and eternal redemption, suggesting that the miraculous events should not need to be repeated. The passage emphasizes that divine salvation is eternal and must be accompanied by human effort, as indicated by the need for the Israelites to actively engage in their own redemption. Their willingness to enter the sea with self-sacrifice demonstrates the necessary partnership between divine intervention and human initiative to ensure that miracles continue through generations. Ultimately, true salvation requires both heavenly and earthly awakenings to sustain the ongoing presence of divine miracles.

passage_content: ועד"ז יתבאר דברי המדרש א"ל הקב"ה למשה הים סוער והשונא רודף וכו', ע"ד דאיתא בחובת הלבבות שיש חילוק בין שונא דעלמא להשונא הגדול המשטין, שסתם שונא אם מנצחין אותו פעם או שתים לא יתגבר ללחום יותר, אבל היצר לא ינוח ולא ישקוט אף שכבר נצחוהו פעמים הרבה, וז"ש השונא רודף תמיד בכל עת, ויצטרכו בנ"י ישועה גם להבא ולא די במה שיושעו כעת לפי שעה, ואתה מרבה בתפלה, ר"ל שאתה רוצה לפעול בתפלתך שיבא הישועה בהתעוררות דלעילא לבד, הלא א"כ לא יהי' הישועה רק לפי שעה, א"ל ומה עלי לעשות ואתה הרם את מטך ע"ד שמצינו (במסכת ר"ה דף כ"ט ע"א) כאשר ירים משה את ידו היו ישראל משעבדין את לבם לאביהם שבשמים ועי"ז ימשך בחי' הנס גם להבא, ע"כ אמרו ה' ימלוך לעולם ועד ר"ל כבוד מלכותו ית' יתקדש ע"י הנסים וימשך גם לדורות לעלם ולעלמי עלמיא והבן.
translation: And similarly, the words of the Midrash will be explained: The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Moses, "The sea is raging and the enemy is pursuing," etc. This is in accordance with what is stated in the Duties of the Heart, that there is a distinction between an ordinary enemy and the great enemy, the accuser. An ordinary enemy, if defeated once or twice, will not have the strength to fight again. However, the evil inclination will not rest or be quiet, even though it has been defeated many times. Therefore, it is said that the enemy pursues constantly at all times, and the Children of Israel will need salvation also in the future, and it is not enough that they are saved for the present moment. And you increase in prayer, meaning that you want to bring about in your prayer that the salvation should come through an awakening from above alone; otherwise, the salvation will only be temporary. Moses asked, "What should I do?" And He said, "Lift up your staff," as we find (in Tractate Rosh Hashanah, 29a) that when Moses raised his hand, Israel would subjugate their hearts to their Father in Heaven, and through this, the quality of the miracle would also be drawn for the future. Therefore, it is said, "The Lord shall reign forever and ever," meaning that the glory of His kingship should be sanctified through the miracles and should be drawn also for generations, forever and ever. Understand this.
summary: The passage discusses the ongoing struggle between the Jewish people and their adversaries, likening the relentless pursuit of the enemy to the persistent nature of the evil inclination (yetzer hara). It emphasizes that unlike a typical enemy who may retreat after defeat, the yetzer hara continuously seeks to challenge individuals. The text highlights the importance of prayer and spiritual elevation, suggesting that true salvation requires not just immediate relief but a sustained connection to divine assistance. Ultimately, it conveys that God's sovereignty and the miracles He performs should be recognized and celebrated across generations, ensuring ongoing divine support.

passage_content: באופן אחר אפ"ל דברי המדרשים הנ"ל דהנה הקשו בספה"ק מהו ענין גודל הנס של קרי"ס שכאשר הפליגו חכז"ל להגזים איזה דבר דימו אותו לנס קריעת ים סוף כאמרם (פסחים דף קי"ח ע"א) קשה מזונותיו של אדם כקריעת ים סוף וכדומה, ולגבי הבוי"ת אין דבר קשה לעשות נסים, רק בעיני האדם שהוא רגיל להטבע הוי הנס חידוש גדול, אבל הקב"ה כמו שברא את הטבע כך הוא עושה נסים ואין רבותא בדבר מה שמשדד מערכות השמים, והבינה לעתים הסביר הענין שבקריעת ים סוף הי' צריך להיות שני הפכים בנושא אחד, דהנה לישראל הי' צורך בהמשכת מדת הרחמים דבלא זה לא היו יכולין להנצל כי גם הם היו נתונים בדין, וכפרש"י עה"פ ויסע מלאך האלקים וגו', בכל מקום הוא אומר מלאך ה' וכאן מלאך האלקים, אין אלקים בכ"מ אלא דין, מלמד שהיו ישראל נתונים בדין באותה שעה אם להנצל אם להאבד עם מצרים, וכן איתא במדרש (ילקוט ראובני) שטען עוזא שר של מצרים מה בין אלו לאלו הללו עע"ז והללו וכו', ע"כ הוצרך הקב"ה להתנהג עמהם במדת הרחמים, ולעומת זאת להמצריים דן אותם במדה"ד לאבדם לגמרי, וזה הי' ענין הגדול של נם קריעת ים סוף, מה ששמשו שתי המדות בשעה וברגע אחת ממש, שני הפכים בנושא אחד שאין זה במציאות לשום נברא בעולם לעשות רק הבורא כל העולמים שהוא כל יכול ובזה הי' הנס של קרי"ס גדול יותר מנס יציאת מצרים, דשם לא הי' צורך להשתמש ברגע אחת בשתי המדות גם יחד, ורק בקרי"ס הי' צורך במדת הרחמים לישראל ובמדת דין הקשה נגד מצרים.
translation: In another way, one can say the words of the aforementioned Midrashim: behold, the holy books have questioned what is the significance of the greatness of the miracle of the splitting of the sea, for when our sages exaggerated something, they likened it to the miracle of the splitting of the sea, as they said (Pesachim 118a) that a person's sustenance is as difficult as the splitting of the sea, and so on. And regarding the creation, there is nothing difficult for God to perform miracles; only in the eyes of man, who is accustomed to nature, is the miracle a great novelty. But the Holy One, blessed be He, just as He created nature, so He performs miracles, and there is no wonder in the matter of overturning the systems of heaven. The understanding at times explains the matter that in the splitting of the sea, there had to be two opposites in one subject. Behold, for Israel, there was a need for the continuation of the attribute of mercy, for without this they would not have been able to be saved, as they too were subject to judgment. And as Rashi explains on the verse, "And the angel of God traveled," everywhere it says the angel of the Lord, and here it says the angel of God; there is no God anywhere except for judgment, teaching that Israel was under judgment at that moment, whether to be saved or to perish with Egypt. And it is also stated in the Midrash (Yalkut Reuveni) that Uzzah, the minister of Egypt, argued, "What is the difference between these and those? These worship idols and those..." Therefore, the Holy One, blessed be He, needed to conduct Himself with them in the attribute of mercy, and in contrast, He judged the Egyptians with strict judgment to completely destroy them. And this was the great matter of the miracle of the splitting of the sea, that both attributes served at the same time and in the very same moment, two opposites in one subject, which is not in the reality of any created being in the world to do, only the Creator of all worlds, who is all-powerful. And in this, the miracle of the splitting of the sea was greater than the miracle of the Exodus from Egypt, for there was no need to use both attributes simultaneously in one moment, and only in the splitting of the sea was there a need for the attribute of mercy for Israel and the attribute of strict judgment against Egypt.
summary: The passage discusses the profound nature of the miracle of the splitting of the Red Sea, emphasizing that it required the simultaneous operation of two opposing divine attributes: mercy for the Israelites and strict judgment for the Egyptians. This duality highlights God's omnipotence, as only He can manifest such contrasting qualities at once. The text suggests that while miracles may seem extraordinary to humans, they are part of God's natural order, who created both nature and miracles. Ultimately, the splitting of the sea represents a greater miracle than the Exodus itself, as it involved the intricate balance of divine attributes in a single moment.

passage_content: ובספה"ק עבודת ישראל (להרה"ק מקאזניץ זלה"ה) במאמריו לר"ה כתב וזל"ק כי ח"ו אם גם ישראל אינם ראויים במעשיהם, וצריך הקב"ה לעשות עמהם צדקה במתנת חנם, אז יוכל להיות שיתאחזו החיצונים בהשפעה זו ובוודאי אין נחת רוח מזה להקב"ה, רק אם ישראל מוציאין המשפט לאורה בדין ומשפט, אז הקב"ה יכול לעשות עמהם צדקה וחסד ואין שטן ואין פגע רע לקטרג או לקבל ההשפעה, כי לעושי רצונו לבדו באה נחלתן בדין ומשפט עכל"ק, והנה אז בשעת קי"ס ודאי שלא זכו ישראל מצד מעשיהם הטובים שיומשך עליהם מדה"ר, דהרי הי' עליהם קטרוג משרו של מצרים הללו עע"ז והללו וכו' וא"כ אם יתעורר להם מדת החסד יש חשש שגם המצריים יהנו מתגבורת הרחמים, והנה איתא בגמרא (יבמות ס"ד ע"א) א"ר יצחק למה נמשלה תפלתן של צדיקים כעתר מה עתר זה מהפך התבואה ממקום למקום כך תפלתן של צדיקים מהפכת מדותיו של הקב"ה ממדת רגזנות למדת רחמנות.
translation: In the holy book "Avodat Yisrael" (by the holy Rabbi from Kazinitz, may his memory be blessed), in his discourses for Rosh Hashanah, he wrote as follows: If, heaven forbid, the Jewish people are not worthy in their deeds, and the Holy One, blessed be He, needs to do kindness with them as a gift of grace, then it is possible that the external forces may latch onto this influence, and certainly, this does not bring satisfaction to the Holy One, blessed be He. Rather, if the Jewish people bring forth the judgment to light through law and justice, then the Holy One, blessed be He, can do kindness and mercy with them, and there is no accuser and no evil force to argue or receive the influence, for to those who do His will alone comes their inheritance through law and justice, as explained. And behold, at the time of the gathering of souls, certainly the Jewish people did not merit, due to their good deeds, that the measure of mercy should be drawn upon them, for they had an accusation from the minister of Egypt and others, etc. Therefore, if the measure of kindness is aroused for them, there is a concern that even the Egyptians may benefit from the increase of mercy. And it is stated in the Gemara (Yevamot 64a): Rabbi Yitzchak said, "Why are the prayers of the righteous compared to a crown? Just as a crown moves the grain from one place to another, so too, the prayers of the righteous transform the attributes of the Holy One, blessed be He, from the attribute of anger to the attribute of mercy."
summary: In the teachings of the Hasidic master from Kaznitz, it is emphasized that if the Jewish people are unworthy in their actions, God's kindness may inadvertently empower negative forces, which is not pleasing to Him. True divine mercy can only be granted when Israel upholds justice and righteousness, allowing for a pure channel of blessings without opposition from adversarial forces. The passage also highlights that during critical moments, such as the giving of the Torah, the Jewish people did not merit divine favor solely based on their deeds, as they faced accusations from their oppressors. Ultimately, the prayers of the righteous can transform God's attributes from anger to mercy, illustrating the profound impact of sincere supplication.

passage_content: ובזה יובן דברי המדרש אמר הקב"ה למשה הים סוער, וא"כ ישראל נתונים בצרה גדולה וצריכים למדת הרחמים, אבל השונא רודף ועליהם צריך לעורר מדת הדין הקשה, ואתה עומד ומרבה בתפלה, ותפלתך יש לה כח סגולה להפך מדה"ד לרחמים גמורים, וכיון שאין ישראל זוכין מצד מעשיהם יוכלו גם המצריים להנות ממדה"ר, א"ל ומה עלי לעשות א"ל ואתה הרם את מטך אתה מרומם ומפאר ומשבח וכו' למי שהמלוכה שלו, פי' תמסור דבר זה בידו של הקב"ה שהוא ית' יכול לעשות שני הפכים בנושא אחד, אבל אם אתה תרבה בתפלה יש חשש שתהפוך לגמרי מדה"ד לרחמים ולא ישאר מדה"ד כלל בעולם, ועכשיו יש צורך גדול במדת הדין על המצריים וז"ש רש"י ז"ל מה תצעק אלי, עלי הדבר תלוי ולא בך, פי' ענין זה א"א לשום נברא בעולם לעשותו רק אני בעצמי בידי לעשות שני הפכים בנושא אחד, וע"כ אין הזמן מוכשר עתה להרבות בתפלה.
translation: And with this, the words of the Midrash will be understood: The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Moses, "The sea is raging, and therefore Israel is in great distress and needs the attribute of mercy. But the enemy is pursuing them, and upon them, it is necessary to awaken the attribute of strict judgment. And you stand and increase in prayer, and your prayer has the power to transform strict judgment into complete mercy. Since Israel is not deserving due to their actions, the Egyptians could also benefit from the attribute of mercy." He said to him, "What should I do?" He said, "And you lift your staff; you elevate, glorify, and praise, etc., to the One whose kingship it is." This means to entrust this matter to the Holy One, Blessed be He, who can perform two opposites in one subject. However, if you increase in prayer, there is a concern that you will completely transform strict judgment into mercy, and there will be no strict judgment left in the world at all. And now there is a great need for the attribute of strict judgment against the Egyptians. Therefore, Rashi, of blessed memory, said, "Why do you cry out to Me? The matter depends on Me, not on you." This means that this matter cannot be done by any created being in the world; only I Myself have the ability to perform two opposites in one subject. Therefore, the time is not suitable now to increase in prayer.
summary: The passage discusses the tension between divine mercy and judgment during a time of crisis for the Israelites, as they face the pursuing Egyptians. It emphasizes the power of prayer to transform divine judgment into mercy, but also warns that excessive prayer could negate the necessary judgment against the oppressors. The text highlights that only God has the authority to enact both mercy and judgment simultaneously, indicating that the current situation requires a balance that cannot be achieved through human intervention alone. Ultimately, it underscores the importance of recognizing God's sovereignty in managing these divine attributes.

passage_content: ועד"ז יתבאר אידך דברי המדרש הנ"ל, אמר הקב"ה למשה הים סוער והשונא רודף ואתה עומד ומרבה בתפלה, א"ל ומה עלי לעשות, א"ל ואתה הרם את מטך, באותה שעה אמרו ה' ימלוך לעולם ועד, עפ"י מה שאמרז"ל (ר"ה כ"ט ע"א) והי' כאשר ירים משה ידו וגבר ישראל וגו' וכי ידיו של משה עושות מלחמה או שוברות מלחמה, אלא לומר לך כל זמן שהיו ישראל מסתכלין כלפי מעלה ומשעבדין את לבם לאביהם שבשמים היו מתגברים וכו', ועד"ז ירמוז כאן ואתה הרם את מטך לשעבד את לבם לשמים, ועי"ז אתעורר עליהם במדת הרחמים, ונטה את ידך להמשיך בחי' יד החזקה ולעורר דין על המצריים, משא"כ אם תרבה בתפלה יתבטל הדין לגמרי דתפלתן של צדיקים מהפכת מדת הדין למדה"ר כנ"ל, וע"כ באותה שעה אמרו ה' ימלוך לעולם ועד, עפימ"ש רז"ל (בב"ר פ' י"ב סי' ט"ו) בתחלה עלה במחשבה לברוא את העולם במדת הדין וראה שאין העולם מתקיים, הקדים מדת הרחמים ושתפה למדה"ד, והקשו המפורשים דכיון שלא נתקיים הבריאה במה"ד בלבד, מ"ט כתבה תורה בראשית ברא אלקים שהוא מדה"ד, ותירצו שיש צורך גם במדה"ד ונתקיים מידה זו לעכו"ם, אבל לישראל מתנהג הקב"ה במדת הרחמים, אמנם לעתיד שיתבערו הרשעים מן העולם לא יהי' צורך במדה"ד, וע"כ באותה שעה אמרו ה' ימלוך לעולם ועד, בלשון עתיד, היינו בחי' שם הוי' שהוא רחמים גמורים בו יהי' הנהגת העולם לעתיד.
translation: And similarly, the other words of the aforementioned Midrash will be clarified. The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Moses, "The sea is raging and the enemy is pursuing, and you are standing and increasing in prayer." He said to Him, "What should I do?" He said, "And you lift up your staff." At that moment, they said, "The Lord shall reign forever and ever," according to what our Sages of blessed memory said (Rosh Hashanah 29a), "And it was when Moses lifted his hand, Israel prevailed, etc." And do Moses' hands make war or break war? Rather, it teaches you that as long as Israel looked upward and subjugated their hearts to their Father in Heaven, they were strengthened, etc. And similarly, it hints here, "And you lift up your staff" to subjugate their hearts to Heaven, and through this, I will be aroused upon them with the attribute of mercy, and stretch out your hand to draw down the aspect of the strong hand and to awaken judgment upon the Egyptians. In contrast, if you increase in prayer, the judgment will be completely nullified, for the prayers of the righteous transform the attribute of judgment into the attribute of mercy, as mentioned above. Therefore, at that moment, they said, "The Lord shall reign forever and ever," as it is stated by our Sages of blessed memory (Bereishit Rabbah, chapter 12, section 15) that initially it was in His thought to create the world with the attribute of judgment, and He saw that the world could not endure, so He preceded the attribute of mercy and combined it with the attribute of judgment. And the commentators questioned that since creation did not endure with the attribute of judgment alone, why did the Torah write "In the beginning, God created" which is the attribute of judgment? They answered that there is a need for the attribute of judgment, and this attribute was established for the idolaters, but for Israel, the Holy One, Blessed be He, conducts Himself with the attribute of mercy. However, in the future, when the wicked will be removed from the world, there will be no need for the attribute of judgment. Therefore, at that moment, they said, "The Lord shall reign forever and ever," in the future tense, meaning in the aspect of the Name Havayah, which is complete mercy, in which the governance of the world will be in the future.
summary: The passage discusses the interaction between Moses and God during the Israelites' struggle against the Egyptians, emphasizing the importance of prayer and the elevation of the heart towards God. It highlights that when the Israelites focus on their connection to the Divine, they gain strength, and Moses' act of raising his staff symbolizes this spiritual elevation. The text also reflects on the balance between divine justice and mercy, noting that while the world was initially created with strict judgment, God's mercy ultimately prevails for Israel, especially in the future when evil will be eradicated. The phrase "The Lord shall reign forever and ever" signifies a future state of complete divine mercy in the world.

passage_content: גם יתבאר דברי המדרש עפי"ד האוה"ח הק' עה"פ ה' ימלוך לעולם ועד כי בא סוס פרעה וגו' (עיי"ש), היוצא מדבה"ק כי ממה שנאבדו המצריים השיגו ישראל שעדיין לא הגיע הזמן של עולם התיקון ורק לעתיד יהי' שלימות הגמור, וזהו פי' המדרש שא"ל הקב"ה ואתה הרם את מטך ונמשך מזה אבדונם של המצריים, באותה שעה אמרו ה' ימלוך לעולם ועד ולא ה' מלך, השי"ת יעזור שיתעוררו הנסים ההם בזמן הזה וכימי צאתנו ממצרים יראנו נפלאות ונזכה במהרה לישועת כל ישראל ושמחתן בהתרוממות קרן התורה וישראל ובהתגלות כבוד שמים עלינו במהרה בימינו אמן. אל
translation: The words of the Midrash will also be explained according to the holy Ohr HaChaim on the verse "The Lord will reign forever and ever" because the horse of Pharaoh came, etc. (see there), which emerges from the holy teachings that from the destruction of the Egyptians, Israel attained that the time of the world of rectification had not yet arrived, and only in the future will there be complete perfection. This is the explanation of the Midrash that the Holy One, Blessed be He, said to him, "And you raise your staff," and from this was drawn the destruction of the Egyptians. At that moment, they said, "The Lord will reign forever and ever," and not "The Lord has reigned." May the Holy One, Blessed be He, help that those miracles be awakened in this time, and as in the days of our exodus from Egypt, may we see wonders and merit quickly to the salvation of all Israel and their joy in the uplifting of the horn of the Torah and Israel, and in the revelation of the glory of Heaven upon us speedily in our days, Amen.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the Israelites' victory over the Egyptians, emphasizing that their defeat was a precursor to the ultimate redemption and the future perfection of the world. It highlights the idea that while God's kingship was not fully realized at that moment, the proclamation "The Lord reigns forever and ever" reflects a deeper understanding of divine sovereignty. The text expresses a yearning for the miraculous events of the Exodus to be replicated in the present, leading to the redemption of all Israel and the revelation of divine glory. Ultimately, it conveys hope for a future where the full realization of God's kingdom will be evident.

summary: In this passage, God instructs Moses not to cry out to Him but to speak to the Israelites and command them to move forward. Rashi interprets this as indicating that the responsibility for the situation lies with God, not Moses, suggesting a divine orchestration of events. This highlights the Hasidic concept of faith in God's control over circumstances and the importance of taking action in alignment with divine will. The emphasis is on the relationship between human initiative and divine providence, illustrating a profound theological insight into the dynamics of faith and action.

passage_content: ב) משה את ידו על הים וישב הים לפנות בוקר לאיתנו וגו', במדרש ילקוט (רמז רל"ו) א"ר יונתן התנה הקב"ה תנאים עם הים שיהא נקרע לפני ישראל, הה"ד וישב הים לפנות בוקר לאיתנו לתנאו שהתנה הקב"ה עמו וכו', והקשו המפרשים דרמז זה הול"ל לעיל עה"פ ויבקעו המים שהרי התנאי הי' על הבקיעה, ומה שחזר לאיתנו אח"כ דרך הטבע כן הוא להיות הים הולך כדרכו וא"צ לתנאי.
translation: Moses raised his hand over the sea, and the sea returned to its strength at dawn, etc. In the Midrash Yalkut (Remez 236), Rabbi Yonatan said that the Holy One, blessed be He, made conditions with the sea that it should split before Israel. This is as it is written, "and the sea returned to its strength at dawn," according to the condition that the Holy One, blessed be He, made with it, etc. The commentators questioned why this hint was not stated earlier regarding the verse "and the waters were split," since the condition was about the splitting, and the fact that it returned to its strength afterward is a natural occurrence, as the sea would go on its way and does not require a condition.
summary: The passage discusses the miraculous splitting of the sea during the Exodus, highlighting that God made a condition with the sea to part before the Israelites. It emphasizes the divine intervention in nature, as the sea returned to its natural state afterward. The text raises a question about why the condition was necessary if the sea would naturally revert to its original form, suggesting a deeper theological insight into the relationship between divine will and the natural order. This reflects key Hasidic concepts of faith, divine providence, and the interplay between the miraculous and the mundane.

passage_content: ג) בגמרא (ערכין ט"ו ע"א) א"ר הונא ישראל שבאותו הדור מקטני אמנה היו וכו' שהיו ישראל ממרים באותה שעה ואומרים כשם שאנו עולים מצד זה כך מצרים עולים מצד אחר, א"ל הקב"ה לשר של ים פלוט אותם ליבשה וכו' וכתבו התוס' וז"ל יש לתמוה איך היו ישראל באותו הדור כ"כ מקטני אמנה, שסברו שכך עשה הקב"ה נסים למצרים להעבירם מארצם לארץ ישראל, ותירצו שישראל לא עברו הים לרחבו מצד זה לזה, אלא רצועה אחת עברו בים לאורך הים עד שפנו למדבר מצד אחד וכו' וז"ש כשם שאנו עולין מצד זה ובאנו למדבר, כך מצרים עולין מצד אחר מן המדבר וירדפו אחרינו וכו', כי סבורים היו שלא יעברו המצריים בים אלא יבואו מצד אחר וכו' עכ"ד התוס' ולכאורה קושית התוס' עדיין במקומה עומדת דאיך היו ישראל קטני אמנה לחשוב ככה שהקב"ה עשה להם נס למגנא לקרוע הים לפניהם ואם ירדפו אחריהם המצריים מצד אחר וישיגום א"כ מה תועלת הנס, גם קשה על המצריים מדוע לא עשו כן, להמתין ביבשה עד שיעלו ישראל מן הים באותו צד עצמו שירדו, כיון שלא עברו את הים מעבר לעבר, ולמה רדפו אחריהם לתוך הים, הן אמת דקושיא זו אפשר לתרץ דבשעה שירדו ישראל לתוך הים לא ידעו המצריים עדיין שיעלו באותו צד עצמו, וחשבו שיעלו בצד השני שמעבר לים ע"כ רדפו אחריהם לתוך הים. אמנם צריך להבין סברת המצריים איך הכניסו עצמם לסכנה זו לירד לתוך הים הלא ידעו שלא יעמוד הים כך לעולם, ועתיד לחזור למהלכו הראשון, ואיך לא חששו לנפשם לעשות כדבר הזה, וכעי"ז הקשה האוהחה"ק (בפ' בא) בפסוק עד מתי יהיה זה לנו למוקש וגו' הטרם תדע כי אבדה מצרים, האם יש שוטה גמור בעולם שיסבול כל הרעות והצרות ההמה ויכניס עצמו לסכנת נפשות, ומן הסתם לא יאומן כי כ"כ טפש הי', והגם כי הקשה ה' את רוחו עכ"ז צריך שתהי' לו איזה סברא שבה יתלה טפשותו, ועיי"ש מה שנדחק ליישב סברתו, וכמו"כ כאן צריכין אנו ליישב במה הסכימה דעתם להכניס למקום סכנה כזה לירד לתוך הים אחר שידעו בבירור שלא יעמוד הים כך לעולם, ואין לך שוטה גדול מזה.
translation: 3) In the Gemara (Erchin 15a), Rabbi Huna said: The Israelites of that generation were of little faith, etc., for they were rebellious at that time and said, "Just as we ascend from this side, so the Egyptians ascend from another side." The Holy One, blessed be He, said to the minister of the sea, "Cast them to dry land," etc. The Tosafot wrote, and I quote: It is puzzling how the Israelites of that generation were so lacking in faith, thinking that the Holy One, blessed be He, performed miracles for the Egyptians to transfer them from their land to the land of Israel. They answered that the Israelites did not cross the sea from one side to the other, but rather crossed a strip in the sea along the length of the sea until they turned toward the desert from one side, etc. Therefore, they said, "Just as we ascend from this side and came to the desert, so the Egyptians ascend from another side from the desert and will pursue us," etc., for they thought that the Egyptians would not cross the sea but would come from another side, etc. Thus far the Tosafot. And seemingly, the question of the Tosafot still stands: How could the Israelites be so lacking in faith to think that the Holy One, blessed be He, performed a miracle for them to split the sea before them, and if the Egyptians pursue them from another side and catch up to them, what benefit is there in the miracle? It is also difficult to understand why the Egyptians did not do so, to wait on dry land until the Israelites came up from the sea on the same side they descended, since they did not cross the sea from one side to the other. Why did they pursue them into the sea? It is true that this question can be answered: At the time the Israelites entered the sea, the Egyptians did not yet know that they would ascend on the same side, and they thought they would ascend on the other side across the sea; therefore, they pursued them into the sea. However, one must understand the reasoning of the Egyptians: How did they put themselves in such danger to enter the sea, knowing that the sea would not stand like this forever and would return to its original course? How did they not fear for their lives to do such a thing? Similarly, the holy author of the Torah (in Parashat Bo) asked regarding the verse, "How long will this be a snare for us?" etc. "Do you not yet know that the Egyptians are lost?" Is there a complete fool in the world who would endure all those evils and troubles and put himself in danger? It is certainly unbelievable that they were so foolish. And even though the Holy One, blessed be He, hardened their hearts, nevertheless, they must have had some reasoning to justify their foolishness. And so here, we need to understand what reasoning led them to enter such a dangerous place to go into the sea after they knew for certain that the sea would not stand like this forever. There is no greater fool than this.
summary: The passage discusses the lack of faith among the Israelites during the Exodus, as they believed that the Egyptians could pursue them through the sea after they crossed. It raises questions about the Egyptians' decision to enter the sea, despite knowing it would not remain parted indefinitely. The text highlights the theological concept of divine intervention and the necessity of faith, suggesting that both the Israelites and Egyptians exhibited a profound misunderstanding of God's power and the nature of the miraculous events occurring around them. Ultimately, it emphasizes the importance of trust in God's protection and the folly of underestimating His capabilities.

passage_content: ד) ילקוט איתא (ישעי' ס"ג רמז תק"ז) אני מדבר בצדקה זה שאמר הכתוב בעת ההוא יעמוד מיכאל, לעתיד לבוא באים שרים ומקטרגים על ישראל, ואומרים לפני הקב"ה רבש"ע וכי יש לפניך משוא פנים, אם אלו עובדי ע"ז אף אלו ע"ז, אם אלו מגלי עריות אף אלו וכו', מפני מה הללו יורדין לגיהנם והללו אין יורדים, באותה שעה מיכאל סניגורן של ישראל משתתק וכו', וכיון שהוא משתתק אומר הקב"ה מיכאל נשתתקת ואין אתה מלמד סנגוריא על בני, חייך שאני מלמד ומדבר עליהם בצדקה ומושיען, שנאמר אני מדבר בצדקה רב להושיע, ובאיזו צדקה וכו', בצדקה שעשיתם עמי שקבלתם את התורה שאלמלא כן היכן היתה מלכותי וכו' ע"כ, ובס' תפלה למשה לק"ז ישמח משה זלה"ה דקדק דמדוע יאמרו אומה"ע דבריהם בלשון ספק אם אלו עובדי ע"ז אף אלו וכו' הלא זה ברור שהאומות עובדי ע"ז הם ותו קשה אם יודעים שגם ישראל עבדו ע"ז למה הוצרכו לתלות טענת הקטרוג באוה"ע לומר אם אלו עובדי ע"ז אף אלו עובדי ע"ז, גם בלא זה היו יכולין לקטרג על ישראל שהם עובדי ע"ז.
translation: D) The Yalkut states (Isaiah 63, hint 697) "I speak in righteousness," as it is written, "At that time Michael will stand up." In the future, ministers come and accuse Israel, saying before the Holy One, Blessed be He, "Master of the Universe, is there favoritism before You? If these are idol worshippers, then these are also idol worshippers; if these are immoral, then these are also..." Why do these descend to Gehinnom while those do not? At that moment, Michael, the advocate for Israel, becomes silent, etc. When he becomes silent, the Holy One, Blessed be He, says, "Michael, you have become silent and you do not advocate for My children; by your life, I will advocate and speak for them in righteousness and save them," as it is said, "I speak in righteousness, abundant to save." And in what righteousness, etc.? In the righteousness that you have done with Me, that you accepted the Torah, for if not, where would My kingdom be, etc. Thus, in the book "Tefillah L'Moshe" (K 137), Moshe, may his memory be blessed, is precise in asking why the nations of the world would express their words in a language of doubt, saying, "If these are idol worshippers, then these..." Is it not clear that the nations are idol worshippers? Furthermore, if they know that Israel also worshipped idols, why did they need to base their accusation on the nations, saying, "If these are idol worshippers, then these are also idol worshippers"? Even without this, they could have accused Israel of being idol worshippers.
summary: The passage discusses a future scenario where the archangel Michael defends the Jewish people against accusations from other nations, who question why Israel is spared from punishment despite their sins. God responds by affirming His commitment to Israel, highlighting their acceptance of the Torah as a significant act of righteousness that merits salvation. The text emphasizes the unique relationship between God and Israel, suggesting that their covenant and adherence to the Torah serve as a basis for divine mercy, even in the face of wrongdoing. This reflects key Hasidic themes of redemption, the power of repentance, and the enduring bond between God and His chosen people.
