passage_content: ונל"פ עפימ"ש בספה"ק בני יששכר בדרושים לשבועות (מאמר ב' סימן ה') בשם ספר לימודי ה' כמה טעמים על מה שאמרו רז"ל דאין תשובה מועלת רק לישראל ולא לאוה"ע, וא' מהטעמים דתנאי התנה הקב"ה במעשה בראשית אם לא יקבלו ישראל את התורה יחזור העולם לתוהו ובוהו. והנה ישראל ע"י שקבלו את התורה קיימו את העולם והרי הם כביכול כשותפין במלכותו, ע"כ לא שייך בישראל הדין מלך שמחל על כבודו אין כבודו מחול, משא"כ אוה"ע לא מהני בהו תשובה מטעם מלך שמחל על כבודו אין כבודו מחול עכת"ד ז"ל, ובזה יובן דברי המדרש הנ"ל בטוב טעם דמבואר בדרז"ל (ע"ז ג' ע"ב) דגם אוה"ע יעשו תשובה לעתיד לבוא וכולם יהיו גרים גרורים ויבואו אל מלך המשיח לשמוע תורה מפיו כמ"ש בב"ר (פצ"ח) עה"פ (ישעי' י"א) אליו גוים ידרושו עיי"ש, אלא שלא יתקבל תשובתם מדין מלך שמחל על כבודו אין כבודו מחול, ולזה יבואו שרי האומות בטענה לפני הקב"ה אם אלו עובדי ע"ז היינו שנחשבו לעובדי ע"ז אף שעשו תשובה מטעם מלך שמחל על כבודו אין כבודו מחול א"כ אף אלו עובדי ע"ז, וגם לגבי ישראל לא יועיל התשובה להיות נחשבין כעובדי ע"ז, וישיב להם הקב"ה אני מדבר בצדקה רב להושיע, בצדקה שעשיתם עמי שקבלתם את התורה וכו', דבאמצעות התורה נעשו ישראל שותפים להקב"ה במלכותו, ולא שייך לגבייהו הדין דמלך שמחל על כבודו אין כבודו מחול ולכן מהני להו תשובה, משא"כ אוה"ע לא מהני להו תשובה מטעם מלך שמחל על כבודו אין כבודו מחול.
translation: And it is explained in the holy book "Bnei Yissachar" in the discourses for Shavuot (Article 2, Section 5) in the name of the book "Limudei Hashem" several reasons for what our sages said that repentance is only effective for Israel and not for the nations of the world. One of the reasons is that the Holy One, blessed be He, conditioned in the act of creation that if Israel does not accept the Torah, the world will return to chaos and void. And behold, Israel, by accepting the Torah, upheld the world, and they are as if partners in His kingship. Therefore, the law does not apply to Israel that a king who forgives his honor, his honor is not forgiven. In contrast, for the nations of the world, repentance is not effective for them due to the reason that a king who forgives his honor, his honor is not forgiven, as stated by our sages. And with this, the words of the aforementioned Midrash are understood well, as it is explained in our sages (Avodah Zarah 3b) that also the nations of the world will repent in the future and all will become proselytes and will come to the Messiah to hear the Torah from his mouth, as it is said in Bereshit Rabbah (Perek 38) on the verse (Isaiah 11) "to him shall the nations seek," as stated there. However, their repentance will not be accepted due to the law that a king who forgives his honor, his honor is not forgiven. And for this reason, the princes of the nations will come with a claim before the Holy One, blessed be He, saying: If these idol worshippers are considered idol worshippers even though they repented, due to the reason that a king who forgives his honor, his honor is not forgiven, then these too are idol worshippers. And regarding Israel, repentance will not help them to be considered as idol worshippers. The Holy One, blessed be He, will respond to them: I speak of great righteousness to save, for the righteousness you have done with Me by accepting the Torah, etc., for through the Torah, Israel became partners with the Holy One, blessed be He, in His kingship, and the law of a king who forgives his honor does not apply to them, and therefore repentance is effective for them. In contrast, for the nations of the world, repentance is not effective for them due to the reason that a king who forgives his honor, his honor is not forgiven.
summary: The passage discusses the unique relationship between the Jewish people and God, emphasizing that their acceptance of the Torah grants them a partnership in God's sovereignty, which allows for their repentance to be effective. In contrast, the nations of the world, despite their future repentance, will not have their atonement accepted due to the principle that a king's honor cannot be compromised. This distinction highlights the theological concept that Israel's covenant with God through the Torah elevates their status, making their repentance valid, while the nations remain outside this covenantal framework. Ultimately, God's response to the nations will affirm the special status of Israel as partners in His kingdom.

passage_content: והנה גם אצל הים הי' קטרוג כזה על ישראל, שטען שר של מצרים מה בין אלו לאלו הללו עוע"ז והללו עוע"ז כמבואר בדברי חכז"ל, והגם שישראל עשו תשובה לפני יציאתם ממצרים, עדיין הי' מקום למקטרג לטעון דלא יועיל להם תשובה, דתינח אחר מ"ת שנעשו שותפין במלכותו ית' כנ"ל, ע"כ מועיל להם התשובה, אבל בשעת קרי"ס לפני מ"ת עדיין שייך אצלם הדין דמלך שמחל על כבודו אין כבודו מחול, א"כ טען המקטרג לכאורה טענה חזקה מה בין אלו לאלו, אך נראה לבאר דהנה הראשונים ז"ל הקשו על מה שאמרז"ל (ב"ר פרשה ה' סימן ה') תנאי התנה הקב"ה עם הים במעשה בראשית שיקרע לפני ישראל, מה צורך לתנאי, ואף לולא תנאי יכול הקב"ה לעשות כרצונו ולשנות חוקי הבריאה, ובש"ך על התורה תירץ דהוצרך הקב"ה לתנאי נגד המקטריגים שקטרגו מה בין אלו לאלו, אך כיון שהי' תנאי מתחלת הבריאה שיקרע לישראל נתבטל קטרוגם, דהתנאי לא הי' רק לישראל ולא למצריים, נמצא לפי"ד דבשעה שנקרע הים לישראל לא הי' צורך עוד לגלות התנאי שהבוי"ת כל יכול ויכולת בידו לקרוע הים גם בלא תנאי, אך כשחזר הים לכסות את המצריים שאז נעשה קטרוג גדול מה בין אלו לאלו הללו עוע"ז והללו עוע"ז אז הי' צורך לגלות התנאי נגד המקטריגים כמ"ש הש"ך דבזה נתבטל קטרוגם, ולפי"ז א"ש מה שנכתב תיבת לאיתנו אצל וישב הים לפנות בוקר, דרק עכשיו הי' צורך לתנאי זה נגד הקטרוג מה בין אלו לאלו, משא"כ בשעה שנקרע לישראל לא הי' צורך בתנאי.
translation: And behold, also at the sea there was such a prosecution against Israel, as the minister of Egypt claimed, "What is the difference between these and those, these are idol worshippers and those are idol worshippers," as explained in the words of our Sages. And although Israel repented before their departure from Egypt, there was still room for the accuser to argue that repentance would not help them, for it can be understood that after the giving of the Torah, when they became partners in His kingship, as mentioned above, therefore repentance is beneficial for them. However, at the time of the splitting of the sea, before the giving of the Torah, the law still applied to them that a king who forgives his honor, his honor is not forgiven. Thus, the accuser seemingly had a strong argument, "What is the difference between these and those?" However, it seems necessary to explain that the early Sages questioned what our Sages said (Bereishit Rabbah, Parashah 5, Siman 5) that the Holy One, blessed be He, made a condition with the sea at the time of creation that it should split before Israel. What need is there for a condition? Even without a condition, the Holy One, blessed be He, could do as He wishes and change the laws of creation. And the Shach on the Torah answered that the Holy One, blessed be He, needed a condition against the accusers who claimed, "What is the difference between these and those?" But since there was a condition from the beginning of creation that it should split for Israel, their prosecution was nullified, for the condition was only for Israel and not for the Egyptians. Therefore, according to this, at the time the sea split for Israel, there was no longer a need to reveal the condition, for the Blessed One is all-powerful and has the ability to split the sea even without a condition. However, when the sea returned to cover the Egyptians, then a great prosecution arose, "What is the difference between these and those, these are idol worshippers and those are idol worshippers?" Then there was a need to reveal the condition against the accusers, as the Shach said, for this nullified their prosecution. And according to this, it is clear why the word "for them" is written next to "and the sea returned at dawn," for only now was there a need for this condition against the prosecution of "What is the difference between these and those," whereas at the time it split for Israel, there was no need for a condition.
summary: The passage discusses the accusations against the Israelites at the Red Sea, where the angel of Egypt questioned the distinction between the Israelites and the Egyptians, both of whom worshipped idols. Despite the Israelites' repentance before leaving Egypt, the accuser argued that their repentance was insufficient prior to receiving the Torah. The text explains that God had established a condition at creation for the sea to part for the Israelites, which nullified the accuser's claims. However, when the sea returned to cover the Egyptians, the need to reveal this condition arose to counter the accusations, emphasizing God's sovereignty and the unique relationship between Him and the Israelites.

passage_content: והנה תנאי זה שהתנה הקב"ה עם הים לא נתגלה בעולם בתחלת הבריאה כנ"ל, ויתכן שגם ישראל לא ידעו מזה בשעה שירדו לתוך הים, רק חז"ל גילו לנו אח"כ כמו שגילו הרבה ענינים שלא היו ידועים מקודם, ולולא תנאי זה יש קושיא עצומה מה בין אלו לאלו, דבאמת גם המצריים בשעה שהיו בצרה עשו תשובה קצת ונכנעו לפני השי"ת, וכמו שאמר פרעה במצרים ה' הצדיק ואני ועמי הרשעים, רק אחר שנעשה הרוחה הקשה את לבו, כדרך הרשעים בשעה שבא להם צרה נכנעים קצת ואח"כ חוזרים לסורם ובוודאי בשעה שנכנסו המצריים לתוך הים שהוא מקום סכנה גדולה נכנע לבם ועשו תשובה, ואז וודאי הי' טענת המקטרג חזקה מה בין אלו לאלו, דאם מועיל תשובה לישראל יועיל גם להם, ולכן היו ישראל יראין ואומרים כשם שאנו עולים מצד זה כך מצריים עולים מצד אחר, ולא מפאת חסרון אמונה חששו לזה רק מפני שידעו שהמצריים עושים תשובה בשעה שהם נתונים בצרה, וטענת המקטרג חזקה מה בין אלו לאלו, ושמא ינצלו מן הים ע"י התשובה, ואח"כ כשיעלו מן הים יחזרו לרשעם כדרכם, וגם המצריים ע"ד כן ירדו למקום סכנה לתוך הים, כי סמכו על הטענה מה בין אלו לאלו, וכיון שראו שהים נקרע לישראל ונכנסו בשלום, חשבו שגם להם יתרמי ככה דמה בין אלו לאלו, שגם הם עשו תשובה ואם מועיל תשובה לישראל גם להם יועיל.
translation: And behold, this condition that the Holy One, blessed be He, made with the sea was not revealed to the world at the beginning of creation, as mentioned above. It is possible that even Israel did not know of it at the time they entered the sea; only the Sages revealed it to us later, as they revealed many matters that were not known beforehand. Were it not for this condition, there would be a tremendous question as to what distinguishes these from those, for indeed, even the Egyptians, at the time they were in distress, repented somewhat and submitted before the Holy One, blessed be He, as Pharaoh said in Egypt, "The Lord is righteous, and I and my people are wicked." However, after their hearts were hardened, as is the way of the wicked, when trouble comes upon them, they submit somewhat and then return to their evil ways. Certainly, at the time the Egyptians entered the sea, which is a place of great danger, their hearts softened, and they repented. Then, undoubtedly, the accuser had a strong claim as to what distinguishes these from those, for if repentance is effective for Israel, it should also be effective for them. Therefore, the Israelites were afraid and said, "Just as we ascend from this side, so the Egyptians ascend from the other side," and it was not due to a lack of faith that they feared this, but because they knew that the Egyptians repent when they are in distress. The accuser's claim was strong as to what distinguishes these from those, and perhaps they would be saved from the sea through repentance. And afterward, when they would come up from the sea, they would return to their wickedness as is their way. And the Egyptians, in this manner, descended into the dangerous place of the sea, for they relied on the claim of what distinguishes these from those. And when they saw that the sea was split for Israel and they entered safely, they thought that they too would be saved in the same way, for what distinguishes these from those, since they also repented, and if repentance is effective for Israel, it should also be effective for them.
summary: The passage discusses the divine condition set by God with the sea, which was not revealed at the beginning of creation and may not have been known to the Israelites as they entered the sea. It highlights the concern that the Egyptians, who showed some repentance in their distress, might also be saved, raising a strong argument against the Israelites' deliverance. The text emphasizes the potential equality of repentance between the Israelites and the Egyptians, suggesting that if repentance could save the Israelites, it could also save their pursuers. Ultimately, the Israelites feared that the Egyptians' repentance might lead to their own salvation, questioning the distinction between the two groups in the face of divine mercy.

passage_content: גם אפ"ל עפ"י תירוצם של בעלי התוס', שחששו ישראל שמא ירדפו המצריים מצד אחר וישיגום וטעם יראתם הי' שמא יגרום החטא, וכדרך הצדיקים שדואגים תמיד שמא גרם החטא, וכמו שדרשו חז"ל עה"פ קטנתי מכל החסדים, אמר יעקב שמא משהבטחתני נתלכלכתי בחטא ויגרום לי להמסר ביד עשו, אך יעקב אבינו לגודל מעלת צדקתו נתחזק בבטחונו על הקב"ה, ואף שלבו נשבר בקרבו מיראת החטא עם כל זה הי' לבו שלם בבטחון חזק ואמיץ בהבוכ"ע שיחלצהו ממיצר, וזה הוא מעלה נשגבה במדריגת הצדיקים. שני הפכים בנושא אחד להיות יראים שמא יגרום החטא ואינם ראוין לישועה, ובו בזמן אמיץ לבם בבטחון אמיתי בהקב"ה, אבל בני ישראל שבאותו הדור לא היו שלמים במדה זו כ"כ, ולצד שהיו יראים שמא גרם חטאם להמסר בידי המצריים, לא היו יכולים לחזק עצמם בשלימות מדת הבטחון, ולכן אמרו חז"ל ישראל שבאותו הדור מקטני אמנה היו, לא אמרו חסרי אמנה אלא קטני אמנה דייקא, כלומר היראה הזאת לא באה להם מחמת חסרון אמונה ח"ו, אלא מחמת גודל מדת ענותנותם חשבו את עצמם שאינם מוכשרים וראויים לישועה ושמא גרם חטאם להמסר ביד המצריים, אך לעומת מעלת האבות הק' הי' מדריגתם במדת הבטחון והאמונה קטנה כנ"ל, כי האבות הק' היו תמיד שלמים וחזקים במדת הבטחון אף שלבם נשבר בקרבם מיראת החטא, ולמדריגה זו לא הגיעו ישראל שבאותו הדור, ולכן קראו אותם חז"ל קטני אמנה.
translation: Also, it can be said according to the explanation of the Tosafists, that the Israelites feared that the Egyptians might pursue them from another direction and catch them, and the reason for their fear was that perhaps their sin would cause this, similar to the righteous who are always concerned that they may have caused a sin. As our Sages expounded on the verse "I am too small for all the kindnesses," Jacob said that perhaps because You have promised me, I have become sullied by sin, and it will cause me to be delivered into the hands of Esau. However, our forefather Jacob, due to the greatness of his righteousness, strengthened his trust in the Holy One, Blessed be He, and even though his heart was broken within him from the fear of sin, nonetheless, his heart was complete with strong and mighty trust in the Holy One, Blessed be He, that He would rescue him from distress. This is a lofty quality in the level of the righteous: two opposites in one matter, being fearful that perhaps sin would cause them not to be worthy of salvation, and at the same time having a courageous heart with true trust in the Holy One, Blessed be He. However, the children of Israel in that generation were not so complete in this measure, and while they were fearful that perhaps their sin had caused them to be delivered into the hands of the Egyptians, they could not strengthen themselves completely in the measure of trust. Therefore, our Sages said that the Israelites of that generation were "small in faith"; they did not say "lacking in faith," but rather "small in faith" specifically, meaning that this fear did not come to them due to a lack of faith, Heaven forbid, but rather because of the greatness of their humility, they thought of themselves as unworthy and not deserving of salvation, and perhaps their sin had caused them to be delivered into the hands of the Egyptians. However, in contrast to the merit of the holy forefathers, their level in the measure of trust and faith was small, as mentioned, because the holy forefathers were always complete and strong in the measure of trust, even though their hearts were broken within them from the fear of sin, and to this level, the Israelites of that generation did not reach. Therefore, our Sages called them "small in faith."
summary: The passage discusses the tension between fear of sin and trust in God, particularly in the context of the Israelites' anxiety about the Egyptians. It highlights that while the righteous, like the patriarchs, maintain a strong faith in God despite their fear of sin, the Israelites of that generation lacked this level of faith, being described as "small in faith." Their humility led them to doubt their worthiness of salvation, contrasting with the unwavering trust exhibited by the patriarchs. Ultimately, this reflects a profound Hasidic insight into the balance between humility, fear of sin, and the necessity of steadfast faith in divine salvation.

passage_content: והנה על טענת שר של מצרים מה בין אלו לאלו הללו עוע"ז והללו וכו' יש עוד תשובה ניצחת עפי"מ שכתב הרמב"ן ז"ל (פרשת האזינו) עה"פ אמרתי אפאיהם וגו' לולי כעס אויב אגור וגו' פן יאמרו ידינו רמה ולא ה' פעל כל זאת וזלה"ק: והטעם בטענה הזאת איננו כרוצה להראות כוחו בין שונאיו, כי כל הגוים כאין נגדו מאפס ותוהו נחשבו לו, אבל השם ברא את האדם בתחתונים שיכיר את בוראו ויודה לשמו וכו', וכאשר חטאו ברצונם וכפרו בו כולם לא נשאר רק העם הזה לשמו ופרסם בהם וכו' כי הוא אלקי האלקים ואדוני האדונים ונודע בזה לכל העמים: והנה אם ישוב ויאבד זכרם ישכחו העמים את אותותיו ואת מעשיו ולא יסופר עוד בהם וכו', הנה תהי' כוונת הבריאה באדם בטלה לגמרי שלא ישאר בהם יודע את בוראו רק מכעיס לפניו, וע"כ ראוי מדין הרצון שהי' בבריאת העולם שיהי' רצון מלפניו להקים לו לעם כל הימים, כי הם הקרובים אליו והיודעים אותו מכל העמים עכלה"ק, נמצא מזה שיש הכרח בקיום עם ישראל בשביל כבודו ית"ש: ואין מקום לקטרג שגם ישראל יאבדו ח"ו עם המצריים, כי אז יהי' תכלית הבריאה בטלה לגמרי ולא יוכר לבאי עולם כבודו ית"ש וע"כ יש הכרח בקיומם.
translation: And behold, regarding the claim of the minister of Egypt, what is the difference between these and those, these are idol worshippers and those are etc. There is another decisive answer according to what the Ramban, may his memory be blessed, wrote (in Parashat Ha'azinu) on the verse "I said, I would scatter them..." If not for the anger of the enemy, I would have been afraid... lest they say, 'Our hand is high, and it was not the Lord who did all this.' And his words are as follows: The reason for this claim is not as if He wants to show His power among His enemies, for all the nations are as nothing before Him, considered as void and emptiness. But the Holy One, blessed be He, created man in the lower realms so that he would recognize his Creator and acknowledge His name, etc. And when they sinned willingly and all denied Him, only this people remained for His name and He made it known among them, etc., for He is the God of gods and the Lord of lords, and this is known among all the nations. And behold, if He were to return and erase their memory, the nations would forget His signs and His deeds, and it would no longer be told among them, etc. Behold, the purpose of creation in man would be completely nullified, and there would remain no one who knows his Creator, only to provoke Him. Therefore, it is fitting, by the decree of the will that was in the creation of the world, that there should be a will before Him to establish for Himself a people all the days, for they are the closest to Him and know Him more than all the nations. Thus, it is evident that there is a necessity for the existence of the people of Israel for His honor, blessed be He. There is no room for accusation that Israel should perish, God forbid, with the Egyptians, for then the purpose of creation would be completely nullified, and His honor would not be recognized by the nations of the world, and therefore there is a necessity for their existence.
summary: The passage discusses the necessity of the existence of the Jewish people for the honor of God, as articulated by the Ramban. It emphasizes that God created humanity to recognize and acknowledge Him, and when all nations sin and reject Him, only Israel remains to uphold His name. The text argues that if Israel were to be lost, the purpose of creation would be rendered void, and God's glory would not be recognized by the world. Therefore, the survival of the Jewish people is essential for the fulfillment of God's will and the acknowledgment of His sovereignty.

passage_content: ובזה פירשתי מאמרם ז"ל (סוף מס' סוטה) אחר שתיארו חז"ל שפלות הדור בעיקבתא דמשיחא, סיימו דבריהם על מה יש לנו להשען על אבינו שבשמים, והקושיא מפורסמת מה גריעותא בזה הלא גם בדורות הקודמים שמו ישראל ציפויים ותקותם אך ורק על אבינו שבשמים ואדרבה זאת היתה מעלתם הגדולה שהי' בטחונם חזק באבינו שבשמים, אך אפ"ל הכוונה דבדורות הקודמים שהיו צדיקים הרבה בכל דור ודור, היו יכולים לצפות לישועת הקב"ה בזכות הצדיקים, אבל בעיקבתא דמשיחא שהדור הוא בתכלית השפלות ובדיוטא התחתונה, אין לנו זכות אחר, רק שיושיענו הבוית"ש למען כבודו ית"ש שלא יתחלל, וכמו שדרשו רז"ל (סנהדרין צ"ח ע"א) אין בן דוד בא אלא בדור שכולו זכאי או כולו חייב וכו' כולו חייב דכתיב וירא כי אין איש וישתומם כי אין מפגיע וכתיב למעני למעני אעשה, וזה שרמזו חז"ל בלשונם הק' על מה יש לנו להשען על אבינו שבשמים, שאין לנו בדור הזה לבקש על הגאולה רק בשביל כבוד אבינו שבשמים ולא שום זכותים אחרים. וזהו כבוד שמים שיהיו ישראל ברום המעלה וכמ"ש הרמב"ן הק' הנ"ל.
translation: And with this, I have explained their statement, may their memory be blessed (at the end of the tractate Sotah). After the Sages described the lowliness of the generation in the footsteps of the Messiah, they concluded their words on what we have to rely on—our Father in Heaven. The well-known question arises: what is the deficiency in this? After all, in previous generations, the Jewish people placed their hopes and expectations solely on our Father in Heaven, and indeed, this was their great merit—that their trust was strong in our Father in Heaven. However, it can be said that in previous generations, where there were many righteous individuals in every generation, they could expect the salvation of the Holy One, Blessed be He, in the merit of the righteous. But in the footsteps of the Messiah, when the generation is in the utmost lowliness and in the lowest level, we have no other merit, except that He should save us, blessed be He, for the sake of His honor, that it should not be desecrated. And as our Sages have expounded (Sanhedrin 98a), the Messiah does not come except in a generation that is entirely righteous or entirely guilty, etc. When it is entirely guilty, as it is written, "And He saw that there was no man, and He was astonished that there was no intercessor," and it is written, "For My sake, for My sake, I will act." This is what our Sages hinted at in their holy language regarding what we have to rely on—our Father in Heaven—that in this generation, we should seek redemption only for the honor of our Father in Heaven and not for any other merits. And this is the honor of Heaven, that the Jewish people should be in a high state, as the holy Ramban mentioned above.
summary: The passage discusses the decline of spiritual merit in the generation preceding the Messiah, emphasizing that unlike previous generations, which had righteous individuals to intercede for them, the current generation is characterized by profound spiritual lowliness. Consequently, the Jewish people must rely solely on God's mercy for redemption, appealing to His honor rather than any personal merits. This reliance reflects a deep theological insight into the nature of divine grace and the importance of God's glory in the process of redemption. Ultimately, the text underscores that the hope for salvation is rooted in the sanctity of God's name and the elevation of the Jewish people.

passage_content: וידוע מש"כ בספה"ק קדושת לוי טעם שלא נקבע יו"ט על הרבה נסים שנעשו לישראל, כגון מלחמת יהושע עם ל"א מלכים, ומפלת סיסרא וסנחרב וכדומה מפני שלא קבעו אנשי כנה"ג לעשות זכר לדורות כ"א על הנסים שראו ברוח קדשם שנמשך השפעתם בכל הדורות ובכל שנה ושנה, כגון נס חנוכה ופורים וכדומה, אבל אותם הנסים שלא היו רק לשעה לא קבעו יו"ט עכ"ד, ולכאורה לפי"ז ראוי להבין מ"ט נקבע יום שביעי של פסח ע"ש הנס של קרי"ס ואיך נמשך לנו השפעת הישועה הזאת בכל דור ובכל שנה ושנה.
translation: It is known what is written in the holy book Kedushat Levi, the reason why a festival was not established for many miracles that occurred for Israel, such as the war of Joshua with the thirty-one kings, and the downfall of Sisera and Sennacherib, and the like, is because the men of the Great Assembly did not establish a remembrance for generations for those miracles that they saw with their holy spirit, whose influence continues throughout all generations and every year, such as the miracle of Hanukkah and Purim, and the like. However, those miracles that were only for a moment did not warrant the establishment of a festival. Thus, it seems that according to this, it is appropriate to understand why the seventh day of Passover was established in honor of the miracle of the splitting of the sea, and how the influence of this salvation continues for us in every generation and every year.
summary: The passage discusses the reasoning behind the establishment of Jewish holidays, emphasizing that only miracles with lasting spiritual significance were designated as holidays, such as Hanukkah and Purim. It contrasts these with temporary miracles, like the battles of Joshua or the defeat of Sisera, which were not commemorated. The author questions why the seventh day of Passover, which celebrates the miracle of the splitting of the Red Sea, was established as a holiday, suggesting that this miracle also has a continuous impact and relevance for each generation. This highlights the Hasidic belief in the enduring influence of divine intervention in the lives of the Jewish people throughout history.

passage_content: אך הענין הוא, דהנה בשעת קי"ס הי' קטרוג גדול על ישראל מה בין אלו לאלו כנ"ל, ולא הי' לישראל זכותים שינצלו והוצרך הקב"ה להציל אותם בשביל כבודו ית"ש, שתכלית התגלות כבודו הוא רק ע"י ישראל וכנ"ל ברמב"ן הק', והישועה הזאת נמשכת ונשפעת בכל דור ודור, ובכל זמן שאין לישראל ח"ו די זכותים, הקב"ה מצמיח להם ישועה בשביל כבוד שמים כמו שהי' בקרי"ס, ולכן בשעה שעמד מרע"ה להתפלל ולהמליץ זכות על ישראל שיזכו לישועה, אמר לו הקב"ה מה תצעק אלי אין לך לבקש זכותים של ישראל, כי בי הדבר תלוי ר"ל אני אושיע את ישראל בשביל כבודי, אף אם אין זכותים לישראל שיהיו ראויין לישועה, אבל למעני ולמען כבודי אעשה שיתגלה כבוד מלכותי ע"י ישראל: והישועה הזאת מתעוררת בכל שנה ושנה, כן יעזור הבוי"ת בדור הזה בעניינו ובשפלותינו שאין זכותים בישראל לזכות לישועה ואין לנו על מי להשען אלא על אבינו שבשמים, יעזרינו בשביל כבודו ית"ש כמו שהי' אז בשעת קרי"ס, וכאשר זכינו לישועה גדולה אז כן נזכה לראות בישועת כל ישראל ושמחתן בקדושה ובטהרה בהתרוממות קרן התורה וישראל ובהתגלות כבוד שמים עלינו במהרה בימינו אמן.
translation: But the matter is that at the time of the splitting of the sea, there was a great accusation against Israel, as mentioned above, and Israel did not have merits to be saved, and the Holy One, blessed be He, needed to save them for His honor, for the ultimate revelation of His honor is only through Israel, as mentioned in the holy Ramban. This salvation is drawn down and flows in every generation, and at any time when Israel does not have sufficient merits, the Holy One, blessed be He, brings them salvation for the sake of the honor of Heaven, just as it was at the time of the splitting of the sea. Therefore, when Moshe Rabbeinu stood to pray and to advocate for Israel to merit salvation, the Holy One, blessed be He, said to him, "Why do you cry out to Me? You do not need to ask for merits for Israel, for the matter depends on Me; I will save Israel for My honor, even if Israel does not have merits that would make them worthy of salvation, but for My sake and for the sake of My honor, I will make My royal honor be revealed through Israel." And this salvation awakens every year. May the Blessed One help in this generation with our matters and our lowliness, as there are no merits in Israel to merit salvation, and we have no one to rely on except our Father in Heaven. May He help us for the sake of His honor, just as it was then at the time of the splitting of the sea. And as we merited great salvation then, so may we merit to see the salvation of all Israel and their joy in holiness and purity, with the uplifting of the banner of the Torah and Israel, and with the revelation of the honor of Heaven upon us speedily in our days, Amen.
summary: The passage discusses the concept that during the Exodus, Israel faced significant accusations and lacked merits for salvation, prompting God to intervene for the sake of His own honor. This divine salvation is portrayed as a recurring theme throughout generations, where God provides deliverance for Israel even in times of their unworthiness, emphasizing that His glory is revealed through them. The text highlights the importance of relying on God's mercy and honor, especially in times of distress, and expresses hope for future redemption and the revelation of divine glory through Israel.

passage_content: ויאמר ה' אל משה מה תצעק אלי דבר אל בני ישראל ויסעו, במדרש (הובא בישמח משה) אמר הקב"ה למשה הים סוער והשונא רודף ואתה עומד ומרבה בתפלה, א"ל ומה עלי לעשות, א"ל ואתה הרם את מטך, באותה שעה אמרו ה' ימלוך לעולם ועד עכ"ד המדרש וצ"ב.
translation: And the Lord said to Moses, "Why do you cry out to Me? Speak to the children of Israel and let them journey forth." In the Midrash (brought in Yismach Moshe), it is said that the Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Moses, "The sea is raging and the enemy is pursuing, and you are standing and increasing in prayer." He said to Him, "What should I do?" He said, "And you lift up your staff." At that moment, they said, "The Lord shall reign forever and ever." Thus concludes the Midrash, and it requires further explanation.
summary: In this passage, God instructs Moses to stop praying and instead take action by raising his staff to part the sea, highlighting the balance between prayer and proactive faith. The Midrash emphasizes that while prayer is essential, it must be accompanied by tangible steps towards redemption. The declaration "The Lord will reign forever and ever" reflects the ultimate sovereignty of God, reinforcing the idea that divine intervention is intertwined with human initiative in the process of salvation. This teaches that faith must be active, demonstrating trust in God's power while also engaging in the necessary actions to fulfill His will.

passage_content: ב) ילקוט (רמז רל"ג) ר' יהודה בן בתירה אומר כבר עשיתי ההבטחה שהבטחתי את אבותיהם שנאמר וישם את הים לחרבה, והוא פלא דהרי עדיין הי' לפני קריעת ים סוף, ומה זה שאמר כבר עשיתי וכו', ובזית רענן מבעל מג"א פי' עד שלא התפללת כבר בקעתי את הים ועדיין צ"ב איך נרמז זה בפסוק וישם את הים לחרבה.
translation: In the Yalkut (Remez 273), Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira says: "I have already fulfilled the promise that I promised their forefathers, as it is said, 'And He turned the sea into dry land.' This is a wonder, for it was still before the splitting of the Sea of Reeds. What does it mean when he says, 'I have already fulfilled' etc.? And in the Zohar, Raanan from the Baal HaMagid explains that before you even prayed, I had already split the sea. Still, it is unclear how this is hinted at in the verse, 'And He turned the sea into dry land.'"
summary: Rabbi Yehuda ben Beterah discusses the promise made to the ancestors regarding the splitting of the sea, highlighting the miraculous nature of this event occurring before it actually took place. He emphasizes that even before the Israelites prayed, the sea was already split, indicating a divine assurance of salvation. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of God's preemptive grace and the idea that divine intervention is already in motion before human action, illustrating the profound relationship between faith and divine providence. The passage invites contemplation on the nature of God's promises and the unfolding of miracles in the context of faith.

translation: 3) Yalkut (Shir HaShirim, Remez 829) "Like the tower of David is your neck," as David magnified you in his book and said to the one who split the Sea of Reeds into pieces. And the question remains: in what way did David magnify Israel more, when the entire matter of the splitting of the Sea of Reeds is already explained in the Torah?
summary: The passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel highlights the significance of King David's role in elevating the Jewish people, particularly through his poetic expression in the Song of Songs. It questions how David's contributions surpass the already established narrative of the splitting of the Red Sea, which is explicitly detailed in the Torah. This reflects a deeper Hasidic understanding of the transformative power of faith and the unique spiritual elevation that David brings to the Jewish experience. Ultimately, it emphasizes the importance of personal and communal connection to divine miracles and the ongoing legacy of leadership in fostering spiritual growth.

passage_content: ד) הים לפנות בוקר לאיתנו וגו', פירש"י ז"ל לתקפו הראשון ובמדרש ילקוט (רמז רל"ו) לאיתנו א"ר יונתן התנה הקב"ה תנאים עם הים שיהא נקרע לפני ישראל הה"ד וישב הים לפנות בוקר לאיתנו לתנאו שהתנה הקב"ה עמו, והקושיא מפורסמת דלפי דרשת המדרש הי' ראוי לכתוב תיבת לאיתנו בפסוק ויבקעו המים דאז נתקיים התנאי, אבל מה שחזר על המצריים לא הי' צורך לתנאי שהרי חזר לטבעו ומהלכו הרגיל, והרבה קולמוסין נשתברו לתרץ קושיא זו.
translation: D) The sea, at dawn, returned to its strength, etc. Rashi, of blessed memory, explains this as referring to its first strength. And in the Midrash Yalkut (Remez 236), it states: "The Holy One, blessed be He, made conditions with the sea that it should split before Israel." As it is said, "And the sea returned at dawn to its strength," to the condition that the Holy One, blessed be He, made with it. The well-known question arises: According to the Midrash's interpretation, it would have been appropriate to write the word "to its strength" in the verse "and the waters were split," for then the condition would have been fulfilled. However, regarding the Egyptians, there was no need for a condition, as it returned to its nature and its regular course. Many pens have been broken to resolve this question.
summary: The passage discusses the miraculous splitting of the sea at dawn, emphasizing that God made a condition with the sea to part before the Israelites. It highlights a theological tension regarding why the term "to its strength" is used, suggesting that the sea's return to its natural state after the miracle did not require a condition. This reflects a deeper Hasidic insight into the relationship between divine intervention and the natural order, illustrating the complexity of God's covenant with creation.

passage_content: ה) ישיר משה ובני ישראל את השירה הזאת לה' וגו', במד"ר (פרשה כ"ג סימן ד') הה"ד (משלי ל"א) פיה פתחה בחכמה ותורת חסד על לשונה, מיום שברא הקב"ה את העולם ועד שעמדו ישראל על הים לא מצינו אדם שאמר שירה להקב"ה אלא ישראל, ברא אדם הראשון ולא אמר שירה, הציל אברהם מכבשן האש ולא אמר שירה וכו', כיון שבאו ישראל לים ונקרע להם מיד אמרו שירה לפני הקב"ה שנאמר אז ישיר וגו' הוי פיה פתחה בחכמה, אמר הקב"ה לאלו הייתי מצפה, ראוי להבין מדוע באמת לא אמרו הראשונים שירה על הנסים שנעשו להם.
translation: 5) "Then Moses and the children of Israel sang this song to the Lord," etc. (Midrash Rabbah, Parashat Ki Tisa, Section 23:4). This is as it is written (Proverbs 31:26), "She opens her mouth with wisdom, and the teaching of kindness is on her tongue." From the day that the Holy One, Blessed be He, created the world until the Israelites stood at the sea, we do not find anyone who sang a song to the Holy One, Blessed be He, except for Israel. Adam was created and did not sing a song; Abraham was saved from the fiery furnace and did not sing a song, etc. Once Israel came to the sea and it split for them, they immediately sang a song before the Holy One, Blessed be He, as it is said, "Then Moses sang," etc. This is "She opens her mouth with wisdom." The Holy One, Blessed be He, said, "For these I was waiting." It is worthy to understand why, indeed, the earlier ones did not sing a song for the miracles that were done for them.
summary: The passage highlights the unique significance of the Israelites singing praise to God after the splitting of the sea, emphasizing that prior to this event, no one had expressed such gratitude through song, despite experiencing divine miracles. It suggests that the act of singing is a profound response to God's salvation, reflecting a deep understanding and appreciation of His kindness. The reference to "a woman of valor" underscores the wisdom and grace inherent in this expression of faith, indicating that the Israelites' song was a culmination of divine expectation. The text invites reflection on the reasons why earlier figures did not sing, suggesting a special role for Israel in recognizing and celebrating God's interventions.

passage_content: ונראה לפרש בהקדם דברי הרמב"ם ז"ל בפי' המשניות (אבות פ"ה מ"ו) עשרה דברים נבראו בערב שבת בין השמשות וכו' שהקב"ה התנה בשעת הבריאה עם כל מעשה בראשית שישתנו לפעמים בעת הצורך, ומה שייחד התנא דוקא אלו עשרה דברים אין הכוונה שרק אלו נבראו בששת ימי המעשה, אבל אמר שרק אלו נבראו בע"ש בין השמשות ושאר הנפלאות והמופתים הושמו בטבעי הדברים אשר נעשו בם בעת העשותם תחלה, על דרך משל ביום השני בהחלק המים הושם בטבע שיחלק ים סוף למשה והירדן ליהושע וכן שאר הנפלאות מלבד אלו העשרה שהושמו בטבעי הדברים ההם בין השמשות, וכן כתב רבינו יונה שם, וכתבו הטעם מפני שאין רצונו של הקב"ה לעשות שידוד המערכות ולשנות טבע העולם על כן התנה על כולם מששת ימי בראשית, דהקב"ה מגיד מראשית אחרית וראה אז כל הנסים שעתידין להעשות והתנה על כולם משעת הבריאה, וכן מבואר במד"ר פרשה בראשית (פרשה ה' סימן ה') שהקב"ה התנה מתחלת הבריאה על כל הנסים שיהיו בעולם, והיפ"ת כתב בזה שני טעמים מדוע הוצרך הקב"ה להתנות מתחלה הרי הבוכ"ע הוא כל יכול ובידו לשנות טבעי העולם כרצונו גם מבלי שיתנה תנאי משעת הבריאה ומי יאמר לו מה יעשה, טעם א' שהוא כבוד יותר למי שנעשה הנס בשבילו, כשכבר התנה הקב"ה משעת הבריאה שישתנה עבורו בעת שיצטרך לנס, והב' דכיון שכבר יש תנאי על הדבר נעשה הענין במהירות יותר מאם היו צריכין לשנות מחדש מה שלא הותנה עדיין, ובנזה"ק כתב טעם דכל דבר שנשתנה מכמו שהי' אף אם חוזר לקדמותו מ"מ שולט בו חולשא קצת ואינו באותו התוקף שהי' מקודם שנשתנה, ע"כ התנה הקב"ה על כל הנסים והנפלאות כדי שלא יחול חולשא בהם ע"י השתנותם מכמו שהיו בתחלת הבריאה.
translation: And it seems appropriate to explain in advance the words of the Rambam, may his memory be blessed, in his commentary on the Mishnah (Avot 5:6) that ten things were created on Friday at twilight, etc. that the Holy One, blessed be He, stipulated at the time of creation with every act of creation that they would change at times when necessary. And the reason the Tanna specifically designated these ten things is not to imply that only these were created during the six days of creation, but rather that only these were created on Friday at twilight, while the other wonders and miracles were placed in the nature of the things that were made at the time of their initial creation. For example, on the second day, when the waters were divided, it was placed in nature that the Sea of Reeds would be divided for Moses and the Jordan for Joshua, and so too with the other wonders, aside from these ten that were placed in the nature of those things at twilight. Thus wrote Rabbeinu Yonah there, and he wrote the reason that the Holy One, blessed be He, does not wish to disrupt the natural order and change the nature of the world; therefore, He stipulated for all of them from the six days of creation, for the Holy One, blessed be He, declares the end from the beginning and saw then all the miracles that would be performed and stipulated for all of them from the time of creation. And it is also explained in the Midrash on Genesis (Parashat Bereshit, 5:5) that the Holy One, blessed be He, stipulated from the beginning of creation for all the miracles that would occur in the world. And the Yefet wrote two reasons why the Holy One, blessed be He, needed to stipulate from the beginning, for the Blessed One is all-powerful and has the ability to change the nature of the world as He wishes, even without stipulating conditions from the time of creation, and who can tell Him what to do? The first reason is that it is more honorable for the one for whom the miracle is performed, since the Holy One, blessed be He, already stipulated from the time of creation that it would change for him when he would need a miracle. The second reason is that since there is already a condition on the matter, the issue is resolved more quickly than if they needed to change anew what had not yet been stipulated. And in the Zohar it is written that any matter that has changed from what it was, even if it returns to its original state, nonetheless has a certain weakness over it and does not possess the same strength it had before it was changed. Therefore, the Holy One, blessed be He, stipulated for all the miracles and wonders so that they would not be weakened by their change from what they were at the beginning of creation.
summary: The passage discusses the Rambam's interpretation of the ten things created at twilight on Friday, emphasizing that God established conditions during creation for miracles to occur without disrupting the natural order. It suggests that these ten items were specifically created at that time, while other wonders were embedded in the natural laws established during creation. The text highlights that God's foresight allowed for these miracles to be preordained, enhancing their significance and ensuring they would occur swiftly when needed, without diminishing their potency. Ultimately, it reflects a deep theological insight into the relationship between divine providence and the natural world.

passage_content: ועפי"ז יובן דרשתם ז"ל לאיתנו לתנאו הראשון, דלכאורה הרי כללא אית לן דאין מקרא יוצא מידי פשוטו לעולם, ומשמעות מלת לאיתנו היינו לתקפו, ואיך הוציאו חז"ל מפשוטו לדרוש בו לתנאי הראשון, ולדרכינו הדרש בא להשלים מה דקשה על משמעות הפשוטו דאיך אמר הכתוב וישב הים לפנות בוקר לאיתנו לתוקפו הראשון, לפי מה שידענו שכל דבר שנשתנה ממה שהי' בתחלת הבריאה שולט בו קצת חולשה, וע"ז בא המדרש לתרץ שחזר לתנאו הראשון דתנאי התנה הקב"ה עם מעשה בראשית שיקרע הים לישראל וכיון שהי' תנאי מתחלת הבריאה שפיר אמר הפסוק שחזר לתוקפו הראשון דלא נעשה בו השתנות שהי' תחלת הבריאה ע"ד כן.
translation: And according to this, we will understand the teaching of our Sages, of blessed memory, regarding its original state, for seemingly we have a general principle that a verse never departs from its simple meaning. The meaning of the word "to its original state" refers to its strength, and how did the Sages derive from its simple meaning to interpret it in terms of the original condition? And in our way of interpretation, it comes to complete what is difficult regarding the simple meaning, namely, how the verse states, "And the sea returned to its strength in the morning," according to what we know that anything that has changed from what it was at the beginning of creation has some weakness over it. And to this, the Midrash comes to explain that it returned to its original condition, for the condition that the Holy One, blessed be He, made with the work of creation was that the sea would split for Israel, and since there was a condition from the beginning of creation, the verse rightly states that it returned to its original strength, that there was no change from what it was at the beginning of creation in this regard.
summary: The passage discusses the concept that biblical verses should be understood in their plain meaning, yet the sages interpret them to reveal deeper truths. It specifically addresses the phrase "to its original strength," suggesting that the sea, which was created with a divine condition to part for Israel, returned to its original state without any inherent weakness. This interpretation emphasizes the idea that God's initial intentions for creation remain intact, reflecting a fundamental belief in the permanence of divine will and the relationship between God and the world.

passage_content: באופן אחר יתבאר עפי"מ דאיתא במכילתא עה"פ ומצרים נסים לקראתו, לקראתם לא נאמר אלא לקראתו של כל מצרי ומצרי, שהי' המים רץ אחר כל מצרי ומורידו אל הים. והקשה במרכבת המשנה ממה דאיתא בגמרא (סוטה י"א ע"א) הבה נתחכמה לו בואו ונתחכם למושיען של ישראל לדונו במים, שכבר נשבע הקב"ה שאינו מביא מבול מים לעולם, והן אינן יודעין שהוא אינו מביא אבל הן באין ונופלין בתוכו, וכן הוא אומר ומצרים נסים לקראתו, והתינח מה שבאו עליהם המים אחר שירדו לתוך הים אינו בכלל שבועת המבול שהרי הם באו בגבול הים, אבל ריצת הים מחוץ לגבולו לסחוף אותם אל תוך הים זה הוא לכאורה נגד השבועה, ולי נראה דלא קשה מידי דבילקוט שמעוני הובא ג"כ דרש זה של המכילתא בתוספת דברים וזה לשונו: שהיו המצריים עושין כשפים ועולין מן הים אמר הים פקדון שהפקיד לי הקב"ה האיך אניחנו, מיד היו המים רצין אחר כל מצרי ומצרי ומורידן לים, הרי שכבר באו לגבולו של הים וזכה בהם הים ואח"כ רדף אחריהם, וא"ש אמרם ז"ל דגם זה נתמעט מהוא אינו מביא וכו'. ואמרז"ל במדרש (תנחומא סי' י' ובילקו"ש רמז רל"ג) עשרה נסים נעשו לישראל על הים וא' מהם שנעשה הים גזרים שנאמר לגוזר ים סוף לגזרים, ולכאורה לאיזה צורך עשה הקב"ה נס זה וקוב"ה לא עביד ניסא למגנא ומה הי' חסר אם לא הי' נקרע רק במקום אחד, ואפ"ל עפ"י אמרם ז"ל שהי' המים רץ אחר כל מצרי וכו' נמצאו נחלקו המים לגזרים הרבה, וזה הכוונה באמרם שנקרע לגזרים.
translation: In another way, it can be explained according to what is stated in the Mechilta on the verse "And the Egyptians fled before it," it does not say "before them" but "before each and every Egyptian," as the waters ran after every Egyptian and brought him down to the sea. The Merkevet HaMishnah questions this based on what is stated in the Gemara (Sotah 11a), "Let us be wise against Him; come, let us be wise against the Savior of Israel to judge them in the waters," for the Holy One, blessed be He, has already sworn that He will not bring a flood of water upon the world, and they do not know that He does not bring it, but they come and fall into it. And so it is said, "And the Egyptians fled before it." This being the case, what can be said about the waters coming upon them after they descended into the sea? This is not included in the oath of the flood, since they came within the boundary of the sea. However, the running of the sea outside its boundary to sweep them into the sea seems, at first glance, to be against the oath. To me, it does not seem too difficult, for in the Yalkut Shimoni, this interpretation from the Mechilta is also brought in addition to the words, and this is its wording: that the Egyptians were performing sorcery and rising from the sea, the sea said, "A deposit that the Holy One, blessed be He, has entrusted to me, how can I leave it?" Immediately, the waters ran after every Egyptian and brought them down to the sea. Thus, they had already come to the boundary of the sea, and the sea was granted authority over them, and afterwards it chased after them. This explains what our Sages said that this too is diminished from "He does not bring" etc. And our Sages said in the Midrash (Tanchuma, section 10, and in Yalkut Shimoni, reference 273) that ten miracles were performed for Israel at the sea, and one of them was that the sea was cut into pieces, as it is said, "To cut the Sea of Reeds into pieces." At first glance, for what purpose did the Holy One, blessed be He, perform this miracle? And the Holy One does not perform miracles for mere protection, and what would have been lacking if it had not been torn except in one place? It can be said according to what our Sages said that the waters ran after every Egyptian, etc., thus the waters were found to be divided into many pieces, and this is the intention in their statement that it was torn into pieces.
summary: The passage discusses the miraculous events during the Exodus, particularly how the waters of the sea pursued each Egyptian individually, reflecting divine justice. It highlights the tension between God's oath not to bring a flood and the unique circumstances of the Egyptians' punishment at the sea. The text emphasizes that the splitting of the sea into many pieces served a purpose, allowing the waters to chase after the Egyptians while still adhering to God's promise. This illustrates the Hasidic belief in the intricate balance of divine mercy and justice in the unfolding of miraculous events.

passage_content: ואיתא במדרש ילקוט (רמז רל"ד) שבא משה ועמד על הים ואמר בשם הקב"ה שיקרע ולא קבל עליו, הראהו את המעה ולא קבל עליו, עד שנגלה אליו הקב"ה בכבודו, כיון שנגלה עליו הקב"ה בכבודו התחיל הים בורח שנאמר הים ראה וינוס, א"ל כל היום הייתי אומר לך בשם הקב"ה ולא קבלת עליך, ועכשיו מה לך הים כי תנוס, א"ל לא מפניך בן עמרם אלא מלפני אדון חולי ארץ עכ"ד המדרש, והטעם שלא רצה מתחלה להקרע לפניהם, כתבו המפורשים שחשב שאין ישראל ראויים לעשות להם נס, או שלא הגיע עדיין זמנם לצאת ישראל ממצרים כי לא נשלמו הארבע מאות שנה, ואחר שנגלה עליו הקב"ה בכבודו ובעצמו מיד נקרע ע"י מאמר ה', ועוד הוסיף בקיעות הרבה לרוץ אחר כל מצרי והורידו לים אף שע"ז לא נצטוה מהקב"ה, אלא מפני שראה שכבר הגיע עת קיום התנאי עשה מעצמו כל הצורך להשלמת התנאי, נמצא לפי"ז שבקיעה הראשונה שנקרע לישראל לא הי' מפאת התנאי רק מפני שנגלה עליו הקב"ה ואף לולא תנאי הי' מוכרח להקרע מפחד הדר כבודו ית' רק מה שנבקע אחר ששב הים לאיתנו לנוס אחר כל מצרי זה הי' מכח התנאי שהתנה הקב"ה עמו בשעת הבריאה, וא"ש למה נכתב לאיתנו אצל וישב הים,
translation: It is stated in the Midrash Yalkut (Remez 274) that Moses came and stood by the sea and said in the name of the Holy One, blessed be He, that it should split, but it did not accept upon itself. He showed it the coin and it still did not accept upon itself, until the Holy One, blessed be He, revealed Himself to him in His glory. As soon as the Holy One, blessed be He, revealed Himself to him in His glory, the sea began to flee, as it is said, "The sea saw and fled." He said to it, "All day I have been telling you in the name of the Holy One, blessed be He, and you did not accept upon yourself, and now what is it to you, sea, that you should flee?" The sea replied, "Not because of you, son of Amram, but because of the Master of the Lord of the earth." Thus concludes the Midrash. The reason it did not want to split before them at first, the commentators wrote, is that it thought the Israelites were not worthy of a miracle, or that the time for the Israelites to leave Egypt had not yet arrived because the four hundred years had not been completed. However, after the Holy One, blessed be He, revealed Himself to him in His glory and essence, the sea immediately split by the word of the Holy One, blessed be He. Furthermore, it added much speed to run after every Egyptian and drown them in the sea, even though it was not commanded to do so by the Holy One, blessed be He, but because it saw that the time for the fulfillment of the condition had arrived, it acted on its own to fulfill the condition. Therefore, it follows that the first splitting that occurred for the Israelites was not due to the condition, but rather because the Holy One, blessed be He, revealed Himself to him, and even without the condition, it would have had to split out of fear of the glory of His presence. Only what happened after the sea returned to its strength to flee after every Egyptian was due to the condition that the Holy One, blessed be He, stipulated with it at the time of creation. This also explains why it is written "to its strength" in connection with "and the sea returned."
summary: The passage discusses the moment when Moses stood at the sea, initially met with resistance from the waters, which did not part until God revealed Himself in glory. This revelation prompted the sea to flee, highlighting the idea that the miraculous event was contingent upon divine presence rather than the worthiness of the Israelites. The text emphasizes that the first parting of the sea was a direct result of God's glory, while the subsequent pursuit of the Egyptians was in fulfillment of a preordained condition established at creation. This illustrates the interplay between divine timing, human action, and the fulfillment of God's promises.

passage_content: ויתבאר בזה דברי המדרש כמגדל דוד צוארך שהגדיל אתכם דוד בספרו ואמר לגוזר ים סוף לגזרים, ע"ד שכתב היפ"ת הנ"ל שע"כ התנה הקב"ה במעשה בראשית על כל הנסים העתידים להיות, מפני שהוא כבוד יותר למי שנעשה הנס בשבילו, א"כ מה שמפורש בתורה ענין קריעת ים סוף לא נתרבה כ"כ כבודן של ישראל, שהרי לא היתה בכח התנאי רק בציווי השי"ת, אמנם דוד המלך מפרש לגוזר ים סוף לגזרים ובקיעה זו היתה מפאת התנאי שהתנה ית' בשביל ישראל ובזה הגדיל את ישראל יותר. ובזה יובן דברי המדרש שאמר ר"י בן בתירה כבר עשיתי ההבטחה שהבטחתי את אבותיהם, היינו מתחלת הבריאה התנתי עם הים שיקרע לישראל ואין צורך בתפלתך, שנאמר וישם את הים לחרבה, ר"ל בשעה שעשה הקב"ה את הים התנה עמו שתהי' חרבה לישראל כשיהיו צריכים לכך.
translation: And the words of the Midrash will be clarified here, as "Your neck is like the Tower of David," which David magnified you in his book and said to the one who divides the Sea of Reeds into pieces, according to what the aforementioned Yefet wrote, that the Holy One, blessed be He, conditioned the act of Creation on all the miracles that would happen in the future, because it is more honorable for the one for whom the miracle is done. Therefore, what is explicitly stated in the Torah regarding the splitting of the Sea of Reeds did not increase the honor of Israel so much, since it was not in the power of the condition but rather in the command of the Holy One, blessed be He. However, King David explains that the one who divides the Sea of Reeds into pieces, and this splitting was due to the condition that the Blessed One conditioned for the sake of Israel, and in this way, He magnified Israel even more. And this will clarify the words of the Midrash that Rabbi Yochanan ben Batera said: "I have already made the promise that I promised their forefathers," meaning from the beginning of Creation, I conditioned with the sea that it would split for Israel, and there is no need for your prayer, as it is said, "And He set the sea to dry land," meaning at the time when the Holy One, blessed be He, created the sea, He conditioned with it that it would be dry land for Israel when they would need it.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the splitting of the Red Sea as a divine act that was conditioned by God's covenant with Israel, emphasizing the honor bestowed upon the Jewish people through this miraculous event. It highlights that King David's interpretation of the event elevates the status of Israel, as the miracle was not merely a command from God but a fulfillment of a pre-existing agreement made at creation. The Midrashic reference to Rabbi Yochanan ben B'tira underscores that the splitting of the sea was assured from the beginning of creation, indicating God's foresight and commitment to Israel's needs. This theological insight reflects the deep connection between divine providence and the Jewish people's destiny.

passage_content: ונבוא לביאור המדרש הנ"ל הה"ד פיה פתחה בחכמה וכו' עפי"מ דאיתא במדרש (ילקוט רמז רנ"ד) עה"פ ויסע משה את ישראל, א"ר סימון לא כל הרוצה לומר שירה אומר שירה, אלא כל מי שנעשה לו נס ואומר שירה בידוע שמוחלין לו על כל עונותיו, ולפי"ז ל"ק מדוע לא אמרו הראשונים שירה כשנעשה להם נס, דלא כל הרוצה לומר שירה אומר כ"א המוכן לכך מן השמים, וכעין שפי' הנועם אלימלך (ריש פ' ויחי) במאמר ר' חנינא בן דוסא ברכות דף ל"ד ע"ב) אם שגורה תפלתי בפי יודע אני שהוא מקובל ואם לאו יודע אני שהוא מטורף, דאם תפלתו שגורה ה"ה סימן שכבר הוכן תפלה זו בכח האין סוף ב"ה שיתפללו על חולה זה ובידוע שהיא מקובלת, ואם אין תפילתי שגורה נמצא לא הי' בכח הא"ס ב"ה שיתפלל רק הוא תפלה חדשה וכו', ועד"ז אפ"ל דהראשונים לא אמרו שירה שלא הי' מוכן להם השירה מן השמים, רק לישראל הי' מוכן השירה הזאת מששת ימי בראשית, וז"ש פיה פתחה בחכמה שזה השירה הי' בבחינת חכמה ע"ד איזהו חכם הרואה את הנולד (תמיד ל"ב ע"א) שהי' מוכן מתחלת הבריאה שיאמרו ישראל שירה וכמ"ש בראשית ברא אלקים את השמים וגו' ותרגם אונקלס בחוכמתא וגם השירה הזאת הוכנה להם בבחינת חכמה בשעת בריאת העולם ע"כ אמר הקב"ה לאלו הייתי מצפה שישראל היו מוכנים לכך מתחלת הבריאה שיאמרו שירה.
translation: And we come to explain the aforementioned Midrash, as it is written: "Her mouth opened in wisdom," etc. According to what is stated in the Midrash (Yalkut, Remez 694) on the verse "And Moses caused Israel to journey," Rabbi Simon said: "Not everyone who wishes to recite a song recites a song, but anyone for whom a miracle occurs and recites a song, it is known that all his sins are forgiven." According to this, it is not difficult to understand why the earlier ones did not recite a song when a miracle occurred for them, for not everyone who wishes to recite a song can do so, but only one who is prepared for it from Heaven. This is similar to the explanation of the Noam Elimelech (at the beginning of Parshat Vayechi) in the saying of Rabbi Hanina ben Dosa (Berakhot 34b): "If my prayer is fluent in my mouth, I know it is accepted; if not, I know it is rejected." For if his prayer is fluent, it is a sign that this prayer was already prepared by the Infinite Blessed One to pray for this sick person, and it is known that it is accepted. But if my prayer is not fluent, it means that the Infinite Blessed One did not have the power to pray; it is merely a new prayer, etc. Similarly, one could say that the earlier ones did not recite a song because the song was not prepared for them from Heaven; rather, this song was prepared for Israel from the six days of creation. Therefore, it is said: "Her mouth opened in wisdom," meaning that this song was in the aspect of wisdom, as it is said: "Who is wise? One who sees the outcome" (Tamid 32a), which was prepared from the beginning of creation for Israel to recite a song. And as it is written: "In the beginning, God created the heavens," etc., and Onkelos translates it as "with wisdom." And this song was also prepared for them in the aspect of wisdom at the time of the creation of the world. Therefore, the Holy One, Blessed be He, said: "For these, I was waiting, for Israel was prepared for this from the beginning of creation to recite a song."
summary: The passage discusses the concept that not everyone is permitted to sing praises to God, but only those who are divinely prepared for it, as indicated by the Midrash. It emphasizes that the ability to sing praise is a gift from Heaven, and that the first generations did not sing because they were not ready for it. In contrast, the song of Israel was prepared from the beginning of creation, reflecting a deep connection between divine wisdom and the readiness of the people to express gratitude. This highlights the idea that true praise arises from a state of spiritual preparedness, rooted in divine wisdom.

passage_content: ויאמר ה' אל משה מה תצעק אלי וגו', במד"ר (פ' כ"א סימן ג') הה"ד (ישעי' ס"ה) והיה טרם יקראו ואני אענה עוד הם מדברים ואני אשמע עכ"ד המדרש, וצ"ב דאדרבה הקב"ה מתאווה לתפלתן של ישראל ולתפלתן של צדיקים, ומ"ט לא הניחו הקב"ה למשרע"ה, שיתפלל.
translation: And the Lord said to Moses, "Why do you cry out to Me?" etc. In the Midrash (Parashat Chayei Sarah, Section 3), it is stated (Isaiah 65:24), "Before they call, I will answer; while they are yet speaking, I will hear." Thus concludes the Midrash. And it is puzzling, for on the contrary, the Holy One, blessed be He, desires the prayers of Israel and the prayers of the righteous. And why did the Holy One, blessed be He, not allow Moses to pray?
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the dialogue between God and Moses highlights the divine desire for the prayers of Israel and the righteous. The Midrash emphasizes that even before they call, God is ready to respond, illustrating the intimate relationship between the Divine and the faithful. The text raises a question about why God did not allow Moses to pray, suggesting a deeper theological insight into the nature of prayer and God's yearning for connection with His people. This reflects the Hasidic belief in the power of prayer and the importance of the spiritual bond between God and humanity.

passage_content: ויתבאר בהקדם דברי כ"ק אבא מארי זלה"ה בקדושת יו"ט (ר"פ נשא) עפימ"ש בספר בני יששכר במאמרי חנוכה לפרש עזרת אבותינו אתה הוא מעולם מגן ומושיע להם ולבניהם אחריהם בכל דור ודור, דהנה החילוק שבין עזרה לישועה, שלשון עזר יצדק על העזרה מבלי בקשה מקודם מהנעזר, ותשועה הוא כשמושיע המושיע אחר בקשת הנושע, כמד"א צעקה הנערה המאורשה ואין מושיע לה, והנה אבותינו שהיו צדיקים גדולים הנה היית עזרתם גם בטרם התפללו אליך, אבל בניהם אחריהם עכ"פ אחר התפלה יש לנו ישועה, וזהו עזר"ת אבותינו אתה הוא מעולם טרם יקראו, מגן ומושיע להם ולבניהם, שלבניהם לא הייתי אלא בבחי' מושיע עוד הם מדברים ואני אשמע עכ"ד הבני יששכר, והנה אנן יתמי דיתמי תש כחינו וחלש שכלינו בעבודת השי"ת, עד שאין בנו התגברות אפי' כדי להתפלל ולהתחנן ולשפוך שיח לבקש ממנו הישועה, ומכ"ש שאין אנו יכולים לעלות להגיע למדריגת אבותינו הקדושים שהשי"ת יעזר לנו בבחי' עזרה בלא בקשה, וא"כ מה יעשו איזובי קיר באיזה אופן נוכל להושע מאתו ית', כי באמת לא תמנו ולא כלו רחמיו וחסדיו המרובים גם עלינו, ומההכרח היא שהשי"ת יפן ברחמיו עלינו ויושיענו בבחינת אבותינו טרם שנקראו יעננו, אף בלא בקשה ישלח עזרו מקודש ומציון יסעדנו אף גם שאין אנו ראוים לכך, ולפי"ז ע"י שאנו במדרגה התחתונה כ"כ עד שאין אנו יכולין אפילו להתפלל ולשפוך תחנונים, ע"כ היא הנותנת שנושע בבחי' עזר כמו אבותינו הקדושים, וזה נ"ל פי' הפסוק כי שחה לעפר נפשינו ואין בנו יכולת להתפלל, כי דבקה לארץ בטננו היינו לארציות וגשמיות, ועי"ז שאנו נשפלים כ"כ ע"כ מההכרח קומה עזרתה לנו וגו' היינו שע"כ תושיענו בבחי' עזר אף בלא בקשות ותחנונים עכל"ק.
translation: And it will be explained in advance the words of our holy father, may his memory be blessed, regarding the sanctity of Yom Tov (Parashat Naso), as mentioned in the book "Bnei Yissachar" in the essays on Chanukah, to interpret "the help of our forefathers, You have been from the world a shield and savior for them and their children after them in every generation." Behold, the distinction between help and salvation: the term "help" can apply to assistance without prior request from the one being helped, while "salvation" refers to when the savior saves another upon the request of the one being saved, as it is said, "the maiden cried out and there was no savior for her." And behold, our forefathers, who were great righteous ones, their help was given even before they prayed to You, but their children after them, at least after prayer, we have salvation. And this is the meaning of "the help of our forefathers, You have been from the world before they call," a shield and savior for them and their children, for for their children I would not be but in the aspect of a savior, while they are still speaking and I will hear. Thus said the Bnei Yissachar. And behold, we, the orphans of orphans, our strength is weak and our intellect is feeble in the service of the Holy One, Blessed be He, to the extent that we have no strength even to pray and plead and pour out our hearts to request from Him salvation. How much more so we cannot rise to reach the level of our holy forefathers, that the Holy One, Blessed be He, should help us in the aspect of help without request. And if so, what will the wallflowers do? In what way can we be saved by Him? For truly, His mercies and abundant kindnesses have not been exhausted or finished even upon us. It is necessary that the Holy One, Blessed be He, turn in His mercy upon us and save us in the aspect of our forefathers before they call, He will answer us, even without request, He will send His holy help and from Zion He will support us, even though we are not worthy of it. And according to this, by the fact that we are in such a lowly state that we cannot even pray and pour out supplications, therefore it is given that we will be saved in the aspect of help like our holy forefathers. And this, I believe, is the meaning of the verse "for our soul is bowed down to the dust, and we have no ability to pray," for we are cleaved to the earth with our belly, meaning to our materiality and corporeality. And through the fact that we are so lowly, therefore it is necessary that "arise, help us," meaning that thus You will save us in the aspect of help even without requests and supplications.
summary: The passage discusses the distinction between "help" and "salvation," emphasizing that while the ancestors received divine assistance even before they prayed, their descendants require a plea for salvation. It highlights the current spiritual weakness of the descendants, who struggle to even pray, and expresses a deep reliance on God's mercy to provide help without their request. The author asserts that despite their lowly state, they hope for divine intervention akin to that of their ancestors, reflecting a belief in God's boundless compassion and readiness to assist even the unworthy.

passage_content: ומבואר מספה"ק שמישועתן של צדיקים נמשך צנור ומעיין ישועה לכל דורות ישראל, שיוושעו מעין ישועה זו כשיצטרכו אלי' עיי"ש, ואפשר דמזה הטעם הי' רצונו ית"ש שלא יתפלל משרע"ה בשעת קריעת ים סוף, אף שהקב"ה מתאווה לתפלתן של צדיקים, אבל בשביל תקנת דורות הבאים שיחסר להם כח התפלה, ויצטרכו לבחי' עזרה מבלי בקשה, ע"כ מנעו הקב"ה למשרע"ה מלהתפלל, כדי להמשיך בחי' זו לדורות שיזכו לטרם יקראו ואני אענה, וז"פ דברי המדרש ויאמר ה' אל משה מה תצעק אלי, ולכאורה קשה הרי הקב"ה מתאוה לתפלתן של צדיקים, לזה מתרץ המדרש הה"ד טרם יקראו ואני אענה עוד הם מדברים ואני אשמע, דלפעמים טרם יקראו וגו' ולפעמים עוד הם מדברים, ותליא במדריגתן של ישראל כנ"ל, וכדי להמשיך ישועה לדורות ישראל שיצטרכו אלי', ע"כ מנע הקב"ה רצון צדיק בענין זה ולא הניחו להתפלל.
translation: It is explained in the holy book that from the salvation of the righteous flows a channel and spring of salvation for all generations of Israel, so that they will be saved from this spring of salvation when they need it, as stated there. It is possible that for this reason, the Holy One, blessed be He, did not want Moshe to pray at the time of the splitting of the Sea of Reeds, even though the Holy One desires the prayers of the righteous. However, for the sake of the rectification of future generations, who will lack the strength of prayer and will need assistance without request, therefore the Holy One prevented Moshe from praying, in order to continue this aspect for generations that will merit it, before they call, and I will answer. This is the meaning of the words of the Midrash: "And the Lord said to Moshe, 'Why do you cry out to Me?'" At first glance, it is difficult, for the Holy One desires the prayers of the righteous. To this, the Midrash answers: "Before they call, I will answer; while they are yet speaking, I will hear." For sometimes it is before they call, and sometimes while they are yet speaking, and it depends on the level of the Israelites, as mentioned. And in order to continue salvation for the generations of Israel who will need it, therefore the Holy One withheld the desire of the righteous in this matter and did not allow him to pray.
summary: The passage discusses the concept that the salvation of the righteous creates a channel of divine assistance for all future generations of Israel, allowing them to receive help even without direct prayer. It explains that God refrained from allowing Moses to pray during the splitting of the Red Sea to ensure that future generations, who might lack the strength to pray, could still receive divine aid. This reflects the idea that God's response to prayer can depend on the spiritual level of the people, and emphasizes the importance of preemptive divine assistance. Ultimately, it highlights the balance between the desire for righteous prayer and the need for ongoing support for the Jewish people.

translation: In the Midrash Yalkut (Remez 243), it says: "Speak to the Children of Israel and let them journey," tell them to carry things from the heart. Last night they were saying, "Is there no burial in Egypt?" and now you are increasing in prayer, and this is a question.
summary: In the Midrash Yalkut, it is noted that the Israelites questioned the necessity of prayer when they previously expressed doubt about their fate in Egypt, asking if there were no graves there. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the power of prayer and the transformation of faith, as the Israelites move from despair to a reliance on divine intervention. The passage emphasizes the importance of turning to God in times of crisis, highlighting the dynamic relationship between human action and divine response. Ultimately, it illustrates the journey from doubt to faith, underscoring the significance of prayer in the process of redemption.

passage_content: ונראה לפרש בהקדם מה דאיתא במדרש ילקוט (רמז רל"ד) עה"פ והמים להם חומה, שירד ס"ם ואמר לפניו רבש"ע לא עבדו ישראל ע"ז במצרים ואתה עושה להם נסים וכו', השיב לו הקב"ה שועה שבעולם וכי לדעתם עבדוה והלא לא עבדוה אלא מתוך שעבוד ומתוך טירוף דעת, ואתה דן שוגג כמזיד ואונס כרצון, והקשו המפורשים דאין זה התנצלות באיסור עבודה זרה שהוא ביהרג ואל יעבור ואינו מועיל טענת אונס, אמנם אפ"ל דהנה ישראל עשו תשובה על כל חטאתם כדרז"ל בזוה"ק ובמד"ת, אלא שהי' קטרוג על תשובתם שלא תתקבל, דע"ז הוא מינות וכתיב בי' (משלי ב' י"ט) כל באיה לא ישובון, וזה שטען הס"ם שגם ישראל עבדו ע"ז במצרים ואף אם עשו תשובה א"א שתהי' תשובה שלימה וראי' להתקבל, דמה שעבדו ע"ז הי' בשביל שלא האמינו בהקב"ה א"כ תשובתם לא חשובה תשובה, וע"ז השיב לו הקב"ה שוטה שבעולם אתה דן שוגג כמזיד ואונס כרצון דמה שעבדו ע"ז הי' מחמת אונס ולא הי' מעורב בה שמץ מינות ומיעוט אמנה בהקב"ה, והגם שלא הותר באונס לעבוד עבודה זרה שהוא ביהרג ואל יעבור, אבל מ"מ מועיל תשובתם שכל מה שעבדו ע"ז הי' רק בשביל אונס ולא הי' בזה אף מחשבת מינות, ואנן קיי"ל דאם עובדין ע"ז מחמת פחד הריגה אין מלקין אותו וק"ו שאין ממיתין אותו כיון דהוי אונס כמ"ש ברמב"ם (פ"ה מה' יסוה"ת ה"ד), אלא שמחויב למסור עצמו להריגה בשביל מצות קידוש השם. וכן מבואר בדבריו בספר המצות (מצוה ט') בעשה דונקדשתי עיי"ש, א"כ מה שעבדו ישראל ע"ז במצרים כיון דהי' ע"י אונס לא נחשב לע"ז אלא שעברו אמצות עשה דונקדשתי ועל זה מועיל תשובה
translation: And it seems appropriate to explain in advance what is stated in the Midrash Yalkut (Remez 274) regarding the verse "and the waters were a wall for them," that the Satan came and said before the Holy One, Blessed be He, "Did Israel not serve idols in Egypt, and You are performing miracles for them, etc." The Holy One, Blessed be He, replied to him, "Fool of the world, do you think they served them willingly? They did not serve them except out of servitude and madness. And you judge the unwitting as if they were deliberate and coercion as if it were desire." The commentators have questioned that this is not a justification regarding the prohibition of idolatry, which one must be killed rather than transgress, and the claim of coercion is not effective. However, it can be said that Israel repented for all their sins, as our sages have said in the Zohar and in the Midrash. Yet, there was an accusation against their repentance that it would not be accepted, for idolatry is heresy, and it is written about it (Proverbs 2:19) "All who go to her will not return." This is what the Satan claimed, that Israel also served idols in Egypt, and even if they repented, it is impossible for their repentance to be complete and accepted. For the reason they served idols was because they did not believe in the Holy One, Blessed be He; therefore, their repentance is not considered true repentance. To this, the Holy One, Blessed be He, replied, "Fool of the world, you judge the unwitting as if they were deliberate and coercion as if it were desire, for the reason they served idols was due to coercion, and there was not even a hint of heresy or lack of faith in the Holy One, Blessed be He." And although it is not permitted under coercion to serve idols, which one must be killed rather than transgress, nevertheless, their repentance is effective, for all that they served idols was only because of coercion, and there was no thought of heresy in it. And we hold that if one serves idols out of fear of death, he is not lashed, and certainly, he is not put to death, since it is considered coercion, as stated by the Rambam (Hilchot Yesodei HaTorah 5:4). However, he is obligated to give his life for the sake of the commandment of sanctifying the Name. And so it is explained in his words in the Book of Commandments (Commandment 9) regarding the positive commandment "And you shall sanctify Me," as stated there. Therefore, what Israel did in serving idols in Egypt, since it was due to coercion, is not considered idolatry, but rather they transgressed the positive commandment "And you shall sanctify Me," and for this, repentance is effective.
summary: The passage discusses the theological implications of the Israelites' worship of idols in Egypt, emphasizing that their actions were driven by coercion and mental turmoil rather than genuine belief. It argues that since their idolatry was not rooted in true faith or intention, their repentance is valid and can be accepted by God. The text highlights the distinction between sin committed under duress and intentional wrongdoing, asserting that the former does not carry the same weight of guilt. Ultimately, it conveys that the Israelites' return to God is meaningful despite their past, as their idolatry was not a reflection of their true beliefs.

passage_content: מבואר דזכו ישראל לנס של קריעת ים סוף ע"י התשובה ולולא זאת הי' הס"ם ושרו של מצרים נוצח בטענת מה בין אלו לאלו הללו עוע"ז והללו עוע"ז, והנה התשובה תולה בנקודה שבלב אשר אין שום נברא יכול להבחין אמיתתה כ"א הבוית"ש, וכמ"ש הרמב"ם ז"ל בה' תשובה (פ"ב ה"ב) ומה היא התשובה וכו' ויעיד עליו יודע תעלומות שלא ישוב לזה החטא לעולם, והגם שהתוס' (שבת י"ב ע"ב ד"ה שאין) כתבו שהמלאכים יודעים מחשבות שבלב אדם, אבל וודאי שעומק המחשבה והנקודה שבלב אין יודע רק הקב"ה לבדו, וגם על עצם התשובה שתתקבל לא הסכים כ"א הבוית"ש, כדאיתא במדרש ילקוט (תהלים כ"ה רמז תש"ב) שאלו לחכמה חוטא מה עונשו א"ל חטאים תרדוף רעה, שאלו לנבואה חוטא מה עונשו א"ל הנפש החוטאת היא תמות, שאלו לתורה וכו' א"ל יביא אשם ויתכפר לו, שאלו להקב"ה חוטא מה עונשו א"ל יעשה תשובה ויתכפר לו וכו', וכמו"כ לעניננו הודיעו הקב"ה למשה שאין הדבר תלוי' אלא בתשובה.
translation: It is explained that Israel merited the miracle of the splitting of the Sea of Reeds through repentance, and were it not for this, the accuser and the minister of Egypt would have been victorious with the argument of what is the difference between these and those, these idols and those idols. Behold, repentance is dependent on the point in the heart, which no created being can discern its truth except for the Holy One, blessed be He, as the Rambam writes in Hilchot Teshuvah (Chapter 2, Halacha 2), "What is repentance?" etc., and the One who knows the hidden will testify that he will never return to this sin. And although the Tosafot (Shabbat 12b, s.v. "that the angels") wrote that the angels know the thoughts in a person's heart, certainly the depth of thought and the point in the heart is known only to the Holy One, blessed be He alone. And regarding the essence of the repentance that will be accepted, only the Holy One, blessed be He, agreed, as it is stated in the Midrash Yalkut (Psalms 25, Remez 252) that they asked wisdom, "What is the punishment of a sinner?" It replied, "Evil pursues sinners." They asked prophecy, "What is the punishment of a sinner?" It replied, "The soul that sins shall die." They asked the Torah, etc., and it replied, "He should bring a guilt offering and he will be atoned for." They asked the Holy One, blessed be He, "What is the punishment of a sinner?" He replied, "Let him repent and he will be atoned for," etc. Likewise, concerning our matter, the Holy One, blessed be He informed Moses that the matter depends only on repentance.
summary: The passage emphasizes that the miraculous splitting of the Red Sea for the Israelites was a result of their repentance, highlighting the unique and profound nature of true repentance that only God can fully understand. It contrasts the perspectives of various spiritual authorities on the consequences of sin, ultimately affirming that only God offers the possibility of forgiveness through repentance. This underscores the centrality of heartfelt repentance in the relationship between humanity and the Divine, as it is the key to redemption and divine mercy.

passage_content: ובזה יתבאר דברי המדרש דבר אל בנ"י ויסעו שיסיעו דברים מלבן ויעשו תשובה על החטאים, וז"ש רש"י ז"ל עלי הדבר תלוי שענין התשובה הוא דבר התלוי רק בהקב"ה כי הוא לבדו ית"ש מכיר הנקודה שבלב ומסכים על התשובה כנ"ל ובזכות התשובה זכו לקריעת ים סוף, וז"ש במדרש א"ל משה ומה עלי לעשות, א"ל הקב"ה ואתה הרם את מטך ונטה את ידך וגו' עפימ"ד במשנה (ר"ה כ"ט ע"א) והי' כאשר ירים משה ידו וגבר ישראל וגו', וכי ידיו של משה עושות או שוברות מלחמה, אלא לומר לך כל זמן שהיו ישראל מסתכלין כלפי מעלה ומשעבדין את לבם לאביהם שבשמים היו מתגברין ואם לאו וכו', ולזה אמר הקב"ה למשה בקרי"ס ואתה הרם את מטך שישליך את המטה מידו להראות שאין ישראל צריכים לשום פעולה בענין הישועה רק שירים משה את ידיו ויסתכלו ישראל כלפי מעלה לשעבד את לבם לאביהם שבשמים ואז מתגברין על כל המצירין להם ואין הדבר תלוי אלא בתשובה.
translation: And this will clarify the words of the Midrash: "Speak to the Children of Israel and they shall journey," meaning they should engage in repentance for their sins. This is what Rashi, may his memory be blessed, says: "The matter is dependent on Me," for the essence of repentance is something that depends solely on the Holy One, blessed be He, for He alone knows the point in the heart and agrees to the repentance as mentioned. And through the merit of repentance, they were worthy of the splitting of the Sea of Reeds. This is what the Midrash says: Moses said, "What shall I do?" The Holy One, blessed be He, said to him, "And you lift up your staff and stretch out your hand," etc. As it is explained in the Mishnah (Rosh Hashanah 29a), "And it was when Moses lifted his hand, Israel prevailed," etc. But do Moses' hands make or break the war? Rather, it is to tell you that as long as Israel looked upward and subjugated their hearts to their Father in Heaven, they would prevail; and if not, etc. Therefore, the Holy One, blessed be He, said to Moses at the splitting of the sea, "And you lift up your staff," to show that Israel does not need any action regarding salvation, only that Moses should raise his hands and Israel should look upward to subjugate their hearts to their Father in Heaven, and then they will prevail over all their oppressors, and the matter depends solely on repentance.
summary: The passage emphasizes the centrality of repentance (teshuva) in the relationship between the Jewish people and God, highlighting that true repentance is solely dependent on God's recognition of the heart's intentions. It illustrates that the miraculous events, such as the splitting of the Red Sea, are contingent upon the people's spiritual focus and their submission to God. The text underscores that Israel's victory in battle is not due to physical actions but rather their spiritual alignment and devotion to God, reinforcing the idea that divine assistance is granted when the heart is directed towards Him. Ultimately, the message conveys that the key to overcoming challenges lies in sincere repentance and a heartfelt connection to the Divine.
