passage_content: ואיתא במדרש שמואל (אבות סו"פ ששי משנה י"א) כל מה שברא הקב"ה בעולמו לא ברא אלא לכבודו שנאמר כל הנקרא בשמי ולכבודי בראתיו יצרתיו אף עשיתיו, ואומר ה' ימלוך לעולם ועד, ופי' המדרש שמואל אמר עוד ואומר ה' ימלוך לעולם ועד, הנראה שאין לו קשר כלל עם האמור, ואפשר שהכוונה וכו' דתינח בשאר העולמות שלא בראם אלא לכבודו לפי שכולם מעריצין ומקדישין את שם הא' המלך הגדול הגבור והנורא, אמנם עולם העשי' אשר ראה ראינו כי גברה יד סט"א ויצר לב האדם רע מנעוריו להכעיס את בוראו, א"כ אין בריאת עוה"ז לכבודו ית' וטוב לו שלא נברא, לזה תירץ כי אף אם עתה רבו כמו רבו עבדים המתפרצים למרות עיני כבודו, עכ"ז לעתיד לבוא יהיה ה' אחד ושמו אחד, ולז"א ה' ימלוך לעולם ועד ואז יהי' כל העולם לאחד לקרוא בשם ה' וכו', נמצא שאף עולם העשיה לא בראו אלא לכבודו עכ"ל, וידוע שגאולה העתידה תלוי בתשובה, וכמ"ש הרמב"ם ז"ל (ה' תשובה פ"ז ה"ה) אין ישראל נגאלין אלא בתשובה וכבר הבטיחה תורה שסוף ישראל לעשות תשובה בסוף גלותן ומיד הן נגאלין, ובזה יובן סיום דברי המדרש כששאל משה מהקב"ה ומה עלי לעשות והשיב לו הבורא יתברך שמו ואתה הרם את מטך ונטה את ידך ורמז לו שאין הדבר תלוי אלא בתשובה כנ"ל, באותה שעה אמרו ישראל ה' ימלוך לעולם ועד כי השיגו ישראל שגם גאולה העתידה תליא בתשובה ובזכות התשובה נזכה לבחי' ה' ימלוך לעולם ועד שיהי' מלא כל הארץ כבודו ואף עולם העשי' כנ"ל.
translation: It is stated in the Midrash Shmuel (Avot, chapter 6, Mishnah 11) that everything the Holy One, blessed be He, created in His world, He created only for His honor, as it is said, "All who are called by My name, and for My glory I have created him, I have formed him, yes, I have made him." And it says, "The Lord shall reign forever and ever." The Midrash Shmuel further explains and says, "The Lord shall reign forever and ever," which seems to have no connection at all with what was said. It is possible that the intention is that this applies to the other worlds, which He did not create except for His honor, since they all revere and sanctify the name of the One, the great, mighty, and awesome King. However, in the world of action, we see that the hand of the Other Side has prevailed, and the inclination of man's heart is evil from his youth, to provoke his Creator. Therefore, the creation of this world is not for His honor, and it would have been better for him not to have been created. To this, it is answered that even if now there are many, like many rebellious servants who defy the honor of His glory, nevertheless, in the future, the Lord will be one and His name one. This is to say, "The Lord shall reign forever and ever," and then the whole world will be united to call upon the name of the Lord, etc. Thus, even the world of action was created only for His honor. It is known that the future redemption depends on repentance, as the Rambam, may his memory be blessed, wrote (Laws of Repentance, chapter 7, halacha 5) that Israel will not be redeemed except through repentance, and the Torah has already promised that in the end, Israel will repent at the end of their exile, and immediately they will be redeemed. In this, the conclusion of the Midrash's words will be understood when Moses asked the Holy One, blessed be He, "What shall I do?" and the Creator, blessed be His name, answered him, "And you lift up your staff and stretch out your hand," hinting to him that the matter depends only on repentance, as mentioned. At that time, Israel said, "The Lord shall reign forever and ever," for they understood that the future redemption is dependent on repentance, and by virtue of repentance, we will merit the aspect of "The Lord shall reign forever and ever," that His glory will fill the whole earth, even the world of action, as mentioned.
summary: The passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel emphasizes that everything created by God is for His honor, as stated in the verse "For My glory I have created it." It acknowledges the challenges of the physical world, where human inclination often leads to sin, seemingly contradicting the notion of creation for divine glory. However, it reassures that in the future, God's sovereignty will be universally recognized, and redemption is contingent upon repentance, as highlighted by the teachings of the Rambam. Ultimately, the text conveys that through sincere repentance, Israel will achieve a state where God's glory fills the earth, including the realm of action.

passage_content: ויבואו בני ישראל בתוך הים ביבשה, במד"ר (פרשה כ"א סי' י') אם בים למה ביבשה ואם ביבשה למה בתוך הים אלא מכאן אתה למד שלא נקרע להם הים עד שבאו לתוכו עד חוטמן ואח"כ נעשה להם יבשה, ובמקו"א איתא בדרז"ל שלא נקרע הים עד שקפץ נחשון בן עמינדב לתוך הים, ואפ"ל דאין בזה סתירה, דנחשון הי' הראשון שהראה להם הדרך אולם לא נתייבשו המים עד שכל ישראל קפצו לתוך הים.
translation: And the children of Israel came into the sea on dry land, as it is stated in the Midrash (Parashat 21, section 10): If they were in the sea, why on dry land? And if on dry land, why in the sea? Rather, from here you learn that the sea did not split for them until they came into it up to their ankles, and then dry land was made for them. And in another place, it is stated in the teachings of our sages that the sea did not split until Nachshon ben Amminadav jumped into the sea. And it can be said that there is no contradiction in this, for Nachshon was the first to show them the way, but the waters did not become dry until all of Israel jumped into the sea.
summary: The passage discusses the miraculous crossing of the Red Sea by the Israelites, emphasizing that the sea did not part until they demonstrated faith by stepping into the water. It highlights the role of Nachshon ben Amminadav, who was the first to leap into the sea, symbolizing the importance of taking initiative in faith. The text conveys a key Hasidic concept that divine intervention often requires human action and trust, illustrating the relationship between faith and the unfolding of miracles. Ultimately, it teaches that true redemption comes through collective commitment and courage in the face of uncertainty.

passage_content: ולבאר הענין מדוע לא נקרע הים עד שקפצו לתוכו ובאו במים עד חוטמן, אפ"ל עפימ"ש בספה"ק דברי חיים (פ' נח) עה"כ קץ כל בשר בא לפני, דאיתא בזוה"ק דעל כל החטאים מהני תשובה, לבר מההוא חטא הידוע פגם הברית מדת היסוד דלא מהני כ"א בתיובתא סגי, וטעם הדבר מבואר בספרים דהחטא פוגם האדם במדותיו, ובמדה שחוטא מסיר עצמו משרשי הקדושה וכו' ובעשותו תשובה מביא חיות חדש משורשו אל האבר והצנור שנחלש וכו', אך בחטא החמור הנ"ל ר"ל הוא כמסיר שרשו לגמרי כמבואר בספה"ק, ולכן כמעט אין לו תרופה, ואך בקושי תשובה מעורר אדם הנהגה רצונית למעלה מהטבע יחון ונעתר לה' גם בשובו מחטא זה. ולעיל מזה כתב עיקר הדבר למסור נפשו להקב"ה בהשתוקקות רב עד דכדוכה של נפש, ומתוקן בזה מה שחרבו העולמות ובא עד הקץ יעייש"ד.
translation: To explain the matter of why the sea did not split until they jumped into it and came into the water up to their nostrils, one can say, as is mentioned in the holy book Divrei Chaim (Parashat Noach), regarding the verse "The end of all flesh has come before Me," that it is stated in the Zohar that for all sins, repentance is effective, except for that known sin, the blemish of the covenant, the attribute of the foundation, which is only rectified through a complete return. The reason for this is explained in the books that the sin blemishes a person in their attributes, and in the attribute in which one sins, they remove themselves from the roots of holiness, etc. And by doing repentance, they bring new vitality from their root to the limb and the channel that has weakened, etc. However, in the aforementioned grave sin, it is as if one completely removes their root, as explained in the holy books, and therefore they have almost no remedy. Only with difficulty does repentance awaken a person to a voluntary conduct above nature, and they will be graciously answered by the Holy One, blessed be He, even when returning from this sin. Furthermore, it is written above that the main thing is to give one's soul to the Holy One, blessed be He, with great longing, even to the point of the soul's anguish, and in this, what has caused the worlds to be destroyed is rectified, and it reaches the end.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the Israelites' leap into the sea before it parted, emphasizing the concept of faith and the necessity of self-sacrifice in serving God. It references the Zohar's teaching that while most sins can be rectified through repentance, the sin of violating the covenant (related to the foundation of holiness) is particularly severe and often lacks remedy. True repentance in this case requires a profound commitment and a willingness to transcend natural limitations, invoking divine mercy. Ultimately, the text highlights the importance of deep spiritual yearning and dedication to God as a means of restoring one's connection to holiness.

passage_content: והנה אמרז"ל במדרש (ילקוט ראובני) שהי' קטרוג גדול על ישראל בעמדם על הים והשר של מצרים והס"מ קטרגו הללו עובדי ע"ז והללו עובדי ע"ז הללו מג"ע והללו מג"ע, ובאמת היו ישראל גדורים מעריות במצרים כאמרז"ל במד"ר (ויק"ר פ' ל"ב סי' ה') אחת היתה ופירסמה הכתוב, ואיתא בזוה"ק שאף מאיסור נדה הוזהרו ואף שלא היו מצווין עדיין ומכ"ש מעריות בפועל, אמנם אם מידי עבירה נשמרו מידי הרהור לא ניצולו. וטומאת המקום גרם, שהיו במצרים ערות הארץ במ"ט שערי טומאה ובלי תורה לא היו יכולין להטהר ממחשבות והרהורים רעים, והרבינו יונה כתב דבעבר ושנה גם מחשבה רעה הקב"ה מצרפה למעשה, וכמו"כ נכשלו בע"ז לצד גודל טומאת הארץ, לכן על מה שנכשלו בע"ז הי' התיקון מ"ש בהוציאך את העם ממצרים תעבדון את האלקים על ההר הזה שקבלו אח"כ את התוה"ק וע"ש זכות העתיד נתלה להם, ועל הקטרוג הללו מג"ע הי' תיקונם ע"י מסירת נפש, לכן הוצרכו למסור נפשם ולקפוץ בתוך הים, ובזה עזרם הבוכ"ע וניצולו מהקטרוג ועברו הים בחרבה.
translation: And behold, our sages have said in the Midrash (Yalkut Reuveni) that there was a great accusation against Israel as they stood by the sea, and the minister of Egypt and the Satan accused them: these are idol worshippers, and those are idol worshippers; these are from forbidden relations, and those are from forbidden relations. In truth, Israel was guarded from forbidden relations in Egypt, as our sages have said in the Midrash (Vayikra Rabbah, Parashah 32, Section 5): there was one and the scripture made it known. And it is stated in the Zohar that they were even warned against the prohibition of Niddah, even though they were not yet commanded, and certainly from forbidden relations in practice. However, if they were guarded from transgressions, they were not saved from thoughts of sin. The impurity of the place caused it, for they were in Egypt, the nakedness of the land, in the forty-nine gates of impurity, and without the Torah, they could not purify themselves from evil thoughts and reflections. Rabbi Yonah wrote that in the past and in the future, even a bad thought is considered as an action by the Holy One, Blessed be He. Likewise, they stumbled in idol worship due to the great impurity of the land. Therefore, for what they stumbled in idol worship, the rectification was what is stated: "When you bring out the people from Egypt, you shall serve God on this mountain," where they later received the Torah and the merit of the future was attached to them. And for the accusation of these forbidden relations, their rectification was through self-sacrifice; therefore, they needed to sacrifice themselves and jump into the sea. In this, the Blessed One helped them, and they were saved from the accusation and crossed the sea on dry land.
summary: The passage discusses the significant accusations against the Israelites as they stood by the sea, with the Egyptian minister and the Satan claiming that both groups were idolaters. Despite the Israelites' adherence to prohibitions against immorality in Egypt, they were still vulnerable to negative thoughts due to the spiritual impurity of their environment. Their eventual redemption came through their willingness to sacrifice themselves by jumping into the sea, which allowed them to overcome these accusations and ultimately receive the Torah, signifying a profound transformation and spiritual elevation.

passage_content: ובמד"ר (פרשה כ"א סי' ה') וישאו בני ישראל את עיניהם והנה מצרים נוסע אחריהם ראו שרן של מצרים פורח באויר, כיון שראו אותו נתייראו הרבה שנא' ויראו מאוד, לכאורה מדוע נתייראו כ"כ הלא בכל מלחמה כן הוא שהשרים של מעלה באים לעזרת אומתם, ואפ"ל בכוונת הענין דהנה שורש החטאים ומדות רעות שנכשלים בה בנ"א בא מכח שר של האומה שדרים בה, דכ"א י"ל מדה רעה אחרת וכמו שכתב בספה"ק מאור ושמש (הו"ד לעיל פ' וארא), וכשיצאו בנ"י ממצרים השיגו עד היכן משוקעים בטומאת מצרים, ולצד זה הי' יראתם משר של מצרים נוסע אחריהם, דמפני שראו וימרו על ים בים סוף. שמקצתם לא אבו שמוע בקול ה', הבינו שזהו מהשפעה רע של שר מצרים ועדיין לא יצאו ממנו לגמרי, וז"ש שרן של מצרים נוסע אחריהם שהשפעתו הרע עדיין נדבק בהם ונוסע אחריהם וע"כ נתייראו הרבה מאוד, ובזה פי' הכתוב הושיעני אלקים כי באו מים עד נפש, דהנה מים ירמוז על אומה"ע, וכמ"ש המפורשים הפסוק מקולות מים רבים אדירים משברי ים, דהכוונה על האומה"ע, והשפעתם הרעה הגיע עד הנפש של כ"א מישראל וגם להגדולים שהם נפש העם, השי"ת ירחם עלינו ויצילנו מהם כי כבר באו מים עד נפש. וכתב במסילת ישרים ע"ד הגמרא (ב"ב דף ע"ח ע"ב) על כן יאמרו המושלים, אלו המושלים ביצרם, באו חשבון בואו ונחשוב חשבונו של עולם הפסד מצוה כנגד שכרה ושכר עבירה כנגד עבירה, דלכאורה כל אחד צריך לחשוב חשבון הזה ומדוע אמר המושלים ביצרם דייקא, ופירש הוא ז"ל דהמקושר ודבוק בהבלי עוה"ז אין במציאות שיעשה חשבון אמיתי וצודק מפני שמשוחד אל תאוותיו ורצוניותיו, וז"ש ע"כ יאמרו המושלים ביצרם דייקא, שהם יכולים לחשוב חשבונו של עולם, ומי שאינו בגדר זה אינו יכול לעשות חשבון אמיתי עכ"ד, ובעוה"ר בזמנינו אלה מי יאמר זכיתי לבי טהרתי מחטאי, ומי יוכל להתפאר שהוא מהמושלים ביצרם, ואין בידינו לחדש עצות ודרכים חדשים בשמירת התוה"ק ובעבדות הבוב"ה וכדומה, דחשבונו של עולם יכולים לחשוב רק המושלים ביצרם דייקא, ואנו אין לנו אלא דרכי אבותינו ורבותינו הקדושים שהנחילו לנו דרך האמת ומפיהם אנו חיים שהם היו המושלים ביצרם באמת ובעוה"ר המה הלכו למנוחות ואותנו עזבו לאנחות, ואין לנו רק לילך בעקבי הצאן שהפסיעות והעקביים ניכרים.
translation: And in the Midrash (Parashat 21, Siman 5), the children of Israel lifted their eyes, and behold, the Egyptians were pursuing them; they saw the minister of Egypt flying in the air. When they saw him, they were very afraid, as it is said, "and they were very afraid." At first glance, why were they so afraid? Is it not the case that in every war, the ministers from above come to assist their nation? And it could be understood in the context that the root of sins and bad traits that people stumble upon comes from the power of the minister of the nation that dwells within them, for each one has a different bad trait, as it is written in the holy books Maor and Shemesh (quoted above, Parashat Va'era). And when the children of Israel left Egypt, they realized how deeply they were immersed in the impurity of Egypt. Alongside this, their fear of the minister of Egypt pursuing them was because they saw and rebelled against the sea at the Sea of Suf, as some of them did not want to listen to the voice of Hashem. They understood that this was due to the bad influence of the minister of Egypt, and they had not yet completely extricated themselves from him. Therefore, it is said, "the minister of Egypt is pursuing them," that his bad influence was still clinging to them and pursuing them, and thus they were very afraid. In this, the verse is explained: "Save me, O God, for the waters have come up to my soul," for waters hint at nations, as the commentators explain the verse, "from the voices of many waters, mighty waves of the sea," referring to the nations, and their bad influence reached the very soul of each one of Israel, even to the great ones who are the soul of the people. May the Holy One, blessed be He, have mercy on us and save us from them, for the waters have already come up to my soul. And it is written in Mesilat Yesharim regarding the Gemara (Baba Batra 78b) that therefore the rulers will say, those who rule over their desires, "Come, let us calculate the account of the world: the loss of a mitzvah against its reward and the reward of a transgression against the transgression." At first glance, everyone should think about this account, and why is it specifically said, "the rulers over their desires"? He explained that one who is connected and attached to the vanities of this world cannot truly and justly make an account because he is biased towards his desires and wants. Therefore, it is said, "the rulers over their desires," specifically, for they can think about the account of the world, and one who is not in this category cannot make a true account. In our times, who can say, "I have merited to purify my heart from my sins," and who can boast that he is among those who rule over their desires? We have no ability to innovate new advice and new ways in the observance of the Torah and in the service of the Blessed One, and so on, for the account of the world can only be thought of by those who rule over their desires specifically. We have nothing but the ways of our forefathers and our holy teachers who bequeathed to us the path of truth, and from their words we live, for they were truly the rulers over their desires, and in our times they have gone to rest and left us in anguish. We have no choice but to walk in the footsteps of the flock, where the steps and the footprints are evident.
summary: The passage discusses the fear of the Israelites upon seeing the Egyptian forces pursuing them, emphasizing that their fear stemmed from the lingering influence of the Egyptian spiritual forces, which represented their past sins and negative traits. It highlights the idea that each nation has a spiritual leader whose negative traits can affect its people, and the Israelites were still under the influence of the Egyptian "serpent." The text also reflects on the importance of self-reflection and the ability to make true moral calculations, which is only possible for those who have mastered their desires. Ultimately, it calls for reliance on the teachings of the righteous ancestors to navigate the challenges of spiritual life.

passage_content: ויסר את אופן מרכבותיו וינהגהו בכבדות, במדרש ילקוט (הובא ברש"י ז"ל) מחמת האש שלמעלן נשרפו גלגלין שלמטן והיו מוטות, ומרכבות רצות ונכנסות על כרחן וכו', דרך ארץ המרכבות נמשכות אחר הפרדים, עכשיו מרכבות מושכות את הפרדים עכ"ד המדרש, ראוי להבין למה עשה ה' נס זה לשנות מדרך הרגיל שהמרכבות נמשכות אחר הפרדים ועכשיו מרכבות מושכות את הפרדים ומה צורך בנס הזה.
translation: And He turned the manner of His chariots and drove them heavily. In the Midrash Yalkut (brought in Rashi, may his memory be blessed), it is said that because of the fire from above, the wheels below were burned and were bent, and the chariots ran and entered against their will, etc. Normally, the chariots are drawn after the mules, but now the chariots are pulling the mules, thus said the Midrash. It is fitting to understand why the Holy One, blessed be He, performed this miracle to change the usual way that the chariots are drawn after the mules, and now the chariots are pulling the mules, and what is the need for this miracle.
summary: The passage discusses a miraculous event where the chariots, typically pulled by horses, are instead seen pulling the horses due to a divine intervention. This reversal of the natural order serves to highlight God's sovereignty over creation and the extraordinary nature of His miracles. The text prompts reflection on the purpose of such a miracle, suggesting that it illustrates a deeper theological insight into the relationship between the divine and the natural world, emphasizing that God's will can transcend the established norms of reality.

passage_content: ב) ילקוט (רמז רמ"א) בשעה שבקש הקב"ה להטביע את מצרים, עמד עוזא שר של מצרים לפני הקב"ה ואמר לפניו רבש"ע נקראת צדיק וישר וכו' למה אתה רוצה להטביע מצרים כלום הטביעו בני מבניך או הרגו מהם וכו' עכ"ד המדרש, והיא פליאה נשגבה איך יתכן לטעון שיקרא קמי שמיא הלא גזרו בגלוי כל הבן הילוד היאורה תשליכוהו ואמרו רז"ל (ב"ר פ' צ"ז ס"ה) ששים רבוא ילדי ישראל הושלכו ליאור גם הרגו הרבה ורמסו בטיט כמבואר בדברי חז"ל, ואיך יטעון שקר לפני הקב"ה.
translation: B) Yalkut (Remez RMA) At the time when the Holy One, blessed be He, sought to drown Egypt, Uzza, the minister of Egypt, stood before the Holy One and said before Him, "Master of the Universe, You are called righteous and upright, etc. Why do You want to drown Egypt? Did they drown any of Your children or kill any of them?" Thus concludes the Midrash. And it is a wondrous astonishment how it is possible to claim such a thing before Heaven, for it was openly decreed, "Every son that is born you shall cast into the river," and our Sages have said (Bereishit Rabbah, chapter 67, section 65) that six hundred thousand Israelite children were cast into the river, and many were killed and trampled in the mud, as explained in the words of our Sages. And how can he make a false claim before the Holy One, blessed be He?
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author reflects on a midrashic account where the angel Uzza defends Egypt before God, questioning why He would drown them despite their past suffering. This raises profound theological questions about justice and divine judgment, particularly in light of the suffering inflicted upon the Israelites. The text highlights the tension between God's mercy and the reality of human cruelty, emphasizing the complexity of divine justice in the face of historical atrocities. Ultimately, it invites contemplation on the nature of righteousness and the moral implications of divine decisions.

passage_content: ג) במדרש ילקוט (רמז רל"ד) והמים להם חומה מלמד שירד ס"מ, ואמר רבש"ע לא עבדו ישראל ע"ז במצרים ואתה עושה להם נסים, מה הללו עובדי ע"ז אף הללו עובדי ע"ז, אמר לו הקב"ה שוטה שבעולם והלא לא עבדו אלא מתוך שעבוד ומתוך טירוף דעת ואתה דן שוגג כמזיד ואונס כרצון, וקשה מדוע תלה זה בזה דכמו שהם עוע"ז גם ישראל כן, ואם יש בטענה זו ממש יספיק אם יאמר הללו עוע"ז ומ"ט הוצרך לתלותו במה שהמצריים עוע"ז, גם יש להבין התירוץ שישראל לא עבדו אלא מתוך שעבוד והיו אנוסים הלא ע"ז ביהרג ואל יעבור וליתא לטענת אונס.
translation: In the Midrash Yalkut (Remez 244), it is taught that "the waters were a wall for them," which indicates that a certain measure of divine intervention occurred. The Holy One, Blessed be He, said, "The Israelites did not serve idols in Egypt, and yet You perform miracles for them. These [Egyptians] are idol worshippers, and these [Israelites] are also idol worshippers." The Holy One, Blessed be He, replied, "Fool of the world! They did not serve idols except out of servitude and madness, and you judge the unwitting as if they were deliberate and the coerced as if they were willing." It is difficult to understand why He connected this to that, as if they are idol worshippers, so too the Israelites. If there is substance to this claim, it would suffice to say that these are idol worshippers. And why was it necessary to connect it to the fact that the Egyptians are idol worshippers? Furthermore, one must understand the response that the Israelites did not serve idols except out of servitude and were coerced, for regarding idol worship, one should be killed rather than transgress, and the claim of coercion does not hold.
summary: The passage discusses a Midrashic interpretation regarding the Israelites' worship of idols in Egypt, emphasizing that their actions were not genuine but rather a result of oppression and mental turmoil. It highlights the distinction between intentional sin and actions performed under duress, arguing that God recognizes the Israelites' lack of true agency in their idolatry. The text critiques the notion that both the Egyptians and Israelites are equally culpable, asserting that the Israelites' worship was coerced rather than willful. This reflects a broader Hasidic theme of divine compassion and understanding of human circumstances.

passage_content: ונראה ליישב בהקדם דברי רש"י ז"ל עה"כ ויקח שש מאות רכב בחור וגו', ומהיכן היו הבהמות הללו, אם תאמר משל מצרי הרי נאמר וימת כל מקנה מצרים, וא"ת משל ישראל והלא נאמר וגם מקנינו ילך עמנו, משל מי היו, מהירא את דבר ה' ע"כ, רואים מזה כמה גדולה התקלה לישראל אם היראים את דבר ה' הם עבדי פרעה, שאילולא הם לא הי' לו לפרעה במה להלחם עם ישראל, ועל כרחן צריכין למימר שהיו יראים את דבר ה' עכ"פ מיראת העונש שהרי הכתוב מעיד עליהם ככה, ואפשר שהם לא הטביעו ילדי ישראל וגם לא עבדו ע"ז, ועפי"ז שפיר טען עוזא שר של מצרים כלום הטביעו בני מבניך או הרגו מהם ורצה עכ"פ להציל היראי ה' כי אלו היראים את דבר ה' באמת לא היו מהטובעים וגם לא הרגו ילדי ישראל, אמנם מפני שהיו מעבדי פרעה ונכנעים אליו נחשבו גם הם כמוהו וכמאמר הכתוב מושל מקשיב על דבר שקר כל משרתיו רשעים, ואפשר שעד"ז הי' הס"מ מקטרג על ישראל, דבאמת בעת שעמדו ישראל על הים כבר נפרשו מע"ז, אמנם טענתו הו' עד"ז, דכמו הירא את דבר ה' מעבדי פרעה, נדונים אף על הרע שלא עשו בעצמם, אלא מפני שהם עבדי פרעה נחשבים כמוהו מטעם דמושל מקשיב על דבר שקר כל משרתיו רשעים, ולפי"ז הרי גם ישראל היו עבדים לפרעה ומה הללו עובדי ע"ז אף הללו עובדי ע"ז שצ"ל נחשבים כמוהו כמוהם, והשיב לו הקב"ה שוטה שבעולם והלא לא עבדו אלא מתוך שעבוד ומתוך טירוף הדעת ואתה דן שוגג כמזיד ואונס כרצון. דהרי מה שעבדו את פרעה לא מרצונם עשו זאת אלא שהיו אנוסים, אבל אלו היראים את דבר ה' מעצמם נעשו עבדים לפרעה ומרצונם הטוב השתתפו אליו לכך נחשבים כמוהו להיות נענשים על כל רעתו.
translation: And it seems appropriate to address at the outset the words of Rashi, may his memory be blessed, on the verse "And he took six hundred chosen chariots, etc." And from where were these animals? If you say they were from the Egyptians, it is stated, "And all the livestock of Egypt died." And if you say they were from Israel, behold, it is said, "And also our livestock will go with us." Whose were they? Those who feared the word of God, thus we see how great the calamity is for Israel if those who fear the word of God are the servants of Pharaoh. For had it not been for them, Pharaoh would not have had anything to fight against Israel. Therefore, we must say that they were at least afraid of the word of God out of fear of punishment, as the scripture testifies about them in this way. And it is possible that they did not drown the children of Israel and did not serve idols. Based on this, Ozah, the minister of Egypt, argued, "Did your children drown any of my children or kill any of them?" He wanted at least to save those who fear God, for those who truly fear the word of God were not among the drowners and did not kill the children of Israel. However, because they were servants of Pharaoh and submitted to him, they were also considered like him, as the verse states, "A ruler who listens to falsehood, all his servants are wicked." And it is possible that similarly, the accuser was slandering Israel, for at the time when Israel stood by the sea, they had already distanced themselves from idol worship. However, his claim was similar, that just as those who fear the word of God among the servants of Pharaoh are judged even for the evil they did not commit themselves, but because they are servants of Pharaoh, they are considered like him, for the reason that "A ruler who listens to falsehood, all his servants are wicked." According to this, Israel were also servants of Pharaoh, and just as those were idol worshippers, so too these are considered idol worshippers, and they are regarded as like him and like them. And the Holy One, blessed be He, responded to him, "Fool of the world! They did not serve except out of servitude and out of madness, and you judge the unwitting as if they were intentional and the coerced as if they were willing." For what they did in serving Pharaoh was not done willingly, but they were coerced. But those who fear the word of God became servants of Pharaoh of their own accord, and willingly participated with him; therefore, they are considered like him and are punished for all his evil.
summary: The passage discusses the theological implications of the Israelites' servitude to Pharaoh, emphasizing that even those who feared God were considered complicit due to their status as Pharaoh's servants. It highlights the severity of their situation, suggesting that their fear of divine punishment did not absolve them from the consequences of their association with evil. The text argues that while the Israelites may not have actively harmed others, their voluntary submission to Pharaoh's authority rendered them guilty by association. Ultimately, it conveys the idea that true fear of God should lead to a rejection of idolatry and oppression, rather than complicity in wrongdoing.

passage_content: ונקדים לפרש הכתוב (בשה"ש) לסוסתי ברכבי פרעה דמיתיך רעיתי, וראוי להבין ענין המשל גם הקישור אל הפסוק שלמעלה צאי לך בעקבי הצאן וגו', ובספה"ק נועם אלימלך בליקוטים פי' הכתוב לסוסתי ברכבי פרעה דמיתיך רעיתי, היות גבי פרעה שינה ב"ה את הסדר, דרך הסוסים מושכין וכו' וכאן הקרון מושך וכו' וזהו לסוסתי כמו הסוסים ברכבי פרעה היו בהיפך הטבע, כן דמיתיך רעיתי, זאת אומרת כנ"י להשי"ת כן דמיתיך כי הצדיקים עושין כן, שהקב"ה גוזר גזירה והצדיק מבטל, והצדיק גוזר והשי"ת מקיים נמצא העולם מתנהג לפי רצון הצדיק עכל"ק, והנה ידוע מש"כ בסה"ק דגל מחנה אפרים פרשת וארא דפשט הפסוק משתנה לפי בחי' הדור עיי"ש (כוונתו בדבר שאינו נוגע להלכה כמובן), ובדורינו השפל אפ"ל כוונת הכתוב עפ"י מה שאמרו רז"ל בגמרא (ביצה דף ל"ז ע"א) בהמה וכלים כרגלי הבעלים, והנה הסוסים היו של יראי ה' והרכב של פרעה ולפי דרך הטבע מהראוי שהסוסים יוליכו את הרכב, אבל לא כן עשה ה' כי אם הרכב משך הסוסים ואף בעליהם נמשכו עמהם [ולקושטא דמילתא תמיד כן הוא שאם יראי ה' מתחברים עם רשעים אז מתהפך הגלגל והרשעים הם מנהיגים את היראי ה', אבל דא עקא שלא תמיד אפשר לראות זאת באתגליא] אולם אז בקרי"ס הי' התגלות גדול וראו במו עיניהם הנס הזה ועי"ז ידעו ישראל להתרחק גם מחבורתם ויש בו גם הוראה לדורות.
translation: And we will begin to explain the verse (in Song of Songs) "As a mare among the chariots of Pharaoh, so did I compare you, my beloved." It is fitting to understand the matter of the parable and also the connection to the preceding verse "Go forth in the footsteps of the flock, etc." In the holy book Noam Elimelech in the Likutim, the verse "As a mare among the chariots of Pharaoh, so did I compare you, my beloved" is explained in light of the fact that regarding Pharaoh, the Holy One, blessed be He, changed the order; normally the horses pull, etc., but here the chariot pulls, etc. This is what is meant by "as a mare," for the horses in the chariots of Pharaoh were contrary to nature. So too, "so did I compare you, my beloved," meaning the Jewish people to the Holy One, blessed be He, "so did I compare you," for the righteous act in this way, that the Holy One, blessed be He, decrees a decree and the righteous nullify it, and the righteous decree and the Holy One, blessed be He, fulfills it. Thus, the world is conducted according to the will of the righteous, as explained at length. And it is known from what is written in the holy book Degel Machaneh Ephraim in Parashat Va'era that the simple meaning of the verse changes according to the level of the generation, as mentioned there (his intention is in matters that do not pertain to halacha, of course). In our lowly generation, one might say the intention of the verse according to what our sages, of blessed memory, said in the Gemara (Beitzah 37a) that animals and utensils are according to the feet of their owners. And behold, the horses were of the God-fearing, and the chariot belonged to Pharaoh, and according to the way of nature, it would be fitting for the horses to lead the chariot. But the Holy One, blessed be He, did not do so; rather, the chariot pulled the horses, and even their owners were drawn along with them. [And the truth of the matter is always that if the God-fearing connect with the wicked, then the wheel turns, and the wicked lead the God-fearing. However, it is unfortunate that this is not always possible to see openly.] Yet then, at the crossing of the sea, there was a great revelation, and they saw this miracle with their own eyes, and through this, Israel knew to distance themselves even from their association, and it also serves as a lesson for generations.
summary: The passage discusses the metaphor of "my horse is like the chariots of Pharaoh," emphasizing the reversal of natural order by God, where the chariot leads the horses instead of the other way around. This reflects the idea that the righteous can influence divine decrees, demonstrating that the world operates according to the will of the righteous. It also highlights the importance of separating from the wicked, as the righteous can become ensnared by their influence. Ultimately, the text serves as a reminder of the need for vigilance in maintaining one's spiritual integrity amidst external pressures.

passage_content: ועד"ז יתבאר קישור הכתוב, דלעיל מיני' כתיב אם לא תדעי לך היפה בנשים צאי לך בעקבי הצאן, פרש"י אם לא תדעי לך להיכן תלכי וכו' שחדל הרועה מלהנהיג אותך וכו' צאי לך בעקבי הצאן, הסתכלי בפסיעות דרך שהלכו הצאן וכו' התבונני בדרכי אבותיך הראשונים וכו', נראה שרש"י ז"ל דייק בלשונו הקדוש שחדל הרועה מלהנהיג אותך, משמע שלא יחסר להם מנהיג, אלא שחדל מלהנהיג, כי אם מתחברים עם רשעים אז הרשעים מנהיגים את המנהיג ולכן הסמיכו אח"כ הפסוק לסוסתי ברכבי פרעה שנמשלו ברכבי פרעה שהרכב נעשה המושך וכמו"כ הרשעים נעשו המנהיגים ע"י שמתחברים אליהם והבן.
translation: And similarly, the connection of the verse will be explained, for above it is written, "If you do not know, O fairest among women, go forth in the footsteps of the flock." Rashi explains, "If you do not know where to go, etc., since the shepherd has ceased to lead you, etc., go forth in the footsteps of the flock, look at the steps of the way the flock has gone, etc., contemplate the ways of your forefathers." It seems that Rashi, blessed be his memory, was precise in his holy language that the shepherd has ceased to lead you, which implies that they will not lack a leader, but rather that he has ceased to lead. For if they connect with the wicked, then the wicked become the leaders of the leader, and therefore the verse is later connected to "My mare among the chariots of Pharaoh," which is likened to the chariots of Pharaoh, where the chariot becomes the one that pulls, and likewise, the wicked become the leaders by connecting to them. Understand this.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of spiritual leadership and the dangers of associating with the wicked. It emphasizes that when the true shepherd (leader) ceases to guide, it is not due to a lack of leadership but rather a consequence of the community's connection to the unrighteous. This connection allows the wicked to assume a leadership role, akin to how chariots lead horses, highlighting the importance of remaining aligned with righteous paths and the teachings of the ancestors. The text encourages reflection on one's spiritual journey and the influences that shape it.

passage_content: ויאמר ה' אל משה נטה את ידך על הים וישובו המים וגו' וישב הים לפנות בוקר לאיתנו וגו', וישובו המים ויכסו את הרכב וגו' יל"ד על שינוי הלשון, דתחלה אמר וישב הים ואח"כ וישובו המים בלשון רבים, משמע שהוא ענין נפרד וב' שיבות היו שם וצ"ב.
translation: And the Lord said to Moses, "Stretch out your hand over the sea," and the waters returned, etc. And the sea returned to its strength at dawn, etc. And the waters returned and covered the chariots, etc. There is a question on the change of language, for initially it says, "And the sea returned," and afterwards, "And the waters returned" in the plural form, implying that it is a separate matter and that there were two returns there, and it is to be pondered.
summary: In the passage, the distinction between the phrases "the sea returned" and "the waters returned" suggests a deeper theological insight into the nature of divine intervention. The use of singular and plural forms indicates that there were two separate acts of return, reflecting the complexity of God's actions in the world. This duality emphasizes the idea that divine miracles can manifest in multiple dimensions, highlighting the interplay between the physical and spiritual realms. Such insights encourage a deeper understanding of God's omnipotence and the multifaceted nature of His miracles.

passage_content: ב) ילקוט (רמז רל"ו) וישב הים לפנות בוקר לאיתנו, א"ר יונתן התנה הקב"ה תנאים עם הים שיהא נקרע לפני ישראל, הה"ד וישב הים לפנות בוקר לאיתנו, לתנאו שהתנה הקב"ה עמו עכ"ד המדרש, והקשו המפורשים דרמז התנאי היל"ל לעיל אצל ויבקעו המים, דהרי התנאי הי' על הבקיעה, ומדוע רמז עלי' הכתוב במאמר וישב הים.
translation: B) Yalkut (Remez 246) "And the sea returned to its strength in the morning," Rabbi Yonatan said: The Holy One, blessed be He, made conditions with the sea that it should split before Israel, as it is written, "And the sea returned to its strength in the morning," according to the condition that the Holy One, blessed be He, made with it. Thus concludes the Midrash. The commentators have questioned why the condition is hinted at above in the phrase "and the waters were split," since the condition was regarding the splitting, and why does the verse hint at it in the statement "And the sea returned."
summary: The passage discusses a midrashic interpretation of the sea's splitting before the Israelites, highlighting that God made a conditional agreement with the sea to part for them. This reflects the Hasidic concept of divine intervention and the relationship between God and creation, emphasizing that nature responds to God's will in favor of the Jewish people. The text raises a question about the placement of this condition, suggesting a deeper theological insight into the nature of miracles and the fulfillment of divine promises. Ultimately, it illustrates the profound connection between divine authority and the natural world in the context of Israel's redemption.

passage_content: ואפשר לתרץ קושית המפרשים הנ"ל, בהקדם דברי המד"ר (פ' כ"ב סי' ב') וישובו המים אמר ר' יוחנן כיון שעלה אחרון שבישראל מן הים ירד לתוכו אחרון של מצרים, ורשב"ל אומר על אלו ועל אלו ננעל הים מד' רוחותיו, אמר משה לפני הקב"ה מה יעשו ישראל, אמר לו אי אתה זקוק, למה שאני עושה להם נס, באותה שעה שלח הקב"ה את ידו והעלן מן הים שנאמר (תהלים י"ח) ישלח ממרום יקחני ימשני ממים רבים עכ"ד המדרש, נמצא לדברי רשב"ל הי' נס הבקיעה כפול, שמתחלה נבקעו המים וישם הקב"ה את הים לחרבה ויבואו בנ"י בתוך הים ביבשה, ואחר ששב הים לאיתנו, עמדו כנד נוזלים ולא נגעו בישראל, עד ששלח הקב"ה את ידו והעלה את ישראל מן הים, ואח"כ שבו גם אלו המים ויכסו את הרכב וכל חיל פרעה, וא"ש שינוי וכפל הלשון וישב הים וגו' וישובו המים ויכסו את הרכב וגו', דב' שיבות היו כנ"ל, וע"כ רמז הכתוב על התנאי שהותנה הקב"ה עם הים במאמר וישב הים לפנות בוקר לאיתנו, כי אחר ששבו המים הי' עוד צורך לתנאי שיעמדו מלפני ישראל, והנס השני הי' גדול מן הראשון, כי הבוי"ת קצב גבול לים כדכתיב חול גבול שמת האומר לים עד פה תבוא, וזהו תנאי בריאתו מששת ימי בראשית, ועד"ז בנס הבקיעה גזר על הים עד פה תבוא ועמדו במקומם, אבל גדול הי' הנס השני שאחר ששבו המים וננעלו ישראל בתוכו אעפ"כ עמדו מפניהם ולא נגעו בהם, ולזה רמז הכתוב על התנאי במאמר וישב הים וגו', וכ"ז לשיטת רשב"ל.
translation:
And it is possible to answer the question of the aforementioned commentators by prefacing the words of the Midrash (Parashat Beshalach, Section 2): "And the waters returned," Rabbi Yochanan said, "Once the last of Israel ascended from the sea, the last of Egypt descended into it." And Resh Lakish says, "The sea was locked on all four sides." Moses said before the Holy One, Blessed be He, "What will Israel do?" He said to him, "You do not need to worry, for I will perform a miracle for them." At that moment, the Holy One, Blessed be He, sent His hand and raised them from the sea, as it is said (Psalms 18), "He sent from on high, He took me; He drew me out of many waters." Thus far the Midrash. 

According to Resh Lakish, the miracle of the splitting was double, for initially the waters were split, and the Holy One, Blessed be He, made the sea dry, and the Children of Israel came into the sea on dry land. And after the sea returned to its strength, it stood like a wall of water and did not touch Israel, until the Holy One, Blessed be He, sent His hand and raised Israel from the sea. Afterwards, the waters returned and covered the chariots and all the host of Pharaoh. 

And this explains the change and repetition in the language: "And the sea returned" and "And the waters returned and covered the chariots," for there were two returns as mentioned. Therefore, the verse hints at the condition that the Holy One, Blessed be He, made with the sea in the statement "And the sea returned to its strength in the morning," for after the waters returned, there was still a need for a condition that they should stand before Israel. 

And the second miracle was greater than the first, for the Holy One, Blessed be He, set a boundary for the sea, as it is written, "The sand is its boundary, which it cannot pass; and though the waves toss themselves, they cannot prevail." This is the condition of its creation from the six days of creation. Similarly, in the miracle of the splitting, He decreed upon the sea, "Until here you shall come," and they stood in their place. But the second miracle was greater, for after the waters returned and Israel was locked within it, nevertheless, they stood before them and did not touch them. And for this, the verse hints at the condition in the statement "And the sea returned," and all this is according to the opinion of Resh Lakish.
summary: The passage discusses the miraculous splitting of the sea during the Exodus, emphasizing a dual nature of the miracle as explained by Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish (Rashbi'l). It highlights that after the waters were split and the Israelites crossed on dry land, the sea returned to its state but did not harm the Israelites, showcasing God's protective intervention. The text underscores the theological concept of divine control over nature, where God sets boundaries for the sea, allowing it to serve His purpose while ensuring the safety of His people. This reflects a profound understanding of God's sovereignty and the layered nature of miracles in the Hasidic tradition.

passage_content: ואפ"ל גם אליבא דר' יוחנן, עפימ"ד במכילתא ומצרים נסים לקראתו ללמדך שכל מקום ומקום שהיו מצרים נסים, הי' הים רץ כנגדו, ופי' במרכבת המשנה דלזה הוצרך השי"ת תנאי על השבת הים חוץ לגבולו, דחול גבולו שמת, אמנם קשה ממה דאיתא בש"ס (סוטה דף י"א ע"א) דהיתר שבועת המבול, שע"ז לא נשבע הקב"ה שהם באים ונופלים בתוך הים, ולפי"ז לא יצדק, להיות הים רץ לקראתם חוץ לגבולו והציף אותם ע"כ קושיתו, ואפשר לתרץ קושיתו עפ"י גירסת המד"ר שגררן הקב"ה לחרבו של ים, ולפי"ז לא הציף אותם הים חוץ לגבולו, ויתכן שכאשר נסו המים אחריהם, המה בעצמם הטעו וחזרו לחרבו של ים שינצלו בחרבה, ואז צפו מים על ראשם ונטבעו, ואין זה בכלל השבועה כמ"ש במדרש אמר הקב"ה כבר נשבעתי שאיני מביא מבול לעולם. אבל מה אעשה לכם, אני מביא אתכם למבול, וא"ש אף לשיטת ר' יוחנן מה שרמז הקב"ה על התנאי במאמר וישב הים לאיתנו, כי אחר ששבו המים על מצרים היו המצרים נסים מן הים, והוצרך הים לנוס אחריהם מחוץ גבולו ולהחזירם לתוך הים ולזה הי' צורך לתנאי דחול גבולו שמת, ולזה רמז הכתוב על התנאי במאמר וישב הים וגו'.
translation: And even according to Rabbi Yochanan, as it is stated in the Mechilta, that the Egyptians were running towards it, to teach you that wherever the Egyptians were running, the sea would rush against them. And it is explained in the Merkevet HaMishnah that for this, the Holy One, Blessed be He, needed a condition regarding the sea's return outside its boundary, that the boundary of its land had died. However, it is difficult regarding what is stated in the Talmud (Sotah 11a) about the allowance of the flood's oath, for which the Holy One, Blessed be He, did not swear that they would come and fall into the sea. According to this, it would not be correct for the sea to rush towards them outside its boundary and drown them; therefore, this is his difficulty. It is possible to answer his difficulty according to the version of the Midrash that the Holy One, Blessed be He, drew them to the sword of the sea, and according to this, the sea did not drown them outside its boundary. It is possible that when the waters fled after them, they themselves were misled and returned to the sword of the sea to be saved by the sword, and then the waters rose over their heads and they drowned, and this is not included in the oath, as it is said in the Midrash: the Holy One, Blessed be He, said, "I have already sworn that I will not bring a flood upon the world. But what shall I do to you? I will bring you to a flood." And this is also understood according to the opinion of Rabbi Yochanan regarding what the Holy One, Blessed be He, hinted at concerning the condition in the statement "And the sea returned to its strength," for after the waters returned upon Egypt, the Egyptians were fleeing from the sea, and the sea needed to flee after them outside its boundary and return them into the sea, and for this, there was a need for the condition that the boundary of its land had died, and for this, the verse hinted at the condition in the statement "And the sea returned, etc."
summary: The passage discusses the miraculous events surrounding the parting of the Red Sea and the subsequent drowning of the Egyptians, emphasizing the divine conditions set by God regarding the sea's boundaries. It explores the tension between God's oath not to bring a flood and the necessity for the sea to pursue the Egyptians beyond its limits. The text suggests that the Egyptians, in their panic, inadvertently led themselves back to the sea's depths, thus fulfilling God's plan without violating His oath. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the interplay of divine justice, mercy, and the fulfillment of God's promises.

passage_content: אז ישיר משה ובני ישראל את השירה הזאת לה' ויאמרו לאמר אשירה לה' כי גאה גאה וגו', זה קלי ואנוהו אלקי אבי וארוממנהו, פירש"י ז"ל זה קלי, בכבודו נגלה עליהן והיו מראין אותו באצבע ראתה שפחה על הים מה שלא ראו נביאים וכו' אלקי אבי לא אני תחלת הקדושה אלא מוחזקת ועומדת לי הקדושה, ואלקותו עלי מימי אבותי, ובמד"ר (פרשה כ"ג סי' ט"ו) כמה גדולים יורדי הים, כמה נתחבט והתחנן מרע"ה הראיני נא את כבודך, ולבסוף לא ראה הדמות בעצם רק בסימן, ועולי הים כ"א מראה בהדמות זה קלי, א"ל הקב"ה לישראל, בעוה"ז אמרתם לפני פעם אחת זה קלי, אבל לע"ל אתם אומרים אותו דבר ב"פ, שנאמר (ישעי' כ"ה) ואמר ביום ההוא הנה אלקינו זה קוינו לו ויושיענו זה ה' קוינו לו וגו' עכ"ד המדרש, ראוי להבין מהו היתרון שיאמרו אותו ישראל לע"ל שתי פעמים, העיקר ה"ה שיזכו להתגלות אלקית בבחי' גדולה כזו ומאי נפק"מ כמה פעמים יאמרו מלת "זה" פעם אחת או ב' פעמים.
translation: Then Moses and the children of Israel sang this song to the Lord, and they said, saying, "I will sing to the Lord, for He has triumphed gloriously," etc. "This is my God, and I will glorify Him; the God of my father, and I will exalt Him." Rashi, of blessed memory, explains: "This is my God," His glory was revealed to them, and they pointed to Him with their fingers. A maidservant saw at the sea what the prophets did not see, etc. "The God of my father," I am not the beginning of holiness, but holiness is firmly established for me, and His divinity has been upon me since the days of my ancestors. And in the Midrash (Parashat 23, Section 15), how great are those who descend to the sea, how much Moses pleaded and entreated, "Show me, please, Your glory," and in the end, he did not see the form itself, only a sign. And those who ascend from the sea each see the form, "This is my God." The Holy One, blessed be He, said to Israel, "In this world, you said once, 'This is my God,' but in the World to Come, you will say the same thing twice," as it is stated (Isaiah 25), "And it will be said in that day, 'Behold, this is our God; we have waited for Him, and He will save us; this is the Lord; we have waited for Him,' etc." Thus concludes the Midrash. It is fitting to understand what the advantage is that Israel will say it twice in the future. The essence is that they will merit a divine revelation in such a great aspect, and what difference does it make how many times they say the word "this," once or twice.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the Hasidic interpretation emphasizes the profound revelation of God's presence experienced by the Israelites at the Red Sea, which surpassed even the visions of the prophets. The phrase "זה קלי" (This is my God) signifies a direct and tangible encounter with the Divine, highlighting the continuity of holiness from the patriarchs to the present. The text suggests that in the future, the Israelites will proclaim this recognition of God twice, indicating a deeper and more complete revelation of the Divine in the Messianic era, reflecting the ultimate fulfillment of their faith and hope.

passage_content: ב) (רות רבתי פ' ז' סי' י"א) איתא דרש פלא עה"כ וזאת לפנים בישראל על הגאולה ועל התמורה, ר' חנינא פתר קרא בגו אפי' דישראל, לשעבר היו מקלסין על הגאולה שנאמר זה קלי ואנוהו, ועכשיו על התמורה שנאמר (תהלים ק"ו) וימירו את כבודם בתבנית שור אוכל עשב, אין לך מנוול ומשוקץ ומשונה כשור בשעה שאוכל עשב וכו' עכ"ד המדרש, ופי' במתנת כהונה בגו אפייא וכו', במנהגם ועניינם של ישראל כדאמר אופיי' של אלהיה, והיפה ענף מביא גירסא שנו אפייא, פי' ששינו פניהם ממה שהיו בתחלה, שלפנים פנו לה' ועתה לעבודת כוכבים, וגם י"ל דדריש וזאת לפנים בישראל, שנשתנו פנים בישראל יעיי"ש, והרד"ל פי' בגו אפייא דישראל וי"ל ביני אפייא דישראל, בין החשובים ופני עדת ישראל הי' מנהג זה, וכמ"ש בזוה"ק פ' חקת דף ק"פ עיי"ש, אמנם יש להבין מ"ש ועכשיו על התמורה שנא' וימירו את כבודם בתבנית שור אוכל עשב, הרי זה כבר הי' ומדוע אמר ועכשיו, גם אינו מובן קישור דרשתם ז"ל לפשטות הכתובים, דמיירי בקנין חליפין שלף איש נעלו ונתן לרעהו, ומה ענין לזה דלשעבר היו ישראל מקלסין על הגאולה ועכשיו על התמורה, שפגמו בחטא העגל ועשו תמורה בתבנית שור אוכל עשב, גם מ"ש בגו אפייא דישראל לכל הפירושים צ"ב הקישור למעשה בועז ורות דעסיק בי' קרא, גם צ"ב מ"ש לשעבר היו מקלסין על הגאולה שנאמר זה קלי ואנוהו, לכאורה לא מצינו שאמרו קילוס זה על הגאולה, ומבואר בדברי רז"ל שאמרו כן על התגלות אלקית שזכו כ"א להראות באצבע כנ"ל, ועל הגאולה אמרו לשונות אחרים של קילוס אשירה לה' כי גאה גאה וגו', ועוד הרבה פסוקים, ומדוע נקטו רז"ל הך קרא דייקא שלא אמרו על הגאולה בעצם.
translation: (2) (Ruth Rabbah, Parashat 7, Section 11) It is stated that the wonder is on the verse, "And this was before in Israel" regarding redemption and transformation. Rabbi Chanina explained the verse in the context of "even in the face of Israel." Previously, they would praise the redemption, as it is said, "This is my God, and I will glorify Him," and now they praise the transformation, as it is said (Psalms 106), "They exchanged their glory for the likeness of an ox that eats grass." There is no more disgraceful, abominable, and strange thing than an ox while it eats grass, etc. Thus concludes the Midrash. And it explains in the context of the gift of the priesthood, etc., in the manner and essence of Israel, as it is said, "the face of their God." And the beautiful branch brings a version that they changed their faces, meaning that they altered their appearance from what they were at first, for previously they turned to the Lord, and now to idol worship. It can also be said that it is interpreted "and this was before in Israel," that the faces of Israel have changed, see there. And the Radal explained "in the face of Israel," and it can be said "between the faces of Israel," among the important ones and the faces of the congregation of Israel, this was their custom, as it is written in the Zohar, Parashat Chukat, page 120, see there. However, one must understand what is meant by "and now on the transformation," as it is said, "They exchanged their glory for the likeness of an ox that eats grass," for this had already been, and why does it say "and now"? It is also not understood how their interpretation connects to the simplicity of the verses, which deal with the acquisition of exchange, where a man took off his shoe and gave it to his friend. What is the connection to the fact that previously Israel would praise the redemption and now the transformation, that they blemished with the sin of the golden calf and made a transformation in the likeness of an ox that eats grass? Also, what is meant by "in the face of Israel" in all interpretations, the connection to the act of Boaz and Ruth, which is engaged in this verse? It is also unclear what is meant by "previously they would praise the redemption, as it is said, 'This is my God, and I will glorify Him,'" for seemingly we do not find that they said this praise regarding the redemption. It is explained in the words of our Sages that they said this regarding the divine revelation that each one merited to point with a finger, as mentioned. And regarding the redemption, they said other expressions of praise, "I will sing to the Lord, for He has triumphed gloriously," etc., and many other verses. Why did our Sages specifically choose this verse, which they did not say about the redemption itself?
summary: The passage discusses the transformation in the spiritual state of Israel, contrasting their past praise for redemption with their current state of idolatry, symbolized by the phrase "they exchanged their glory for the likeness of an ox that eats grass." It highlights the shift from a direct relationship with God to a distorted worship, reflecting a deeper theological insight into the consequences of sin, particularly the sin of the Golden Calf. The text raises questions about the nature of this transformation and the specific scriptural references used, emphasizing the need for understanding the connection between Israel's past and present spiritual condition.

passage_content: ג) בפרשה ויבוא עמלק וילחם עם ישראל ברפידים, דקדק המהר"ל מפראג ז"ל בגור ארי' דהול"ל ויצא עמלק וילחם עם ישראל, דבמלחמה שייך לשון יציאה וכמ"ש ויצא סיחון לקראתינו, ובאמת ויבוא עמלק מיותר דהי' מספיק שיאמר וילחם עמלק עם ישראל ברפידים, ואם לחם עמם ידוע נדע שבא אליהם.
translation: In the section "And Amalek came and fought with Israel at Rephidim," the Maharal of Prague, may his merit protect us, is precise in his interpretation that it should have said "And Amalek went out and fought with Israel," for in warfare, the term "going out" is appropriate, as it is stated, "And Sichon went out to meet us." Indeed, the phrase "And Amalek came" is superfluous, as it would have been sufficient to say "And Amalek fought with Israel at Rephidim," and if he fought with them, it is known that he came to them.
summary: The passage discusses the phrase "and Amalek came and fought with Israel" from the Torah, highlighting a linguistic nuance noted by the Maharal of Prague. He questions the necessity of the word "came," suggesting that the term "went out" is more appropriate for a battle context. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the nature of conflict, emphasizing that the act of coming signifies a more profound spiritual challenge faced by the Israelites, rather than merely a physical confrontation. The discussion underscores the importance of understanding the spiritual implications behind the actions of adversaries in the context of divine providence and the struggle of the Jewish people.

passage_content: ד) פירש"י ז"ל מאי רפידים, שרפו ידיהן מן התורה, לכאורה תורה לא נרמז בכתוב ובמלת רפידים יש רמז שרפו ידיהן, ועדיין לא ידענא ממה רפו ידיהן.
translation: 4) Rashi, of blessed memory, explains what Raphidim means: they burned their hands from the Torah. At first glance, the Torah is not hinted at in the text, but in the word Raphidim there is a hint that they burned their hands. Yet, we still do not know from what they burned their hands.
summary: The passage discusses the term "Rafidim," interpreted by Rashi as a reference to the people's weakening commitment to the Torah, suggesting that they "burned their hands" from engaging with it. This implies a spiritual decline or detachment from divine teachings. The inquiry into the cause of their weakening highlights the importance of understanding the relationship between faith and practice in Hasidic thought, emphasizing the need for constant engagement with Torah to maintain spiritual vitality.

passage_content: ה) (פ' כ"ו סי' א') ויבוא עמלק הה"ד (איוב ג') לא שלותי ולא שקטתי ולא נחתי ויבוא רוגז וכו', לא שלותי מגזירה ראשונה שגזר פרעה עלי שנאמר (שמות א') וימררו את חייהם, והעמיד לו הקב"ה גואל זה מרים ע"ש המירור, ולא שקטתי מגזירה שני' (שם) אם בן הוא והמתן אותו, והעמיד הקב"ה גואל זה אהרן ע"ש ההריון, ולא נחתי מגזירה שלישית שגזר ואמר (שם) כל הבן הילוד תשליכוהו. והעמיד הקב"ה גואל ע"ש המים זה משה שנאמר (שם ב') כי מן המים משיתוהו, ויבוא רוגז זה עמלק עכ"ד המדרש, ראוי להבין דדריש לא שלותי ולא שקטתי ולא נחתי וכו' והעמיד להן גואל וכו'. והרי ע"י שהעמיד להן גואל, הרי נחו מהגזירה ומהו לא נחתי, גם היכן מצינו באהרן ומרים שהיו גואלים, גם צ"ב מ"ש ויבוא רוגז זה עמלק איך נרמז עמלק בלשון רוגז, וכי הצרות והגזירות של פרעה לא היו רוגז, ולמה דוקא הצרות של עמלק נרמז בלשון רוגז, גם הלשון ויבוא רוגז צ"ב דבאחריני לא אמר לשון ויבא כ"א בזה דייקא וטעמא בעי.
translation: 5) (Parashat Ki Tisa, Siman Aleph) And Amalek came, as it is written (Job 3), "I have not been at ease, nor have I been quiet, nor have I rested, and trouble came." I have not been at ease from the first decree that Pharaoh decreed against me, as it is said (Exodus 1), "They made their lives bitter." And the Holy One, blessed be He, established for them a redeemer, this is Miriam, in the merit of the bitterness. And I have not been quiet from the second decree (Exodus 1), "If it is a son, you shall kill him," and the Holy One, blessed be He, established for them a redeemer, this is Aaron, in the merit of the pregnancy. And I have not rested from the third decree that he decreed and said (Exodus 1), "Every son that is born you shall cast into the river." And the Holy One, blessed be He, established for them a redeemer in the merit of the waters, this is Moses, as it is said (Exodus 2), "For from the waters I drew him." And trouble came, this is Amalek. Thus far the Midrash. It is fitting to understand why it is expounded "I have not been at ease, nor have I been quiet, nor have I rested," and yet the Holy One, blessed be He, established for them a redeemer, etc. And behold, by the fact that He established for them a redeemer, they rested from the decree, and what does it mean "I have not rested"? Also, where do we find that Aaron and Miriam were redeemers? It is also necessary to clarify what is meant by "trouble came, this is Amalek," how is Amalek hinted at in the language of trouble? And were not the troubles and decrees of Pharaoh also trouble? And why specifically are the troubles of Amalek hinted at in the language of trouble? Also, the phrase "and trouble came" is puzzling, for in other instances it does not say "and came," but specifically here it is precise, and the reason is needed.
summary: The passage discusses the suffering of the Israelites under Pharaoh's decrees and the subsequent emergence of three redeemers: Miriam, Aaron, and Moses, each associated with different aspects of their oppression. It emphasizes that despite the presence of these redeemers, the Israelites still experienced a lack of peace, as symbolized by the term "Rogez" (rage) associated with Amalek. The text raises questions about the nature of this rage and why it specifically pertains to Amalek, suggesting a deeper theological insight into the ongoing struggle against evil and the complexities of redemption.

passage_content: ו) ר' יהושע אומר כשבא עמלק להזיק את ישראל מתחת כנפי אביהם שבשמים אמר משה לפני הקב"ה, רבש"ע רשע זה בא לאבד בניך מתחת כנפיך, ס"ת שנתת להם בהר סיני מי יקרא בו, ר"א המודעי אומר כשבא עמלק להזיק את ישראל וכו' אמר משה לפני הקב"ה רבש"ע בניך שאתה עתיד לפזרן תחת ארבע רוחות השמים וכו', רשע זה בא לכלם מתחת כנפיך ס"ת שנתת להם מי יקרא בו עכ"ד המכילתא, וצ"ב מה שאמר תורה שנתת להם מי יקרא בו, הרי הי' עדיין לפני מתן תורה ואם יכלה ח"ו זרע ישראל, א"כ לא יהי' מי שיקבל התורה, והול"ל מי יקבל את התורה, גם בדברי ר"א המודעי צ"ב ענין הטענה מ"ש בניך שאתה עתיד לפזרן וכו', וכי זכות הוא להם, הרי מפני חטאינו גלינו מארצנו, ומה ענינו להמליץ זכות בזה.
translation: And Rabbi Yehoshua says: When Amalek came to harm Israel from under the wings of their Father in Heaven, Moses said before the Holy One, Blessed be He, "Master of the Universe, this wicked one has come to destroy Your children from under Your wings. The Torah that You gave them at Mount Sinai, who will read it?" Rabbi Eliezer the Modai says: When Amalek came to harm Israel, etc., Moses said before the Holy One, Blessed be He, "Master of the Universe, Your children whom You are destined to scatter under the four corners of the heavens, etc., this wicked one has come to all of them from under Your wings. The Torah that You gave them, who will read it?" Thus far the Mechilta. And it is difficult to understand what it means when it says, "the Torah that You gave them, who will read it?" For it was still before the giving of the Torah, and if, Heaven forbid, the seed of Israel were to be destroyed, then there would be no one to receive the Torah. It should have said, "Who will receive the Torah?" Also, in the words of Rabbi Eliezer the Modai, it is difficult to understand the claim, "Your children whom You are destined to scatter," etc. Is it a merit for them? For due to our sins, we were exiled from our land, and what relevance do we have to advocate for merit in this?
summary: Rabbi Yehoshua highlights the urgency of Moses' plea to God when Amalek threatens Israel, emphasizing the importance of the Torah given at Sinai and questioning who will read it if Israel is destroyed. Rabbi Eliezer the Modai echoes this concern, pointing out that the future scattering of the Jewish people underlines their vulnerability. The passage raises profound theological questions about the continuity of the Jewish people and the significance of the Torah, suggesting that even in exile, the connection to the Torah remains a vital aspect of their identity and survival.

passage_content: ז) דרשו במכילתא ויבא עמלק שבא בגילוי פנים לפי שכל הביאות שבא לא בא אלא במטמוניות שנאמר אשר קרך בדרך וגו', אבל ביאה זו לא בא אלא בגילוי פנים לכך נאמר ויבוא עמלק עכ"ד המכילתא, וצ"ב דלא מצינו בשום מקום שבא במטמוניות, גם איך נשמע מאשר קרך בדרך שבא במטמוניות, ובמדרש יש הרבה דרשות במאמה"כ אשר קרך בדרך ולכולהו קאי על מלחמה זו ואיך נשמע מכאן על מלחמות הקודמים שהיו במטמוניות, גם איך הי' יכול ללחום במטמוניות וישראל היו מוקפים בעננים ולא הי' בידו לגשת אליהן.
translation: 7) It is expounded in the Mechilta that Amalek came with revealed intent, for all the other arrivals were only in hidden ways, as it is said, "that encountered you on the way," etc. However, this arrival came only with revealed intent; therefore, it is said, "And Amalek came." Thus far is the Mechilta. And it is puzzling, for we do not find anywhere that he came in hidden ways, and how can we understand from "that encountered you on the way" that he came in hidden ways? Moreover, in the Midrash, there are many interpretations on the verse "that encountered you on the way," and all of them refer to this war. How can we derive from here about the previous wars that were in hidden ways? Additionally, how could he wage war in hidden ways when Israel was surrounded by clouds, and he had no ability to approach them?
summary: The passage discusses the unique nature of Amalek's attack on Israel, emphasizing that it was a direct confrontation ("גילוי פנים") rather than a covert one, as seen in previous battles. The reference to "אשר קרך בדרך" suggests that Amalek's approach was brazen and open, contrasting with the hidden nature of other adversaries. This raises questions about the interpretation of past battles and the nature of divine protection, as Israel was surrounded by clouds, making Amalek's direct assault seemingly impossible. The text highlights the significance of Amalek's challenge to Israel's faith and the theological implications of open versus hidden confrontations in the spiritual struggle.

passage_content: ח) כאשר ירים משה ידו וגבר ישראל וכאשר יניח ידו וגבר עמלק במתני' (ר"ה דף כ"ט ע"א) הקשו וכי ידיו של משה עושות מלחמה או שוברות מלחמה, אלא לומר לך כל זמן שישראל מסתכלין כלפי מעלה ומשעבדין את לבם לאביהם שבשמים היו מתגברים וכו', וצ"ב מהו הקושיא וכי ידיו של משה עושות מלחמה, דבוודאי כן הוא שהי' בכח ידיו של משרע"ה להכריע נצחון המלחמה לטובה, גם התירוץ צ"ב דמ"ט הניח משרע"ה את ידו, אם בזה הי' תליא נצחונם והצלתם של ישראל, גם על ישראל קשה מ"ט כשהניח משרע"ה את ידו לא היו מסתכלים כלפי מעלה ומשעבדין את לבם לאביהם שבשמים.
translation: When Moses raised his hands, Israel prevailed, and when he lowered his hands, Amalek prevailed, as stated in the Mishnah (Rosh Hashanah 29a). They asked, "Do the hands of Moses wage war or break war?" Rather, it is to tell you that as long as Israel looks upward and subjugates their hearts to their Father in Heaven, they would prevail, etc. However, it is difficult to understand what the question is: "Do the hands of Moses wage war?" Certainly, it is true that through the power of the hands of Moshe Rabbeinu, the victory of the war was determined for the good. Also, the answer is difficult: Why did Moshe Rabbeinu lower his hands? If their victory and salvation depended on this, it is also difficult regarding Israel: Why, when Moshe Rabbeinu lowered his hands, did they not look upward and subjugate their hearts to their Father in Heaven?
summary: The passage discusses the significance of Moses raising and lowering his hands during the battle against Amalek, emphasizing that Israel's victory is linked to their spiritual focus and connection to God. It questions the nature of Moses' hands as the determining factor in the battle, suggesting that the true power lies in the people's devotion and reliance on the Divine. The text highlights the interplay between human action and divine assistance, illustrating that when the Israelites direct their hearts towards God, they gain strength, while neglecting this connection leads to vulnerability. Ultimately, it underscores the importance of faith and spiritual awareness in achieving success and overcoming challenges.

translation: 9) It is written in the language of the text, "And it shall be when Moses lifts up..." This war has already occurred, so why is it mentioned in the future tense? It should have said, "And when he lifts up..."
summary: The passage discusses the phrase "and it will be when Moses raises" in the context of a past battle, questioning why it is expressed in the future tense. This reflects a Hasidic understanding of the ongoing spiritual struggle and the idea that every action has future implications. It emphasizes the belief that the spiritual elevation achieved through prayer and effort can transform past events and influence future outcomes. Ultimately, it highlights the dynamic relationship between human actions and divine providence in the unfolding of history.

passage_content: י) ה' אל משה כתוב זאת זכרון בספר ושים באזני יהושע כי מחה אמחה את זכר עמלק מתחת השמים, נחלקו המפורשים בפי' הכתוב, הראב"ע ז"ל פי' כתוב זאת זכרון בספר, כי הוא ספר מלחמות ה', ואיננו אתנו שנאבד כאשר אין לנו דברי הימים למלכי ישראל וכו' עיי"ש, והרמב"ן ז"ל דחה פירושו עיי"ש וכתב הנכון בעיני כי בספר ירמוז לספר התורה שיזכרו בנ"י מה שעשה עמלק, וכ"כ הספורנו כתוב זאת זכרון בספר פרשת זכור, והפי' הוא שהבוכ"ע צווהו לכתוב בס"ת המצוה זאת של זכור את אשר עשה לך עמלק וכו', אמנם גם זה צ"ב דלא נזכר כן בשאר המצות שהקב"ה צוה לו עליהן לכותבם בספר התורה, וכל המצות כתבם משרע"ה בס"ת עפ"י ציווי השי"ת, ומי שאומר אפי' על אות א' שבתורה שמשה מפי עצמו כתבה, ה"ה בכלל האומר תורה לא מן השמים הוא וכופר בתורה, ועל כולם נצטוה מפי הקב"ה לכתוב, ואעפי"כ לא מצינו בפרטיות כל מצוה ומצוה שיאמר לו הקב"ה במיוחד כתוב זאת זכרון בספר, ומדוע במצוה זו דייקא הזכיר הכתוב שהקב"ה צווהו לכתבה זכרון בספר, גם דאין כאן מקומו דפ' זכור נאמרה במשנה תורה בפ' תצא, ומדוע הקדימו הכתוב לצוותו על ככה עכשיו.
translation: 10) The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Moses, "Write this as a remembrance in a book and place it in the ears of Joshua, for I will utterly blot out the remembrance of Amalek from under heaven." The commentators have disagreed on the interpretation of this verse. The Ra'avad, may his memory be blessed, explained that "write this as a remembrance in a book" refers to the Book of the Wars of the Lord, and it is not with us, as we have lost the Chronicles of the Kings of Israel, etc. See there. However, the Ramban, may his memory be blessed, rejected his interpretation and wrote what seems correct to me, that the "book" alludes to the Torah, so that the Children of Israel will remember what Amalek did. So too, the Sforno explained that "write this as a remembrance in a book" refers to the portion of Zachor, and the interpretation is that the Blessed One commanded him to write in the Torah this commandment of remembering what Amalek did to you, etc. However, this too is questionable, for it is not mentioned in other commandments that the Holy One, Blessed be He, commanded him to write them in the Torah. All the commandments were written by Moses in the Torah according to the command of the Holy One, Blessed be He, and anyone who says that even one letter in the Torah was written by Moses from his own mouth is included among those who say that the Torah is not from heaven and denies the Torah. And all of them were commanded by the Holy One, Blessed be He, to write. Nevertheless, we do not find specifically for each commandment that the Holy One, Blessed be He, particularly told him to write this as a remembrance in a book. Why, specifically for this commandment, does the verse emphasize that the Holy One, Blessed be He, commanded him to write it as a remembrance in a book? Also, it is not the place for it, as the portion of Zachor is stated in the Deuteronomy in the portion of Ki Teitzei. Why did the verse precede to command him about this now?
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author discusses the commandment given to Moses to write a remembrance of Amalek in a book, highlighting the differing interpretations of this directive by various commentators. The text emphasizes the unique significance of this command, as it is explicitly stated to be recorded in the Torah, unlike other commandments. This raises questions about the importance of remembering Amalek's actions and the theological implications of divine memory and historical accountability in Jewish thought. The passage reflects on the necessity of preserving collective memory as a means of spiritual and moral instruction for future generations.

passage_content: יא) באזני יהושע, צ"ב מהו באזני יהושע, והרי נצטווה לכתבו בתוה"ק ונתפרסם לכ"א מישראל ולא רק ליהושע, ואמרז"ל (סנהדרין דף כ' ע"ב) שלש מצות נצטוו ישראל בכניסתן לארץ וא' מהם מחיית עמלק, הרי לא נמסרה ליהושע בלחישה ומהו באזני יהושע.
translation: 11) "In the ears of Joshua," what does it mean "in the ears of Joshua"? After all, he was commanded to write it in the Torah and it was made known to all of Israel, not just to Joshua. And our Sages of blessed memory said (Sanhedrin 20b) that three commandments were given to Israel upon their entering the land, and one of them is the annihilation of Amalek; thus, it was not given to Joshua in a whisper, so what does it mean "in the ears of Joshua"?
summary: The passage discusses the phrase "in the ears of Joshua," questioning its significance since the command was meant for all of Israel and not just for Joshua. It references a Talmudic source that highlights the three commandments given to Israel upon entering the land, including the command to eradicate Amalek, which was not whispered to Joshua. This raises a theological insight about the unique role of leadership and the transmission of divine commandments, emphasizing the importance of personal engagement and understanding in fulfilling God's will.

passage_content: יב) ז"ל פירש דע"כ נצטו' למסרו ליהושע מפני שהוא עתיד להכניס את ישראל לארץ וכן הוא במד"ר (פ' כ"ו סי' ג') אמנם לכאורה לא מצינו שיהושע נלחם בעמלק אחר כניסת הארץ חוץ מפעם הזה עכשיו, ולא הגיע זמנה עד מלוך שאול והוא לחם עם עמלק, ולמה נאמר ושים באזני יהושע, גם צ"ב הלשון "ושים" דהול"ל אמר אל יהושע, ולא מצינו כזאת במקום אחר כמ"ש אמור אל אהרן ולא כתיב ושים באזניו ומה נשתנה כאן דכתיב לשון שימה.
translation: 11) It is explained that it was necessary to give it to Joshua because he was destined to bring Israel into the land, and so it is in the Midrash (Parashat 26, section 3). However, seemingly we do not find that Joshua fought against Amalek after entering the land, except for this instance now, and it did not come to pass until the reign of Saul, who fought with Amalek. And why is it said, "and place in the ears of Joshua"? Additionally, the wording "and place" is puzzling, as it should have said "say to Joshua," and we do not find such a thing elsewhere, as it is written "say to Aaron," and it does not say "and place in his ears." What is different here that it is written in the language of placing?
summary: The passage discusses the command to Moses to convey the battle against Amalek to Joshua, emphasizing Joshua's future role in leading Israel into the Promised Land. It raises questions about why this instruction was given, considering that Joshua did not fight Amalek after entering the land, and why the phrase "put in his ears" was used instead of a more direct command. This highlights the unique significance of Joshua's leadership and the ongoing spiritual struggle against Amalek, suggesting a deeper theological insight into the nature of divine guidance and the continuity of Israel's mission.

passage_content: והנה בגמרא מגילה (דף ז' ע"א) דרשו רז"ל הכתוב כתוב זאת זכרון בספר על כתיבת המגילה, כתוב זאת מ"ש כאן ובמשנה תורה, זכרון מה שכתוב בנביאים, בספר מה שכתוב במגילה, ואיתא בירושלמי מגילה פ"א ה"ה) דקריאת המגילה ניתנה למשרע"ה בהר סיני, ופי' היפה מראה דע"כ נאמר ושים באזני יהושע דמורה שילחוש לו באזניו דרך סוד נסתר מהמון, דבימי מרדכי ואסתר היו צריכים ישראל לתשובה גדולה כמבואר בדרז"ל, ואלמלי הי' נגלה ונתפרסם מקודם נפילת המן וכו' ותשועתם של ישראל, בוודאי מורא לא הי' עולה על ראשם מגזירת המן, וממילא לא הי' סיבה המביאם לעשות תשובה, לזה נסתר מהמון מצות קריאת המגילה בשעת מ"ת, ולא נמסר רק למשה לבדו והוא מסרה ליהושע, וכן כל ראש הדור מסר זה בדרך סוד לראש הדור שלאחריו עד מרדכי, והיינו שים באזני יהושע דייקא עכת"ד ז"ל, ועפי"ד יתיישב הלשון שימה שאמר הכתוב ושים באזני יהושע, עפימ"ד בירושלמי (ע"ז) ואלה המשפטים אשר תשים לפניהם, דד"ת הם כאוצר שהוא מכוסה, ודריש תשים לשון סימא שהוא מכוסה כאוצר, ואין לגלותם לבנ"א שאינם מהוגנים. וכ"ש מצות קריאת המגילה שהיתה צריכה להיות נסתר מהמון כנ"ל, לז"א "ושים'' "באזני" יהושע שיהי' מכוסה כאוצר ורק לאזני יהושע נאמרה בלחישה.
translation: And behold, in the Gemara Megillah (page 7a), our Sages expounded the verse "Write this as a remembrance in a book" regarding the writing of the Megillah. "Write this" refers to what is stated here and in the Mishneh Torah, "remembrance" refers to what is written in the Prophets, and "in a book" refers to what is written in the Megillah. And it is stated in the Jerusalem Talmud Megillah (Chapter 1, Halacha 5) that the reading of the Megillah was given to Moshe Rabbeinu at Mount Sinai. The beautiful explanation is that therefore it is said "and place in the ears of Yehoshua," which indicates that it should be whispered to him in a secret manner from the multitude. For in the days of Mordechai and Esther, the Jewish people needed a great repentance, as explained by our Sages. Had it been revealed and publicized beforehand, before the downfall of Haman, etc., and the salvation of Israel, certainly the fear would not have risen upon them from the decree of Haman, and consequently, there would have been no reason for them to repent. Therefore, the commandment of reading the Megillah was concealed from the multitude at the time of the giving of the Torah, and it was not entrusted except to Moshe alone, and he passed it on to Yehoshua. Likewise, every head of the generation passed this down in a secret manner to the head of the subsequent generation until Mordechai. This is the meaning of "place in the ears of Yehoshua" specifically, as stated by him. According to this, the wording of "place" that the verse says "and place in the ears of Yehoshua" is clarified, as it is stated in the Jerusalem Talmud (Avodah Zarah) "and these are the judgments that you shall place before them," that the Torah is like a treasure that is covered, and the term "place" is a language of concealment, like a treasure that is hidden, and it should not be revealed to people who are not worthy. How much more so the commandment of reading the Megillah, which needed to be concealed from the multitude as mentioned above, hence it says "and place" "in the ears" of Yehoshua, that it should be covered like a treasure, and it was only said to the ears of Yehoshua in a whisper.
summary: The passage discusses the hidden nature of the commandment to read the Megillah, which was given to Moses at Sinai and passed down through generations in secrecy. It emphasizes that the reading was intended to be concealed from the masses, as it was crucial for the Jewish people to engage in deep repentance during the time of Mordechai and Esther. The text highlights the importance of transmitting sacred teachings discreetly, akin to a hidden treasure, ensuring that only those deemed worthy, like Joshua, receive this knowledge. This reflects a broader Hasidic theme of the necessity for inner spiritual awareness and the significance of maintaining the sanctity of divine commandments.

passage_content: אמנם כל זה ניחא לפי הדרש שדרשוהו רז"ל על קריאת המגילה, אבל לפי פירוש הפשוט עדיין צ"ב פי' הקרא, והנה דרש זה דקאי על המגילה לא נתגלה לחכמים כ"א בימי מרדכי ואסתר, וחכז"ל מקודם לא ידעו מזה ולא רצו להכניס מגילת אסתר בין הכתובים עד שנתגלה להם דרש זה וסמכוהו אקרא כמבואר בגמרא שם, והכתוב הרי צריך שיהי' לו פירוש גם בדורות הקודמים ומה הי' פירוש הפסוק עד אז, וכמ"ש בגמ' עד דאתי יחזקאל מאן אמרינהו, גם כי זה דרך דרש, וכללא אית לן דאין מקרא יוצא מידי פשוטו לעולם, ואפשר דמה"ט נקטו המפורשים דכתוב זאת זכרון בספר קאי על מצות התורה הכתובה בפ' תצא, ועכ"פ עפ"י פשוטו צ"ב מה נשתנה מצוה זו שנתייחד עלי' הציווי לכתבו זכרון בספר משא"כ שאר המצות.
translation: Indeed, all this is acceptable according to the interpretation that our sages have expounded regarding the reading of the Megillah, but according to the simple interpretation, the meaning of the verse is still in question. This interpretation that pertains to the Megillah was not revealed to the sages until the days of Mordechai and Esther; prior to that, they did not know of it and did not wish to include the Megillah of Esther among the sacred writings until this interpretation was revealed to them, and they supported it with a verse, as explained in the Gemara there. The verse indeed needs to have an interpretation also in earlier generations, and what was the interpretation of the verse until then, as it is stated in the Gemara, "Until Ezekiel came, who said them?" Even though this is a way of interpretation, we have a general principle that a verse never departs from its simple meaning. It is possible that for this reason the commentators have stated that "Write this as a remembrance in a book" refers to the commandments of the Torah written in Parashat Ki Teitzei. Nevertheless, according to its simple meaning, it is still in question why this commandment is singled out for the command to write it as a remembrance in a book, unlike other commandments.
summary: The passage discusses the interpretation of the Book of Esther and its significance in Jewish tradition, emphasizing that the deeper understanding of its meaning was revealed only during the time of Mordechai and Esther. It raises questions about the necessity of a clear interpretation of the text prior to that period, highlighting the principle that scripture must always have a straightforward meaning. The author notes that the command to record the events of Esther as a remembrance is unique compared to other commandments, suggesting a special theological significance attached to this mitzvah. Ultimately, it reflects on the relationship between revealed wisdom and the foundational texts of Judaism.
