passage_content: ולדרכינו יל"פ בדברי המדרש הנ"ל (קושיא ה') ויבא עמלק הה"ד לא שלותי ולא שקטתי ולא נחתי ויבא רוגז, לא שלותי מגזירה ראשונה שגזר פרעה עלי שנא' וימררו את חייהם, והעמיד לו הקב"ה גואל זה מרים, ולכאורה איזה גאולה הי' ע"י מרים, וכשנולדה התחילה השעבוד וקראו לה מרים ע"ש המרירות, אמנם מרים בישרה בנבואה ואמרה עתידה אמי שתלד בן שיגאל את ישראל, ובכובד הגלות וקושי השעבוד הי' ג"ז נחמה לבנ"י שידעו שכבר נולד הגואל וקרבה עת גאולתם, ועכשיו ההסתרה גדולה ומרה כ"כ שג"ז לא נודע, וכמ"ש הנביא פתאום יבוא אל היכלו האדון אשר אתם מבקשים, והגאולה תהי' בהיסח הדעת, ועכ"פ ע"י נבואתה של מרים הרגישו ישראל בחי' הגאולה קצת, ולז"א והעמיד להן גואל זה מרים, ואעפי"כ לא הי' להם מנוחה כי עדיין לא תיקנו ולא עשו תשובה שיהיו ראויים להיגאל, ולז"א ולא שקטתי מגזירה שני' אם בן הוא והמתן אותו, והעמיד הקב"ה גואל זה אהרן ע"ש ההריון, ויל"פ ע"ד הכתוב ויהי כי יראו המילדות את האלקים ויעש להם בתים, ודרשו רז"ל בתי כהונה ולוי' מיוכבד ובתי מלכות ממרים, והנה ידוע דהבוית"ש ברוב רחמיו וחסדיו מקדים לחשב זכות העתיד לטובתן של ישראל, ומסגולת העבודה של כהן גדול לשכך כעס וחמה ולהמתיק את הדינים, כמ"ש בפייט ליוכ"פ ובקרבנותיו הפרת את כעסך, והקדים הבוי"ת לישראל זכותו של אהרן לבטל גזירת אם בן הוא והמתן אותו, ולז"א והעמיד הקב"ה גואל זה אהרן ע"ש ההריון, דגזירה זו הי' לבטל ההריון, שיפרשו ישראל מד"א, ובזכותו של אהרן נתבטלה.
translation: And according to our path, it can be explained in the words of the aforementioned Midrash (question 5) that Amalek came, as it is written: "I was not tranquil, nor did I rest, nor was I at ease, and Amalek came." I was not tranquil from the first decree that Pharaoh decreed against me, as it is said: "And they made their lives bitter." And the Holy One, blessed be He, established for them this redeemer, Miriam. And seemingly, what redemption was there through Miriam? For when she was born, the servitude began, and they named her Miriam after the bitterness. However, Miriam announced through prophecy and said: "My mother will give birth to a son who will redeem Israel." And in the heaviness of the exile and the difficulty of the servitude, this was also a comfort to the Children of Israel, for they knew that the redeemer had already been born and that the time of their redemption was approaching. And now the concealment is so great and bitter that it is not known at all, as the prophet says: "Suddenly, the Lord whom you seek will come to His temple," and the redemption will come unexpectedly. Nevertheless, through her prophecy, the Israelites felt a bit of the aspect of redemption, and thus it is said: "And the Holy One, blessed be He, established for them this redeemer, Miriam." And yet, they did not have rest, for they had not yet rectified nor repented to be worthy of redemption. Therefore, it is said: "And I was not at ease from the second decree: 'If it is a son, you shall kill him.'" And the Holy One, blessed be He, established for them this redeemer, Aaron, in the name of pregnancy. And it can be explained according to the verse: "And it was when the midwives saw the God of Israel, He made them houses." The sages have interpreted this as the houses of the priesthood and Levites from Yocheved, and the houses of royalty from Miriam. And behold, it is known that the Holy One, blessed be He, in His abundant mercy and kindness, anticipates to consider the merit of the future for the benefit of Israel. And from the virtue of the service of the High Priest to appease anger and wrath and to sweeten the judgments, as it is said in the piyyut for Yom Kippur: "And in His offerings, You have removed Your anger." And the Holy One, blessed be He, anticipated for Israel the merit of Aaron to annul the decree: "If it is a son, you shall kill him." Therefore, it is said: "And the Holy One, blessed be He, established for them this redeemer, Aaron, in the name of pregnancy," for this decree was to annul the pregnancy, so that Israel would be separated from the decree of death, and by the merit of Aaron, it was annulled.
summary: The passage discusses the role of Miriam and Aaron as redeemers during the oppression of the Israelites in Egypt. It highlights Miriam's prophetic announcement of future redemption, which provided hope amidst suffering, and Aaron's merit in countering Pharaoh's decree against male infants. The text emphasizes the importance of divine mercy and the anticipation of redemption, suggesting that even in times of great concealment and despair, the potential for salvation exists through the righteous actions of leaders like Miriam and Aaron. Ultimately, it reflects on the interplay between human agency and divine providence in the process of redemption.

passage_content: ובכל זאת לא נחתי מגזירה שלישית שגזר ואמר כל הבן הילוד היאורה תשליכוהו, והעמיד הקב"ה גואל ע"ש המים זה משה שנא' כי מן המים משיתוהו, שבזכותו של משה נצולו ישראל מגזירת המים כאמרז"ל במד"ר ובגמ' סוטה (דף י"ב ע"ב) והיינו דקאמר שש מאות אלף רגלי העם אשר בקרבו בשבילי נצלתם כולכם, אבל עדיין לא הי' להם הצלה גמורה וגאולה שלימה, ולמה לא שלותי ולא שקטתי ולא נחתי, והרי העמיד הקב"ה לישראל גואלים צדיקים משה אהרן ומרים, ולזה סיים ויבא רוגז זה עמלק, היינו שרו של עמלק הס"ם כדברי האלשיך הק', ולכן קראו בלשון רוגז ע"ד מ"ש רז"ל (ברכות דף ה' ע"א) לעולם ירגיז אדם יצ"ט על יצה"ר, ופירשתי בכוונת הלשון לעולם ירגיז, דהול"ל לעולם יתגבר יצ'"ט על יצה"ר, אמנם בכל דין ומריבה מצוה לבצוע ולתווך השלום ע"י פשרה, כאמרז"ל (סנהדרין דף ו' ע"ב) איזהו משפט שיש בו צדקה הוי אומר זה ביצוע, אולם במלחמת היצר אינו כן. שאם יעשה האדם פשרה עמו לסוף נופל ברשתו לגמרי ח"ו, כאמרז"ל היום אומר לו עשה כך, ולמחר אומר לו עשה כך וכו' עד שאומר לו לך ועבוד ע"ז והולך ועובד, וז"ש לעולם ירגיז אדם יצ"ט על יצה"ר שיהי' בבחי' רוגז ומלחמת תמידית ולא יבקש דרך הפשרה והשלו', וכמו"כ כאן ויבא רוגז זה עמלק היינו שרו של עמלק הס"ם והוא היצה"ר ונקרא רוגז שהמלחמה עמו תמידית ומחוייבת.
translation: And yet, I did not rest from the third decree that he decreed and said, "Every son that is born you shall cast into the river," and the Holy One, blessed be He, established a redeemer for the sake of the waters, this is Moses, as it is said, "For from the waters I drew him," that through the merit of Moses, Israel was saved from the decree of the waters, as our Sages have said in Midrash and in the Gemara Sotah (12b). And this is what is meant by the six hundred thousand foot soldiers of the people who are in his midst, for your sake you were all saved. But still, they did not have complete salvation and full redemption. And why did I not bring peace, nor quiet, nor rest? For the Holy One, blessed be He, established righteous redeemers for Israel: Moses, Aaron, and Miriam. And therefore it concludes, "And there came the wrath, this is Amalek," meaning the minister of Amalek, the evil inclination, as the holy Alshich says. And that is why it is called in the language of wrath, according to what our Sages have said (Berakhot 5a), "A person should always provoke his good inclination against his evil inclination." And I explained the intention of the language: "A person should always provoke," for it could have said, "A person should always overcome his evil inclination." However, in every judgment and dispute, it is a commandment to mediate and to seek peace through compromise, as our Sages have said (Sanhedrin 6b), "What is a judgment that has righteousness? You should say this is compromise." Yet, in the war against the evil inclination, it is not so. For if a person makes a compromise with it, in the end, he falls completely into its net, Heaven forbid, as our Sages have said, "Today it tells him, 'Do this,' and tomorrow it tells him, 'Do that,' until it tells him, 'Go and serve idols,' and he goes and serves." Therefore, it is said, "A person should always provoke his good inclination against his evil inclination," that it should be in a state of wrath and perpetual war, and he should not seek a way of compromise and peace. And likewise here, "And there came the wrath, this is Amalek," meaning the minister of Amalek, the evil inclination, and it is called wrath because the war with it is perpetual and obligatory.
summary: The passage discusses the divine providence in the face of Israel's suffering, highlighting Moses as a savior from the decree of drowning. Despite the presence of righteous leaders like Moses, Aaron, and Miriam, the ultimate redemption was not yet achieved, symbolized by the emergence of Amalek, representing the ongoing struggle against the evil inclination (Yetzer Hara). The text emphasizes the necessity of a constant and uncompromising battle against the Yetzer Hara, advocating for a state of perpetual vigilance rather than seeking compromise, as yielding can lead to spiritual downfall. This reflects a broader Hasidic theme of the continuous struggle between good and evil within the human experience.

passage_content: ולז"א ויבא רוגז, וכן ויבא עמלק דהוא"ו של ויבא פירושו שבא וחוזר ובא, וכמו שדרשו רז"ל (ב"ר פ' ס"ו סי' ג') ויתן ויחזור ויתן. שהוא"ו להוסיף בא, וכן היצה"ר אף אם יתגבר עליו האדם פ"א, הוא חוזר ובא להלחם בתחבולות חדשים ובלבוש חדש אשר לא שערום אבותינו, ויתורץ קושית הגו"א מדוע לא אמר הכתוב ויצא עמלק וכמ"ש ויצא סיחון לקראת ישראל, ובמלחמה יצדק יותר לשון יציאה, ולדרכינו מלחמה זו שונה משאר מלחמות שבעולם, דהנה סיחון הוכרח לצאת ממקומו לקראת ישראל כדי שיפגשם בקירוב מקום עד שיוכל לערוך מלחמה אתם, משא"כ עמלק היינו הס"ם אינו צריך לצאת למלחמה כי יכול לערוך מלחמה ממקום שהוא, גם יש לו שלוחים הרבה מסיתים ומדיחים ומלאכים רעים הנבראים מעבירות והמה מסיתים לחטוא עוד, ונמצאים בכל מקום וע"כ לא כתיב ויצא, כי נשאר גם במקומו לפעול פעולתו ומגיע בכל מקום מבלי שיצא למלחמה, וז"ש רז"ל במדרש לא שלותי ולא שקטתי ולא נחתי, ולמה הרי העמיד הקב"ה גואלים לישראל, ולז"א ויבא רוגז שהי' מתמיד ובא רוגז של עמלק והתגבר להחטיא את ישראל, וע"כ לא הי' לישראל מרגוע מהצרות, ולא אמר בזו והעמיד להם גואל כבגזירה ראשונה ושני' וכו', שזה יהי' רק לעתיד כשרות הטומאה תעביר מן הארץ בב"א.
translation: And to explain, "And anger came," and likewise "And Amalek came," the "and" in "came" means that it came and returned and came again, as our Sages have expounded (Bereishit Rabbah, Parashat 66, Section 3) "and he gave and returned and gave." The "and" is to add more coming. Similarly, the evil inclination, even if a person overcomes it once, it returns and comes to fight with new strategies and in a new guise that our ancestors did not anticipate. This resolves the question of why the scripture does not say "And Amalek went out," as it is written "And Sichon went out to meet Israel." In warfare, the term "going out" is more appropriate. However, this war is different from other wars in the world. Sichon was compelled to leave his place to meet Israel in order to confront them in close proximity so that he could wage war against them. In contrast, Amalek, which is the Satan, does not need to go out to war because he can wage war from wherever he is. He also has many agents who incite and lead astray, and evil angels created from sins, and they incite to sin further, and they are found everywhere. Therefore, it is not written "and went out," because he remains in his place to carry out his actions and reaches everywhere without going out to war. This is what our Sages said in the Midrash: "I have not been tranquil, nor have I rested, nor have I had peace." And why? For the Holy One, blessed be He, has established redeemers for Israel. And to explain, "And anger came," which was constant, and the anger of Amalek came and intensified to cause Israel to sin. Therefore, Israel had no respite from troubles, and it did not say in this instance that He established a redeemer for them as in the first and second decrees, etc., for this will only be in the future when the impurity will be removed from the land in the days of the Messiah.
summary: The passage discusses the persistent nature of the evil inclination (yetzer hara) and its relentless attacks on individuals, likening it to the Amalekite threat that continually resurfaces. Unlike other adversaries that must approach Israel to engage in battle, Amalek represents a constant, pervasive force that can operate from anywhere, symbolizing the ever-present struggle against sin. The text emphasizes that this ongoing conflict prevents Israel from finding peace, highlighting the need for divine intervention and redemption in the future, when purity will ultimately prevail.

passage_content: ונבוא לבאר דברי המדרש רות רבתי וזאת לפנים בישראל וגו' לשעבר היו מקלסין על הגאולה וכו' ועכשיו על התמורה שנא' וימירו את כבודם וגו' (הדקדוקים כבר נפרטו לעיל קושיא ב'), ואפ"ל דמ"ש ועכשיו על התמורה, רמזו חז"ל בדרשותיהם על הזמן של עכשיו בעיקבא דמשיחא, לא על חטא העגל שכבר הי' מלפנים, ומפני דקנין זה של בועז הי' שורש השתלשלות מלכות בית דוד ושורש משיח, ע"כ תיארו חז"ל ע"ד רמז הכתובים מה שיארע לישראל בימי הגואל, וז"ש וזאת לפנים בישראל ר' חנינא פתר קרא בגו אפיא דישראל, וגירסת היפה ענף שינוי אפיא, פי' ששינו פניהם ממה שהיו בתחילה, וי"מ על פני העדה והחשובים, ובעוה"ר כולהו איתנייהו שכללות הדור שינו פניהם, וגם פני העדה והחשובים נסוגו אחור, לשעבר היו מקלסין על הגאולה שנא' זה קלי ואנוהו, שהי' התגלות גדול וכ"א מראה באצבע ואומר זה קלי, ועכשיו על התמורה שנא' וימירו את כבודם וגו', שמחליפין כבוד שמים בחילול ש"ש, ובעוה"ר מקלסין להקב"ה על התמורה זו, ונתהפכו הפנים והדעות מקצה אל הקצה ממה שהי' בדורות הראשונים. וכשיעזור השי"ת ויזריח עלינו אור חדש ורוח טהרה לפני ביאת המשיח, אז נודה לה' ויהיו ישראל מקלסין על התמורה האמיתית שיתחלף הכל לטובה, ונזכה להתגלות גדולה יותר מבקרי"ס, וג"ז נרמז בדרז"ל ועכשיו על התמורה, שבימי הגואל נזכה לקלס להקב"ה על התמורה לטובה, שבערך שפלות מצבינו של עכשיו, יהי' ההתחלפות והתמורה גדולה ונסיי, וזה רמזו חז"ל במד"ר בעוה"ז אמרתם לפני פעם אחת זה קלי, דזה מורה על בחי' ההתגלות, דכ"א מראה באצבע כאמרז"ל ראתה שפחה על הים וכו', אבל לע"ל אתם אומרים דבר זה ב' פעמים, שתהי' ההתגלות בישראל גדולה פי כמה ותתרבה הדעת והשגת אלקית עד אין חקר, והביאו ראי' ממ"ש ואמר ביום ההוא הנה אלקינו זה קוינו לו ויושיענו, זה ה' קוינו לו נגילה ונשמחה בישועתו, כי מלת ההוא לשון נסתר, והזה מורה על התגלות, ולעתיד ישיגו ישראל כי גם בתוך ההסתרה הי' ה' עמנו ויהיו מקלסים להשי"ת גם על העבר ובקרי"ס היו ישראל מקלסין זה קלי וגו' אלקי אבי וארוממנהו, מורה על ידיעת אלקית מקבלת האבות ולע"ל יאמרו ישראל הנה אלקינו זה, שתהי' התגלות כבודו ית' מורגש לכל ישראל ויזכו לידיעה עצמית, והשי"ת יעזור שנזכה לראות הישועה האמיתית בהתרוממות קרן התורה וישראל ובהתגלות כבוד שמים עלינו במהרה בימינו אמן.
translation: And we will come to explain the words of the Midrash Ruth Rabbah, "And this was previously in Israel," etc. In the past, they would praise the redemption, etc., and now for the transformation, as it is said, "They exchanged their glory," etc. (The grammatical details have already been elaborated above in question 2). And it can be said that what is meant by "and now for the transformation," our Sages hinted in their teachings about the current time in the footsteps of the Messiah, not about the sin of the golden calf which had already occurred previously. And because this acquisition of Boaz was the root of the unfolding of the Davidic monarchy and the root of the Messiah, therefore our Sages depicted, in a manner of allusion to the scriptures, what will happen to Israel in the days of the Redeemer. And this is what is meant by "and this was previously in Israel." Rabbi Chanina interpreted the verse in the context of the appearance of Israel, and the beautiful version is "the branch of a change in appearance," meaning that they changed their faces from what they were at first. And it can be understood regarding the faces of the congregation and the important ones, and in our current time, all of them have changed their faces, and also the faces of the congregation and the important ones have receded. In the past, they would praise the redemption, as it is said, "This is my God, and I will glorify Him," for there was a great revelation, and everyone pointed with their finger and said, "This is my God." And now for the transformation, as it is said, "They exchanged their glory," etc., that they exchange the honor of Heaven for the desecration of the Holy Name. And in our current time, they praise the Holy One, Blessed be He, for this transformation, and the faces and opinions have turned completely around from what they were in the earlier generations. And when the Holy One, Blessed be He, will help and shine upon us a new light and a pure spirit before the coming of the Messiah, then we will thank the Lord, and Israel will praise the true transformation that will change everything for the good, and we will merit a greater revelation than that of the splitting of the sea. And this is also hinted at in the words of our Sages, "And now for the transformation," that in the days of the Redeemer, we will merit to praise the Holy One, Blessed be He, for the transformation for the good, that in relation to the lowliness of our current state, the change and transformation will be great and miraculous. This our Sages hinted at in the Midrash, "In this world, you said once, 'This is my God,'" for this indicates a level of revelation, that everyone points with their finger, as our Sages said, "A maidservant saw at the sea," etc. But in the future, you will say this thing twice, that the revelation in Israel will be many times greater, and the knowledge and understanding of the Divine will increase without measure. And they brought proof from what is said, "And it will be on that day, behold, this is our God, we waited for Him, and He will save us; this is the Lord, we waited for Him, we will rejoice and be glad in His salvation," for the word "that" is a term of concealment, and this indicates revelation. In the future, Israel will understand that even within the concealment, the Lord was with us, and they will praise the Holy One, Blessed be He, also for the past. And at the splitting of the sea, Israel would praise, "This is my God," etc., "The God of my father, and I will exalt Him," indicating the knowledge of the Divine received from the fathers. And in the future, Israel will say, "Behold, this is our God," that there will be a revelation of His glory felt by all of Israel, and they will merit to a personal knowledge. And may the Holy One, Blessed be He, help us to see the true salvation with the elevation of the banner of the Torah and Israel, and with the revelation of the glory of Heaven upon us speedily in our days, Amen.
summary: The passage discusses the shift in Israel's perception of divine redemption from the past to the present, highlighting a decline in spiritual awareness and reverence. It contrasts the former joyous recognition of God's presence with the current state of confusion and disrespect, symbolized by the phrase "they exchanged their glory." The text emphasizes the hope for a future redemption, where a renewed understanding of God's greatness will lead to a profound transformation and a deeper connection to the divine, culminating in a greater revelation than ever before. Ultimately, it expresses a longing for the Messianic era, when Israel will once again praise God for His true and ultimate redemption.

passage_content: אז ישיר משה ובני ישראל את השירה הזאת וגו', יל"ד מה שפרט הכתוב משה ובנ"י, ומשרע"ה נמי בכלל ישראל, ובשירת הבאר נאמר אז ישיר ישראל, ולא אמר משה וישראל.
translation: Then Moses and the Children of Israel sang this song, etc. The question arises: why does the verse specify Moses and the Children of Israel? For Moshe Rabbeinu is also included in all of Israel. And in the Song of the Well, it is stated, "Then Israel sang," and it does not say "Moses and Israel."
summary: The passage highlights the distinction between Moses and the Israelites in their expressions of song, emphasizing that while Moses is a leader, he is also part of the collective experience of Israel. In the context of the Song of the Sea, the unity of the people is underscored, as they sing together, reflecting a communal relationship with God. This suggests that true spiritual expression arises from collective faith and experience, where individual leadership harmonizes with the collective voice of the community. The reference to the Song of the Well further illustrates the importance of communal worship and the shared journey of faith among the people.

passage_content: ב) רבה (פ' כ"ג סי' ו') אז ישיר משה הה"ד (תהלים נ"ט) ואני אשיר עוזך זו עוזו של ים, וארנן לבקר חסדך זו בוקרו של מתן תורה עכ"ד המדרש וצ"ב הקישור.
translation: B) Rabba (Parashat 23, Siman 6) Then Moshe sang, as it is said (Psalms 59) "And I will sing of Your strength," this refers to the strength of the sea, "and I will sing in the morning of Your kindness," this refers to the morning of the giving of the Torah. Thus concludes the Midrash, and the connection is to be questioned.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the connection between Moses' song after the crossing of the Red Sea and the morning of the giving of the Torah is highlighted. The phrase "I will sing of Your strength" refers to the power of the sea, while "I will rejoice in Your kindness" alludes to the grace bestowed upon the Israelites at the time of the Torah's revelation. This linkage emphasizes the continuity of divine intervention and the significance of gratitude in the Jewish faith, illustrating how moments of salvation and revelation are intertwined in the spiritual journey.

passage_content: ג) (פ' כ"ג סי' ד') אז ישיר משה וגו', הה"ד (משלי ל"א) פיה פתחה בחכמה ותורת חסד על לשונה, מיום שברא הקב"ה את העולם ועד שעמדו ישראל על הים לא מצינו אדם שאמר שירה להקב"ה אלא ישראל, ברא אדה"ר וכו' הציל אברהם מכבשן האש ומן המלכים ולא אמר שירה, וכן יצחק וכו' וכן יעקב מן המלאך וכו' כיון שבאו ישראל לים ונקרע להם מיד אמרו שירה לפני הקב"ה שנא' אז ישיר משה ובני ישראל, הוי פיה פתחה בחכמה עכ"ד המדרש, וראוי להבין טעמא מאי מדוע אבות הראשונים לא אמרו שירה על הנס שנעשה להם, וישראל על הים אמרו שירה, גם צ"ב סיום דברי המדרש הוי פיה פתחה בחכמה, מדוע יחס זה אל מעלת החכמה דייקא.
translation: 3) (Parashat Ki Tavo, Section 4) "Then Moses sang," etc. This is as it is written (Proverbs 31:26) "She opens her mouth with wisdom, and the teaching of kindness is on her tongue." From the day that the Holy One, Blessed be He, created the world until Israel stood by the sea, we do not find anyone who sang a song to the Holy One, Blessed be He, except for Israel. Adam, for example, etc., Abraham was saved from the fiery furnace and from the kings, yet he did not sing a song. Likewise, Isaac, etc., and Jacob from the angel, etc. But when Israel came to the sea and it split for them, they immediately sang a song before the Holy One, Blessed be He, as it is said, "Then Moses and the children of Israel sang." Therefore, "She opens her mouth with wisdom." Thus far the Midrash. It is fitting to understand the reason why the forefathers did not sing a song for the miracle that was done for them, while Israel at the sea sang a song. It is also necessary to clarify the conclusion of the Midrash, "She opens her mouth with wisdom," why this attribute is specifically related to the quality of wisdom.
summary: The passage discusses the unique act of singing praise to God by the Israelites at the Red Sea, contrasting it with the patriarchs who did not sing despite experiencing divine miracles. It highlights that from the creation of the world until the Israelites' crossing of the sea, no one had sung to God, emphasizing the significance of this moment. The reference to "her mouth opened in wisdom" suggests that the act of singing is deeply connected to understanding and wisdom, indicating that true praise arises from a profound recognition of God's greatness and the miracles He performs.

passage_content: ויתבאר בהקדם דברי הגמ' סוטה (י"ג ע"א) בא וראה כמה חביבות מצות על משרע"ה, שכל ישראל כולן נתעסקו בביזה והוא נתעסק במצות, שנא' חכם לב יקח מצות עכ"ד הגמ', והמהרש"א ז"ל דקדק אמאי תיארו אותו בתואר חכם דייקא על עשי' זו, הול"ל צדיק או חסיד, גם יל"ד בלישנא דגמ' שכל ישראל כולן נתעסקו בביזה, ותרי ריבויי כל כולן למאי אתי, וסגי שיאמר כל ישראל, והטו"ז בה' ר"ה פי' מ"ש בנוסח התפלה מלוך על כל העולם כולו. דטעם הכפל, שלא נטעה לפרש דרובו ככולו, לז"א כל העולם כולו, ר"ל כולו ממש עיי"ש, וכמו"כ הכא צ"ב כוונת הכפל, ונקדים עוד דברי המדרש בפ' ואתחנן עה"פ אעברה נא ואראה, אמר לו הקב"ה למשה כתבתי עליך שחכם אתה שנא' חכם לב יקח מצות ואתה רוצה לכנס לארץ עכ"ד המדרש וצ"ב.
translation: And it will be explained at the outset the words of the Gemara in Sotah (13a), "Come and see how beloved the commandments are to Moshe Rabbeinu, for all of Israel were occupied with plunder, and he was occupied with the commandments," as it is stated, "A wise heart will take commandments." Thus concludes the Gemara. And the Maharsha, of blessed memory, noted why he is specifically described with the title "wise" regarding this action; it could have said "righteous" or "pious." It is also to be questioned in the language of the Gemara that all of Israel were occupied with plunder, and what is the purpose of the two repetitions of "all"? It would suffice to say "all of Israel." And the Taz in the fifth chapter of Rosh Hashanah explains what is meant by the wording in the prayer, "Reign over the entire world." The reason for the repetition is so that we do not err in interpreting it as "most of it is like all of it," hence it says "the entire world," meaning truly all of it, as explained there. Similarly, here it is to be questioned what the intention of the repetition is, and we will precede with the words of the Midrash in Parashat Va'etchanan on the verse "Please let me pass and see," that the Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Moshe, "I have written about you that you are wise," as it is stated, "A wise heart will take commandments," and you wish to enter the land. Thus concludes the Midrash, and it is to be questioned.
summary: The passage discusses the exceptional devotion of Moses to the commandments, contrasting it with the rest of Israel's focus on material gain during the spoils of war. It highlights the significance of Moses being referred to as "wise" for his commitment to mitzvot, suggesting that true wisdom lies in spiritual pursuits rather than worldly interests. The text also raises questions about the redundancy in the phrasing regarding the entirety of Israel's involvement and the implications of God's acknowledgment of Moses' wisdom, emphasizing the depth of his character and the divine approval of his priorities.

passage_content: ונל"פ דהנה לכאורה ראוי להבין מ"ט שביק משרע"ה העסק בביזה שהי' ג"כ מצוה ונאמרה להם מפי הגבורה כדי שלא יאמר אותו צדיק וכו', אך ידוע שא"א במציאות שיקיים כל אדם התרי"ג מצות כולן דישנם מצות שנוהגים בכהנים לבד, ומי שאין לו בית איך יקיים מצות מעקה וכדומה, אלא שכל ישראל מתקשרים ומתאחדים כחדא ע"י התוה"ק, וע"כ יש לכל או"א חלק גם במעשה המצות של חבירו, ולטעם זה כתב האריז"ל לומר בכל מעשה המצות ביחודא שלים בשם כל ישראל, ופי' בספה"ק כל ישראל ערבים זל"ז, שהם כמעורבים ומקושרים כגוף א' ויש לכל או"א חלק במעשה המצות של חבירו ואולי שכח זה קבלו ישראל רק במתן תורה, שע"י התוה"ק נתקשרו כולן כחדא, דאילולא זה א"א במציאות שיקיים כל אחד התרי"ג מצות כולם, ועכ"ח שבנתינת התורה ניתן להם כח הערבות וההתקשרות, אבל לפני מ"ת לא הי' להם כח הערבות כי לא הי' הכרח אליו, אמנם כבר גילה הקב"ה למשרע"ה וא"ל בהוציאך את העם ממצרים תעבדון את האלקים על ההר הזה, שבזכות שעתידים לקבל את התורה יהיו נגאלים, והפר"ד הוכיח מכאן דלטובה הקב"ה דן ע"ש העתיד עיי"ש, וק"ז הייטב לב זלה"ה כתב דלא צריכנא לטעמא דע"ש העתיד נגאלו, אלא מפני שקיבלו על עצמם בעודם במצרים, שלכשיצאו יקבלו עול התורה והמצות נחשב להם הקבלה כמעשה מיד עייש"ד.
translation: And it seems that, seemingly, it is appropriate to understand why Moshe Rabbeinu engaged in the plunder, which was also a mitzvah and was commanded to them from the mouth of the Almighty, so that the righteous one would not say, etc. However, it is known that it is impossible in reality for every person to fulfill all 613 commandments, as there are commandments that apply only to the priests, and one who does not have a house, how can he fulfill the commandment of a railing and similar ones? Rather, all of Israel are connected and united as one through the Torah, and therefore each person has a share in the mitzvahs of his friend. For this reason, the Arizal wrote to say in every act of the mitzvahs, particularly in the name of all of Israel, and it is explained in the holy books that all of Israel are mutually responsible for one another, as they are intertwined and connected like one body, and each person has a share in the mitzvahs of his friend. Perhaps this concept was accepted by Israel only at the giving of the Torah, that through the Torah they all became connected as one, for without this it would be impossible for each one to fulfill all 613 commandments. And thus, in the giving of the Torah, they were given the power of mutual responsibility and connection, but before the giving of the Torah, they did not have the power of mutual responsibility because there was no necessity for it. However, the Holy One, Blessed be He, already revealed to Moshe Rabbeinu and said to him, "When you bring the people out of Egypt, you shall serve God on this mountain," that by virtue of their future acceptance of the Torah, they would be redeemed. And the Pardes proved from here that for good, the Holy One, Blessed be He, judges based on the future, as mentioned there. And similarly, the Baal Shem Tov wrote that we do not need the reason that they were redeemed because of the future, but rather because they accepted upon themselves while still in Egypt, that when they would leave, they would accept the yoke of the Torah and the commandments, and this acceptance is considered as an act immediately.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of collective responsibility among the Jewish people regarding the fulfillment of the commandments, emphasizing that not every individual can observe all 613 mitzvot due to varying circumstances. It highlights the unity of Israel through the Torah, which connects each person to the mitzvot performed by others, as they are all considered part of a single body. The text also notes that this interconnectedness and mutual responsibility were established at the giving of the Torah, and that the Jewish people's acceptance of the Torah while still in Egypt was a significant factor in their eventual redemption.

passage_content: ובזה יתבאר לעניננו כי משרע"ה עסק בעצמות יוסף לטעם שאמרז"ל כבודו בגדולים יותר, ושביק העסק בביזה אף שהי' ג"כ מצו' גדולה מ"מ סמך על ההתכללות והתקשרות עם כלל ישראל, שהם קיימו מצו' זו ונחשב גם הוא עמהם, ולזה תיארו אותו חז"ל במעשה זו בתואר חכם, ודרשו הכתוב חכם לב יקח מצות על משרע"ה שעסק בעצמות יוסף, דאיזה חכם הרואה את הנולד, וע"ש העתיד שעתידים ישראל לקבל את התורה, נחשב להם משעת הקבלה כאילו כבר עשו, נמצא כל ישראל מקושרים ומתאחדים כאחד ע"י התוה"ק ויש לו חלק במעשה המצוה של כל א' מישראל, ולז"א חכם לב יקח מצות, שע"י בחי' החכמה זכה למצות הרבה, העסק בעצמות יוסף גם הי"ל חלק במצות של כל ישראל, כי משרע"ה הי' כלולים בו כל נשמות ישראל כידוע, וכל ישראל כלולים כחדא ע"י התוה"ק, ולדרכנו יובן כפילת הלשון שכל ישראל כולן נתעסקו בביזה, ואולי ירמוז על ההתכללות, שכל ישראל כולם כלולים כחדא ונתעסקו בביזה, ועי"ז הי"ל חלק עמהם, ועי"ז חכם לב יקח מצות כנ"ל.
translation: And this will clarify our matter, that Moshe Rabbeinu engaged with the bones of Yosef for the reason that our Sages of blessed memory said, "His honor is greater among the great ones." And although he was also engaged in the spoils, which was also a great mitzvah, nevertheless, he relied on the inclusion and connection with all of Israel, who fulfilled this mitzvah, and he was considered with them. Therefore, our Sages described him in this act with the title of "wise," and they expounded the verse "A wise heart will acquire commandments" regarding Moshe Rabbeinu who engaged with the bones of Yosef, for what wise person sees the future, and concerning the future that Israel is destined to receive the Torah, he is considered from the time of the receiving as if they have already done it. Thus, all of Israel is connected and united as one through the Torah, and he has a share in the act of the mitzvah of each one of Israel. And this is why it says "A wise heart will acquire commandments," that through the aspect of wisdom he merited many commandments; the engagement with the bones of Yosef also gave him a share in the commandments of all of Israel, for Moshe Rabbeinu contained within him all the souls of Israel, as is known, and all of Israel are included as one through the Torah. And according to our path, the repetition of the language is understood, that all of Israel were engaged in the spoils, and perhaps it hints at the inclusion, that all of Israel are included as one and were engaged in the spoils, and through this he had a share with them, and thus "A wise heart will acquire commandments," as mentioned above.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of Moses' engagement with the bones of Joseph, emphasizing that his actions reflect a deep connection to the collective identity of the Jewish people. It highlights the concept that through the Torah, all Israelites are unified, allowing Moses to partake in the merits of their collective mitzvot. The term "wise heart" signifies the foresight of Moses in recognizing the future acceptance of the Torah by Israel, thus linking him to their spiritual achievements. Ultimately, this illustrates the profound interconnectedness of all Jewish souls through their shared commitment to the commandments.

passage_content: ועד"ז יתבאר אידך דברי המדרש א"ל הקב"ה למשה כתבתי עליך שחכם אתה שנא' חכם לב יקח מצות, ואתה רוצה ליכנס לארץ, דהנה אמרז"ל בטעם שהשתוקק משרע"ה ליכנס לארץ, וכי לאכול מפרי' הוא צריך, אלא כדי לקיים מצות התלויות בארץ אמנם ע"י ההתכללות בכלל כל ישראל הרי יש לו חלק עמהם, ולז"א לו הקב"ה כתבתי עליך שחכם אתה שנא' חכם לב יקח מצות, וע"י בחי' החכמה זכה להיות חלק במעשה המצות של כל ישראל, כי משרע"ה בחי' הדעת של כל ישראל וכולם כלולים בו, ומעתה אין מוכרח כניסתך לארץ בשביל לקיים מצות התלויות בארץ שבלא"ה יהי' לך חלק במעשיהם, כי הכל מכוחך וכלולים בך בשורש.
translation: And similarly, the other words of the Midrash will be explained: The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Moses, "I have written about you that you are wise," as it is said, "A wise heart will acquire commandments." And you wish to enter the Land; behold, our Sages have said regarding the reason that Moses yearned to enter the Land, "Is it to eat from its fruits that he needs?" Rather, it is in order to fulfill the commandments that are dependent on the Land. However, through the inclusion in the whole of Israel, he has a portion with them. Therefore, the Holy One, Blessed be He, said to him, "I have written about you that you are wise," as it is said, "A wise heart will acquire commandments." And through the aspect of wisdom, he merited to be a part of the performance of the commandments of all of Israel, for Moses is the aspect of the knowledge of all of Israel, and all are included in him. From now on, your entry into the Land is not necessary in order to fulfill the commandments that are dependent on the Land, for you will have a portion in their deeds anyway, because everything is through you and included in you at the root.
summary: The passage discusses God's affirmation to Moses that he is wise, as indicated by the verse "A wise heart will acquire commandments." It emphasizes that Moses' desire to enter the Promised Land is not for personal benefit, but to fulfill the commandments associated with the land. However, due to his integral role as the intellectual and spiritual leader of the Jewish people, Moses is already connected to their collective observance of the commandments, suggesting that his wisdom allows him to partake in their merits without needing to physically enter the land. This highlights the concept of unity within the Jewish people and the idea that spiritual leadership transcends physical boundaries.

passage_content: נחזור לעניננו לבאר דברי המדרשים (בפ' שירה) אז ישיר משה וגו' הה"ד פיה פתחה בחכמה וגו', מיום שברא הקב"ה את העולם וכו' לא מצינו אדם שאמר שירה להקב"ה אלא ישראל וכו' הוי פיה פתחה בחכמה, ולדרכנו אפ"ל עפימ"ש רז"ל לא כל הרוצה לומר שירה אומר והנה האבוה"ק לגודל ענותנותם ושפלותם בעיני עצמם חשבו שאינם ראויים לומר שירה להקב"ה, אמנם משרע"ה אף שלא חשב א"ע כדאי, מ"מ חשב שלצד התכללותו עם כל ישראל ובצירוף זכותם של כל ישראל יוכל לומר שירה להקב"ה משא"כ אבות הראשונים אדה"ר ואברהם יצחק ויעקב לא יכלו לסמוך על כח ההצטרפות, ולזה נמנעו מלומר שירה מחמת היראה כנ"ל, ולז"א הכתוב אז ישיר משה ובני ישראל את השירה הזאת, שמה שעלה בלבו לומר שירה, הי' בשביל שנצטרפו אליו כל ישראל, וגם בני ישראל סמכו על זה שיצטרף זכותם של כל או"א ע"י התכללותם במשרע"ה וכח התוה"ק שקבלו עליהם, ולזה סיימו במדרש הוי פיה פתחה בחכמה, שע"י בחי' החכמה איזהו חכם הרואה הנולד השיגו כח ההתכללות משה רבינו וכל ישראל כאחד ולזה פתחו פיהם לומר שירה, ובזה יתבאר דברי המדרש ואני אשיר עוזך זו עוזו של ים וארנן לבקר חסדך זו בוקרו של מתן תורה, שסמכו על כח הערבות של מ"ת ופתחו פיהם לומר שירה והבן.
translation: Let us return to our matter to explain the words of the Midrash (in Parashat Shira) "Then Moses sang..." as it is written, "Her mouth opened with wisdom..." From the day that the Holy One, blessed be He, created the world, etc., we do not find anyone who sang a song to the Holy One, blessed be He, except for Israel, etc. Therefore, "Her mouth opened with wisdom." According to our approach, we can say as our Sages have said, "Not everyone who wishes to sing a song sings," and behold, the Patriarchs, due to their great humility and lowliness in their own eyes, thought that they were not worthy to sing a song to the Holy One, blessed be He. However, Moses, even though he did not consider himself worthy, nevertheless thought that through his inclusion with all of Israel and by virtue of the merit of all of Israel, he could sing a song to the Holy One, blessed be He. This is unlike the earlier Patriarchs, Adam, Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, who could not rely on the power of inclusion, and therefore refrained from singing a song out of fear, as mentioned above. And thus the verse states, "Then Moses and the children of Israel sang this song," for what arose in his heart to sing a song was because all of Israel joined him, and the children of Israel relied on this, that their merit would be included through their connection with Moses our teacher and the power of the Torah that they accepted upon themselves. Therefore, the Midrash concludes, "Her mouth opened with wisdom," that through the aspect of wisdom, "Who is wise? One who sees the birth," they attained the power of inclusion, Moses our teacher and all of Israel as one, and thus they opened their mouths to sing a song. In this, the words of the Midrash will be clarified: "I will sing of Your strength," this is the strength of the sea, "and I will sing aloud of Your kindness in the morning," this is the morning of the giving of the Torah, for they relied on the power of the mutual responsibility of the giving of the Torah and opened their mouths to sing a song. Understand this.
summary: The passage discusses the unique ability of the Jewish people to sing praises to God, emphasizing that this capacity stems from their collective identity and the merit of their unity. It contrasts the humility of the patriarchs, who felt unworthy to sing due to their individual greatness, with Moses, who, through his connection to all of Israel, felt empowered to lead them in song. The text highlights the significance of the Torah and the communal bond among the Jewish people, which allows them to express their gratitude and praise to God, particularly in the context of the miraculous events surrounding the Exodus and the giving of the Torah. Ultimately, it illustrates the concept of "arvut," or mutual responsibility, as a foundational element in their relationship with God.

passage_content: אז ישיר משה ובני ישראל את השירה הזאת לה' וגו', במד"ר (פ' כ"ג סי' ד') הה"ד (משלי ל"א) פיה פתחה בחכמה ותורת חסד על לשונה, מיום שברא הקב"ה את העולם, ועד שעמדו ישראל על הים, לא מצינו אדם שאמר שירה להקב"ה אלא ישראל, ברא אדה"ר ולא אמר שירה, הציל אברהם מכבשן האש ומן המלכים ולא אמר שירה, וכן יצחק וכו' וכן יעקב וכו', כיון שבאו ישראל לים ונקרע להם, מיד אמרו שירה לפני הקב"ה שנאמר אז ישיר משה ובני ישראל, אמר הקב"ה לאלו הייתי מצפה, ואין אז אלא שמחה שנאמר (תהלים קכ"ו) אז ימלא שחוק פינו עכ"ד המדרש, וצ"ב מדוע באמת לא אמרו האבוה"ק שירה, ולהלן במדרש (סי' ה') תשורי מראש אמנה וכו', א"ר שמעון בר אבא בשביל האמנה שהאמין אברהם להקב"ה שנאמר והאמין בה', ממנה זכו ישראל לומר שירה על הים שנאמר אז ישיר משה, הוי תשורי מראש אמנה עכ"ד המדרש, הרי שאמרו ישראל שירה בזכות אברהם, ואיך הוא בעצמו לא אמר והוא פלא.
translation: Then Moses and the children of Israel sang this song to the Lord, etc. In the Midrash (Parashat Ki Tisa, Section 4), it is stated (Proverbs 31) "She opens her mouth with wisdom, and the teaching of kindness is on her tongue." From the day that the Holy One, Blessed be He, created the world, until Israel stood by the sea, we do not find anyone who sang a song to the Holy One, Blessed be He, except for Israel. Adam was created and did not sing a song; Abraham was saved from the fiery furnace and from the kings and did not sing a song; likewise Isaac, and so too Jacob. Once Israel came to the sea and it split for them, they immediately sang a song before the Holy One, Blessed be He, as it is said, "Then Moses and the children of Israel sang." The Holy One, Blessed be He, said, "For these I was waiting," and "then" signifies joy, as it is said (Psalms 126) "Then our mouth was filled with laughter." Thus far the Midrash. It is indeed puzzling why the forefathers did not sing a song. Later in the Midrash (Section 5), "Awake from the heights of faith," etc. Rabbi Shimon bar Abba said, "Because of the faith that Abraham had in the Holy One, Blessed be He, as it is said, 'And he believed in the Lord,' from that faith Israel merited to sing a song at the sea, as it is said, 'Then Moses sang.'" Therefore, "Awake from the heights of faith." Thus, it is stated that Israel sang a song in the merit of Abraham, and how is it that he himself did not sing? This is indeed a wonder.
summary: The passage discusses the unique moment when the Israelites sang a song of praise to God after crossing the Red Sea, highlighting that prior to this event, no other figures in the Torah, including Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, had sung to God despite their significant experiences. It emphasizes that this act of singing was a culmination of faith, particularly referencing Abraham's belief in God, which enabled the Israelites to express their gratitude and joy. The text suggests that the ability to sing praises is linked to a deep spiritual connection and fulfillment of divine expectation, illustrating the importance of communal worship and the legacy of faith passed down from the patriarchs.

passage_content: ב) איתא במדרש (פ' כ"ג סי' ז') הה"ד (תהלים ס"ח) קדמו שרים אחר נוגנים א"ר יוחנן בקשו המלאכים לומר שירה לפני הקב"ה באותו הלילה שעברו ישראל את הים ולא הניחן הקב"ה א"ל לגיונותי נתונין בצרה ואתם אומרים לפני שירה, הה"ד ולא קרב זה אל זה כל הלילה, כמה דתימא (ישעי' ו') וקרא זה אל זה ואמר, וכיון שיצאו ישראל מן הים באו המלאכים להקדים שירה לפני הקב"ה א"ל הקב"ה יקדמו בני תחלה הה"ד אז ישיר משה, אז שר לא נאמר אלא אז ישיר שהקב"ה אמר ישיר משה ובני ישראל תחלה, וכן דוד הוא אומר קדמו שרים אלו ישראל שעמדו על הים דכתיב אז ישיר משה, אחר נוגנים אלו המלאכים ולמה כך, אמר הקב"ה למלאכים לא מפני שאני משפיל אתכם אני אומר שיקדמו תחלה, אלא מפני שב"ו יאמרו תחלה עד שלא ימות אחד מהם, אבל אתם כל זמן שאתם מבקשים אתם חיים וקיימים, משל למלך שנשבה בנו והלך והצילו והלכו בני הפלטין מבקשין לקלס למלך ובנו מבקש לקלסו אמרו לו אדונינו מי יקלסך תחלה א"ל בני, מכאן ואילך מי שרוצה לקלסני יקלסני, כך כשיצאו ישראל ממצרים וכו' עכ"ד המדרש, לכאורה רישא לאו סיפא דבתחלה מבאר הטעם שישראל יקדמו תחלה לא מפני שאני משפיל אתכם אלא עד שלא ימות אחד מהם, ובדמיון המשל שהביא אח"כ לא שייך טעם זה, שיקלס בנו קודם שמא ימות, דגם באחרים איכא חשש מיתה וע"כ הטעם משום חשיבות לא כמו שאמר ברישא.
translation: It is stated in the Midrash (Parashat Ki Tisa, section 7) regarding the verse (Psalms 68) "The leaders preceded those who played music." Rabbi Yochanan said that the angels sought to sing praise before the Holy One, Blessed be He, on that night when Israel crossed the sea, but the Holy One, Blessed be He, did not allow them. He said to them, "My legions are in distress, and you are singing praise before Me." This is as it is written, "And there was no one who drew near to one another all night," as it is said (Isaiah 6), "And one called to another and said." And when Israel emerged from the sea, the angels came to precede the song before the Holy One, Blessed be He. The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to them, "Let My children precede first," as it is written, "Then Moses sang." It does not say "Then he sang," but "Then Moses sang," for the Holy One, Blessed be He, said, "Moses and the children of Israel will sing first." And David also says, "The leaders who stood by the sea," as it is written, "Then Moses sang." The "after those who played music" refers to the angels. And why is this? The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to the angels, "Not because I am degrading you do I say that they should precede first, but because the children will sing first so that none of them will die." But you, as long as you are seeking, you are alive and enduring. It is like a king who was captured by enemies and went and saved himself, and the sons of the palace were seeking to praise the king, and his son was seeking to praise him. They said to him, "Our master, who will praise you first?" He said to them, "My son, from now on, whoever wants to praise me may praise me." Thus, when Israel went out of Egypt, etc. Thus concludes the Midrash. At first glance, the beginning does not align with the end, as the reason that Israel should precede first is not because I am degrading you, but so that none of them will die. And in the parable that he later brought, this reason does not apply, that the son should praise first lest he die, for there is also a concern of death among others, and therefore the reason is due to importance, not as stated in the beginning.
summary: The passage discusses a midrashic interpretation of the events following the crossing of the Red Sea, highlighting the tension between the angels and the Israelites regarding who should sing praise to God first. God instructs the angels to allow the Israelites to sing first, emphasizing the unique status of humanity, as their lives are fragile and precious. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of the importance of human experience and the divine preference for human expression of gratitude and praise, underscoring the relationship between God and His people. The analogy of a king and his son illustrates the idea that the personal connection and vulnerability of the Israelites warrant their precedence in worship.

translation: 3) Yalkut (Shir HaShirim Remez 829) that those who ascended from the bathhouse, that the Holy One, Blessed be He, sprinkled upon them dew and they were purified from their sins, all of them were fitting, as they were aligned between the Shechinah and the angels, and there was not one among them who was not harmed, nor were there any with blemishes, thus concludes the Midrash, and the connection is questioned.
summary: The passage discusses a mystical interpretation of a verse from the Song of Songs, highlighting that those who emerged from purification were blessed by God with dew, which cleansed them of their sins. It emphasizes the harmony between the Divine Presence (Shechinah) and the angels, indicating that all individuals were perfectly aligned and free from blemishes. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of spiritual elevation and the transformative power of divine grace in achieving purity and wholeness. The text invites contemplation on the connection between the divine and the celestial, underscoring the importance of spiritual readiness and alignment.

passage_content: ד) במדרש (פ' כ"א סי' ג') ויאמר ה' אל משה מה תצעק אלי, הה"ד (ישעי' ס"ה) והי' טרם יקראו ואני אענה שהקב"ה וכו', אבל הקב"ה אינו כן עד שלא ידבר אדם הוא יודע מה בלבו וכו', לכך כתיב והי' טרם יקראו ואני אענה, לכך נאמר מה תצעק אלי עכ"ד המדרש, והקשה היפ"ת דא"כ אין צורך לעולם להתפלל בפה דהקב"ה יודע בקשתו ותסגי במחשבה בלב, והלכה פסוקה שצריך להתפלל בדיבור פה דייקא.
translation: In the Midrash (Parashat 21, Section 3), it says: "And the Lord said to Moses, 'Why do you cry out to Me?' This is as it is written (Isaiah 65), 'Before they call, I will answer.' The Holy One, blessed be He, etc. However, the Holy One, blessed be He, is not like that; before a person speaks, He knows what is in his heart, etc. Therefore, it is written, 'Before they call, I will answer.' This is why it is said, 'Why do you cry out to Me?' Thus concludes the Midrash. The question arises: If so, there is no need for a person to pray verbally, for the Holy One, blessed be He, knows his request, and it would suffice with thought in the heart. Yet, it is a definitive law that one must pray with the mouth specifically."
summary: The passage discusses the idea that God knows a person's thoughts and needs even before they articulate them, as illustrated by the verse from Isaiah. However, it raises the question of why verbal prayer is necessary if God is already aware of one's heart's desires. The conclusion emphasizes that despite God's omniscience, there is a halachic requirement for individuals to pray verbally, highlighting the importance of spoken prayer in connecting with the Divine. This reflects a key Hasidic concept that while God understands our inner thoughts, the act of verbal prayer serves a vital role in spiritual practice.

passage_content: ה) במדרש (פ' כ"א סי' ד') הה"ד (תהלים ס"ה) שומע תפלה עדיך כל בשר יבואו, מהו שומע תפלה, א"ר פנחס בשם ר"מ ור' ירמי' בשם ר' חייא בר אבא בשעה שישראל מתפללין אין אתה מוצא שכולן מתפללין כאחד אלא כל כנסי' וכנסי' מתפללת בפני עצמה וכו', ומאחר שכל הכנסיות גומרת כל התפלות, המלאך הממונה על התפלות נוטל כל התפלות שהתפללו בכל הכנסיות כולן, ועושה אותן עטרות ונותנן בראשו של הקב"ה שנאמר עדיך כל בשר יבואו ואין עדיך אלא עטרה שנאמר וכו', התחיל משה אף הוא מתפלל לפני המקום, א"ל הקב"ה למשה מה אתה עומד ומתפלל כבר התפללו בני ושמעתי תפלתן שנאמר מה תצעק אלי עכ"ד המדרש, לכאורה הוא סתירה מני' ובי' דברישא אמר שהמלאך ממתין על כל תפלות ישראל ועושה אותן עטרה, וא"כ מ"ט לא המתין הקב"ה על תפלת משרע"ה ואמר לו כבר התפללו בני, והרי ממתינין להצטרף תפלתן של כל ישראל, ומכ"ש תפלת הצדיקים שהקב"ה מתאוה לתפלתן.
translation: In the Midrash (Parashat 21, Siman 4), it is stated (Psalms 65) "You hear prayer, to You all flesh will come." What does it mean "You hear prayer"? Rabbi Pinchas said in the name of Rabbi Meir, and Rabbi Yirmiyah said in the name of Rabbi Chiya bar Abba: At the time when Israel prays, you do not find that they all pray as one, but each congregation prays separately, etc. And since all the congregations complete all the prayers, the angel appointed over prayers takes all the prayers that were prayed in all the congregations and makes them crowns and places them on the head of the Holy One, Blessed be He, as it is said, "to You all flesh will come," and "to You" means a crown, as it is said, etc. Moses also began to pray before the Holy One, Blessed be He. The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Moses, "Why are you standing and praying? My children have already prayed, and I have heard their prayer," as it is said, "Why do you cry out to Me?" Thus far the Midrash. At first glance, this is a contradiction: in the beginning, it said that the angel waits for all the prayers of Israel and makes them a crown, and if so, why did the Holy One, Blessed be He, not wait for the prayer of Moses and said to him, "My children have already prayed"? And behold, they wait to join the prayer of all Israel, and certainly the prayer of the righteous, for the Holy One, Blessed be He, desires their prayer.
summary: The passage discusses the nature of prayer in Judaism, emphasizing that while individual congregations pray separately, their collective prayers are gathered by an angel and transformed into crowns for God. It highlights the idea that God listens to the prayers of all Israel, yet when Moses prays, God tells him that He has already heard the prayers of the people, raising questions about the relationship between individual and communal prayer. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the significance of both collective and individual supplication, illustrating God's desire for the prayers of the righteous.

passage_content: ונתחיל בביאור דברי המדרש הנ"ל (קושיא ב') שהקדים הקב"ה שירת ישראל לפני המלאכים לטעם חשש המיתה הנוהגת בבשר ודם ואינו במלאכים, ובהמשל שהסמיך אליו מבואר דטעם הקדמתן משום יתרון מעלתם וחיבתן, ויתבאר בהקדם דברי רש"י ז"ל (ר"פ תשא) שהקשה איך אפשר שבב' המנינים שנמנו ישראל בשנה ראשונה בתשרי, ובאייר שנה שני', הי' מספרם שוה בצמצום ת"ר אלף וג' אלפים ותק"נ, וא"א שלא היו בשעת מנין הראשון בני י"ט שנה שלא נמנו ובשני' נעשו בני כ', תשובה לדבר אצל שנות האנשים בשנה א' נמנו, אבל למנין יציאת מצרים היו ב' שנים וכו' עיי"ש, והרמב"ן ז"ל תמה על דבריו דאיך יתכן שיהי' קהל גדול כמותו, ולא ימותו בו בחצי שנה למאות ולאלפים, והנה לפי דברי הרב עמדו בשבעה חדשים ולא מת א', וכתיב ויהי אנשים אשר היו טמאים לנפש אדם וכו' עיי"ש תירוצו, ובספה"ק פנים יפות מביא מדברי המדרש דלא הי' מיתה נוהגת בישראל כלל בזמן ההוא, זולת באותן המפורשין בכתוב נדב ואביהו, ואחר חטא המרגלים נגזרה גזירת המיתה על דור המדבר, במדבר הזה יתמו ושם ימותו, אבל באותו הזמן שבין מנין ראשון לשני לא מת א' מישראל, וא"כ הקושיא מעיקרא ליתא.
translation: And we will begin with the explanation of the words of the aforementioned Midrash (question 2) that the Holy One, blessed be He, preceded the song of Israel before the angels due to the concern of death that applies to flesh and blood and does not apply to angels. And in the parable that is connected to it, it is explained that the reason for their precedence is due to the superiority of their status and their affection. It will be clarified by first mentioning the words of Rashi, of blessed memory (in Parashat Terumah), who asked how it is possible that in the two counts in which Israel was counted in the first year in Tishrei, and in Iyar of the second year, their number was the same, precisely 603,550. It is impossible that there were not at the time of the first count those who were 19 years old and were not counted, and in the second count they became 20. The answer to this is that regarding the years of the people, in the first year they were counted, but for the count of the Exodus from Egypt, there were two years, etc., as explained there. And Ramban, of blessed memory, was astonished at his words, how it is possible for such a large congregation to exist without hundreds or thousands dying within half a year. And according to the words of the Rabbi, they stood for seven months and not one died. And it is written, "And there were men who were unclean because of a dead person," etc., as explained there in his resolution. And in the holy book "Panim Yafot," he brings from the words of the Midrash that there was no death occurring among Israel at that time, except for those explicitly mentioned in the scripture, Nadav and Abihu. And after the sin of the spies, the decree of death was pronounced on the generation of the wilderness, "In this wilderness they shall be consumed, and there they shall die." However, at that time, between the first and second counts, not one of Israel died. Therefore, the initial question is not applicable.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of God's preference for the song of Israel over that of the angels, highlighting the unique status and love for the Jewish people. It addresses the question of how the population of Israel remained constant despite the passage of time and the potential for death, suggesting that during the period between the first and second census, death did not occur among the Israelites, except for specific individuals like Nadav and Avihu. This reflects a theological insight into the sanctity and protection of the Jewish people during that time, which was later altered due to the sin of the spies. Ultimately, the text emphasizes the special relationship between God and Israel, underscoring their elevated spiritual standing.

passage_content: ויתכן דמעלה זו שנעדר מהם המיתה, לא הי' רק לישראל אבל הערב רב לא זכו לזה, וכמ"ש בגמרא (פסחים דף ס"ח ע"א) עולא רמי כתיב (ישעי' כ"ה) בלע המות לנצח וכתיב (שם ס"ה) כי הנער בן מאה שנה ימות, לא קשיא כאן בישראל כאן באומות העולם עכ"ד הגמרא, ואף שהאומה"ע יהיו כולם גרים גרורים לע"ל, אבל מעלה זו שיעדר המיתה מהם לא ישיגו, וכמו"כ הע"ר שנתגיירו לא זכו למעלה זו, והנה וודאי שכל ישראל אמרו שירה ביחד והקדימו למלאכים ואף הע"ר, דראתה שפחה על הים מה שלא ראה יחזקאל בנבואה (מכילתא), ואף עוברין שבמעי אמן אמרו שירה, ומעתה א"ש דברי המדרש הנ"ל אמר הקב"ה למלאכים לא מפני שאני משפיל אתכם וכו' יקדמו בני תחלה, אלא מפני שבשר ודם יאמרו תחלה עד שלא ימות אחד מהם, וזהו טעם על הקדמת הע"ר שהי' המיתה נוהגת בהם, אבל בישראל ליתא לטעם זה, וטעם הקדמתן מפני מעלתן וחיבתן, דגדולים צדיקים יותר ממה"ש, וזה הטעם מבואר בהמשל שאמר המלך בני יקלס תחלה וכו', ובזה יבואר כוונת דברי המדרש שה"ש, שעלו מן הרחצה וכו' ונרחצו מעונותיהם, שכולם מתאימות שהיו מותאמים בין שכינה למלאך, ונתעלו יותר ממה"ש, וע"כ הקדימו לומר שירה. ושכולה אין בהם שלא ניזוק א' מהם, וליתא לחששא שמא ימות א' מהם, וע"כ טעם הקדמתן לגודל מעלתם.
translation:
It is possible that this merit of being free from death was not only for Israel, but the mixed multitude did not merit this, as it is stated in the Gemara (Pesachim 68a) that Ulla posed a contradiction: it is written (Isaiah 25) "He will swallow up death forever," and it is written (Isaiah 65) "For the youth will die at a hundred years." This is not a contradiction; here it refers to Israel, and there it refers to the nations of the world, thus concludes the Gemara. And although the nations of the world will all be converts in the World to Come, they will not attain this merit of being free from death. Likewise, the mixed multitude that converted did not merit this elevation. 

And certainly, all of Israel sang together and preceded the angels, even the mixed multitude, as the maidservant saw at the sea what Ezekiel did not see in prophecy (Mechilta), and even the fetuses in the womb of Amram sang. From now on, I understand the words of the aforementioned Midrash, that the Holy One, Blessed be He, said to the angels, "Not because I am degrading you, etc., will the children precede you," but because flesh and blood will say first before one of them dies. This is the reason for the precedence of the mixed multitude, as death was applicable to them, but for Israel, this reason does not apply. The reason for their precedence is due to their merit and affection, for the righteous are greater than the ministering angels. This reason is clarified in the parable that the king said, "My children will be praised first," etc. 

And this will clarify the intent of the words of the Midrash that they ascended from the washing, etc., and were cleansed from their sins, as they were all aligned between the Shechinah and the angel, and they ascended higher than the ministering angels, and therefore they preceded in singing. And there is not one among them who was not harmed, and there is no concern that one of them might die, and therefore the reason for their precedence is due to their great merit.
summary: The passage discusses the unique spiritual status of the Jewish people, emphasizing that they are exempt from death in a way that the mixed multitude (Erev Rav) and converts are not. It highlights that all of Israel sang together at the sea, surpassing even the angels, and that their merit and closeness to God allowed them to express praise without the fear of death. The text illustrates that the greatness of the righteous is such that they are considered superior to the angels, and their ability to sing first reflects their elevated spiritual state. Ultimately, this underscores the special relationship between Israel and the Divine, marked by a profound connection that transcends mortality.

passage_content: ונקדים מ"ש. החיד"א זלה"ה (וק"ז הישמח משה זלה"ה בתפלה למשה קמ"ו פי' כן מד"ע) לפרש הפסוק תהלת ה' ידבר פי ויברך כל בשר שם קדשו לעולם ועד דהנה הקב"ה הוא בוחן כליות ולב ויודע במחשבת אדם, א"כ למה צריכין להתפלל בפה, ופירשו דבאמת לגבי הקב"ה כביכול אין צורך לזה רק כדי שיתעוררו גם אחרים מקולו ויודו וישבחו להשי"ת, כמ"ש כבוד מלכותך יאמרו וגו' להודיע לבני האדם גבורותיו וז"פ הפסוק תהלת ה' ידבר פי, ויברך כל בשר שם קדשו, כדי שגם אחרים יברכו את השי"ת על ידו, וזה הוא התכלית הבריאה שיהיו משפיעין גם על אחרים, וכמו שפי' בספה"ק בינה לעיתים אם למדת תורה הרבה אל תחזיק טובה לעצמך כי לכך נוצרת, היינו שלא תחזיק לעצמך את התורה שלמדת, אלא תשפיע גם לאחרים, כי לכך נוצרת שזהו תכלית הבריאה, עכ"פ זה הוא הטעם שצריך להתפלל בפה כדי שיתעוררו אחרים.
translation: And we will precede with what is stated by the Chida, of blessed memory (and so too the Yismach Moshe, of blessed memory, in the prayer for Moshe, chapter 136, explains this according to the teachings of our sages) to explain the verse "The praise of the Lord shall be spoken by my mouth, and all flesh shall bless His holy name forever and ever." Behold, the Holy One, blessed be He, is the one who examines the kidneys and the heart and knows the thoughts of man. If so, why is there a need to pray with the mouth? They explained that in truth, regarding the Holy One, blessed be He, so to speak, there is no need for this, except that others should also be aroused by His voice and give thanks and praise to the Blessed One, as it is said, "The glory of Your kingdom they shall speak," etc., to make known to mankind His mighty deeds. And this is the meaning of the verse "The praise of the Lord shall be spoken by my mouth, and all flesh shall bless His holy name," so that others may also bless the Blessed One through him. This is the purpose of creation, that they should also influence others. And as it is explained in the holy books, "If you have learned much Torah, do not hold the good for yourself, for this is why you were created," meaning that you should not keep the Torah you have learned for yourself, but rather influence others as well, for this is the purpose of creation. In any case, this is the reason why one must pray with the mouth, so that others may be aroused.
summary: The passage discusses the necessity of verbal prayer, emphasizing that while God knows the thoughts and intentions of individuals, prayer serves to inspire others to acknowledge and praise Him. It highlights the idea that the ultimate purpose of creation is to influence and uplift others, as reflected in the teachings of Hasidic thought. The text underscores that one should not hoard the knowledge gained from studying Torah but rather share it with others, reinforcing the communal aspect of worship and spiritual growth.

passage_content: והנה אצל הים לא היו צריכין לזה לעורר כל ישראל לתפלה, שהרי היו בעת צרה, כמו שדרשו רז"ל (במד"ר פ' כ"א סי' ה') שהקריב את לבן של ישראל לאביהם שבשמים, ומעצמן ג"כ מתפללין ולא הי' צורך לעוררן, ולגבי הקב"ה סגי בתפלה בלב שהוא יודע מחשבות אדם, וא"ש דברי המדרש מה תצעק אלי הה"ד טרם יקראו ואני אענה וכו' דאין צורך עכשיו להתפלל בפה דייקא כדי לעורר את ישראל, ול"ק קושית היפ"ת דאין ראי' מכאן על מקום אחר, ששם לא הי' צורך לתפלה בפה רק טרם יקראו ואני אענה.
translation: And behold, by the sea they did not need to awaken all of Israel to prayer, for they were in a time of distress, as our Sages expounded (Midrash Rabbah, Parashat Ki Tisa, Section 5) that He brought the heart of Israel close to their Father in Heaven, and they themselves were also praying, and there was no need to arouse them. And regarding the Holy One, blessed be He, it suffices with prayer from the heart, for He knows the thoughts of man. And the words of the Midrash are understood: "Why do you cry out to Me?" This means that before they call, I will answer, etc. There is no need now to pray specifically with the mouth to awaken Israel, and the question of the opposite is not a proof from here to another place, where there was no need for prayer with the mouth, only "before they call, I will answer."
summary: The passage discusses the unique nature of prayer during times of distress, particularly at the sea, where the Israelites naturally turned to God without needing external encouragement. It emphasizes that God understands the thoughts of individuals, making heartfelt prayer sufficient, even without verbal expression. The text references a Midrash that highlights God's readiness to respond to unspoken prayers, illustrating a deep connection between divine awareness and human need. Ultimately, it conveys the idea that in moments of crisis, genuine inner prayer is recognized and answered by God.

passage_content: והנה הך כללא הוא רק לגבי תפלה שכ"א יכול לזכות להתפלל להבוי"ת, אבל לגבי שירה אינו כן, דלאו כל אדם זוכה לומר שירה לבורא כל העולמים וצריך זכות גדול שיזכו לומר שירה, וגם שם הי' כן שהכלל ישראל השפיע על הע"ר שגם הם יזכו לומר שירה, ומקור ההשפעה הי' ע"י משה רבינו שהשפיע על ישראל שיוכלו להשפיע על הע"ר, וזה הוא פירוש הפסוק אז ישיר משה ובנ"י וכו' ויאמרו לאמר, שבאמירתם השפיעו על הע"ר כדי שיוכלו גם הם לומר שירה, וזהו ויאמרו לאמר שע"י אמירתם יאמרו גם אחרים, אמנם האבות הקדושים לא היו צריכין לומר שירה בפה דייקא כדי להשפיע על זולתם כי הנפשות שגיירו לא היו בכלל הנס, גם לא היו ראויים לומר שירה, ע"כ לא אמרו שירה רק במחשבה, משא"כ בים הי' צורך לומר שירה בפה להשפיע לזולתם משה רבינו לכלל ישראל ובנ"י להע"ר.
translation: And behold, this principle applies only to prayer, as everyone can merit to pray to the Creator, but regarding song, it is not so, for not every person merits to sing a song to the Creator of the worlds, and one needs a great merit to be able to sing a song. And even there, it was so that the entire Jewish people influenced the lower realms (the spiritual worlds) that they too would merit to sing a song, and the source of this influence was through Moshe Rabbeinu, who influenced Israel so that they could influence the lower realms. This is the meaning of the verse "Then Moshe sang and the children of Israel," etc., "and they said to say," that through their saying they influenced the lower realms so that they too could sing a song. And this is "and they said to say," that through their saying, others would also say. However, the holy patriarchs did not need to say a song with their mouths specifically to influence others, for the souls they converted were not included in the miracle, nor were they worthy of singing a song. Therefore, they only sang a song in thought, whereas at the sea there was a need to sing a song with the mouth to influence others, Moshe Rabbeinu for the entire Jewish people and the children of Israel for the lower realms.
summary: The passage discusses the distinction between prayer and song in the context of spiritual elevation, emphasizing that while everyone can pray, not everyone is granted the merit to sing praises to God. It highlights the role of Moses in enabling the Jewish people to influence others, including the non-Jewish souls, to also sing praises. The text explains that the patriarchs did not need to vocalize their songs to have an impact, as the souls they converted were not part of the miraculous events, whereas at the sea, vocal expression was necessary to inspire others. Ultimately, it underscores the communal aspect of spiritual elevation and the importance of vocal expression in certain contexts.

passage_content: ואיתא בגמרא (סוטה דף מ"ט ע"ב) ותורת חסד על לשונה, וכי יש תורה שאינה של חסד, אלא זה תורה שמלמדה לאחרים נקרא תורת חסד, וז"פ דברי המדרש פיה פתחה בחכמה שאמרו שירה בפה, ולכאורה למה היו צריכין לזה דסגי גם במחשבה, רק ותורת חסד על לשונה שהיו צריכין להשפיע לאחרים ע"כ הוצרכו לומר בפה, וז"ש מיום שברא הקב"ה וכו' לא מצינו אדם "שאמר" שירה להקב"ה ר"ל בפה עד שבאו אלו ואמרו שירה בפה, אמר הקב"ה לאלו הייתי מצפה ואין אז אלא שמחה שנאמר אז ימלא שחוק פינו, ובאותו זכות אנו אומרים גם עכשיו שירה בכל יום ונמחלו עונותינו ע"י השירה כמו דאיתא במדרש, ונזכה שיתעוררו הנסים כמ"ש כימי צאתך ממצרים אראנו נפלאות ונזכה לראות בישועת כל ישראל ושמחתן בהתרוממות קרן התורה וישראל ובהתגלות כבוד שמים עלינו במהרה בימינו אמן.
translation: And it is stated in the Gemara (Sotah 49b) "and the Torah of kindness is upon her tongue," and is there a Torah that is not of kindness? Rather, this is the Torah that when one teaches it to others is called the Torah of kindness. This is the meaning of the words of the Midrash, "She opened her mouth with wisdom," which they said song with their mouths. And seemingly, why did they need this, since it suffices even in thought? Rather, "and the Torah of kindness is upon her tongue" indicates that they needed to influence others, therefore they were required to say it with their mouths. And this is what is meant by "From the day that the Holy One, blessed be He, created the world, etc., we do not find a person who 'sang' a song to the Holy One, blessed be He," meaning with their mouth, until these came and sang a song with their mouths. The Holy One, blessed be He, said, "For these I was waiting," and there is nothing but joy, as it is said, "Then our mouth will be filled with laughter." And in that merit, we also sing a song every day, and our sins are forgiven through the song, as it is stated in the Midrash. And may we merit that miracles will be awakened, as it is said, "As the days of your coming out of Egypt, I will show you wonders," and may we merit to see the salvation of all Israel and their joy in the uplifting of the crown of the Torah and Israel, and in the revelation of the glory of Heaven upon us speedily in our days, Amen.
summary: The passage emphasizes the concept of "Torah of kindness," highlighting that true Torah is meant to be shared and taught to others, which is why it must be expressed verbally. It reflects on the significance of singing praises to God, noting that prior to certain individuals, no one had sung to God aloud, and this act brings joy and forgiveness of sins. The text expresses a hope for the revival of miracles and the ultimate redemption of Israel, culminating in the revelation of divine glory in the world.

passage_content: עוד אפ"ל בביאור דברי המדרש הנ"ל בהקדם דברי ק"ז הישמח משה זלה"ה (פ' וישב) על מה דאיתא בירושלמי (פרק ערבי פסחים) כתיב בפרוע פרעות בישראל בהתנדב עם ברכו את ה', התנדבו ראשי עם כשהקב"ה עושה לכם ניסים תהי' אמרין שירה, עפימ"ש בספר כבוד חכמים כי ראשי עם היינו הצדיקים, שהנס נעשה להם בדין אינם מחוייבין לומר שירה רק שאומרים דרך נדבה, אבל שאר ישראל שעושה להם בחסדו מחוייבין לומר שירה, והיינו בפרוע פרעות בישראל שהם הצדיקים ראשי עם בהתנדב, אבל עם שהם הפחותים ברכו את ה' דהיינו בציווי עכ"ד, וק"ז פי' בתוס' נופך בפרוע פרעות בישראל, דבישראל הוי רק פרעון על פירות מעשיהם לכך השירה רק בהתנדב והבן עכל"ק.
translation: It can also be explained in the interpretation of the words of the aforementioned Midrash by prefacing the words of K"Z, may his memory be blessed (in Parashat Vayeshev), regarding what is stated in the Jerusalem Talmud (in the chapter of Arvei Pesachim): it is written, "In the time of the upheaval of Israel, when the leaders of the people volunteered, they blessed the Lord." The leaders of the people volunteered when the Holy One, blessed be He, performs miracles for you; they will sing a song. As explained in the book "Kavod Chachamim," the leaders of the people refer to the righteous, for whom the miracle is done by judgment; they are not obligated to sing a song, but they sing out of generosity. However, the rest of Israel, for whom it is done by His grace, are obligated to sing a song. This is what is meant by "In the time of the upheaval of Israel," which refers to the righteous, the leaders of the people, who volunteer. But the people who are lesser bless the Lord, meaning by command, thus concludes the matter. And K"Z explains in Tosafot Nofach regarding "In the time of the upheaval of Israel," that in Israel it is only a payment for the fruits of their deeds; therefore, the song is only out of generosity. Understand this in all its depth.
summary: The passage discusses the distinction between the righteous (tzaddikim) and the rest of Israel in their obligation to sing praises to God following miracles. It explains that while the tzaddikim, who experience divine intervention through strict justice, are not required to sing but do so voluntarily, the lesser individuals, who receive God's kindness, are obligated to praise Him. This reflects a deeper understanding of the relationship between divine justice and mercy, emphasizing that the nature of one's experience with God influences their response of gratitude and praise. The concept of "prua praut" highlights the idea that the righteous are seen as leaders in their voluntary devotion, while the broader community responds to God's benevolence with mandated praise.

passage_content: והנה מי שאינו מחוייב לומר שירה ורק רוצה לומר בתורת נדבה אזי צריכה השירה להיות יותר נאה ומפוארת שיתרצה לפניו ית' מאלו הי' אומרה בדרך חובה כמו שהסביר החוזה מלובלין זצלה"ה הא דפסקינן אם טעה בקריאת שמע אינו חוזר ואם טעה בשמונה עשרה חוזר, למה"ד למלך בשר ודם שאם אחד רוצה להביא לפניו דורן, צריך להשתדל ולהביא מן המובחר שבמובחרים ונאה ומהודרת ביותר כדי שיתרצה לפניו, ובאם לאו יקצוף עליו המלך באמרו מי חייבך להביא לי דורן, ובאם נדבה לבך לעשות יקר למלך, עליך להשתדל שיהא המנחה מהודרת כיאות לכבוד המלך, לא כן הוא באם המלך נתן צו ופקודה לכל אנשי מדינתו שכל אחד יבוא דורן לפניו דאזי אין מדקדקין כל כך על איכות הדורן, ואף אם לא ישוה בערך גדולת וכבוד המלך, עכ"ז יש מענה בפיו להצטדק לפני המלך כי הוא בעצמו מרגיש חסרונו שאינו ראוי להביא דורן כראוי לכבוד המלך, אבל מה אעשה כי המלך גזר עלי, ומוכרח אני לקיים פקודתו כפי השגת ידי, וכמו"כ לענין ק"ש שהוא חיוב מדאורייתא בגזירת המלך מלכו של עולם לאמרה בכל יום, ע"כ אף אם לא אמרה כהוגן לא חייבוהו חז"ל לחזור כי מוכרח הוא לקיים גזירת המלך כפי השגתו ויכולתו, וע"כ אין מקפידין עליו כ"כ ואפילו טעה מקבלין ממנו, משא"כ תפילת שמו"ע שאינו מחוייבת מדאורייתא ע"כ כשטעה צריך לחזור כי אם הוא מתנדב להביא דורן למלך צריך להיות נאה ביותר ומדקדקים אחריו.
translation: And behold, one who is not obligated to say a song and only wishes to say it as a freewill offering, then the song needs to be more beautiful and splendid so that He, blessed be He, will be pleased with it more than if one were to say it out of obligation, as explained by the Chozeh of Lublin, may his merit protect us. This is similar to the ruling that if one made a mistake in the reading of Shema, he does not return, but if he made a mistake in the Amidah, he does return. This is analogous to a king of flesh and blood, that if someone wishes to bring a gift before him, he must strive to bring from the best of the best, beautiful and most splendid, so that the king will be pleased with it. If not, the king will be angry with him, saying, "Who obligated you to bring me a gift?" But if your heart is moved to do something precious for the king, you must strive to ensure that the offering is fittingly splendid for the honor of the king. However, if the king has issued a decree and command to all the people of his kingdom that each one should bring a gift before him, then they do not scrutinize so much the quality of the gift, and even if it does not match the greatness and honor of the king, nevertheless, there is an excuse in his mouth to justify himself before the king, for he himself feels his shortcoming in not being worthy to bring a gift fitting for the honor of the king. But what can I do, for the king has decreed upon me, and I am compelled to fulfill his command according to my means. Similarly, regarding the Shema, which is an obligation from the Torah by the decree of the King, the King of the Universe, to say it every day, therefore, even if he did not say it properly, the Sages did not obligate him to return, for he is compelled to fulfill the decree of the king according to his understanding and ability. Therefore, they do not insist so much upon him, and even if he made a mistake, they accept it from him. In contrast, the prayer of the Amidah, which is not an obligation from the Torah, therefore, when he makes a mistake, he must return, for if he is volunteering to bring a gift to the king, it must be the most beautiful, and they scrutinize him closely.
summary: The passage discusses the distinction between obligatory and voluntary acts of worship, using the analogy of bringing a gift to a king. It emphasizes that when one is obligated, such as reciting the Shema, the quality of the offering is less scrutinized, as it is a command from the King of Kings. In contrast, when one voluntarily offers a prayer, like the Amidah, it must be done with great care and beauty to honor God properly. This reflects the Hasidic teaching that the intention and quality of one's service to God are paramount, especially in voluntary acts of devotion.

passage_content: וכמו"כ לענינינו דהנה דורות הראשונים נעשו להם נסים בזכותם כי הי' להם מע"ט, וע"כ לא היו אומרים שירה, כי בתורת נדבה לא רצו לומר, דלמא לא יאמרו כיאות לכבוד המלך ונמצא שאינו מודה רק ח"ו להיפך, אבל בקריעת ים סוף שקיטרג עליהם שר של ים הללו עוע"ז והללו עוע"ז, א"כ מה שנעשה להם נס ונבקע הים לא הי' בזכותם, כ"א שהקב"ה ברוב רחמיו ריחם עליהם ועשה להם נס ע"כ היו מחוייבים לומר שירה מצד הדין ואין למנוע מחשש דילמא לא יאמרו כהוגן דהרי הוא מחוייב לומר כפי השגתו, וא"ש דברי המדרש שמעולם לא אמר אדם שירה להקב"ה, ר"ל מחמת היראה כי מי יאמר זכיתי לבי כיאות לפני מלך הכבוד, עד שבאו אלו ואמרו שירה על שהיו מחוייבים מן הדין והבן.
translation: And likewise regarding our matter, behold, the earlier generations had miracles done for them due to their merit, for they had a great level of righteousness. Therefore, they did not sing a song, because they did not want to say it as a freewill offering, lest they not say it properly in honor of the King, and it would appear that they were not acknowledging Him, G-d forbid, but at the splitting of the Sea of Reeds, when the minister of the sea accused them, these idols and those idols, then the miracle that was done for them and the sea was split was not due to their merit, but rather that the Holy One, blessed be He, in His abundant mercy, had compassion on them and performed a miracle for them. Therefore, they were obligated to sing a song by law, and one should not refrain from the concern that perhaps they would not say it properly, for he is obligated to say according to his understanding. And this explains the words of the Midrash that no person ever sang a song to the Holy One, blessed be He, meaning out of fear, for who would say that he has merited to speak properly before the King of Glory, until these came and sang a song because they were obligated by law, and understand.
summary: The passage discusses the nature of miracles experienced by the earlier generations, emphasizing that they were granted miracles due to their merit, which led to a reluctance to sing praises out of fear of inadequacy in honoring God. In contrast, during the splitting of the Red Sea, the miracles were not due to their merit but rather God's compassion, obligating them to sing praises as a matter of justice. This reflects a deeper theological insight that true praise arises from a sense of obligation and recognition of divine mercy, rather than personal merit. The text highlights the tension between fear of inadequacy in worship and the necessity of expressing gratitude for divine intervention.
