passage_content: באופן אחר אפ"ל דברי המדרש הנ"ל, בהקדם דברי הגמ' (מגילה י"ד ע"א) אין אומרים הלל על נס שבחו"ל, והקשו בגמ' יציאת מצרים דנס שבחו"ל היכי אמרינן שירה, כדתניא עד שלא נכנסו ישראל הוכשרו כל ארצות לומר שירה, משנכנסו ישראל לארץ לא הוכשרו כל הארצות לומר שירה עכ"ד הגמ', וק"ז הישמח משה זלה"ה (בפ' בשלח) הביא בשם ס' ברית שלו' בתוס' נופך מדילי', דע"כ לא אמרו ישראל שירה על נס דיציאת מצרים גופא, כי על נס שבחו"ל אין אומרים שירה, אבל על נס שנעשה במים דהוא כארץ ישראל אומרים, והיינו הלכו ביבשה בתוך הים, וא"כ נעשה נס בים דהוא כא"י לכך אז ישיר עכ"ל עוד כתב שם נ"ל ליתן טעם להא דכל הארצות לא הוכשרו לומר שירה רק א"י, עפימ"ד במד"ר (בראשית פ' ל"ב סי' ג') ואף שבחו של הקב"ה אומרים כן מקצתו בפניו וכו', וידוע מה שכתבו דבפניו שרי לשבוחי דלא שייך לומר סיימתינהו וכו' משא"כ שלא בפניו, והנה ארץ ישראל עיני ד' אלקיך בה וכו', והיינו טעמא דברייתא דעד שלא נכנסו ישראל הוכשרו כל הארצות וכו', דהי' יכול להיות התגלות השראת שכינה בכל מקום לכך הוכשרו, משא"כ אחר כך וכו', וז"ש אשירה לד' כי גאה גאה. כפרש"י גאה גאה על כל השירות וא"כ כל מה שאקלס יש בו תוספת, וא"כ אין לשיר רק בא"י דהוי בפניו ולא שייך לומר סיימתינהו וכו', מ"מ אשירה דהרי סוס ורוכבו רמה בים והוי כארץ ישראל ע"כ מקצת לה"ק.
translation: In another way, one can say the words of the aforementioned Midrash, by prefacing the words of the Gemara (Megillah 14a) that we do not say Hallel for a miracle that occurred outside of the land. The Gemara questions how we can say song for the Exodus from Egypt, as it is taught that before Israel entered, all lands were fit to sing, but once Israel entered the land, not all lands were fit to sing, thus concludes the Gemara. And so, Moshe, peace be upon him (in Parashat Beshalach), brought in the name of the Book of Brit Shalom a nuance of my own, that indeed Israel did not sing a song for the miracle of the Exodus itself, for on a miracle that occurred outside the land, one does not sing, but for a miracle that occurred in the water, which is like the land of Israel, one does sing, and this is because they walked on dry land in the midst of the sea. Therefore, a miracle occurred in the sea, which is like the land of Israel, and that is why they sang. Furthermore, he wrote there that it seems to me to give a reason for the fact that not all lands were fit to sing, only the land of Israel, according to the Midrash (Genesis 32:3), and even though the praise of the Holy One, blessed be He, is said in part before Him, etc., it is known what they wrote that before Him it is permitted to praise, for it is not appropriate to say "you have completed them," etc., unlike when not before Him. And behold, the land of Israel, the eyes of the Lord your God are upon it, etc. This is the reason for the teaching that before Israel entered, all lands were fit to sing, for there could have been a revelation of the Divine Presence in every place, therefore they were fit, unlike afterwards, etc. And this is what is meant by "I will sing to the Lord for He has triumphed gloriously." As Rashi explains, "gloriously" refers to all the songs, and thus everything that is sung has an addition. Therefore, one should not sing except in the land of Israel, which is before Him, and it is not appropriate to say "you have completed them," etc. Nevertheless, "I will sing," for behold, the horse and its rider He has thrown into the sea, and this is like the land of Israel, thus partially to the Holy One, blessed be He.
summary: The passage discusses the concept that songs of praise (Hallel) are not recited for miracles that occur outside of the Land of Israel, as highlighted in the Talmud. It explains that the Israelites did not sing about the miracle of the Exodus itself, but rather for the miracle that took place in the sea, which is likened to the holiness of the Land of Israel. The text emphasizes that the Divine Presence is more manifest in Israel, allowing for a unique expression of praise there, and that singing in the presence of God carries a deeper significance. Ultimately, the miracle at the sea is seen as a connection to the sanctity of the land, warranting a song of praise.

passage_content: ולכאורה דבה"ק צ"ב דהרי מפורש בגמ' דעד שלא נכנסו ישראל לארץ הוכשרו כל הארצות לומר שירה, וא"כ מ"ט צריכנא לטעמא דנס שנעשה במים הוי כא"י, ובלא"ה הוכשרו כל הארצות אז, ואפ"ל עפימ"ש ק"ז בייט"פ (מאמר שפת הים סי' י') לפרש דברי המדרש (פ' כ"ג סי' ו') אז ישיר משה ובנ"י וגו' הה"ד (תהלים נ"ט) ואני אשיר עזיך אימתי בשעה שעמדו על הים ואמרו שירה, ומה אמרו עזי וזמרת י"ה, וארנן לבקר חסדך זה בוקר של מתן תורה, כי ידוע שכל הנביאים בעת שתבוא אליו הנבואה אע"פ שהוא במראה וע"י מלאך יחלשו כחותיו ויתקלקל בנינו כמעט שתצא רוחו ממנו, כמ"ש בדניאל כשדיבר עמו גבריאל במראה, אמר לא נשאר בי כח והודי נהפך עלי וגו', ואני הייתי נרדם ע"פ ארצה וגו', מלבד משרע"ה לא הי' כן, וז"ש ודבר ד' אל משה פא"פ כאשר ידבר איש אל רעהו וכו' וא"כ לכאורה יקשה להבין לפי משאמרז"ל (מכילתא) ראתה שפחה על הים מה שלא ראה יחזקאל, שנא' זה אל"י שכל או"א מראה באצבעו וכו', והי' מהראוי לישראל ליפול ע"פ ארצה, נבהל ונרדם עד כמעט שתצא רוחם, ואיך קמו על רגלם ופתחו פיהם ואמרו שירה, אע"כ אין זה מכוחם כ"א ברוך הנותן ליעף כח ולאין אונים עצמה ירבה, להעצים כוחן של ישראל לקום ולומר שירה וכו', וז"ש אשירה לד' וגו', לא מכחי כ"א עזי וזמרת י"ה ויהי לו לישועה, שיד ה' הושיעה לי להתחזק בכח ולזמר לשמו ית' וכו' ולא נתבטלו במציאות וכן הי' במ"ת, וכן לעתיד שנא' כי עין בעין יראו וגו' עיי"ש ביאור הענין.
translation: And seemingly, it is difficult to understand, for it is explicitly stated in the Gemara that before Israel entered the land, all the lands were prepared to sing a song. Therefore, why do we need the reasoning that the miracle that occurred in the waters is considered like the land of Israel? And if so, all the lands were prepared then. And it can be said, as mentioned in Kitzur Shulchan Aruch (the section on the Song of the Sea, chapter 10), to explain the words of the Midrash (Parashat Beshalach, section 6) that then Moses and the Children of Israel sang, as it is said (Psalms 59), "And I will sing to Your strength," when did this happen? At the time they stood by the sea and sang a song. And what did they say? "My strength and the song of YHWH," and I will sing in the morning of Your kindness, this morning of the giving of the Torah, for it is known that all the prophets, when the prophecy comes to them, even if it is through a vision and by an angel, their powers weaken and their being is almost disrupted to the point that their spirit is about to leave them, as it is said about Daniel when Gabriel spoke to him in a vision, he said, "No strength remained in me, and my appearance was transformed upon me," etc. And I was asleep on my face, etc. Except for Moshe Rabbeinu, it was not so, and therefore it is said, "And the Lord spoke to Moses face to face as a man speaks to his friend," etc. And thus, it is seemingly difficult to understand according to what our sages said (Mechilta), that a maidservant saw at the sea what Ezekiel did not see, as it is said, "This is my God; I will glorify Him," for it would have been appropriate for Israel to fall on their faces, terrified and asleep to the point that their spirit would almost leave them. And how did they rise on their feet and open their mouths and sing a song? Therefore, it is not from their own strength, but rather blessed is He who gives strength to the weary and increases power to the powerless, to empower the strength of Israel to rise and sing a song, etc. And thus it is said, "I will sing to the Lord," etc., not from my own strength, but rather "My strength and the song of YHWH, and He became my salvation," that the hand of the Lord saved me to strengthen me with power and to sing to His name, etc., and they did not become nullified in existence, and so it was at the giving of the Torah, and so it will be in the future, as it is said, "For eye to eye they will see," etc. There, the explanation of the matter is found.
summary: The passage discusses the miraculous nature of the Israelites' song at the Sea of Reeds, emphasizing that their ability to sing was not from their own strength but a divine gift that empowered them. It contrasts the experience of other prophets, who often felt weakened in the presence of divine revelation, with Moses, who spoke to God directly without losing strength. The text highlights that the song was a response to God's salvation, illustrating the theme of divine assistance in moments of spiritual elevation. Ultimately, it connects this event to the future revelation at Mount Sinai and the anticipated future redemption, reinforcing the idea that God's support enables the faithful to rise and express their devotion.

passage_content: ומעתה אפ"ל דאה"נ דעד שלא נכנסו ישראל לארץ הוכשרו כל הארצות לומר שירה, אמנם לבחי' זו שיהיו למעלה ממדריגת הנביאים א"א לזכות בחו"ל, אלא לפי שהי' הנס במים שהוא מקום טהרה, גם שכבר השפיל הקב"ה הסט"א ושר של מצרים הוסר ממשלתו, כמ"ש (רז"ל במד"ר דברים פי"א י"ט) סוס ורוכבו רמה בים סוסיהם ורוכביהם אין כתיב כאן, אלא סוס ורוכבו זה השר שלהן, ע"כ מאז נתעלו ישראל לבחי' א"י שהוא תחת יד הקב"ה לבדו ויכלו לומר שירה בבחי' גבוה כזו שלא זכו אלי' כל הנביאים, ואפשר דלבחי' כזו לא זכו אף האבוה"ק מטעם דאין אומרים שירה בחו"ל, ואף דעד שלא נכנסו ישראל לארץ הוכשרו כל הארצות, מ"מ לצד היותן תחת ממשלת שרים החיצונים לא זכו לזה, וישראל על הים זכו לזה מטעם הנ"ל וכן יהי' לע"ל.
translation: And from now on, it can be said that indeed, until the Israelites entered the land, all the lands were prepared to sing a song. However, for the level that they would be above the rank of the prophets, it is impossible to attain this outside of the land. This is because the miracle occurred in the waters, which is a place of purity, and also because the Holy One, blessed be He, had already humbled the Other Side, and the minister of Egypt was removed from his dominion, as it is said (our sages in Midrash Devarim 11:19) "A horse and its rider He threw into the sea," it does not say "their horses and their riders," but rather "a horse and its rider," referring to their minister. Therefore, from that time, the Israelites were elevated to the level of the Land of Israel, which is solely under the hand of the Holy One, blessed be He, and they were able to sing a song at such a high level that all the prophets did not merit to reach. It is possible that even the forefathers did not merit this level because one does not sing a song outside of the land. And although until the Israelites entered the land, all the lands were prepared, nevertheless, due to being under the dominion of external ministers, they did not merit this. And the Israelites at the sea merited this for the reasons mentioned above, and so it will be in the future.
summary: The passage discusses the unique spiritual elevation of the Jewish people upon entering the Land of Israel, emphasizing that prior to this, while all lands were prepared to sing praises, they could not attain a level higher than that of the prophets. This elevation is attributed to the miraculous events at the sea, which represented a place of purity, and the removal of the spiritual forces opposing God. Consequently, the Israelites were able to achieve a level of praise and connection to God that even the patriarchs and prophets did not experience, as they were still under the influence of external powers outside the Land of Israel. This theme suggests a future continuation of this elevated state for the Jewish people.

passage_content: וז"ש במדרש אז ישיר משה וגו' הה"ד פיה פתחה בחכמה ותורת חסד על לשונה, שהי' מחסדו ית' להעצים כחן של ישראל שיכלו לפתוח פיהן ולסדר דבריהם בחכמה, ולא נבהלו ולא נרדמו, ולז"א מיום שברא הקב"ה את העולם ועד שעמדו ישראל על הים, לא מצינו אדם שאמר שירה ר"ל בבחי' זו, ואף הנביאים לא זכו אלי', ואין אז אלא שמחה שנא' אז ימלא שחוק פינו, דלע"ל יזכו ישראל ג"כ אל הבחי' ההוא.
translation: And this is what is said in the Midrash: "Then Moses sang" etc. This means, "She opened her mouth with wisdom, and the Torah of kindness was on her tongue," for it was by His kindness that the Holy One, blessed be He, empowered the strength of Israel so that they could open their mouths and arrange their words with wisdom, and they were not frightened nor did they fall asleep. And it is said that from the day the Holy One, blessed be He, created the world until Israel stood by the sea, we do not find anyone who sang a song, meaning in this manner, and even the prophets did not merit it. And "then" is only joy, as it is said, "Then our mouth was filled with laughter," for in the future, Israel will also merit that aspect.
summary: The passage emphasizes the unique moment when the Israelites sang at the sea, highlighting that this expression of song and joy was a divine gift that empowered them to articulate their thoughts with wisdom. It notes that prior to this event, no one had sung in such a manner, not even the prophets, indicating the extraordinary nature of this experience. The reference to "then our mouths will be filled with laughter" suggests a future hope for Israel to attain similar joy and spiritual elevation. This reflects key Hasidic themes of divine grace and the transformative power of joy in the relationship between God and His people.

passage_content: אז ישיר משה ובנ"י וגו', פרש"י ז"ל עלה בלבו שישיר וכו', ראוי להבין מה צורך להשמיעינו זה, ובודאי שעלה בלבו לפני העשי', דסוף מעשה מחשבה בתחלה.
translation: Then Moses and the Children of Israel sang, etc. Rashi, of blessed memory, explains that it arose in his heart to sing, etc. It is fitting to understand what is the need to inform us of this, and certainly it arose in his heart before the action, for the end of the deed is rooted in the thought at the beginning.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author reflects on the moment when Moses and the Israelites sang after their deliverance, emphasizing that this song was premeditated in Moses' heart even before the miraculous events occurred. This highlights the Hasidic concept that thoughts and intentions precede actions, suggesting that the ultimate purpose of creation and redemption is rooted in divine contemplation. The idea that "the end of an action is found in its thought" underscores the importance of inner spiritual preparation and the connection between intention and fulfillment in the divine plan.

passage_content: ב) (פ' כ"ג סי' ד') אז ישיר משה וגו' הה"ד (משלי ל"א) פיה פתחה בחכמה ותורת חסד על לשונה, מיום שברא הקב"ה את העולם וכו', לא מצינו אדם שאמר שירה להקב"ה אלא ישראל וכו' ראוי להבין מ"ט לא אמרו אבות העולם שירה על הנסים שנעשו להם, ומדוע דייקא ישראל אמרו שירה, גם צ"ב הקישור אל הפסוק פיה פתחה בחכמה.
translation: B) (Parashat Ki Tisa, Section 4) Then Moses sang, etc. This is as it is written (Proverbs 31:26) "She opens her mouth with wisdom, and the teaching of kindness is on her tongue." From the day that the Holy One, Blessed be He, created the world, etc., we do not find anyone who sang a song to the Holy One, Blessed be He, except for Israel, etc. It is fitting to understand why the Patriarchs of the world did not sing a song for the miracles that were done for them, and why specifically Israel sang a song. It is also necessary to clarify the connection to the verse "She opens her mouth with wisdom."
summary: The passage discusses the unique role of the Jewish people in singing praise to God, particularly after experiencing miracles, as exemplified by Moses' song. It raises questions about why the patriarchs did not sing praises for the miracles they witnessed and emphasizes the connection to the verse "She opens her mouth with wisdom and the law of kindness is on her tongue." This highlights the idea that true praise and understanding of God's actions are rooted in wisdom and kindness, which are central to the Hasidic perspective on divine relationship and expression.

passage_content: ונל"פ בהקדם מ"ד בספה"ק ייטב לב בשם א"ז הגה"ק מו"ה אלעזר ניסן זלה"ה עה"פ וירא פנחס ויקח רומח בידו, עפ"י מאמחז"ל (קידושין דף מ' ע"א) מחשבה טובה הקב"ה מצרפה למעשה, הענין כי אמרת אלקי צרופה היינו צירופי אותיות, ותיכף כשעלה במחשבת אדם לטוב, נעשה מזה צירוף אותיות ונכתב בפועל לפניו ית' וכו', ע"כ תיכף כשראה פנחס ועלה בלבו שיקח רומח בידו, ויגל ד' את עיני פנחס וראה אלו האותיות וכו', וכיון שראה מעשה זו בצירופי אותיות נזכר הלכה עיי"ש, ופי' בזה ק"ז הייטב זלה"ה דכמו"כ באברהם הי' מסופק אם הוא מחוייב להטריח עצמו באורחים מחמת שהי' חולה מאוד, אך השי"ת הוא חוקר לב וכו' ומחשבה טובה הקב"ה מצרפה למעשה, ונעשה מזה צירוף אותיות וירץ לקראתם פתח האוהל, וכשראה אברהם צירוף האותיות וירץ לקראתם, הבין שזאת הוא רצון הבוי"ת וכו' עיי"ש.
translation: And we will explain in advance what is written in the holy book Yitav Lev in the name of the holy Rabbi, our teacher Elazar Nisan, may his memory be blessed, on the verse "And Pinchas saw, and he took a spear in his hand." According to our sages (Kiddushin 40a), a good thought is considered by the Holy One, blessed be He, as if it were an action. The matter is that the phrase "Elokai Tzrufah" refers to the combinations of letters, and immediately when a good thought arises in a person's mind, a combination of letters is created from it and is written in action before Him, blessed be He, etc. Therefore, as soon as Pinchas saw and it arose in his heart to take a spear in his hand, the Holy One, blessed be He, opened Pinchas's eyes and he saw these letters, etc. And when he saw this action in the combinations of letters, he remembered the law, as mentioned there. And the explanation of this is that just as Abraham was in doubt whether he was obligated to trouble himself for guests because he was very ill, the Holy One, blessed be He, searches the heart, etc., and a good thought is considered by the Holy One, blessed be He, as if it were an action, and from this a combination of letters was created, and he ran to greet them at the entrance of the tent. And when Abraham saw the combination of letters and ran to greet them, he understood that this was the will of the Creator, etc., as mentioned there.
summary: The passage discusses the Hasidic concept that good intentions are recognized and actualized by God, as illustrated through the actions of Pinchas and Abraham. When Pinchas resolved to take a spear, God revealed to him the letters of his good intention, signifying that thoughts of goodness are transformed into divine actions. Similarly, Abraham, despite his illness, was inspired to welcome guests upon realizing that his good thoughts were aligned with God's will. This highlights the belief that God actively connects human intentions with their fulfillment in the spiritual realm.

passage_content: ועד"ז אפ"ל לענינינו כי משה ובנ"י היו מסופקים אם יאמרו שירה או לאו כי ראו שכל הדורות שלפניהם לא אמרו שירה, אולם מיד שעלה בלבם לומר שירה, מחשבה טובה הקב"ה מצרפה למעשה, ונעשה מזה צירופי אותיות אלו אז ישיר משה ובנ"י את השירה הזאת, ובראותם צירופי אותיות אלו, מיד אמרו שירה, ולזה פרש"י ז"ל עלה בלבם לומר שירה, ר"ל כי מחשבה הטובה הביאם לידי מעשה, וע"י צירופי האותיות שנעשה ממחשבתם הכריעו לומר שירה, והנה ידוע דכוונת הלב הוא העיקר, והבוית"ש יודע מחשבתו של אדם והי' מספיק זה בלבד, אלא שאעפ"כ יש יתרון במוצא שפתים, שלפעמים המחשבה בלבד אינה זכה וברורה לש"ש, וסגולת הקול מעורר הכוונה כאמרז"ל, ומה"ט האבוה"ק לא הוצרכו לומר שירה בפה, כי הי' סגי במחשבה בלב, כי היו דבוקים ואדוקים במחשבתם בו ית"ש תמיד בלי הפסק בכוונה לש"ש בכל תנועה והרהור, וישראל אצל קרי"ס הגם שהיו ג"כ במדריגה מאוד נעלה כאמרז"ל ראתה שפחה על הים מה שלא ראה יחזקאל וכו', מ"מ מורא עלה על ראשם, פן לא יעמדו במדריגה זו ולא יהיו כל מחשבותם זכה לש"ש, ע"כ פתחו לומר שירה כדי להגיע ע"י התעוררות הקול לכוונה אמיתית לש"ש.
translation: And similarly, it can be said regarding our matter that Moses and the Children of Israel were in doubt whether to sing a song or not, for they saw that all the generations before them did not sing a song. However, as soon as the thought arose in their hearts to sing a song, the Holy One, blessed be He, combines a good thought with an action, and from this, these combinations of letters were made, and then Moses and the Children of Israel sang this song. Upon seeing these combinations of letters, they immediately began to sing. This is what Rashi, of blessed memory, explains: the thought arose in their hearts to sing, meaning that the good thought brought them to action, and through the combinations of letters that were made from their thoughts, they were prompted to sing. And it is known that the intention of the heart is the main thing, and the Holy One, blessed be He, knows a person's thoughts, and this alone would have been sufficient. However, nevertheless, there is an advantage in the utterance of the lips, for sometimes the thought alone is not pure and clear for the sake of Heaven, and the power of sound awakens the intention, as our sages of blessed memory said. For this reason, the forefathers did not need to sing a song with their mouths, as it was sufficient with the thought in their hearts, for they were always attached and bound in their thoughts to Him, blessed be He, without interruption, with intention for the sake of Heaven in every movement and contemplation. And the Israelites at the splitting of the sea, although they were also at a very elevated level, as our sages of blessed memory said, a maidservant saw at the sea what Ezekiel did not see, nevertheless, fear was upon them, lest they not maintain this level and that all their thoughts would not be pure for the sake of Heaven. Therefore, they began to sing in order to reach true intention for the sake of Heaven through the awakening of sound.
summary: The passage discusses the hesitation of Moses and the Israelites to sing a song of praise after the crossing of the Red Sea, as they observed that previous generations had not done so. However, once the thought to sing arose in their hearts, God combined this good intention with action, leading to the singing of the song. It emphasizes the importance of heartfelt intention in worship, while also highlighting that vocal expression can enhance one's spiritual focus and intention, especially when there is fear of not maintaining a pure thought. Ultimately, the act of singing serves to elevate their intentions and connect them more deeply with God.

passage_content: ובזה יבואר קישור דרשת המדרש לסמיכת הפסוק פיה פתחה בחכמה וכו', עפימ"ש רז"ל (סוכה מ"ט ע"ב) מ"ד פיה פתחה בחכמה ותורת חסד על לשונה, וכי יש תורה של חסד ויש תורה שאינה של חסד, אלא תורה לשמה זו היא תורה של חסד, תורה שלא לשמה זו הוא תורה שאינה של חסד, עכ"ד הגמ', והרי"ף בעין יעקב שם פי' בזה מאמה"כ פיה פתחה בחכמה, שכך היא דרכה של תורה ללמוד בתחלה שלא לשמה כדי שיקראוהו חכם, ואח"כ מביאתו ללמוד לשמה ותורתו תורת חסד עייש"ד, וי"ל עוד דתכלית ההתחלה שלא לשמה, כדי שאח"כ יביאהו ללימוד לשמה, וז"פ פיה פתחה בחכמה, ע"ד שאמרז"ל (תמיד ל"ב ע"א) איזהו חכם הרואה את הנולד, וע"כ התחלה זו שלא לשמה, בחי' חכמה יקרא, כדי שיזכה אח"כ לתורת חסד על לשונה, ועד"ז בישראל בשעת קרי"ס שעלה בלבם לומר שירה, אלא שחששו פן לא יהי' מחשבתם זכה וברורה לש"ש, וע"כ אמרו שירה בפה כנ"ל, וז"פ קישור דברי המדרש הה"ד פיה פתחה בחכמה ע"ד איזהו חכם הרואה את הנולד, ועי"ז ותורת חסד על לשונה, שזכו להגיע למדריגת לשמה.
translation: And this will clarify the connection of the Midrash's interpretation to the verse "Her mouth opens with wisdom," etc., as our Sages of blessed memory said (Sukkah 49b), "What does it mean, 'Her mouth opens with wisdom and the Torah of kindness is on her tongue'? Is there a Torah of kindness and a Torah that is not of kindness? Rather, the Torah learned for its own sake is the Torah of kindness, and the Torah learned not for its own sake is the Torah that is not of kindness." Thus said the Gemara. And the Rif in Ein Yaakov there explains this according to the verse "Her mouth opens with wisdom," that this is the way of the Torah: to learn initially not for its own sake so that one may be called wise, and afterwards to bring him to learn for its own sake, and his Torah will be a Torah of kindness, as explained there. It can also be said that the purpose of the initial learning not for its own sake is so that afterwards it will bring him to learn for its own sake, and this is the meaning of "Her mouth opens with wisdom," in the manner that our Sages said (Tamid 32a), "Who is wise? One who sees the outcome." Therefore, this initial stage of learning not for its own sake is called wisdom, so that he may merit afterwards to the Torah of kindness on his tongue. Similarly, with Israel at the time of the reading of the Shema, it arose in their hearts to sing a song, but they were concerned that their thoughts might not be pure and clear for the sake of Heaven. Therefore, they sang a song with their mouths as mentioned above. This is the connection of the words of the Midrash, as it is said, "Her mouth opens with wisdom" in the manner of "Who is wise? One who sees the outcome," and through this, "and the Torah of kindness is on her tongue," that they merited to reach the level of learning for its own sake.
summary: The passage discusses the relationship between learning Torah for its own sake (lishma) and the initial motivation of learning for other reasons (shelo lishma). It emphasizes that while the beginning of Torah study may not be pure, it ultimately serves to elevate the learner to a higher level of understanding and kindness, as reflected in the phrase "her mouth opens with wisdom and the Torah of kindness is on her tongue." This progression mirrors the journey of the Jewish people, who, despite initial doubts about their intentions, ultimately achieve a state of sincere praise and connection to God. The text highlights the importance of starting from a place of wisdom to reach the ultimate goal of embodying kindness through Torah.

passage_content: במדרש (הובא בישמח משה) הים ראה וינס מה ראה, ראה ישראל באים ורכוש מצרים בידם עכ"ד המדרש וצ"ב.
translation: In the Midrash (brought in Yismach Moshe), it states that the sea saw and fled. What did it see? It saw Israel coming with the possessions of Egypt in their hands. Thus concludes the Midrash, and it requires further explanation.
summary: In the Midrash cited in "Yismach Moshe," it is noted that the sea fled upon seeing the Israelites approaching with the wealth of Egypt. This flight of the sea symbolizes the recognition of divine providence and the power of faith, as the sea perceives the spiritual significance of the Israelites' journey. The passage invites reflection on the transformative nature of faith and the inherent connection between the Jewish people and their divine mission. The question posed at the end suggests a deeper inquiry into the reasons behind the sea's reaction, emphasizing the importance of understanding the interplay between the material and spiritual realms.

passage_content: ונל"פ בהקדם דברי הראב"ע ז"ל עה"פ התיצבו וראו את ישועת ד' וגו', יש לתמוה איך יירא מחנה גדולה של שש מאות אלף איש מהרודפים אחריהם, ולמה לא ילחמו על נפשם ועל בניהם, התשובה כי המצרים היו אדונים לישראל וזה הדור היוצא ממצרים למד מנעוריו לסבול עול מצרים ונפשו שפלה וכו' ואינם מלומדים למלחמה עכ"ד, אמנם סותר ד"ע שפי' לעיל עה"פ וחמשים עלו בנ"י, וחמשים מזויינים חגורי חומש למלחמה וכו', כי ביד רמה יצאו בכלי מלחמה, ולא כמו עבדים בורחים עכ"ל, ומה שהקשה למה לא ילחמו על נפשם אין זה קושיא, דמפני שא"ל משרע"ה מפי הגבורה התייצבו וראו את ישועת ד' וגו' ד' ילחם לכם ואתם תחרישון, ע"כ אף שהיו בסכנה גדולה, עמדו בנסיון ולא נלחמו עם המצריים, אף שהיו מזויינים וגבורי חיל, אבל כן הי' רצון הבוי"ת שלא ילחמו והשלימו רצון הבוי"ת, וראי' לדבר שנמנעו רק לטעם זה, שהרי בג' ימי אפילה היו המצרים כולם ככפותים, העומד אינו יכול לישב וכו', וישראל נכנסו לבתיהם והיו מחפשים במטמוניותם, והי' בידם להרגם כולם וליקח כל כלי חמדתם ולצאת מארצם באין מפריע, ומדוע לא קשיא להראב"ע שם איך לא לחמו על נפשם ונפש בניהם, ולא הי' צורך לגבורה ולא לכלי זיין, אע"כ שנמנעו רק להשלים רצון הבוי"ת, ונצטוו על ככה שלא לצאת בזרוע ולא יקחו הרכוש בזרוע כ"א בדרך שאלה.
translation: And we will explain, at the outset, the words of the Ra'avad, may his memory be blessed, regarding the verse "Stand still and see the salvation of the Lord," etc. It is puzzling how a great camp of six hundred thousand people would fear those pursuing them, and why they would not fight for their lives and for their children. The answer is that the Egyptians were masters over Israel, and this generation coming out of Egypt had learned from their youth to endure the yoke of Egypt, and their souls were lowly, etc., and they were not trained for battle. However, this contradicts the words mentioned earlier regarding the verse "And fifty ascended from the children of Israel," and "fifty armed, girded with weapons for battle," etc., for they went out with a high hand and with weapons of war, and not like fleeing slaves. As for the question of why they did not fight for their lives, this is not a difficulty, for since Moses told them, from the mouth of the Almighty, "Stand still and see the salvation of the Lord," "The Lord will fight for you, and you shall hold your peace," therefore, even though they were in great danger, they stood firm in the test and did not fight with the Egyptians, even though they were armed and mighty warriors. But indeed, it was the will of the Blessed One that they should not fight, and they fulfilled the will of the Blessed One. A proof of this is that they refrained only for this reason, for during the three days of darkness, all the Egyptians were like bound, unable to sit, etc., and Israel entered their homes and were searching in their treasures, and they had the ability to kill them all and take all their valuables and leave their land without hindrance. And why was it not a question to the Ra'avad there how they did not fight for their lives and the lives of their children? And there was no need for valor or for weapons. Rather, it must be that they refrained only to fulfill the will of the Blessed One, and they were commanded not to go out with force and not to take the possessions by force, but rather in a manner of asking.
summary: The passage discusses the paradox of the Israelites' fear in the face of the Egyptian army, despite their numerical strength and military preparedness. It emphasizes that their reluctance to fight stemmed from a divine command given through Moses, instructing them to stand firm and witness God's salvation. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of surrendering to God's will, as the Israelites chose to trust in divine intervention rather than resorting to violence, demonstrating their faith and obedience. The text highlights that their actions were not due to cowardice but rather a fulfillment of God's desire for them to rely on Him.

passage_content: ועד"ז אפ"ל דברי המדרש הנ"ל הים ראה וינס מה ראה רכוש מצרים בידם, דאמרו רז"ל (במד"ר פ' י"ד סי' ג') כששאלו ישראל מהמצריים להשאיל להם כלי כסף וכלי זהב וכו', היו אומרים אין בידינו כלום אומר לו ישראל אני ראיתיו בביתך ובמקום פלוני הוא, נמצא מהרכוש הי' ראי' שעמדו ישראל בנסיונם וציפו לישועת ד', ולא בטחו בזרוע בשר ובדרך מלחמה, וע"כ היו ראויים לנס שלא כדרך הטבע בקרי"ס, ולא הוצרכו לפעולה טבעיות בדרך מלחמה, וז"ש מה ראה רכוש מצרים בידם וע"כ וינוס.
translation: And similarly, one can say about the words of the aforementioned Midrash, "The sea saw and fled" — what did it see? The wealth of Egypt in their hands. As our Sages of blessed memory said (Midrash Rabbah, Parashat Yitro, Section 3), when the Israelites asked the Egyptians to lend them silver and gold vessels, they would say, "We have nothing." The Israelite would respond, "I saw it in your house and in such and such a place." Thus, from the wealth, it was evident that the Israelites stood firm in their trial and awaited the salvation of the Holy One, blessed be He, and did not rely on the arm of flesh or on the ways of war. Therefore, they were worthy of a miracle that was not according to the natural order at the splitting of the sea, and they did not need natural actions in the way of war. This is what it means, "What did it see? The wealth of Egypt in their hands," and therefore it fled.
summary: The passage discusses the miraculous nature of the Israelites' escape from Egypt, emphasizing their faith in God's salvation rather than reliance on military might. It highlights that when the Israelites asked the Egyptians for gold and silver, they demonstrated their trust in divine intervention, as they knew the wealth was available despite the Egyptians' denial. This unwavering faith made them deserving of a supernatural rescue, as indicated by the sea's retreat. Ultimately, their spiritual readiness and reliance on God led to their miraculous deliverance.

passage_content: והנה איתא במדרש ילקוט (רמז רנ"ד) ויסע משה את ישראל מים סוף הסיען בעל כרחם, שעטרו מצרים סוסיהם בתכשיטי זהב וכסף ואבנים טובות וכו' לפיכך הוצרך להסיען בעל כרחם, ולכאורה צ"ב דהרי בהשאלת כליהם כתיב דבר נא באזני העם וגו' ודרשו רז"ל (ברכות דף ט' ע"א) אין נא אלא לשון בקשה, א"ל הקב"ה למשה לך אמור לישראל בבקשה מכם שאלו מן המצרים וכו', הרי דלא הי' רצונם להרבות מרכוש מצרים, והי' צורך לבקשם על ככה, ומדוע נשתנה דעתם אח"כ והוצרך להסיעם בע"כ, ואפ"ל בפשטות דמפני שבמצרים היתה ציווי הבוי"ת על כך שישאלו, ולזה הי' התגברות ונסיון בדבר, ולזה הי' צורך להזהירם ולבקשם על כך, משא"כ אחר ביזת הים שכבר נצטוו ליסע משם הי' ההתגברות והנסיון על ההיפך וע"כ הי' צורך להסיעם בע"כ ולסייע בידם והבן.
translation: And behold, it is stated in the Midrash Yalkut (Remez 754) that Moses led the Israelites from the Sea of Reeds against their will, for the Egyptians adorned their horses with gold and silver jewelry and precious stones, etc. Therefore, he needed to lead them against their will. At first glance, this is puzzling, for regarding the borrowing of their possessions, it is written, "Speak now in the ears of the people," etc., and our Sages interpreted (Berakhot 9a) that "now" is only a term of request. The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Moses, "Go and tell the Israelites, 'Please, ask the Egyptians for their possessions,' etc." Thus, it was not their desire to increase the wealth of the Egyptians, and there was a need to request this from them. Why then did their minds change afterward, necessitating that he lead them against their will? It can be simply explained that in Egypt there was a command from the Creator to ask for this, and therefore there was a strengthening and trial in this matter, and thus there was a need to warn and request them about it. However, after the plundering at the sea, since they were already commanded to leave from there, the strengthening and trial was in the opposite direction, and therefore there was a need to lead them against their will and to assist them. Understand this.
summary: The passage discusses the paradox of the Israelites needing to be compelled to leave Egypt despite initially being instructed to ask for the Egyptians' possessions. It highlights the divine command that motivated the Israelites to request wealth, contrasting it with their reluctance to leave after the plagues. The text suggests that the initial willingness to ask for riches was a result of divine influence, while their later hesitance required God's intervention to ensure their departure. This reflects the Hasidic concept of divine assistance in overcoming human resistance to fulfilling God's will.

passage_content: במדרש הים ראה וינס מה ראה, ראה ישראל באים ורכוש מצרים בידם, וצ"ב, ונל"פ בהקדם לבאר הכתוב ויהפך לבב פרעה ועבדיו אל העם ויאמרו מה זאת עשינו כי שלחנו את ישראל מעבדנו, פרש"י ז"ל ויהפך בשביל ממונם שהשאילום, וצ"ב דאין זה טעם המפורש בכתוב כי שלחנו את ישראל וגו', הרי שהתחרטו על עצם השליחות ולא על חסרון הממון.
translation: In the Midrash, the sea saw and fled. What did it see? It saw Israel coming with the possessions of Egypt in their hands, and this is a question. It is necessary to explain the verse, "And the heart of Pharaoh and his servants was turned against the people, and they said, 'What is this we have done, that we have sent Israel from our service?'" Rashi, of blessed memory, explains that it was turned because of their possessions that they had lent them. And this is a question, for this is not the reason explicitly stated in the verse, "that we have sent Israel," etc. It is clear that they regretted the very act of sending them away, not due to a lack of wealth.
summary: In the passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the Midrash discusses Pharaoh's change of heart upon seeing the Israelites leaving with the wealth of Egypt. It questions why Pharaoh and his servants regretted sending the Israelites away, suggesting that their remorse stemmed not merely from the loss of material wealth but from a deeper realization of the spiritual and existential implications of their actions. This reflects a Hasidic understanding that true regret involves recognizing the loss of connection to the divine purpose, rather than just a concern for physical possessions. The text emphasizes the importance of understanding the spiritual dimensions of one's choices and the consequences they carry.

passage_content: ואפ"ל בהקדם דברי הפר"ד שכתב דישראל זכו בהרכוש מדין הענקה, עפימ"ד במדרש שפרעה שיחרר את ישראל וא"ל הרי אתם ברשותכם הרי אתם בני חורין ועבד עברי יש לו הענקה עכ"ד ז"ל, וק"ז הישמח משה זלה"ה כתב דהטעם שהי' צורך לשיחרורו, מפני שעדיין לא נשלם זמנם של ישראל לצאת, אלא שדילג הקב"ה על הקץ ויצאו לסוף רד"ו כי לא יכלו להתמהמה עוד, אמנם קשה ע"ז דהרי פרעה הי' מוכרח לשחררם מחמת שנלאה לסבול כובד המכות, א"כ השחרור לאו כלום הוא, דאונסא כמאן דלא עביד, ותירץ דקיי"ל (במס' ב"ב מ"ח) תלוהו וזבין זביני' זבינא, דאגב אונסא וזוזי גמר ומקנה, אבל תלוהו ויהיב במתנה לא מהני, וכאן הוי תלוהו וזבין, דאם בזמן ההוא שיצאו כתיב וינצלו את מצרים בשכר העבודה, א"כ אלמלי נשארו שם עד השלים הזמן גם ארצם לא הי' מספיק, והרכוש שנטלו הוי כמו פשרה דדינו כמכר עכ"ד ק"ז זלה"ה, נמצא דמרכוש מצרים יש הוכחה שיצאו ברשות ופרעה שיחררם כדין, ולפי"ד הפר"ד שזכו ברכוש מדין הענקה, בעכ"ח שהי' שחרור גמור וכדין, דבורח אין לו הענקה, וז"ש רש"י ז"ל בשביל ממונם שהשאילום דעי"ז נעשו משוחררים ואין לומר אונסא כמאן דלא עביד, והיינו טעם הכתוב כי שלחנו את ישראל מעבדנו.
translation: And even though the words of the Parde"c (Rabbi David ben Zimra) state that Israel merited the wealth by virtue of the gift, as it is explained in the Midrash that Pharaoh freed Israel and said to them, "Here you are in your own authority, here you are free men," and a Hebrew slave has a gift, thus far his words, blessed be he. And so too, the joyous Moshe, peace be upon him, wrote that the reason there was a need for their liberation was because the time for Israel to leave had not yet been completed, but that the Holy One, blessed be He, skipped the end and they left at the end of 210 years because they could no longer delay. However, this is difficult, for Pharaoh was compelled to free them because he could no longer bear the weight of the plagues; thus, the liberation is of no consequence, for coercion is like one who did not act. And he answered that we hold (in Bava Batra 48) that if one lends and sells, the sale is valid, because due to coercion and money, it is completed and acquired. But if one lends and gives as a gift, it is not effective. And here it is as if he lent and sold, for at that time when they left it is written that they plundered Egypt in payment for their labor; therefore, had they remained there until the time was completed, even their land would not have sufficed, and the wealth they took is like a settlement, and its law is like a sale, thus far his words, blessed be he. It follows that from the wealth of Egypt there is proof that they left with permission and that Pharaoh freed them lawfully, and according to the words of the Parde"c, they merited the wealth by virtue of the gift, with the understanding that it was a complete and lawful liberation, for one who flees does not have a gift. And this is what Rashi, may his memory be blessed, said: "For their money that they borrowed, for through this they became free, and one cannot say coercion is like one who did not act," and this is the reason for the verse, "For we sent away Israel from our service."
summary: The passage discusses the concept of Israel's liberation from Egypt, emphasizing that their release was not merely a result of Pharaoh's coercion due to the plagues, but rather a divinely sanctioned act that allowed them to leave with wealth, akin to a legal transfer of ownership. It highlights the idea that their departure was a fulfillment of God's plan, as they were granted freedom and material possessions as a form of divine grace. The text also underscores that this liberation was complete and legitimate, countering the notion that it was merely an act of compulsion. Ultimately, it illustrates the theological principle that Israel's exodus was a significant and purposeful event in their relationship with God.

passage_content: והנה איתא במדרש (ילקוט ראובני) שקטרג שר של ים ואמר מה נשתנו אלו מאלו הללו עובדי ע"ז והללו עוע"ז וכו', ולכאורה מה טענה הוא זו הלא המצריים היו רודפים אחר ישראל להורגם, וקיי"ל דרוצח ניתן להצילו בנפשו אף אם הנרדף אינו צדיק יותר ממנו, אלא צ"ל שהשר של ים סבור ששחרורם של ישראל הי' שלא כדין וה"ה בורחים ואין דינם של מצריים כרודפים, אולם מרכוש מצרים ראה והשיג דשחרורם הי' כדין, ולז"א הים ראה וינס ראה רכוש מצרים בידם והבן.
translation: And behold, it is stated in the Midrash (Yalkut Reuveni) that the minister of the sea accused and said, "What distinguishes these from those? These are idol worshippers and these are idol worshippers," etc. At first glance, what kind of accusation is this? After all, the Egyptians were pursuing Israel to kill them, and we hold that a murderer can be saved by his own life even if the pursued is not more righteous than him. Rather, it must be that the minister of the sea believes that the liberation of Israel was not just, and thus the fleeing ones are not considered as being pursued. However, he saw and understood from the wealth of Egypt that their liberation was indeed just. Therefore, it is said, "The sea saw and fled," for it saw the wealth of Egypt in their hands. Understand this.
summary: The passage discusses a midrashic interpretation where the angel representing the sea questions the justice of the Israelites' liberation from Egypt, arguing that both the Egyptians and Israelites were guilty of idolatry. The angel believes that the Israelites' escape was unjust, as they were fleeing from their pursuers. However, upon witnessing the wealth of the Egyptians in the hands of the Israelites, the sea recognizes that their liberation was indeed justified. This highlights the Hasidic concept of divine justice and the idea that true liberation is rooted in righteousness.

passage_content: ה' איש מלחמה ה' שמו, פירש"י ז"ל אף בשעה שהוא נלחם ונוקם מאויביו אוחז הוא במדתו לרחם על ברואיו וכו' עיי"ש, ונל"פ עוד מאמר הכתוב בסוף הפרשה ויאמר כי יד על כס י"ה מלחמה לה' בעמלק מדור דור, פירש"י ידו של הקב"ה הורמה לישבע בכסאו להיות לו מלחמה ואיבה בעמלק עולמית, ומהו כס ולא נאמר כסא ואף השם נחלק לחציו, נשבע הקב"ה שאין שמו שלם ואין כסאו שלם עד שימחה שמו של עמלק כולו, וכשימחה שמו יהי' השם שלם והכסא שלם וכו', ובספה"ק פי' הפסוק (תהלים כ') ימלא ה' כל משאלותיך, שזה יהי' כל משאלותיך שיתמלא השם ויהי' שמו שלם, והאלשיך הק' האריך לבאר שעיקר מלחמת עמלק היינו מלחמת היצה"ר כי עונותינו מוסיפים כח בשרו של עמלק הוא ס"מ הוא השטן וכ"א מישראל צריך ללחום מלחמה זו עכת"ד, והנה זה א"א רק בעזר השי"ת, דאלמלא הקב"ה עוזרו אינו יכול לו כמו שאמרו חכז"ל, נמצא הקב"ה הוא הלוחם מלחמת עמלק בכל דור ודור, והתכלית מזה שיהי' שמו שלם כשימחה שמו של עמלק כולו.
translation: The Lord is a man of war; the Lord is His name. Rashi, may his memory be blessed, explains that even at the time He is fighting and avenging against His enemies, He holds on to His attribute of mercy towards His creations, etc. See there. And it seems to me that the statement in the end of the portion, "And He said, 'For the hand is on the throne of the Lord, a war for the Lord against Amalek from generation to generation,'" means that the hand of the Holy One, blessed be He, is raised to swear by His throne to have a perpetual war and enmity against Amalek. And what is the throne? It does not say "throne" but rather "throne," and even the name is divided in half. The Holy One, blessed be He, swore that His name is not complete and His throne is not complete until the name of Amalek is completely erased. And when the name is erased, the name will be complete and the throne will be complete, etc. And in the holy books, the verse (Psalms 20) "May the Lord fulfill all your requests" is explained to mean that this will be all your requests, that the name will be fulfilled and His name will be complete. And the Kadosh Elshich elaborated that the essence of the war against Amalek is the war against the evil inclination, for our sins give strength to the flesh of Amalek, who is the Sitra Achra, who is the Satan, and every Jew must wage this war. Thus far the words. And behold, this is only possible with the help of the Holy One, blessed be He, for if the Holy One, blessed be He, does not assist him, he cannot prevail, as our sages of blessed memory said. Therefore, the Holy One, blessed be He, is the one fighting the war against Amalek in every generation, and the purpose of this is that His name should be complete when the name of Amalek is completely erased.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of God's eternal struggle against Amalek, symbolizing the evil inclination (yetzer hara) and spiritual adversaries. It emphasizes that God's name and throne are incomplete until Amalek is eradicated, reflecting a profound theological belief in the necessity of divine assistance in this ongoing battle. The text highlights that every individual must engage in this spiritual warfare, relying on God's support, as the ultimate goal is to achieve the completeness of God's name and presence in the world.

passage_content: וז"פ הכתוב ה' איש מלחמה שהקב"ה הוא בעל מלחמה כמ"ש מלחמה לה' בעמלק מדור דור, ותכלית מלחמה זו ה' שמו, שיהי' השם שלם. שאין השם שלם עד שימחה שמו של עמלק כולו, ולזה הקב"ה מסייע לכל איש מישראל ללחום עם שרו של עמלק הוא הס"מ הוא היצה"ר כדי שנזכה לבחי' ה' שמו, והשי"ת יעזור שבימינו נזכה לזה להיות שמו וכסאו ית' שלם.
translation: And the verse states, "The Lord is a man of war," that the Holy One, blessed be He, is the Master of war, as it is said, "War belongs to the Lord against Amalek from generation to generation." The purpose of this war is for the Lord's name to be complete, for the name is not complete until the name of Amalek is entirely erased. Therefore, the Holy One, blessed be He, assists every man of Israel to fight against his minister, which is the Sitra Achra, the evil inclination, so that we may merit the aspect of the Lord's name. May the Blessed One help that in our days we merit this, that His name and His throne be complete.
summary: The passage emphasizes that God is portrayed as a warrior, particularly in the context of the ongoing struggle against Amalek, symbolizing the forces of evil and the evil inclination (yetzer hara). The ultimate goal of this spiritual warfare is to achieve the completeness of God's name, which can only be realized by eradicating the influence of Amalek. It highlights the divine assistance granted to every Jew in their personal battles against these negative forces, with the hope that in the present time, God's name and throne will be fully established and complete.

passage_content: ויאמר ה' אל משה הנני ממטיר לכם לחם מן השמים ויצא העם ולקטו דבר יום ביומו, לכאורה תיבת לכם כמיותר, גם מה שאמר ולקטו דבר יום ביומו תיבת דבר מיותר וצ"ב, ובמדרש (הובא בישמח משה) הים ראה וינוס מה ראה ישראל באים ורכוש מצרים בידם וצ"ב.
translation: And the Lord said to Moses, "Behold, I am raining down bread from heaven for you," and the people went out and gathered a thing day by day. At first glance, the word "for you" seems superfluous, and also what it says, "and they gathered a thing day by day," the word "thing" is unnecessary and requires explanation. And in the Midrash (brought in Yismach Moshe), the sea saw and fled; what did it see? Israel coming with the possessions of Egypt in their hands, and this requires explanation.
summary: In this passage, the Divine promise of manna from heaven emphasizes God's direct provision for the Israelites, highlighting the concept of daily reliance on divine sustenance. The seemingly superfluous words "for you" and "thing" suggest deeper layers of meaning, inviting reflection on the nature of spiritual nourishment and the importance of daily faith. Additionally, the reference to the sea fleeing upon seeing the Israelites with the spoils of Egypt underscores the miraculous nature of their redemption and the power of faith in overcoming obstacles. This illustrates the Hasidic belief in the constant presence of divine intervention in the lives of the faithful.

passage_content: ונקדים לבאר מאמה"כ (בפ' בא) דבר נא באזני העם וישאלו וגו' פי' רשיז"ל אין נא אלא לשון בקשה, בבקשה ממך הזהירם על כך. שלא יאמר אותו צדיק אברהם ועבדום ועינו אותם קיים בהם, ואחרי כן יצאו ברכוש גדול לא קיים בהם ודקדקו המפורשים דתיבת בהם שהוכפל שני פעמים מיותרים, עוד הקשו בקשה זו למה כיון דכל אדם להוט אחר ממון ונפשו של אדם מחמדתן, גם מה צורך לטעם זה כדי שלא יאמר אותו צדיק, וגם בלא זה יקיים השי"ת הבטחתו.
translation: And we will precede to explain from the Holy Torah (in Parashat Bo) "Speak please in the ears of the people and let them ask..." Rashi explains that "please" is only a term of request, as if to say, "I beseech you, warn them about this." So that the righteous one, Abraham, should not say, "And they will serve them and they will oppress them," which is fulfilled in them, and afterwards they will go out with great wealth, which is not fulfilled in them. And the commentators have scrutinized the word "in them," which is repeated unnecessarily twice. Furthermore, they questioned this request, why, since every person is eager for money and the soul of a person covets it, what need is there for this reason to prevent the righteous one from saying this? And even without this, the Holy One, Blessed be He, will fulfill His promise.
summary: The passage discusses the request made by God to Moses to instruct the Israelites to ask their Egyptian neighbors for valuables before leaving Egypt. It emphasizes that the term "please" indicates a plea for caution, urging the Israelites to avoid giving the impression that God's promise to Abraham about their eventual liberation and wealth was unfulfilled. The repetition of the word "them" suggests a deeper significance, highlighting the importance of recognizing God's faithfulness to His promises, even amidst suffering. Ultimately, it reflects a Hasidic understanding of divine providence and the necessity of human action in fulfilling God's plans.

passage_content: וכל אלה באחת יתבארו בהקדם מה שהקשה התבו"ש על מ"ש הרמ"א ז"ל (סי' תרפ"ב ס"א) דאם שכח לומר על הנסים בבהמ"ז, כשמגיע להרחמן יאמר הרחמן הוא יעשה לנו נסים וכו', והתבו"ש דחה דין זה וטעמו דאין להתפלל שיעשה לו נס, והביא ראי' מהא דאמרינן בגמרא (ברכות ס' ע"א) היתה אשתו מעוברת ואמר יה"ר שתלד אשתי זכר הרי זה תפילת שוא, ופריך מהא דכתיב ואחר ילדה בת שדנה לאה דין בעצמה וכו' מיד נהפכה לבת, ומשני אין מזכירין מעשה נסים, ואי נימא דמותר להתפלל שיעשה לו נס, עדיין תקשה דאמאי הוי תפלת שוא הרי יכול להתפלל שתלד זכר בדרך נס, אלא וודאי שאין להתפלל על נס.
translation: And all these will be clarified at the outset regarding what the Tzavah Shalom questioned on what the Rama, of blessed memory, wrote (Orach Chaim 582:1) that if one forgot to say "Al Hanissim" in the Birkat Hamazon, when he reaches "Harachaman" he should say "Harachaman, may He perform miracles for us," etc. The Tzavah Shalom rejected this ruling and his reason is that one should not pray for a miracle to be done for him. He brought a proof from what we say in the Gemara (Berachot 60a) that if his wife is pregnant and he says, "May it be Your will that my wife gives birth to a male," this is a prayer in vain. And it is asked from the fact that it is written, "And afterward she gave birth to a daughter," as Leah herself said, etc., immediately she was turned into a daughter. And it answers that we do not mention miraculous deeds. And if we say that it is permissible to pray for a miracle to be done for him, it still remains difficult why it is considered a prayer in vain, since he can pray for her to give birth to a male in a miraculous way. Rather, it is certainly not appropriate to pray for a miracle.
summary: The passage discusses a debate regarding the permissibility of praying for miracles, specifically in the context of the Jewish blessing after meals (Birkat Hamazon). It references the Rema's ruling that one can invoke God's ability to perform miracles if one forgets to mention "miracles" in the blessing. However, the Tzafnat Paneach argues against this, citing that praying for a miracle is considered futile, as demonstrated by a Talmudic example where a prayer for a specific outcome (a male child) is deemed ineffective. The underlying theological insight emphasizes a belief in the natural order and the idea that one should not rely on miraculous interventions in prayer.

passage_content: והישועות יעקב מתרץ שיטת הרמ"א ז"ל עפי"ד המדרש בפסוק אל תירא אברם אנכי מגן לך שכרך הרבה מאוד, הכל יודעין שאנכי מגן לך, והכוונה בזה דהנה אמרו רז"ל (שבת דף ל"ב ע"א) שאם עושין לאדם נס מנכין לו מזכיותיו. אמנם כשהנס מפורסם ועי"ז נתקדש ש"ש הנה ניתוסף לו זכות חדש בשביל קידוש השם, וז"ש אל תירא אברם מכח נכיון הזכות ע"י הנסים, כי אנכי מגן לך והכל יודעין שאנכי מגן לך, וע"כ שכרך הרבה מאוד וכו' וע"כ על נס מפורסם לרבים ראוי להתפלל כדי שיתקדש שמו ית' עכ"ד, והנה במסכת תענית (דף כ"ד ע"א) מבואר דאסור להנות ממעשה נסים גבי מעשה דאלעזר איש בירתא שנתמלא אוצרו חטים בדרך נס ואמר לבתו הרי הן הקדש עליך ואין לך בהן אלא כאחד מעניי ישראל, וכתב רש"י ז"ל משום דמעשה נסים הוא ואסור לאדם להנות ממעשה נסים כדאמר לעיל (דף כ' ע"ב) ואם עושין לו נס מנכין לו מזכיותיו
translation: And the salvations, Yaakov explains the approach of the Rema, may his memory be blessed, according to the interpretation of the Midrash on the verse "Do not fear, Abram, I am your shield; your reward is very great." Everyone knows that I am your shield, and the intention here is that our Sages have said (Shabbat 32a) that if a miracle is performed for a person, his merits are diminished. However, when the miracle is publicized and thereby the Name of Heaven is sanctified, a new merit is added to him because of the sanctification of the Name. Therefore, it is said, "Do not fear, Abram," regarding the diminishing of merit through miracles, for I am your shield, and everyone knows that I am your shield; therefore, your reward is very great, etc. And thus, for a public miracle, it is appropriate to pray so that His Name be sanctified. Thus it is stated in Tractate Ta'anit (24a) that it is forbidden to benefit from acts of miracles, as in the case of Eliezer of Birtah, whose storehouse was filled with wheat through a miracle, and he said to his daughter, "Here they are consecrated to you, and you have no more than one of the poor of Israel." And Rashi, may his memory be blessed, wrote that it is because it is an act of miracles, and it is forbidden for a person to benefit from acts of miracles, as stated above (20b), and if a miracle is performed for him, his merits are diminished.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of divine protection and the implications of miracles in relation to one's merits. It emphasizes that while miracles can diminish a person's merits, a public miracle that sanctifies God's name can actually add to one's merits. The text also highlights the prohibition against benefiting from miraculous events, as illustrated by the story of Eliezer, which underscores the idea that one should not derive personal gain from divine interventions. Ultimately, the focus is on the importance of maintaining a balance between recognizing God's protection and the ethical considerations surrounding miraculous occurrences.

passage_content: אמנם עפ"י המבואר בדברי הישועות יעקב דאם הוא נס מפורסם ונתקדש ש"ש על ידו אין מנכין לו מזכיותיו, אפשר דבכה"ג מותר להנות ממעשה נסים והנה בענין הרכוש שהוציאו ממצרים הי' ג"כ מעשה נסים, כפי' רש"י וישאלום אף מה שלא שאלו מהם היו נותנים להם, ואמרז"ל במס' בכורות (דף ה' ע"ב) אין לך כל אחד ואחד מישראל שלא היו עמו תשעים חמורים טעונים מכספם וזהבם של מצרים, וא"כ א"א להנות ממנה ומחויבים להקדישו ומה ירויחו עם הרכוש, אמנם באם לקחו הרכוש רק להשלים רצון הבוי"ת א"כ אדרבה יתוסף זכותם ושפיר הותר להם להנות ממנה, וע"כ אמר השי"ת שענין השאלת כליהם לא יהי' לכוונת תועלתם כי אז יאסר להנות מהם. רק כוונת השאילה יהי' למען יקוים מאמר השי"ת אל אברהם, וע"ז בוודאי צריך אזהרה רבא שלא יכוונו להנאת עצמם וישליכו תאות נפשם מנגד, רק יכוונו למלאות רצון השי"ת שיקוים הבטחתו אל אברהם, וז"ש דבר נא באזני העם אין נא אלא לשון בקשה, בבקשה ממך הזהירם על כך. היינו שלכוונה זו יהי' השאלה כדי שלא יאמר אותו צדיק וכו', וממילא יהי' מותר ליהנות מהם אף כי הוא מעשה נסים ולא יהיו מחויבים להקדישו, וזהו אמרו כדי שלא יאמר אותו צדיק, ועבדום ועינו אותם קיים בהם דייקא, ואח"כ יצאו ברכוש גדול לא קיים בהם, כי אינו שלהם ומחויבים להקדישו, ולזה יבקש מהם שיהי' כוונת השאלה רק לעשות רצונו ית' ולהרבות כבוד שמים ולא בשביל תאות וחמדת הממון. ועפי"ז יתבאר המדרש דהנה ידוע דעל הים הי' קטרוג גדול מה נשתנו אלו מאלו, אולם כאשר ראה שר של ים ישראל באים ורכוש מצרים בידם דייקא, דהיינו שהוא שלהם ואינם מחוייבים להקדישו, ומזה מוכח אשר כל כוונתם הי' למען יתקדש ש"ש, ע"כ וינוס כי עי"ז נסתמו פיות המקטריגים.
translation: Indeed, according to what is explained in the words of Yeshuot Yaakov, if it is a well-known miracle and sanctified by the Holy Name through it, one does not diminish from his merits. It is possible that in such a case it is permitted to benefit from acts of miracles. And behold, regarding the property that they took out of Egypt, there was also an act of miracles, as Rashi explains, "and they will ask of them," even what they did not ask of them, they would give to them. And our Sages said in Tractate Bekhorot (5b) that there is not one individual among Israel who did not have ninety donkeys loaded with the silver and gold of Egypt. Therefore, it is impossible to benefit from it, and they are obligated to sanctify it. What will they gain with the property? However, if they took the property only to fulfill the will of the Blessed One, then on the contrary, their merit will increase, and it is permitted for them to benefit from it. Therefore, the Holy One, Blessed be He, said that the matter of asking for their vessels should not be for their own benefit, for then it would be forbidden to benefit from them. Rather, the intention of the asking should be so that the word of the Holy One, Blessed be He, to Abraham will be fulfilled. And for this, there certainly needs to be a great warning not to intend for their own enjoyment and to cast aside the desires of their souls, but rather to intend to fulfill the will of the Holy One, Blessed be He, so that His promise to Abraham will be fulfilled. This is what is meant by "Speak now in the ears of the people," for "now" is only a term of request, a request from you to warn them about this. That is, for this intention will be the asking, so that that righteous one should not say, etc., and consequently, it will be permitted to benefit from them even though it is an act of miracles, and they will not be obligated to sanctify it. And this is what he said, "so that that righteous one should not say," and "they enslaved them and afflicted them" is fulfilled in them precisely, and afterwards they went out with great wealth is not fulfilled in them, for it is not theirs and they are obligated to sanctify it. And for this, he will ask of them that the intention of the asking should only be to do His will and to increase the honor of Heaven, and not for the desire and greed for money. And according to this, the Midrash will be explained, for it is known that at the sea there was a great accusation, "What distinguishes these from those?" However, when the minister of the sea saw that Israel was coming with the property of Egypt in their hands precisely, that is, that it is theirs and they are not obligated to sanctify it, from this it is proven that all their intention was for the sake of sanctifying the Holy Name. Therefore, he fled, for through this the mouths of the accusers were sealed.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of divine providence and the proper intention behind the Israelites' request for the Egyptians' possessions during the Exodus. It emphasizes that if their intention was solely to fulfill God's will and honor His promise to Abraham, they would be permitted to enjoy the spoils, as they would not be obligated to dedicate them. The text highlights the importance of selflessness and the need to prioritize God's glory over personal gain, which ultimately silenced the accusers in the heavenly court when they saw the Israelites carrying the Egyptians' wealth.

passage_content: והנה אמרו חכז"ל (יומא דף ל"ח ע"א) כל מה שברא הקב"ה לא ברא אלא לכבודו, כי מכל הנבראים שבעולם יש ללמוד מציאות השי"ת וגדולתו, כי חכמת הפעולה תעיד על פועלה כמבואר בחובת הלבבות שער הבחינה, וכמ"ש השמים מספרים כבוד א"ל ומעשה ידיו מגיד הרקיע יום ליום יביע אומר וכו', כי בהתבונן האדם מעשה השי"ת וברואיו הנפלאות חדשים לבקרים, יגיע אליו היראה וההכנעה, וכמו שמצינו באברהם אבינו ע"ה שמזה הפליא עצה והגדיל תושי' להאמין במציאות השי"ת ואחדותו והשגחתו, אמנם כ"ז יועיל לבני עלי' אשר המה מועטים, כי לאשר הוטבע כן בטבע לא יתפעל האדם מחמתם, ולזה צריך התבוננות גדול ועמקות נפלא, לאשר הוא רגיל בתמידות אינו מתפעל ממנו כאשר ביאר זאת בחובת הלבבות בטוב טעם באריכות, אולם כאשר יקרה איזה דבר ניסיי חדש מה שחוץ לטבע, הנה זאת תפעול התעוררות גדול בלב הרואים לידע כי לה' הארץ והטבע וכל אשר בה.
translation: And behold, our sages of blessed memory said (Yoma 38a) that everything the Holy One, blessed be He, created, He created only for His honor, for from all the creations in the world one can learn about the existence of the Blessed One and His greatness. For the wisdom of the action testifies to its doer, as explained in the Duties of the Heart, Gate of Reflection. As it is said, "The heavens declare the glory of God, and the firmament shows His handiwork; day unto day utters speech" (Psalms 19:1-2). For when a person contemplates the works of the Blessed One and His wondrous creations, new every morning, he will come to fear and humility. And as we find with our forefather Abraham, peace be upon him, that from this he was amazed and greatly strengthened in his belief in the existence of the Blessed One, His oneness, and His providence. However, all this will benefit the righteous, who are few, for those who are naturally inclined will not be affected by it. Therefore, great contemplation and profound depth are needed, for one who is accustomed to it continuously will not be moved by it, as explained in the Duties of the Heart with good reason and at length. However, when a miraculous event occurs, something outside of nature, this will greatly awaken the hearts of those who see it to know that to the Lord belongs the earth and the nature and all that is in it.
summary: The passage emphasizes that everything created by God serves to reflect His glory and greatness, as the wisdom of the Creator is evident in His creations. It highlights that through contemplation of God's wonders, one can develop awe and humility, similar to Abraham's realization of God's existence and unity. However, this understanding is primarily beneficial for the spiritually elevated, as those accustomed to the natural order may require extraordinary, miraculous events to awaken their awareness of God's sovereignty over nature. Ultimately, such miraculous occurrences can lead to a profound recognition of God's dominion over the earth and all within it.

passage_content: והנה המן שהמטיר השי"ת לישראל מן השמים הי' דבר ניסיי היפך הטבע, כי הטבע מחייב להצמיח לחם מן הארץ ולא מן השמים, ולפי"מ דקיי"ל אסור להנות ממעשה נסים איך אכלו ישראל את המן, אמנם לפי האמור דכאשר יצמח קידוש השם ע"י הנס אז מותר להנות ממנה א"ש, כי באמת אין לך קידוש השם גדול מזה שהוא לגמרי היפך הטבע עד קצה האחרון ועי"ז יכירו וידעו כל באי עולם כי ה' הוא אלקים משדד הטבע, וזהו אומרו הנני ממטיר לכם שיהי' לעצמכם ותוכלו להנות ממנו, הגם כי הוא לחם מן השמים והוא דבר ניסיי ואסור להנות ממעשה נסים, ע"ז אמר ויצא העם ולקטו דבר יום ביומו דייקא, כי מן המן ידעו לספר כבוד השי"ת, ודברי נפלאותיו ישיחו בכל יום ויום, כענין אמרו יום ליום יביע אומר, אשר מזה יהי' קידוש השם גדול מאוד, ועי"ז מותר להנות ממנו כדברי הישועות יעקב והבן.
translation: And behold, the manna that the Holy One, blessed be He, rained down for Israel from the heavens was a miraculous thing, contrary to nature, for nature requires that bread be produced from the earth and not from the heavens. And according to this, since we hold that it is forbidden to derive benefit from acts of miracles, how did Israel eat the manna? However, according to what has been said, that when the sanctification of the Name arises through the miracle, then it is permitted to derive benefit from it, for indeed there is no greater sanctification of the Name than this, which is entirely contrary to nature to the utmost extent, and through this all the inhabitants of the world will recognize and know that the Lord is God, who overturns nature. And this is what He says: "Behold, I am raining down for you," that it should be for yourselves and you will be able to benefit from it, even though it is bread from the heavens and it is a miraculous thing, and it is forbidden to derive benefit from acts of miracles. To this, it says, "And the people went out and gathered, day by day precisely," for from the manna they knew to proclaim the glory of the Holy One, blessed be He, and His wondrous deeds they would speak of every day, as it is said, "Day to day utters speech," which will bring about a very great sanctification of the Name, and through this it is permitted to derive benefit from it, as stated by the Yeshuos Yaakov and his son.
summary: The passage discusses the miraculous nature of the manna provided by God to the Israelites, emphasizing that it defies natural laws by being bread from heaven rather than from the earth. It highlights that enjoying the manna is permissible because it serves to sanctify God's name, demonstrating His power over nature. The act of collecting the manna daily allows the Israelites to proclaim God's glory and share His wonders, leading to a significant sanctification of His name. Thus, the miraculous sustenance becomes a means for spiritual elevation and recognition of God's sovereignty.

passage_content: ויאמר ה' אל משה הנני ממטיר לכם לחם מן השמים וגו' למען אנסנו הילך בתורתי אם לא, פירש"י ז"ל הילך בתורתי, אם ישמרו מצות התליות בו שלא יותירו ממנו ולא יצאו בשבת ללקוט עכ"ל והרמב"ן ז"ל העתיק דברי רש"י ז"ל וכתב עליו ואיננו נכון אבל הוא כמו שאמר המאכילך מן במדבר וגו' ולמען נסותך להיטיבך באחריתך כי נסיון הוא להם, שלא יהי' לאדם מזון ולא יראו להם עצה במדבר, רק המן שלא ידעו מתחלה ולא שמעו מאבותם, ויורד להם דבר יום ביומו וירעיבו אליו, ועם כל זה שמעו ללכת אחרי השם לא מקום לחם, וככה אמר להם עוד וזכרת את כל הדרך וגו' ולמען נסותך לדעת וגו' התשמור מצותיו אם לא וכו', והוליכם במדבר וכו' ושלא יהי' להם לחם רק מן השמים דבר יום ביומו לנסותם ולהטיב להם באחרונה שיאמינו בו לעולם עכ"ל הרמב"ן ז"ל, ולשני הפירושים צ"ב בלשון הפסוק הילך בתורתי, דלפירש"י הי' לו לומר הישמרו מצותי, גם לדעת הרמב"ן שהנסיון בענין האמונה קשה ג"כ הלשון הילך והול"ל למען אנסנו אם יאמינו לדברי, עוד יל"ד למה הוצרך הכתוב להזכיר דבר והפיכו הילך בתורתי אם לא, ומובן מאליו שהמציאות הוא דבר והפיכו דאל"כ אינו בגדר נסיון כלל, ומלות אם לא המה מיותרים.
translation: And the Lord said to Moses, "Behold, I am raining down bread from heaven for you..." in order to test them whether they will walk in My Torah or not. Rashi, of blessed memory, explained: "Will they walk in My Torah," if they will keep the commandments that are dependent on it, that they should not leave over from it and not go out on Shabbat to gather. Thus far the words of Rashi. And Nachmanides, of blessed memory, copied Rashi's words and wrote upon them that it is not correct, but it is as the one who feeds you from the wilderness... and to test you to do good for you in your end, for it is a test for them, that a person should have no food and they should not see for themselves a counsel in the wilderness, only the manna, which they did not know at first and did not hear from their forefathers, and it descends to them a thing day by day and they are to be hungry for it. And with all this, they listened to go after the Lord, not for the sake of bread. And thus He said to them again, "And you shall remember all the way..." and "to test you to know..." if you will keep His commandments or not, etc. And He led them in the wilderness, etc., and that they should have no bread except from heaven, a thing day by day, to test them and to do good for them in the end, that they should believe in Him forever. Thus far the words of Nachmanides. And on both interpretations, the language of the verse "Will they walk in My Torah" is difficult, for according to Rashi, it should have said "Will they keep My commandments." Also according to Nachmanides, since the test is regarding faith, the language "Will they walk" is also difficult, and it should have said "to test us if they will believe My words." Furthermore, it needs to be understood why the verse needed to mention "a thing" and "will they walk in My Torah or not," and it is self-evident that the reality is a thing and "will they walk" is not a test at all, and the words "if not" are superfluous.
summary: The passage discusses God's provision of manna in the desert as a test for the Israelites, emphasizing the importance of following His commandments. Rashi interprets this as a trial to see if they will observe the commandments related to the manna, while Ramban suggests it serves to strengthen their faith in God's sustenance. The text raises questions about the phrasing "if not," suggesting a deeper exploration of the nature of faith and obedience. Ultimately, it highlights the divine intention behind trials, aiming to cultivate a lasting belief in God's providence.

passage_content: ב) ביום הששי לקטו לחם משנה וגו' ויבאו כל נשיאי העדה ויגידו למשה ויאמר אליהם הוא אשר דבר ה' שבתון שבת קודש וגו' פירש"י מכאן יש ללמוד שעדיין לא הגיד להם משה פרשת שבת שנצטווה לומר להם והי' ביום הששי והכינו וגו', עד ששאלו את זאת, אמר להם הוא אשר דבר ה' שנצטויתי לומר לכם, ולכן ענשו הכתוב שאמר לו עד אנא מאנתם ולא הוציאו מן הכלל, ובמד"ר (פר' כ"ה סימן י') ויותירו אנשים ממנו וכו' מיד ויקצוף עליהם משה, כיון שכעס שכח לומר להם שילקטו ביום הששי שני עומרים לאחד, כיון שהלכו ולקטו ביום הששי ומצאו כפלים, באו הנשיאים ואמרו למשה וכו', וע"ז נאמר עד אנה מאנתם שהוא מכניס משה בכללם עכ"ד המדרש, והקשו המפורשים מדוע לא אמר להם מצות השבת מיד ביום הראשון, שהרי ירד להם המן בראשון בשבת תחלה כדאי' בגמ', ואז היה עדיין לפני הקצף שהותירו ביום הב'.
translation: On the sixth day, they gathered a double portion of bread, etc. And all the leaders of the congregation came and told Moses, and he said to them, "This is what the Lord has said: a Sabbath of holy rest," etc. Rashi explains that from here we learn that Moses had not yet told them the section of the Sabbath that he was commanded to say to them, "And it shall be on the sixth day, and you shall prepare," etc., until they asked about this. He said to them, "This is what the Lord has commanded me to tell you." Therefore, the text punishes him by saying, "Until when will you refuse?" and he did not exclude himself from the general. And in the Midrash (Parashat 25, Section 10), "And some left over," etc., immediately Moses became angry with them. Since he was angry, he forgot to tell them to gather on the sixth day two omers for each person. When they went and gathered on the sixth day and found double, the leaders came and said to Moses, etc. And regarding this, it is said, "Until when will you refuse?" which includes Moses among them, thus concludes the Midrash. The commentators questioned why he did not tell them the commandment of the Sabbath immediately on the first day, since the manna descended for them on the first Sabbath, as stated in the Gemara, and then he would have still been before the anger for leaving over on the second day.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the discussion revolves around the Israelites' failure to initially grasp the commandment of Shabbat, as indicated by their inquiry about collecting manna on the sixth day. The text highlights the importance of divine instruction and the consequences of doubt, as Moses, in his frustration, includes the people in his reprimand. The underlying theological insight emphasizes the necessity of clear communication of God's commandments and the significance of obedience to divine will, particularly regarding the sanctity of Shabbat.

passage_content: ונל"פ בהקדם קושית המפורשים ז"ל מדוע לא ירד המן בשבת, כמו שהקב"ה מוריד גשמים וטללים בשבת, ואמרז"ל במד"ר (בראשית פי"א ס"ה) טורנוסרופוס הרשע שאל את ר"ע אם כדבריך שהקב"ה מכבד את השבת אל ישב בה רוחות, אל יוריד בה גשמים, א"ל אמשול לך משל לשנים שהיו דרין בחצר א', אם אין זה נותן עירוב וזה נותן עירוב שמא מותרין לטלטל בחצר, אבל אם הי' אחד דר בחצר הרי הוא מותר בכל החצר, אף הקב"ה לפי שאין רשות אחרת עמו, וכל העולם כולו שלו מותר בכל העולם כולו, וה"ה כרה"י עיי"ש במד"ר, וכמו"כ מה"ט הי' יכול הקב"ה להוריד המן בשבת, וי"ל שנשבת המן בשביל ישראל, דנאסר להם לקיטתו משום תחומין והוצאה, כדרשתם ז"ל (עירובין י"ז ע"ב) אל יצא איש ממקומו, אל יצא עם הכלי ללקוט המן, ועיין בתוס' שם דתרווייהו משתמעי מיני' הוצאה ותחומין.
translation: And we will discuss in advance the question of the commentators, why the manna did not fall on Shabbat, just as the Holy One, blessed be He, brings down rain and dew on Shabbat. And our sages said in Midrash Rabbah (Genesis 11:65) that the wicked Turnus Rufus asked Rabbi Akiva if, as you say, the Holy One, blessed be He, honors Shabbat, should not the winds refrain from blowing, and should it not rain? He replied, I will give you a parable of two people who lived in one courtyard; if one does not provide an eruv and the other does, perhaps they are permitted to carry in the courtyard. But if one person lived in the courtyard, he is permitted throughout the entire courtyard. So too, the Holy One, blessed be He, since there is no other authority with Him, and the entire world belongs to Him, is permitted throughout the entire world. And the same applies to a private domain, as stated there in Midrash Rabbah. Likewise, for this reason, the Holy One, blessed be He, could have brought down the manna on Shabbat, and it can be said that the manna ceased for the sake of Israel, for it was forbidden for them to gather it due to the boundaries and carrying, as our sages expounded (Eruvin 17b), that no man should go out from his place, nor should he go out with a vessel to gather the manna. And see in the Tosafot there that both are derived from it, carrying and boundaries.
summary: The passage discusses the question of why manna was not provided on Shabbat, despite God's ability to send rain on that day. It emphasizes that while God honors the sanctity of Shabbat, the prohibition against collecting manna was intended to teach the Israelites about the importance of rest and the limits of their actions on this holy day. The text illustrates a theological perspective that God's relationship with the world is one of sovereignty, where He could have provided manna but chose not to in order to uphold the sanctity of Shabbat and the laws governing it. This reflects a deeper understanding of divine providence and the significance of observing the commandments.

passage_content: והנה אמרז"ל יומא (ע"ה ע"א) כתיב ירד המן עליו, וכתיב ויצא העם ולקטו וכתיב שטו העם ולקטו, (פירש"י ירד המן עליו אלמא בתוך המחנה הי' יורד, וכתיב ויצא העם ולקטו יציאה מחוץ למחנה משמע, וכתיב שטו משמע למקום רחוק) הא כיצד צדיקים יורד על פתח בתיהם, בינונים יצאו ולקטו, רשעים שטו ולקטו עכ"ד הגמ', ולפי"ז הי' אפשר שירד המן לצדיקים, דליכא לגבייהו איסור תחומין והוצאה, שירד על פתח בתיהם, ואפשר דמפני שלא הי' רוב הדור במדריגה זו, ע"כ לא ירד אף לצדיקים משום לא פלוג, אמנם אלמלי הי' כל ישראל במדריגה זו שירד להם המן על פתח אהליהם, הי' יורד המן גם בשבת.
translation: And behold, our Sages of blessed memory said in Yoma (38a) that it is written, "The manna descended upon him," and it is written, "And the people went out and gathered," and it is written, "The people strayed and gathered." (Rashi explains that the manna descended upon him, which implies that it fell within the camp, and it is written, "And the people went out and gathered," which indicates going outside the camp, and it is written, "strayed," which implies going to a distant place.) How is this so? The righteous had it descend at the entrance of their homes, the average ones went out and gathered, and the wicked strayed and gathered. Thus far the Gemara. According to this, it was possible for the manna to descend for the righteous, as there was no prohibition of boundaries and carrying for them, since it descended at the entrance of their homes. It is possible that because the majority of the generation was not on this level, therefore it did not descend even for the righteous, due to the principle of "not distinguishing." However, had all of Israel been on this level, that the manna would descend at the entrance of their tents, the manna would have also descended on Shabbat.
summary: The passage discusses the nature of the manna that fell during the Israelites' journey in the desert, highlighting different experiences based on one's spiritual level. It explains that the righteous received the manna at their doorsteps, the average individuals had to go out to collect it, and the wicked had to venture far to find it. The text suggests that if the entire nation had reached a higher spiritual level, the manna would have descended directly to their tents, even on Shabbat. This reflects the Hasidic idea that spiritual elevation can transform one's experience of divine provision.
