passage_content: ובזה יתורץ קושית המפרשים ז"ל (קושיא ב') דע"כ לא אמר להם משרע"ה מצות השבת ביום הראשון שהי' עדיין לפני הקצף, כי הי' משרע"ה מצפה שכל ישראל יזכו למדריגת הצדיקים וירד להם המן גם בשבת, והגם שהקב"ה אמר לו והי' ביום הששי והכינו בשעת הציווי, אפשר שנאמרה על תנאי, ע"ד שאמרז"ל (ע"ז ה' ע"ב) למימרא דאי לא חטאו, והכתיב פרשת יבמות ופרשת נחלות, ותירצו בגמ' שנכתבו על תנאי עיי"ש, וכמו"כ הכא אפשר שהציווי והי' ביום הששי על תנאי נאמרה, אבל משרע"ה הי' מצפה שלא יצטרך לצוות את ישראל בכך, כי עדיין תליא בבחירתם ואולי יזכו במעשיהם וירד להם המן גם בשבת, וע"ד שפירשתי מאמרם ז"ל (סנהדרין קי"א ע"א) א"ל ר' יוחנן לר"ל לא ניחא לי' למרייהו דאמרת עלייכו הכי וכו', דמלתא דתליא בבחירה, לא ניחא להקב"ה שיתאמר העונש בבחי' דיבור, כי אולי יזכו ישראל ויתבטל הגזירה עיי"ש, ואפשר דמה"ט המתין משרע"ה מלאמרה להם ביום הראשון, אמנם ביום השני דכתיב ולא שמעו אל משה ויותירו וגו' השיג משרע"ה כי לא זכו כולם למדריגת הצדיקים, ע"כ אז הי' זמני' למסור להם מצות השבת, שיכינו מיום הששי לשבת כי לא ירד המן בשבת, אלא מתוך שכעס שכח וא"ש דברי המדרש.
translation: And with this, the difficulty of the commentators, may their memory be blessed (difficulty 2), is resolved: for it is not said to them by Moshe Rabbeinu about the commandment of Shabbat on the first day, as it was still before the anger, because Moshe Rabbeinu was hoping that all of Israel would merit the level of the righteous and that the manna would descend for them even on Shabbat. And although the Holy One, blessed be He, told him, "And it shall be on the sixth day, and they shall prepare," it is possible that it was said conditionally, as the sages have said (Avodah Zarah 5b) to imply that if they had not sinned, and it is written in the sections of Yevamot and the sections of Inheritances, and the Gemara answers that they were written conditionally, as mentioned there. Likewise, here it is possible that the commandment "And it shall be on the sixth day" was said conditionally, but Moshe Rabbeinu was hoping that he would not need to command Israel in this way, for it still depended on their choice, and perhaps they would merit through their deeds and the manna would descend for them even on Shabbat. This is in accordance with my explanation of their statement (Sanhedrin 111a) where Rabbi Yochanan said to Rabbi Levi, "It is not pleasing to Him that you say such a thing about them," etc., for a matter that depends on choice, it is not pleasing to the Holy One, blessed be He, that the punishment be stated in a manner of speech, for perhaps Israel would merit and the decree would be nullified, as mentioned there. And it is possible that for this reason Moshe Rabbeinu waited to tell them on the first day, but on the second day, as it is written, "And they did not listen to Moshe, and they left over," Moshe Rabbeinu realized that not all had merited the level of the righteous. Therefore, at that time it was appropriate to instruct them about the commandment of Shabbat, to prepare from the sixth day for Shabbat, for the manna would not descend on Shabbat, but out of anger, he forgot, and the words of the Midrash are clear.
summary: The passage discusses the expectation of Moses that the Israelites would attain the level of the righteous and receive manna on Shabbat, thus not requiring a commandment for its preparation. It suggests that the divine command regarding the manna was conditional, dependent on the Israelites' choices and actions. However, upon realizing that not all had reached this level of righteousness, Moses then communicated the commandment for Shabbat preparation. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the interplay between divine expectation, human free will, and the consequences of actions.

passage_content: ולדרכינו יתבאר הכתוב למען אנסנו הילך בתורתי אם לא ופירש"י ז"ל אם ישמרו מצות התליות בו שלא יותירו ממנו ולא יצאו בשבת ללקוט, (עיין קושיא א' לעיל) דהנה ב' בחינת נסיונות יש, אחד נסיון הצדיקים שהוא ע"צ הטובה, כענין והאלקים נסה את אברהם ופי' הראב"ע ז"ל בשם הגאון שענינו להראות צדקתו לבנ"א, והרמב"ן ז"ל פי' להוציא הדבר מן הכח אל הפועל להיות לו שכר מעשה טוב, לא שכר לב טוב בלבד עיי"ש, ובחי' הב' נסיון הבא ע"י גרמת החטא. כגון נסיון הזה אם ישמרו מצות התליות בו שלא יצאו בשבת ללקוט, דאלמלי זכו ישראל הי' המן יורד להם בשבת, ולא הי' במציאות נסיון הזה כלל וכעין שפי' הראב"ע ז"ל (בפ' ראה) עה"פ לא תשמע אל דברי הנביא ההוא וגו', כי מנסה ה' אלקיכם אתכם וגומר, בעבור שעזבו ולא המיתו וכו' עיי"ש, דענין הנסיון הזה ע"י גרמת החטא, והוא ע"ד העונש וההתגברות בזה קשה מאוד, וככה אנו רואים בדורות האחרונים שישנם הרבה נסיונות, שלא הי' בגדר נסיון כלל בדורות הראשונים, ובפרט בזמן שהי' הביהמ"ק קיים שראו כל בשר כבוד ה', וכ"א מישראל הי' לו אימה ופחד מהדר גאונו ית', ע"ד שאמרו ז"ל (ירושלמי דמאי מ"ד ה"א) שאף ע"ה לא הי' משקר בשבת מאימת שבת עליו, ובאותן הדורות לא הי' נסיון כ"כ בשמירת התורה ומצות, משא"כ בדורות האחרונים שע"י גרמת העונות נענשנו בהסתרת פנים ר"ל, ואין שום פחד ואימה לעשות ככל העולה על רוחו, גדלו הנסיונות מאוד ה' ישמרינו.
translation: And according to our path, the verse will be clarified in order to test us whether we will walk in His Torah or not. And Rashi, of blessed memory, explained that if they keep the commandments that are dependent upon it, that they should not leave any of it over and should not go out on Shabbat to gather, (see the first question above). Behold, there are two types of trials: one is the trial of the righteous, which is for the sake of goodness, as in the matter of "And God tested Abraham," and the explanation of the Rabbi Abraham Ibn Ezra, of blessed memory, in the name of the Gaon, is to show his righteousness to mankind. And Ramban, of blessed memory, explained it to bring the matter from potential to actual, to have a reward for a good deed, not just a reward for a good heart, see there. And the second type of trial comes through the cause of sin. For example, this trial, whether they will keep the commandments that are dependent upon it, that they should not go out on Shabbat to gather, for had Israel merited it, the manna would have descended for them on Shabbat, and this trial would not have existed at all. And it is similar to what Rabbi Abraham Ibn Ezra, of blessed memory, explained (in Parashat Re'eh) regarding the verse "Do not listen to the words of that prophet," for the Lord your God is testing you, etc., because they abandoned and did not kill, etc., see there. The matter of this trial through the cause of sin is in the nature of punishment and the struggle in this is very difficult. And thus we see in the last generations that there are many trials that were not at all in the category of trial in the earlier generations, especially at the time when the Holy Temple was standing, when all flesh saw the glory of the Lord, and each one of Israel had fear and dread of His glorious majesty, as our sages, of blessed memory, said (Jerusalem Talmud, Demai, chapter 4, Mishnah 1) that even a non-Jew would not lie on Shabbat out of fear of Shabbat upon him. And in those generations, there was not such a trial in the observance of the Torah and commandments, whereas in the last generations, due to the cause of sins, we have been punished with the hiding of the face, may God have mercy, and there is no fear or dread to do whatever comes to one's mind. The trials have greatly increased, may the Lord protect us.
summary: The passage discusses two types of trials: one for the righteous, which serves to reveal their goodness and earn them reward, and another resulting from sin, which leads to challenges in observing commandments. It emphasizes that had the Israelites been worthy, they would have received manna on Shabbat without trial. The text reflects on the increased challenges faced in later generations due to the concealment of divine presence as a consequence of sin, contrasting this with the earlier times when the presence of God was evident and instilled a sense of awe and fear, leading to greater adherence to the Torah and commandments.

passage_content: ועד"ז יתפרש הכתוב למען אנסנו הילך בתורתי אם לא, ולדרכינו נאמרה הכתוב על תנאי, ותליא בבחירתם של ישראל, שאם יזכו יהי' הנסיון ע"צ הטובה כבחי' נסיון הצדיקים, שהוא להראות צדקת המנוסה, וכפי' הרמב"ן ז"ל שיתברר אמונתם החזקה ולהטיב להם באחרונה וכו', ואם לא יזכו להשתלם בשמירת התורה אז יהי' הנסיון באופן הב' אם ישמרו מצות התליות בו ולא יצאו בשבת ללקוט, שגרמת הנסיון ע"י שעברו והותירו, וזשה"כ למען אנסנו הילך בתורתי אם לא, שבחי' הנסיון ישתנה כפי בחירתם, אם ילכו בתורתי יהי' הנסיון ע"צ הטובה כנסיון הצדיקים להטיב להם באחרונה כדברי הרמב"ן ז"ל, ואם לא אז יהי' הנסיון באופן הב' אם ישמרו מצות התליות בו כדברי רש"י ז"ל ושניהם נרמזו בקרא.
translation: And similarly, the verse will be explained: "In order to test us, whether we will walk in His Torah or not," and regarding our ways, the verse is stated conditionally, and it depends on the choice of Israel. If they merit, the trial will be for the sake of good, like the trial of the righteous, which is to demonstrate the righteousness of the one being tested, and according to the explanation of the Ramban, that their strong faith will be clarified and it will be good for them in the end, etc. But if they do not merit to perfect themselves in the observance of the Torah, then the trial will be in the second manner, if they keep the commandments that are dependent upon it and do not go out on Shabbat to gather, as the trial is caused by their transgression and neglect. And thus it is written: "In order to test us, whether we will walk in His Torah or not," that the nature of the trial will change according to their choice. If they walk in His Torah, the trial will be for the sake of good, like the trial of the righteous, to benefit them in the end, as stated by the Ramban. But if not, then the trial will be in the second manner, if they keep the commandments that are dependent upon it, as stated by Rashi, and both are hinted at in the verse.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of divine testing as contingent upon the choices of the Jewish people, emphasizing that their adherence to the Torah determines the nature of their trials. If they merit it through their commitment to the commandments, the tests will serve to reveal their righteousness and ultimately lead to their benefit, akin to the trials of the righteous. Conversely, if they fail to uphold the Torah, the tests will manifest in a different manner, highlighting the consequences of their actions. This reflects a dynamic relationship between human choice and divine providence, as illustrated by interpretations from both Ramban and Rashi.

passage_content: עוד יל"פ הילך בתורתי אם לא, שהכוונה על כלליות התורה והעסק בה, ועפימ"ש רש"י ז"ל עה"פ למען יראו את הלחם אשר האכלתי אתכם וגו' בימי ירמי' כשהיה ירמי' מוכיחם למה אין אתם עוסקים בתורה, והם אומרים נניח מלאכתינו ונעסוק בתורה מהיכן נתפרנס, הוציא להם צנצנת המן, אמר להם ראו דבר ה' וכו' בזה נתפרנסו אבותיכם, הרבה שלוחים יש לו למקום להכין מזון ליראיו עכ"ל, ואפ"ל הכוונה בזה דוודאי לא הי' כוונת הנביא שלא יעסקו בפרנסתם כלל וירד להם לחם מן השמים, כי לא זכו לזה כ"א דור המדבר, ולימות המשיח ג"כ ירד המן לישראל כמבואר בדברי רז"ל, אמנם איתא בספה"ק דבפ' המן יש סגולת השפעת פרנסה לכל דורות ישראל, ומהמן שירד לישראל במדבר, נמשך צינור השפעה לכל העוסקים בתורה, וזה נרמז במאמה"כ למשמרת לדורותיכם, ובזה הוכיח ירמי' הנביא לאנשי דורו שבאו בטענת הצטדקות מהיכן נתפרנס ואיך נניח מלאכתינו ונעסוק בתורה, הוציא להם צנצנת המן ואמר להם ראו דבר ה' וכו' בזה נתפרנסו אבותיכם, ומשם נמשך השפעת פרנסה לכל עוסקי תורה.
translation: It should be further explained how it is in my Torah, if not, that the intention is regarding the generality of the Torah and engaging in it. And according to the words of Rashi, may his memory be blessed, on the verse "so that they may see the bread that I fed you," etc., in the days of Jeremiah, when Jeremiah was rebuking them for not engaging in the Torah, they said, "Shall we abandon our work and engage in the Torah? From where will we earn a living?" He brought out to them a jar of manna and said to them, "See the word of the Lord," etc., "In this, your forefathers were sustained." The Holy One, blessed be He, has many messengers to prepare food for His fearful ones. Thus far are his words. And I can say that the intention here is certainly not that the prophet meant for them not to engage in their livelihood at all and that bread would fall from the heavens for them, for they were not worthy of this except for the generation of the desert. And in the days of the Messiah, too, the manna will fall for Israel, as is explained in the words of our Sages. However, it is stated in the holy books that in the section of the manna there is a merit of providing sustenance for all generations of Israel. And from the manna that fell to Israel in the desert, a channel of influence for sustenance extends to all who engage in the Torah. This is hinted at in the verse "to be kept for your generations." And with this, Jeremiah the prophet proved to the people of his generation who came with a claim of justification, asking from where they would earn a living and how they could abandon their work to engage in the Torah. He brought out to them a jar of manna and said to them, "See the word of the Lord," etc., "In this, your forefathers were sustained," and from there, the influence of sustenance extends to all who engage in the Torah.
summary: The passage discusses the relationship between engaging in Torah study and divine sustenance, referencing the biblical example of the manna provided to the Israelites in the desert. The prophet Jeremiah uses this example to challenge his contemporaries' concerns about neglecting their work for Torah study, emphasizing that God has the ability to provide for those who prioritize spiritual pursuits. It highlights the belief that the merit of Torah study creates a channel for divine sustenance, which is accessible to all generations. Ultimately, the text underscores the idea that reliance on God for sustenance is a fundamental aspect of faith and devotion in Judaism.

passage_content: וע"כ החיוב על כ"א מישראל אף אם עוסק במו"מ או במלאכה, צריך לקבוע עיתים לתורה, ותחלת דינו של אדם ליום הדין שואלין לו קבעת עיתים לתורה כאמרז"ל במסכת שבת (דף ל"א ע"א) ואל ידמה בעיניו שבזה מחסר פרנסתו, אבל צריך להאמין שנמשך השפעת פרנסה לעוסקי תורה מפ' המן, וז"פ הפסוק הנני ממטיר לכם לחם מן השמים וגו' למען אנסנו הילך בתורתי אם לא, והכוונה על הנסיון בעסק התורה, דאלמלי הי' טענת מהיכן נתפרנס צודקת, לא הי' נקרא בשם נסיון כלל, דאין הקב"ה בא בטרוניא עם בריותיו, אבל לפי שנמשך מירידת המן השפעת פרנסה לכל עוסקי תורה, נדחה טענת מהיכן נתפרנס, וקיים ועומד הנסיון הזה לכל הדורות הילך בתורתי לקבוע עיתים לתורה, ואפשר דמה שכפל הכתוב לפרש דבר והפיכו הילך בתורתי אם לא, ירמוז דאף בדור חלוש שכח התורה בשפלות מאוד, מ"מ אם הולכין בדרך התורה וקובעים עיתים לתורה כ"א כפי יכולתו, נמשך לו השפעת פרנסה מהמן, ולז"א למען אנסנו הילך בתורתי אם לא, ר"ל בין אם ילכו בתורתי אם לא, עומד וקיים הנסיון הזה ע"י השפעת פרנסה מירידת המן.
translation: Therefore, the obligation upon each Jew, even if he is engaged in business or work, is to set times for Torah study. The initial judgment of a person on the Day of Judgment will inquire whether he has set times for Torah study, as our Sages have said in Tractate Shabbat (31a). One should not think that this detracts from his livelihood, but rather he must believe that the influence of sustenance is drawn to those who engage in Torah, as derived from the manna. This is the meaning of the verse, "Behold, I am raining down for you bread from heaven," etc., "in order to test us whether we will walk in My Torah or not." The intention is regarding the trial in the engagement of Torah. If the claim of "from where will we be sustained" were valid, it would not be called a trial at all, for the Holy One, blessed be He, does not come to argue with His creations. However, since the influence of sustenance is drawn from the descent of the manna to all who engage in Torah, the claim of "from where will we be sustained" is dismissed, and this trial remains for all generations: "to walk in My Torah" and to set times for Torah study. It is possible that the repetition in the verse, "to test us whether we will walk in My Torah or not," hints that even in a generation weak in the strength of Torah, very lowly, nevertheless, if they walk in the way of Torah and set times for Torah study according to each one's ability, the influence of sustenance from the manna will be drawn to them. Thus, it is said, "in order to test us whether we will walk in My Torah or not," meaning that whether they walk in My Torah or not, this trial remains and exists through the influence of sustenance from the descent of the manna.
summary: The passage emphasizes the obligation of every Jew to set aside time for Torah study, regardless of their work or business commitments. It highlights that during the Day of Judgment, individuals will be questioned about their dedication to Torah learning, and one should not fear that this commitment will detract from their livelihood. The text draws on the example of the manna, illustrating that divine sustenance is provided to those who engage in Torah study, thereby affirming that reliance on God for sustenance is a fundamental aspect of faith. Even in challenging times, maintaining a commitment to Torah study ensures the continuation of divine support and sustenance.

passage_content: ובוקר וראיתם את כבוד ה' בשמעו את תלנתיכם על ה' ונחנו מה כי תלונו עלינו, פירש"י ז"ל שתרעימו עלינו את הכל את בניכם ונשיכם ובנותיכם וערב רב, ועל כרחי אני זקוק לפרש תלינו בלשון תפעילו, מפני דגשותו וקרייתו, שאלו הי' רפה הייתי מפרשו בלשון תפעלו, כמו וילן העם על משה, או אם הי' דגוש ואין בו יו"ד ונקרא תלונו, הייתי מפרשו לשון תתלוננו, עכשיו הוא משמע תלינו את אחרים כמו במרגלים וילינו עליו את כל העדה ע"כ, והנה הגם שפירוש רשיז"ל מוכרח מלשון הכתוב, שהרי דיבר משה אל הכלל ישראל ולא אל הערב רב, שהם לא ראו את כבוד ה' שהיו חוץ לעננים, וגם המן לא ירד להם ולא אכלו רק מתמצית המן כמבואר בדבריהם ז"ל, א"כ בהכרח צ"ל שמשה רבינו אמר זאת להכלל ישראל שהם המלינים את אחרים, עכ"ז הענין פליאה נשגבה, דבכ"מ מצינו להיפוך שהע"ר הי' תמיד אבן נגף לישראל כמ"ש בחטא העגל שחת עמך, ופירש"י הערב רב שקבלת מעצמך הם שחתו והשחיתו, וכן בשאר החטאים הם היו הגורמים ואיך נעשה כאן התהפכות כ"כ שהכלל ישראל הרעימו את הע"ר על משה ואהרן וכי היו הע"ר צריכין לזה, וגם בלא"ה היו מושחתין ממקורם הרע.
translation: And in the morning you will see the glory of the Lord, as He hears your complaints against the Lord, and what are we that you complain against us. Rashi, of blessed memory, explains that you are raising your voices against us, against all, your sons, your wives, your daughters, and the mixed multitude. And I am compelled to explain "complain" in the active sense, due to its emphasis and pronunciation. If it were weak, I would interpret it in the passive sense, like "the people camped against Moses," or if it were strong and did not have a yud and was read as "complain," I would interpret it as "you will complain." Now it implies that you are complaining about others, as with the spies, "and they complained against him the whole congregation." Therefore, although Rashi's explanation is necessary from the language of the text, since Moses spoke to the entire congregation of Israel and not to the mixed multitude, who did not see the glory of the Lord as they were outside the clouds, and the manna did not descend for them, and they only ate from the essence of the manna, as explained in their words of blessed memory, it must be that Moses our teacher said this to the congregation of Israel, who are the ones complaining about others. Nevertheless, the matter is a wondrous perplexity, for we find elsewhere the opposite, that the mixed multitude was always a stumbling block for Israel, as stated regarding the sin of the golden calf, "they have corrupted your people," and Rashi explains that the mixed multitude, which you accepted upon yourself, are the ones who corrupted and destroyed. And so it is with other sins; they were the causes. How then is there such a reversal here, that the congregation of Israel raised their voices against the mixed multitude regarding Moses and Aaron? And were the mixed multitude in need of this? Moreover, they would have been corrupt from their own evil source.
summary: The passage discusses the relationship between the Jewish people and the mixed multitude (Erev Rav) during their journey in the desert, highlighting the tension between collective responsibility and individual actions. It emphasizes that while the Israelites often blamed the Erev Rav for their sins, they themselves were also complicit in the complaints against Moses and Aaron. The text reflects on the paradox of the Erev Rav being a source of temptation and sin, yet the Israelites' own actions led to their grievances. This illustrates a deeper theological insight into the nature of sin, communal dynamics, and the complexities of leadership within the context of faith.

passage_content: ב) צ"ב לשון רש"י ז"ל ועל כרחי אני זקוק לפרש וכו', דלמה לו לומר ועל כרחי, ובכל המקומות מזכיר פירוש הפסוק בלבד ולא אמר על כרחי וכו'.
translation: B) It is difficult to understand the language of Rashi, may his memory be blessed, when he says "and necessarily I need to explain," etc. Why does he say "and necessarily"? In all other places, he only mentions the explanation of the verse and does not say "necessarily," etc.
summary: In this passage, the author reflects on the phrase "על כרחי" (against my will) used by Rashi, questioning its necessity in the context of his commentary. The emphasis on this phrase suggests a deeper understanding of divine will and human agency, highlighting the tension between personal desire and the overarching plan of God. This insight aligns with key Hasidic themes of surrendering to divine providence while recognizing the struggle inherent in aligning one's will with that of the Creator. Ultimately, it invites contemplation on the nature of faith and the acceptance of life's challenges as part of a greater spiritual journey.

passage_content: ויתבאר בהקדם לפרש מאמה"כ (בפ' יתרו) וישמע יתרו כהן מדין וגו' את כל אשר עשה אלקים למשה ולישראל עמו כי הוציא ה' את ישראל ממצרים פירש"י מה שמועה שמע ובא קריעת ים סוף ומלחמת עמלק, ויל"ד מדוע נקטו רז"ל הני תרתי דייקא, והרבה נסים נעשו לישראל זולתם.
translation: And it will be explained in advance to interpret from our holy Torah (in Parashat Yitro) "And Yitro, the priest of Midian, heard all that God had done for Moses and for Israel His people, that the Lord had brought Israel out of Egypt." Rashi explains what news he heard and came: the splitting of the Sea and the war with Amalek. It is to be wondered why our Sages specifically mentioned these two matters, as many miracles were performed for Israel besides them.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of Jethro's (Yitro's) hearing about God's miracles for Moses and the Israelites, specifically the splitting of the Red Sea and the battle against Amalek. It questions why the sages specifically highlighted these two events among the many miracles performed for Israel. This focus emphasizes the transformative power of these experiences in shaping the faith and identity of the Jewish people, illustrating key Hasidic themes of divine intervention and the importance of recognizing God's presence in pivotal moments of history.

passage_content: ונקדים דברי הגמרא (סוטה דף י"א ע"ב) ג' היו באותה עצה (של הבה נתחכמה לו) בלעם ואיוב ויתרו, בלעם שיעץ נהרג, איוב ששתק נידון ביסורין יתרו שברח זכו מבני בניו שישבו בלשכת הגזית, וראוי להתבונן א) מדוע באמת ברח יתרו ויתכן דאלמלא נשאר שם הי' יכול להצטרף עם איוב שהי' צדיק ולהתגבר על עצת בלעם הרשע, ב) קשה על איוב למה שתק על עוולה הנוראה של הבה נתחכמה, דמצינו בפסוקי איוב שנלחם נגד כל עושי עוולה במסנ"פ, (עיי"ש סי' כ"ט) שמונה הכתוב צדקותיו כי אמלט עני משוע ויתום ולא עוזר לו, ואשברה מתלעות עול ומשניו אשליך טרף, ואיך כאן שתק ולא מיחה כלל. ג) צריך להבין סברת פרעה ויועצו מצרים שהיו רשעים בהחלט ורצו לעשות לישראל רעה בכל יכולתם, איך לקחו להם ליועצים יתרו ואיוב שהיו שניהם צדיקים, הגם שאפשר שלא הכירו את יתרו לצדיק אבל איוב הי' מפורסם לאיש תם וישר ירא אלקים שאינו סובל עולה, ולכל היותר יעלה בידם לרצותו שישתוק ולא ימחה נגדם, מה להם לצרה הזאת ליקח יועצים שיהיו צריכים לפעול אצלם שישתקו, הי' יכולים ליקח יועצים שיהיו מדברים כרצונם, ד) קשה למה נענש איוב על ששתק, הלא בלא"ה לא הי' מועיל מחאתו כיון שנשאר יחידי נגד בלעם ומה הי' יכול לעשות.
translation: And we will precede with the words of the Gemara (Sotah 11b): There were three who were in that counsel (of "let us be cunning against Him"): Bilam, Iyov, and Yitro. Bilam, who advised, was killed; Iyov, who was silent, was judged with suffering; Yitro, who fled, merited that his descendants sat in the Lishkat HaGazit. It is fitting to contemplate: a) Why did Yitro truly flee? It is possible that had he remained there, he could have joined with Iyov, who was righteous, and overcome the counsel of the wicked Bilam. b) It is difficult regarding Iyov why he was silent about the terrible injustice of "let us be cunning," for we find in the verses of Iyov that he fought against all who commit injustice (see there 29:16), where the text enumerates his righteousness, that he rescued the poor from the hand of the oppressor and the orphan, and he broke the yoke of the oppressor and cast off the burden from him. How is it that here he was silent and did not protest at all? c) One must understand the reasoning of Pharaoh and his advisors from Egypt, who were definitely wicked and wanted to do evil to Israel with all their might. How did they take for themselves advisors like Yitro and Iyov, who were both righteous? Although it is possible they did not recognize Yitro as a righteous man, Iyov was well-known as a perfect and upright man, God-fearing, who does not tolerate injustice. At most, they could have hoped to persuade him to remain silent and not protest against them. Why would they take this trouble to choose advisors who would need to be persuaded to be silent? They could have taken advisors who would speak according to their wishes. d) It is difficult why Iyov was punished for being silent; after all, his protest would not have been effective since he remained alone against Bilam, and what could he have done?
summary: The passage discusses the fates of Bilaam, Job, and Jethro in the context of their responses to the evil counsel against Israel. It raises questions about Jethro's decision to flee, suggesting he could have joined Job in opposing Bilaam, and critiques Job's silence in the face of wrongdoing despite his known righteousness. Additionally, it examines the rationale behind Pharaoh's choice of advisors, highlighting the paradox of selecting righteous figures like Job and Jethro to counsel evil intentions. Ultimately, it questions the justice of Job's punishment for his silence, considering the futility of his protest against Bilaam's wickedness.

passage_content: אמנם יתבאר הענין בהקדם דברי הרמב"ן ז"ל בפסוק הבה נתחכמה לו וזל"ק: לא ראה פרעה וחכמי יועציו להכותם בחרב, כי תהי' בגידה גדולה להכות חנם העם אשר באו בעצת המלך הראשון וכו', אבל מר שיעשו דרך חכמה, שלא ירגישו ישראל כי באיבה יעשו בהם וכו', והענין שלא רצה לצוות לשרי הטבחים אשר לו להרגם בחרב המלך, או שישליכו אותם ליאור, אבל אמר לעם כאשר ימצא כל איש ילד יהודי ישליך אותו ביאור, ואם יצעק אבי הילד אל המלך או אל שר העיר, יאמרו שיביא עדים ויעשה בו נקמה, וכאשר הותרה רצועת המלך, היו המצריים מחפשים בבתים ומוציאים הילדים משם וכו' עכ"ל, מבואר כי התחלת הגזירה הי' בדרך התחכמות לחפות על מעשיהם שלא ירגישו ישראל כי באיבה יעשו בהם, גם נמנעו מלהרגם במצות המלך כי יחשב לבגידה גדולה וכו'.
translation: Indeed, the matter will be clarified by first presenting the words of the Ramban, of blessed memory, on the verse "Come, let us deal wisely with them," and he writes: Pharaoh and his wise counselors did not see fit to strike them down with the sword, for it would be a great betrayal to kill the people who came at the counsel of the first king, etc. Rather, they devised a cunning plan, so that the Israelites would not feel that they were acting out of hatred against them, etc. The matter is that he did not want to command his executioners to kill them with the king's sword, nor to throw them into the river, but he said to the people, "Whenever you find a Jewish child, throw him into the river," and if the father of the child cries out to the king or to the mayor, they would say that he should bring witnesses and take revenge on him. And when the king's leash was loosened, the Egyptians searched the houses and took the children out from there, etc. Thus, it is clear that the beginning of the decree was through cunning to cover up their actions so that the Israelites would not feel that they were acting out of hatred against them, and they also refrained from killing them by the command of the king, for it would be considered a great betrayal, etc.
summary: The passage discusses the cunning strategy of Pharaoh and his advisors in their oppression of the Israelites, emphasizing that they sought to disguise their malicious intent. Instead of directly ordering the killing of Jewish children, they manipulated the situation to appear as if it was a natural consequence of the people's actions, thus avoiding the perception of betrayal. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the nature of evil, where the oppressor uses deceit to mask their true intentions, highlighting the struggle between divine justice and human cruelty. The text underscores the importance of recognizing the hidden motivations behind actions that may seem justified on the surface.

passage_content: ובזה יובן מה שלקחו להם יועצים צדיקים, כי עי"ז יכלו לחפות על כל מעשיהם הרעים ולתרץ כל רשעתם ולומר הרי צדיקים יושבים במועצת המלכות והסכימו על עצתינו, ומזה שיעכבו על ידם מלגזור גזירות אכזריות לא היו יראים, כי היו בטוחים בכח המלכות שיעלה בידם לגזור ככל העולה על רוחם, וידעו בבירור שלא ימחו היועצים בתוקף כ"כ ולכל היותר ישתקו ולא ידברו כלל, ועכ"פ כלפי חוץ יוכלו לתרץ את מעשיהם במה שצדיקים יושבים בעצתם, וע"כ יתרו שהשיג כוונתם לא רצה לישב במעצתם וברח מהם, שלא רצה לחפות על מעשיהם הרעים, אבל איוב לא השיג את זאת ואולי הי' לו חשבון שמוטב יותר לישב במועצתם ולהציל מה דאפשר, אמנם אעפ"כ נחשב לו כל הרשעות שעשו המצריים כאילו הוא הי' עושה, ע"י שישב ביניהם ונתחבר להם וחיפה על מעשיהם, וכמו שכתב רבינו יונה ז"ל (אבות פ"א מ"ז) במשנה אל תתחבר לרשע וז"ל: שהוא עונש גדול שאין כמותו, כי החטא החמור פשע בו עשה עבירה אחת, אבל זה בכל העבירות שעושה הרשע יש לו חלק בהם, ונמצא עושה חטאים רבים גדולים ועצומים, ואם ידיו אסורים ולא נהנה בהם אוי לרשע ואוי לשכינו וכו' ע"כ.
translation: And with this, it will be understood why they took for themselves righteous advisors, for through this they could cover up all their evil deeds and justify all their wickedness, saying, "Look, the righteous are sitting in the council of the kingdom and have agreed to our counsel." Because of this, they were not afraid to impose cruel decrees, as they were confident in the power of the kingdom that they would be able to decree whatever they desired. They knew clearly that the advisors would not strongly oppose them, and at most would remain silent and not speak at all. And in any case, outwardly they could justify their actions by saying that the righteous are sitting in their counsel. Therefore, Yitro, who understood their intentions, did not want to sit in their council and fled from them, as he did not want to cover up their evil deeds. However, Iyov did not grasp this, and perhaps he thought it better to sit in their council and save what he could. Nevertheless, despite this, all the wickedness that the Egyptians did was considered as if he himself had done it, because he sat among them, connected with them, and covered for their actions. And as our Rabbi Yonah, may his memory be blessed, wrote (Ethics of the Fathers 1:7) in the Mishnah, "Do not associate with the wicked," and he said: it is a great punishment unlike any other, for the serious sin that one commits is one transgression, but this one, in all the transgressions that the wicked does, has a share in them, and thus he ends up committing many great and severe sins. And if his hands are bound and he does not benefit from them, woe to the wicked and woe to his neighbor, etc.
summary: The passage discusses the moral implications of associating with wicked individuals, highlighting that righteous advisors can provide a facade for evil actions, allowing wrongdoers to justify their deeds. It contrasts the responses of Jethro, who rejected such counsel to avoid complicity in wrongdoing, with Job, who, despite his intentions to mitigate harm, is still considered guilty by association. The text emphasizes the severe consequences of connecting with the wicked, as it implicates one in their sins, illustrating a key Hasidic teaching on the importance of maintaining moral integrity and the dangers of compromising one's values for the sake of influence or power.

passage_content: ואפשר שבאמת הי' איוב לפעמים מוחה על מעשיהם הרעים, ועיקר עונש שלו הי' מפני ישיבתו ביניהם, ומה שאמרו איוב ששתק, הכוונה כי אע"פ שהי' מוחה לפעמים קצת, במה נחשב הוא. כי רוב פעמים הי' מוכרח לשתוק מיראת המלכות, ואף אם עיתים רחוקות השמיע קולו במחאה חלושה, אין זה נחשב לכלום דבלא"ה לא היו דבריו נשמעים כלל ונידון כשתיקה, ועיקר החטא הוא מה שישב ביניהם ועל זה הגיע לו עונש הגדול שנדון ביסורים, כי בישיבתו שם נתן חיזוק ואומץ לרשעים לעשות רשעתם מה שלולא זאת לא הי' להם חוצפה גדולה כ"כ כמבואר בדברי הרמב"ן ז"ל.
translation: And it is possible that Job sometimes protested against their evil deeds, and his main punishment was due to his sitting among them. And what they said about Job being silent means that although he occasionally protested a little, it was of no account. For most of the time, he was compelled to remain silent out of fear of the kingdom, and even if on rare occasions he raised his voice in a weak protest, it is considered nothing, for otherwise his words would not have been heard at all and he would be judged as if he were silent. The main sin was his sitting among them, and for this he received the great punishment of being judged with suffering, for by sitting there he gave strength and courage to the wicked to carry out their wickedness, which without this they would not have had such great audacity, as explained in the words of the Ramban, may his memory be blessed.
summary: The passage discusses the character of Job, suggesting that his punishment stemmed from his choice to reside among the wicked, which inadvertently empowered their wrongdoing. Although Job occasionally protested against their actions, his silence and fear of authority rendered his objections ineffective. The core sin lies in his association with the evildoers, as his presence provided them with the audacity to continue their misdeeds, highlighting the importance of communal influence in moral conduct. This reflects a Hasidic understanding of the interconnectedness of individuals within a community and the spiritual consequences of one's environment.

passage_content: ועד"ז יובן גם ענין התלונה שהיו ישראל מלינים את הערב רב, דבאמת היו תמיד הע"ר אבן נגף לישראל כנ"ל, אולם הם בלבדם לא היו בהם כח לפתות את בנ"י, כי מי מהכשרים ישמע לעצת הערב רב, ורק ע"י שנמצאו גם מישראל כאלו שהתחברו עמהם עי"ז קבלו חיזוק ואומץ ופנים של חוצפה להסית את ישראל, נמצא אותם שנתחברו אל הע"ר הם היו הגורמים אל התלונה, שעל ידם קבלו הע"ר חיזוק ואומץ, וזולתם לא היו ביכולתם כלל להסית את ישראל, ובפועל היו הערב רב המלינים את ישראל, אבל הכח הי' מבני ישראל מאותם שנתחברו אל הע"ר, והם היו עיקר המלינים שע"י התחברותם אל הע"ר היו מחפים על כל מעשיהם, וז"ש רשיז"ל ועל כרחי אני זקוק לפרש כן, דייק בלשני' שלא ניחא לי' לפרש הפסוק כן שהיו ישראל מלינים את הע"ר, אבל בע"כ צריך לפרש כן כי האמת כך הי' שאותם בנ"י שהתחברו אל הע"ר הם היו עיקר הגורמים אל התלונה, אע"פ שלמעשה בפועל היו הע"ר המלינים את ישראל.
translation: And similarly, the matter of the complaint that the Israelites were complaining about the mixed multitude can be understood. In truth, the mixed multitude was always a stumbling block for Israel, as mentioned above. However, by themselves, they did not have the power to entice the Children of Israel, for who among the righteous would heed the counsel of the mixed multitude? Only by the fact that there were also some from Israel who joined with them did they receive strength, courage, and a brazen face to incite the Israelites. Thus, those who connected themselves to the mixed multitude were the ones who caused the complaint, through whom the mixed multitude gained strength and courage. Without them, they would not have been able to incite the Israelites at all. In practice, it was the mixed multitude that complained about Israel, but the power came from the Israelites who connected with the mixed multitude. They were the main complainers, for by their association with the mixed multitude, they covered for all their actions. And this is what the Rebbe Shlita said: "I am compelled to explain it this way," emphasizing in the language that it was not pleasing to him to interpret the verse as if the Israelites were complaining about the mixed multitude. However, it must be interpreted this way because the truth is that those Israelites who connected with the mixed multitude were the main causes of the complaint, even though in practice it was the mixed multitude that complained about Israel.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of the "erev rav" (mixed multitude) and their influence on the Israelites, emphasizing that while the erev rav were a source of temptation, they lacked the power to sway the righteous on their own. It argues that the real instigators of complaints against the Israelites were those among the Israelites who allied themselves with the erev rav, thereby empowering them. This highlights the idea that the connection between certain Israelites and the erev rav facilitated the latter's ability to incite discord, illustrating the theological insight that internal affiliations can significantly impact communal dynamics and spiritual integrity.

passage_content: ואפשר שמטעם זה לא זכה יתרו להיות במ"ת וכמו שהובא בבעה"ת בפסוק ויהי ממחרת בשם המדרש תנחומא שיתרו לאחר מ"ת בא, ודורש עליו מקרא זה (משלי י"ד י') לב יודע מרת נפשו ובשמחתו לא יתערב זר, אמר הקב"ה בני היו בשעבוד מצרים ויתרו הי' יושב שוקט ובוטח, אינו דין שישמח בשמחת התורה עכ"ד המדרש, ולדרכינו י"ל מפני שהי' גם הוא באותו עצה מתחלה כאמרז"ל, וטרם שברח הי' להמצריים חיזוק על ידי ישיבתו ביניהם, נמצא הי"ל חלק קצת בשעבוד ישראל, ואף שברח אח"כ ועשה תשובה מ"מ לא הי' ראוי לשמוח בשמחתם.
translation: And it is possible that for this reason Yitro did not merit to be at the Giving of the Torah, as it is brought in the Ba'al HaTurim on the verse "And it came to pass on the morrow" in the name of the Midrash Tanchuma that Yitro came after the Giving of the Torah, and it expounds on this verse (Proverbs 14:10) "The heart knows its own bitterness, and in its joy a stranger does not intermeddle." The Holy One, Blessed be He, said: "My children were in the bondage of Egypt, and Yitro was sitting quietly and confidently; is it not right that he should rejoice in the joy of the Torah?" Thus concludes the Midrash. And according to our way, it can be said that since he was also part of that counsel from the beginning, as our Sages of blessed memory said, and before he fled, he had support by sitting among them, it turns out that he had a share in the enslavement of Israel. And even though he fled afterwards and repented, nonetheless, he was not worthy to rejoice in their joy.
summary: The passage discusses why Jethro (יתרו) was not present at the giving of the Torah (מ"ת), referencing a Midrash that highlights his complacency during the Israelites' suffering in Egypt. It suggests that despite his later repentance and departure from Egypt, Jethro's initial acceptance of the situation and his lack of active participation in the Israelites' plight disqualified him from fully rejoicing in the joy of the Torah. This reflects a Hasidic understanding of the importance of empathy and active involvement in the struggles of others as essential for true spiritual fulfillment and joy.

passage_content: ולדרכינו יתבאר דברי רשיז"ל מה שמועה שמע ובא קריעת ים סוף ומלחמת עמלק עפימ"ד במד"ר (ר"פ יתרו) וישמע יתרו הה"ד (משלי י"ט כ"ה) לץ תכה ופתי נערים וכו' עמלק ויתרו היו בעצה עם פרעה, כשראה יתרו שאבד הקב"ה את עמלק מן העוה"ז ומן העוה"ב, תוהא ועשה תשובה שכן כתיב למעלה כי מחה אמחה את זכר עמלק ואח"כ וישמע יתרו, אמר אין לי לילך אלא אצל אלקי ישראל עכ"ד המדרש, הגם שבגמרא הנ"ל לא נזכר עמלק שהי' בעצת פרעה רק בלעם ואיוב ויתרו, י"ל שעמלק הי' ממונה על גבייהו ואין לעשות פלוגתא, עכ"פ מבואר בדברי המדרש שע"י שראה גודל ענשו של עמלק שנאבד מן העוה"ז והעוה"ב, זה הניע את לבו לחזור בתשובה על שישב באותו עצה תחלה והי' להם להמצריים חיזוק מישיבתו ביניהם, ובזה יובן שיטת המדרש בפסוק וישמע יתרו שמלחמת עמלק שמע, והוא הי' הגורם לתשובתו ולבוא להתקרב אל ישראל, וגם מקריעת ים סוף ראה העונש שקבל איוב על ישיבתו במועצת פרעה דאי' במדרש (שמו"ר פ' כ"א ס"ז) משל לרועה שהי' מעביר צאנו בנהר כו' כך בשעה שיצאו ישראל ממצרים עמד ס"ם לקטרג אותן כו', מה עשה הקב"ה מסר לו איוב שהי' מיועצי פרעה וכו' עכ"ד המדרש, ולזה נקט רשיז"ל שני ענינים אלו שהם היו הגורמים על ביאתו ולעשות תשובה על ישיבתו באותה עצה ומקריעת ים סוף ראה עונשו של איוב וממלחמת עמלק ראה עונשו של עמלק.
translation: And according to our path, the words of Rashi will be clarified regarding what news he heard and came about the splitting of the Sea of Reeds and the war with Amalek, as it is stated in the Midrash (Parashat Yitro). And Yitro heard, as it is written (Proverbs 19:25), "Strike a scoffer, and the simple will become wary," etc. Amalek and Yitro were in counsel with Pharaoh. When Yitro saw that the Holy One, Blessed be He, had wiped out Amalek from this world and the next, he was astonished and repented, as it is written above, "For I will surely wipe out the remembrance of Amalek." And afterwards, "And Yitro heard." He said, "I have no choice but to go to the God of Israel," thus concludes the Midrash. Although in the aforementioned Gemara, Amalek is not mentioned as being in Pharaoh's counsel, only Bilam, Job, and Yitro, it can be said that Amalek was appointed over them, and there is no need to dispute this. In any case, it is clear from the words of the Midrash that by seeing the great punishment of Amalek, who was wiped out from this world and the next, this moved his heart to return in repentance for having sat in that counsel at first, and they had strength from his sitting among them. And this will clarify the Midrash's approach to the verse "And Yitro heard," that he heard about the war with Amalek, and he was the cause of his repentance and coming close to Israel. Also, from the splitting of the Sea of Reeds, he saw the punishment that Job received for sitting in Pharaoh's council, as is stated in the Midrash (Shemot Rabbah, Parashat 21, Section 67), a parable of a shepherd who was leading his flock across a river, etc. Thus, at the time when Israel went out of Egypt, the accuser stood to prosecute them, etc. What did the Holy One, Blessed be He, do? He handed over Job, who was one of Pharaoh's advisors, etc. Thus concludes the Midrash. And for this reason, Rashi mentioned these two matters, which were the causes for his coming and repenting for his sitting in that counsel, and from the splitting of the Sea of Reeds, he saw the punishment of Job, and from the war with Amalek, he saw the punishment of Amalek.
summary: The passage discusses how Yitro's decision to join the Israelites was influenced by witnessing the punishment of Amalek and Job for their roles in advising Pharaoh against the Israelites. Yitro, upon realizing that Amalek was erased from both this world and the next, felt compelled to repent and seek the God of Israel. The text emphasizes the interconnectedness of divine justice and repentance, illustrating how the consequences faced by others can lead to personal transformation and a desire to align oneself with the divine. Ultimately, Yitro's response to these events highlights the power of witnessing God's actions in the world as a catalyst for spiritual awakening.

passage_content: באופן אחר יל"פ בהקדם מה דאיתא בגמרא (ערכין ט"ו ע"א) ישראל שבאותו הדור מקטני אמנה היו וכו' מ"ד וימרו על ים בים סוף, מלמד שהיו ישראל ממרים באותה שעה ואומרים כשם שאנו עולים מצד זה כך מצרים עולים מצד אחר, א"ל הקב"ה לשר של ים פלוט אותם ליבשה וכו', וכתבו התוס' יש לתמוה איך היו ישראל באותו הדור כ"כ מקטני אמנה, שסברו שכך יעשה הקב"ה נסים למצרים להעבירם מארצם לא"י, ותירצו שישראל לא עברו הים לרחבו מצד זה לזה, אלא רצועה אחת עברו בים לאורך הים כחצי גורן עגולה וכו' עכ"ד התוס' ולכאורה אין תירוצם מספיק ועדיין הקושיא במקומה עומדת דהרי עכ"פ זה עצמו הי' נס גדול, שהמצרים רדפו אחרי ישראל לתוך הים ולא שמו על לבם לחשוב שלא יעמוד כך הים לעולם ואחר שיעברו ישראל יחזור הים לאיתנו, אלא שהקב"ה חיזק ואימץ את לבבם לרדוף אחריהם לתוך הים נגד השכל, ואיך חשבו ישראל שהקב"ה יעשה ח"ו ניסא למגנא, ומה נפ"מ אם עברו את הים לרחבו ליכנס תיכף לא"י או לא, בין כך ובין כך נעשו נסים גדולים ואיך יחשבו שהקב"ה עושה נסים לרשעים ח"ו.
translation: In another way, it can be explained in light of what is stated in the Gemara (Erchin 15a) that the Israelites of that generation were of little faith, etc. As it is said, "And they rebelled against Him by the sea, at the Sea of Reeds," which teaches that the Israelites were rebelling at that moment and saying, "Just as we are going up from this side, so too the Egyptians are coming up from the other side." The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to the minister of the sea, "Cast them onto dry land," etc. The Tosafot wrote that it is puzzling how the Israelites of that generation were so lacking in faith, believing that the Holy One, Blessed be He, would perform miracles for the Egyptians to bring them from their land to the Land of Israel. They answered that the Israelites did not cross the sea from side to side, but rather crossed a strip in the sea along the length of the sea, like half a circular threshing floor, etc. Thus far the Tosafot, and seemingly their answer is not sufficient, and the question remains in place, for after all, this itself was a great miracle, that the Egyptians pursued the Israelites into the sea and did not consider that the sea would not stand like this forever, and that after the Israelites crossed, the sea would return to its strength. Rather, the Holy One, Blessed be He, strengthened and hardened their hearts to pursue them into the sea against reason. And how did the Israelites think that the Holy One, Blessed be He, would perform miracles, Heaven forbid, for the wicked? And what difference does it make if they crossed the sea width-wise to enter immediately into the Land of Israel or not? In either case, great miracles occurred, and how could they think that the Holy One, Blessed be He, would perform miracles for the wicked, Heaven forbid?
summary: The passage discusses the lack of faith among the Israelites during the crossing of the Red Sea, as they feared that God would perform miracles for the Egyptians to pursue them. It highlights the paradox of their belief that God would create a miraculous path for the Egyptians while simultaneously performing miracles for the Israelites. The text questions the rationale behind the Israelites' doubts, emphasizing that regardless of the nature of the miracle—whether crossing the sea widthwise or lengthwise—both scenarios involved significant divine intervention. Ultimately, it reflects on the complexities of faith and divine providence in the face of seemingly contradictory circumstances.

passage_content: ובדרך אגב נתברר לי עפ"י דברי התוס' הללו ענין קשה, דאיתא במדרש ילקוט (רמז רל"ג ובתנחומא סי' י') הביאו הרמב"ם ז"ל בפי' המשנה (אבות פ"ה מ"ד) עשרה נסים נעשו לאבותינו במצרים ועשרה על הים, וא' מהם שנבקע הים לי"ב גזרים כמנין השבטים, וכל שבט עבר בים בדרך בפ"ע וזהו שנאמר לגוזר ים סוף לגזרים, ולפי"ז קשה מה הי' עם הערב רב, ובאיזה מן הדרכים עברו הם את הים, וא"א לומר שהלכו בא' מן הדרכים של השבטים, דאם הרבה הקב"ה בנס לעשות י"ב שבילין שיהי' כל שבט מיוחד בפ"ע, כש"כ שלא ניתן להערב רב שיתחבר בדרך אחד עמהם ואיך עברו הם את הים, אמנם לפי דברי התוס' הנ"ל יתיישב כפשוטו דאה"נ שהע"ר לא עברו את הים כלל, שהם לא האמינו בכח הנס שיעמוד הים כך עד שיעברו, והי' להם חשבון שיחזרו למצרים בלית ברירה, רק אחר שעלו ישראל מן הים באותו צד עצמו שירדו נתחברו עוה"פ הע"ר לישראל והלכו עמהם במדבר, אבל את הים לא עברו כלל.
translation: And incidentally, it became clear to me according to the words of these Tosafot a difficult matter, as it is stated in the Midrash Yalkut (Remez 273 and in Tanchuma, section 10) which the Rambam, may his memory be blessed, brought in his commentary on the Mishnah (Avot 5:4) that ten miracles were performed for our ancestors in Egypt and ten at the sea, and one of them was that the sea was split into twelve paths corresponding to the number of the tribes, and each tribe passed through the sea on its own path. This is what is meant by "He who divides the Sea of Reeds into paths." According to this, it is difficult to understand what happened with the mixed multitude (Erev Rav), and by which of the paths they crossed the sea. It cannot be said that they went along one of the paths of the tribes, for if the Holy One, blessed be He, performed a miracle to create twelve paths so that each tribe would have its own path, certainly it would not have been permitted for the Erev Rav to join together with them on one path. How then did they cross the sea? However, according to the words of the aforementioned Tosafot, it can be understood simply that indeed the Erev Rav did not cross the sea at all, for they did not believe in the power of the miracle that the sea would stand like this until they crossed. They calculated that they would return to Egypt out of necessity. Only after the Israelites emerged from the sea on the same side they had descended did the Erev Rav join with the Israelites and go with them in the desert, but they did not cross the sea at all.
summary: The passage discusses a challenging issue regarding the crossing of the Red Sea by the Israelites and the mixed multitude (Erev Rav). It references the Rambam's mention of ten miracles that occurred during the Exodus, including the splitting of the sea into twelve paths for each tribe. The author suggests that the Erev Rav did not actually cross the sea, as they lacked faith in the miracle, and instead joined the Israelites only after they had safely crossed. This highlights themes of faith, divine intervention, and the distinction between the faithful and those who doubt.

passage_content: אמנם עדיין צריך ביאור בדברי התוס' להבין החילוק בין אם עברו ישראל את הים לרחבו או שהלכו לאורך הים וכנ"ל, ונל"פ עפימ"ד במדרש ילקוט (רמז רל"ד) עה"פ והמים להם חומה, שירד ס"מ ואמר לפניו רבש"ע לא עבדו ישראל ע"ז במצרים ואתה עושה להם נסים וכו', השיב לו הקב"ה שוטה שבעולם וכי לדעתם עבדוהו והלא לא עבדוהו אלא מתוך שעבוד ומתוך טירוף הדעת ואתה דן שוגג כמזיד ואונס כרצון, וידוע קושית המפורשים הלא אין התנצלות זה מועיל לגבי ע"ז שהוא ביהרג ואל יעבור ואין טענת אונס מועיל לפטור, ופירשנו בדברנו לעיל דהנה ישראל עשו תשובה שלימה כמבואר במד"ת (סי' ח') עה"פ ופרעה הקריב שהקריב את ישראל לתשובה, רק שיש לדון על תשובתם, דעבודה זרה הוא מינות וכל באי' לא ישובין כתיב (משלי ב' י"ט), וזה שטען הס"ם מה בין אלו לאלו, דיתכן שגם המצריים עשו אז תשובה, שכך הוא דרכם של רשעים כשנמצאים בעת צרה מהרהרין בתשובה קצת, ולזה טען ממנ"פ אם מועיל תשובה על עבודה זרה, גם המצריים ינצלו שגם הם עשו תשובה, ואם תשובתם אינה מתקבלת גם לישראל לא תועיל, השיב לו הקב"ה שוטה שבעולם אתה דן שוגג כמזיד ואונס כרצון, דמה שישראל עבדו ע"ז הי' מתוך אונס וטירוף הדעת ולא הי' בה צד מינות, אע"פ שמחוייבים למסור נפשם שלא לעבוד ע"ז, מ"מ מועלת תשובתם כיון שלא הי' ע"י כפירה ומינות, משא"כ המצריים עבדוהו ברצון נפשם אינו מועיל להם תשובה.
translation: Indeed, there is still a need for clarification in the words of the Tosafot to understand the distinction between whether the Israelites crossed the sea widthwise or walked along the length of the sea, as mentioned above. It can be inferred according to the Midrash Yalkut (Remez 244) on the verse "and the waters were a wall for them," that the Satan descended and said before the Holy One, Blessed be He, "Did the Israelites not serve idols in Egypt, and You are performing miracles for them?" The Holy One, Blessed be He, replied to him, "Fool of the world! Do you think they served it willingly? They did not serve it except out of servitude and madness, and you judge a mistake as if it were intentional and coercion as if it were willful." It is known that the question of the commentators is that this excuse is not effective regarding idolatry, which one must be killed rather than transgress, and the claim of coercion does not exempt one. We explained in our earlier discussion that the Israelites made complete repentance, as is clarified in the Midrash (Section 8) on the verse "and Pharaoh drew near," that he brought the Israelites to repentance. However, there is a need to discuss their repentance, for idolatry is heresy, and "all who come to it do not return" is written (Proverbs 2:19). This is what the Satan claimed: "What is the difference between these and those?" It is possible that the Egyptians also repented then, for it is the way of the wicked that when they find themselves in distress, they contemplate repentance a little. Therefore, he argued from this perspective: if repentance is effective for idolatry, the Egyptians will also be saved since they too repented. And if their repentance is not accepted, it will not be effective for the Israelites either. The Holy One, Blessed be He, replied to him, "Fool of the world! You judge a mistake as if it were intentional and coercion as if it were willful, for what the Israelites served idols was out of coercion and madness, and there was no aspect of heresy in it. Although they are obligated to give their lives not to serve idols, their repentance is effective since it was not through denial and heresy. In contrast, the Egyptians served it willingly; their repentance is not effective for them."
summary: The passage discusses the distinction between the Israelites' worship of idols in Egypt and the potential repentance of the Egyptians. It emphasizes that the Israelites' actions were driven by coercion and mental turmoil, which allows for their sincere repentance to be accepted by God, despite their obligation to resist idolatry. In contrast, the Egyptians, who worshipped idols willingly, cannot claim the same justification for repentance, as their actions stemmed from a conscious choice rather than duress. This highlights the Hasidic concept of divine mercy and the nuances of repentance based on intent and circumstances.

passage_content: ואולי עד"ז היתה יראתם של ישראל במה שאמרו כשם שאנו עולים מצד זה כך המצריים עולים מצד אחר, דהנה ידעו בעצמם שגם הם עבדו ע"ז במצרים ואעפ"כ נעשה להם נסים, ה"ז מגיד שנתקבלה תשובתם על ע"ז, והשיגו כמו"כ שגם המצריים עשו תשובה בעת צרה כזה ודרכו של הקב"ה לרחם על בריותיו בשעה שעושין תשובה אף דקמי שמיא גליא דאח"כ יחזרו לסורם כמקדם, מ"מ הקב"ה דן את האדם באשר הוא שם וכפי אותה שעה, וכמו שמצינו בננוה שחזרו בתשובה לפי שעה וריחם הקב"ה עליהם, ע"כ חששו ישראל שגם המצריים יעלו מן הים ע"י התשובה שעושין, והי' מקום לחשוב כן, ולא מחמת חסרון אמונה ח"ו אמרו כן, אלא מצד סברא זו עצמה שהקשה הס"ם מה בין אלו לאלו, והתירוץ שהשיב לו הקב"ה לחלק בין אונס כרצון לא השיגו עדיין, ע"כ חששו גם הם שאין חילוק בין ישראל להמצריים וכמו שהקב"ה עושה נס לישראל ע"י שעשו תשובה, כמו"כ יעשה נס להמצריים ע"י התשובה שעשו, אלא שבערך דור דיעה דור המדבר נחשב גם מחשבה זו למיעוט אמונה, כי אחר שמרע"ה צוה להם לילך אין להרהר, וע"כ קראו אותם חכז"ל לקטני אמנה.
translation: And perhaps similarly was the fear of Israel in what they said, "Just as we ascend from this side, so too the Egyptians ascend from another side." Behold, they knew themselves that they also served idols in Egypt, and yet miracles were done for them. This indicates that their repentance from idolatry was accepted, and they also understood that the Egyptians repented in such a time of distress. It is the way of the Holy One, blessed be He, to have mercy on His creatures at the time they repent, even though it is clear to Heaven that afterwards they will return to their folly as before. Nevertheless, the Holy One, blessed be He, judges a person as they are at that moment. And as we find with Nineveh, who repented for a time, and the Holy One, blessed be He, had mercy on them. Therefore, Israel feared that the Egyptians would also ascend from the sea due to the repentance they were doing. There was reason to think so, and not because of a lack of faith, Heaven forbid, but rather from this very reasoning that the accuser posed: what is the difference between these and those? And the answer that the Holy One, blessed be He, gave to distinguish between coerced and willing was not yet grasped by them. Therefore, they also feared that there is no distinction between Israel and the Egyptians, and just as the Holy One, blessed be He, performs a miracle for Israel due to their repentance, so too He would perform a miracle for the Egyptians due to the repentance they did. However, in relation to the generation of knowledge, the generation of the desert, this thought was also considered a lack of faith, for after Moses commanded them to go, there is no room for doubt. Therefore, our Sages referred to them as "small in faith."
summary: The passage discusses the fear of the Israelites that the Egyptians, having repented during their time of distress, might also be saved by God, similar to their own experience. It highlights the theological concept that God judges individuals based on their current state and actions, as seen in the case of Nineveh. However, the Israelites' concern is viewed as a lack of faith, especially since they were commanded by Moses to proceed without doubt. This reflects a deeper Hasidic insight into the nature of divine mercy and the expectations of faith in the face of God's miracles.

passage_content: ובזה נבוא לביאור דברי התוס', דהנה מתחלה הי' ס"ד שעברו ישראל את הים לרחבו מצד זה לצד השני שיבואו תיכף לא"י, וע"כ הקשו איך היו ישראל קטני אמנה כ"כ שסברו שכן יעשה הקב"ה נסים למצרים להעבירם מארצם "לא"י דייקא", דהגם שמדתו של הקב"ה שמקבל בתשובה את הרשעים, אף אם תשובתם הוא רק לשעה כל עוד שנמצאים בצרה, מ"מ נתקבל אצל הקב"ה מטעמים הכמוסים לפניו ית"ש, ואולי מטעם ומשלם לשונאיו אל פניו וימצא לפעמים שיקבל הקדוש ברוך הוא תשובת רשעים ולעשות להם נס להצילם, אבל לעשות להם נס כזה להוליכם לא"י ולהושיבם שם, זה דבר שלא ניתן להעלות על הדעת, ומי שהוא מאמין בהשי"ת ובתורתו הקדושה אין מציאות שיחשוב כן, שכמה פסוקים מפורשים בתוה"ק שא"י אינה סובלת עוברי עבירה ופולטת ומקיאה את הרשעים, ע"כ א"א שדור המדבר יחשבו ככה ח"ו שהקב"ה יעשה להם למצרים נסים להושיבם בא"י, וזה שדייק התוס' בלשונם הק' איך היו ישראל באותו הדור קטני אמנה כ"כ שסברו שכך יעשה הקב"ה נסים למצרים להעבירם מארצם "לא"י דייקא" שזה הוא עיקר הקושיא, וע"ז תירצו שלא עברו את הים לרחבו מצד זה אלא הלכו לאורך הים כחצי גורן עגולה וחזרו לאותו מקום עצמו במדבר באותו צד שירדו ולא נכנסו תיכף לא"י, וע"כ הי' להם מקום לחשוש שמא יעשה הקב"ה נסים גם למצרים ע"י שהרהרו בתשובה באותה שעה שכך הוא מדותיו של הקב"ה לקבל גם תשובה כזאת וכנ"ל, אלא שלפי גודל ערכם של דור המדבר נחשב גם זאת לקטנות אמונה וכנ"ל.
translation: And with this we will come to explain the words of the Tosafot. Behold, initially there was a thought that Israel crossed the sea widthwise from this side to the other side so that they would immediately enter the Land of Israel. Therefore, they asked how Israel could be so lacking in faith that they thought that the Holy One, blessed be He, would perform miracles for the Egyptians to bring them from their land "specifically to the Land of Israel." For although the attribute of the Holy One, blessed be He, is to accept the repentance of the wicked, even if their repentance is only for a moment as long as they are in distress, nonetheless, it is accepted by the Holy One for reasons hidden before Him, blessed be He. And perhaps it is for the reason that He pays back His enemies to their face, and it may be that sometimes the Holy One, blessed be He, accepts the repentance of the wicked and performs a miracle to save them. However, to perform such a miracle to bring them to the Land of Israel and settle them there is something that cannot be conceived. And anyone who believes in the Holy One, blessed be He, and in His holy Torah cannot possibly think this, as there are many explicit verses in the Holy Torah that the Land of Israel does not tolerate transgressors and expels and vomits out the wicked. Therefore, it is impossible that the generation of the desert would think such a thing, Heaven forbid, that the Holy One, blessed be He, would perform miracles for the Egyptians to settle them in the Land of Israel. And this is what the Tosafot emphasized in their holy language, how could Israel in that generation be so lacking in faith that they thought that the Holy One, blessed be He, would perform miracles for the Egyptians to bring them from their land "specifically to the Land of Israel," which is the essence of the question. And to this they answered that they did not cross the sea widthwise from this side, but rather walked along the length of the sea like half a circular threshing floor and returned to the same place in the desert on the same side they descended and did not immediately enter the Land of Israel. Therefore, they had reason to be concerned that perhaps the Holy One, blessed be He, would perform miracles for the Egyptians as they contemplated repentance at that moment, as such is the nature of the Holy One, blessed be He, to accept even such repentance, as mentioned above. However, according to the greatness of the value of the generation of the desert, this was also considered a lack of faith, as mentioned above.
summary: The passage discusses the doubts of the Israelites regarding God's ability to perform miracles for the Egyptians, allowing them to enter the Land of Israel. It emphasizes that, despite God's willingness to accept repentance, the notion that He would perform such miracles for sinners to settle in the Holy Land contradicts the fundamental belief that the Land cannot tolerate transgressors. The text highlights the Israelites' lack of faith, suggesting that their concerns stemmed from a misunderstanding of God's nature and the sanctity of the Land, which ultimately reflects a deeper theological insight into the relationship between divine justice and mercy.

passage_content: היוצא לנו מזה שגם המצריים עשו תשובה בעת קריעת ים סוף אלא שלא נתקבלה תשובתם כלל ונאבדו, ובאמת תשובה אינה מועלת רק לישראל ולא לאוה"ע, ואפשר שמטעם זה הי' יתרו מיצר ודואג על איבוד מצרים, כי ידע שגם הם עשו תשובה ומדוע לא נתקבלה תשובתם, שלא הבין עדיין מדוע אינו מועיל גם להם תשובה, אבל מקרי"ס השיג שאין מועיל תשובה רק לישראל, ולזה נשא לבו לבוא דוקא אל המדבר ולהתגייר, ולא סגי שיעשה תשובה בביתו על מה שישב בין יועצי פרעה, וזה הי' סברת המדרש בפ' וישמע יתרו מה שמועה שמע "ובא" דייקא, קריעת ים סוף שמע, שמשם השיג שאין מועיל תשובה רק לישראל והוא שהניע אותו להתקרב לישראל, ושם יעשה תשובה על העבר והבן.
translation: What emerges from this is that the Egyptians also repented at the time of the splitting of the Sea of Reeds, but their repentance was not accepted at all, and they were lost. In truth, repentance is only effective for Israel and not for the nations of the world. It is possible that for this reason, Yitro was troubled and worried about the destruction of Egypt, for he knew that they too had repented and wondered why their repentance was not accepted, not yet understanding why repentance does not benefit them as well. However, from the splitting of the sea, he realized that repentance is only effective for Israel. This motivated him to specifically come to the desert and convert, and it was not sufficient for him to repent in his home for having sat among Pharaoh's advisors. This was the reasoning of the Midrash in Parashat Yitro regarding what news he heard, "and he came" specifically, that he heard about the splitting of the Sea of Reeds, from which he understood that repentance is only effective for Israel, and this is what prompted him to draw closer to Israel, where he would repent for the past and understand.
summary: The passage discusses the concept that repentance (teshuva) is effective only for the Jewish people and not for the nations of the world, as exemplified by the Egyptians during the splitting of the Red Sea, whose repentance was not accepted. It highlights that Yitro, upon witnessing this event, realized the unique status of Israel in relation to teshuva, prompting him to seek conversion and repentance specifically among the Israelites rather than remaining in his previous life. This understanding led him to the desert, emphasizing the importance of communal identity and the transformative power of genuine repentance within the Jewish faith.

passage_content: השמטה אליו משה כצאתי את העיר אפרוש את כפי וגו' ואתה ועבדיך ידעתי כי טרם תיראון מפני ד' אלקים, יל"פ הסמיכות עפימ"ד במד"ר (הובא ברשיז"ל) כצאתי את העיר אבל בתוך העיר לא התפלל לפי שהיתה מלאה גלולים, וכתבו בעה"ת שגם לשאר תפלות הי' יוצא מן העיר ומזה אנו למדין לכל השאר וכ"כ הרמב"ן ז"ל, אמנם במכה זו הודה והתודה פרעה ואמר חטאתי הפעם ד' הצדיק וגו' העתירו אל ד' ורב מהיות קולות אלקים, ובזה הודה בשם הוי' ב"ה ובשם אלקים (עיין אבן עזרא) מה שלא הודה עד עכשיו בשניהם (עיין בדברי המפרשים ובדברנו לעיל), ומעתה הי' מקום לחשוב שבהודאה זו ביטל גלולי מצרים והע"ז שלהם, ששורשה הי' בטעות ב' רשויות שהפועל הרע אינו פועל הטוב, ועכשיו ביטל דיעה זו הנפסדת ולפי"ז אין צורך לצאת מן העיר לתפלה לטעם הרחקת הע"ז, ע"כ א"ל משרע"ה ואתה ועבדיך ידעתי כי טרם תיראון מפני ד' אלקים, וכפרש"י ז"ל עדיין לא תיראון, והודאה והחרטה אינו אלא מיראת העונש ואחר סור המכה תשובו ותמרו את פי ד', ואין בזה ביטול ע"ז ובהכרח יצא להתפלל חוץ לעיר מפני הרחקת ע"ז.
translation:
The translation is as follows:

"To him, Moses said, 'As I go out of the city, I will spread out my hands, etc., and you and your servants, I know that you will not yet fear the Lord, God.' It is to be explained the proximity according to the interpretation of the Midrash (as brought in the writings of the holy ones) 'as I go out of the city,' but within the city, he did not pray because it was full of idols. And it is written in the Torah that for other prayers, he would go out of the city, and from this, we learn for all the rest, and so wrote the Ramban, may his memory be blessed. However, in this plague, Pharaoh admitted and confessed, saying, 'I have sinned this time; the Lord is righteous, etc. Pray to the Lord, for there are many voices of God.' And in this, he acknowledged the name of the Holy One, blessed be He, and the name of God (see Ibn Ezra), which he had not acknowledged until now in both (see the words of the commentators and our earlier discussion). From now on, one might think that through this acknowledgment, he nullified the idols of Egypt and their idolatry, whose root was in the mistaken belief of two authorities, that the evil doer does not perform the good. And now he nullified this erroneous opinion, and according to this, there is no need to go out of the city to pray for the reason of distancing from idolatry. Therefore, Moses said to him, 'And you and your servants, I know that you will not yet fear the Lord, God,' as Rashi, may his memory be blessed, explains, 'you will not yet fear.' And acknowledgment and regret are only out of fear of punishment, and after the plague has ceased, you will return and rebel against the word of the Lord, and there is no nullification of idolatry in this, and it is necessary to go out to pray outside the city because of the distancing from idolatry."
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author discusses the significance of Moses' prayer outside the city of Egypt, emphasizing that the city was filled with idolatry, which necessitated this separation for proper worship. The acknowledgment of sin by Pharaoh, where he admits to wrongdoing and calls upon God, is seen as a superficial recognition that does not genuinely renounce idolatry. The text highlights the theological concept that true repentance must involve a complete rejection of false beliefs, which Pharaoh fails to achieve, thus reinforcing the need for Moses to pray away from the influence of idolatry. Ultimately, the passage illustrates the tension between fear of punishment and authentic faith, suggesting that mere acknowledgment of God's power does not equate to true devotion.

passage_content: השמטה באמ"צ וגו' והכיתי כל בכור וגו', דרשו רז"ל בספרי ובהגדש"פ ועברתי בארץ מצרים אני ולא מלאך, והכיתי כל בכור וגו' אני ולא שרף, ובכל אלהי מצרים אעשה שפטים אני ולא השליח, יל"ד מה צורך לכפול כל הני מיעוטי, לשלול מלאך שרף ושליח, ויספיק שיאמר הכתוב בפירוש שכל אלה נעשה ע"י הבוית"ש בכבודו ובעצמו כביכול, וא"צ לפרוט מיעוטין כי כבר נתמעטו כולם, ואפ"ל עפימ"ש המפרשים ז"ל להסביר הטעם דאין מלאך א' עושה שתי שליחות, כדי להראות דהרבה שלוחים למקום ואינו מחוסר עבדים, והנה ביציאת מצרים הי' רצון הבוית"ש לעשות כל אלו הפעולות בכבודו ובעצמו ית' לא ע"י שליח, וכדי שלא יהי' נראה כמחוסר עבדים ח"ו, על כן לקח כביכול ית' עמו חיל גדול של מלאכים שרפים וכו', ואעפ"כ לא נעשה דבר כ"א ע"י הבוית"ש בכבודו ובעצמו, וז"פ ולא יתן המשחית לבוא אל בתיכם וגו', כי באמת היו שם משחיתים, אלא שלא ניתן להם רשות לעשות דבר, ולזה דרשו רז"ל מיתור הכתוב אני ולא מלאך וכו' ולא שרף ולא השליח, להודיע שכל אלה היו שם, שאין חוסר עבדים לפניו ית"ש, אלא שלחיבתן של ישראל עשה הכל בכבודו ובעצמו.
translation:
The omission in "I will strike every firstborn" etc., our Sages of blessed memory expounded in the Sifrei and in the Haggadah: "And I passed through the land of Egypt, I Myself, and not an angel; and I will strike every firstborn, I Myself, and not a seraph; and against all the gods of Egypt, I will execute judgments, I Myself, and not a messenger." One might ask, what is the need to repeat all these exclusions, to negate an angel, a seraph, and a messenger? It would suffice for the verse to explicitly state that all this was done by the Holy One, blessed be He, in His glory and essence, as it were, and there is no need to detail the exclusions since they have all already been negated. 

And it can be said, according to what the commentators of blessed memory explain, that the reason is that no single angel performs two missions, to show that there are many messengers in the presence of the Holy One, blessed be He, and He is not lacking in servants. And behold, at the Exodus from Egypt, it was the will of the Holy One, blessed be He, to perform all these actions in His glory and essence, not through a messenger, and in order that it should not appear as if He were lacking in servants, Heaven forbid, therefore He took, as it were, a great host of angels, seraphim, etc., and nevertheless, nothing was done except by the Holy One, blessed be He, in His glory and essence. 

And this is the meaning of "And the destroyer shall not enter your houses" etc., for indeed there were destroyers there, but they were not given permission to do anything. And for this reason, our Sages of blessed memory derived from the superfluity of the verse "I, and not an angel" etc., "and not a seraph, and not a messenger," to inform us that all these were present, that there is no lack of servants before Him, blessed be He, but out of His love for Israel, He did everything in His glory and essence.
summary: The passage emphasizes that during the Exodus from Egypt, God Himself, rather than angels or messengers, executed the plagues and judgments, highlighting His direct involvement in the redemption of the Israelites. This insistence on God's personal action serves to demonstrate His love for the Jewish people and His desire to show that He is not lacking in servants, as He commands a host of angels. The text underscores the theological concept that God's relationship with Israel is intimate and direct, reflecting His commitment to their salvation. Ultimately, it conveys that despite the presence of destructive forces, God alone determined the course of events, protecting His people with His own authority.
